fields.headline: The boys from Brazil
fields.standfirst: They're travelling all over the world - and three of them scored four of the five goals in Spartak's midweek game against Arsenal
fields.trailText: Last year a grand total of 658 Brazilian footballers emigrated to foreign climes - and three of them scored in Spartak's midweek game against Arsenal.
fields.body:
As the ball glided around on an ice-rink in Moscow's Luzhniki Stadium, there was something surreal about the fact that four of the five goals in a game between Russian and English teams were scored by players who supposedly hone their skills on the beach. How did this happen? What are all these Brazilians doing here?

While Brazilian football, currently under government investigation to stem the flood of bungs, passport fraud and clandestine transfers, doesn't know whether it is coming or going, its players certainly do. They have dancing boots, and will travel. Last year a grand total of 658 Brazilian footballers emigrated to foreign climes. That would make enough teams to fill the Premiership, First Division and most of Division Two. Not only are they exported to the major European paymasters in Italy, Spain, Germany, France and England, they crop up everywhere from from Senegal to Slovenia, from Indonesia to India. Heaven knows what the son of Samba plying his trade in Iceland makes of life.

Arsenal's defender Silvinho contemplated the exodus and simply exclaimed: 'Jesus!' He explains that the opportunity to learn about a new culture, language and style of football is enticing. But basically they go for one reason: money.

A commission revealed 98 per cent of Brazilian players survive on a minimum salary of £90 a month, scant reward for enduring an 11-month season that is so random and complex it leaves everyone as bemused as they are exhausted. As Edmundo moaned: 'In Europe you play twice a week at the most. Here in Brazil it's an absolute marathon; you play Sunday, Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday again.'

The lucky travellers, such as Roberto Carlos, Ronaldo or Jardel, make their names and their fortunes abroad. As for the rest, Adlo Rebelo, who is heading the national investigation, says that for every one who succeeds another young starlet ends up signing a contract in a language they don't understand before being rejected and kicked out into the street. 'I didn't have many problems but I know there are many cases where players go back to Brazil complaining that they don't like the weather, the country, the language, the coach...' muses Silvinho. 'I am lucky to be here in England, God knows.'

To flourish demands as much mental will as technical wizardry. The case of Francileudo dos Santos is a typical example of how things work. He was recruited by Standard Liege from the northern state of Maranhao at the age of 16, before he had ever played professionally. He arrived in the middle of winter with a suitcase of full Bermuda shorts. Despite this, he had an excellent season, was dispatched to a club in Tunisia (glad he brought those shorts after all?), impressed again, and was bought by Sochaux for $1 million, where he is currently top scorer in France's Second Division and improving fast.

The hurdles to be overcome depend on the destination. It took Robson, such an unsettling presence for Arsenal in Moscow last week, a couple of years to thrive in Russia. Spartak Moscow's coach, president and general overlord, Oleg Romantsev, decided some years ago that he wanted to integrate some South American soul into his Soviet machine. The first to make an impression was Leonadis, but he didn't last long after picking up a frostbitten finger during training - not a common injury among Russians. Robson, a fixture in the Spartak side, is made of sterner stuff.

At first he had to cope with being the butt of jokes at the training ground. The usual stuff, like when he asked Ilya Tsymbalar what to say to get an apple and he ended up with a beer.

It's hardly surprising it took time to work out what tickles his team-mates' tastebuds: at Spartak's restaurant, a plush cellar frequented by wealthy locals, which also serves as a meeting place for the club's players and officials, a special dish called 'Footballer's Dream' promises toast with bacon, marinated cucumbers, cubes of pineapple and chips.

Three years into his exile, Robson still has problems with the language.

The adaptation process, though, is not all jocular. One day he was strolling through Gorky Park only to be confronted by a band of skinheads. Fortunately - and this is the club's official line - potential distress was diluted because there were some Spartak fans among them. 'The unpleasantness,' wrote the club's magazine, 'was limited to a lecture on the superiority of the white race.'

Against this backdrop, and the fact that bananas are lobbed from the stands when Spartak visit the provinces, the idea of Robson becoming football's first black Russian is an astounding one. After three years in the country he made such an impression that Romantsev, who coaches the national team as well as Spartak, spoke of arranging citizenship. His Cameroonian club-mate, Jerry Christian Tchuise, has already been naturalised.

Naturally Robson gets homesick. During two days spent exploring Moscow I saw only two black people going about their business in town. Having said that, this thriving city is embracing cosmopolitan variety at breathless pace. Players like Robson can expect salaries of more than $250,000 a year and he won't struggle to enjoy his wealth among Moscow's high society. The first of a parade of shops flanking Red Square is Christian Dior, mobile phones trill permanently, new bars and restaurants open every day, ranging from TGI Friday's to Tibetan.

Robson has been joined at Spartak by Marcao. A handful of compatriots to keep him company have come and gone but the latest, who terrorised Arsenal in the Champions League, looks like he is here to stay. Even though Romantsev was strangely grumpy about his performance and demanded improvements, Spartak's boisterous followers seemed enthusiastic enough about their exotic match winners.

Overrun in midfield, how Arsenal could have done with Edu, the Corinthians playmaker who got as far as Heathrow when the club tried to buy him last summer, before passport irregularities sent him packing back to Brazil.

He was distraught. Silvinho, who flew over with Edu after spending his summer break in Sao Paulo, recalls how excited the young midfielder was.

'Before we flew over I was in Sao Paulo for my holidays and spoke to him a few times, congratulating him on his contract and telling him it was a really good team and a good country. It's wonderful here, and he expected to come, saying, "Oh, Silvinho, there are so many great players there!" I told him they were good guys. Passports are a problem and it's for the people who run the game to sort it out.'

Provided his documents arrive before the 1 January deadline, Edu will be straight on the plane to London. Arsène Wenger is hopeful his passport will be the perfect Christmas present.

If he does finally make it, he should at least be eligible for the resumption of the Champions League after the winter break. Against Bayern, he would cross swords with compatriots Elber and Paulo Sergio, before meeting up with Lyon's Sonny Anderson and Edmilson.

Although the result in Moscow was forgettable, Silvinho was happy to catch up with Robson, an old mate from Corinthians days. They didn't swap shirts though. For Brazilians, playing in the cold is a challenge worth trying, stripping is out of the question.

Additional reporting by Brian Homewood in Rio de Janeiro.

fields.headline: Is Rio worth it?
fields.standfirst: Ferdinand may not be the world's best defender but £18 million has got Leeds a player who should serve them well over the long term
fields.trailText: Ferdinand may not be the world's best defender but £18 million has got Leeds a player who should serve them well over the long term.
fields.body:
So, are Leeds United setting out to be the new Newcastle United? Buccaneering big spenders using their new-found wealth to tilt at the more sober-suited establishments of Manchester and London, building their fan base all the while by virtue of their bravery in the transfer market?

It seems as if we have been here before, although for proof we should wait until Peter Ridsdale starts talking of a Yorkshire nation or David O'Leary admits he would love it, just love it, should Manchester United slip up.

In the meantime, though Leeds can only be applauded for the courage of their convictions, their determination to break the British transfer record raises more questions than answers. Why Rio Ferdinand? Why £18m? Why now, when the future of the transfer system is in doubt? And what's wrong with signing cut-price foreigners like everybody else does, including Harry Redknapp, who is already looking at a couple of players around the £2m mark.

As a bold stroke, an indication to the fans of the extent of your ambition, few things beat breaking the transfer record for an English player. Just ask Newcastle supporters how they felt in 1996. The Alan Shearer deal remains just about the only time Newcastle put one over Manchester United when it mattered. Yet even so, Shearer was acknowledged as the best striker in the country at the time, an England regular fresh from a successful Euro 96.

The most expensive players are almost always strikers, or at least forwards. Kevin Keegan would never have splashed £15m on a defender, even had he known what one looked like. And Shearer was a Geordie, returning to his roots. Whether Newcastle saw good value for their £15m is a moot point, as it often is when players move for such astronomical sums, but at least you could see why they did it.

The deal made sense from all parties' points of view, even including Andy Cole, Les Ferdinand and Darren Huckerby, whose departures from St James' Park between 1995 and 1997 put over £13m in the kitty.

The same cannot be said of the deal Leeds have just completed. Rio Ferdinand is a splendid player with a lot of potential, but not even his best friends, who appear to include Franco Baresi, would describe him as the best defender in the world.

Yet Leeds have just made him the most expensive. It was tempting to wonder what Real Madrid made of it all on Wednesday at Elland Road. No strangers to breaking transfer records or paying out eye-watering wages, the Spanish giants' defence is full of world class defenders - Roberto Carlos, Ivan Campos, Fernando Hierro, Michel Salgado and the enviably accomplished Ivan Helguera - who suddenly look like bargains. Ferdinand is not in that league at the moment, and there is room for debate, shall we say, about whether he ever will be.

Helguera, moreover, is understood to be available and has been linked with a move to England. At 25, he is already the player Leeds hope Ferdinand will turn into. Strong, assertive, fabulous on the ball, and with a Champions League winner's medal already in his collection. Leeds would not have had to break the transfer record to sign a player like that, although they would have had to revise their wage structure.

Ferdinand's estimated £30,000 a week will not be out of line with other Elland Road earners, and is in fact only £10,000 a week more than he was picking up at West Ham. (Apologies for the ludicrousness of that last sentence, but it is becoming increasingly difficult to maintain even a pretence of normality when discussing footballers' wages.) You can see the logic, though it seems a peculiar sort of parsimony when you are throwing £18m around for a 22-year-old.

Credit where it is due, however. Leeds have not only shown the colour of their money, they have done two things which English clubs are criticised for not doing. In the first place they have bought an Englishman, actually paying over the odds instead of seeking to bring in a more reasonably priced mercenary from abroad. And they have also splashed out on a young player, someone with the best years of his career still ahead of him, instead of going for the safety-first option of a proven performer with only a couple of seasons left at the highest level.

In the brave new Yorkshire world of spendthriftery, Leeds paying Ferdinand £30,000 a week is more sensible than Middlesbrough handing Alen Boksic £63,000.

This is not anti-foreign prejudice, or even bias against Middlesbrough. The fact of the matter is that Leeds can afford to spend £18m on a player because they are in the Champions League, and want to still be in the Champions League next season. Middlesbrough are closer to the Nationwide League than the Champions League, and though a charitable view of Robson's signing policy might be that you have to spend big to catch the big spenders, the Teesside experience suggests this is not a path many other small but ambitious clubs will follow.

The difference between the two positions represents a real dilemma for Premiership clubs. The Champions League is incredibly divisive. If you are in it, you receive all the financial incentives necessary to practically double your playing strength, either by increasing the size of your squad or splashing out on players. Make a decent fist of the first group stage and you also get at least a dozen high-intensity games against the best sides in Europe.

When you have gone toe to toe with Barcelona or AC Milan you may be tired, but that Saturday trip to Highfield Road is never going to be as daunting again. If you are outside the echelon, on the other hand, it is impossible to compete for leading players, and you have a choice between buying what is left in a desperate bid to crash the party (Liverpool, Chelsea, Middlesbrough) or keeping your head down and accepting a reduced station (too many to mention). From time to time you will also lose your best players to clubs with more ambition, ie those in the Champions League. You will receive compensation, but not be able to spend it on players of similar quality, and soon your supporters will be accusing you of lacking ambition.

West Ham are going through this now, though they will probably cope more cheerfully than Spurs, who will have even more angst to come when Sol Campbell jumps ship to a Champions League club. You can't blame players for wanting to perform at the highest level, and neither can clubs be expected to do anything other than seek to maintain their Champions League status.

The one, hollow, consolation for small clubs is that though Rio Ferdinand could not have become the world's most expensive defender without Ridsdale's ambition or O'Leary's skill, he could not have done it either without Southampton and Bradford.

Those two clubs between them were responsible for taking four points off Liverpool in the final games of last season, letting Leeds slip into the Champions League practically by default. If Gerard Houllier isn't having nightmares about that already, he certainly will be should Ferdinand's contribution help Leeds to a top-three finish this season.

webTitle: All alone, Robbo? Send for the Samaritans

fields.headline: All alone, Robbo? Send for the Samaritans
fields.standfirst: Alan Smith on troubled managers in need of friends.
fields.trailText: This is the time of year we managers feel most insecure, the sacking season of November and December.
fields.body:
This is the time of year we managers feel most insecure, the sacking season of November and December.

If chairmen are going to change manager in the hope of changing their side's fortunes, they will usually do it before Christmas, and being unemployed is not exactly the nicest way to spend the festive season.

Already we have seen some high-profile managers depart this season - most surprisingly Gianluca Vialli at Chelsea in September, as well as Chris Hutchings at Bradford and Huddersfield's Steve Bruce. The man most under threat at the moment is Bruce's former Manchester United team-mate Bryan Robson, who must be feeling the pressure from fans and media alike as his team have slid down into the relegation zone.

I know exactly how he feels because I've been there. I would have to say management can be the loneliest job in the world when you are not winning games. There is no shortage of people phoning and wanting to share your thoughts when it is going well, but once you get on a losing streak you find out who your true friends are.

I don't know how much support Robson has had from fellow managers and former colleagues, and I am sure he has close friends around him, but I would not be surprised if he would welcome the opportunity to share his burden with his peers.

The sad truth, however, is that the informal support network of managers no longer exists because of the changing nature of our game.

For a start there are more foreign coaches and what Dave Bassett calls the 'designer-suit managers', the millionaire former leading players who have gone straight into top jobs.

I've nothing against managers from overseas -- as regular readers know I am all for embracing overseas attitudes and ideas on coaching - but I can't imagine having a chinwag with Arsène Wenger or Claudio Ranieri in quite the same way I might with Bassett, for example, or Joe Kinnear.

Another major factor in the breakdown of the management 'community' is the change in the transfer market - now you speak to agents rather than fellow managers about players.

I pride myself on being in touch with fellow coaches and managers, but I still spend far more time talking to agents than my peers when I'm trying to sign players. I have no problem with this - it is the way we do business now - but the side-effect is that managers no longer have the same sense of helping each other out.

It is particularly helpful for young managers to be able to ring up their more experienced counterparts for advice, especially when times are tough. Just the other week I had a call from George Foster at Lincoln, who rang me out of the blue to ask advice and admitted it was only because he had read about my situation at Palace in the newspapers that he thought of calling me.

Not that his was the only call - I had several calls of support from managers at all levels including George Graham. Yet most young managers wanting support or advice would be overawed at the thought of ringing someone like George or Alex Ferguson, who are the most successful men in the business.

I know Alex is quickly on the phone to offer congratulations and support whenever a new manager is starting out, even if he doesn't know him. There are others, too, such as Graham Taylor and Dave Bassett - they genuinely want to give something back to a profession that has been good to them.

But I think that network of support is waning and I would like to see a proper structure put in place to help out managers in what is a highly stressful job. The governing bodies could help, particularly the League Managers' Association and the PFA, who tend to stop worrying about their members' welfare once they retire from playing - especially if they move on to management.

Yet most managers have spent many years as players paying subs to their union without taking much back in return, so why should they not be supported in later life?

I would not go so far as to suggest full-time counsellors or therapists, although God knows there are times you feel that you are on the verge of cracking up!

But I'm sure there are enough ex-managers and experienced football people around to be on hand to offer support and advice for managers going through a difficult time. It could also be a development body for those managers who want to carry on learning.

The one thing that seems to be in Robson's favour is that he has a very strong relationship with his chairman, Steve Gibson. That is so important, as I know from personal experience.

When I was under a lot of pressure at Palace a month ago, after a string of bad results and problems with one or two players, my chairman Simon Jordan was a rock. He gave me his full backing - not just the public statement of support that usually precedes the sack - and made that clear to everyone concerned at the club.

That gave me the authority and confidence to do what I needed to do, and fortunately we were able to turn things around. I would not go as far as saying we are out of the woods, but we have made significant stride.

But not all managers get that chance - and you can be sure there will be more casualties before Christmas.

There is no shortage of people phoning and wanting to share your thoughts when it is going well, but once you get on a losing streak you find out who your true friends are. I don't know how much support Robson has had from fellow managers and former colleagues, and I am sure he has close friends around him, but I would not be surprised if he would welcome the opportunity to share his burden with his peers. The sad truth, however, is that the informal support network of managers no longer exists because of the changing nature of our game. For a start there are more foreign coaches and what Dave Bassett calls the 'designer-suit managers', the millionaire former leading players who have gone straight into top jobs. I've nothing against managers from overseas -- as regular readers know I am all for embracing overseas attitudes and ideas on coaching - but I can't imagine having a chinwag with Arsène Wenger or Claudio Ranieri in quite the same way I might with Bassett, for example, or Joe Kinnear. Another major factor in the breakdown of the management 'community' is the change in the transfer market - now you speak to agents rather than fellow managers about players. I pride myself on being in touch with fellow coaches and managers, but I still spend far more time talking to agents than my peers when I'm trying to sign players. I have no problem with this - it is the way we do business now - but the side-effect is that managers no longer have the same sense of helping each other out. It is particularly helpful for young managers to be able to ring up their more experienced counterparts for advice, especially when times are tough. Just the other week I had a call from George Foster at Lincoln, who rang me out of the blue to ask advice and admitted it was only because he had read about my situation at Palace in the newspapers that he thought of calling me. Not that his was the only call - I had several calls of support from managers at all levels including George Graham. Yet most young managers wanting support or advice would be overawed at the thought of ringing someone like George or Alex Ferguson, who are the most successful men in the business. I know Alex is quickly on the phone to offer congratulations and support whenever a new manager is starting out, even if he doesn't know him. There are others, too, such as Graham Taylor and Dave Bassett - they genuinely want to give something back to a profession that has been good to them. But I think that network of support is waning and I would like to see a proper structure put in place to help out managers in what is a highly stressful job. The governing bodies could help, particularly the League Managers' Association and the PFA, who tend to stop worrying about their members' welfare once they retire from playing - especially if they move on to management. Yet most managers have spent many years as players paying subs to their union without taking much back in return, so why should they not be supported in later life? I would not go so far as to suggest full-time counsellors or therapists, although God knows there are times you feel that you are on the verge of cracking up! But I'm sure there are enough ex-managers and experienced football people around to be on hand to offer support and advice for managers going through a difficult time. It could also be a development body for those managers who want to carry on learning. The one thing that seems to be in Robson's favour is that he has a very strong relationship with his chairman, Steve Gibson. That is so important, as I know from personal experience. When I was under a lot of pressure at Palace a month ago, after a string of bad results and problems with one or two players, my chairman Simon Jordan was a rock. He gave me his full backing - not just the public statement of support that usually precedes the sack - and made that clear to everyone concerned at the club. That gave me the authority and confidence to do what I needed to do, and fortunately we were able to turn things around. I would not go as far as saying we are out of the woods, but we have made significant stride. But not all managers get that chance - and you can be sure there will be more casualties before Christmas.

fields.headline: United break drought
fields.trailText: Scottish review.
fields.body:
Dundee United have won a match at last; but their 3-2 victory over Dunfermline - achieved with a last-minute penalty by Charlie Miller - was nothing if not nerve-wracking.

United should not have needed to put their supporters through such emotional agony. With Dunfermline suffering the setback of losing their captain, Ian Ferguson, through injury after only four minutes, Sean O'Connor gave United the lead two minutes later and just before half-time Craig Easton made it 2-0 with a header from a Neil Heaney cross.

Dunfermline then had another blow with their Moroccan defender, Youssef Rossi, being shown the red card for dissent. Then, it was United's turn to make life difficult for themselves - Easton was sent off for a second bookable offence and Dunfermline drew level with two goals in five minutes from Lee Bullen and David Moss

It probably would have stayed that way, but for the penalty area handball which caused Moss to be sent off, and Miller to push United to their first win of the season, and their first home league victory for almost a year.

In addition to Hibernian, Kilmarnock were also on the receiving end of a surprise - in their case a 2-0 home defeat by St Johnstone.

The latter gained the breakthrough in the 51st minute, with a penalty awarded for a foul on Momo Sylla by Gus McPherson and converted by Keigan Parker. It was Parker's seventh goal of the season, and a poor clearance by the home keeper, Gordon Marshall, led to the youngster adding a superb second.

For those who like dramatic finales, Tannadice was not the only place to be. Take the Aberdeen-Motherwell clash, where the home team fought back from 3-1 down to a 3-3 draw.

Lee McCullouch had done most of the damage to their defence by scoring twice. He was then upstaged by Alex Di Rocco, Aberdeen's most dangerous player. Eleven minutes from the end, Di Rocco scored his first goal for the club from a cross by Ken McNaughton, and steered Aberdeen to a deserved point in the third minute of stoppage time.

There was a similar performance from Hearts's Colin Cameron, whose two late goals, gave the troubled Edinburgh club their 3-1 win over Dundee - and a memorable send-off for their caretaker-manager Peter Houston.

Hearts, whose list of managerial candidates now appears to include the former Wimbledon manager, Joe Kinnear, showed plenty of character in recovering from the glorious free-kick which enabled Beto Carranza gave Dundee the lead. But at the end, 500 Hearts fans still deemed it necessary to stage a 'sit-in' against the club's chief executive, Chris Robinson.

fields.headline: Signing 'could backfire'
fields.trailText: Leeds could have bought Rio Ferdinand for no more than £4.5 million if they had waited for imminent changes to the transfer system to take effect.
fields.body:
Leeds could have bought Rio Ferdinand for no more than £4.5 million if they had waited for imminent changes to the transfer system to take effect.

Players boss Gordon Taylor said that whatever new system of establishing players' value is introduced, the 22-year-old would then be worth only a fraction of the £18m Leeds have agreed to pay.

The Professional Footballers Association chief executive said that, although there is still a dispute about how much money selling clubs should get in future, there is broad agreement that clubs should always receive some form of compensation for players under the age of 23.

'Whatever the system, there is no doubt that the figure West Ham would have received would have been nowhere near £18m. It probably would have been nearer a quarter of that,' said Taylor. 'The European Commission considers that Fifa's proposals on how exactly compensation would be constructed are still too vague, but the idea is that they would reflect a club's investment in developing that player.'

If a tribunal were convened to decide on compensation for Ferdinand, 'West Ham might argue that they spent a couple of hours a week working with him from the age of nine or so,' added Taylor. 'But the fact is that he could only have been full-time from leaving school at 16. Once you've arrived at a figure for that, you consider that he's been playing regular first-team football for a few years and is also already an international. If you add on the value of the contract he's on, the total compensation figure would still only be a few million at the most.'

The PFA boss said that Leeds' decision to buy the defender, and interest in taking Irish striker Robbie Keane from Inter Milan, was a 'high-risk strategy' that could backfire. 'Football clubs often fly in the face of common sense. Despite all the uncertainty some will continue to behave like lemmings in buying players for huge sums of money.'

fields.headline: Said & Done
fields.trailText: Chairman Dot denies all
fields.body:
Chairman Dot denies all

Smooth words from gossip-loving Leeds chairman Peter 'Dot Cotton' Ridsdale last week. After denying responsibility for spreading rumours designed to prise Rio Ferdinand from West Ham, Ridsdale - according to Sunderland boss Peter Reid - then tried the same trick with Kevin Phillips. 'How do I feel about these Phillips rumours?' Reid told hacks. 'I'm delighted. It's great. Just ask Peter Ridsdale about Phillips. There is an unwritten rule that you don't talk about another club's players in public, but Ridsdale prefers to do it differently. I'm sick and tired of it.'

Reid's in good company - in August, Harry Redknapp said he was 'pissed off' with Ridsdale's public wooing of Ferdinand, which ultimately resulted in last week's £18m deal. Ridsdale, though, says he was clean then - he denies unsettling Ferdinand over a five-month period - and, in an entertainingly put statement last week says he's clean now. 'I spoke to Peter Reid a week last Friday and told him we had no interest in Kevin Phillips. I will not allow him to blame me for the constant rumours in football that Phillips is unhappy at Sunderland and is desperate to leave.' According to reports, Ridders has now turned his attention to Inter's Robbie Keane, Atletico Madrid's Juninho and Feyenoord midfielder Brett Emerton - all of whom, we hear, are unhappy, desperate to leave, and would be happier with a Yorkshire-based club.

Fergie 'Pugwash' shocker

Did Alex Ferguson learn his motivational tactics from Captain Pugwash? On Manchester United's coma-inducing new Christmas video Beyond the Promised Land , there's some strange footage of a United players' quiz night. Despite allegations of question-rigging from Roy Keane, the management team of Fergie, Steve McLaren and various coaches romps home. First, the over-competitive gaffer knows that tanks run on caterpillar tracks and that Gershwin wrote Rhapsody in Blue (Teddy Sheringham opts for Schubert). Then comes the clincher: 'Which sailor was captain of a ship called the Black Pig?' 'Captain Pugwash!' shouts Ferguson, who then bangs the table in triumph at winning the quiz. Hence - presumably - his refusal to censor David Beckham for wearing bandanas - and for spending £10m on Barnabas lookalike Jaap Stam - it's all just Pugwash chic.

Manchester United Beyond the Promised Land - almost certainly the worst football video ever made - now available from Icon, £15.99

'Bizarre' referee starts riots

Officials in Malawi took a referee to hospital for blood and alcohol tests after a controversial Super League match in which he awarded both teams two penalties and then attacked a photographer. Referee Dinner Nathaya, who serves on the Fifa panel, was found to be sober despite allegations from both Telecom Wanderers and Silver Strikers, who described his performance as 'bizarre'. The fourth penalty decision prompted rioting in the stands - at one point the game was halted for 20 minutes while police fired tear gas - but once the game resumed, Nathaya's erratic behaviour increased. 'Officiating in this country has left a lot to be desired in the past but honestly I have never seen anything as bad as this,' said Super League chairman Hastings Kapenuka. Players watched as Kapenuka drove the referee away for tests. 'He's a crazy man.'

Caring wife of the week

'Yeah, he's got that obsessive compulsive thing where everything has to match. He's got it, like, ridiculously.'

- Victoria Beckham, reacting to her husband's illness, revealed by last Sunday's tabloids.

Tales from the Tabs

CHELSEA LAND DAVIDS

Claudio Ranieri's move for Edgar Davids could go through this week after Ken Bates approved a massive £20m package for Juve's Dutch midfielder. Arsenal had been favourites to land the Euro 2000 star, but Arsène Wenger won't spend big before Christmas.

FIND ME A STRIKER

Aston Villa chairman Doug Ellis has told manager John Gregory: 'Find me a new striker to buy - and be quick about it.' Ellis is ready to splash £10m on Celta Vigo's Benni McCarthy, but wants a deal quickly. 'John has a list of 13 targets - we need to bid now.'

And the rest...

 Coventry keeper Magnus Hedman has denied discussing a £6m switch to Arsenal - Arséne Wenger has targeted Francesco Toldo instead, but won't match Fiorentina's £20m asking price. Brazilian Edu, meanwhile, is still excited about his move to London: 'I'm going to play for one of Europe's great clubs.'

 Aston Villa are lining up a move for Wolves left-back Lee Naylor.

 Bradford are scouring Scotland for defenders to stand in for injured David Wetherall.

 Charlton have swooped for Millwall prodigy Goma Lambu - Alan Curbishley could be forced to pay up to £2m compensation.

 Chelsea have agreed to send striker Sam Parkin to Wycombe on loan.

 Carlton Palmer has been transfer-listed by Coventry at his own request. Formula One boss Eddie Jordan, meanwhile, has denied preparing a takeover bid.

 Derby are considering a new £3m Middlesbrough bid for Rory Delap.

 Everton's new winger, Idan Tal, has been backed by Walter Smith: 'He's doing well. If anything, he's trying a bit too hard to impress.'

 Titus Bramble's future at Ipswich is in doubt - West Ham have targeted the defender.

 Leeds face competition from Reggina for Inter's Robbie Keane, but are close to finalising a £3.5m deal for African star Felix Etienne from Levante.

 Leicester have rejected a second £4m bid from Celtic for Neil Lennon: 'I've told Celtic that I expect this to be the end of the matter once and for all,' says Peter Taylor.

 Liverpool have agreed a £3m fee with West Ham for Rigobert Song, and could sell Titi Camara this week.

 Man City's Terry Cooke will find out tomorrow whether Sheffield Wednesday plan to make his loan move permanent. .

 Man United have lined up a move for AZ Alkmaar striker Robin Nelisse.

 Alex McLeish has denied receiving an approach from Middlesbrough to replace fast-fading Bryan Robson.

 Newcastle face competition from Crystal Palace for Chinese star Sun Jihai - Palace want to re-sign the defender.

 Southampton will open talks with Blackburn this week for Jason McAteer.

 Sunderland could sell Chris Lumsden to Crewe this week - Peter Reid will put the cash towards a £1.5m deal for Swede Anders Svensson.

 Spurs have stalled on contract talks with Darren Anderton.

 Chelsea have denied making an £8m offer for West Ham's Frederick Kanoute.

fields.headline: Fulham forging ahead
fields.trailText: League review.
fields.body:
With Watford's match against Burnley being postponed at the last minute - because of a sudden downpour - Fulham took full advantage with a 2-1 win over Grimsby that increased their championship lead to nine points.

It wasn't until the second half that Fulham were able to seize the initiative, through goals by Luis Boa Morte and Lois Saha. But Grimsby owed much to their goalkeeper, Danny Coyne; and even their manager, Lenny Lawrence, had to admit that Fulham deserved their success: 'This match was an education to us all,' he said. 'Fulham show us what the game is all about.'

Fulham's clinical demolition job was in sharp contrast to the performance of third-placed Bolton, who wasted numerous scoring opportunities at Sheffield United, and paid for it with the 81st- minute Lee Sandford goal which gave United a 1-0 win.

But taking chances is clearly no problem at the moment with West Bromwich Albion, thanks to Lee Hughes. He scored his second hat-trick in a week to take his total for the season to 14, give his team a 3-1 win over Preston and lift them to fourth in the table - not a bad way to celebrate the birth of his baby daughter. West Brom's manager, Gary Megson, said: 'Lee deserves all his success because he is working his socks off. His previous hat-trick (against Gillingham) came from shots inside the box. This time, they were all long-range efforts.'

Perhaps the pick of the bunch was his third, when he charged past two Preston defenders and looped a perfect shot over their keeper, David Lucas. Preston's efforts to get back into the game, after Iain Anderson had reduced the arrears, were not helped when they had Michael Appleton sent off half an hour from the end for a second bookable offence.

The biggest surprise was Blackburn's 2-1 home defeat by Gillingham, their first in nine matches. What made it particularly hard for Graeme Souness and his troops to take was that Mark Hughes had put them in the driving seat after just 12 minutes and the goal which sunk them was an own goal by Blackburn's defender John Curtis. On top of this, Blackburn's David Dunn was shown the red card, as was Gillingham's Paul Shaw.

'Put it down as a bad day at the office,' Souness said. 'We have too many players who took their eye off the ball. Just when you think it is going along lovely something like this happens, but that's what you can expect in football, and it's how you deal with it that really matters.'

On the premise that football management can damage your health, Souness has a good reason for not getting uptight about setbacks. Five weeks ago, he had another heart operation - in Ohio - and he said: 'When I had a triple bypass eight years ago, it later came out that one of the arteries was still blocked.

'I hadn't felt too good during my time over in Portugal and this was an opportunity to get it sorted out. The doctors over in America have put what they call scaffolding in and hopefully that will do the trick, I feel better already.'

If Wimbledon's John Hartson is disappointed at having lost another chance to move on to a bigger stage - at Charlton - he certainly isn't showing it.

He scored the first goal in Wimbledon's 2-1 win against Norwich, which took him into double figures for the season, and Wimbledon's manager, Terry Burton, said: 'It was an excellent goal. It just shows how good he can be when he gets the ball in and around the box - in fact, I don't think there is a better finisher in this division.'

In addition to that man Hughes, another striker who might have something to say about this is Wolves's George Ndah, whose comeback following more than 12 months out through injury yielded his second goal in as many matches at QPR.

The latter twice came from behind to get a 2-2 draw, courtesy of two goals (one a penalty) by Gavin Peacock.

But the best scoring achievement could be found in the Third Division, where Scunthorpe's Guy Ipoua, who scored a hat-trick last week, got four of the goals in their 6-0 win against Mansfield.

The doctors over in America have put what they call scaffolding in and hopefully that will do the trick, I feel better already.' He scored the first goal in Wimbledon's 2-1 win against Norwich, which took him into double figures for the season, and Wimbledon's manager, Terry Burton, said: 'It was an excellent goal. It just shows how good he can be when he gets the ball in and around the box - in fact, I don't think there is a better finisher in this division.' In addition to that man Hughes, another striker who might have something to say about this is Wolves's George Ndah, whose comeback following more than 12 months out through injury yielded his second goal in as many matches at QPR. The latter twice came from behind to get a 2-2 draw, courtesy of two goals (one a penalty) by Gavin Peacock. But the best scoring achievement could be found in the Third Division, where Scunthorpe's Guy Ipoua, who scored a hat-trick last week, got four of the goals in their 6-0 win against Mansfield.

webTitle: Clark: I could not turn Gallowgate red and white

fields.headline: Clark: I could not turn Gallowgate red and white
fields.standfirst: Fulham's midfielder tells Bill Bradshaw why he could not face playing against his beloved Newcastle United for Sunderland.
fields.trailText: Fulham midfielder Lee Clark on why he could not face playing for Sunderland against Newcastle.
fields.body:
Fulham are leading the Nationwide League's charge on the Worthington Cup, but influential midfielder Lee Clark is uncompromising in his assessment of how important the competition is to the First Division leaders.

With seven of the last 16 coming from outside the Premiership - six from the First Division - the scent of a major final will grow stronger for those who prevail in this week's fourth round. But, with his side about to face struggling Derby County, Clark's focus remains fixed on the league.

'Promotion is what this season is all about,' he said. 'Give everyone at Fulham the choice between three points at Preston next weekend or making progress against Derby and we'll take the three points.

'Nevertheless, we also know that the Worthington Cup means a direct route into Europe for the winners. That's a great incentive.'

If all the above sounds like stock diplomacy from a disciplined, focused professional, it's perhaps understandable. Clark has sailed close to controversy in the past and while he has the air of a young, carefree player, it's a good mask.

At 28 he finds himself locked once again into a promotion campaign, having helped Newcastle reach the fledgling Premiership in 1993 and prompted and probed in Sunderland's midfield as they won the league by a record margin in 1999. On the day he left Newcastle for Wearside in 1997 he was named in an England squad by Glenn Hoddle. He is a player of genuine class and Premiership quality yet here he is again, scrapping to join the elite.

His last move two summers ago was coloured with controversy. Having enjoyed the celebrations following Sunderland's promotion he found himself in the middle of a furore after the revelation that he had joined Newcastle-supporting pals at the FA Cup final against Manchester United ... wearing a T-shirt mocking the Wearside fans he then played for: 'Sad Mackem Bastards' screamed the logo and Clark, a lifelong Gallowgate fan, had to go.

His account of that departure from the North-East is compellingly honest. 'The T-shirt incident is a massive regret in my career,' he says. 'But although we'd won promotion, I had already told Peter Reid, the manager, that I was thinking of moving. In hindsight, joining Sunderland was a mistake.

'A mistake because of my background. Everyone knows I'm Newcastle through and through. When I left Newcastle, the prospect of staying in the North-East, close to my family, was the big pull in going to Sunderland. But when we won promotion it dawned on me what that really meant. I would have to go to Newcastle the following season as a Sunderland player.

'I couldn't do that. Not to go there and give 100 per cent for Sunderland against the club I love and played for. And if I couldn't do that I'd have been cheating on Peter Reid, his assistant Bobby Saxton, the fans and all my team-mates. It was best that I went and Peter Reid knew how I felt before what happened at Wembley.'

If that sounds 'unprofessional' Clark is unfazed and brutally frank. 'I'm just being honest. It's how I feel. It won't be a problem if Fulham are lucky enough to win promotion. It's not a problem at all in my going to Newcastle as a Fulham player and giving everything - that would be a very different situation.To understand you have to know the feeling in the North-East between the two clubs.'

Clark tempers this confession by accentuating the upside of his two years on Wearside. He was accepted by the fans: 'They knew where my heart lay but were happy so long as I did the business for Sunderland on the pitch. And they knew I did that - always.

'We got to the play-off final in my first year and won the title in the second. It was the right manager - Peter was great for me - the right people but ultimately the wrong move.'

Although there were other options, almost certainly including Premiership clubs, Clark went to Fulham to be reunited with Paul Bracewell, his old team-mate at Newcastle.

'This club felt right for me,' he says. '"Brace" had been my team-mate at Newcastle and then my assistant manager at Sunderland and he's been a big influence on my career. The club had big ambitions and I wanted to be part of that.'

When Bracewell was sacked last season it left Clark a little bewildered in the big city at a club now stripped of the North-East influence that had formed part of the attraction when he joined.

'It hit me quite hard,' he admits. 'He [Bracewell] was certainly a major influence in my coming here. But he was adamant that I should stick around with Fulham.'

And stick he did, finding a the new manager with even better international midfield credentials than Bracewell - Jean Tigana. So far, the move has been wonderful for Tigana, Fulham and also Clark.

A blip following an unbeaten start to the campaign followed defeat in October at home to Preston but that is now forgotten. Fulham went into the weekend five points clear and the talk is often not if Fulham go up - but when.

Clark, a veteran of those successful Tyne-Wear campaigns in the Nineties, is perfectly placed to assess their chances and their capability. 'I'd say right away that we're not taking anything for granted. I know only too well that it can go wrong if you take your eyes off the target.

'It's getting harder all the time to get out of this division. But we are well-placed and there are plenty of players here at Fulham, not only me, who have played Premiership football and want to get back there.'

If Fulham make the top flight for the first time since the Sixties, what will Clark's advice to his colleagues be, especially those without Premiership experience? His answer is swift and characteristically frank: 'Keep the ball for as long as possible, as long as you can,' he says.

'Because once the opposition have got it, they'll give it to strikers who are world class and will punish you. One chance and it's in the back of your net.'

Last weekend, as he was scoring and helping Fulham to a convincing win against Portsmouth, his old clubs were meeting on Tyneside, where Sunderland won 2-1 before more than 52,000 fans.

'I was so pleased to beat Pompey and then I was instantly gutted when I heard the derby score,' Clark admitted. But now he has the prospect - without counting chickens - of facing both clubs if Fulham go up.

'If we do, I'd love to go back to St James' because I haven't played there since I left. As for the Stadium of Light...' he smiles awkwardly to himself... 'that will be a bit hot, won't it?'

fields.headline: Sinclair sinks Saints
fields.trailText: Post-Rio era starts with ding-dong at The Dell.
fields.body:
A right old ding-dong at the Dell proved that even without Rio, West Ham are still doing grand. Harry Redknapp, their manager, watched his side coast to their fifth win in six games and then confirmed that he expects Rio Ferdinand to finally sign on the dotted line for Leeds today.

And when the record-breaking £18 million transfer is rubber-stamped Redknapp will spend as much as he is allowed, starting with Liverpool's Rigobert Song tomorrow. But on this evidence, Redknapp need not go on a spending spree just yet, his side having moved from the relegation zone to the top half of the table in a month. As he said: 'When you've got good players, you know it will turn eventually.'

Southampton went ahead in the 20th minute when Matt Oakley hammered in an unstoppable half-volley from 25 yards after a poor clearance from a corner.

But West Ham took the lead with a similar effort from Stuart Pearce shortly after Frederic Kanoute had equalised in the 42nd minute. The French under-21 striker is strong and quick but had struggled to find the target. But he made no mistake with a header when Trevor Sinclair whipped in a cross from the right.

And when Stuart Pearce hammered home one of his thunderbolts a minute later, West Ham were in control.

Southampton hit back seven minutes into the second half with yet another goal from the reborn James Beattie, who struck his sixth in four games when he stole in front of his marker to flick home Hassan Kachloul's deep cross.

But West Ham secured the win they deserved with a quick break in the 68th minute that ended with Sinclair drilling a low shot into the far corner of the goal. The joy of victory was tempered by Frank Lampard being carried off on a stretcher with a knee ligament injury in the closing stages, while Kanoute was denied a hat-trick by sharp saves from Paul Jones in the Southampton goal.

Redknapp turned down a bid of £8m from Chelsea for the Frenchman this week and said: 'He's not for sale. I'm more concerned about how much of the £18m I've got to spend.

'Hopefully I'll sign Song on Monday and then buy a few decent players to take us on once the uncertainty over the transfer market is resolved in the next month or so.'

fields.headline: Silver lining for Strachan
fields.trailText: Sky Blues work hard to end their losing streak.
fields.body:
After five consecutive defeats, it appeared that nothing but the elements could rescue Coventry from another. A heavy downpour before kick-off put the match in jeopardy but the clouds cleared from Highfield Road to leave the pitch in passable condition and in the end Mustapha Hadji's late strike secured a flattering point.

Even then, Coventry did their best to give it away. In the dying minutes Chris Kirkland produced his only notable save to deny Gareth Southgate. Then, in injury time, Kirkland scooped up David Thompson's tackle-cum-back pass but Alan Wright blasted the resulting free-kick at the defensive wall.

So while Gordon Strachan may be celebrating the result he struggled to find positives in the performance. 'The football we're playing isn't great, but our workrate has been,' he said. 'It's hard for the players to relax and play when things aren't going for them. You've got to work for your points, and that's what we're doing.'

John Gregory also paid tribute to Coventry's desire. 'I thought the game was won, and it should have been,' he said. 'But I've got to give Coventry credit. Our players know that they've been in a game today.'

While you can't deny their commitment, the passing from both sides was poor, with Coventry particularly culpable for needlessly giving the ball away in vital areas of the pitch. On one such occasion Villa took the lead, Paul Williams allowing Ian Taylor to steal the ball from his toes and send in a low centre that Dion Dublin converted, his first goal in two months.

Amid the general mediocrity, Paul Merson shone. Playing up front in the absence of Julian Joachim, who has a broken toe, Merson's running and distribution were exemplary. It is just a shame that no one else could emulate him.

With Craig Bellamy relegated to the bench, Coventry ended the game with Mustapha Hadji partnering John Aloisi up front. He proved quite at home there, however, and his left-foot finish after Aloisi flicked on David Thompson's cross was emphatic. 'Although we should have been further ahead by then,' said Gregory grudgingly, 'they probably deserved their equaliser on the balance of play.'

Strachan must now translate tempo into technique if his side are to escape from the relegation mire. Until then, Coventry's hard work must continue.

fields.headline: Respect due to United
fields.trailText: Sir Alex sends a loaded message to Arsène Wenger.
fields.body:
Manchester United surely have more than enough going for them without requiring any extra motivation. They would probably have cruised this game anyway, but Arsène Wenger's musings that adversaries feel beaten as soon as they catch sight of the supreme force in English football struck a chord.

Sir Alex Ferguson's cheeky decision to substitute his goalkeeper Fabien Barthez for no apparent reason once his team were home and dry sent out a loaded message. He later explained that Raimond van der Gouw needed to get his eye in before a rare outing in the Worthington Cup on Tuesday. Who was he trying to kid? Surely it is not a certain rival manager from north London. Demonstrations of clear superiority don't come much more smug than that.

And so, after another display which showed off how brilliantly United fuse appetite and ability, they disappeared even further over the Premiership horizon - eight points in front of a shaky Arsenal to be exact. Since their last - and only - defeat of the season at Highbury they have responded with a sequence of seven straight Premiership wins.

There may be a grain of truth in Wenger's opinion. Jim Smith's admissions gave it some credence: 'On the scale of who to get points off, Manchester United is a zero. If you get something out of them it's a big plus. They are an outstanding team, they have stepped up another gear from two or three years ago.

'You can't defend against them for 90 minutes. Whatever you do against them you know they are going to score goals.' And so Derby clung on for a while, but the instant United finally fashioned the breakthrough they threw in the towel, and were subsequently crushed.

Encouraging though Derby's recent mini-revival has been, they never looked like adding to to last week's first win of the season. Sorry Bradford is one thing, soaring Manchester United an entirely different proposition. Even deprived of influential absentees - David Beckham was rested, and Ryan Giggs and Andy Cole recuperating - they are still an awesome proposition.

Luke Chadwick, the home-grown 20 year old who filled in on the right, clearly relished his first Premiership start. A dribble here, a shimmy there, crowned by the odd delivery the King of the Cross himself would not have been disappointed to call his own. Chadwick was also self-possessed enough to aim an audacious curler towards goal. It was a touch too high but promising nonetheless. Praise from Ferguson was fulsome: 'He did very well. He's quick, brave, sees the pass and attacks defenders all the time. If he can break through it gives me options with David Beckham.' Terrifying stuff.

The scoreline was respectable thanks to the efforts of Mart Poom and the serene presence of Taribo West, who were resolute enough to keep United at bay for an hour. But County just did not create any meaningful chances. Georgi Kinkladze played within himself, and although Lee Morris came on to lend much needed support to Malcolm Christie, Derby remained penned in their own half for long periods.

You sensed it had to come, and County's defence was finally unstitched when Dennis Irwin picked out a typically impish run from Paul Scholes, whose artistic cut-back was clipped in clinically by the prolific Sheringham. It was his fifteenth of a marvellous season so far. 'I couldn't see the goal coming - that's why I'm so pleased,' reflected Ferguson. 'It needed something special from Scholes to set up Sheringham, and with Teddy in such form you'd bet your life on him finishing those. Once we got the first the doors opened and it was very comfortable for us.' Indeed.

Butt doubled United's advantage with a pearl of a strike from 25 yards. Derby's shellshocked heads sunk, allowing United to express their class. Dwight Yorke got in on the act, chipping over a defender's head before whistling an angled volley past Poom.

The pressure on Arsenal and Leeds, who meet today at Elland Road, is almost suffocating. 'I'm not worried about that at the moment,' countered Ferguson. 'You don't get points for being complacent.' Right now, as far as United are concerned, there is no chance of that.

fields.headline: Reid has a Rae of light
fields.trailText: Reid sees Rae of light at The Valley.
fields.body:
Never mind the quality or the entertainment, points win prizes and pay the bills. And who cares about the neutrals?

Few full-on supporters worry about anything bar the result and at least the right team won, the goal from Alex Rae worthy of claiming any match.

Charlton recorded only one shot on target so had only themselves to blame for a dismal end to their unbeaten home record and manager Alan Curbishley was man enough to admit it.

Solid Sunderland had not won away before they beat their arch rivals Newcastle last week. They did the same thing last season, when their win on Tyneside sparked a 10-game unbeaten run. 'Maybe it's an omen,' wondered Sunderland manager Peter Reid. 'What I do know is that we deserved to win - and it's not often that you feel you will win as a manager.'

Reid, like many others in attendance, got that feeling early on as Sunderland controlled the first half and were only denied a lead at the interval when a Kevin Kilbane shot was superbly saved by Dean Kiely.

But it was an afternoon big on rain and small on thrills. These sides played out a 4-4 bonanza when they last met, in that epic 1998 First Division Play-Off Final, which Charlton won on penalties. But there was no sign of a repeat yesterday.

Admittedly, there was an early storm of an intensity rarely recorded since Noah took to his ark, and the players only had sets of long studs to help them cope with the conditions. But Sunderland seemed to handle it well enough and they remained on top after the break as Rae twice threatened to break the deadlock before he cracked his superb 58th-minute goal.

Don Hutchison played him through and Rae ran on unchallenged before firing into the roof of the net with a 25-yard shot so powerful that Kiely just managed to throw a glance sideways as the ball flashed past him.

Few will have witnessed a more venomous left-foot shot, so it is a mystery why this was Rae's first goal of the season.

Charlton responded by making a double substitution, throwing on strikers Martin Pringle and Kevin Lisbie to form a three-man attack. Their problem, however, was that they were not getting the ball to the potential goalscorers - not their lack of presence up front.

fields.headline: Parity at the Gate
fields.trailText: All square as both teams hint at greater things to come.
fields.body:
This was a game to cherish, the most skilful and controlled here so far this season. Both teams mocked their Second Division status - and Bristol City left the field wondering how they failed to win.

Home manager Danny Wilson, who played for Wigan as a teenager, seemed satisfied with the outcome, though. He said afterwards: 'If we remain as determined and as committed as this I really believe we can cause problems for anyone in the division.'

Things had started badly for the home side. Matthew Hill, the promising defender from Ashton Gate Academy, was at fault as Wigan mounted their opening raid with just three minutes gone. Andy Liddell crossed from the right and although the home side tried desperately to cover, Louis Carey could only divert the ball into his own net as he chased back.

Wigan were full of bright ideas but so were the home side, who efficiently redressed the balance after a most assertive and skilful burst by Mickey Bell. He found space to turn the ball back from the left wing and, with Wigan seeming close to conceding an own goal themselves, Lee Peacock pounced to drill a close-range shot over the line.

The £600,000 summer signing from Manchester City has recently been integrated effectively alongside Tony Thorpe in a twin strikeforce. But just as threatening were shots from Simon Clist, another Bristol teenager, Bell from 35 yards and Brian Tinnion from 30 yards.

The warm half-time response from the crowd reflected the measure of controlled endeavour put in by both teams: nothing better than when Wigan staged a five-man assault, resulting in a Steve Phillips save from Stefan Bidstrup.

The sturdy rivalry continued in the second half. Wigan may have finished slightly the stronger but neither defence looked like they were ever going to cave in. Phillips made one valuable sprawling save as the visiting forwards attempted to get on the end of Green's cross from the right flank.

Wigan manager Bruce Rioch was clearly delighted with the point his team earned and positively gushed with praise after a game which left everybody happy. 'This was a fantastic performance by two teams very much in form,' he beamed. 'I was particularly pleased to see the way the crowd applauded our players off the field at the end.'

fields.headline: Late blow for Hibs
fields.trailText: McGarry's last-minute strike denies Hibs.
fields.body:
An injury-time equaliser by substitute Steven McGarry denied Hibernian victory at Love Street and put paid to their chances of significantly closing the gap on Celtic ahead of today's Old Firm encounter at Ibrox. Yet Hibs will be angry that they had not put the game out of reach by then. John O'Neil's early goal looked as if it would prove decisive until McGarry struck. Within seven minutes of the match Hibs were ahead. Russell Latapy, taking over the captain's role from the absent Franck Sauzee, set up O'Neil, who drilled a low shot past Derek Scrimgour from outside the penalty area.

Frenchman David Zitelli then forced Scrimgour into a block with a 30-yard drive. Graham Fenton's off-target shot was the home side's first serious attempt as Saints gradually began to look more potent as the half wore on.

But Hibs still threatened. Lovell had a shot blocked and Mixu Paatelainen went down in the box under Barry McLaughlin's challenge, but play went on for Latapy to force Scrimgour into a block that rebounded back to O'Neil, who fired over.

Saints' Ricky Gillies was felled in the box by Matthias Jack but play continued for Gillies to receive the ball once more and float in a cross that Ulrik Laursen had to head clear.

The visitors could easily have put the game beyond St Mirren early in the second half. Within four minutes of the restart Hibs had come close three times, Zitelli's 25-yard free-kick which forced Scrimgour into a good save the pick of their efforts.

However, Saints offered the Edinburgh side a portent of things to come when Gillies set up Brown for a cross that Hibs failed to clear properly and Fenton forced Colgan into his first real save of the match, blocking at his near post.

The home side's increasing propensity to attack was exploited by Latapy, who used the space to put Paatelainen through but the flag was up before he put the ball in the net.

As time ebbed away, Gillies fired a good chance over with Colgan off his line. The Hibs goalkeeper then denied Gillies with an excellent tip over to deny Saints an injury-time equaliser. However, he was caught off his line soon afterwards when he failed to collect and gave McGarry the simple task of finding the empty net.

fields.headline: Ince to the rescue
fields.trailText: Ince's late goal throws Robson a lifeline.
fields.byline: John Wardle at The Riverside Stadium
fields.body:
They came to bury Bryan Robson, but reckoned without the resolve of Paul Ince. Ninety minutes had elapsed when Ince scored the goal that might - just might - extend Robson's managerial reign at Middlesbrough as Terry Venables hovers in the background.

The timely contribution by the Middlesbrough captain avoided an outcome that would have intensified the pressure on Robson. 'You are the weakest link. Goodbye,' was the graphic message on one banner in the crowd.

They are out of tune with the chairman, though. Incredible as it seems, a seventh successive Premiership defeat against the bottom club was still unlikely to earn Robson a P45 from Steve Gibson.

But even a man with the determined qualities of Robson might have finally blinked. Perhaps he was just seconds from quitting. We will probably never know.

Last night, Robson offered few clues to his thinking, while insisting he knew nothing of suggestions that Venables is on his way to the club.

'People ask whether I would be sacked if we lost - for me, it's not an issue,' he said. 'I know I've got 100 per cent backing from my chairman and I know what I want to do for this football club.

'We've come a hell of a long way and what I've got to do is make sure my decisions are the right ones for Middlesbrough. I've said before that things don't turn round because you sack a manager and bring another in. It doesn't work like that.'

A decision to leave may emerge as the right option, perhaps the only one available to Robson if he can't transform Middlesbrough's sorry season. For the time being, though, Ince's goal has given him a little breathing space, while denying Jim Jefferies a three-point start to his managerial reign at Bradford City.

Bradford are still without an away win in the league this season, but they do have two more goals to add to the solitary one scored on their travels.

Both came in the opening 10 minutes. Gianluca Festa committed two errors in quick succession on the greasy surface, presenting fellow-Italian Benito Carbone with the chance to cross to Dean Windass, who directed his header inside the post.

Bradford's second goal was only delayed a further six minutes. Middlesbrough gave Carbone space within range of goal and he sent a sweetly-struck shot across keeper Mark Schwarzer and high into the corner.

At least Middlesbrough were treating it like a cup final, as demanded by Robson in his programme column. They have figured in three finals in their history and lost them all.

Alen Boksic was consistently Boro's best hope of a first-half reply, notably when he headed against the bar after 42 minutes. Yet nothing could mask the reality. This was one of the most awkward 45 minutes of Robson's managerial life.

The second 45 threatened to be more daunting with Boksic ruled out because of hamstring trouble, but Ugo Ehiogu headed in within three minutes to give Boro badly-needed impetus.

Middlesbrough were reduced to 10 men when Carlos Marinelli, one of their more inventive performers, was dismissed for a high challenge on Billy McKinlay in the 68th minute.

But, with the stadium emptying, Ince's left-foot shot evaded Clarke. 'It's disappointing to be so close, said Jefferies. 'But at least we've stopped the rot and I can take some positive things out of the game.'

fields.headline: Ferdinand's three aces
fields.trailText: Ferdinand hat-trick caps Spurs' special week.
fields.byline: Ian Ridley at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
They may not show much of it away, but home is where Tottenham's heart is. A hat-trick by Les Ferdinand, his first for the club, made it seven wins in eight unbeaten Premiership games here, scuppering a disappointing Leicester's hopes of moving up to second in the table.

Ferdinand's treble, doubling his tally for the season, was the classic centre-forward's combination of right foot, header and left foot; this against a side who came into the game with the best defensive record in the top flight, having previously conceded only one goal away from home. Perhaps Les was a bit annoyed that cousin Rio was stealing all the headlines.

The man Peter Taylor had once made captain for an England B international made it an unhappy return for the City manager, back at the club he graced as a player. Taylor also had to endure his centre-back Gerry Taggart being sent off. For the first time in his managerial career, Taylor said, he would be asking a referee, in this case the notorious Rob Harris, to look at the video and reconsider his decision.

Sometimes you get the feeling that the most perverse of Spurs fans do not especially relish winning these days; it merely prolongs George Graham's tenure as manager. Yesterday, though, they caught a mood of recent optimism at the end of a good week for the club that saw Liverpool beaten, their right-back Stephen Carr sign a new contract and Sol Campbell return after two months out with a dislocated shoulder. 'It just needs Sol to sign a new contract now,' said Graham.

Campbell will need to see this being more than a false dawn, however. Certainly Graham wasn't fooled. He recognises that Spurs' away form remains worrying, with Manchester United the next opponents, grinning when it was suggested that Old Trafford next Saturday was a good place to test out new-found resolution.

Significantly, too, he still bracketed Spurs below the best despite the three points moving them up to seventh in the table, in responding to an observation that his uncharacteristic 3-5-2 looks to suit the players available: 'The top teams all play 4-4-2 but it seems to suit those in the next band.'

Leicester are one such and, combined with their organisation and spirit, they have risen to heady heights. Little of it was in evidence in a tetchy encounter worsened by Mr Harris's limp control of the game. 'I didn't think there was a lot of common sense shown,' lamented Taylor.

These two teams have combustible chemistry, stemming from their feisty Worthington Cup final of two seasons ago, and it began in the first minute with Stephen Clemence squaring up to Robbie Savage, main target of the home support's disdain for those Wembley events. Late on, Savage was withdrawn with a second yellow card a likely prospect.

Tottenham always seemed more likely to emerge from the skirmishes with a goal, their midfield of the talented 20-year-old Ledley King, Tim Sherwood and Darren Anderton dominating a side content to absorb pressure.

It was the enthusiasm of King that broke the deadlock, as he harassed Gary Rowett into a wayward backpass, intercepted by Ferdinand, who went on to turn inside Matt Elliott and drive home a right-footer from 18 yards.

Within five minutes it was two. Simon Royce turned aside a header by Tim Sherwood but from the corner, only half-cleared; Sergei Rebrov drove in a low shot that was kicked off the line by Frank Sinclair only to Ferdinand, who headed home the rebound off a post.

Leicester had to come out of their shell in the second half and should have reduced the deficit, Elliott driving a volley straight at Neil Sullivan and Taggart blasting over the rebound. Soon Taggart's frustration surfaced as he lunged at Carr and received a second yellow card, though Taylor insisted no contact was made.

With Taggart went Leicester's hopes of salvaging something and it came as no surprise when Ferdinand added a third, tapping home left-footed after Royce had only parried Anderton's shot. Rowett hit the bar with a header late in the game, but it was a token gesture. Much more of this, from both sides, and they could soon swop positions near the top of the Premiership's second strata.

webTitle: New Deal to scour streets and set homeless to work

fields.headline: New Deal to scour streets and set homeless to work
fields.standfirst: Hardcore underclass will be targeted in purge on welfare claimants
fields.trailText: Drug addicts and the homeless will be rounded up by benefits advisers for the most radical expansion yet of Labour's programme to drive welfare claimants into work.
fields.body:
Drug addicts and the homeless will be rounded up by benefits advisers for the most radical expansion yet of Labour's programme to drive welfare claimants into work.

Hostel places for rough sleepers could even be made conditional on joining job-preparation schemes, under plans being considered for Labour's second term.

But the proposal to target homeless people living in hostels was last night condemned by Louise Casey, the Government's homelessness tsar. 'You have to get people away from drugs and their problems before trying to get them to work. Forcing them on to the New Deal will not necessarily achieve this.'

New Deal personal advisers would be sent to shelters and on to the streets to find rough sleepers, alcoholics and others currently overlooked by the flagship welfare-to-work programme, in an effort to reach the hard core of Britain's underclass.

Initially, they would be offered benefits and help with housing, medical problems or illiteracy on voluntary grounds, before entering the New Deal proper.

'What we need to look at for this group is something like a pre-New Deal programme to address their needs, in order that they can get enough of their lives sorted to start even thinking about work,' said a senior source. It will be about personal advisers going out to people, rather than waiting for people to come to them.

'People who might be on incapacity benefit because of problems, or on no benefit at all, don't qualify for the New Deal, and that is another issue we have got to face.'

Tony Blair will this week announce that the election pledge to get 250,000 unemployed young people into work has officially been met.

Meanwhile, Social Security Secretary Alistair Darling will trumpet savings of £8 billion on unemployment benefits, thanks to the New Deal and fraud crackdowns.

But amid criticism that the Government has only skimmed off the 'easier' cases of relatively employable young people, Ministers are looking for ways to crack problems at the bottom of the pile. Benefits advisers are already due to be sent into GPs' surgeries to target those on long-term sick leave. And in future Ministers want personal advisers to find other hard-to-reach cases. The New Deal currently identifies those claiming jobseekers' allowance, but the chaotic lives of the most marginalised groups means they may not even be able to claim and so fall through the net.

A report from Labour's influential Social Exclusion Unit argues that, once a New Deal for the homeless is established, Ministers could eventually make hostel places dependent on participation.

Six ground-breaking pilot projects were set up in London last month offering help with housing, addiction treatment and careers advice to homeless people. They then pass on to the full New Deal, with options for the 18-24 age group of a job, training, voluntary work or benefit sanctions if they won't co-operate.

The first phase will target people attending job centres, but in future it is likely to use volunteer outreach workers to find rough sleepers. If the pilots work, they are expected to be extended nationally.

The charity Shelter gave a warning last night that, while it welcomed attempts to get the homeless back on their feet, compulsion would backfire. 'Our view is that compulsion can be counter-productive. We would want New Deal advisers to work in such a way that actually supports people and encourages them,' said a spokeswoman.

'Just saying to people "well, here's a job" will not necessarily be helpful.'

Research from the United States shows that its welfare-to-work schemes miss a hard core of about 10 per cent of their target audience - including lone parents who refuse to buckle under US benefit sanctions, drug addicts and rough sleepers.

But programmes teaching the so-called 'four Rs' - not just reading, writing and arithmetic, but 'readiness for work' skills like communication or punctuality - before entering work have had some success in the US, offering a model for the UK.

The standard New Deal will also emphasise 'work-readiness' skills to help candidates get better jobs with promotion prospects.

A key theme for Labour's next term will be not just getting people into work regardless, but creating 'good' jobs where employees are trained and treated well.

Six ground-breaking pilot projects were set up in London last month offering help with housing, addiction treatment and careers advice to homeless people. They then pass on to the full New Deal, with options for the 18-24 age group of a job, training, voluntary work or benefit sanctions if they won't co-operate. The first phase will target people attending job centres, but in future it is likely to use volunteer outreach workers to find rough sleepers. If the pilots work, they are expected to be extended nationally. The charity Shelter gave a warning last night that, while it welcomed attempts to get the homeless back on their feet, compulsion would backfire. 'Our view is that compulsion can be counter-productive. We would want New Deal advisers to work in such a way that actually supports people and encourages them,' said a spokeswoman. 'Just saying to people "well, here's a job" will not necessarily be helpful.' Research from the United States shows that its welfare-to-work schemes miss a hard core of about 10 per cent of their target audience - including lone parents who refuse to buckle under US benefit sanctions, drug addicts and rough sleepers. But programmes teaching the so-called 'four Rs' - not just reading, writing and arithmetic, but 'readiness for work' skills like communication or punctuality - before entering work have had some success in the US, offering a model for the UK. The standard New Deal will also emphasise 'work-readiness' skills to help candidates get better jobs with promotion prospects. A key theme for Labour's next term will be not just getting people into work regardless, but creating 'good' jobs where employees are trained and treated well.
