fields.headline: Abuse witch-hunt traps innocent in a net of lies
fields.standfirst: Public alarm over paedophiles has led to a relentless 'trawl' for sex perverts. David Rose and Gary Horne report on one man whose life was ruined when he fell victim to the wave of panic.
fields.trailText: Public alarm over paedophiles has led to a relentless 'trawl' for sex perverts. David Rose and Gary Horne report on one man whose life was ruined when he fell victim to the wave of panic.
fields.body:
In a spartan special-visits room at Wakefield prison, Roy Shuttleworth leans across the bolted-down table and displays his most treasured possessions: letters and cards from his wife, Irene. 'My darling, innocent Roy,' one begins, 'I am as much in love with you as the day we met nearly 40 years ago. My only wish is to spend what life we have left together. I only hope nothing happens to either one of us, because I know the other will die of a broken heart.'

As he speaks of his shattered family, he makes no attempt to hide his grief. His children, Roy junior and Suzanne, cross the Pennines from Cheshire to visit him twice a month. Now 67, the pale, broken man they find is a ghost of the jolly paterfamilias they see in family photos. This former champion swimmer, mining foreman and long-distance truck driver is serving a 10-year sentence for crimes deemed by some to be worse than murder - 11 counts of sexual assault and buggery against boys once in his care.

From his arrest in 1995, he has protested his innocence. Although it could shorten his sentence by two years, he refuses to take the prison sex offender treatment programme: 'How can I sit there in a so-called therapy group talking about my crimes if I haven't committed them? And listening to them who has done it - it's disgusting.'

Tonight, after five months of investigation, the BBC Panorama programme will reveal dramatic new evidence supporting Shuttleworth's claim of innocence, including evidence from former residents at the home where he worked - Greystone Heath in Warrington - who refute key elements of the prosecution case, contradicting key elements in the stories told by Shuttleworth's alleged victims. One man, confronted by huge discrepancies in his story, has now changed it beyond recognition from the version he gave in court.

All of the eight men who made allegations against Shuttleworth have criminal records for dishonesty; three were serving seven-year sentences when they testified. Three have since allegedly disclosed they fabricated their claims for money, hoping to be awarded compensation from the government criminal injuries scheme and from civil actions against Liverpool City Council, which owned and ran Greystone Heath. The rewards from this process may run to more than £100,000 for each claimant.

It would be deeply disturbing if Shuttleworth's story was an isolated case. But it is not. Since the time allegations of sexual abuse in care homes first surfaced in North Wales in 1991, more than 100 former care workers have been convicted and jailed for terms of up to 18 years. Some of them, perpetrators of foul and degrading crimes whose victims were long disbelieved, confessed to the police and pleaded guilty. Others, like Shuttleworth, continue to protest their innocence.

Police investigations into care-home abuse have become an unregulated phenomenon with 90 separate inquiries under way at present, and thousands of former and serving care workers and teachers under suspicion. Officers from a single inquiry in South Wales recently announced they had more than 500 suspects.

All are using 'the trawl' - the highly unusual method piloted in North Wales and by the Cheshire force that investigated Greystone Heath. It relies, not on victims coming forward, but on the police visiting hundreds or thousands of men once at a particular care home to discover if they were abused. Shuttleworth's solicitor, Chris Saltrese, calls it a 'begging bowl operation, a hunt for allegations'. Some of those identified this way are genuine abusers. But as Shuttleworth's case shows, it is a blunt weapon, likely to produce false allegations.

The trawl that led to Shuttleworth's conviction began with a single allegation from a resident of Greystone Heath, a prolific offender sent there by the courts. Early in 1994 'Paul' (the law says alleged victims of sexual offences must have their identities protected) found himself in the custody of the police. He told them that nine months earlier he had been driving his car in Widnes when he saw a former Greystone worker, Alan Langshaw, leaving the magistrates' court with a boy. This, he said, brought back the horror of the sexual abuse Langshaw inflicted on him at the home during the 1970s.

'Paul' made a statement, and in the days that followed, accused a further 17 former care workers, including Roy Shuttleworth. Without independent evidence his claims posed a serious problem for the police. However, two years earlier the media had fiercely criticised the failure of police in North Wales to bring the perpetrators of sexual abuse in local homes to justice. The Cheshire officers talking to 'Paul' did not want to expose themselves to similar attacks. The force decided to set up a major investigation - Operation Granite.

Using health, prison and benefit records, the police traced hundreds of former Greystone residents. At least 1,000 made statements, though only a small minority claimed they were victims. When the police arrested Langshaw, he confessed almost immediately and was finally jailed for eight years. Langshaw's Greystone Heath contemporary, Roy Shuttleworth, was a different matter.

There were striking differences. Langshaw, a gay single man, had a private flat at Greystone Heath where he could lock the door and do as he pleased with his victims, immune from scrutiny. Shuttleworth lived on the campus with his wife and children. He had come into care work in his forties, when his wife Irene, sick of his absences driving HGVs, persuaded him to apply for a joint post as houseparents. The couple did everything together. Why such a man would want to abuse young boys is a matter for psychologists. How he could have done so is a crucial question on which his proof of innocence turns.

The vital principle which trawl inquiries must follow is to avoid 'leading' potential witnesses by planting ideas in their minds. Professor Mike McConville of Warwick University, an authority on miscarriages of justice, tells tonight's Panorama how easy it is to generate a false allegation in this way. The police, he points out, do not simply record what interviewees say: they write up their statements from lengthy question and answer sessions, and it is impossible to tell the spontaneous account from one which has been suggested.

By telling interviewees they were investigating sexual abuse and reminding them of the names of care staff, detectives could sow the seeds of a wrongful conviction. McConville believes that introducing mandatory taping of all detective-witness encounters in trawl investigations is urgently needed.

When talks with police generate untrue statements, says McConville, the witness will almost invariably 'adopt' the misleading account as his own. In the present climate, a wrongly accused care worker is the deadly foe.

Panorama's investigation revealed that this process was at work in Operation Granite. A former Greystone inmate who left the home seven years before Shuttleworth began to work there in 1974 made a graphic statement, describing how Shuttleworth had forced him to masturbate him in the shower. The man sticks to his account now, insisting that Shuttleworth abused him. But the man got Shuttleworth's name from the police who descended 'out of the blue' one day in 1995. The detectives, he says, showed him photographs of Shuttleworth and told him they were investigating claims he was a paedophile.

The case reveals a second, deadly way in which wrongful convictions can be generated by trawls - the lure of compensation. After the man had made his statement, the police suggested he see a solicitor. He went to Abney Garsden McDonald in Cheadle, which by early 1995 was co-ordinating actions for damages on behalf of alleged abuse victims throughout the North-West. (Today there are more than 700 claimants in these actions, all funded by legal aid, 350 of whom the Cheadle firm represents.)

The lawyers told him he had two ways of making a claim: the Government criminal injuries compensation scheme, and a civil action against Greystone's operators, Liverpool City Council. He began to pursue both courses. Only then did the police realise the discrepancy over dates, forcing him to withdraw from both the criminal and civil legal process.

The police have taken an unusually close interest in the compensation aspect of the case. Senior officers visited the government scheme's Glasgow headquarters and persuaded them to waive the normal three-year time limit for claimants. They also had meetings with Peter Garsden, Abney Garsden McDonald's lead partner in the abuse cases, and with other lawyers involved in the civil actions.

'It very quickly became apparent that it was important for us and the police to have a symbiotic relationship,' Garsden says. 'For example, the police would want us to refer any new complaints of abuse that they didn't know about to them, because it would help them in their process. We depended on them, because we wanted as much information about the pending criminal trials as possible.'

Garsden also appointed a 'press relations officer' who succeeded in getting articles placed in the local media which made it clear that victims might be able to claim thousands of pounds in damages. A former Greystone resident, Eric Oldham, went to the firm and lodged a claim after seeing this publicity. Only after he had made his statement for the lawyers did he agree to talk to the police.

In McConville's eyes, this relationship between criminal and civil justice was risky. 'You cannot have a cheque book investigation in a criminal case. Victims can be legitimately assisted in pursuing compensation, that's one thing, but you must not have the issue of compensation colouring their accounts.'

In some cases, the relation between lawyers and police has been closer still. 'The police have been very helpful,' says solicitor Keith Robinson, handling over 100 abuse claims. 'I have had several clients who have been referred to me by officers. They will often supply important documents, such as unused material from a trial and supporting evidence.'

A third and final factor made the position in which Shuttleworth found himself more perilous still.

In 1991, a House of Lords judgment in the case known as Director of Public Prosecutions versus P changed the law. Normally, an allegation of a criminal offence has to stand or fall on its own merits: if a witness accusing someone of sexual abuse was sufficiently credible, or could adduce supporting evidence, then an abuser would be convicted. Until 1991, multiple allegations against the same person could only be held to be mutually corroborating if there were 'striking similarities' between the alleged crimes, indicating a criminal's 'signature,' a distinct modus operandi. But the judgment removed this protection. In effect, the courts have accepted the idea of 'corroboration by volume'.

Peter Garsden insists that every allegation in the 700 cases he is co-ordinating is true, because nobody would be prepared to put up with the unpleasant business of giving evidence unless they were telling the truth. He further believes he is, literally, fighting the forces of Satan: 'I believe that we're messing with the Devil, because you know, child abuse is evil, and the people that get involved in it are powerful, manipulative people. And they will do their level best to stop us succeeding and stop us getting justice for the victims.'

Garsden, who is also executive officer of the national Association of Child Abuse Lawyers, says that even when discrepancies occur between allegations and known facts, this doesn't cast doubt on their story: their memory may have deceived them over some of the details, but the one thing they will always remember is how they were abused, and by whom.

Lesley Cohen from Nottingham, who has prepared reports for more than 100 victims disagreed. 'You cannot tell from using a psychometric assessment whether a person has experienced [the abuse] they're talking about.'

The seven men who gave evidence accusing Shuttleworth all made criminal injuries claims, most before his trial; all have also lodged civil actions. One already had been convicted and jailed in 1991 for conspiracy to defraud the Criminal Injuries Compensation Board.

A psychiatric assessment dating from 1983 described this claimant as 'unable to separate fact from fantasy'. Nevertheless, as the trial opened at Chester Crown Court in May 1996, the police were convinced that he and the other men were telling the truth.

Shuttleworth's defence scored important points. For example, faced with the difficulty that Shuttleworth had no private space to take his supposed victims, the complainants claimed they'd been abused in public parts of the home. One, 'Dave', said he had a key to the swimming pool where he worked alone as a cleaner and Shuttleworth used to abuse him there.

Peter McCudden, the former head of PE, said this was untrue: there were only two keys to the swimming pool, guarded religiously by himself and the duty head, and anyone found alone there would be banned from the pool for life. The discrepancies were ignored by the jury. The judge described the men as 'coming forward', and asked the jury to consider how they could have made their claims independently unless they were true. But they had not 'come forward'.

Panorama tested 'Dave's' story further. He also claimed that Shuttleworth used to wake him in the dormitory and take him away to abuse him at night. We traced two of his former room-mates, both of whom insisted such a thing was impossible: they would have known. They denied Dave's claim that one of them had also been abused. One, abused by Langshaw, is now a successful entrepreneur who asked to remain anonymous. He said: 'No, no, not in this world, no, no, never - Shuttleworth never did anything to me.'

This was nothing to the unravelling of the claims of another witness - 'Jim'. He claimed he was assaulted one afternoon in the shower in a brutal attack which ended in buggery and lasted for 10 to 15 minutes. Finally, he said, he pushed Shuttleworth off him, banging his head against the shower door, and ran wrapped in a towel to the headmaster's office.

But 'Jim' would have had to run 400 yards in full view of the road and passers-by who used Greystone Heath as a short cut - on his account, crying, screaming and bleeding from his anus. Unfortunately, the trial never heard crucial details of the evening shower routine which cast further doubt: the shower was open, with no door against which Shuttleworth could bang his head. The boys showered together in a tightly supervised regimen, with two staff patrolling. 'There was never any stragglers,' says Lee Fielding, once 'Jim's' best friend.

Confronted by Panorama with these discrepancies, Jim changed his story: the attack, he said, lasted only 'a matter of seconds'; and he was no longer sure whether he had been penetrated. His one-time friend Lee then asked how he could have left the building, because the doors were always locked. 'Jim' claimed he jumped from a first-floor window - a detail he never mentioned before. Last week we went back to Greystone Heath and found - as Lee had told us - that the windows were restrained by metal brackets, and could not open more than three inches. 'Oh, aye,' 'Jim' said. 'I was skinny in them days.' Our inquiries found problems with the evidence of all the witnesses. The more we checked it, the more it fell apart.

Some of this fresh evidence was available when Shuttleworth applied for leave to appeal in 1999. The most dramatic example was the story of 'Tony,' who claimed Shuttleworth bent him over his bed and started to bugger him, and that he screamed and bit Shuttleworth's finger so hard he fell to the floor in agony. He claimed that another care worker, Phil Fiddler, was drawn by the commotion and was told by Shuttleworth (with trousers, presumably, at half-mast) that 'Tony' had attacked him.

In 1997, 'Tony' gave evidence in Fiddler's own trial. This time he claimed that Fiddler bent him over his bed and started to bugger him, and that he screamed and bit Fiddler's finger so hard he fell to the floor in agony. Drawn by the commotion, he said another care worker, Ted Tipton, entered the room and Fiddler told him (with trousers, presumably, at half-mast) that 'Tony' had attacked him. Fiddler's jury acquitted him of all charges. It was a carbon copy of the evidence against Shuttleworth. As Fiddler's barrister told the court, he had to be lying. In tonight's Panorama, another former Greystone resident who met 'Tony' in prison describes how he boasted that he was making false allegations for money, adding: 'You should try it yourself.'

At about the same time as Fiddler's trial, Shuttleworth's solicitor, Chris Saltrese, traced 'Paul', the man whose claims had first triggered Operation Granite. He admitted he had fabricated his allegations against Shuttleworth, and agreed to consider making a statement saying so. However, after consulting his lawyer, he declined. He is still claiming compensation - although by the time of Shuttleworth's trial, the police had decided not to call him as a witness. The reason, an internal police memo records, was that 'doubts must be cast on his competence as a credible prosecution witness'.

Shuttleworth was refused leave to appeal. Last year Irene suffered a heart attack and died. Shuttleworth was allowed to throw a handful of earth on her coffin handcuffed to a prison officer.

'My life is in fragments,' he says. 'I am in darkness. What those men's lies have taken away can never be put back. All there is left is to clear my name.'

 Panorama's investigation, In the Name of the Children, is on BBC1 tonight at 10.15.

In the present climate, a wrongly accused care worker is the deadly foe. Panorama's investigation revealed that this process was at work in Operation Granite. A former Greystone inmate who left the home seven years before Shuttleworth began to work there in 1974 made a graphic statement, describing how Shuttleworth had forced him to masturbate him in the shower. The man sticks to his account now, insisting that Shuttleworth abused him. But the man got Shuttleworth's name from the police who descended 'out of the blue' one day in 1995. The detectives, he says, showed him photographs of Shuttleworth and told him they were investigating claims he was a paedophile. The case reveals a second, deadly way in which wrongful convictions can be generated by trawls - the lure of compensation. After the man had made his statement, the police suggested he see a solicitor. He went to Abney Garsden McDonald in Cheadle, which by early 1995 was co-ordinating actions for damages on behalf of alleged abuse victims throughout the North-West. (Today there are more than 700 claimants in these actions, all funded by legal aid, 350 of whom the Cheadle firm represents.) The lawyers told him he had two ways of making a claim: the Government criminal injuries compensation scheme, and a civil action against Greystone's operators, Liverpool City Council. He began to pursue both courses. Only then did the police realise the discrepancy over dates, forcing him to withdraw from both the criminal and civil legal process. The police have taken an unusually close interest in the compensation aspect of the case. Senior officers visited the government scheme's Glasgow headquarters and persuaded them to waive the normal three-year time limit for claimants. They also had meetings with Peter Garsden, Abney Garsden McDonald's lead partner in the abuse cases, and with other lawyers involved in the civil actions. 'It very quickly became apparent that it was important for us and the police to have a symbiotic relationship,' Garsden says. 'For example, the police would want us to refer any new complaints of abuse that they didn't know about to them, because it would help them in their process. We depended on them, because we wanted as much information about the pending criminal trials as possible.' Garsden also appointed a 'press relations officer' who succeeded in getting articles placed in the local media which made it clear that victims might be able to claim thousands of pounds in damages. A former Greystone resident, Eric Oldham, went to the firm and lodged a claim after seeing this publicity. Only after he had made his statement for the lawyers did he agree to talk to the police. In McConville's eyes, this relationship between criminal and civil justice was risky. 'You cannot have a cheque book investigation in a criminal case. Victims can be legitimately assisted in pursuing compensation, that's one thing, but you must not have the issue of compensation colouring their accounts.' In some cases, the relation between lawyers and police has been closer still. 'The police have been very helpful,' says solicitor Keith Robinson, handling over 100 abuse claims. 'I have had several clients who have been referred to me by officers. They will often supply important documents, such as unused material from a trial and supporting evidence.' A third and final factor made the position in which Shuttleworth found himself more perilous still. In 1991, a House of Lords judgment in the case known as Director of Public Prosecutions versus P changed the law. Normally, an allegation of a criminal offence has to stand or fall on its own merits: if a witness accusing someone of sexual abuse was sufficiently credible, or could adduce supporting evidence, then an abuser would be convicted. Until 1991, multiple allegations against the same person could only be held to be mutually corroborating if there were 'striking similarities' between the alleged crimes, indicating a criminal's 'signature,' a distinct modus operandi. But the judgment removed this protection. In effect, the courts have accepted the idea of 'corroboration by volume'. Peter Garsden insists that every allegation in the 700 cases he is co-ordinating is true, because nobody would be prepared to put up with the unpleasant business of giving evidence unless they were telling the truth. He further believes he is, literally, fighting the forces of Satan: 'I believe that we're messing with the Devil, because you know, child abuse is evil, and the people that get involved in it are powerful, manipulative people. And they will do their level best to stop us succeeding and stop us getting justice for the victims.' Garsden, who is also executive officer of the national Association of Child Abuse Lawyers, says that even when discrepancies occur between allegations and known facts, this doesn't cast doubt on their story: their memory may have deceived them over some of the details, but the one thing they will always remember is how they were abused, and by whom. Lesley Cohen from Nottingham, who has prepared reports for more than 100 victims disagreed. 'You cannot tell from using a psychometric assessment whether a person has experienced [the abuse] they're talking about.' The seven men who gave evidence accusing Shuttleworth all made criminal injuries claims, most before his trial; all have also lodged civil actions. One already had been convicted and jailed in 1991 for conspiracy to defraud the Criminal Injuries Compensation Board. A psychiatric assessment dating from 1983 described this claimant as 'unable to separate fact from fantasy'. Nevertheless, as the trial opened at Chester Crown Court in May 1996, the police were convinced that he and the other men were telling the truth. Shuttleworth's defence scored important points. For example, faced with the difficulty that Shuttleworth had no private space to take his supposed victims, the complainants claimed they'd been abused in public parts of the home. One, 'Dave', said he had a key to the swimming pool where he worked alone as a cleaner and Shuttleworth used to abuse him there. Peter McCudden, the former head of PE, said this was untrue: there were only two keys to the swimming pool, guarded religiously by himself and the duty head, and anyone found alone there would be banned from the pool for life. The discrepancies were ignored by the jury. The judge described the men as 'coming forward', and asked the jury to consider how they could have made their claims independently unless they were true. But they had not 'come forward'. Panorama tested 'Dave's' story further. He also claimed that Shuttleworth used to wake him in the dormitory and take him away to abuse him at night. We traced two of his former room-mates, both of whom insisted such a thing was impossible: they would have known. They denied Dave's claim that one of them had also been abused. One, abused by Langshaw, is now a successful entrepreneur who asked to remain anonymous. He said: 'No, no, not in this world, no, no, never - Shuttleworth never did anything to me.' This was nothing to the unravelling of the claims of another witness - 'Jim'. He claimed he was assaulted one afternoon in the shower in a brutal attack which ended in buggery and lasted for 10 to 15 minutes. Finally, he said, he pushed Shuttleworth off him, banging his head against the shower door, and ran wrapped in a towel to the headmaster's office. But 'Jim' would have had to run 400 yards in full view of the road and passers-by who used Greystone Heath as a short cut - on his account, crying, screaming and bleeding from his anus. Unfortunately, the trial never heard crucial details of the evening shower routine which cast further doubt: the shower was open, with no door against which Shuttleworth could bang his head. The boys showered together in a tightly supervised regimen, with two staff patrolling. 'There was never any stragglers,' says Lee Fielding, once 'Jim's' best friend. Confronted by Panorama with these discrepancies, Jim changed his story: the attack, he said, lasted only 'a matter of seconds'; and he was no longer sure whether he had been penetrated. His one-time friend Lee then asked how he could have left the building, because the doors were always locked. 'Jim' claimed he jumped from a first-floor window - a detail he never mentioned before. Last week we went back to Greystone Heath and found - as Lee had told us - that the windows were restrained by metal brackets, and could not open more than three inches. 'Oh, aye,' 'Jim' said. 'I was skinny in them days.' Our inquiries found problems with the evidence of all the witnesses. The more we checked it, the more it fell apart. Some of this fresh evidence was available when Shuttleworth applied for leave to appeal in 1999. The most dramatic example was the story of 'Tony,' who claimed Shuttleworth bent him over his bed and started to bugger him, and that he screamed and bit Shuttleworth's finger so hard he fell to the floor in agony. He claimed that another care worker, Phil Fiddler, was drawn by the commotion and was told by Shuttleworth (with trousers, presumably, at half-mast) that 'Tony' had attacked him. In 1997, 'Tony' gave evidence in Fiddler's own trial. This time he claimed that Fiddler bent him over his bed and started to bugger him, and that he screamed and bit Fiddler's finger so hard he fell to the floor in agony. Drawn by the commotion, he said another care worker, Ted Tipton, entered the room and Fiddler told him (with trousers, presumably, at half-mast) that 'Tony' had attacked him. Fiddler's jury acquitted him of all charges. It was a carbon copy of the evidence against Shuttleworth. As Fiddler's barrister told the court, he had to be lying. In tonight's Panorama, another former Greystone resident who met 'Tony' in prison describes how he boasted that he was making false allegations for money, adding: 'You should try it yourself.' At about the same time as Fiddler's trial, Shuttleworth's solicitor, Chris Saltrese, traced 'Paul', the man whose claims had first triggered Operation Granite. He admitted he had fabricated his allegations against Shuttleworth, and agreed to consider making a statement saying so. However, after consulting his lawyer, he declined. He is still claiming compensation - although by the time of Shuttleworth's trial, the police had decided not to call him as a witness. The reason, an internal police memo records, was that 'doubts must be cast on his competence as a credible prosecution witness'. Shuttleworth was refused leave to appeal. Last year Irene suffered a heart attack and died. Shuttleworth was allowed to throw a handful of earth on her coffin handcuffed to a prison officer. 'My life is in fragments,' he says. 'I am in darkness. What those men's lies have taken away can never be put back. All there is left is to clear my name.'  Panorama's investigation, In the Name of the Children, is on BBC1 tonight at 10.15.

webTitle: Neo-Nazi hooligans target black football stars

fields.headline: Neo-Nazi hooligans target black football stars
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: A gang of neo-Nazi football hooligans linked to the killers of Stephen Lawrence is targeting black soccer stars amid a sharp upsurge in racism throughout the game.
fields.body:
A gang of neo-Nazi football hooligans linked to the killers of Stephen Lawrence is targeting black soccer stars amid a sharp upsurge in racism throughout the game.

Police are investigating the English Volunteer Force (EVF), which organises racial harassment at matches involving England and the south London club, Charlton Athletic.

The group has attacked rival fans near The Valley, Charlton's ground, and is active on the fringe of racist England fans who cause trouble abroad. Its literature bears a swastika and boasts that they are 'fucking racists'.

Charlton is one of several clubs where black players suffered racist abuse last weekend. Fans who made monkey noises at Chelsea's Marcel Desailly are thought to be EVF members.

Norwich City fan Peter Bloomfield was fined £250 and banned from domestic football for three years after he hurled racist jibes at Bolton Wanderers' Michael Ricketts when he scored.

At the FA Cup tie between Ilkeston Town and Swindon Town, several hundred home supporters subjected visiting black players to similar taunts.

In some incidents this season several thousand fans have taken part in racist chanting, systematically bar racked black players and sung xenophobic songs.

Campaigners claim such incidents disprove claims - voiced by Emile Heskey, the black Liverpool and England striker, among others - that black players now only suffer abuse abroad.

Piara Power, co-ordinator of the Premier League-backed Kick Racism Out of Football campaign, said: 'Racism is a huge problem in parts of Europe... But we shouldn't think that racist abuse and violence within stadiums has been eradicated from the British game. It hasn't.'

The police, the stewards and the clubs needed to take tougher action against racist fans, he said.

Offensive chanting is now a criminal offence, but stewards and police are often reluctant to act against offenders in case they provoke other fans. Closed-circuit television is rarely used to identify racists. Only 32 people were convicted of racist abuse at English grounds last season.

Lord Bassam, the Home Office Minister responsible for football hooliganism, said he was 'disturbed' by the rise in racist incidents this season. He urged police to follow the lead set by Millwall where police and club officials ensure that fans involved in racist chanting are arrested, ejected and prosecuted. Since 1997 the club has banned 29 fans for such behaviour.

webTitle: The House of Mirth by Edith Wharton, read by Eleanor Bron

fields.headline: The House of Mirth by Edith Wharton, read by Eleanor Bron
fields.standfirst: Unabridged, 12 hrs  Cover to Cover £26.99
fields.trailText: In her attack on moneyed New Yorkers at the beginning of the twentieth century, Edith Wharton shows just how foolish, empty and cruel that shallow society is
fields.body:
'The heart of fools is in the house of mirth,' says Ecclesiastes, and in her attack on moneyed New Yorkers at the beginning of the twentieth century, Edith Wharton shows just how foolish, empty and cruel that shallow society is.

Lily has been raised exclusively to be as decorative as her name, so that when, as a punishment for social indiscretion, her aunt leaves her only a tiny legacy, she is completely unequipped to cope with life unsupported and with little money. The connoisseur, Selden, regards her merely as a rare objet d'art for his collection, and when Lily fails finally to ensnare even him into marriage, she slides into debt, disgrace and misery. Through Lily's fate Wharton shows the tragedy that awaits a woman brought up in this way, and Eleanor Bron's consistently gentle American harmonies convey the author's enormous sympathy for this victim of a worthless, callous society.

 Mail order 01672-562255

webTitle: US backs Blair on rapid reaction force

fields.headline: US backs Blair on rapid reaction force
fields.standfirst:
Europe's defence plans on the right track, says Clinton

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Bill Clinton has signalled his full backing for plans for a European rapid reaction force, wrongfooting critics of the Government who say deploying British troops undermines Nato and Britain's alliance with the United States.
fields.body:
Bill Clinton has signalled his full backing for plans for a European rapid reaction force, wrongfooting critics of the Government who say deploying British troops undermines Nato and Britain's alliance with the United States.

In a remarkable move, the White House and Downing Street agreed an article in today's Observer written jointly by Robin Cook, the Foreign Secretary, and Madeleine Albright, the US Secretary of State.

Sources at Number 10 and the Foreign Office made it clear that the article was written with the President's full backing. Tony Blair and Clinton held a 50-minute telephone conversation on Thursday during which the issue was discussed. 'This is work in progress,' the article, agreed in London and Washington, says. 'There is no room for complacency. European forces must become more mobile, deployable and sustainable. They must improve their lift, logistics and intelligence capacities.

'That is why we believe that European nations are on the right track toward developing more capable forces that can meet today's challenges and tomorrow's crises. And that is why our governments fully support Europe's Common Security and Defence Policy and the contribution it can make to European and transatlantic security.'

Joint articles written by such senior members of the two governments are rare and reveal the importance Blair and Clinton put on getting a positive message about the reaction force across.

Blair and Cook agreed to approach Washington about the article at the EU summit at Zagreb last week. A Foreign Office source said the Government was 'wholly wedded' to keeping the European debate in the headlines in the run-up to the Nice summit next week. 'We have nothing to be afraid of,' the source said. 'As long as we are leading the agenda and not leaving it to the Eurosceptics to run this debate.'

Russia has now also backed the new force.

The moves came as fresh doubts were raised about the chief of defence staff's support for the force.

General Sir Charles Guthrie, the head of the army who has been embroiled in the controversy over the EU plans, was reported to have told a private meeting of MPs 11 days ago that it would be easier to promote European defence within Nato rather than creating a separate European force.

Guthrie has publicly backed Blair's plans but his private comments appear to reveal new fears within the army.

He is said to have told MPs that the EU force was a 'political idea' rather than one driven by the military.

In a further twist, Blair's leading political guru has admitted that the EU should hand back some powers to the nation state and should get away from backroom deals and old-boy networks if it is to gain public support.

In a significant intervention, Professor Anthony Giddens, who Blair has said is one of the most important influences on his political thinking, said it was time for the EU to reform its institutions and become more democratic.

'A transfer of authority downwards, including the handing back of some powers to nations or localities, should surely be basic to the future evolution of the EU,' Giddens writes in an article to be published by the Foreign Policy Centre this week.

Giddens attacks not only the institutions of the EU but also domestic parliaments for not giving the public enough information about how they operate.

'Existing political structures, even the most democratic of them, are not democratic enough in a globalising information age,' says Giddens, director of the London School of Economics.

webTitle: Agony aunt: Entitled to pay for sleeping on the job

fields.headline: Entitled to pay for sleeping on the job
fields.trailText: Entitled to pay for sleeping on the job.
fields.body:
I occasionally sleep at the hotel where I work - on nights when I am required to be there as the duty manager. Can these hours be taken into account when working out how much work I should do each week under the Working Time Directive?

Yes, you probably have quite a strong argument to say that those hours should be included in the calculation of your working week. Even though you could be sleeping for most of them, you would, presumably, prefer to sleep at home.

This sort of issue was one of many left unclear when the Working Time Directive came into force in 1998. But subsequent legal decisions suggest that time on call at work can count. If, however, you were a doctor on call from home, the situation would probably be different. The only time which would then be counted towards your working hours would be the hours for which you had actually travelled to work.

Many areas of the directive are still unclear in their effect. But the overall aim of the weekly hours part is to ensure that most workers do not have to work more than a weekly average of 48 hours - unless they opt to do so.

 Legal advice from Hammond Suddards Edge. Problem at work? Write to Neasa MacErlean, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1 3ER. Answers are for guidance only.

fields.headline: Pump up the volumes - part 2
fields.trailText: Jilly Cooper
fields.body:
Jilly Cooper

Anyone wanting an introduction to the lunacy, avarice and sexual merry-go-round of the New York contemporary art scene should read Danny Moynihan's marvellously funny and accomplished novel, Boogie Woogie (Duckworth). Having run galleries, curated and exhibited himself, Moynihan knows everything about bent dealers, pretentious collectors and thrusting young artists. All the characters are so awful that one ends up very fond of the less awful ones.

Katherine Whitehorn

I usually read paperbacks, so my books of the year are mostly last year's - and the best novel, The Homemaker by Dorothy Canfield Fisher, was resurrected from 1924 by Persephone Books. This is about a miserably obsessive housewife who is able to take a satisfying job only when her husband is crippled. However, I enjoyed The Pale Abyssinian (HarperCollins), Miles Bredin's witty biography of James Bruce, the preposterous Scot who discovered the source of the White Nile, and Yvonne Roberts 's gripping novel, A History of Insects (Headline) about residual snobbery in Pakistan after the Raj.

Paul Bailey

I found Victoria Clark's study of the Orthodox Church in Europe, Why Angels Fall (Macmillan), absolutely engrossing. The book provides insights into a Christian religion notably different from either Roman Catholicism or Protestantism. The novel that most impressed me was Alasdair MacLeod's No Great Mischief (Cape), a haunting family history set in the wilds of Canada and the Scottish Highlands. Lorna Sage's memoir of her nightmarish childhood, Bad Blood (Fourth Estate) is funny, moving, and wonderfully written. In The Million Dollar Mermaid by Esther Williams with Digby Diehl (Simon & Schuster), the aquatic film star says of her third husband, the relentlessly priapic Fernando Lamas, 'He talked about his penis as if it were a dear and talented friend, with excellent posture.' Thanks to Digby, Esther's autobiography is crammed with similar memorable conceits.

Jacqueline Rose

Both my books this year come from or return to South Africa. Gillian Slovo's Red Dust (Virago) transforms South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, with extraordinary skill, into an impossible-to-put-down detective story so that the reader is forced to enter the minds of all sides of the apartheid era, oppressor and victim alike. Marlene Van Neikerk's prize-winning Afrikaans novel Triomf (Little,Brown) rescues for South African literature the forgotten white trash of the country, while presenting its staggeringly dysfunctional, sometimes inspired, family in such uncompromising terms that Coetzee's Disgrace seems positively redemptive in comparison.

David Cannadine

Here are three books which should stimulate and divert the mind over the seasonal shutdown. Michael Howard's The Invention of Peace: Reflections on War and International Order (Profile) distils a lifetime's learning by our greatest military historian. John Simpson's A Mad World, My Masters: Tales from a Traveller's Life (Macmillan) is by turns hilarious and horrifying. And Simon Schama's A History of Britain: At the Edge of the World? 1,000 BC to AD 1603 (BBC) is a bravura performance by the Lord Macaulay of our day.

Paul Muldoon

One of the best books of poetry of the past year was Derek Mahon's Selected Poems (Penguin). Among numerous other distinctions, Mahon is the single most effective manager of the long stanza since Philip Larkin, as is clear from such anthology pieces as 'A Disused Shed in County Wexford' and 'A Garage in County Cork'.

Kathy Lette

John Mortimer is in his anecdotage and his autobiographical The Summer of a Dormouse (Viking), a mix of warmth, wit and wisdom is my book of the year. Whether ruminating on Napoleon's dick, the poor bastard who was jailed for sleeping with his own wife while wearing a beard, the Princess and the dipsomaniac Irish undertaker or the Swede caught spanking his wife with a live eel (and fined for cruelty to animals), the mischievous Mortimer weaves comedy and compassion into his prose.

Simon Callow

Tom Phillips's millennium project, The Postcard Century (Thames & Hudson) is an inexhaustibly fascinating account of private lives and public images over the past 100 years, as intimate and authentic an account of the experience of being alive at that time as we shall ever have. Thomas Wright's Oscar Wilde: Table Talk (Cassell) suggests more than anything else in print what it was like to hear the great man do what he did better than anyone: talk.

John Mortimer

A plot which involves two alleged Lord Lucans and a lady psychiatrist who faked the stigmata could only have gestated in the fertile brain of Muriel Spark. Aiding and Abetting (Viking) is written with the meticulous sparkle which makes her prose the envy of contemporary writers. We live at a time when we seem to be determined to cut ourselves off from our history, a fatal tendency that might be cured by Simon Schama's excitingly readable A History of Britain: At the Edge of the World? 1,000 BC to AD 1603 (BBC), full of kings and battles, puts an end to the fashionable idea that history should only be studied in the lives of medieval bakers or eighteenth-century piano tuners. Finally, the English obsession with verdant and manicured lawns is entertainingly weeded and watered in Tom Fort's The Grass is Greener: Our Love Affair with the Lawn (HarperCollins). It contains one of the best descriptions of a potting shed ever written.

Adam Mars-Jones

The novel and the book of stories I most enjoyed this year are both products of creative Indian summers: Philip Roth's The Human Stain (Cape) and Penelope Fitzgerald's The Means of Escape (Flamingo). Roth's novel addresses with subtlety the issues of sex, race, identity. Fitzgerald, whose death this year ends a brilliant literary career that began when she was 60, constantly brushes up against profundity without ever seeming to have designs on it. A striking debut collection of stories was Never Trust A Rabbit by Jeremy Dyson (Duckworth). His stories nestle in the little vacant chink between Roald Dahl and Borges. Jeremy Seabrook's Love in a Different Climate: Men Who Have Sex with Men in India (Verso) is illuminating - an attempt to describe taboo experience without imposing Western assumptions.

Stephen Bayley

I checked and I haven't actually read anything in the Amazon Hot 100. Not even The Thunderbirds Colouring Book, or David Beckham: My World. It's been a thin year for good books. Certainly, no fiction that sticks. This is a straightforward compilation of art, architecture and restaurant tips by people who really know the city: it's cruelly tempting, insightful and inspiring, as well as being nicely designed. The ordinary thing done extraordinary well: I'd never lend my copy, it's always in use.

Melvyn Bragg

The latest collection of Alan Jenkins's poems, The Drift (Chatto & Windus), is stunningly good. Full of passionate regret, clear, erudite, both a chronicle of the poet's time and a comment on it in poems as fine as any being written today. Conjure (Picador) contains poems which are as deeply structured, as lucid, moving and witty as Auden at his best. He brings powerful forces to bear on the memory of deep attachments and his vivid story-telling sense is a marvel. Adam Phillips's Promises, Promises: Essays on Psychoanalysis and Literature (Faber) is a brilliant collection of essays around the subjects in which disciplines Phillips excels.

Rowan Pelling

I have just started the book which I have waited patiently for all year - Philip Pullman's finale to his 'Dark Materials' trilogy, The Amber Spyglass. After only 20 pages I find myself spellbound by Pullman's storytelling. All my godchildren will receive the complete hardback set for Christmas.

Ian Hislop

fields.bodyText: Jilly Cooper Anyone wanting an introduction to the lunacy, avarice and sexual merry-go-round of the New York contemporary art scene should read Danny Moynihan's marvellously funny and accomplished novel, Boogie Woogie (Duckworth). Paul Bailey I found Victoria Clark's study of the Orthodox Church in Europe, Why Angels Fall (Macmillan), absolutely engrossing. The book provides insights into a Christian religion notably different from either Roman Catholicism or Protestantism. The novel that most impressed me was Alasdair MacLeod's No Great Mischief (Cape), a haunting family history set in the wilds of Canada and the Scottish Highlands. Thanks to Digby, Esther's autobiography is crammed with similar memorable conceits. Jacqueline Rose Both my books this year come from or return to South Africa. Gillian Slovo's Red Dust (Virago) transforms South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, with extraordinary skill, into an impossible-to-put-down detective story so that the reader is forced to enter the minds of all sides of the apartheid era, oppressor and victim alike. David Cannadine Here are three books which should stimulate and divert the mind over the seasonal shutdown. Michael Howard's The Invention of Peace: Reflections on War and International Order (Profile) distils a lifetime's learning by our greatest military historian. John Simpson's A Mad World, My Masters: Tales from a Traveller's Life (Macmillan) is by turns hilarious and horrifying. And Simon Schama's A History of Britain: At the Edge of the World? 1,000 BC to AD 1603 (BBC) is a bravura performance by the Lord Macaulay of our day. Among numerous other distinctions, Mahon is the single most effective manager of the long stanza since Philip Larkin, as is clear from such anthology pieces as 'A Disused Shed in County Wexford' and 'A Garage in County Cork'. Simon Callow Tom Phillips's millennium project, The Postcard Century (Thames & Hudson) is an inexhaustibly fascinating account of private lives and public images over the past 100 years, as intimate and authentic an account of the experience of being alive at that time as we shall ever have. John Mortimer A plot which involves two alleged Lord Lucans and a lady psychiatrist who faked the stigmata could only have gestated in the fertile brain of Muriel Spark. webTitle: OAP winter death toll is on the rise

fields.headline: OAP winter death toll is on the rise
fields.trailText: More pensioners died from cold last winter than during any winter since 1976. If latest weather predictions are correct, the death toll this winter will be even worse.
fields.body:
More pensioners died from cold last winter than during any winter since 1976. If latest weather predictions are correct, the death toll this winter will be even worse.

Almost 55,000 people died from cold-related illnesses between last December and March, new figures from the Office of National Statistics reveal. The figures will acutely embarrass Ministers who had pledged to end pensioner poverty.

'It's a tragedy that people in Britain are still literally freezing to death and a main reason is poverty,' said Ben Harding of Help the Aged. 'We deal with thousands of cases where older people can't meet the costs of heating their home. They need heat all day and sometimes at night and are particularly vulnerable.'

'I simply can't afford to heat my flat properly,' says 89-year old Sue Williams from Battersea in south London. She has two small gas fires but no central heating. 'I usually sit with a hot water bottle during the day if it's cold. I'm terribly afraid of the bills coming in.

'When I finally have to pay a bill I usually go without shopping for a week. I scrape around with what's in the kitchen,' explains Mrs Williams, who has no savings and manages on about £90 a week.

On Christmas Day last year, William Gallagher, a retired miner from Clackmannanshire, froze to death in his bed when his wife found that the £5 card she had bought to restore power was not enough to reconnect their electricity. They owed £20. Mrs Gallagher did not approach neighbours until she had sat with her husband's body for 24 hours.

Albert Smith from Norfolk is 82. He fought in Africa and was then a postman for 40 years. 'There's no point hiding the fact that I'm frightened of winter. My doctor has told me firmly to have the heating on whenever I need it, but that's simply not possible.

'When I'm moving around it's fine, but if I sit down and rest I start to feel the temperature badly. Last winter was particularly unpleasant. Our £200 winter fuel allowance does make a difference and I'm delighted that we're going to get it,' said Mr Smith, 'but it certainly won't pay what I need to heat the house.'

The winter fuel payment was increased to £200 in Chancellor Gordon Brown's pre-Budget statement two weeks ago.

Harding of Help the Aged said: 'It's now well-established that the surge in winter deaths is connected very closely with cold-related illnesses such as bronchitis and pneumonia. Every degree the outside temperature falls below freezing adds about 2 per cent to the death rate.'

Last week, weather forecasts predicted a January of snow and ice, with inland temperatures falling as low as -10 C, a cold snap which could mean disaster for thousands more pensioners.

Paul Wilkinson, who has researched winter deaths for Harding's charity and British Gas, said: 'Last year in the depth of winter, there were 54 per cent more deaths in Britain than in the summer. The key factor is undoubtedly the cold. If you look at figures from Scandinavia, you see what a big contrast there is. Our winters are milder and Scandinavian winters are colder, but the number of deaths there is much lower than in the UK.'

MP Steve Webb, social security spokesman for the Liberal Democrats, said: 'The Government really can't pretend that the winter fuel payments scheme is the answer because these deaths when pensioners were already receiving a winter payment of £100. It's a question of overall pensioner poverty.'

Two years ago, during a mild winter, deaths from cold were just 25,630. But if January is as cold as predicted, the figure could rise to 70,000.

ben.summerskill@observer.co.uk

webTitle: The peer, the porn king and  the Shell-shocked Express

fields.headline: The peer, the porn king and  the Shell-shocked Express
fields.standfirst: When Lord Hollick sold his tabloid titles to Richard Desmond, the first his staff knew of the coup was when they saw it on TV.  John Arlidge, Paul Farrelly and Ben Summerskill  dissect the deal and ask how the new proprietor plans to seize the middle ground
fields.trailText: When Lord Hollick sold his tabloid titles to Richard Desmond, the first his staff knew of the coup was when they saw it on TV. John Arlidge, Paul Farrelly and Ben Summerskill dissect the deal and ask how the new proprietor plans to seize the middle ground.
fields.byline: John Arlidge, Paul Farrelly and Ben Summerskill
fields.body:
At four o'clock on Wednesday afternoon the Daily Express newsroom fell silent as staff gathered around television sets to watch Sky News. The channel was carrying live coverage of the dramatic announcement of the sale of their group's newspapers to soft-porn publisher Richard Desmond.

The drama was unfolding on the steps of the Express headquarters, the 'Grey Lubianka', on London's Blackfriars Bridge. But Express staff had no idea the sale was about to be announced, nor that their own reporters would be scooped by Sky.

By 4.15pm, the new owner swept on to the forecourt in his powder-blue Bentley, registration RCD1. 'Porn King buys Express ', a nearby newspaper hoarding screamed.

These farcical scenes marked the climax of almost two months of horse-trading which has damaged the reputation of United News chief executive Clive Hollick, the New Labour peer, and plunged one of Britain's best-known newspapers into a surreal mix of relief and despair.

'People are amused, concerned and shell-shocked,' one senior Express executive said this weekend. 'There's a slight atmosphere of hysteria about the mad things already being done.' On Friday, for example, Express editor Rosie Boycott knew nothing about a change in the paper's masthead in between editions to run a colour plug for OK! , the most successful of Desmond's magazines. Staff were already finding newcomers occupying their desks. And from next week, a deluge of 50 OK! journalists will inject their mix of celebrity and gossip into the Daily and Sunday Express titles and their red-top stablemate, The Star .

So far Boycott is biting her lip. With the ink barely dry on the contracts, the Express editor - a pin-up of the liberal establishment - met Desmond for a 'celebratory drink' on Wednesday afternoon. The boss of Northern & Shell, who has brought the nation 38 soft-porn magazines, including Asian Babes and Big Ones and Forty Plus, as well as the celebrity soft-soap rival to Hello!, is, like Boycott, teetotal. He toasted the deal in Coca-Cola; for her it was mineral water. 'I'm just relieved it is all over,' Boycott confided to a colleague. Few staffers, however, expect Boycott,

co-founder of feminist magazine Spare Rib, to be there by Christmas.

Over the past two years, under Boycott and with advice from Tony Blair's focus group guru Philip Gould, Hollick has transformed the Express ' s editorial line. Instead of challenging the Daily Mail on its own Tory turf, the Express began supporting New Labour. In the run-up to the next general election, the politics of the Express are once again up for grabs. But for now, most of the bile has been reserved for the Labour peer rather than the 'People's Pornographer'.

'He's behaved just like a right-wing shit,' one staffer said. 'It's a typically shabby performance,' said another. 'Hollick will go down in history as the first person to sell a national newspaper to a pornographer.'

The Northern & Shell boss is aggressive, famously foul-mouthed and does not suffer fools gladly. He left school at 14 and started work as a cloakroom attendant at the Manor House pub in north London. In his early twenties, he set up a music magazine, pre-selling a whole six months' advertising at a Frankfurt music show.

Desmond's big break came in 1982 when Northern & Shell gained the UK rights to Bob Guccione's Penthouse magazine. The soft porn stable flourished from there, along with Desmond's colourful reputation for bust-ups, serious minders and hounding enemies until, metaphorically speaking, they dropped.

'Richard was on the fund-raising committee of the local synagogue. They'd never heard anyone swear as much as him in front of the rabbi,' one close acquaintance said. 'But because it's Richard, no one takes much notice. You don't ever want to be on the wrong side of him, though.'

The Penthouse tie-up was one to dissolve in acrimony a few years back. A failed venture with credit card entrepreneur David Elias - to sell soft porn magazines through petrol stations - wound Desmond up so much that he relentlessly pursued his former partner through the courts. Elias then lost his own business empire to a coup by disgraced Guinness chief Ernest Saunders.

Ironically, former Express chairman Lord Stevens was yet another scalp. In 1993, Northern & Shell made a handsome £16m profit flogging Stevens several magazine titles to settle a legal action after the Express ended a distribution contract. Later Desmond was thwarted in trying to buy the Express itself, and the rancour towards Stevens remained.

'Richard can be ruthless,' one associate said. 'But he also gives a lot to charity and is a strong family man. At Northern & Shell Towers, which is stuffed full of minders, butlers serve tea in the Richard Desmond room, the Janet Desmond room [named after his wife] and the Robert Desmond room [his son]'.

Now he finally has the titles, Desmond has lost little time in making changes. He has ordered staff to increase the print-run of the Daily Express by 200,000 from tomorrow. That is a refreshing change from the frightened Express executives who cut the run so harshly to save cash that many newsagents ran out of papers by midday.

But Desmond quickly demonstrated his reputation as a ruthless cost-cutter himself. The Express's £30,000 annual newspaper bill was the first to go. From now on journalists will have to pop to the newsagent to see what rival papers are up to. 'Richard will boost circulation by bringing OK's broad appeal to the Express ,' one adviser said. 'Hollick has not paid full attention to cost-cutting. He's been soft, and Desmond is a hard man on costs.'

The hard man, anti-intellectual approach will hardly endear Desmond to his editor. If nothing else, Boycott is a campaigner for high-profile causes. At the Independent on Sunday , she backed the decriminalisation of cannabis. At the Express , she has not been frightened to tell the often elderly and conservative-leaning readership that she believes in abortion on demand, that Britain's attitude to Third World poverty is shameful and that our immigration policies are cruel.

Despite his initial charm offensive, Desmond is already understood to be seeking a new editor, more amenable to his line, from a red-top tabloid.

His never-say-die drive and ambition have already given others pause for thought. Associated Newspapers, publisher of the Daily Mail, which had hoped to buy the Express , has most to lose. Mail bosses have already held a crisis meeting to discuss competing with Desmond, who also told Express staff in a memo on Thursday that he would 'spend what it takes' to restore the papers to 'their rightful position - number one in their respective markets'. To make matters worse for the Mail , Middle England's market leader, Desmond has identified 'new readers from among 18-34, intelligent independent-minded females' as his target market. 'If that's not our tanks on th e Mai l's lawn, they're blind as bats,' said a Desmond associate.

The Mail , however, has a long history of seeing off rivals - and far deeper pockets than Desmond's.

The Express , oddly for a company suffering from decades of mismanagement, under-investment and vanishing profits, attracted a scramble of eager buyers now licking their wounds. Besides Associated, they included the secretive Barclay brothers, owners of the Scotsman and Sunday Business ; India's equally secretive Hinduja brothers; Conrad Black's Daily Telegraph ; former Mirror boss David Montgomery; Harrod's chief Mohammed al-Fayed; and fellow porn baron David Sullivan.

How did Desmond - a man with no experience of newspapers - put one over some of the shrewdest players in Fleet Street? In the end it was speed and cash that clinched the deal. After months of negotiations with newspaper groups, Hollick and his chairman, Sir Ronnie Hampel, opted for speed and certainty.

Desmond first signalled his interest in the Express in a call to Andrew Neil, the former Sunday Times editor masterminding the Barclays' bid. Desmond put forward a simple deal. 'The Barclays want the Daily and Sunday Express . If they buy the two Expresses , what would you say to selling the Star ?' The Barclays liked the idea, but it fell through when Hollick rejected their £75m offer.

Four weeks ago, Desmond decided to go for broke and bid £125m for all three titles and the Express's printing plants. The assets include a valuable 50 per cent share in the Westferry printworks in London's Isle of Dogs which prints the Daily and Sunday Telegraph, the Guardian and The Observer, as well as the Express titles. 'He knew Hollick wanted a quick deal and gave him a quick deal,' one source said. Since Desmond had no newspaper interests, Hollick also knew there was no need for a lengthy Competition Commission inquiry.

Desmond, however, is nothing if not sharp. The Telegraph is now considering whether to trigger its pre-emption clause and buy out the Express's 50 per cent of Westferry. If it does, however, the amount the Telegraph will have to pay, plus the value of the Express' northern printing plant, underpins a large part of the £125m Desmond has shelled out.

Insiders reckon, however, that unless he is prepared to invest as much as £40m a year for at least five years he will fail to reverse the Express's historic decline. All three titles in the group are struggling to compete against better-financed rivals. The titles' combined editorial budget is £53m, of which £41m goes to the Express titles - less than half what the Daily Mail spends . Sales of the Mail are more than double those of the Daily Express .

So far, however, Desmond's business plan revolves around little more than boosting the Express through a tie-up with OK!.

The papers will gain second rights access to the magazine's exclusive photo shoot deals, such as those for the weddings of David and Victoria Beckham and Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta Jones. The Star will also benefit from tie-ins with Desmond's top-shelf titles.

Desmond has an easily accessible stable of models - still a staple of the paper.

Paul Ashford, editorial director of Northern & Shell, says: 'It will be our intention to keep the campaigning parts of the papers, and we want to take the celebrity coverage and give it more impact and greater exclusivity.'

Analysts have little doubt that Desmond can turn round the Star and make it a worthier adversary for the Sun . Northern & Shell executives have already praised the Star's success in attracting 'young, high-spending, fast- living males and their female counterparts'.

The paper has enjoyed mild success in the past year, stabilising circulation at around 500,000. Production costs on a paper largely filled with pictures are tiny. Small wonder that on the second floor of Ludgate House, the Star's home, staff cheered the OK! takeover.

There are question marks, however, over whether Northern & Shell, which has had to borrow heavily from Germany's Commerzbank to pay for the deal, has the resources for a long struggle. Northern & Shell Group, the holding company for OK! and the non-adult titles, reported profits of £1.8m last year, compared with a loss of £122,000 the previous year. The adult companies, which trade under the name Portland Investments, also made £1.8m profit last year

Then again, the Mail's owner made £223m and is capitalised at £3.5bn.

Northern & Shell magazines include:

Amateur Video
Asian Babes
Best of Fifty Plus
Best of Forty Plus
Best of Eros
Best of Forum
Best of Readers' Wives
Big and Black
Big Ones International
Contact Girls
Double Sex A
Electric Blue
Eros
Fifty and Over
For Men
Forty Plus
Forum
For Women
Horny Housewives
Mother-in-laws
New Talent
Nude Readers' Wives
Only 18
Private Lust
Readers' Wives
Red-hot Pack

These farcical scenes marked the climax of almost two months of horse-trading which has damaged the reputation of United News chief executive Clive Hollick, the New Labour peer, and plunged one of Britain's best-known newspapers into a surreal mix of relief and despair. 'People are amused, concerned and shell-shocked,' one senior Express executive said this weekend. 'There's a slight atmosphere of hysteria about the mad things already being done.' On Friday, for example, Express editor Rosie Boycott knew nothing about a change in the paper's masthead in between editions to run a colour plug for OK! , the most successful of Desmond's magazines. Staff were already finding newcomers occupying their desks. And from next week, a deluge of 50 OK! journalists will inject their mix of celebrity and gossip into the Daily and Sunday Express titles and their red-top stablemate, The Star . So far Boycott is biting her lip. With the ink barely dry on the contracts, the Express editor - a pin-up of the liberal establishment - met Desmond for a 'celebratory drink' on Wednesday afternoon. The boss of Northern & Shell, who has brought the nation 38 soft-porn magazines, including Asian Babes and Big Ones and Forty Plus, as well as the celebrity soft-soap rival to Hello!, is, like Boycott, teetotal. He toasted the deal in Coca-Cola; for her it was mineral water. 'I'm just relieved it is all over,' Boycott confided to a colleague. Few staffers, however, expect Boycott, co-founder of feminist magazine Spare Rib, to be there by Christmas. Over the past two years, under Boycott and with advice from Tony Blair's focus group guru Philip Gould, Hollick has transformed the Express ' s editorial line. Instead of challenging the Daily Mail on its own Tory turf, the Express began supporting New Labour. In the run-up to the next general election, the politics of the Express are once again up for grabs. But for now, most of the bile has been reserved for the Labour peer rather than the 'People's Pornographer'. 'He's behaved just like a right-wing shit,' one staffer said. 'It's a typically shabby performance,' said another. 'Hollick will go down in history as the first person to sell a national newspaper to a pornographer.' The Northern & Shell boss is aggressive, famously foul-mouthed and does not suffer fools gladly. He left school at 14 and started work as a cloakroom attendant at the Manor House pub in north London. In his early twenties, he set up a music magazine, pre-selling a whole six months' advertising at a Frankfurt music show. Desmond's big break came in 1982 when Northern & Shell gained the UK rights to Bob Guccione's Penthouse magazine. The soft porn stable flourished from there, along with Desmond's colourful reputation for bust-ups, serious minders and hounding enemies until, metaphorically speaking, they dropped. 'Richard was on the fund-raising committee of the local synagogue. They'd never heard anyone swear as much as him in front of the rabbi,' one close acquaintance said. 'But because it's Richard, no one takes much notice. You don't ever want to be on the wrong side of him, though.' The Penthouse tie-up was one to dissolve in acrimony a few years back. A failed venture with credit card entrepreneur David Elias - to sell soft porn magazines through petrol stations - wound Desmond up so much that he relentlessly pursued his former partner through the courts. Elias then lost his own business empire to a coup by disgraced Guinness chief Ernest Saunders. Ironically, former Express chairman Lord Stevens was yet another scalp. In 1993, Northern & Shell made a handsome £16m profit flogging Stevens several magazine titles to settle a legal action after the Express ended a distribution contract. Later Desmond was thwarted in trying to buy the Express itself, and the rancour towards Stevens remained. 'Richard can be ruthless,' one associate said. 'But he also gives a lot to charity and is a strong family man. At Northern & Shell Towers, which is stuffed full of minders, butlers serve tea in the Richard Desmond room, the Janet Desmond room [named after his wife] and the Robert Desmond room [his son]'. Now he finally has the titles, Desmond has lost little time in making changes. He has ordered staff to increase the print-run of the Daily Express by 200,000 from tomorrow. That is a refreshing change from the frightened Express executives who cut the run so harshly to save cash that many newsagents ran out of papers by midday. But Desmond quickly demonstrated his reputation as a ruthless cost-cutter himself. The Express's £30,000 annual newspaper bill was the first to go. From now on journalists will have to pop to the newsagent to see what rival papers are up to. 'Richard will boost circulation by bringing OK's broad appeal to the Express ,' one adviser said. 'Hollick has not paid full attention to cost-cutting. He's been soft, and Desmond is a hard man on costs.' The hard man, anti-intellectual approach will hardly endear Desmond to his editor. If nothing else, Boycott is a campaigner for high-profile causes. At the Independent on Sunday , she backed the decriminalisation of cannabis. At the Express , she has not been frightened to tell the often elderly and conservative-leaning readership that she believes in abortion on demand, that Britain's attitude to Third World poverty is shameful and that our immigration policies are cruel. Despite his initial charm offensive, Desmond is already understood to be seeking a new editor, more amenable to his line, from a red-top tabloid. His never-say-die drive and ambition have already given others pause for thought. Associated Newspapers, publisher of the Daily Mail, which had hoped to buy the Express , has most to lose. Mail bosses have already held a crisis meeting to discuss competing with Desmond, who also told Express staff in a memo on Thursday that he would 'spend what it takes' to restore the papers to 'their rightful position - number one in their respective markets'. To make matters worse for the Mail , Middle England's market leader, Desmond has identified 'new readers from among 18-34, intelligent independent-minded females' as his target market. 'If that's not our tanks on th e Mai l's lawn, they're blind as bats,' said a Desmond associate. The Mail , however, has a long history of seeing off rivals - and far deeper pockets than Desmond's. The Express , oddly for a company suffering from decades of mismanagement, under-investment and vanishing profits, attracted a scramble of eager buyers now licking their wounds. Besides Associated, they included the secretive Barclay brothers, owners of the Scotsman and Sunday Business ; India's equally secretive Hinduja brothers; Conrad Black's Daily Telegraph ; former Mirror boss David Montgomery; Harrod's chief Mohammed al-Fayed; and fellow porn baron David Sullivan. How did Desmond - a man with no experience of newspapers - put one over some of the shrewdest players in Fleet Street? In the end it was speed and cash that clinched the deal. After months of negotiations with newspaper groups, Hollick and his chairman, Sir Ronnie Hampel, opted for speed and certainty. Desmond first signalled his interest in the Express in a call to Andrew Neil, the former Sunday Times editor masterminding the Barclays' bid. Desmond put forward a simple deal. 'The Barclays want the Daily and Sunday Express . If they buy the two Expresses , what would you say to selling the Star ?' The Barclays liked the idea, but it fell through when Hollick rejected their £75m offer. Four weeks ago, Desmond decided to go for broke and bid £125m for all three titles and the Express's printing plants. The assets include a valuable 50 per cent share in the Westferry printworks in London's Isle of Dogs which prints the Daily and Sunday Telegraph, the Guardian and The Observer, as well as the Express titles. 'He knew Hollick wanted a quick deal and gave him a quick deal,' one source said. Since Desmond had no newspaper interests, Hollick also knew there was no need for a lengthy Competition Commission inquiry. Desmond, however, is nothing if not sharp. The Telegraph is now considering whether to trigger its pre-emption clause and buy out the Express's 50 per cent of Westferry. If it does, however, the amount the Telegraph will have to pay, plus the value of the Express' northern printing plant, underpins a large part of the £125m Desmond has shelled out. Insiders reckon, however, that unless he is prepared to invest as much as £40m a year for at least five years he will fail to reverse the Express's historic decline. All three titles in the group are struggling to compete against better-financed rivals. The titles' combined editorial budget is £53m, of which £41m goes to the Express titles - less than half what the Daily Mail spends . Sales of the Mail are more than double those of the Daily Express . So far, however, Desmond's business plan revolves around little more than boosting the Express through a tie-up with OK!. The papers will gain second rights access to the magazine's exclusive photo shoot deals, such as those for the weddings of David and Victoria Beckham and Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta Jones. The Star will also benefit from tie-ins with Desmond's top-shelf titles. Desmond has an easily accessible stable of models - still a staple of the paper. Paul Ashford, editorial director of Northern & Shell, says: 'It will be our intention to keep the campaigning parts of the papers, and we want to take the celebrity coverage and give it more impact and greater exclusivity.' Analysts have little doubt that Desmond can turn round the Star and make it a worthier adversary for the Sun . Northern & Shell executives have already praised the Star's success in attracting 'young, high-spending, fast- living males and their female counterparts'. The paper has enjoyed mild success in the past year, stabilising circulation at around 500,000. Production costs on a paper largely filled with pictures are tiny. Small wonder that on the second floor of Ludgate House, the Star's home, staff cheered the OK! takeover. There are question marks, however, over whether Northern & Shell, which has had to borrow heavily from Germany's Commerzbank to pay for the deal, has the resources for a long struggle. Northern & Shell Group, the holding company for OK! and the non-adult titles, reported profits of £1.8m last year, compared with a loss of £122,000 the previous year. The adult companies, which trade under the name Portland Investments, also made £1.8m profit last year Then again, the Mail's owner made £223m and is capitalised at £3.5bn. fields.headline: Express boss pulls float
fields.standfirst: Desmond abandons bid to cash in on porn empire
fields.trailText: Desmond abandons bid to cash in on porn empire
fields.body:
Soft porn magnate Richard Desmond has scrapped plans for a £500 million-plus flotation of his magazine empire after snapping up Express Newspapers last week.

The move comes as mid-market rival the Daily Mail prepares for a ferocious circulation war against the Express, to stop Desmond encroaching on its turf.

In a swift move, Desmond intends to parachute 50 staff from his best-selling OK! magazine into Express Newspapers to boost circulation and take the fight to the Mail.

The Mail's owner, Associated Newspapers, will however pour millions into testing the depth of Desmond's pockets in a clash that threatens to rival Fleet Street's bloodiest.

Thirteen years ago, Robert Maxwell closed his new London Daily News after only five months when Associated resurrected its defunct London Evening News at 5p a copy to protect its hugely profitable Evening Standard. Last year, Associated launched a free London newspaper, the Metro, to thwart Rupert Murdoch's plans for a free rival to the Standard .

This weekend, the Mail group declined to comment on its battle plans, which are understood to include aggressive promotions and greater editorial investment.

But Peter Williams, finance director of Associated's holding company, the Daily Mail & General Trust, said: 'We've always competed with the Express and will continue to compete with them. Complacency is not a word allowed here, and we don't intend to introduce it now.'

The City already fears the worst and has wiped £1 billion off DMGT's market value since Lord Hollick's United News & Media put the Express on the market two months ago.

Analyst Louise Barton at broker Investec Henderson Crosthwaite said: 'We're bearish about the Mail's profits. They'll set out to destroy the Express. It's that sort of company.'

The postponement of the flotation of Northern & Shell, Desmond's media empire, marks the second time, at least, that he has failed to cash in on his success. Sources close to him say the plans have been sidelined now by the need to get to grips with the Express . In the Eighties, a flotation with merchant bank BZW was scrapped because stuffy corporate financiers balked at sponsoring Desmond's stable of soft porn magazines. Since then, however, Desmond has launched the celebrity magazine OK!, as well as a string of other titles and Fantasy Channel on TV.

Last week, the publisher beat rivals including the Mail and Indian billionaires the Hinduja Brothers to win the Express for £125m. Desmond's advisers, however, declined to reveal how much he put up himself and how much was debt from his German backer, Commerzbank. The lack of clarity has led rivals to doubt whether he has deep enough pockets to match the Mail.

As Northern & Shell owns no other newspapers the deal faces no problems with the Competition Commission.

In 1990, however, rival soft porn baron David Sullivan was blocked from taking over the Bristol Evening Post . Regulators said the character and content of the Post would be affected, following Sullivan's previous involvement with the Daily Star.
