webTitle: He's got his newspapers. Now he needs a miracle

fields.headline: He's got his newspapers. Now he needs a miracle
fields.trailText: It's easy to be sniffy when downmarket magazine tycoons turn national newspaper proprietors. But Richard Desmond will probably need to be a twenty-first century Harmsworth to make sense of his Express delivery. By Peter Preston.
fields.body:
It's easy to be sniffy when downmarket magazine tycoons turn national newspaper proprietors. Remember how media society curled its lips as Alfred Harmsworth (of Answers) started the Daily Mail? But Richard Desmond will probably need to be a twenty-first century Harmsworth to make sense of his Express delivery.

What has he got for his £125million? A flagship daily still losing sales steadily - by 2 or 3 per cent every year - and selling only 900,000 or so when you strip out the bulks and cut-price deals: a Sunday partner in an even more parlous plight; and a sprauncy little red-top tabloid that wins praise for making much of scant resources, but with a half-million circulation heavily dependent on the North of England and even more dependent on 90,000 sales of one sort or another in Ireland.

There's nothing central to any of the titles' positioning here. They are - all of them - flat bottom of their particular markets, and the job of turning them round will take flair, patience and far more cash than the first £125m.

In business terms, it's hard to see the point of the purchase. Lord Hollick has offloaded the ex-United Three simply because their feeble profitability - barely a row of beans once the profit from the half-share in the Westferry printing plant is excluded - was a drag on his own share price.

There are doubtless property deals to be done: there always are when a new owner takes over. But Desmond - without other newspapers to his name - brings nothing obvious to the synergy table. Cost-cutting savings have been squeezed from the Express group for years. That cupboard is bare. It isn't deals the Expresses need, it's investment.

These are all marginal brands now, only a slip or two away from the big drop right off advertising schedules. And the figures, from an ad agency point of view, are unforgiving. Readership - on the latest NRS survey - can be made to look quite decent: 2.4 million a day, still a tad more than the Telegraph and more than the Times and Independent combined. But these aren't the comparisons that matter. The Daily Mail has 5.6 million readers - and its curve continues upwards; the Mail on Sunday (at 6 million) dwarfs the Sunday version of the Express (2.3 million).

Worse, Express readers, in spite of some gallant improvements under Rosie Boycott's editorship, are still too old, dying off by the year and making the business of gaining circulation over and above this natural decline even more daunting.

The Mail has 718,000 readers aged between 25 and 34, the Express only 283,000. The Mail, moreover, has almost unlimited resources. Now it can, and will, turn that panzer division of pounds sterling against Desmond - just as the Mirror and Sun (from still stronger circulation bunkers) can outspend the Star at every turn.

How does Desmond hope to take on these formidable battalions? So far - apart from his installation of a non-journalist editorial director to oversee the daily decision-making of the editors he inherits - the emphasis is all on joint bidding for the kind of celebrity picture exclusives he has used to build his OK! against Hello! To start, the Express gets photos from Catherine Zeta Jones's wedding.

Yet, quite apart from pushing the Mail and Hello! into a rival consortium, it's difficult to see how this particular synergy can make durable sense. OK! sells at £1.85 and the cash surge from 200,000 or so extra sales is formidable. Daily middle market or red-top papers can put on something approaching such sales for a day if there's something really juicy on offer - but next day that impact has gone. The key to Mail success has been a brand that can sustain itself and grow through the days when nobody in particular is getting married, giving birth or welcoming the cameras into her lovely home.

What Desmond has to do, in short, is to create a trio of all-round newspapers that attract readers every day of the week for what they are, not what they can occasionally offer on muddy newsprint rather than glossy mag sheets. To do that he will need editors committed to development over long years of hard pounding, with the freedom to give their papers an individual feel that may attract vital young readers, many of whom do not buy newspapers regularly but pick up the headlines from TV and flesh out their week by reading targeted magazines such as OK!

One long-term factor of Express decline, in short, has been the success of competitors like Desmond's own celebrity magazine: and the same, save for the Mail, could be said to be true across the tabloid market. These magazines and newspapers don't go together. They are natural competitors. Put them together and what have you got? A very messy balancing act. Who gets first pickings? Who wants to see their wedding on newsprint first?

Desmond may surprise us all with his answers.

fields.headline: Old Bank Hotel, Oxford
fields.trailText: A terrace of three properties, whose history can be traced back to the thirteenth century but most recently formed a branch of Barclays Bank, is now a modern hotel and restaurant.
fields.body:
The high life?
Yes. From an attic room the dreaming spires seem to float above Oxford. And the Old Bank is on the High, the street at the heart of the university city. A terrace of three properties, whose history can be traced back to the thirteenth century but most recently formed a branch of Barclays Bank, is now a modern hotel and restaurant.

High on style?
The rooms have a clean modern design with some classical trimmings. It seemed sinful to ruffle the linen bedcovers which are trimmed with velvet and silk. Best of all is the art collection in both public and private rooms. Owner Jeremy Mogford has bought up some big bold canvases, many from graduate shows. We would much rather have walked out with the wonderful Henrietta Dubrey canvas 'Tea on the Beach' than the soap from our room.

High table?
The banking hall has been transformed into the Quod bar and grill, a lively restaurant with an Italian influence. There are plenty of pasta and pizza main courses for under £7 but it would be a shame to miss the cocsca d'anitira (confit of duck with lentils and Swiss chard) at £8.95 or the monkfish and speck salad at £9.55. There were good wines at under £15 a bottle. You don't have to be a resident to enjoy the breakfast (good value at £5 for continental and £7.95 for cooked). It was a bit frantic on a busy Saturday night when the tables were squeezed close together but there can be few more inspiring places to linger over The Observer on a Sunday morning than at a window table overlooking All Souls.

High jinks?
Oxford has a youthful buzz that defies the snobbery and champagne image of the setting for Brideshead Revisited. There is some excellent shopping beyond the book-shops. But you must follow the splendid walking tour in the hotel's own booklet. Slip out the back down Magpie Lane between Merton and Oriel colleges to come out at the Meadows (the swans were having a grand time in the floods last month) and explore the oldest botanic gardens in Britain.

High prices?
The Old Bank is busy enough not to have to offer weekend rates. A double room costs from £155. Breakfast is extra.

· The Old Bank Hotel, 92-94 High Street, Oxford OX1 4BN (01865 799599), email: info@oldbank-hotel.co.uk or see www.oxford-hotels-restaurants.co.uk.

fields.headline: Yahoo! for brave French courts
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Free speech on the net
Net news
fields.trailText: The poor defenceless little multi-billion dollar company that was taken to court by French groups fighting anti-Semitism because it allows sales of Nazi memorabilia on its US (.com) website (though not on Yahoo.fr).
fields.body:
Anyone who doubts the ingenuity of French judges has never appeared before one. Ask Yahoo! - a poor defenceless little multi-billion dollar company that was taken to court by French groups fighting anti-Semitism because it allows sales of Nazi memorabilia on its US (.com) website (though not on Yahoo.fr).

The charge was that the company had violated French laws prohibiting the advertisement, exhibition or sale of any objects likely to incite racial hatred, and that it had offended the 'collective memory' of the country - an allusion to the Holocaust years - by allowing online auctions of Nazi paraphernalia.

In the court case last May, Yahoo's lawyers smiled indulgently and patiently explained to Judge Gomez in words of one syllable that the internet was a borderless phenomenon, that the laws of France could not possibly apply to a US company based in California and that in any event it was technically impossible to block French users from accessing the offending websites.

The judge, however, was neither intimidated nor impressed by this transatlantic guff. Nor, one suspects, did he take kindly to being patronised. Instead he handed down a verdict against Yahoo, but with a stay of execution until a panel of three established experts in internet technology, headed by Vint Cerf (one of the godfathers of TCP/IP, the protocols that still underpin the net), could advise him on whether it was indeed technically impossible for a US-based site to identify and exclude French surfers.

The experts duly deliberated and reported - with a perceptible uneasiness on Vint Cerf's part at least - that a filtering system based on inspecting the ISP addresses of site visitors and keywords used in searches could block 90 per cent of French users. The judge then confirmed his ruling, and gave Yahoo 90 days to comply, telling the company it would be fined $13,000 for every day thereafter that it was in breach of his order. It is not yet clear what Yahoo's response will be, though the company lawyers were making the ritual noises about appealing the verdict to a higher court.

There are some delicious ironies here, are there not? To those of us who have endured decades of cultural imperialism, in which American companies claim an apparently God-given right to impose their values on every territory they choose to occupy, US outrage at the French verdict raises, at best, hollow laughter. A society that thinks that the writ of its Digital Millennium Copyright Act should run worldwide is hardly in a position to be affronted by the temerity of a French judge's assertion that French law should prevail over an American company.

There was some huffing and puffing about how impotent the French courts would be if Yahoo decided to ignore Gomez's judgment. US legal experts seemed unanimous that Yahoo could not be extradited. (How, one wonders, would you extradite a server farm?) But the Jewish groups that brought the original court actions promised pressure to prosecute Yahoo's owners individually if the company does nothing about the Nazi memorabilia sales on its auction site.

Some optimists argued that Yahoo is effectively immune to legal pressure since it has no assets in France. But this falls at the first hurdle - a thriving website named www.yahoo.fr. And besides, the revelation last week that Yahoo has entered into a partnership with Minitel - France's pioneering but now antiquated online system - to provide email and other services to Minitel users, suggests the company does want to operate in France. So the smart money is on Yahoo swallowing its Californian pride and playing ball with the sainted MÒ Gomez. C'est magnifique!

Ask Yahoo! - a poor defenceless little multi-billion dollar company that was taken to court by French groups fighting anti-Semitism because it allows sales of Nazi memorabilia on its US (.com) website (though not on Yahoo.fr). The charge was that the company had violated French laws prohibiting the advertisement, exhibition or sale of any objects likely to incite racial hatred, and that it had offended the 'collective memory' of the country - an allusion to the Holocaust years - by allowing online auctions of Nazi paraphernalia. fields.headline: Pump up the volumes - part 2
fields.trailText: The critics' choice
fields.body:
Jilly Cooper

Anyone wanting an introduction to the lunacy, avarice and sexual merry-go-round of the New York contemporary art scene should read Danny Moynihan's marvellously funny and accomplished novel, Boogie Woogie (Duckworth). Having run galleries, curated and exhibited himself, Moynihan knows everything about bent dealers, pretentious collectors and thrusting young artists. All the characters are so awful that one ends up very fond of the less awful ones.

Katherine Whitehorn

I usually read paperbacks, so my books of the year are mostly last year's - and the best novel, The Homemaker by Dorothy Canfield Fisher, was resurrected from 1924 by Persephone Books. This is about a miserably obsessive housewife who is able to take a satisfying job only when her husband is crippled. However, I enjoyed The Pale Abyssinian (HarperCollins), Miles Bredin's witty biography of James Bruce, the preposterous Scot who discovered the source of the White Nile, and Yvonne Roberts 's gripping novel, A History of Insects (Headline) about residual snobbery in Pakistan after the Raj.

Paul Bailey

I found Victoria Clark's study of the Orthodox Church in Europe, Why Angels Fall (Macmillan), absolutely engrossing. The book provides insights into a Christian religion notably different from either Roman Catholicism or Protestantism. The novel that most impressed me was Alasdair MacLeod's No Great Mischief (Cape), a haunting family history set in the wilds of Canada and the Scottish Highlands. Lorna Sage's memoir of her nightmarish childhood, Bad Blood (Fourth Estate) is funny, moving, and wonderfully written. In The Million Dollar Mermaid by Esther Williams with Digby Diehl (Simon & Schuster), the aquatic film star says of her third husband, the relentlessly priapic Fernando Lamas, 'He talked about his penis as if it were a dear and talented friend, with excellent posture.' Thanks to Digby, Esther's autobiography is crammed with similar memorable conceits.

Jacqueline Rose

Both my books this year come from or return to South Africa. Gillian Slovo's Red Dust (Virago) transforms South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, with extraordinary skill, into an impossible-to-put-down detective story so that the reader is forced to enter the minds of all sides of the apartheid era, oppressor and victim alike. Marlene Van Neikerk's prize-winning Afrikaans novel Triomf (Little,Brown) rescues for South African literature the forgotten white trash of the country, while presenting its staggeringly dysfunctional, sometimes inspired, family in such uncompromising terms that Coetzee's Disgrace seems positively redemptive in comparison.

David Cannadine

Here are three books which should stimulate and divert the mind over the seasonal shutdown. Michael Howard's The Invention of Peace: Reflections on War and International Order (Profile) distils a lifetime's learning by our greatest military historian. John Simpson's A Mad World, My Masters: Tales from a Traveller's Life (Macmillan) is by turns hilarious and horrifying. And Simon Schama's A History of Britain: At the Edge of the World? 1,000 BC to AD 1603 (BBC) is a bravura performance by the Lord Macaulay of our day.

Paul Muldoon

One of the best books of poetry of the past year was Derek Mahon's Selected Poems (Penguin). Among numerous other distinctions, Mahon is the single most effective manager of the long stanza since Philip Larkin, as is clear from such anthology pieces as 'A Disused Shed in County Wexford' and 'A Garage in County Cork'.

Kathy Lette

John Mortimer is in his anecdotage and his autobiographical The Summer of a Dormouse (Viking), a mix of warmth, wit and wisdom is my book of the year. Whether ruminating on Napoleon's dick, the poor bastard who was jailed for sleeping with his own wife while wearing a beard, the Princess and the dipsomaniac Irish undertaker or the Swede caught spanking his wife with a live eel (and fined for cruelty to animals), the mischievous Mortimer weaves comedy and compassion into his prose.

Simon Callow

Tom Phillips's millennium project, The Postcard Century (Thames & Hudson) is an inexhaustibly fascinating account of private lives and public images over the past 100 years, as intimate and authentic an account of the experience of being alive at that time as we shall ever have. Thomas Wright's Oscar Wilde: Table Talk (Cassell) suggests more than anything else in print what it was like to hear the great man do what he did better than anyone: talk.

John Mortimer

A plot which involves two alleged Lord Lucans and a lady psychiatrist who faked the stigmata could only have gestated in the fertile brain of Muriel Spark. Aiding and Abetting (Viking) is written with the meticulous sparkle which makes her prose the envy of contemporary writers. We live at a time when we seem to be determined to cut ourselves off from our history, a fatal tendency that might be cured by Simon Schama's excitingly readable A History of Britain: At the Edge of the World? 1,000 BC to AD 1603 (BBC), full of kings and battles, puts an end to the fashionable idea that history should only be studied in the lives of medieval bakers or eighteenth-century piano tuners. Finally, the English obsession with verdant and manicured lawns is entertainingly weeded and watered in Tom Fort's The Grass is Greener: Our Love Affair with the Lawn (HarperCollins). It contains one of the best descriptions of a potting shed ever written.

Adam Mars-Jones

The novel and the book of stories I most enjoyed this year are both products of creative Indian summers: Philip Roth's The Human Stain (Cape) and Penelope Fitzgerald's The Means of Escape (Flamingo). Roth's novel addresses with subtlety the issues of sex, race, identity. Fitzgerald, whose death this year ends a brilliant literary career that began when she was 60, constantly brushes up against profundity without ever seeming to have designs on it. A striking debut collection of stories was Never Trust A Rabbit by Jeremy Dyson (Duckworth). His stories nestle in the little vacant chink between Roald Dahl and Borges. Jeremy Seabrook's Love in a Different Climate: Men Who Have Sex with Men in India (Verso) is illuminating - an attempt to describe taboo experience without imposing Western assumptions.

Stephen Bayley

I checked and I haven't actually read anything in the Amazon Hot 100. Not even The Thunderbirds Colouring Book, or David Beckham: My World. It's been a thin year for good books. Certainly, no fiction that sticks. I devoured Michael Lewis's The New New Thing: A Silicon Valley Story (Coronet), a pacy romp around the idiot-savant computer geek Jim Clark, but it's really just a long article, like so many US business books. Two late 1999 publications that have real value are James Campbell's This is the Beat Generation (Secker & Warburg) , an excellent popular history of Kerouac, Ginsberg and their dissolute company, and the re-issue by Books & Co/Helen Marx Books of Iris Origo's gloriously elegant 1953 life: Leopardi - A Study in Solitude. This last has a new introduction by Shirley Hazzard whose miniature Greene on Capri (Virago) was a small pleasure, full of fine observation and detail. But best of all has been City Secrets: Rome (The Little Bookroom) edited by Robert Kahn. This is a straightforward compilation of art, architecture and restaurant tips by people who really know the city: it's cruelly tempting, insightful and inspiring, as well as being nicely designed. The ordinary thing done extraordinary well: I'd never lend my copy, it's always in use.

Melvyn Bragg

The latest collection of Alan Jenkins's poems, The Drift (Chatto & Windus), is stunningly good. Full of passionate regret, clear, erudite, both a chronicle of the poet's time and a comment on it in poems as fine as any being written today. It is some sort of minor miracle that Michael Donaghy's masterly collection comes out in the same year as Jenkins. Conjure (Picador) contains poems which are as deeply structured, as lucid, moving and witty as Auden at his best. He brings powerful forces to bear on the memory of deep attachments and his vivid story-telling sense is a marvel. Adam Phillips's Promises, Promises: Essays on Psychoanalysis and Literature (Faber) is a brilliant collection of essays around the subjects in which disciplines Phillips excels.

Rowan Pelling

I have just started the book which I have waited patiently for all year - Philip Pullman's finale to his 'Dark Materials' trilogy, The Amber Spyglass. After only 20 pages I find myself spellbound by Pullman's storytelling. All my godchildren will receive the complete hardback set for Christmas.

Ian Hislop

Having been a judge in the recent Blue Peter Book Awards, I have read a lot more children's fiction this year than anything aimed at adults. This probably explains why most of the books have seemed so well-written and entertaining. Can I recommend The Shadow of the Minotaur by Alan Gibbons (Dolphin Paperback) and Pilgrim's Progress by Geraldine McCaughrean (Hodder)? You should probably find a child to give them to, but you could do a lot worse than read them yourself first.

Philip Hensher

The novels I liked best this year were Jane Smiley's grand, detailed Horse Heaven (Faber), one of those books which seems interested in absolutely everything, and Patrick McGrath's Martha Peake (Viking). He is a one-off; someone who has infused the tawdry old genre of the Gothic novel with a showy, enchanting intelligence. I simply could not put down John Drummond's entertainingly poisonous memoirs, Tainted By Experience (Faber). Graham Robb's life of Rimbaud (Picador) was unfailingly good; a calm, sceptical eye turned on a turbulent life. Helen Simpson's collection Hey Yeah Right Get A Life (Cape) was simply brilliant. Individual stories gave only a suggestion of the cumulative, terrifying force of the whole book. She has always been funny; with this, she displays herself a writer of unusual power.

fields.headline: Now is his future
fields.standfirst: In an 83-year odyssey, he has predicted satellite communications, man's landing on the moon and giant space stations circling the Earth. Now he just wants to make it to the big party in 2001
fields.trailText: In an 83-year odyssey, he has predicted satellite communications, man's landing on the moon and giant space stations circling the Earth. Now he just wants to make it to the big party in 2001
fields.body:
He made his fortune from seeing into the future, and his fame from getting it right. He's written more than 60 books, and sold more than 50 million copies of them. He's been nominated for both an Oscar and the Nobel Prize, and won countless other awards. The world's best selling science-fiction writer now has just one more ambition left. And he only has to wait a few more weeks till he achieves it.

Sir Arthur Charles Clarke has long nurtured the aspiration to see in the year that made him a household name: 2001. 'I want to exercise to keep my strength up so I can make it through the year 2001 - this is my real aspiration now,' he said in 1995. In three weeks he turns 83, and two weeks after that the world turns 2001.

He has good reason to want to see the year in. Confined to a wheelchair by post-polio syndrome, and having difficulty travelling from his technopolis compound in Sri Lanka, 2001 won't be a space odyssey for him, more an odyssey of the ego. For a man who impresses on his visitors his boundless but remarkably inoffensive love of adulation, next year will be almost an ante-chamber to heaven. Celebrations of the film and book 2001: A Space Odyssey, are set to explode across the planet.

The extravaganza is kicking off with a concert by Jean Michel Jarre on 31 December, followed by features in magazines from Forbes to Playboy, as well as video lectures, dedications and more awards. The Smithsonian Institute in Washington is holding a viewing of the film, while Warner are launching films of several others of his books. Debrett's have asked him to write the forward for that year's edition of People of Today.

In his house in the centre of Colombo, he describes his favourite room as his 'ego chamber', covered wall-to-wall in photos of him with the Pope, Prince Charles and Neil Armstrong; books dedicated to him not from VIPs but, he insists, VVIPs including Buzz Aldrin and Buckminster Fuller; and videos paying homage to him. In 2001, the whole world will become his 'ego chamber'.

The public excitement started last week when it was revealed that Sir Arthur is collaborating with the British computer entrepreneur Joseph de Saram, a 28-year-old who claims to be worth £4 billion but who is being pursued through the courts for debts of £1 million. With Clarke's backing, de Saram plans to launch the Clarke Ominputer, a mass-market reincarnation of the artificially intelligent HAL-9000 computer, the real star of the film.

The global adulation of Sir Arthur is a world away from his undistinguished origins in Minehead in Somerset, where he grew up on a farm, and his mother ran the local post office. His only memory of his father, who died when he was 13, was when they were riding a donkey cart, and Clarke elder passed young Arthur a cigarette card with a picture of a dinosaur on it, sparking his interest in science. An uncle who was an engineer gave him electrical fittings to play with, and when he wasn't attempting to fire rockets to the moon from his garden, Clarke spun stories for his friends at school.

When the war broke out, he volunteered to join the RAF, and worked with an American team on a top-secret radar project. It was while working on this that he made the prediction that established him as a visionary of remarkable foresight. Before there was anything global about communications, he wrote a paper suggesting that 'geo-stationary' satellites (in orbit above fixed points on the Earth's surface) could be used to bounce radio signals instantaneously around the world. His paper, 'Extra-Terrestrial Relays', published by the magazine Wireless World , earned him just £15 but launched an industry worth hundreds of billions.

After the war he attained a first in Maths and Physics from King's College in London, and in 1956 moved to Sri Lanka, enticed by the scuba-diving and warm climate. He spent many years relatively unknown, but churning out his visions of the future. 'I never thought I would be successful. Writing was always an enjoyable hobby,' he said recently.

Then one short story, and one collaboration, catapulted him into the premier league. He met Stanley Kubrick, the film director, in Trader Vic's bar in New York to talk about a project. Stanley told Clarke that he wanted to do 'the proverbial good science fiction movie'.

They decided to make 2001 after spotting a UFO from the roof of Kubrick's apartment. Staring at the bright full moon, they saw a light move up into the star-splattered night sky and stop above them. They checked the New York Times, which listed the movements of satellites, and there was nothing. 'Then, a little shame-facedly, we called the Pentagon, and they admitted that, yes, it had been a satellite. It seemed a good omen at the time.'

The film - provisionally entitled Journey Beyond the Stars - was based on his short story, The Sentinel. The director and the author co-wrote the screenplay, while Clarke simultaneously turned it into a full novel. Although the two remained friendly until Kubrick's death last year, it was a fractious working relationship, with Kubrick getting particularly frustrated. When asked about his screenwriter, Kubrick joked: 'Arthur Clarke? Isn't that some nut who lives up a tree in India?'

Clarke later retorted with a limerick:

'For MGM did Kubrick, Stan
A stately astrodome decree
While Art, the science writer, ran
Through plots incredible to man,
In search of solvency.'

The film, released in 1968, provoked a mixed reaction, but became an instant sci-fi classic. Its depiction of the HAL computer (each letter one place before IBM in the alphabet) sinisterly trying to kill off the crew of the spaceship, Discovery, and then pleading for its life has haunted more than just one generation. It prediction of man's contact with Jupiter became reality six years early when the probe Galileo started sending back pictures from the gaseous giant in 1995.

Clarke followed 2001 with a 2010: Odyssey Two, which was released as a film in 1982, and then 2061: Odyssey Three. Then a few years ago came 3001: A Final Odyssey. In that book he predicts the 'soul-catcher' micro-chip that can accommodate the essence of humanity, immortalising human life and down-loading it from computers at will.

Such predictions - he calls them extrapolations - would be easy to scoff at if Clarke hadn't been proved right so many times before. He predicted the moon landings to within a year, as well as the method of landing - having a mother ship circle the moon, sending a smaller pod down to the surface. He predicted vast space stations circling the earth decades before the International Space Station that is currently being assembled in orbit.

His personal life has been just as unconventional as his professional one, but far more mysterious. His only public relationship was a failed marriage in the 1950s that lasted less than a year and was finally dissolved in 1964. He is widely thought to be gay, although he has never publicly acknowledged it. When directly asked the question, he jests he is 'merely mildly cheerful'. The answer presumably lies in the many volumes of his journal, which are to be sealed until 30 years after his death, because there might be 'all sorts of embarrassing things in them'.

Clarke says he was severely hurt by allegations in the Sunday Mirror two years ago that he paid young boys for sex, which he vehemently denied. However, the controversy - which flared up just before a visit by Prince Charles to Sri Lanka - lead to a postponement of his knighthood, which he finally received earlier this year.

He lives in his compound - surrounded by TVs and computers - in an extended menage with his business partner, Hector Ekanayake, his wife, their three daughters and a one-eyed chihuahua called Pepsi. With a coterie of staff to answer to his every whim and need, he jokes that he is living the life of the 'imperialist running dog'.

Arthur Charles Clarke

Education: Huish's Grammar School, Taunton; King's College, London (first class honours, Physics and Mathematics)

Best known for: 2001: A Space Odyssey; foreseeing the geostationary satellite

Recreations: Diving, table-tennis

Lives at: Barnes Place, Colombo 7, Sri Lanka
fields.bodyText: He made his fortune from seeing into the future, and his fame from getting it right. He's written more than 60 books, and sold more than 50 million copies of them. He's been nominated for both an Oscar and the Nobel Prize, and won countless other awards. The world's best selling science-fiction writer now has just one more ambition left. And he only has to wait a few more weeks till he achieves it. Sir Arthur Charles Clarke has long nurtured the aspiration to see in the year that made him a household name: 2001. 'I want to exercise to keep my strength up so I can make it through the year 2001 - this is my real aspiration now,' he said in 1995. In three weeks he turns 83, and two weeks after that the world turns 2001. He has good reason to want to see the year in. Confined to a wheelchair by post-polio syndrome, and having difficulty travelling from his technopolis compound in Sri Lanka, 2001 won't be a space odyssey for him, more an odyssey of the ego. For a man who impresses on his visitors his boundless but remarkably inoffensive love of adulation, next year will be almost an ante-chamber to heaven. Celebrations of the film and book 2001: A Space Odyssey, are set to explode across the planet. The extravaganza is kicking off with a concert by Jean Michel Jarre on 31 December, followed by features in magazines from Forbes to Playboy, as well as video lectures, dedications and more awards. The Smithsonian Institute in Washington is holding a viewing of the film, while Warner are launching films of several others of his books. Debrett's have asked him to write the forward for that year's edition of People of Today. In his house in the centre of Colombo, he describes his favourite room as his 'ego chamber', covered wall-to-wall in photos of him with the Pope, Prince Charles and Neil Armstrong; books dedicated to him not from VIPs but, he insists, VVIPs including Buzz Aldrin and Buckminster Fuller; and videos paying homage to him. In 2001, the whole world will become his 'ego chamber'. The public excitement started last week when it was revealed that Sir Arthur is collaborating with the British computer entrepreneur Joseph de Saram, a 28-year-old who claims to be worth £4 billion but who is being pursued through the courts for debts of £1 million. With Clarke's backing, de Saram plans to launch the Clarke Ominputer, a mass-market reincarnation of the artificially intelligent HAL-9000 computer, the real star of the film. The global adulation of Sir Arthur is a world away from his undistinguished origins in Minehead in Somerset, where he grew up on a farm, and his mother ran the local post office. His only memory of his father, who died when he was 13, was when they were riding a donkey cart, and Clarke elder passed young Arthur a cigarette card with a picture of a dinosaur on it, sparking his interest in science. An uncle who was an engineer gave him electrical fittings to play with, and when he wasn't attempting to fire rockets to the moon from his garden, Clarke spun stories for his friends at school. When the war broke out, he volunteered to join the RAF, and worked with an American team on a top-secret radar project. It was while working on this that he made the prediction that established him as a visionary of remarkable foresight. Before there was anything global about communications, he wrote a paper suggesting that 'geo-stationary' satellites (in orbit above fixed points on the Earth's surface) could be used to bounce radio signals instantaneously around the world. His paper, 'Extra-Terrestrial Relays', published by the magazine Wireless World , earned him just £15 but launched an industry worth hundreds of billions. After the war he attained a first in Maths and Physics from King's College in London, and in 1956 moved to Sri Lanka, enticed by the scuba-diving and warm climate. He spent many years relatively unknown, but churning out his visions of the future. 'I never thought I would be successful. Writing was always an enjoyable hobby,' he said recently. Then one short story, and one collaboration, catapulted him into the premier league. He met Stanley Kubrick, the film director, in Trader Vic's bar in New York to talk about a project. Stanley told Clarke that he wanted to do 'the proverbial good science fiction movie'. They decided to make 2001 after spotting a UFO from the roof of Kubrick's apartment. Staring at the bright full moon, they saw a light move up into the star-splattered night sky and stop above them. They checked the New York Times, which listed the movements of satellites, and there was nothing. 'Then, a little shame-facedly, we called the Pentagon, and they admitted that, yes, it had been a satellite. It seemed a good omen at the time.' The film - provisionally entitled Journey Beyond the Stars - was based on his short story, The Sentinel. The director and the author co-wrote the screenplay, while Clarke simultaneously turned it into a full novel. Although the two remained friendly until Kubrick's death last year, it was a fractious working relationship, with Kubrick getting particularly frustrated. When asked about his screenwriter, Kubrick joked: 'Arthur Clarke? Isn't that some nut who lives up a tree in India?' Clarke later retorted with a limerick: 'For MGM did Kubrick, Stan A stately astrodome decree While Art, the science writer, ran Through plots incredible to man, In search of solvency.' The film, released in 1968, provoked a mixed reaction, but became an instant sci-fi classic. Its depiction of the HAL computer (each letter one place before IBM in the alphabet) sinisterly trying to kill off the crew of the spaceship, Discovery, and then pleading for its life has haunted more than just one generation. It prediction of man's contact with Jupiter became reality six years early when the probe Galileo started sending back pictures from the gaseous giant in 1995. Clarke followed 2001 with a 2010: Odyssey Two, which was released as a film in 1982, and then 2061: Odyssey Three. Then a few years ago came 3001: A Final Odyssey. In that book he predicts the 'soul-catcher' micro-chip that can accommodate the essence of humanity, immortalising human life and down-loading it from computers at will. Such predictions - he calls them extrapolations - would be easy to scoff at if Clarke hadn't been proved right so many times before. He predicted the moon landings to within a year, as well as the method of landing - having a mother ship circle the moon, sending a smaller pod down to the surface. He predicted vast space stations circling the earth decades before the International Space Station that is currently being assembled in orbit. His personal life has been just as unconventional as his professional one, but far more mysterious. His only public relationship was a failed marriage in the 1950s that lasted less than a year and was finally dissolved in 1964. He is widely thought to be gay, although he has never publicly acknowledged it. When directly asked the question, he jests he is 'merely mildly cheerful'. The answer presumably lies in the many volumes of his journal, which are to be sealed until 30 years after his death, because there might be 'all sorts of embarrassing things in them'. Clarke says he was severely hurt by allegations in the Sunday Mirror two years ago that he paid young boys for sex, which he vehemently denied. However, the controversy - which flared up just before a visit by Prince Charles to Sri Lanka - lead to a postponement of his knighthood, which he finally received earlier this year. He lives in his compound - surrounded by TVs and computers - in an extended menage with his business partner, Hector Ekanayake, his wife, their three daughters and a one-eyed chihuahua called Pepsi. With a coterie of staff to answer to his every whim and need, he jokes that he is living the life of the 'imperialist running dog'. He has had an operation for prostate cancer, his frame is collapsing, and he must rest for hours every afternoon. Above all, there's one prediction that he must wish will come true quicker than others: that of immortality. But even if it doesn't, he's still set to fulfil his ambition of seeing in 2001. fields.headline: Dessert storm
fields.standfirst: The world's sweet wines have a battle on their hands with Tokaj's affordable whites
fields.trailText: The world's sweet wines have a battle on their hands with Tokaj's affordable whites.
fields.body:
I've never envied the grape picker's lot. The image of bucolic bonhomie is invariably betrayed by the boring, spine-twisting reality. Harvesting is a tough job wherever you do it, but in Tokaj, isolated on Hungary's north-eastern border with Slovakia, it's doubly so. Whereas most vineyard workers pick bunches of grapes, they pick individual berries, their faces muffled against the autumn chill. The task requires expertise and a light touch, which is probably why men are so bad at it.

These pickers perform an essential task, removing shrivelled, botrytis-affected, sugar-rich aszú berries from bunches of late-season grapes. Without aszú, Tokaj would make drinkable but essentially forgettable dry whites from Furmint and Hárslevelü grapes. With them, it is arguably the greatest sweet-wine area in the world. The problem for Tokaj is that great aszú years are rarer than victories by the England football squad. In the last decade, only 1993, 1999 and 2000 would qualify. The rest of the time, the region is stuck with a product (its dry wines) that are hard to sell. No wonder so many growers are selling or abandoning their vineyards.

Tokaj has a distinguished heritage stretching back to the 13th century. Over the years, this pretty, gently sloping region has seduced everyone from Schubert to Catherine the Great. And yet just a decade ago, the place was heading for the historical slagheap. Forty years of Communist rule turned Tokaj into an also-ran. A few good wines were produced, but the state monopoly betrayed the region's inheritance with cold insouciance. Most of Tokaj's wines ended up in the Soviet Union, exchanged for oil. In some cases, it was hard to tell which was the more drinkable.

Things picked up in the early 1990s, when a new government decided to sell off some of the region's best vineyards to foreign investors from England, France, Spain, Italy, Japan and the United States. The outsiders were resented in Tokaj, but they have begun to resurrect its reputation. Companies such as Disznókö, Oremus, Chteau Pajzos and Hétszölö have brought new ideas and techniques to the area, replanting great vineyard sites and building new cellars.

In the process, they are changing the style of Tokaj's sweet wines, making them fresher, racier and less oxidised, often with an oaky undertone. To traditionalists, this is a sacrilege; to the modernisers it is essential progress. At the moment, the latter group appears to be winning the argument, although the official tasting committee in Budapest (a remnant of the days of five-year plans) still rejects modern wines from time to time as 'inauthentic'.

Not everyone makes modern wines. Nor is it true that these are necessarily superior to the old-fashioned stuff. István Szespi, the region's star producer, makes two styles to cater to different tastes. 'We weren't allowed to experiment in Tokaj for 40 years, so what's wrong with trying new things? There are several ways to make great Tokaji.'

There are also several ways to drink it. Tokaj produces not one, but many different styles of wine, from dry Furmint to thick, treacly Essencia. In between, it makes medium dry Szamarodni and, in ascending order of sweetness, Late Harvest and 3, 4, 5 and 6 Puttonyos wines. The ideal Tokaj, for this taster at least, is a 5 Puttonyos which has enough sweetness to balance pronounced levels of acidity, and vice versa.

Tokaj wines are not cheap by the standards of Muscat de Beaumes de Venise or Monbazillac. But when you set them against the world's great dessert wines - against Sauternes, Coteaux du Layon, Vin Santo and German and Austrian Trockenbeerenauslesen - they don't seem so expensive after all. Especially when you remember the poor sods who have to pick the grapes.

Best cellars: Hungary's sweetest pudding wines

1996 Noble Late Harvest Sweet, Oremus (from £7.20 per 50cl, The Oxford Wine Company 01865 301144; Noel Young Wines, 01223 844 744; Morris & Verdin, 020 7722 5577).
Made from late-picked rather than aszú berries, this is medium sweet with notes of honey and citrus fruit.

1993 Berry's Tokaji Aszú, 4 Puttonyos, Royal Tokaji (£13.95 per 50cl; £7.95 per 25cl, Berry Brothers & Rudd, 0870 900 4301).
A crossover style between the modern and traditional camps, showing the burnt-sugar characters of the former allied to the raciness of the latter.

1993 Tokaji Aszú 5 Puttonyos, Disznókö (£15.99 per 50cl, Oddbins Fine Wine).
A lovely, modern style Tokaj from an exemplary French-owned operation. The wine's tarte-tatin characters are balanced by vibrant acidity, orange-peel freshness and subtle oak.

1996 Tokaji 6 Puttonyos, Szepsi (£42 per 50cl, Cambridge Wine Merchants, 01223 568 989).
Almost a second-mortgage job, but it's worth the money. A peachy, ultra-rich, ultra-sweet, massively concentrated wine made in a traditional style. Silky, textured stuff.

fields.headline: Beautiful game
fields.standfirst: When you're chilled to the bone, nothing gives a home advantage like a hearty winter stew
fields.trailText: When you're chilled to the bone, nothing gives a home advantage like a hearty winter stew
fields.body:
The cast-iron casserole has come out early this year. An attempt to bring bonhomie to a cold and soggy autumn. Soaked through and scratched pink from playing in the garden, I am in need of food with a backbone. (The 80 wallflowers are now planted, but I am unsure if I will ever again stand up straight.) Typical autumn roasts of neat but diminutive birds don't warm your marrow after digging a trench and 'heeling in' a dozen bushes in the rain. Only meat with a hearty slop of onions and wine will do that.

A summer that never got going and an autumn that turned instantly to slime have brought an urgency to sniffing out recipes to comfort and nourish. Never before has my cooking been so butch, so early. As I said, food with a backbone, and by that I don't mean a neck of lamb or clod of beef, but a backbone of aromatics. It is the sweet onions, knobbly roots and tough herbs that provide the flavour base - the skeleton, if you like - with the body coming from the meat and cooking liquor.

The knee-jerk reaction is to chop up a hotch-potch of carrot, onion and celery, and to ask the butcher for a bit of stewing beef, but I think it can be more interesting than that. Game birds - light meat, high flavours and some bones to impart goodness - seem more appropriate while there are a few golden leaves left clinging to the trees.

We add carrots to a casserole for the sweetness they impart. But there is no reason why we cannot use parsnips or swedes instead - both have enough sugar to caramelise at the edges as we sweat them in fat at the start of cooking. What a cold, wet family is looking for is a deep-seated, earthy sweetness that can only come from roots.

If cold-weather food is to be satisfying, it needs that earthy note. Without thinking, I would reach for the celery, for its faintly bitter, mineral notes, but there is no reason why celeriac, the celery's root, couldn't be given an outing. Better that than letting the creamy globe wither in the vegetable rack, its fate in my kitchen more often than I would care to admit. What about chard? This up-and-coming vegetable has an earthiness even stalwart celery cannot approach.

Little things matter even in the murky depths of a casserole. Bay leaves, even one or two, contribute more than you expect as you blow the dust off them. Twigs of thyme look unprepossessing as they hang from the ceiling, but a slow stewing will tease out their goodness. That doesn't mean we should chuck stuff at the pot willy nilly. Each addition should be thought out. A few blue-black juniper berries with a pigeon, or some woodsy mushrooms with a pheasant.

Rowley Leigh of Kensington Place in London's Notting Hill adds chocolate to his game casserole. It makes sense - he calls its effect dry, smoky and slightly bitter, which seems perfect for warming the soul. He served it at the launch party for his new book No Place Like Home (£25, Fourth Estate), atop a mound of rib-sticking white polenta. (Just as well he did, too, bravely throwing his bash in a marquee on a rainy night in Shepherd's Bush.) His book, quietly perfect in every way, is currently bringing great joy to my kitchen, with its understated and thoughtful recipes, its handsome illustrations made even stronger by a free-thinking and original design.

The syrupy sensuousness of the gravy can only really work if you involve a bone or two. The texture of the sauce will depend somewhat on how much collagen is present in the carcass. In the case of game birds, this is not a lot, but you will still get a more interesting result than if you miss them out altogether. Purists will no doubt throw one of their little tiffs but I see no reason why you cannot tuck a few chicken wings into the pot with the game to add their sticky glue and give the whole thing more body.

Whether you fine-tune your casserole with chocolate, redcurrant jelly, juniper or coriander, the point here is the chemistry that results from cooking roots, alliums, herbs and meat together at a low setting. A recipe that slowly, surely warms us from the feet up. Which reminds me: somewhere, out there in the mud, is my left shoe.

A simple game casserole

Some mashed parsnip, celeriac and potato, or swede is quite wonderful with this. Serves 4.

Cut a couple of pheasants into four and brown them nicely on all sides in a little groundnut oil in a casserole. Lift them out and, adding more oil if needs be, brown two large chopped onions, a few carrots and stalk or two of celery. You want the vegetables to be tender and lightly browned here and there. Add about 300g mushrooms cut into chunks, let them brown in the pan, then sprinkle over a scant tablespoon or so of flour, stirring it as it colours and binds the vegetables together.

Return the pheasant to the pan, pour over a bottle of red wine - I suggest a Rioja or some other such rich red - and bring slowly to the boil. Turn down the heat immediately, add a bunch of thyme and a couple of bay leaves, a strip of orange peel or whatever else seems appropriate, then cover with a lid and put in the oven at 180 C/gas mark 5 till the meat is tender (about an hour). Check for seasoning - it will need salt, black pepper and maybe a little redcurrant jelly - then serve with the mashed roots.

Rowley Leigh's venison stew with chestnuts and chocolate

A truly warming casserole for a dozen people. Serve with polenta. Serves 12.

3kg stewing venison, shoulder, neck or haunch

1 cup olive oil

2 dessertspoons plain flour

500g button onions

150g unsalted butter

1 dessertspoon sugar

250g peeled chestnuts

15-25g extra-bitter chocolate

1 lemon

for the marinade

3 large carrots

3 onions

3 sticks of celery

6 cloves of garlic

1 red chilli

6 juniper berries

20 black peppercorns

4 cloves

2 bay leaves

a large sprig of thyme

2 large strips of lemon zest

1 cup of red wine vinegar

2 bottles of red wine

cup olive oil

Trim the meat and cut it into large, walnut-sized cubes. For the marinade, peel the carrots and onions and cut them, with the celery, into 1cm cubes. Separate the garlic cloves (do not peel), seed and coarsely slice the chilli and put all the ingredients into a large bowl with the meat, finishing with a film of the oil. Cover and marinate overnight in the fridge.

The next day, pour the marinade into a colander placed over a bowl. Lift out the meat and dry it on kitchen paper. Season with sea salt and then brown it in the olive oil in a frying pan, in batches, transferring it to a large, ovenproof casserole as each batch is done. When all the meat has been well browned, fry the vegetables from the marinade in the same pan. When they are nicely coloured, sprinkle over the flour and cook for a minute or two until it also lightly browned. Pour over the liquid from the marinade and scrape up the residue from the base of the pan with a wooden spoon. As soon as the marinade comes to the boil, pour it over the meat in the casserole. Add a little water if the meat is not covered, put it on the stove and bring back to the boil, skimming well to remove any grease that surfaces. Place the casserole in an oven preheated to 170 C/gas mark 3 for 2 hours, until the meat is intact but quite tender. Leave to cool for 20 minutes.

Soak the button onions in warm water for 20 minutes and then peel them. Melt 50g of the butter in a frying pan or sauté pan and add the onions. Let them colour gently on all sides before adding the sugar. Let this caramelise a little, then pour in just enough water to cover the onions. Cover with a butter paper and cook for 15 minutes or until the onions are tender and the liquid has evaporated.

Put the peeled chestnuts in a saucepan with 50g of the butter and enough cold water to cover. Stew very gently for 30 minutes, until soft.

Drain the stew in a colander over a bowl. Lift out all the pieces of meat and put them back in the casserole. Strain the liquid through a fine sieve back over the meat, squeezing through every drop of juice but discarding the vegetables. Add the onions and chestnuts to the stew. Bring it very gently back to a simmer and cook equally gently for five minutes so the flavours meld. Finely grate the chocolate and whisk in, a teaspoon at a time, so it melts into the stew. Proceed cautiously, tasting, adding a little chocolate, a knob of the remaining butter, a squeeze of lemon juice and a pinch of salt. Do not let the chocolate boil. The minute you think you can taste the chocolate, stop immediately and correct with a little more lemon juice. When you are content with the seasoning and balance, serve forthwith.

Visit www.nigelslater.co.uk for a week's worth of recipes.

A simple game casserole Some mashed parsnip, celeriac and potato, or swede is quite wonderful with this. Serves 4. Cut a couple of pheasants into four and brown them nicely on all sides in a little groundnut oil in a casserole. Lift them out and, adding more oil if needs be, brown two large chopped onions, a few carrots and stalk or two of celery. You want the vegetables to be tender and lightly browned here and there. Add about 300g mushrooms cut into chunks, let them brown in the pan, then sprinkle over a scant tablespoon or so of flour, stirring it as it colours and binds the vegetables together. Return the pheasant to the pan, pour over a bottle of red wine - I suggest a Rioja or some other such rich red - and bring slowly to the boil. Turn down the heat immediately, add a bunch of thyme and a couple of bay leaves, a strip of orange peel or whatever else seems appropriate, then cover with a lid and put in the oven at 180 C/gas mark 5 till the meat is tender (about an hour). Check for seasoning - it will need salt, black pepper and maybe a little redcurrant jelly - then serve with the mashed roots. Rowley Leigh's venison stew with chestnuts and chocolate A truly warming casserole for a dozen people. Serve with polenta. Serves 12. 3kg stewing venison, shoulder, neck or haunch 1 cup olive oil 2 dessertspoons plain flour 500g button onions 150g unsalted butter 1 dessertspoon sugar 250g peeled chestnuts 15-25g extra-bitter chocolate 1 lemon for the marinade 3 large carrots 3 onions 3 sticks of celery 6 cloves of garlic 1 red chilli 6 juniper berries 20 black peppercorns 4 cloves 2 bay leaves a large sprig of thyme 2 large strips of lemon zest 1 cup of red wine vinegar 2 bottles of red wine cup olive oil Trim the meat and cut it into large, walnut-sized cubes. For the marinade, peel the carrots and onions and cut them, with the celery, into 1cm cubes. Separate the garlic cloves (do not peel), seed and coarsely slice the chilli and put all the ingredients into a large bowl with the meat, finishing with a film of the oil. Cover and marinate overnight in the fridge. The next day, pour the marinade into a colander placed over a bowl. Lift out the meat and dry it on kitchen paper. Season with sea salt and then brown it in the olive oil in a frying pan, in batches, transferring it to a large, ovenproof casserole as each batch is done. When all the meat has been well browned, fry the vegetables from the marinade in the same pan. When they are nicely coloured, sprinkle over the flour and cook for a minute or two until it also lightly browned. Pour over the liquid from the marinade and scrape up the residue from the base of the pan with a wooden spoon. As soon as the marinade comes to the boil, pour it over the meat in the casserole. Add a little water if the meat is not covered, put it on the stove and bring back to the boil, skimming well to remove any grease that surfaces. Place the casserole in an oven preheated to 170 C/gas mark 3 for 2 hours, until the meat is intact but quite tender. Leave to cool for 20 minutes. Soak the button onions in warm water for 20 minutes and then peel them. Melt 50g of the butter in a frying pan or sauté pan and add the onions. Let them colour gently on all sides before adding the sugar. Let this caramelise a little, then pour in just enough water to cover the onions. Cover with a butter paper and cook for 15 minutes or until the onions are tender and the liquid has evaporated. Put the peeled chestnuts in a saucepan with 50g of the butter and enough cold water to cover. Stew very gently for 30 minutes, until soft. Drain the stew in a colander over a bowl. Lift out all the pieces of meat and put them back in the casserole. Strain the liquid through a fine sieve back over the meat, squeezing through every drop of juice but discarding the vegetables. Add the onions and chestnuts to the stew. Bring it very gently back to a simmer and cook equally gently for five minutes so the flavours meld. Finely grate the chocolate and whisk in, a teaspoon at a time, so it melts into the stew. Proceed cautiously, tasting, adding a little chocolate, a knob of the remaining butter, a squeeze of lemon juice and a pinch of salt. Do not let the chocolate boil. The minute you think you can taste the chocolate, stop immediately and correct with a little more lemon juice. When you are content with the seasoning and balance, serve forthwith. Visit www.nigelslater.co.uk for a week's worth of recipes.

fields.headline: Clove hitch
fields.standfirst: His mother viewed garlic as a symbol of suspect food, low morals and over-sexed continentals... small wonder Monty loves it
fields.trailText: His mother viewed garlic as a symbol of suspect food, low morals and over-sexed continentals... small wonder Monty loves it.
fields.body:
I normally write these pages in a set order. First the main piece - you would be amazed at how long that takes me. Lots of research, pencil sucking and displacement activity. Then I do whatever is in the Your Roots section as a piece of social duty and, lastly, with the friskiness of a lamb on a trampoline, I romp home with My Roots.

But this week the lines have got blurred. Prompted by guilt at not having finished this piece by Friday night and by the first clear day for weeks and weeks, yesterday I planted our garlic. I was, by chance, doing it on the 11th hour of the 11th day of this month and stood quietly for a couple of minutes, fist full of garlic and mud, thinking about Edward Thomas and the chalk that runs undersea from Steep to the battlefields of northern France. No chalk here. I had dug over the ground a couple of days before, lifting Florence fennel (mostly bolted) and sweetcorn (astonishing crop), the roots doing an amazingly effective job of sucking up moisture and keeping the otherwise sodden ground dry enough to work.

Sharp sand had been added to one of the squares a couple of years ago to encourage better carrots out of the heavy soil, and a huge amount of cattle manure added to the other. The sanded soil was still noticeably lighter and free-draining, while the manured plot - which was made horribly sticky for a full year after manuring, had developed a crumbly, suety texture. I added mushroom compost to both, rotovated and raked them over. Then it rained all night.

Normally, I would have left it to dry out, but because of this article and sunshine the garlic went in nevertheless. Some people recommend dibbing a hole for each clove, but I find that too laborious. Instead, I push them in as far as my fingers will reach into the sticky earth. Nowadays, however dry the ground, I always work off a length of scaffolding plank cut to the size of the bed and use it both to stand on, so as to avoid compacting the carefully prepared soil, and as a marker for planting.

As for the spacing between individual cloves, I always go by eye, working out at about 8in per plant. For the first time ever, I used last summer's crop for seed, selecting bulbs as fat as possible and sitting in the November sunshine breaking them open, big cloves in one basket, small ones in another. As a rule, the bigger the seed clove the bigger the garlic bulb it will produce. I use only the Spanish Moraluz, which grows well for us and, perhaps more importantly, seems to keep very well. At the end, I was left with two bare pieces of ground dotted with rows of tiny holes. But it was good magic for an hour or two.

Garlic has always had a powerful magic. Ancient everybody, from Egyptians to first-century Hindu doctors used it to keep their insides clean, cure heart disease and ward off terrors in the night. I have grown huge amounts of it over the past few years. Actually, the scale of this year's harvest was a mistake. When we ordered our seed garlic last October, somehow our estimate of the cloves we needed got translated into an order for the same quantity of bulbs. I had been generous, anyway, so the seed delivery arrived like the weekly supplies to a Mediterranean supermarket. But it is an ill wind and I had just read in Eliot Coleman's wonderful The New Organic Grower (£19.95, Chelsea Green Publishing) that he uses garlic as a cleansing crop that improves the subsequent quality of brassicas grown in the same ground. I had just cleared two long beds of pumpkins and squashes, so I filled both of them with garlic. I got them in at the end of November, their names reading like the race card for the 3.30 at Sandown; Cledar, Moraluz, Printnor and Sultop.

The reason for sowing garlic in autumn is to let the roots develop before the cold weather sets in. Once the roots have established, and the tops have appeared like green wisps of flame above the ground, they need a month with the temperature below 10 C, otherwise they tend to develop into one small bulb without dividing into cloves. Sometimes this happens erratically within the same crop. The best thing is to keep the 'rounds', as they are called, and use them as seed for next year. As with all onions, they need to be kept weed free and watered while growing, and they like well-drained but moderately rich ground - so I always add mushroom compost just before planting. If any of the plants develop seed-heads, simply cut them off as they appear.

Garlic needs to be harvested as soon as it is ready, otherwise the bulbs start to shrivel and their storing capacity reduces. Leave them in the ground until the leaves have yellowed, then dig them up, preferably on a clear, sunny day so that they can be left on the ground to dry. Failing that, bring them in to a dry, well-ventilated place and let them dry for a few weeks, leaves and all. This is when their storage capacity is established. Not all garlic, however, is able to store for long. Any trace of dampness will almost inevitably induce rotting and fungal trouble. We always cut the leaves off ours when they are dried.

Fresh garlic straight from the ground is wonderful, with its sheath of leaf covering the whole bulb and the cloves as shiny and white as an unripe conker. We start lifting it from the end of May when it is mild enough to eat raw. I saw the rerun of Alan Bennett's wonderful play An Englishman Abroad the other day and particularly enjoyed the scene where the Burgess character served a lunch of a raw tomato and proceeded to wedge cloves of garlic into each quarter, which he then ate with gusto. I remember reading somewhere that Burgess used to munch raw garlic - which should have immediately told his masters that beneath that Etonian breast beat the treacherous heart of Johnny Foreigner. I rather like raw garlic, too, and were it not for the tiny relics of a social life that I do have, I'd munch it the more. I don't mind the smell in other people, any more than I mind someone smelling of bonfires or box bushes. But I know that for some people garlic never just smells, it stinks.

I don't remember garlic being grown in the garden of my childhood, although we grew all the other edible members of the allium family: onions, shallotts, leeks and chives. My mother and most of her pre-Elizabeth David generation would have viewed a garlic bulb with about the same degree of suspicion as a vampire out on the midnight razzle, it being the archetypal symbol of suspect food, low morals and over-sexed continentals. And if that isn't proof positive that you should plant some, then you are on the side of the vampires.

My roots: A week in Monty's garden

I've done garlic already, so that has cut my news down by half. While it has surprised me how relatively unsodden the cultivated ground has been, the grass paths are a joke. Just walking around has compacted them sufficiently to reduce drainage to the speed of flowing bitumen. Now we don't just need wellies to walk to the end of the garden but special trousers, too.

We extended the land drains by digging another overflow soakaway because the existing land drain soakaway has given up soaking. This meant another very handsome trench and hole. I seriously find holes in the ground exciting and beautiful.

Outside the propagating greenhouse we have masses of plants in pots standing out through unplanted herbaceous plants, and dozens of lilies in terracotta pots. The other morning I thought it was time to rescue them from the pool of water that they have been sitting in for the past month and I moved the lot, cleared out the cold frames, cleaned everything up and put what would fit in the frames and raised the rest out of the flood.

We have dozens of plants in square 9cm pots and they were all in moulded plastic trays. Very handy, too. But when I lifted them up I found snails clustered in the interstices like bunches of grapes. Hundreds of the things. So the trays have been abandoned and everything has to be moved singly, which is a pain but highlights that one of the best ways of dealing with snails is to deny them dark, dry hiding places.

I went to the Organic Food awards lunch the other week and heard a disturbing story from a fellow guest. She had been taken on a tour of Wisley and was shocked to see that only a tiny section of the vegetable garden was organic, although the staff selling plants told her that most customers assumed all the plants for sale were grown organically.

When she raised the lack of interest in organics with her RHS hosts they responded blankly, unable to comprehend the issue. I know that at Chelsea, organic growers have been openly discriminated against in the past. It amazes me that the best-known garden body in this country is so out of touch and out of sympathy with the general gardening trend and interest towards organic gardening, and it is time that they crept into the 21st century and championed holistic, organic horticulture.

Your roots: How to grow your own garlic

It is getting quite late to order garlic, but here are some places you could try:

 Simpson's Seeds, 27 Meadowbrook, Old Oxted, Surrey RH8 9LT (tel/fax 01883 715 242).

 The Organic Gardening Catalogue, Riverdene Business Park, Moseley Road, Hersham, Surrey KT12 4RG (01932 253 666, fax 01932 252 707, www.organiccatalog.com).

 Edwin Tucker & Sons, Brewery Meadow, Stonepark, Ashburton, Newton Abbot, Devon TQ13 7DG (01364 652 403, fax 01364 654 300).

As a workable last resort you can buy a healthy bulb from a greengrocer or supermarket and use the biggest cloves from that for seed.

Garlic can be easily grown in containers. Add plenty of drainage material to potting compost and put in a sunny place. A weekly feed with dilute seedweed from March onwards would not do any harm.

Garlic is said to be greatly beneficial to tomato plants if they are grown together. It also has a reputation for keeping greenfly away from roses if a clove is planted by each shrub.
