fields.headline: Toy story
fields.standfirst: Time was when all a kid wanted for Christmas was a Dinky car or a Sindy doll. But that was before the days of hi-tech toys, movie tie-ins and 'toy rage' riots. Welcome to Christmas present...
fields.trailText: Time was when all a kid wanted for Christmas was a Dinky car or a Sindy doll. But that was before the days of hi-tech toys, movie tie-ins and 'toy rage' riots. Welcome to Christmas present...
fields.body:
Christmas is coming. The lights are up, the shops are crowded, and my five-year-old son is sitting in front of the television repeating a mantra every 30 seconds during the commercial breaks (with pauses only for Barbie ads): 'I want that. I want that. I want that.' Working out what he really wants in the middle of this deluge of advertising is hard enough; but then, if what he's chosen turns out to be this year's favourite, the problem is getting it. Last-minute toy shortages have become such a feature of the festive season that there's even been a Christmas-shopping action movie, Arnold Schwarzenegger's dismal 1996 flop Jingle All The Way , in which he plays a dad battling through the malls on Christmas Eve for that season's must-have toy, a Turboman doll.

To prove the cliché that it seems to come earlier each year, this time round the Christmas queues started on Thursday 7 September, when shops gave out pre-order forms for Sony's much-anticipated PlayStation 2 computer games console. Forms were strictly rationed, and some shops in London opened at midnight to satisfy demand. By the following Monday, there were none left in most parts of the country, and although the console was released here just two days ago, only customers who ordered in September will be able to collect their hardware in time for Christmas.

The delays in manufacturing are due to shortages of various electronic components, not helped the massive success of the console in Japan, where more than 3.52m have been sold since its launch last spring. As a result, Britain will be getting fewer than 200,000 consoles before Christmas, and only 500,000 went on sale in the US on 26 October - half the number originally planned. By early November, the online auction site E-bay was selling consoles at $500 to $600 - double the $299 retail price, and rising.

Was it always like this? Every parent fears their child being disappointed on the big day, but I have no recollection of ever opening my presents and feeling let down. But then, my desires were always quite generic: a bike, a bat, a Sindy doll, roller skates. Specific brands or designs rarely seemed important.

As for computer games, I remember the Christmas when my brother and I eagerly unwrapped a piece of plastic the size of a small suitcase and connected it to our TV. A mono picture came up, with two short white lines on either side. By manoeuvring the hefty controls, you could move the lines up and down and hit a square 'ball' in the clumsiest tennis game ever seen. Not that this bothered us. We played for hours. This was the cutting edge of leisure technology, an episode of Star Trek come to life in our very own living room. We had seen the future. And its name was Pong.

But the 70s were a more innocent time, and not just in terms of the technology available. Children's shows were only on television for a couple of hours a day, and the art of saturation advertising to the young had yet to be perfected. It wasn't until the success of Star Wars in 1977 that film became wedded irrevocably to merchandising, while the deregulation of TV in the early 80s led to shows such as He-Man and Masters of the Universe actually made by toy companies to sell product. From Ninja Turtles to Power Rangers, Batman to Buzz Lightyear, many of the year's Christmas successes since have been tied to films and TV shows.

But toy manufacturers also face more competition than ever. As well as toys, your average eight-year-old may well be asking for a replica football kit or expensive trainers, a Spice Girls or Westlife CD, computer games and hardware - Toys 'R' Us even stocks mobile phones now. And no matter how sophisticated the marketing, children constantly surprise - take the yo-yo craze of 1998, in which 30m of them were sold in the UK alone without any aggressive marketing.

Many toy manufacturers have gone bankrupt due to the failure of one toy, and even successful products can disappoint. Having sold 3m Star Wars books to tie in with the new film, children's publisher Dorling Kindersley ordered a print run of 9m more to cope with a Christmas rush that never materialised, and were destroyed. The giant toy corporation Hasbro also announced lower than expected profits after their Star Wars lines failed to perform as expected.

At the moment, says Allen of the toy giant Mattel, her company is talking to the big retailers about Christmas. Christmas 2001, that is. By February, nearly all the big manufacturers will have shown their new lines at the annual toy fairs, and will be forecasting how many of each to make.

But it's an inexact science. 'With perennial favourites like Barbie and Action Man, you can tell year on year more or less where they will sit in the market. What you can't predict is what the competition is going to do to you. And then you've got crazes like Pokémon cards or yo-yos that suddenly appear. Throughout the year, the retailers could change their forecasts, other things could come on the market. Which is why you'll suddenly see an awful lot of toys discounted because somebody got their forecasting wrong and produced too much, and you'll get things that have been a big success that are in short supply.'

This year's shortage looks set to be a familiar one. Taken by surprise by the success of the BBC's revival of its 60s children's series Thunderbirds , in 1992 shops quickly ran out of the model of Tracy Island, the Thunderbirds HQ. Although the show was again revived by the BBC this autumn, no one expected it to have the same impact the third time around. So Thunderbirds are no once more. The company behind Tracy Island, Vivid Imaginations, says that it is too big and heavy to bring over from factories in Far East by air, but extra supplies will be shipped in before Christmas. And Hamleys is expecting a limited stock of it to arrive in store in December, though it admits that it probably won't satisfy demand.

At Mattel, Sarah Allen says there's only so much that can be done at this point. 'Usually, if you've got a hit in this country, you've got a hit across the world, but sometimes you will get a retailer, say, in Germany who overordered and we can take the stock off their hands. If we can do that, you can bet we do, because we've got such a small window to sell them. It's not in our interests to short-ship the trade.'

Talking to me a few months after the great Teletubby shortage of 1997, the programme's creator, Anne Wood, was still distraught. 'I felt awful,' she said. 'I was really unhappy. It certainly wasn't engineered. It was just that the response to the programme was way, way beyond what anyone anticipated.'

That was the year that the phrase 'toy rage' began routinely appearing in the press. In one incident, Gerry Masters of the British Association of Toy Retailers was going to give a TV interview at a branch of Toys 'R' Us, holding up a Teletubby doll while discussing the shortage. The interview was cancelled after the shop couldn't guarantee his safety.

Perhaps, in the end, this isn't about children at all. In the year of the Great Teletubby Shortage, the show was my son's favourite. And I wanted him to have a doll for Christmas. Once it became clear that this might be difficult, however, his grandmothers decided that he must have all four. They worked together with admirable efficiency, mobilising battalions of friends to comb the shelves of almost every Mothercare and Woolworths in the country. They queued, they plotted, they flexed their bus passes and left no shopping centre unturned in their quest. On Christmas Day, he had his very own Tinky Twinky, Dipsy, Laa Laa and Po. And he was happy. Although, being only a toddler, he found the wrapping paper and boxes for all his presents just as much fun to play with as the toys themselves.

Three years on, the four Tubbies sit abandoned on a high shelf in his room, all but ignored. But our mums are still telling their battle stories from the Great Campaign of 1997, laughing as they swap tales with friends who fought when Buzz Lightyear sent queues to infinity and beyond. This year, both nans are determined to get him Tracy Island and all the matching Thunderbirds accessories, despite the shortages. I'm not sure he really wants them. And I'm definite he doesn't need them. But it's Christmas, and who am I to deny them their little pleasures?

Toy story 2

1901 Meccano

Conceived by Frank Hornby, a clerk at a Liverpool meat importers during a train journey one Christmas Eve, the first 'Mechanics Made Easy' sets featured 17 parts that could be made into 12 different objects for 7/6 (37.5p). The Meccano name was trademarked six years later, and although the product peaked in the 30s, it was made in Liverpool until the late 70s, and is still produced today by a French manufacturer.

1902 Teddy bears

On 16 November, the Washington Post published a Clifford Berryman cartoon celebrating an incident in which US president Teddy Roosevelt had apparently refused to shoot a captured bear produced to liven up an unsuccessful hunting trip in Mississippi. Russian immigrants Morris and Rose Michtom subsequently put a stuffed Teddy bear in the window of their novelty and stationery shop in Brooklyn, New York, and later began manufacturing them. Meanwhile, German toymaker Margarete Steiff had begun making jointed cuddly toy animals, with the bears selling especially well in the US - sparking a global craze for teddies.

1903 Crayola crayons

Cousins Edwin Binney and Harold C Smith launched their first box of eight coloured crayons. Their company in Pennsylvania produced its 100-billionth crayon in 1996: no one has counted the number of hours parents have spent scrubbing walls clean in between times.

1925 Hornby train sets

Frank Hornby's company launched their first electric trains sets, operated from a mains supply of 100-250v - which must have been a shocking experience. A safer version came on to the market four years later.

1929 The yo-yo

Pedro Flores began selling a traditional toy that had once been used as a weapon in his native Philippines in California in 1928. Donald Duncan bought the business shortly after and began aggressively marketing the toy, recruiting stars such as Bing Crosby, who recorded 'My Little Yo-Yo'. In 1930, he brought teams of demonstrators over to Europe to tour the music halls. The toy's fortunes have gone up and down ever since: in the 1998 revival, 30m of them sold in the UK alone.

1930 Mickey Mouse dolls

Mickey made his debut in 1928, but the first dolls were made by Charlotte Clarke two years later, selling at $4.95 - an extraordinary sum in the middle of the Depression - and forever sealing the bond between cartoons and kids' toys. Tie-ins with McDonald's took rather longer to arrange.

1934 Dinky toys

Die-cast miniature vehicles launched.

1935 Monopoly

A board game called The Landlord's Game was patented in 1903 by Lizzie J Magie, a young Quaker who saw it as a way of teaching the evils of land monopolism. Over the years, players adapted the rules and added new features, and the game was finally packaged into its current form by Charles Darrow of Philadelphia. He sold it to Parker Brothers in 1935, when it became the bestselling game in the USA. More than 200m sets have since been sold worldwide, containing more than 5bn little green houses.

1949 Cluedo

Mystery board game invented by Anthony Pratt, a solicitor's clerk from Birmingham, and launched by Waddington's in Leeds. It's been a massive international success, with local variations: in Norway, Mrs Peacock is Baronesse von Blau, while in Spain she's a man called Capitano Azurro; in Germany, Miss Scarlet is Fraulein Ming; in Switzerland, Colonel Mustard is known as Madam Curry.

1952 Mr Potato Head

A pack of plastic eyes, mouths and noses to turn your fruit and veg into toys, this $1 novelty sold 1m in the US in its first year, with West Coast retailers paying for them to be flown in from new toy manufacturer Hasbro's East Coast base to keep shelves stocked. Became a hot item again after being featured in Disney's Toy Story in 1996.

1953 Slinky

The spring which walks down stairs now usually comes in multicoloured plastic. The original metal version was invented by American Richard James in 1943 as an anti-vibration device for ships' instruments. It failed, but made it big as a toy instead.

1954 Sooty

Electrical engineer/part-time magician Harry Corbett bought a Chad Valley glove puppet in a Blackpool shop to entertain his children. After he and Sooty won a Manchester talent competition together in 1952, the BBC offered him a TV series and its success made Sooty the must-have toy ofthe year. It's since become a family franchise - Harry's son Matthew now has his hand in it.

1955 Scrabble

Invented by American architect Alfred Butt in 1932 under the name Lexico, it was rejected by all the major toy manufacturers and was a failure when it first came out under the name of Criss Cross Words. It was sold to James Brunot, who changed the name to Scrabble. Launched in the UK in the mid-50s, now more than half the households in Britain have a set.

1957 Scalextric

In 1952 a small British company called Minimodels launched Scalex, a range of metal cars with a keyless clockwork motor. The electric version followed five years later, and has been a favourite ever since with immature males - who sometimes let their sons play with it, too.

1958 Hula Hoop

A craze made in America inspired by Australian children exercising with a bamboo hoop, this is the toy that really launched plastic. More than 20m were sold in the UK, yet there were still Christmas shortages. Frisbees (invented the year before at the Frisbee Pie Factory) were also big.

1959 Barbie

A cleaned-up version of Lilli, a sexy German doll based on a newspaper cartoon and aimed at adult males, Mattel's new toy created controversy at a time when it was generally thought that girls wanted baby dolls to play with and that toys should not have breasts. Launched with coast-to-coast TV advertising in the US, it sold so quickly that it was three years before the factories could keep pace with demand.

1960 Lego

Ole Kirk Christiansen was a carpenter from the small town of Billund, Denmark, who started selling wooden toys in 1932 under the name Lego (leg godt is Danish for 'play well'). It was his son Godtfred who saw the potential in the new plastics and developed the classic Lego brick, which now sells 100m sets annually. The company is still based in Billund, and run by Godtfred's son Kjeld.

1963 Sindy

Britain's Barbie clone stepped out of her box wearing a stripy T-shirt and jeans outfit and º ª sporting a strange bouffant hairdo in a choice of blonde or brunette shades. She didn't shape up in the beauty-queen stakes until sold to US toy giant Hasbro by Pedigree in 1986. Meanwhile, British boys celebrated the fact that Matchbox cars came for the first time this year with doors that actually opened!

1964 GI Joe

America's Movable Fighting Man made his TV advertising debut in New York, and despite initial fears that boys wouldn't play will dolls, it did $5.3m worth of business in its first year, $23m a year later. He was known as Action Man when posted overseas, but he didn't see service in Britain for two more years. In 1964, we were consumed instead with a craze for ugly, squat dolls with fluorescent spiky hair that pre-dated punk by 13 years. They were trolls - as promoted by Diana Dors.

1965 James Bond Aston Martin

The ultimate in model motoring, complete with pop-up machine guns, the Corgi car sold out just before Christmas, as did the best-selling toy of the year, Spirograph.

1971 Clackers (aka Klik Klaks)

Two hard plastic balls suspended on string, which banged together hypnotically. In theory, a few wrist flicks could produce all kinds of tricks; in practice, you ended up with bloody knuckles and bruised wrists. This was also the year of the Space Hopper, a giant ball with ears that you sat on and bounced along. In theory.

1973 Mastermind

The board game of the television series had to 'pass' on many potential seasonal sales when the manufacturers ran out of plastic.

1978 Star Wars toys

A success story that redefined Hollywood's relationship with the toy industry, with $100m worth of action figures sold in the US alone the year after the movie took off.

1980 Rubik's cube

Designed by Hungarian professor Erno Rubik, it flooded the shops just before Christmas and ended up in almost every present pile that year. There were international cube contests, books written on how to solve it, a health scare about wrist strain. And within two years all of them were gathering dust in corners, never to be seen again.

1984 Cabbage Patch Kids

Invented by Xavier 'Happy' Roberts in Georgia in 1976, each homely stuffed doll came with a birth certificate and they were offered for adoption rather than for sale. He sold as many as could be made - 2.8m of them - in 1983, and Cabbage Patch fever raged for the following three years. There were reports of desperate American parents flying to the UK to find dolls, while anxious shoppers responding to a newspaper ad in New York and Los Angeles promising 'Send $34.95 and we will send you a Cabbage Patch' were rewarded with packets of cabbage seeds.

1985 Transformers

An adaptation of a popular Japanese toy, robots which turned into vehicles and weapons. Christmas shortages caused riots in the US in 1984, with reports of a mother trampled in the rush outside a toy store in Virginia. They were Britain's top-selling toy a year later.

1989 Nintendo GameBoy

The re-emerging computer-games market increasingly blurred the line between children's toys and adult diversion: the hand-held GameBoy cost a hefty £70 and appealed to yuppies, teens and kids alike.

1990 Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles

The children's cartoon based on a satirical comic aimed at an older audience made its UK TV debut in February; by May, the first stories of toy shortages began to appear. By Christmas, there were queues everywhere. Six years later, pet terrapins bought during the Ninja craze and dumped when they grew alarmingly big began turning up in sewers across the country and were caught savaging wild birds at a nature reserve in Cornwall.

1992 Tracy Island

A BBC relaunch of the 60s TV favourite Thunderbirds led to acute shortages of this model of the International Rescue HQ, with all-night queues outside some shops and headlines such as 'Thunderbirds are no'.

1993 Mortal Kombat

The popular arcade video game was released on 'Mortal Monday' for both of the big home consoles: Sega's MegaDrive and the Super Nintendo Entertainment System. Nintendo censored some of the fight game's gore, and Sega drew ahead in the battle of the computer giants. Toy companies missed out as the consoles took over Santa's sacks. By the end of the year, 6m copies of Mortal Kombat had been sold worldwide

1994 Power Rangers

The new Fox TV network commissioned 40 half-hour episodes of a cheap Japanese series they renamed Mighty Morphin' Power Rangers. With the two female rangers helping sell what was essentially a boy toy to girls too, sales of the action figures topped $300m in the US in the first year, and worldwide demand led to long queues and frustrations. In the UK, Toys 'R' Us had to limit them to one per customer. According to the Mail's New York correspondent: 'Last winter, 5,000 fans lined up in Los Angeles to meet a new character, Tommy the Green Ranger, while barely two dozen parents and children waited to see Santa Claus.' By 1995, Tommy had turned white and taken over as leader of the Rangers in the TV series - leading to a severe seasonal drought of white Ranger dolls.

1996 Buzz Lightyear dolls

Toy Story was a merchandising dream: an animated children's film in which the stars were toys. Yet demand was underestimated, and many didn't get their Christmas Buzz. 'Sales have gone through the roof - we never dreamed that it would be this big,' John Barton, director of the Canadian manufacturer Thinkway Toys told The Mirror. 'We're still making them in China, but there simply aren't enough raw materials or manpower to make enough. We've had a request from President Clinton. And we are even having to ship one to the president of Disney, because she can't get one.'

1997 Teletubbies

One million dolls went into the shops before Christmas, but demand was for three times as many. There was rationing, all-night queues, and outbreaks of 'toy rage'. One mother and grandmother were charged with assault after trying to snatch dolls from another customer's trolley in a Kent branch of Toys 'R' Us.

1998 Furby

The interactive 'pet' caused the longest Christmas queues - by New Year's Eve, parents had realised that it didn't have an off switch, and those who had failed to buy one were sobbing with relief.
fields.bodyText: Christmas is coming. The lights are up, the shops are crowded, and my five-year-old son is sitting in front of the television repeating a mantra every 30 seconds during the commercial breaks (with pauses only for Barbie ads): 'I want that. I want that. I want that.' Working out what he really wants in the middle of this deluge of advertising is hard enough; but then, if what he's chosen turns out to be this year's favourite, the problem is getting it. Last-minute toy shortages have become such a feature of the festive season that there's even been a Christmas-shopping action movie, Arnold Schwarzenegger's dismal 1996 flop Jingle All The Way , in which he plays a dad battling through the malls on Christmas Eve for that season's must-have toy, a Turboman doll. To prove the cliché that it seems to come earlier each year, this time round the Christmas queues started on Thursday 7 September, when shops gave out pre-order forms for Sony's much-anticipated PlayStation 2 computer games console. Forms were strictly rationed, and some shops in London opened at midnight to satisfy demand. By the following Monday, there were none left in most parts of the country, and although the console was released here just two days ago, only customers who ordered in September will be able to collect their hardware in time for Christmas. The delays in manufacturing are due to shortages of various electronic components, not helped the massive success of the console in Japan, where more than 3.52m have been sold since its launch last spring. As a result, Britain will be getting fewer than 200,000 consoles before Christmas, and only 500,000 went on sale in the US on 26 October - half the number originally planned. By early November, the online auction site E-bay was selling consoles at $500 to $600 - double the $299 retail price, and rising. Was it always like this? Every parent fears their child being disappointed on the big day, but I have no recollection of ever opening my presents and feeling let down. But then, my desires were always quite generic: a bike, a bat, a Sindy doll, roller skates. Specific brands or designs rarely seemed important. As for computer games, I remember the Christmas when my brother and I eagerly unwrapped a piece of plastic the size of a small suitcase and connected it to our TV. A mono picture came up, with two short white lines on either side. By manoeuvring the hefty controls, you could move the lines up and down and hit a square 'ball' in the clumsiest tennis game ever seen. Not that this bothered us. We played for hours. This was the cutting edge of leisure technology, an episode of Star Trek come to life in our very own living room. We had seen the future. And its name was Pong. But the 70s were a more innocent time, and not just in terms of the technology available. Children's shows were only on television for a couple of hours a day, and the art of saturation advertising to the young had yet to be perfected. It wasn't until the success of Star Wars in 1977 that film became wedded irrevocably to merchandising, while the deregulation of TV in the early 80s led to shows such as He-Man and Masters of the Universe actually made by toy companies to sell product. From Ninja Turtles to Power Rangers, Batman to Buzz Lightyear, many of the year's Christmas successes since have been tied to films and TV shows. But toy manufacturers also face more competition than ever. As well as toys, your average eight-year-old may well be asking for a replica football kit or expensive trainers, a Spice Girls or Westlife CD, computer games and hardware - Toys 'R' Us even stocks mobile phones now. And no matter how sophisticated the marketing, children constantly surprise - take the yo-yo craze of 1998, in which 30m of them were sold in the UK alone without any aggressive marketing. Many toy manufacturers have gone bankrupt due to the failure of one toy, and even successful products can disappoint. Having sold 3m Star Wars books to tie in with the new film, children's publisher Dorling Kindersley ordered a print run of 9m more to cope with a Christmas rush that never materialised, and were destroyed. The giant toy corporation Hasbro also announced lower than expected profits after their Star Wars lines failed to perform as expected. At the moment, says Allen of the toy giant Mattel, her company is talking to the big retailers about Christmas. Christmas 2001, that is. By February, nearly all the big manufacturers will have shown their new lines at the annual toy fairs, and will be forecasting how many of each to make. But it's an inexact science. 'With perennial favourites like Barbie and Action Man, you can tell year on year more or less where they will sit in the market. What you can't predict is what the competition is going to do to you. And then you've got crazes like Pokémon cards or yo-yos that suddenly appear. Throughout the year, the retailers could change their forecasts, other things could come on the market. Which is why you'll suddenly see an awful lot of toys discounted because somebody got their forecasting wrong and produced too much, and you'll get things that have been a big success that are in short supply.' This year's shortage looks set to be a familiar one. Taken by surprise by the success of the BBC's revival of its 60s children's series Thunderbirds , in 1992 shops quickly ran out of the model of Tracy Island, the Thunderbirds HQ. Although the show was again revived by the BBC this autumn, no one expected it to have the same impact the third time around. So Thunderbirds are no once more. The company behind Tracy Island, Vivid Imaginations, says that it is too big and heavy to bring over from factories in Far East by air, but extra supplies will be shipped in before Christmas. And Hamleys is expecting a limited stock of it to arrive in store in December, though it admits that it probably won't satisfy demand. At Mattel, Sarah Allen says there's only so much that can be done at this point. 'Usually, if you've got a hit in this country, you've got a hit across the world, but sometimes you will get a retailer, say, in Germany who overordered and we can take the stock off their hands. If we can do that, you can bet we do, because we've got such a small window to sell them. It's not in our interests to short-ship the trade.' Talking to me a few months after the great Teletubby shortage of 1997, the programme's creator, Anne Wood, was still distraught. 'I felt awful,' she said. 'I was really unhappy. It certainly wasn't engineered. It was just that the response to the programme was way, way beyond what anyone anticipated.' That was the year that the phrase 'toy rage' began routinely appearing in the press. In one incident, Gerry Masters of the British Association of Toy Retailers was going to give a TV interview at a branch of Toys 'R' Us, holding up a Teletubby doll while discussing the shortage. The interview was cancelled after the shop couldn't guarantee his safety. Perhaps, in the end, this isn't about children at all. In the year of the Great Teletubby Shortage, the show was my son's favourite. And I wanted him to have a doll for Christmas. Once it became clear that this might be difficult, however, his grandmothers decided that he must have all four. They worked together with admirable efficiency, mobilising battalions of friends to comb the shelves of almost every Mothercare and Woolworths in the country. They queued, they plotted, they flexed their bus passes and left no shopping centre unturned in their quest. On Christmas Day, he had his very own Tinky Twinky, Dipsy, Laa Laa and Po. And he was happy. Although, being only a toddler, he found the wrapping paper and boxes for all his presents just as much fun to play with as the toys themselves. Three years on, the four Tubbies sit abandoned on a high shelf in his room, all but ignored. But our mums are still telling their battle stories from the Great Campaign of 1997, laughing as they swap tales with friends who fought when Buzz Lightyear sent queues to infinity and beyond. This year, both nans are determined to get him Tracy Island and all the matching Thunderbirds accessories, despite the shortages. I'm not sure he really wants them. And I'm definite he doesn't need them. But it's Christmas, and who am I to deny them their little pleasures? fields.headline: Pump up the volumes
fields.standfirst:
Which is the best book of the year? Philip Roth's The Human Stain or Zadie Smith's White Teeth? Writers and critics choose their favourites
Part two
fields.trailText: Lucy Moore
fields.body:
Lucy Moore

The Journals of Sylvia Plath edited by Karen V. Kukil (Faber) make uncomfortable reading because she is so searingly, desperately intense - but that is also what makes them so compelling. A fascinating look into a brilliant, tortured mind.

Lewis Wolpert

James Lovelock's Homage to Gaia - The Life of an Independent Scientist (OUP) is not so much a homage to his captivating idea but rather a homage to science and his own life in it. There is no autobiography of a scientist to compete with this one. Hitler's Gift, by Jean Medawar and David Pyke (Metro), tells the stories of 21 brilliant scientists who took refuge in Britain shortly after Hitler came to power in 1933 and Jews were dismissed from their university posts. A moving story and a moral tale.

Simon Jenkins

White Teeth (Random House) by Zadie Smith is funny and sad. Larry Siedentop's Democracy in Europe (Allen Lane, Penguin) was the most original political book of the year. For politics of a lighter hue, nothing beats Andrew Rawnsley's gossipy Servants of the People (Hamish Hamilton), presenting New Labour as a court that Machiavelli would recognise and from which Blairism will never quite recover. And let us hear a cheer for Gladwyn Turbutt's four-volume History of Derbyshire (Merton Priory). This masterpiece of local history, 10 years in the making, is proof that such invaluable books can still see the light of day, defying the outpourings of technology.

Barbara Trapido

While I have tried to make this a writing rather than a reading year, there were two books I couldn't not read. One was Günther Grass's time travelling, massively long Too Far Afield (Faber), in which the 'footnote slaves' of a GDR archive tell the story of an aged file courier whose life is rescued by an obsession with a literary Huguenot. The other, Jonathan Coe's The Rotters' Club (Viking), not out until next March but read in a sneak preview, is a boys' school story set in 1970s Birmingham. Coe can present social history without sacrificing characters to events and both here are a joy. I also caught up, in paperback, with Romesh Gunesekera's beautiful exile story, The Sandglass (Granta).

Robert Harris

The latest selection from Alan Clark's Diaries, Into Politics (Weidenfeld & Nicolson) still offers, for my money, the strongest narrative voice of the year - an elongated Etonian drawl of selfishness, lechery, snobbishness, hypochondria, self-delusion and melancholy, all of which are transfigured by the razor quality of Clark's prose and his reckless honesty.

Graham Robb's Rimbaud (Picador) demythologises the subject while leaving quite intact the magic of the art. Penelope Fitzgerald, who died in April, left us a farewell present of short stories, The Means of Escape (Flamingo): economical enigmas which remind us to reread her last four great novels.

Joan Bakewell
L

J. G. Ballard has always been astonishingly prophetic in his visions. Now Super-Cannes (Flamingo) imagines the dangers, plausible and horrifying, of the culture of global corporations. Even when not on major biographical duty, Richard Holmes is always interesting. Sidetracks - Explorations of a Romantic Biographer (HarperCollins) are minor excursions down biographical byways but offer up insights I couldn't have anticipated. Experience by Martin Amis (Jonathan Cape) is brilliant for its cun ning structure and density of impressions.

Zadie Smith

I choose Martin Amis's memoir Experience (Jonathan Cape) because it's exquisitely written, Edward Platt's intimate biography of the A40, Leadville (Picador), for the same reason, and Dave Eggers's A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius (Picador) because it kicks ass.

Misha Glenny

Michael Burleigh's The Third Reich: A New History (Macmillan) is how history should be written. Illuminating and stylish, it offers insights for the general reader and scholar alike without boring either. Night of Stone (Granta) , Catherine Merridale's account of how ordinary Russians coped with violent death on a scale few of us can even imagine, is an epic and moving his tory. Kosovo: War and Revenge (Yale), Tim Judah's reconstruction of the war in Kosovo and the dynamics of Serb and Albanian politics in the territory, is clear and instructive.

Nicci Gerard

In The Human Stain (Cape) - a stunning, complex novel of snarling rage, passion, sarcasm, scorching humour and extraordinary beauty - Philip Roth manages to weave together public history and private lives and seems to pack 10 novels into this dense one. In October, Philip Pullman published the final in his dazzling Dark Materials trilogy, The Amber Spyglass (David Fickling Books). He understands the power of a good story, but he is an uncosy, often scary and troubling novelist: besotted by myth, compelled by death and desire and faith and grief, in love with Milton and Blake, angry with religion, intimate with compromise and complicity and corruption, capable of radiant prose.

Christopher Frayling

I particularly enjoyed David Skal's Screams of Reason - Mad Science and Modern Culture (W. W. Norton & Co) which begins with Dr Faustus and ends with Stephen Hawking but concentrates in between on Boris Karloff and Hollywood horror. The best-written book I read was Thomas McGuane's elegant and thoughtful essays about the partnership - a partnership he calls 'a burst of poetry' - between humans and horses collected as Some Horses (The Lyons Press).

Jonathan Meades

Atomised by Michel Houllebecq (Heinemann) is the most thrilling novel I've read in several years. Its directness, its energy, its centripetal concentration, its candour, its nihilism and its sod-you-ism are exhilarating. In The Third Reich: A New History (Macmillan), Michael Burleigh proceeds from the premise that Nazism was a quasi-religion whose programme allowed the faithful to perpetrate enormities with a clear conscience. His book is a massive accretion of detail and appalling anecdote.

Brenda Maddox

Andrew Roberts's Salisbury: Victorian Titan (Weidenfeld and Nicolson) is as learned, accessible and well-shaped a biography as I've read. Roberts is a rare historian, with an eye for the human detail and for contemporary relevance. I also loved the outrageous Letters of Kingsley Amis edited by Zachary Leader (HarperCollins).

Antony Holden

Angry, outrageous, wildly funny and infinitely sad, Philip Roth's The Human Stain (Cape) completes the majestic postwar US trilogy which began in equally high style with American Pastoral. Martin Amis's memoir Experience (Jonathan Cape) is up there with Roth's The Facts; when fine fictional stylists turn their laser-prose upon themselves, the result is an auto-brainscan offering a tantalising glimpse towards the heart. I also much admired Miranda Seymour's exhaustive biography of Mary Shelley.

Charles Saumarez Smith

My favourite book of the year is called City Secrets: Rome (The Little Bookroom). Edited by the architect Robert Kahn, it consists of recommendations of what to see and do in Rome as sent in by the American Academy of Rome's many supporters. It's a brilliant idea. I also enjoyed The Long Afternoon (Sceptre), Giles Waterfield's dry and atmospheric novel about his grandparents' life in Menton between the wars.

Jan Morris

In non-fiction I greatly admired and enjoyed Simon Schama's Rembrandt's Eyes (Allen Lane, Penguin), which was published in the autumn of 1999 but did not reach me until the present millennium; also Peter Ackroyd's virtuoso evocation of the most timeless of cities, London: The Biography (Chatto & Windus). I was delighted by Miles Bredin's life of James Bruce, The Pale Abyssinian (HarperCollins), but since Mr Bredin is my godson I'd better not say anything too nice about it.

Mary Riddell

As lucid as anything he has written and, in the paperback edition, particularly well-timed Matt Ridley's Genome - the Autobiography of a Species in 23 Chapters (Fourth Estate) is the A to Z route map for anyone trying to get to grips with the completion of the Human Genome Project.

Tom Paulin

Martin Allen's Hidden Agenda: How the Duke of Windsor Betrayed the Allies (Macmillan) paints a devastating picture of this truly evil royal who was a close friend of Charles Bedaux, a Nazi spy so dangerous that the FBI would appear to have bumped him off in 1944 (officially he committed suicide). Frank Kermode's Shakespeare's Language (Allen Lane, Penguin) is an inspiring work of evaluative critical analysis.

Edna O'Brien

Snow and Guilt by Giorgio Pressburger (Granta) is a perfect little book. Translated by Shaun Whiteside, these six stories have an underlying unity; the writing is austere yet with a life-affirming tenderness. The same cannot be said for The Journals of Sylvia Plath (Faber). Here we witness the rage, the torment and the competitiveness of a deeply wounded young woman. As I began to read them I wondered if all journals ought not to be consigned to the pyre, but by the time I had finished I marvelled at her industriousness and her capacity at transforming her demons into great art. Eilis Ni Dhuibhne is the most gifted young Irish writer. In The Pale Gold of Alaska (Blackstaff Press), her prose shimmers like poetry.

George Steiner

My book of the year (if a delayed finding in paperback is allowed), is Colin Thubron's In Siberia (Chatto & Windus) . There is hardly a sentence in this grim yet strangely luminous memoir without a taut vivacity which makes the whole book 'sing'. Thubron's account of the abandoned Stalinist death-camps in the Siberian Kolyma, of the pounding into ice and mud of millions of innocent men and women, is almost unbearable. Yet even here, in the hell of the anonymous, there are touches of human dignity, of that Russian investment in resurrection.

Gita Sereny

Brigitte Hamann's Hitler's Vienna is a really original account of the young Hitler's years of political apprenticeship between 1907 and 1913. Mark Roseman's The Past in Hiding (Allen Lane, Penguin) is an extraordinary story of a life, particularly read - as I read it - in conjunction with Ian Kershaw's two volumes of Hitler biography - Hubris and Nemesis (Penguin), both of them richly annotated with previously unknown facts. I loved Simon Sebag Montefiore's Prince of Princes: The Life of Potemkin (Weidenfeld & Nicolson). George Monbiot's Captive State: The Corporate Takeover of Britain (Macmillan) confronts us with the corporate control of British hospitals, schools, universities and, indeed, the food we buy and eat. Scary. But I also read a lot of novels this past year, some new, some older: I loved Kent Haruf 's Plainsong and Niall Williams's Four Letters of Love (both Picador). And I have, with enormous pleasure, re-read Robert Harris's Archangel (Arrow), Richard North Patterson's The Final Judgement (Hutchinson), the perfect legal novel, and all the wonderful thrillers written by Michael Connelly (Orion).

Mavis Cheek

'Not for horrid profs,' says Frank Kermode of his Shakespeare's Language (Allen Lane, Penguin) - and he's quite right. It's engaging and clear to read. One critic called Colm Toibin's The Blackwater Lightship (Picador) 'emotional choreography'. I'd add the word 'beautiful' to that. Three generations, three different beliefs, three women coming to terms with each other and themselves. With The World's Smallest Unicorn (Cape), Shena Mackay brings us 10 more immaculate short stories of human folly and fortune and finding the skull beneath the perm.

A L Kennedy

This year No Great Mischief (Cape) made Alistair MacLeod's position as a master of prose even more firmly assured. This is a work of true lyricism, emotional intelligence and breathtakingly acute observation.

Terry Eagleton

Years ago, I read Mikhail Bakhtin's great classic of the carnivalesque, Rabelais and His World, and wondered why I had never heard of him before. There's now no doubt that this previously obscure Russian thinker, who is said to have torn up one of his own priceless manuscripts for cigarette paper, is one of the supreme literary thinkers of our time. To write the very best book on him to date is thus a remarkable achievement. Ken Hirschkop's Mikhail Bakhtin: An Aesthetic for Democracy (OUP) combines dogged work in the Russian archives with some brilliant insights to show Bakhtin's relevance to questions of politics and popular democracy today.

Glen Baxter

My contenders for book of the year would have to include Flick Knives and Forks (Zillah Bell Contemporary Art) by Anthony Earnshaw - a collection of the great English surrealists' aphorisms spiced with black humour. My next choice would be The Book of Leviathan (Sort of Books) by Peter Bleguad which is funny, enigmatic and beautifully limned - what more could one ask?

Hermione Lee

My book of the year is the Selected Poems of Yehuda Amichai (Faber) edited by his friend Ted Hughes and by Daniel Weissbort. His wry, conversational poems - tender, humane and pragmatic - on war, love, memory, and the fierce history of his city, Jerusalem, are all the more moving now. I was also delighted by the dazzling stories of Peter Ho Davies, Equal Love (Granta) , and by Michèle Roberts's deliciously sensual French novel, The Looking Glass (Virago).

Helen Dunmore

It's seven years since Michael Donaghy last published a poetry collection. Here, after a magical interval, is Conjure (Picador), his best book yet. Conjure takes all the Donaghy virtues - wit, clarity, breathtaking control of rhyme and rhythm - and adds a new intensity of feeling.

David Hare

Why do women write about the recent past so much better than men? Only John Osborne has described the day before yesterday as skilfully as Barbara Skelton, Doris Lessing and Joan Wyndham. Stet (Granta), is a record of Diana Athill's years as an editor at Andre Deutsch. It's hard to believe that most of her authors came anywhere near Athill's own superb literary pitch. Over the internet you can order the American edition of The Selected Letters of Tennessee Williams, Volume 1 1920-1945 (New Directions) - essential reading for admirers of one of America's greatest dramatists

Emma Tennant

Lorna Sage's Bad Blood (Fourth Estate) is a deceptively simple account of a Second World War childhood in deepest Flintshire, which makes sense of the enormous and bewildering changes in society in the last century.

Michael Foot

Don't be misled by any neglect or false testimony into imagining that Rebecca West was not one of the great women of the century. Her Selected Letters, edited by Bonnie Kime Scott (Yale) should dispose of all such misconceptions. She would have appreciated the latest of essays from her protégé, Merlin Holland's The Oscar Wilde Anthology (HarperCollins). And don't miss Have You Forgotten Yet? The First World War Memoirs of C P Blacker, edited by John Blacker (Pen and Sword Books ), an original, plain-spoken record of the First World War which confronts the reader fairly with the Siegfried Sassoon verdict on the whole affair.

Adam Phillips

R. F. Langley's Collected Poems (Carcanet) has a new music of sense-making about it that is, in the way only poetry and music can be, like an illumination. Larry Siedentop's Democracy In Europe (Allen Lane, Penguin) has a remarkable clarity and exhilaration about something that runs the risk of becoming just another topic of debate. Richard Lewontin with The Triple Helix (Harvard) continues to be the scientist everyone should read.

J G Ballard

In The Heart Of The Sea by Nathaniel Philbrick (HarperCollins) is a deeply moving account of the sinking of the whale ship Essex , which inspired Melville's Moby Dick. Rammed by a sperm whale, the Essex sank three days later, and the survivors set out by boat for the South American coast, 4,000 miles away. Nathaniel Philbrick unsparingly describes their ordeal, a hellish descent into starvation and cannibalism. None the less, these desperate men emerge as heroes.

Philip French

George Orwell is possibly the greatest writer of the twentieth century and next year's major publishing event will be the paperback editions at affordable prices of the first three volumes of his complete essays, letters and diaries: All Propaganda is Lies 1941-42, Keeping Our Little Corner Clean and Two Wasted Years 1943 (Secker & Warburg). My three new favourites all address themselves to settling the business of the last century. Douglas Dunn's vivid book-length poem The Donkey's Ears (Faber), purports to be the letters home to his wife by the self-questioning flag engineer of the Russian fleet steaming from the Baltic to the East China Sea to be destroyed by the Japanese in May 1905.

Philip Roth's The Human Stain (Cape) magnificently completes the informal trilogy about post-war America that Roth began with American Pastoral and I Married a Communist. My film choice is Christopher Frayling's Sergio Leone: Something To Do With Death (Faber), a fascinating biography that locates a great director in the complex social and cultural context of twentieth-century Italy.

Andrew Motion

Derek Mahon has always been a busy reviser and re-presenter of his own work. His latest Selected Poems (Penguin) is his best shot yet at self-definition - a wonderfully varied, skilful and abundant book by a writer who is working at his formidable best. Wordsworth was a grand old tinkerer, too, and watching him chop and change is just one of the fascinations of Juliet Barker's enormous, and enormously sympathetic, biography Wordsworth: A Life (Viking). And yet another revision: the third edition of Michael Gray's Song and Dance Man III: The Art of Bob Dylan (Cassell) - the best book there is on Dylan, now better than ever.

Peter Conrad

Condemned to spend hours each week inching in and out of London along Western Avenue, I was fascinated by Edward Platt's Leadville: A Biography of the A40 (Picador). On a trek from White City to Hanger Lane, Platt investigates the lives of the roadside householders, and documents the death of their suburban dream. A small, gritty, monoxide-scented epic.

Chris Patten

Philip Roth's The Human Stain (Cape) is the best new novel I have read for years. It is a powerful, gripping story with some strong set-pieces. Roth is not afraid to wrestle with ideas, some of them unfashionable but troubling for any liberal conscience. The book I used most was the Royal Horticultural Society's Gardeners' Encyclopaedia of Plants and Flowers (Dorling Kindersley). I couldn't garden without it.

Cressida Connolly

The American Rick Moody is one of the most original and inventive of current fiction writers. His new short stories, Demonology (Faber), are touching and funny and downright odd. I very much enjoyed Kazuo Ishiguro's extraordinary novel, When We Were Orphans (Faber). My best book of the year was Carlo Gebler's Father & I (Little, Brown ). Compassionate, wry and ringingly honest. And John Burnside 's new poems, the Asylum Dance (Cape), are pretty good, too.

Steven Berkoff

In characteristic style Peter Ackroyd pulls back the veil and lets us peer within, examining London with intense fascination in London: The Biography (Chatto & Windus) . In Ackroyd's view we are invited to see London as a living, breathing creature, greedy, bestial, even demonic. It is a work on the level of Mayhew's London, raw and compelling.

A Positively Final Appearance (Penguin) affords another view of London. Alec Guinness 's impeccably delicate prose is so undiluted you feel you can hear the old boy's voice. A man of consummate taste and culture, he epitomises England, an England unfamiliar to us now but which still surrounds Guinness like a bubble. His reading is Trollope and Anthony Powell, while for comfort he quotes from Montaigne, but all so unpretentiously. This is an actor's actor, a man of culture, breeding and even a defined morality.

Martin Amis

Fiction: Saul Bellow's Ravelstein (Penguin). Non-fiction: Inside Stalin's Russia: The Diaries of Reader Bullard, 1930-1934 edited by Julian and Margaret Bullard (Day Books).

Over the internet you can order the American edition of The Selected Letters of Tennessee Williams, Volume 1 1920-1945 (New Directions) - essential reading for admirers of one of America's greatest dramatists Emma Tennant Lorna Sage's Bad Blood (Fourth Estate) is a deceptively simple account of a Second World War childhood in deepest Flintshire, which makes sense of the enormous and bewildering changes in society in the last century. Michael Foot Don't be misled by any neglect or false testimony into imagining that Rebecca West was not one of the great women of the century. Her Selected Letters, edited by Bonnie Kime Scott (Yale) should dispose of all such misconceptions. She would have appreciated the latest of essays from her protégé, Merlin Holland's The Oscar Wilde Anthology (HarperCollins). And don't miss Have You Forgotten Yet? The First World War Memoirs of C P Blacker, edited by John Blacker (Pen and Sword Books ), an original, plain-spoken record of the First World War which confronts the reader fairly with the Siegfried Sassoon verdict on the whole affair. Adam Phillips R. F. Langley's Collected Poems (Carcanet) has a new music of sense-making about it that is, in the way only poetry and music can be, like an illumination. Larry Siedentop's Democracy In Europe (Allen Lane, Penguin) has a remarkable clarity and exhilaration about something that runs the risk of becoming just another topic of debate. Richard Lewontin with The Triple Helix (Harvard) continues to be the scientist everyone should read. J G Ballard In The Heart Of The Sea by Nathaniel Philbrick (HarperCollins) is a deeply moving account of the sinking of the whale ship Essex , which inspired Melville's Moby Dick. Rammed by a sperm whale, the Essex sank three days later, and the survivors set out by boat for the South American coast, 4,000 miles away. Nathaniel Philbrick unsparingly describes their ordeal, a hellish descent into starvation and cannibalism. None the less, these desperate men emerge as heroes. Philip French George Orwell is possibly the greatest writer of the twentieth century and next year's major publishing event will be the paperback editions at affordable prices of the first three volumes of his complete essays, letters and diaries: All Propaganda is Lies 1941-42, Keeping Our Little Corner Clean and Two Wasted Years 1943 (Secker & Warburg). My three new favourites all address themselves to settling the business of the last century. Douglas Dunn's vivid book-length poem The Donkey's Ears (Faber), purports to be the letters home to his wife by the self-questioning flag engineer of the Russian fleet steaming from the Baltic to the East China Sea to be destroyed by the Japanese in May 1905. Philip Roth's The Human Stain (Cape) magnificently completes the informal trilogy about post-war America that Roth began with American Pastoral and I Married a Communist. My film choice is Christopher Frayling's Sergio Leone: Something To Do With Death (Faber), a fascinating biography that locates a great director in the complex social and cultural context of twentieth-century Italy. Andrew Motion Derek Mahon has always been a busy reviser and re-presenter of his own work. His latest Selected Poems (Penguin) is his best shot yet at self-definition - a wonderfully varied, skilful and abundant book by a writer who is working at his formidable best. Wordsworth was a grand old tinkerer, too, and watching him chop and change is just one of the fascinations of Juliet Barker's enormous, and enormously sympathetic, biography Wordsworth: A Life (Viking). And yet another revision: the third edition of Michael Gray's Song and Dance Man III: The Art of Bob Dylan (Cassell) - the best book there is on Dylan, now better than ever. Peter Conrad Condemned to spend hours each week inching in and out of London along Western Avenue, I was fascinated by Edward Platt's Leadville: A Biography of the A40 (Picador). On a trek from White City to Hanger Lane, Platt investigates the lives of the roadside householders, and documents the death of their suburban dream. A small, gritty, monoxide-scented epic. Chris Patten Philip Roth's The Human Stain (Cape) is the best new novel I have read for years. It is a powerful, gripping story with some strong set-pieces. Roth is not afraid to wrestle with ideas, some of them unfashionable but troubling for any liberal conscience. Cressida Connolly The American Rick Moody is one of the most original and inventive of current fiction writers. His new short stories, Demonology (Faber), are touching and funny and downright odd. I very much enjoyed Kazuo Ishiguro's extraordinary novel, When We Were Orphans (Faber). My best book of the year was Carlo Gebler's Father & I (Little, Brown ). Compassionate, wry and ringingly honest. And John Burnside 's new poems, the Asylum Dance (Cape), are pretty good, too. In Ackroyd's view we are invited to see London as a living, breathing creature, greedy, bestial, even demonic. It is a work on the level of Mayhew's London, raw and compelling. A Positively Final Appearance (Penguin) affords another view of London. Alec Guinness 's impeccably delicate prose is so undiluted you feel you can hear the old boy's voice. A man of consummate taste and culture, he epitomises England, an England unfamiliar to us now but which still surrounds Guinness like a bubble. His reading is Trollope and Anthony Powell, while for comfort he quotes from Montaigne, but all so unpretentiously. This is an actor's actor, a man of culture, breeding and even a defined morality. Martin Amis Fiction: Saul Bellow's Ravelstein (Penguin). Non-fiction: Inside Stalin's Russia: The Diaries of Reader Bullard, 1930-1934 edited by Julian and Margaret Bullard (Day Books). Read part two of Pump Up The Volumes here.

webTitle: No more NHS teeth braces for children

fields.headline: No more NHS teeth braces for children
fields.trailText: A generation of British children will be left with crooked teeth under government cost-saving proposals, Anthony Browne reports.
fields.body:
A generation of British children will be left with crooked teeth under government cost-saving proposals. The Department of Health is planning to put a stop to the childhood rite of passage of wearing braces and tramlines to straighten teeth, The Observer can reveal.

Dentists warn that 50,000 children a year will be denied treatment, leaving them prone to bullying, low self-confidence, and oral health problems later in life. Only children with severely deformed teeth will still get free treatment on the NHS.

At present it is up to the general dentist or specialist orthodontic dentist to decide what treatment a child needs, if any. However, under the government plans they will be allowed only to treat children with such crooked teeth that they endanger their health - for example if they have buck teeth that stick out so far they are in danger of being knocked out.

All other children, who presently receive free treatment on the NHS, will have to go private, with the average cost of treatment being £3,000. The British Orthodontic Society estimates around half of the estimated 100,000 children who currently receive corrective treatment would no longer be entitled to it.

The cutbacks - outlined in a document called 'Modernising Orthodontic Services' - are aimed at controlling the cost of corrective treatment as parents become more insistent on their children having perfect teeth. The total cost of orthodontic treatments has doubled to £80 million in the past six years.

The rationing has caused fury among patient groups. Mike Stone, director of the Patients Association, said: 'It's very bad news for children with problem teeth. It's not just down to cosmetics - buck teeth lead to teasing and bullying. It's also short sighted. If kids aren't having teeth sorted, it will lead to greater problems later in life.'

Jonathan Sandler, spokesman for the British Orthodontic Society, said: 'For many families, the cost of private treatment is out of the question. Without a doubt there will be a reduction in treatment. There will be a large number of children who have to put up with disfiguring teeth. We are opposed to any form of rationing.'

British children are known for having wonky teeth. In the US - which is about 10 years ahead in the use of orthodontic dentistry - dentists refer to the condition of having crooked teeth as 'English mouth'. Sandler said: 'Any parent whose child has crooked teeth and is teased on a daily basis would want it done. There are going to be thousands of angry middle-class parents.'

The Government had planned to introduce the rationing in April 2001, but it is likely to be postponed for a year, giving time to train dentists to identify how crooked teeth need to be before they qualify. Britain has about 1,000 orthodontic dentists, with half the 16,000 general dentists also practising corrective treatment.

A Department of Health spokesman said the rationing of treatment was not about saving money, but about targeting resources more effectively. The rising demand for orthodontics had led to long delays, with children waiting up to two years for treatment.

The spokesman said: 'The proposals are aimed at ensuring resources are used more effectively and that waiting times for those most in need are significantly reduced. Clinical opinion within the orthodontic community is now questioning the health gain of treating some minor conditions.'

However, the department document makes clear the proposals will slow the growth in the cost of orthodontic treatment. It projects that by the third year, the rise in costs will be brought back in line with that of dental services as a whole.

webTitle: French farmers under siege as BSE fears grip continent

fields.headline: French farmers under siege as BSE fears grip continent
fields.standfirst:
Evidence that cows may have contracted BSE after controls to halt the disease were imposed has fuelled a growing sense of panic

Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: Europe's BSE crisis took a disturbing new turn yesterday when France announced that it was investigating a case of 'mad cow' disease in an animal born after 1996 - the year in which tougher controls were imposed on feedstuffs to try to halt the spread of the disease.
fields.body:
Europe's BSE crisis took a disturbing new turn yesterday when France announced that it was investigating a case of 'mad cow' disease in an animal born after 1996 - the year in which tougher controls were imposed on feedstuffs to try to halt the spread of the disease.

The discovery of the diseased animal at an unspecified farm in western France, if confirmed, would support the theory that animal feed is not the only means of transmitting the disease and might mean that the epidemic will be around for much longer than hitherto believed. The discovery came as French farmers mounted a campaign this weekend to show that their beef is the safest in Europe.

Fear over mad cow disease is already gripping the continent, with both Germany and Spain this week reporting their first cases of BSE.

In a statement, France's food safety agency AFSSA said that four tests had already been done on the animal, which was born in May 1998. But more investigations were needed, it added.

Even before this latest revelation, French confidence in traditional beef delicacies had taken a battering. Figures published yesterday showed that French beef sales between 6 and 12 November were 47 per cent lower than the same week in the previous year. Three weeks ago beef amounted to 25 per cent of all meat purchases in France. But now it is only 13 per cent, according to pollsters Secodip.

In this climate, it is no surprise that French butchers were on the defensive yesterday. 'There's no problem with our beef,' said Gilbert Fabre, a butcher in the Rue Ober-kampf, Paris. 'It all comes from naturally raised herds in Limousin. They eat grass, not muck.' So how does he account for the slump in sales? 'Panic. The media have exaggerated the problem.'

His cleaver-wielding assistant Thierry, 19, was also keen to blame the messenger. 'Let's get this straight,' said Thierry. 'You're English and a journalist? That's perfect. It was the English who created the mad cow problem, thanks to their poisonous animal feeds. And it's the journalists who are making the problem worse by spreading panic.'

Whether the media are to blame or not, French people are certainly in a panic about what they eat. 'When they sit down to eat, the French are getting more and more suspicious about what's on their plate,' lamented Le Monde this week. About 63 per cent of French people think that what they eat is a danger to their health, according to a report published on Thursday by the national lifestyle research centre, Credoc. The report also found that French people have detected a general decline in the quality of the foods they buy in the past decade.

And no wonder. In France recently, chickens have been found to be polluted with dioxins, and last month there was even a listeria outbreak among geese raised in Périgord. In France this year 112 cases of BSE have been discovered, compared with 30 in 1999 - a rise that can be explained by tougher tests for BSE introduced in June. Two people have died from the human vCJD in France, compared with 80 in Britain. Such developments are disturbing in France, a country which lives to eat.

In this climate few farmers are happy. The French Association of Ostrich Breeders has reported a 30 per cent rise in sales of its meat.

Olivia Lyon was one of the few customers I saw buying beef yesterday. 'This faux filet is wonderful,' she said. 'It's on special offer down the street - there you can get it for 54 francs a kilo, but here it's 95. The difference is in the quality.' Why does she think the beef she's just bought is safe? 'Because I know my butcher. I've been coming here for years. I trust him.'

Both French butchers and beef farmers are engaged in a desperate public relations campaign to make customers think the same way as Madame Lyon. Posters in butchers' shops often proselytise that your local butcher is a man you can trust. Throughout France this weekend, the public has been invited to visit farms to see for themselves that French beef is safe. In Bourg-en-Bresse, farmers' unions have organised debates and discussions to improve public awareness. 'We're sick of being branded poisoners and polluters,' said Jean-Luc Duval, president of the young farmers' union, CNJA, who has been instrumental in organising the campaign.

But allied to this campaign, French farmers are also mounting blockades this weekend to protest at partial bans on exports of their beef in Spain, Austria, Greece, Italy and Holland, as well as what they describe as a derisory £320 million aid package offered to them last week by Agriculture Minister Jean Glavany. They will be setting up blockades at key motorway junctions to halt meat trucks coming from abroad.

Foreign beef has been targeted partly because French farmers are exasperated at blockades preventing their beef entering neighbouring countries, but also because such measures won't upset French shoppers. With beef sales in freefall, the last thing farmers want to do is to irritate customers.

'We must be careful not to upset the consumer. That would be a catastrophe,' said a spokesman for the young farmers' union. Out, then, goes that hitherto very popular blockading tactic les opérations escargots, or go-slow drives along motorways. Out, too, go blockades of refineries, which farmers had considered.

Meat and bonemeal feed is widely believed to be the source of BSE, and French farmers blame Britain for selling them contaminated bone-meal in the 1980s and 1990s. It is banned as a feedstuff for cattle and other ruminants in the European Union, and France has extended the ban on feeding meat and bonemeal to all livestock and pets.

The German Chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, said on Friday that a full-scale meat and bonemeal ban was likely to be imposed in Germany from Monday and called for an EU-wide ban to follow. The Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeit-ung reported that Germany planned to ban people from giving blood if they had lived in Britain for more than six months between 1980 and 1996 to combat the spread of the human form of BSE.

Agriculture Ministers will hold talks on the BSE crisis on 4 December. The European Commissioner responsible for health and consumer protection, David Byrne, said he would press for 'maximum control measures'.

webTitle: Maria Scott: Hostile Halifax needs reality check

fields.headline: Hostile Halifax needs reality check
fields.trailText: The Halifax, traditionally a stoical and unbendingly unemotional institution, is resorting to undignified mud-slinging to get its message across.
fields.body:
Times really must be getting tough for mortgage lenders. The Halifax, traditionally a stoical and unbendingly unemotional institution, is resorting to undignified mud-slinging to get its message across.

It responded to rival Nationwide's rate cut last week with a stinging attack on the building society's move, puffing up one of its own products as far superior. Halifax's mortgages have become more competitive of late, but its customers owe much of this to competition over the last two years from Nationwide.

Halifax points out in its attack that it is contacting customers to offer them better deals, but this requires borrowers on the standard variable rate - 7.74 per cent, against Nationwide's new rate of 7.09 per cent - to make a switch to get a better deal. At Nationwide, everyone paying a standard rate receives a reasonable deal. Borrowers who are disinclined to shop around at the end of a special deal will pay that rate.

Halifax doth protest a little too much.

The Government's proposed new system for speeding up the house buying process could have far-reaching implications for the way we look after our properties.

The new system will require that sellers have their properties surveyed before they are put on the market. If the surveys are to be worthwhile they should identify any defects that could, under today's chaotic system, scupper a sale.

In the pilot scheme conducted to test the Government's reforms, surveyors and estate agents criticised the reports for lack of detail. Assuming that the surveys are beefed up, it will be more difficult to offload a property that has faults.

The new system should, therefore, put homeowners under pressure to maintain their properties to avoid nasty surprises when the time comes to sell.

As most of us know, property maintenance is expensive and often not budgeted for in the euphoria that goes with the purchase of a property. Even if you have the money, finding reliable experts to put problems right is a hit and miss business.

The Government plans a pilot scheme for accrediting builders, and the new house-buying system should focus ministerial minds on homeowners' need to obtain easy access to reliable builders at fair prices.

webTitle: Euro force will beef up Nato

fields.headline: Euro force will beef up Nato
fields.standfirst:
US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright and our Foreign Secretary Robin Cook hit back at critics

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright and our Foreign Secretary Robin Cook hit back at critics.
fields.body:
As colleagues over the past three years, we have faced many challenges together. None has been greater than that in the Balkans, where Nato launched a successful campaign to reverse Milosevic's brutal ethnic cleansing in Kosovo. Nato met the challenge of Kosovo, but that crisis offers some important lessons for the alliance and for Europe.

A central lesson is that not enough European armed forces are ready for the diverse, rapidly evolving challenges of the post-Cold War world. Too many are trained and equipped to defend against a threat that no longer exists.

In response to these changes, Nato has modernised its strategic concept and launched a defence capabilities initiative. Britain's Strategic Defence Review has committed the United Kingdom to a real defence spending increase for the first time in 15 years.

But Europe as a whole needs to do more to strengthen its contribution to alliance missions. It also should assume greater responsibility for common security and defence and act quickly and effectively in fast-breaking crises.

Tony Blair's European defence initiative, launched with France in 1998, is a response to these needs. It will improve the European Union's crisis management capacity and develop, in cooperation with Nato, a European security and defence policy on the basis of improved European capabilities.

A key benchmark of success will be the British-inspired headline goal, which commits EU nations to be able to deploy up to 60,000 soldiers by 2003 at 60 days' notice, for crisis-management operations lasting at least a year.

Last week in Brussels, European nations took some welcome first steps to achieving this end. Forces to meet the headline goal were offered by EU countries, non-EU European allies and EU candidate countries.

EU nations committed themselves to the capability improvements necessary to achieve the goal in full by 2003. Nato and the EU will work together to ensure that shortfalls are met and that the planning to meet capability goals of both organisations is co-ordinated.

This is a work in progress; there is no room for complacency. European forces must become more mobile, deployable and sustainable. They must improve their lift, logistics and intelligence capacities.

That is why we believe that European nations are on the right track toward developing more capable forces which can meet today's challenges and tomorrow's crises. And that is why our governments fully support Europe's common security and defence policy and the contribution it can make to European and transatlantic security.

What does European defence involve? It means that European contributions to Nato operations, in the Balkans now, and perhaps elsewhere in the future, will be stronger and more effective. It means that where Nato as a whole chooses not to become engaged, the EU will be able to act in response to humanitarian crises, to provide disaster relief and also undertake peace-keeping tasks.

It means that European nations, inside and outside the EU, will be ready and able to offer forces for EU-led operations and be afforded the opportunity to participate, just as they have in Nato-led operations in Bosnia and Kosovo.

Europe's security and defence policy is not and will not become a European army run from Brussels. Any military operation organised by the EU will require the consent of every member state. Any national deployment will be a matter for that nation to decide.

Nor is this a blueprint for dividing Europe or the Atlantic alliance. Nato remains the foundation of the collective defence of its members. An important part of this initiative is the crafting of new arrangements to link the EU and Nato in unprecedented ways, laying the foundation for a true strategic partnership between the two key institutions of the West.

Nato military expertise has helped EU nations define their capability needs. The EU has welcomed the offer of assured access to Nato planning. None has been greater than that in the Balkans, where Nato launched a successful campaign to reverse Milosevic's brutal ethnic cleansing in Kosovo. Nato met the challenge of Kosovo, but that crisis offers some important lessons for the alliance and for Europe. A central lesson is that not enough European armed forces are ready for the diverse, rapidly evolving challenges of the post-Cold War world. Too many are trained and equipped to defend against a threat that no longer exists. In response to these changes, Nato has modernised its strategic concept and launched a defence capabilities initiative. Britain's Strategic Defence Review has committed the United Kingdom to a real defence spending increase for the first time in 15 years. But Europe as a whole needs to do more to strengthen its contribution to alliance missions. It also should assume greater responsibility for common security and defence and act quickly and effectively in fast-breaking crises. Tony Blair's European defence initiative, launched with France in 1998, is a response to these needs. It will improve the European Union's crisis management capacity and develop, in cooperation with Nato, a European security and defence policy on the basis of improved European capabilities. webTitle: Israel could be forced to accept observer mission

fields.headline: Israel could be forced to accept observer mission
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Senior Israeli officials have conceded that they may be forced to accept the deployment of an international observer force, following a week of intense diplomatic pressure from Britain, France and the United States.
fields.byline: Virginia Quirke in Jerusalem and Peter Beaumont
fields.body:
Senior Israeli officials have conceded that they may be forced to accept the deployment of an international observer force, following a week of intense diplomatic pressure from Britain, France and the United States.

Continuing negotiations in New York have persuaded officials that, despite their opposition to the creation of an observer mission to monitor the violence, as demanded by Palestinian President Yasser Arafat, they may be forced to back down to keep the support of the US and other key allies.

The Observer understands that three options are under consideration. The first is a UN monitor force operating under the mandate of the UN Security Council and deployed on both Israeli and Palestinian sides of the confrontation lines.

The unarmed force would be multinational in flavour and several hundred strong. Although favoured by the permanent members of the Security Council, the principal Israeli objection stems from its complaint that the 'non-aligned' countries sitting on the council are often pro-Palestinian.

A second option would be for a mission drawn from countries such as the US, France, Britain and Norway operating as an invited force, but not under UN auspices. The third option - considered the least likely - would see a force placed under the umbrella of the commission of inquiry into the present violence being led by the former US senator and Northern Ireland peace negotiator, George Mitchell.

Israel objects in principle to the deployment of an observer force, saying it suits the Palestinian agenda of attempting to 'internationalise' the crisis and dilute America's influence in the peace process, which Palestinians claim favours Israel. Israel claims that the deployment of the force would 'reward' the Palestinians for their violence.

The moves came as Palestinian reformers launched an attack on the culture of cronyism and corruption surrounding Arafat.

In the first signs of a genuine split within Arafat's Fatah movement - between the old guard that sustained Arafat in exile abroad and a younger generation that grew up in Palestine itself - a leading Fatah activist last week accused corrupt officials of endangering the two-month-old Al Aqsa intifada.

The Palestinian newspaper Al-Hayat al-Jadida last week called for an 'institutional uprising' to remove crooked officials. In his article, writer Kamal al-Astal said the Palestinian leadership was jeopardising the 'blood of martyrs'. He accused Arafat's officials of using their positions for personal gain.
