webTitle: A tide of partisan poison  engulfs America

fields.headline: A tide of partisan poison  engulfs America
fields.standfirst:
Both sides are digging in for the four-year battle to come, reports Ed Vulliamy

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Both sides are digging in for the four-year battle to come, reports  Ed Vulliamy
fields.body:
'Don't speak too soon, for the wheel's still in spin,' counselled Bob Dylan four decades ago. 'And there's no tellin' who that it's naming; For the loser now will be later to win.' It makes a perfect soundtrack to another week of ferocious tug of war in the epic election that refuses to end.

But while the times in Florida are a-changing, with a frantic see-saw motion between the camps of Al Gore and George Bush, a deeper tide rips beneath the ebb and flow of litigation and ballot counts.

It is an undercurrent of political acrimony and ideological vitriol ready to engulf all of America, as supporters of Bush and Gore prepare to turn the next four years of American politics into a scorched terrain of political warfare.

At the end of a week of court orders and counter-orders, challenges and counter-challenges, recounts and counter-counts, Bush is poised (again) to claim victory and the US presidency at 5pm today, while Gore is resolved to challenge any such declaration.

In case things do not go his way as the deadline for re-counting ballots passes, Bush has secured a hearing next Friday before the highest authority in the land, the US Supreme Court, aiming to overturn all the recounts which snatched the moment of victory claimed for him in Florida at the start of last week.

It is the first time in history that the court - guardian of no less than the US Constitution itself - will have been asked to adjudicate on the Presidency; and it is astonishing that the court, which usually deliberates at a snail's pace on America's equivalent of the Ten Commandments, should decide to move and claim jurisdiction on such a fast track.

And by way of an added complication, a new player burst onto the scene on Friday night, further muddying the putrid waters between politics and the law: the Republican speaker of the Florida state legislature, Tom Feeney, said the House would join Governor Bush in his appeal to the US Supreme Court. He set up a special committee to supervise the counting of ballots and accused the (Democrat-nominated) Supreme Court of his own state, which had ordered the recounts to go ahead, of defying the 'accuracy and fairness' of the vote

Thus the battle line between political parties now perfectly divides the supposedly independent machinery assigned to pilot the democratic electoral process.

Meanwhile, Gore's own tally in the counts that press ahead amid baying crowds in Broward and Palm Beach is rising by numbers closer to his original, optimistic estimates. With Bush's lead down to around 700 and Palm Beach still counting, Gore's hopes have taken another hike, on borrowed time, as the counts move towards the deadline of 5pm today.

But whichever way the result finally goes it will be, in Winston Churchill's phrase, no more than 'the end of the beginning'. The casting of votes by the Electoral College next month, and the pomp of the inauguration of either man next January, cannot but be tainted, not only by the events that brought it about, but by the prospect of four years of a Presidency faced by a bare-knuckled opposition bent on subverting what is already being called a coup d'état.

One thing is for sure: if the manual recount had gone ahead in the Democrat megalopolis of Miami-Dade, rather than being stopped by the county canvassing board, which said it could not meet today's deadline, Gore would by now be preparing to move offices in the White House, with no thought of moving out. The decision by the board, made up of Democrat Lawrence King and two Democrat-leaning independents, yet again snatched victory from Gore's grasp and was the first, and for the Democrats baffling, defiance of party affiliation in the entire saga. The circumstance led to allegations that the body was intimidated by Republican pressure - from crowds storming the corridors of the civic building and from Florida's heavy-handed Republican Secretary of State, Katherine Harris.

Republican militants have been mobilised into rowdy demonstrations which, say the Democrats, have intimidated local authorities with what the aspirant Democrat Vice-President, Joe Lieberman, on Friday night called 'the rule of the mob'.

Senator Lieberman accused 'public relations' organisations under the direct authority of the Republican Party of orchestrating the demonstrations, and challenged the party to call them off. Local Democratic representative Peter Deutsch called them a 'paid mob trying to disrupt the result of a fair democratic ballot'.

The Republican Party said simply that its mobile rent-a-crowd, which bussed its way from Miami to Broward County on Friday, was made up of angry counting monitors and 'the new face of the Republican Party'.

But away from the Florida limelight, in Washington DC, there were stirrings last week that seemed to justify the ire of both Lieberman and Deutsch; signs that the mobs in Florida are the shape of things to come, and visible preparations for a rebellion against an embryonic Gore presidency which would make the conspiracies mounted against Bill Clinton look like a schoolyard game.

From the conservative think-tanks to talk radio and the Wall Street Journal, there was a roar of anger from names familiar from the days of the impeachment scandal, who are now coming forward with language they refrained from using even against their betes noires , Bill and Hillary Clinton.

One of the ring-leaders of America's conservative Right, former Education Secretary William Bennett, threatened that the election would be 'illegitimate' if it were won by Gore, whom he accused of 'trying to steal this election... This may be the worst thing I have ever seen'.

His sentiment was echoed by columnists and activists who propelled the impeachment of President Clinton: Peggy Noonan, grande dame of the anti-Clinton hard Right, also accused Gore, in the Wall Street Journal , of 'stealing the election'. The conservative George Will accused the Vice-President of 'slow-motion larceny', and of harbouring a 'corrupting hunger for power'.

The pressure groups and publications that built the groundswell for impeachment are back in action: the rhetoric of talk show host Rush Limbaugh has gone into overdrive, and Grover Norquist, leader of the right-wing Americans for Tax Reform, said Gore's team had 'lost the democratic branches of government; they know that in a fair fight they will lose the Presidency, and they are retreating to the redoubt of trial lawyers and politicised judges'.

The Bush legal team is led by Theodore Olson, the Washington lawyer who, as chairman of the ultra-right-wing American Spectator magazine, chaired the meeting that first launched the Troopergate scandal and the Paula Jones lawsuit against Clinton which culminated in the Lewinsky and impeachment dramas.

Thomas Mann, of the independent Brookings Institution think-tank, said the level of vitriol from conservatives had reached 'the worst of what we saw during the impeachment fervour - unbridled, self-righteous defiance and venom, bordering on McCarthyism, with accusations of traitorous behaviour'.

At the same time, the Gore camp was preparing its end-game strategy and assembling the echelons for all-out war against a Bush administration it would claim had failed to win the election, and clung to a bogus victory through 'mob rule' and deploying partisan election officials in Florida.

There are dire warnings from Capitol Hill, where the Senate is divided 50-50 and the lower House is controlled only precariously by the Republicans, that for Gore to continue down the apparently endless legal track will make bipartisan politics impossible within a riven legislature. Senator Robert Torricelli of New Jersey said openly that he thought it 'very unlikely' that Gore could amass the necessary votes, and said it was a 'political risk' to continue to contest the declared results.

But campaign manager Bill Daly and the steel core of the campaign, Lieberman, are digging in on a 'no surrender' stance. Chris Lehane, Gore's spokesman, said this was 'hardly a time to fold', insisting he remained 'extremely optimistic' about the final tally.

Ronald Klain, Gore's senior legal adviser, has pledged to challenge the returns to date from Miami-Dade county, saying that they 'fail to reflect a full, fair and accurate tally of the votes'.

Apart from fury at the influx of Republican mobs, Democrat ire has been directed against the figure of Harris. Gore's lawyer, Alan Dershowitz, calls the Secretary of State 'a crook and an operative', while Paul Begala, Svengali behind the Gore campaign, daubed her 'a dilettante, debutante Republican hack'.

If there is no President by tomorrow night, the spotlight moves north from Florida to the grand stage of the national capital and the Supreme Court itself.

So far, apart from the infamous case of the Miami-Dade board, barely a single 'neutral' official in Florida has defied party affiliation - not the Republicans nor Democrats on the county canvassing commissions, not Katherine Harris, not the Florida legislature, not even the judges of the Florida Supreme Court, six of whom were appointed by Democrats. Cynics have come to believe that the single lesson to be learnt from this drama is that politics is above the law, rather than vice-versa.

If such party-predictable logic were to apply to the highest authority, Bush would hold the advantage - but only just.

The present court, headed by the conservative Chief Justice William Rehnquist, is the most narrowly divided for decades. The court has a history as a bastion of the Right, but two appointments by Clinton turned it into a closely balanced scale which the slightest weight can tip decisively to right or left - which is, incidentally, exactly what both Bush and Gore intend to do, in opposite directions, on assuming office.

Although the court is made up of seven judges nominated by Republican Presidents, and only two by Clinton, its decisions on major issues over the past two Presidential terms have invariably been settled 5-4, occasionally 6-3, with Clinton's judges, Stephen Beyer and Ruth Bader Ginsburg, cancelling out the ultra-conservatives Antonin Scalia and Clarence Thomas, who consistently take a hard right-wing line (Bush has consistently praised both of them).

In between are moderate Republicans and Justice Sandra O'Connor, a 'floating' independent. And, by next weekend, she could be the latest in the now long line of people deemed to 'hold the Presidency in their hands'.

Above Judge O'Connor and her colleagues, however, there is no terrestrial authority to which either side can appeal.

webTitle: Comment: There'll be a pygmy in the White House

fields.headline: There'll be a pygmy in the White House
fields.standfirst:
Whether it's President Gush or President Bore, the United States will - eventually - have a leader in office, but a leader without power

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Whether it's President Gush or President Bore, the United States will - eventually - have a leader in office, but a leader without power.
fields.body:
Here are some suggestions from America about how Al Gore and George Bush should resolve who takes charge of a nuclear arsenal that can destroy the planet several times over.

The Veep and the Governor pull the wishbone from the carcass of a Thanksgiving turkey. Whoever grasps the bigger twig gets to be President. The snag with this is that the loser would instantly unleash a slew of law suits accusing the other contestant of twisting the wishbone.

The Chief Justice of the Supreme Court flips a commemorative 'Indecision 2000' coin. Make it a dime, which will be the rough value of the presidency by the time this is decided. The snafu is that the coin is fated to land on its edge.

My favourite solution is for Al Gore and George Bush to meet on the White House lawn to fight a duel, the most popular outcome of which would be that both men prove to be fatally accurate shots. The trouble is that everything that has happened so far warns you that both would miss.

It's Groundhog Day in the United States: today, every day of the last 18, and many more days into the future, as America finds itself imprisoned in an endless circle populated by lawyers and pundits leaping from whichever legal or ethical contention might serve to secure the outcome they want. Some nightfalls, it's a smugger Gore who has inched closer to the Oval Office; other midnights, it's a perkier Bush creeping forward. Though the fine details of the arguments change, the cycle doesn't. Each morning, the United States wakes up to find that it still doesn't know the identity of its next head of state.

Tomorrow, the famous pregnant chads may have given birth to just enough little votes for Gore to move Florida into his column. But if the Democrat is still losing, he won't be conceding. His legal gunslingers will ride back to court. If George Bush is the loser in the alligator state, he isn't talking about taking defeat on a dignified chin. The Republicans speak apocalyptically of using their majorities in the Florida legislature to overturn a result for Gore which would mean Jeb Bush signing his older brother into the Oval Office.

You want lurid scenarios? They're piling them high, they're selling them cheap, all the way up to the Supremes. One Democrat tells me that the only reason there won't be a civil war with bullets is because the Republicans have got all the guns.

The impasse will be overcome eventually because it must be overcome. One of the protagonists, let us call him President Bore, will be sworn in on 20 January. But this man, let us call him President Gush, will have won the emptiest of victories. A halo of illegitimacy will now attend whoever takes the office. After the dead heat, the deadlock; after the deadlock, the dead presidency.

Most of the United States won't much care. Whether it's Bush or Gore, only a quarter of Americans will have voted for their President. They moan like hell about gridlock in Washington, but you fancy Americans must secretly like semi-paralysing their government, otherwise they wouldn't keep making it happen. They are going to get a Senate split down the middle, and a President in name, but not a great deal more.

That's because the partisans do care. They care with a passion that has moved beyond the frontiers of reason and logic into the swamps of pure venom. The language being used by the antagonists is more inflammatory than during the impeachment of Bill Clinton. Republicans already talk of boycotting the inauguration of President Gore. The air is acrid with charge and counter-cry of cheat and hypocrite, chicanery and criminality. A presidency born out of so much contention will be a weakling thing, deprived of a mandate for reform and the authority to take dynamic and creative action. Whenever the Commander in Chief attempts to do anything big, bold or controversial, the losing side will undermine him by chanting 'Hail to the Thief'. Whoever gets to sip from this chalice is going to find that it is foaming with poison.

This hands a couple of advantages to Bush. Gore will be a weak President because vengeful Republicans in Congress will be determined to finish him off before he has even started. Dubya will be a weak President because he's an intellectual void who only got interested in politics late in life when old man Bush told him that the White House kitchen makes a nice jelly sandwich and behind the West Wing there 's a really neat putting green. Bush the Second won't mind being gridlocked; it's the bespoke excuse to take longer naps. If the President is going to be lame, then it helps to be the guy who will take that lying down, snoozing.

Dubya's other edge is that the Republicans hate Al Gore much more than the Democrats love the Vice-President. While the Right is ferociously hungry to reoccupy the White House, there's a jaded appetite for the throne among Democrats. Many of them are saying, more or less openly, that a period in opposition will be cleansing after the morally stained ambiguities of the Clinton chapter. They surmise that a Dubya presidency will actually be good for Democrats, so long as they are not Democrats called Gore. It would virtually guarantee that they will make large gains in the Congressional elections in two years time, and make it more likely that they will capture the White House in 2004.

You will note the absence from this Machiavellian calculation of a care for what Republicans might in the meantime try to do to the people for whom the Democrats claim to care. It is this sort of politics-by-numbers that has brought America to its present nadir. No one ever thought that the insufferable Gore or the ineffable Bush possessed faces that were candidates for being carved on Mount Rushmore. No one ever mistook either man for a Washington, a Lincoln or an FDR. Neither has ever hinted at being more than an average occupant of the Oval Office. Stripped of the authority which comes from legitimacy, they are unlikely even to vault that low.

A pygmy President may be what America deserves. It is certainly what Americans have engineered. The United States is in its second Gilded Age. The first era of that name, in the late nineteenth century, was characterised by sustained and complacent prosperity presided over by nonentities who are only remembered now, when they are recalled at all, for their scandals. This was the era when Rutherford B. Hayes lost the popular vote, but was fixed into the White House. Permanently embattled by recriminations and ever after known as 'His Fraudulency', four grisly years in office ended with not one achievement of consequence. The best guess is that President Gore/Bush will be a one-term unwonder.

The good news is that a pygmy President probably can't do the rest of the world too much harm. The bad news is that he will not be equipped to do the rest of the world any good. The chances of America taking its fair share of responsibility for despoiling the planet - and this will be particularly true of President Dubya - will be even closer to zero. For Europeans, a disengaging United States may actually turn out to be the beneficial spur we need to take proper responsibility for our own continent. The European rapid reaction force may come to be seen as a farsighted preparation for the encroaching day when the Yanks fold their tents. In the shorter term, an America which treats the rest of the planet like an absentee landlord is likely to make parts of the world, not least the Middle East, more dangerous.

Abdicating abroad and impotent at home, whichever of the protagonists eventually snatches the presidential seal will have office without power. Air Force One is a fabulous ride, but it won't be taking its next owner to a destination anywhere near greatness. This will be a job fit for someone who is excited by the idea of having the title but not animated by what can be achieved with the office.

And that suggests that the man most likely to be the next President of the United States is George W. Bush, if only because the most apt outcome of a contest for a booby prize is to award it to the prize booby.

The snag with this is that the loser would instantly unleash a slew of law suits accusing the other contestant of twisting the wishbone. The Chief Justice of the Supreme Court flips a commemorative 'Indecision 2000' coin. Make it a dime, which will be the rough value of the presidency by the time this is decided. webTitle: Comment: Austin Morgan's  The Belfast Agreement

fields.headline: Good Friday, but for who?
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Since the Good Friday Agreement a Sinn Fein strategy has been to portray the settlement as a stepping stone towards a united Ireland.
fields.body:
Since the Good Friday Agreement a Sinn Fein strategy has been to portray the settlement as a stepping stone towards a united Ireland. The Provisionals' spokesmen have set off green flares aimed at deflecting the republican base from zeroing in on the partitionist core of the 1998 historic compromise. As the republican movement marched en masse towards the Stormont parliament they once vowed to smash, their generals shrouded the political battlefield in emerald mists, convincing foot soldiers they were about to plant the Tricolour in triumph over unionist trenches.

Now the fog that descended over the political landscape is clearing. That Sinn Fein are using the courts to try to overturn David Trimble's ban on republicans attending North/South Ministerial Council meetings indicates their concern that a central truth about the agreement is finally exposed. Trimble's ban on Martin McGuinness and Bairbre de Brun is evidence that the unionist veto is alive and well. The First Minister's ability to bar Sinn Fein Ministers from what republicans regard as the crucial aspect of the agreement has rekindled suspicions that the accord has underpinned partition and the unionist consent principle. Combined with Mandelson's ruling that the Union Flag must fly over McGuinness's and de Brun's departments, Trimble's action marks a significant victory for pro-agreement unionism.

Nationalists might protest that the agreement belongs to everyone but at its heart Good Friday signified a major compromise. The Irish government dropped the territorial claim and Sinn Fein agreed to enter a partitionist parliament. In essence, the agreement doesn't imply a move towards unity.

With the smoke of propaganda fading, Austin Morgan's The Belfast Agreement: a Practical Legal Analysis is dense legalistic prose which, if you bear with it, provides a map to help you through the blur of rhetoric and lies.

Morgan, a Derry-born London-based barrister, in a segment on constitutional matters says that 'the constitutional changes brought about by the Belfast Agreement are characterised predominantly by the end of the territorial claim over Northern Ireland' rather than a weakening of the link with the UK. He stresses the importance Northern Ireland's May 1998 referendum, noting that the simultaneous vote in the Republic was just to change the 1936 Irish Constitution and overturn articles two and three. It was the vote in the North that counted. The veto survived.

He also takes southern legal and political figures to task for talking up the repeal of the 1920 Government of Ireland Act, particularly section 75. Morgan notes that this section is about parliamentary sovereignty over domestic law, not the territorial sovereignty of the UK. Given the vagaries of the unwritten British constitution, there never was a British territorial claim over the North that could be ditched.

Elsewhere Morgan deals with the North-South bodies and how Trimble's unionists pruned back the areas that were to be dealt with on an all-Ireland basis, noting 'the area changed most in the last days of Castle Buildings was Strand Two, in particular the matters designed for practical cooperation'. He adds that initially there were 49 matters that would be dealt with on an all-Ireland framework. By Good Friday this had been reduced to 12.

Morgan's analysis would be an ideal Christmas present for republican dissidents such as Rurai O'Bradaigh or Bernadette Sands-McKevitt. It would undoubtedly confirm their suspicions that the Agreement has not eroded British sovereignty and may have given unionists the ability to manage change within the northern state. The book should also go into a few stockings in sceptical unionist households. It might convince them that something was actually achieved two years ago.

 'The Belfast Agreement: a Practical Legal Analysis' can be purchased on the internet at:www.austenmorgan.com.

webTitle: Heather Connon: Buying cheap but not piling it high

fields.headline: Buying cheap but not piling it high
fields.trailText: Buy cheap and sell dear. For much of the past five years, that old stock market adage has been turned on its head.
fields.body:
Buy cheap and sell dear. For much of the past five years, that old stock market adage has been turned on its head. Those who bought shares because they were cheap often found themselves selling out even more cheaply - Marks & Spencer, British Airways, Imperial Chemical Industries or Rentokil, for instance. It seemed the only way to make money was to buy expensive shares and wait for them to get more expensive.

That could be changing. The collapse in technology stocks - the perfect example of the dear getting dearer - has been obvious for some weeks. What has attracted less attention, however, is the gradual recovery in some of the cheap stocks. Indeed, three of the four companies mentioned earlier, M&S being the exception, have been among the best performers in the FTSE 100 index in the past two months; BA alone has risen by more than a third since the start of October.

Overall, Dresdner Kleinwort Benson calculates that value investors - the jargon term for those who buy cheap - have done 15 per cent better than growth investors in the last month.

So is value investing making a comeback? It is still too early to say. The hysteria that sent technology stocks soaring at the start of the year is slowly evaporating. Likewise, investors are realising that some of our traditional companies are not facing Armageddon.

But there is still a huge gap between the valuation of old- and new-economy companies. Shares in Bookham Technology, which makes components for fibre-optic networks, are worth less than a quarter of their peak price, but are still valued at more than 100 times analysts' forecasts of next year's earnings. BA's shares may have soared recently but they are still worth just half their 1997 peak. Will the gap continue to narrow? Or will investors resume their love affair with the new economy?

Certainly, many technology shares still look hugely overvalued. No doubt a few will eventually prove that they were worth their astronomical valuations, but it will take years. Growth investors could, therefore, find themselves struggling.

The price of many traditional companies, however, is still low by historic standards. In some cases, that may be justified: shoppers are still wondering if M&S can ever get its offering right again; Corus (the former British Steel) continues to be dogged by high fuel prices.

So investors still have to guard against buying companies just because they are cheap. It is essential to look beyond the simple valuation statistics, such as price-earnings multiples and yields, to appreciate whether they have a profitable future. Among those worth considering are Great Universal Stores, Safeway, Bass and Halifax, all of which seem to be pulling themselves together well. Wait at least until the new year before buying into growth companies: they may be a lot cheaper by then.

fields.headline: Our future is European
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Mid-term byelections usually run against the government of the day, but the clutch held on Thursday gave no sign of positive discontent with the Blair administration.
fields.body:
Mid-term byelections usually run against the government of the day, but the clutch held on Thursday gave no sign of positive discontent with the Blair administration. Yet there was an eloquence in the silence of thousands who stayed away, producing in Anniesland the lowest turnout in a Scottish by-election since the war.

Perhaps so large an abstention carried the gravest warning for Labour, implying a sullen kind of apathy flowing from a dislike for the ideological blandness of Blairism or a complacency about the continuing feebleness of the opposition. The Nationalist dogs failed to bark and, like the silent t in Montrachet, the Tory rump still seems part of an antique orthography.

It was with a sense of shock, indeed of resentment, that I switched on the news last week to find Lady Thatcher once more dominating our screens with her eccentric views on Britain's place in the world - which stop just short of proposing that we should become the fifty-first state.

It was after her ejection from the leadership, in 1994, that she came to the Nato summit in Turnberry to enunciate her vision of an 'Atlanticism' to which Britain would owe its primary loyalty. Her anti-Europeanism, which had festered during the latter years of her premiership, had crystallised into a theory formalising Britain's dependence on the American shield.

Her evocation of the war years last week was faux-Churchillian. She appears to have forgotten that her great hero was an early enthusiast for the European cause. And if it was pathetic to see her creature, William Hague, obediently jump out of his box at her bidding, and tedious to see the xenophobic and racist elements in our press once more leap to the battlements, there was also a quality of tragedy about her pronouncements.

Even as she spoke the mood music from the putative Bush administration was discordant. Thatcher remains a hero for Republicans, certainly; but their admiration does not mean they endorse continued European military dependency on the US. Indeed, during the election campaign a senior Bush aide has said his administration would pull troops out of peace-keeping commitments in the Balkans, concentrating itself on the Gulf and other regions where America's vital interest - in a word, oil - requires protection.

Yet this great country which Lady Thatcher so uncritically admires last week almost sabotaged the Hague conference on the environment. It continues, through its enormous current account deficit, to live off the rest of the world. Worst of all, it has the temerity to pass extra-terrestrial legislation and try foreign subjects in its courts while refusing to ratify the International Criminal Court. Now, we discover, it can't even count its election results.

The cultural domination of America cannot be stopped, of course, although it can be resisted. It has long been the complacent habit of the British to mock French attempts to preserve the purity of their beautiful language. But last week our own Government issued guidelines to avoid the creep of American orthography into written English.

If there was one positive note from last week's political transactions, it lay in Tony Blair's new and welcome determination to confront xenophobes and Little Englanders. Sensing a brutish popular dislike of foreigners, his administration has been fearful of having to fight the election on unfavourable ground. The weakness of the euro, which may be approaching an end, has given the new currency little attraction.

But an election must necessarily be fought on many issues. Michael Portillo said the other day that the chief antithesis would be between tax cuts and more public expenditure. But Labour must also have the courage to speak more clearly on the European question, and to assert that our future lies there rather than in dependency on American might and the American Right.

webTitle: Comment: The Tories and the sugar industry

fields.headline: The beet goes on
fields.standfirst:
The Tories defending Third World sugar growers? No, the Tories up to their usual tricks: Irvine's law: the rich shall inherit the work

Special report: World Trade Organisation
fields.trailText: The Tories defending Third World sugar growers? No, the Tories up to their usual tricks:  Irvine's law: the rich shall inherit the work.
fields.body:
On Wednesday, Clare Short stood up in the Commons with a reasonable expectation of being asked about the great issues which fill the days of her International Development Department. The bloodbath in the Middle East was topical, as was the war in the Congo, and famine, drought and flood. Yet none of these man-made disasters disturbed Conservative MPs. They wanted to get down to the real business of shouting about sugar.

When the conversation was in danger of turning to such trivial matters as whether aid should be given to kleptomaniac dictators, James Paice interrupted with a 'May I take the Right Hon lady back to the issue of sugar?' When the religious war in Sudan, which has cost 1,500,000 lives, was raised, Cheryl Gillan butted in with 'Of the 48 least and less-developed countries, 21 produce sugar, and Sudan has the largest sugar production among them'.

A faintly bewildered Short sat down and Tony Blair took the floor to be confronted by another sweet-toothed Tory. John Greenway wasted one of the few opportunities he will get in his career to interrogate the Prime Minister by hitting him with a sugar question. Blair did not quite reply 'Sugar? Come again?' but few would have blamed him if he had.

The Conservatives addressed the PM and Short in the concerned, simpering tone of the new Portilloised party. Caribbean islands faced devastation and impoverishment, they warned, and for a moment a cynic could be convinced that they truly cared about the plight of the Third World. It is always worth counting your fingers after a compassionate Conservative has squeezed your hand. In this instance, the reckoning shows that the Conservatives have allied with sugar interests and the most pampered farmers in Europe in an attempt to destroy an initiative to give back to the poorest people on the planet a little of the money we screw from them. They may yet succeed.

The World Trade Organisation can now meet only behind regiments of riot police because of the disgust at how the wretched of the Earth are treated. The free trade enforced by the Washington consensus flows in one direction. The poor must open their markets to Western corporations, but the favour is rarely returned.

Oxfam estimates that backward countries lose $700 billion (£460bn) a year because of tariffs and barriers in Europe, North America and Japan. Third World farmers suffer most, not only from the formal charges but from the constraints health faddism brings. The European Union insists that dairy products, for example, must come from cows which have been mechanically milked and thus bans virtually every Indian smallholder from exporting.

The WTO has lived up to its reputation for being a protection racket for the wealthy and done nothing. Its failure provoked Pascal Lamy, the European Trade Commissioner, to be generous to the South. The poorest 48 countries, mainly in Africa, should have unrestricted access to EU markets, he decided. There would be no tariffs and no quotas. They would be free to sell any product except arms.

As Short herself admits, the largess from Brussels will not change the world. The 600 million people living in the 48 nations have an average annual income of £191 - or 52 pence a day. Their importing and exporting accounts for a mere 0.4 per cent of world trade. As far as global capitalism is concerned, they might as well be dead - and many soon will be.

Nevertheless, Lamy's gesture would at least bring benefits to a few and end the enormous hypocrisy of a 'free' market which becomes very restrictive indeed when the traders and producers have black or brown skins. Unfortunately, he will probably be defeated by the power of the ferocious sugar lobby.

There is no reason why Europe needs to grow sugar beet rather than import sugar cane from the Tropics. In the Napoleonic and First and Second World Wars, beet could be presented as a vital resource which would help frustrate a blockade.

Any conceivable modern war will either be nuclear and over pretty quickly or a guerrilla conflict which will not close the ports. Yet through production-limiting quotas, minimum prices for farmers and import restrictions, European sugar business continues to demand and receive formidable protection. The prices for consumers and industry are always twice and often three times as high as world prices.

Only the Caribbean plantations - built on slavery, the sugar industry's first contribution to a global market - are allowed to export without restriction, hence the Tory predictions of impoverishment and the insistence of the Tate & Lyle press office that journalists should concentrate on the threat to the West Indies. Neither says that Lamy merely wants to accord the poorest countries the same rights as the Caribbean. He is not trying to take West Indian rights away.

Anyone who believes that the Conservatives are motivated by altruism should look at who is behind the campaign. The National Farmers Union and British Sugar, the makers of Silver Spoon, are lobbying Parliament hard. The thought of any concession to impoverished countries is intolerable.

They won't get anywhere in Britain if Blair stands firm, although I accept that that is always a giant 'if'. But the Tories and the industry are part of a pan-European movement which has a good chance of persuading the EU to forget about Lamy's benevolence, probably with the aid a French or German veto.

The Third World and consumers will still be ripped off, but at least the Conservative Party will have re-established its role as clients of the sugar industry. From 1945 onwards, Tate & Lyle was a generous corporate sponsor. In 1996, with the party heading for defeat, the company spread its bets in a tripartisan fashion by funding New Labour and the Liberal Democrats as well as their traditional friends.

This year, Michael Portillo rebuilt bridges when he promised to abolish Labour taxes on companies which move money offshore, after Tate & Lyle, among others, had complained of the pain it would suffer from being made to pay its way. Bowen Wells, the Tory chairman of the International Development Committee, was an adviser to Michael Ashcroft, the offshore banker whose donations to the party brought him a peerage. Welles lobbied on Tate & Lyle's behalf. The company enjoyed the indulgent tax benefits offered by Ashcroft's Bank of Belize. Wells joined the assault on Short in the Commons last week.

All of which puts Conservative complaints about military cooperation in Europe into perspective. Although the party is always ready to denounce real and imaginary Euromadness, scepticism has its limits. It will fight to the last ditch to defend the most pernicious Europrivileges for its supporters regardless of the consequences for an electorate and an impoverished South which must pay for them.

Cardinal Irvine, the Lord High Chancellor of all England, art collector, Blair placeman and millionaire corporate lawyer, cuts a faintly preposterous figure when he poses as a working-class hero.

For all his unsuitability for the role, he explains that cuts in legal aid to the poorest as an act of class war against 'fat cat' lawyers on behalf of the oppressed masses rather than an assault on the welfare state. In September he took the cant of pseudo-populism further when he effectively banned defendants without means from being represented by Queen's Counsel, the most distinguished advocates. Even when they are up against a murder charge and a mandatory life sentence, they must now make do with junior barristers. Once again, meanness was justified as a legitimate defence against the greed of grasping lawyers.

As I noted the other week, Irvine was denying QCs to the swinish multitude while using public money to hire a QC to defend his reputation. What I did not realise was how much money was being spent on saving His Eminence's face.

Irvine is appealing against an employment tribunal ruling that he was guilty of indirect sex discrimination when he appointed Garry Hart as his special adviser. Hart, who worked for the enormously expensive City law firm, Herbert Smith, would push large briefs in Irvine's direction, when the Lord Chancellor was one of the fattest felines at the Bar.

Hart is the godfather of the PM's daughter and, what with one thing and another, you can see why the Lord Chancellor was fond of him.

To overturn the tribunal's impertinent rulings that unadvertised jobs and secret appointments guarantee discrimination, Irvine has hired Sir Sydney Kentridge QC, one of the best lawyers in London. Sir Sydney costs £500 an hour (135 times the minimum wage). If he is working long hours, he offers a discount. You can book his services from dawn to dusk and beyond for a mere £5,000 a day.

Sir Sydney will be assisted by Richard McManus QC, who charges a paltry £250 an hour. Just as one Jag is not enough for Prescott, one QC is not enough for Irvine - although it is one too many for the poor.

webTitle: Focus: A choice time for Blair to pick a fight

fields.headline: The gloves come off
fields.standfirst:
With the Right ranting over EU defence plans and the legacy of Thatcher, it was a choice time for Tony Blair to pick a fight. Kamal Ahmed and Gaby Hinsliff report

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: With the Right ranting over EU defence plans and the legacy of Thatcher, it was a choice time for Tony Blair to pick a fight. Kamal Ahmed and Gaby Hinsliff report.
fields.body:
In the palatial offices of the Daily Mail in Kensington, Edward Heathcoat Amory sat and stared at a blank screen. It was Wednesday morning and he had the rest of the day to write an article about the most powerful man in the British Army.

Heathcoat Amory, former Conservative Party adviser and nephew of the Tory MP David Heathcoat-Amory, was used to stirring up a hornet's nest with right-wing polemics about subjects ranging from single mothers to the outrages of multi-cultural Britain and the decline of morality in broadcasting.

But his article on General Sir Charles Guthrie was about to take him into a different league. It would be the talk of the next day's Cabinet meeting. The Prime Minister would call it a disgraceful act of 'utter desperation'. The columnist was about to make political history.

He wrote: 'When General Sir Charles Guthrie was made Chief of the Defence Staff three years ago, no one would have predicted that he would preside over the greatest political defeat inflicted on our armed forces this century. He has stood supinely by while Labour signs up to the European Army, a decision which many feel will not only undermine Nato, but will put yet another strain on our already over-stretched forces.'

The following day at 10.30am the Cabinet gathered. Tony Blair, who had been briefed about the article by Alastair Campbell, his official spokesman, was furious. The Mail had perpetrated an injustice. Guthrie, far from the 'Tony's crony' described by Heathcoat Amory, had 'served with distinction', Blair told his colleagues. Geoff Hoon, the Defence Secretary, said Guthrie was 'a first class professional soldier who had never been afraid to give first class advice'.

In a carefully stage-managed briefing to political journalists an hour later, the Government's anger with the Mail was revealed. Reporters expressed surprise that a Prime Minister who constantly insists he never reads the papers had been so riled by 600 words from someone whose name most readers would not even remember.

But it was all part of a bigger strategy, the start of a campaign to carry the Government to the next general election, now firmly expected on 3 May. Blair attacked the Mail, the voice of Middle England. He has attacked Margaret Thatcher, whom he once viewed with something approaching awe. He has taken on the Eurosceptics and accused them of fundamental dishonesty.

On the surface, the issue has been Europe and the commitment of British troops to an EU rapid reaction force. But the Government is staking out a territory that for many years it was too timid to take. Blair wants clear blue water between him and the Conservatives. To achieve that he needs enemies, and he needs to define who they are. The Tories are an enemy, but they appear weak to the public. The Mail, edited by Paul Dacre, is stronger. Thatcher has always had something of a sacred status for Blair. But attacking her sends out a strong signal that Labour is not the Conservatives. So attacked she was.

Downing Street officials admit that if the Government has learnt anything from Al Gore's failure to sweep all before him in the US presidential election, it is that simply having a strong economy is not enough to win. The people need a narrative which starts with the 'tough choices' made to gain a strong economy. This leads to Labour's investment in health, education and schools, and finally to a warning that the whole project will be at risk if the Tories get in.

A senior Downing Street aide said: 'We will keep saying this again and again. Then by the time we get to the election we will be fighting it on our territory, not anyone else's.'

Labour's election strategists have devised a campaign of 'five fundamentals'. Economic stability versus boom and bust; public investment versus £16bn of cuts; full employment versus mass unemployment; community values versus the 'no such thing as society' argument; engagement with Europe versus isolationism.

Behind it all will be the mood music of patriotism. Yesterday it was reported that Blair wants the Cabinet to stage 'patriotic campaigns'. Michael Wills, an Education Minister, has been made his 'patriotism envoy'.

Campbell and David Miliband, head of the No 10 Policy Unit, spent last week touring the offices of national newspaper editors explaining the plan. It was going into action.

A few weeks after the 1997 election, the Prime Minister entertained Thatcher to tea and an hour-long discussion at No 10. Afterwards she uttered six effusive words: 'He will not let us down.'

Labour supporters were baffled. What was a man who had spent his whole political career arguing against the party Thatcher led doing? Blair's argument was simple. Yes, Thatcher did a lot wrong, but as a conviction politician who bestrode the world stage she could not be bettered.

But the positive relationship with Thatcher was part of the early Government strategy that has been changed gradually. The first cracks appeared in 1999 when Thatcher's support for General Pinochet caused intense irritation at No 10. Thatcher thought that Blair had 'let her down'. This year, during a series of question and answer sessions around the country, Blair reiterated that although much had been done in the Eighties, the Thatcher legacy was also one of economic crisis and social division.

Now the Thatcher strategy has moved on again. She is the past. Blair is the future. She is increasingly irrelevant.

'When a big issue hits the headlines I don't believe the public are sitting around and saying, "I wonder what Margaret Thatcher thinks about that"?' said a senior Downing Street official. 'The press still get very excited about her. No one else does.'

The press's excitement was palpable last week when Thatcher agreed to speak to Trevor Kavanagh, the political editor of the Sun, whose influence is not underestimated by Downing Street. Thatcher told Kavanagh that Britain's plans to send troops to join a European rapid reaction force was a 'monumental folly'. Alongside it was a piece from Blair, criticising the Sun's coverage of the fighting force issue. At that stage he did not mention Thatcher.

Blair was asked what he thought of the Thatcher attack at Wednesday's press conference on public spending. 'We are in a new era,' he said. 'It is time we moved British politics beyond the time of Margaret Thatcher.' The coverage of Blair's comments obscured the Government's public spending message, which fortunately had been pre-briefed the day before. But Blair had got a more important message out.

In the restaurant on the sixteenth floor of the Intercontinental Hotel in Zagreb last Thursday night, Robin Cook ate a sumptuous meal with leaders of the European Union nations. They had gathered for a conference on the Balkans, and the discussions centred on the Nice European summit in less than two weeks' time. The Foreign Secretary was later joined by Blair.

The following day the 15 leaders discussed how to bring the Balkans closer to the centre of EU affairs. Blair told Cook this showed what the EU could achieve with positive engagement: it was a message they must contrast it with the Tory approach.

Blair believes the Tories have a problem with Europe, and events last week seemed to support him. Chris Patten, the European Commissioner and a former Conservative Cabinet Minister, said Hague's attack on the rapid reaction force was 'a considerable mistake'. Yesterday the Daily Telegraph published a letter in which Michael Heseltine along with Field Marshals Lord Bramall and Lord Carver said the Tory position was wrong.

'They can try and attack us on Europe but that is not a priority for the public,' said a leading Labour strategist.

Not surprisingly many on the Right do not see it that way. A dinner last Wednesday night of the No Turning Back Group, keepers of the Iron Lady's flame, was 'a very jolly affair'. Members were delighted that Europe was back on the agenda. After a few glasses of fine wine, they scribbled spoof briefing notes for Blair on Nice. Like their idol, they scented blood.

The danger for William Hague however is that, his more hardline followers may get carried away. 'The only risk is that we become victims of our own success, but we have seen that coming,' said one Tory insider. Thus there have been efforts to temper the rhetoric with professions of support for the EU.

Hague's apparent raising of his game during the European army campaign has startled Whitehall. Crucial to this success has been expert help from the Shadow Defence Secretary Iain Duncan-Smith, a former Scots Guards officer.

One casualty of last week's 'European war' was a host of Government announcements on public spending and education, which were drowned out. They will go out again, starting with the trumpeting by the Alistair Darling this week of an extra £12.5bn in this parliament, child benefit and child-centred tax credits.

But with the Nice summit approaching, these messages risk being drowned out again. Edward Heathcoat Amory will have many more columns to fill.

fields.headline: What the Supreme Court decides
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The US Supreme Court, under Chief Justice William Rehnquist turned down Bush's argument that manual recounts violated constitutional guarantees of equal protection, due process and freedom of political association.
fields.body:
The US Supreme Court, under Chief Justice William Rehnquist turned down Bush's argument that manual recounts violated constitutional guarantees of equal protection, due process and freedom of political association.

Instead it agreed to determine two tighter questions and added one of its own.

All three concern the interaction between the Florida Supreme Court's decision last Tuesday to allow recounts and a state legislature's rights under the Constitution and federal law.

Bush's lawyers argue that by letting recounts go on beyond a seven-day deadline specified in a state code, the Florida Supreme Court rewrote state law and disregarded federal law.

A section of the US code governing elections says a state's laws enacted before election day 'shall be conclusive, and shall govern in the counting of the electoral votes'.

Bush's team argues that by setting 26 November instead of 14 November for certification, the state supreme court set new rules. Gore's lawyers argue that it simply carried out an 'ordinary act' of interpreting a statute.

The US Supreme Court also agreed to decide whether the state court's ruling was inconsistent with a clause in the federal constitution which allots to each state the duty of choosing electors for the Electoral College 'in such manner as the legislature thereof may direct'. By taking up this question the court is breaking a tradition by stepping into a struggle between two branches of state government.

The question the court has added is 'what would be the consequences' of finding that the Florida court's decision did not comply with the US code? In other words, what would be the remedy?

fields.headline: Milosevic denounces 'betrayers'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: A defiant Slobodan Milosevic began his political comeback yesterday by standing as the only candidate for president of the Socialist Party at its congress in the Yugoslav capital.
fields.byline: Gillian Sandford in Belgrade and Nicholas Wood in Pristina
fields.body:
A defiant Slobodan Milosevic began his political comeback yesterday by standing as the only candidate for president of the Socialist Party at its congress in the Yugoslav capital.

It was an act of extraordinary chutzpah for a man who, facing a popular revolt less than two months before, wanted to send tanks on to the streets of Belgrade to maintain his power after election defeat.

But the former Yugoslav President was neither penitent not reformed. In a blistering anti-Western speech, he blasted the new government, describing its actions in gaining power as an on-going war.

'We all know what kind of violence and lawlessness took place after the 5 October coup,' Milosevic told the 2,300 Socialist Party delegates.

'The war which is being conducted against this country is now being conducted with money,' Milosevic said. He accused the West of wanting to bribe the new leadership so that they would allow the break-up of Yugoslavia.

The former President was defeated on 24 September in local, federal and presidential elections, but he refused to accept the results until an uprising in Belgrade on 5 October saw the police and the army side with the protesters, after which he stood down.

His congress speech laid into the new government for agreeing to co-operate with the United Nations war crimes tribunal. He said the new government was full of 'traitors' who want to hand over 'national heroes' to 'the new Gestapo'.

Meanwhile, the Yugoslav police and an Albanian guerrilla group have signed a ceasefire on Serbia's boundary with Kosovo after a week of intense fighting in which at least three people died.

The truce was signed amid increased tension within Kosovo, where senior UN officials fear that a wave of violent attacks may have ended ethnic Albanians' hopes of independence by alienating world opinion. Serbia had warned it might intervene.

A spokesman for the Nato-led K-For peacekeeping force in Kosovo said the Liberation Army for Preshevo, Buj-anovac and Mevedja (UCPMB), an off-shoot of the Kosovo Liberation Army, had signed the ceasefire last Friday evening.

The group wants independence for three Albanian-speaking areas in the Preshevo valley in southern Serbia. Flight Lieutenant Mark Whittey, a K-For spokesman, said the group was expected to hand over the bodies of three Serbian Interior Ministry police late yesterday as 'a goodwill gesture'. The three men disappeared last Tuesday during fighting around the village of Koncul.

Tension has risen in Pristina after the assassination there of a senior adviser to the leading Albanian moderate politician, Ibrahim Rugova.

webTitle: Ousted ruler may face Sierra Leone war crimes court

fields.headline: Ousted ruler may face Sierra Leone war crimes court
fields.standfirst: Special report: Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: The man who was once the youngest head of state in the world may be deported back to Sierra Leone to face war crimes charges.
fields.body:
The man who was once the youngest head of state in the world may be deported back to Sierra Leone to face war crimes charges.

Valentine Strasser, who ruled Sierra Leone with bloody consequences from 1992 to 1996, has lived in London since 1996 but his application for asylum was rejected last month.

Strasser, 34, fled to Gambia on 27 October after The Observer disclosed he was living in Islington. He had been unemployed for two years and had changed his first name to 'Reginald'.

He was detained in Gambia and deported back to Britain, where he was denied entry. He was returned to Gambia on Tuesday and was detained by military officers in Talinding, nine miles west of the capital Banjul. He is being held for questioning in the National Intelligence Bureau headquarters.

Strasser, immensely popular with his fellow soldiers and injured after anti-rebel action, was the driving force behind mutineers who overthrew President Joseph Momoh in 1992.

At 26 the world's youngest head of state, he was a flamboyant figure in Ray-Ban sunglasses and designer clothing. And despite widespread criticism of his human rights record from organisations such as Amnesty International, the young leader quickly ingratiated himself with world leaders including Bill Clinton, John Major and Nelson Mandela.

But only eight months into his leadership, Strasser's armed forces executed 26 political opponents on a beach outside Freetown. The international community was appalled, and Britain immediately suspended aid to the country.

In January 1994, Strasser's government began an army recruitment drive, enlisting children from the age of 12. Army ranks swelled from 5,000 in 1991 to 12,000 in 1994. Amnesty International said people suspected of supporting the rebel Revolutionary United Front had been tortured. Government soldiers were accused of atrocities. By January 1995 state radio was urging citizens to 'have sticks and stones and machetes ready', as hundreds poured into Freetown, with tales of torture, mutilation and cannibalism.

Ousted from power in 1996, Strasser led a nomadic life in the UK as his application for asylum was being considered. He abandoned a law degree at Warwick University, having entered the country on a student's visa.

'I would not count him out at this stage,' said a London-based acquaintance of Strasser's on Friday night. 'He still has a support base in Sierra Leone, and any moves to take him back there would have to be considered very carefully.'

webTitle: Throg  Street: To bag a bargain, the place to be is Safeway

fields.headline: To bag a bargain, the place to be is Safeway
fields.trailText: What difference does a change of chief executive make? Plenty, judging by the performance of Safeway, the supermarkets group.
fields.body:
What difference does a change of chief executive make? Plenty, judging by the performance of Safeway, the supermarkets group. Carlos Criado-Perez joined the group in August 1999 and took over as chief executive three months later.

The group was struggling. Safeway 2000, its strategy of focusing on families and store revamps, was failing. Sales growth was fading away and profits were falling. In short, it had lost its way.

After just one year under Criado-Perez's leadership, it has regained its confidence - and with good reason. Sales have been rising for 15 months, starting almost as soon as he walked in the door.

In the six months to 14 October the rise, excluding new space, was 5 per cent. Profits over the same period rose by 10 per cent and Safeway claims to have attracted 1 million new customers.

Now ask the question again: what difference does a chief executive make? Not much, judging by the performance of Sainsbury. Sir Peter Davis took over as chief executive in March when the group was struggling. A series of management changes - including the appointment of the first chief executive from outside the Sainsbury family - had failed to give it direction. Sales growth was fading away and profits were falling. In short, it had lost its way.

After nine months of Sir Peter's leadership, little has changed. Sales in the first six months of its financial year rose by just 0.7 per cent, excluding petrol and new space, below the average for food retailers. Underlying profits fell by 17 per cent and it appears still to be losing customers.

To be fair to Sir Peter, he has been in the job just half as long as Criado-Perez so it is too early to compare performance - particularly when Sir Peter has made it clear that his recovery programme will take three years. But Safeway's very success underlines the difficulty he faces.

Criado-Perez came from Wal-Mart, and his experience there persuaded him that everyday low pricing, the strategy pursued by the US giant and by most of the British supermarket groups, would not work for a small player like Safeway. Its larger rivals could too easily undercut it.

Instead, he decided to use what he calls a high/low strategy, what we know as loss-leading. The technique is familiar - cut the price of 20 or so selected items each week. The radical part came in the implementation.

Instead of making it a national campaign, which would allow its rivals to instantly follow its price cuts, Safeway's 'best deals ever' vary from town to town and change every week. It employs 5,500 people to distribute the leaflets - one home in every three gets one. The price cuts are dramatic -half-price chickens, 40 per cent off family-sized Coca Cola - indeed, many are sold at below the cost to Safeway.

Shoppers seem to love it, as is evident from Safeway's sales. But it is high risk - sales have to increase by enough to limit the impact on profits, and it has to be able to deliver the stock.

That is harder than it sounds. Some of the products on offer fly out of the door. Finance director Simon Laffin, who has been seeing the demand at first-hand with a three-month stint as manager of the Wokingham store, says some sell as much in a week as they normally would in a year. Organising stock levels for that kind of demand, on different products around the country, is a logistical nightmare.

That is one of the reasons why rivals have not emulated Safeway's strategy, despite its success. Tesco, as the dominant player, does not need to. Asda is wedded to the every-day low pricing strategy of its parent Wal-Mart, and Sainsbury's centralised distribution systems would make it difficult. Sainsbury would also have to drop its loyalty card, something Davis seems reluctant to do.

Instead, he seems to be promising more of the same, but executed better and faster. Sainsbury will not go out and out to compete with Tesco and Asda on price but will instead focus on its traditional strengths of service and quality.

So it is investing in new product development ('taste the difference') refurbishing stores and removing 'inappropriate' products like televisions from its shelves. Davis is also doing the traditional new-broom thing of cutting costs - a £600 million cut is promised by the end of the three-year programme. Added to what Davis hopes to be accelerating sales growth, that should get Sainsbury's margins back to the level of Tesco and the other leaders -roughly 6 per cent at the moment.

There is no doubt that Sainsbury is less efficient than its rivals, although the scale of the promised savings surprised some observers. But analysts doubt whether Sainsbury can keep all those savings for itself and expect that at least some of the £600m will have to be given back to customers in price cuts.

Davis has other headaches too. The Homebase disposal is taking longer than expected, sales at its US business went into reverse and its Egyptian business (why Egypt, Davis must be asking) is proving a financial disaster. It is confident that the US problem is a short-term blip, caused by integrating a recent acquisition. All the more worrying, then, that it is adding yet more stores there with the acquisition of the Grand Union chain.

Safeway's strategy may be winning customers but it is Sainsbury that has won over the City. While Safeway shares have had a good run, they still stand at a 20 per cent discount to Sainsbury, based on analysts' estimates of profits for the full year.

Safeway has just passed the first anniversary of its promotional campaign so it will be more and more difficult to keep sales rising. But it is working hard to keep the momentum going with store refurbishments, improvements in product availability and a renewed focus on fresh products.

Sainsbury has been mismanaged for years so there is much to go for if someone finally manages to get the formula right. However, there is little sign that Davis has done that so far, while Safeway grows more confident by the day. Follow the lead of the Safeway shoppers and bag yourself a bargain.

webTitle: Why trains are no longer just the ticket

fields.headline: Why trains are no longer just the ticket
fields.standfirst:
UK transport strategy has been derailed, argues Stephen Glaister
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: UK transport strategy has been derailed, argues Stephen Glaister.
fields.body:
Plans to spend £180 billion on Britain's crumbling transport system over the next 10 years need urgent revision if they are to deliver us from jammed roads, choking pollution and rail chaos.

The Government's ambitious scheme was very welcome when it was announced in July, but always had significant risk and speculation built into it.

Now, just four months on, the outlook has changed dramatically, with a full-scale crisis on the railways and fuel tax cuts proposed in Chancellor Gordon Brown's pre-Budget statement.

Huge investment pledged for the railways over the next decade may not prove the best use of public resources. There is a strong case for saying that spending more to improve travel for motorists, lorries and bus riders will benefit a great many more people than, for example, subsidising inter-city rail lines such as the West Coast.

The Government is making car ownership easier by forcing purchase prices down and cutting vehicle excise duty (road tax) on fuel-efficient cars, and that is a Good Thing, particularly for rural motorists, who often have little public transport, and people on lower incomes. But moves to cut fuel duty encourage extra use of those cars and could make the 10-year plan's aspiration to cut congestion and pollution extremely difficult to achieve.

The headline back in July was: 'Ten-year £180bn investment plan to deliver top-class transport system'. But after inflation, spending in the next decade at today's prices drops to around £150bn. Public money, in terms of capital investment and every day transport expenditure, comes out as £111bn in the next 10 years, compared with £91bn in the last decade - a modest increase.

Private sector funding will have to make up the shortfall and that is one of the first risks - such investment cannot be guaranteed at this stage.

The railways are to receive £60bn in the 10-year plan, with more than half expected from the private sector, supported by revenues from an expected 50 per cent increase in passengers to around 1.5bn a year.

But can this be relied upon?

Recent accidents and the disruption caused by Railtrack's emergency speed restrictions and maintenance work can only have damaged the confidence of the travelling public and the freight industry in the already-questionable quality of service railways can deliver. The rail renaissance has been stopped in its tracks, as it were, and may not fully recover.

The 10-year plan preceded any recommendations on safety that may emerge from inquiries into the Southall, Paddington and Hatfield crashes. Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott has since hinted that cash will be provided to assist with extra safety measures, such as automatic train protection. But it is impossible to quantify or guarantee this and there is always the danger that money for modernisa tion and expansion gets swallowed up by safety improvements that should have been done years ago.

Meanwhile, the fragile competitive position of rail freight and the modest target to double it by 2010 are likely to be adversely affected both by lack of capacity and by the concessions to road hauliers.

And for ordinary motorists, a 3p a litre cut in duty on low-sulphur petrol means that, as supplies spread, prices at the pump will be 6 per cent lower than if the Chancellor had imposed an inflation-only increase (having already scrapped the inflation-plus 'escalator').

This could lead to 2 per cent more traffic, 4 per cent more fuel consumption and ever-worsening congestion in the long run, rather than the 'far fewer journeys by car' optimistically trumpeted by Prescott in 1997. Meanwhile the Government's own calculations show that investing in transport to reduce delays costs £11 an hour saved for passenger rail, £25 an hour for rail freight but only £5 for trunk roads.

Given that around 70 per cent of workers in large cities outside London commute by car, 10 per cent by bus and as few as 1 per cent by rail, public investment may be more wisely spent on road-building and bus services. The private sector is welcome to invest in those high-speed rail projects that are commercially viable.

We should not tear up the 10-year plan, nor rely on it as a panacea. But it does not stand up to scrutiny and must be revisited.

 Stephen Glaister is Professor of Transport and Infrastructure, Imperial College, London.

webTitle: Barbara Ellen: Why the rich are different

fields.headline: Why the rich are different
fields.trailText: Over the years, I've asked many celebrities, 'What is money good for?' Invariably they'd reply: 'Freedom.'
fields.body:
Over the years, I've asked many celebrities, 'What is money good for?' Invariably they'd reply: 'Freedom.' In certain cases, the effect was spoiled somewhat by said celebrity then turning around and snorting a huge cable of cocaine off the sideboard, but, as ever, it's the thought that counts.

The fact is, these celebrities were more right than they probably realised. The secret of wealth - real wealth, life-changing wealth - is that it releases you from everyday drudgery and allows you to be the person you intended to be, before life and all its petty irritations put out the small fire that was you. Just as the enemy of creativity is said to be the pram in the hall, the chief foe of individuality has to be the bill on the doormat. That's why F Scott Fitzgerald got it slightly wrong when he wrote his famous line: 'The rich are different.' What he should have said was: 'The rich are both different and difficult.' Difficult to understand, and difficult to forgive.

It goes without saying that I'm as bloodcurdlingly jealous of mega-rich people as anybody. There are only so many sarky bank letters a woman can take before she considers making the trek to meet the devil at the crossroads. Saying that, there are many things I wouldn't do for money - the chief one of which seems to be having an ingenious creative or business idea, and working really hard to make it work. Apart from that, I'm yours. Over the past week, I've scoured the latest 'Rich List' several times, and I still can't quite get over the fact that I'm not on there, nestling alongside the John Hargreaves, the Barbara Taylor Bradfords and the Dean Allens.

Dean Allen is a special case, because before his £13.9m lottery win in August, he was just like the rest of us, bumbling along, working as a printer, trying not to kick the dog when the red bills came in. Only the blackest of hearts could begrudge Allen his good luck. By contrast, the knives were out in my local newsagents for this week's first £1m jackpot winner of Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? . From what I gleaned from the scrum of headscarves and rain caps around me, Judith Keppel's big offence was to be a distant cousin of Camilla Parker Bowles. Which made her ersatz royalty, which in turn made her posh, undeserving, and that most British of crimes - just plain greedy.

You can understand the public's consternation - lottery and gameshow jackpots are traditionally the preserve of people who've got nothing, not avaricious so-and-sos who've got everything already but would like some more. For all they knew, Ms Keppel could be the poorest and kindest semi-royal in the world, who will now spend the rest of her life roaming the planet doing Good Works. Still, the fact remains that most of us would rather have seen a nurse, a disabled person or a single parent win the million. In these situations, it's almost as if you want to see poverty rewarded. And that may be because we all secretly feel that poor people are somehow nicer, more big hearted and generous than richer folk. And, of course, we're probably right.

In all fairness, the rich aren't the only ones who are are tight with money. I've had my share of jack-the-lad boyfriends who would dodge rounds in the pub, leaving me melting with embarrassment by the beer pumps. However, one of the great unheralded laws of civilised society seems to be the richer you are, the meaner, the more tight fisted you get. Strangely, this phenomenon even extends to the mega-rich. When Michael Douglas recently married Catherine Zeta Jones, it made front pages all over the world. The dress. The cake. The pre-nup. The £1m deal with OK! for exclusive photographs. Stop, I'll get misty-eyed.

You could understand the fuss: Zeta Jones is a rare beauty, and Douglas is an accomplished actor/producer. However, the OK! deal also exposed them as a couple of the richest, tightest people in Hollywood. One wonders just how rich celebrities like the Zeta-Douglas's would have to be before they decided that actually they could afford to take their own snaps and organise their own security. That maybe, just maybe, it would be worth it not to have a glossy magazine hanging around, hijacking their special day.

Clearly, the rich are after all different, though not in the way F Scott Fitzgerald meant. I think I've known this since the day, some years ago, when my friend and I manned a jumble stall for a local charity in Mayfair. We spent the afternoon falling over laughing at the endless stream of 'toffs' who fell on the bobbly jumpers and torn slacks, hawk-eyed for a bargain, seemingly beyond the reach of mortification. In between giggling fits, the penny, or the wedge of used fivers, dropped - this is how rich people become and stay rich: they act like the poor, if the poor had no shame.

webTitle: Dublin excludes unionist culture, report claims

fields.headline: Dublin excludes unionist culture, report claims
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The Irish Republic is still intolerant of the unionist tradition and its communal fears, despite the Good Friday Agreement, according to a new report obtained by  The Observer .
fields.body:
The Irish Republic is still intolerant of the unionist tradition and its communal fears, despite the Good Friday Agreement, according to a new report obtained by The Observer .

The Dublin authorities are accused of failing to challenge anti-British prejudice, which, the authors claim, continues to alienate unionists from the southern state.

The 67-page report, drawn up by 16 different southern Irish peace and reconciliation groups, accuses institutions such as the Catholic Church and the Gaelic Athletic Association of promoting a one-sided, 'rigidly nationalist mindset'. Officials at the Department of Foreign Affairs in Dublin are understood to be furious about the report, which they believe will confirm unionists' fears of being subsumed into a Catholic and nationalist-dominated Ireland.

The study, to be published next month by the southern -based Irish Peace and Reconciliation Platform, cites a large number of issues on which it saysthe Republic has failed to live up to the ideals of the Agreement. It concludes that there is:

 Exclusion of people from the unionist tradition.

 A tendency to avoid the concerns of both sides in Northern Ireland.

 A fault in school curricula so serious that children can complete their entire education without properly learning the history, culture and beliefs of any tradition or religion but their own.

 A fostering of selective cultural and historical amnesia, such as allowing whole swathes of people to be 'airbrushed' out of history if their 'faces didn't fit'. These include Irish people who fought on the British side in the world wars, and a mistaken belief that only Catholics suffered in the nineteenth century famines.

 An under-emphasis in the media of the integrity of the unionist position and the por trayal of people of that tradition in over-simplified terms.

Overall, the authors note that since 1922 there has been 'little attempt to address the fears and apprehensions of unionists in the context of possible new political dispensations'.

They say anti-British attitudes have helped 'restrict the creation of trust-building with the unionist community' in Northern Ireland.

John Taylor, the deputy leader of the Ulster Unionists, said he was not surprised by the findings, which portrayed the position of the Irish state since partition.

'Even though the Irish government recognised the existence of Northern Ireland as part of the UK when they signed the agreement, the state broadcaster, RTE, still refers to Northern Ireland as the "North" rather than its proper name. Even RTE is required to be re-educated in parity of esteem,' Taylor said.

But he believed the problem was 'bound to improve, especially since there has been an increase in the numbers of Irish citizens applying for British passports from the UK embassy in Dublin'.

The organisations represented in the report include Co-operation Ireland, the Glencree Centre for Reconciliation in Wicklow, the Irish School of Ecumenics and the Peace Train Organisation.

Among the experts called to help put the paper together was Chris Hudson, the Irish government envoy who opened talks with loyalists in the early Nineties, the former Education Minister Niamh Breathnach, and the Anglican Bishop of Meath and Kildare, the Most Rev Richard Clarke.
