webTitle: Dirty Uncle Sam wrecks deal on global warming

fields.headline: Dirty Uncle Sam wrecks deal on global warming
fields.standfirst: Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: In the small hours of yesterday morning, John Prescott almost saved the planet. He thought he had a deal with the United States on 'supplementarity'. It turned out he hadn't.
fields.body:
In the small hours of yesterday morning, John Prescott almost saved the planet. He thought he had a deal with the United States on 'supplementarity'. It turned out he hadn't. The deal foundered even before United Nations officials at the conference on global warming could tell the world what supplementarity meant.

To European delegates the last-minute negotiations were yet another US attempt to dress up its resistance to risking a single American job or profit opportunity in the increasingly urgent struggle to counteract global warming. Earlier versions of US obduracy left delegates arguing about how large a plant had to be in order to be included in a US 'carbon sink' (as tall as a maple? as small as a cabbage?) and whether to factor in 'trading emissions', allowing rich countries to carry on burning fossil fuels, but pay the Third World not to do so. It is a tragedy that these last-chance talks were reduced to such banality.

In the end, Prescott could not temper European anger over such chicanery, but he was right to try anything - flattery, fudge, fury - to keep the largest polluter talking. The US, with 4 per cent of the world population, is responsible for 24 per cent of all carbon emissions. And while the dirtiest nation swaggers around the globe policing how the rest of the world trades and organises its finances, it apparently believes it should come under no scrutiny at all for running its own industry with fuel-inefficient, environmentally damaging technologies long abandoned by Europe.

But the US itself is not immune to global warming. When forest fires return next year with even greater vigour let us hope its citizens start to demand a more intelligent approach from their leaders to the most important debate in the world.

webTitle: How future of the planet grew dark

fields.headline: How future of the planet grew dark
fields.standfirst:
Europe wants drastic cuts in carbon emissions. America wants to carry on guzzling. John Prescott thought he had a solution... and then it all went wrong. Robin McKie reports from The Hague

Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Europe wants drastic cuts in carbon emissions. America wants to carry on guzzling. John Prescott thought he had a solution... and then it all went wrong. Robin McKie reports from The Hague.
fields.body:
At 11am yesterday the United Nations talks aimed at imposing realistic greenhouse gas reductions unravelled catastrophically. Faced with implacable opposition from his European counterparts, the UK head of delegation John Prescott found himself isolated in his bid to broker a deal with the United States.

His attempt to save the planet had collapsed and the enraged head of Britain's delegation stalked furiously from the convention.

'I am gutted,' the furious Deputy Prime Minister told the reporters who followed him out of The Hague's convention centre. Shortly afterwards Svend Auken, head of the Danish delegation, emerged. The climate convention had begun to disintegrate.

The cleaners started to sweep away the debris and to prepare for the next conference, a meeting of oil industry specialists.

Only a few hours earlier, an ebullient Prescott and an equally enthusiastic Environment Minister Michael Meacher had briefed reporters that the pair were close to brokering a deal between the US and the European Union, the two major opponents in the talks.

Meacher and Prescott had entered the final phase of negotiations late on Friday and were prepared, with other delegates, to sit up all night to hammer out a plausible deal. These negotiations centred on a basic ideological division. On one side stood an umbrella group - led by the United States - that included New Zealand, Australia and Japan. On the other stood the European Union nations and the developing world.

The US camp had come to The Hague seeking to avoid cuts in carbon dioxide emissions from cars and factories. Instead they wanted to fund carbon sinks - forests and plants that absorb carbon dioxide - as a substitute for halting their profligacy with petrol and their factories' energy inefficiency.

By paying for the growing of new plantations in developing nations and by demanding that greater allowance be made for their own forests, these countries - particularly the United States - hoped to avoid cutting their own emissions.

Europe was committed to the idea that the developed world had to reduce its burning of fossil fuels and considered the American carbon sink plan as a bid to avoid global responsibilities. Who would be responsible for such plantations, asked European delegates? What would happen when they died off? And would they be made of giant monoculture plantations of endless rows of pines and eucalyptus trees that would devastate local wildlife? They received few satisfactory answers.

The deadlock held until 3am yesterday, when Prescott decided to take action. He persuaded US delegates that if they abandoned their attempts to fund carbon sink forests in developing nations, European delegates would be more sympathetic to America's arguments that its own carbon sinks, both its forests and its agriculture land, would be given greater importance in negotiations.

John Loy, head of the US delegation, agreed - and so Meacher and Prescott called in the media to announce their plan. 'We have put this to the European Union delegation, and they asked for more information,' said Prescott. The deal looked good, in other words, a view that was later shared by Jan Pronk, the conference president who was responsible for all negotiations. 'At six o'clock this morning it looked too close to call,' he said. There was everything still to play for.'

Prescott then called a meeting of his fellow European delegates in the expectation of success. It was to be a disillusioning experience. Europe's delegates were led by the formidable Dominique Voynet from France, and by the equally committed Jürgen Tritten, from Germany. Both are Green Party members and view with extreme suspicion the antics of the US delegation.

Why should the US have special exemptions and be allowed to reduce its cutback quota just because it is a rich and powerful country, they asked? One by one delegates voted down the Prescott plan.

This rejection might not have been so bad if European delegates had then offered a negotiating response. But time was running out and Pronk called a halt just after 11am. 'It was incredibly frustrating,' said Meacher later on. 'We were that close to a deal in there.'

A few minutes later Prescott walked from the building, with stunned members of the world's media trailing in his wake. 'The talks are finished, there is no deal,' he announced, before heading to Amsterdam airport.

It was a grim experience for the ebullient Prescott. He had pinned great hopes on his ability to persuade the two sides to agree, but failed - mainly because he had, naively, underestimated European hostilities to the Americans and to the belligerent negotiating of the US team. As a result he had been made to look ridiculous as he stormed from the conference, furious at his treatment by his fellow European delegates. It had been a chastening visit.

His failure and that of the other delegates raises a critical question, however. Can a global climate deal ever be negotiated? To judge from events, the answer is not encouraging. The US has consistently treated these negotiations as just another round of trade talks. The US - whose citizens account for 4 per cent of the world's population and 24 per cent of its greenhouse gas emissions - will have to reduce its carbon output by 650 million tonnes by 2010 if it is to meet its Kyoto obligations, about a third of its current output.

From the start of these talks the US team attempted to find any way it could to reduce this amount. It was simply a haggle for a bargain.

But Europe could see no justification for giving America any deal over carbon sinks. After all, no other developed nation was to be given one. It was a matter of principle, of climatic importance - an attitude that has defined Europe's but not America's position.

In the end, it was this difference in ideology that so fatally damaged last week's talks and that has now left the world's hopes of a deal over climate control, and of saving the planet from catastrophe, in tatters.

Can plantations save the Earth?

Establishing plantations of young trees is one way of creating a 'carbon sink' as part of attempts to absorb carbon dioxide from the atmosphere rather than contribute to it. America wanted to include a large contribution of sinks in the total, so that it would not have to reduce the amount of fossil fuels that it was burning. In other words, it wanted to grow trees rather than cut down on car use.

Environmentalists are opposed to carbon sinks because there are huge uncertainties about the amount of carbon that forests really absorb. Also a plantation of fast-growing pine trees absorbs far more carbon dioxide than a mature forest. That would mean that including forests in the total would encourage countries to cut down old forests such as rainforests and replace them with monoculture plantations.

Europe was opposed to the American proposal on carbon sinks because the Americans wanted to be allowed to claim credit for so much carbon being absorbed by its forests, that it would have allowed them to increase their emissions of greenhouse gases by 8 per cent rather than cutting them by 7 per cent as they had promised under Kyoto. If this formula were accepted, it would have meant that Sweden and Finland would be allowed to increase their fossil fuel emissions by up to 40 per cent. European countries were opposed to this because it would have undone the hard-won agreement at Kyoto to cut the emission of greenhouse gases.

fields.headline: Gore narrows Bush lead to a few dozen votes
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: As today's 5pm deadline approaches for recounting votes in Florida's contested election, latest figures show Al Gore narrowing George W Bush's lead - standing officially at 550 yesterday morning - to an agonisingly close margin.
fields.body:
As today's 5pm deadline approaches for recounting votes in Florida's contested election, latest figures show Al Gore narrowing George W Bush's lead - standing officially at 550 yesterday morning - to an agonisingly close margin.

In response, the Republican Party mounted a campaign of tumult across Florida's scorched political earth yesterday, as a mob of demonstrators accused of shutting down a recount in Miami that could have won the election for Gore was bused up to Fort Lauderdale, hoping to stifle and stop the count in Broward County.

The demonstrations were joined by a phalanx of Republican heavy-hitters, brought in from elsewhere in the US to object to the counting methods and join a local attempt to stop the count by a Republican lawyer alleging a conflict of interests on the canvassing board.

Projections from Palm Beach and Broward counties, both counting frantically yesterday, showed Gore on course for a shortfall of only 90 votes from Bush's originally certified win by 930 ballots.

Bush is set to be declared the winner of the Florida election and thereby the US Presidency this afternoon - but by his side only.

The hit squad of politicians included Marc Racoicot, Governor of Montana - who said of the Broward board: 'They are not counting votes, they are casting votes' - along with New Jersey Governor Christine Todd Whitman and the Governor of Oklahoma Frank Keating. As allegations of Republican intimidation fly, the party insists the demonstrations are by local supporters of Bush. However, The Observer has identified a number of faces that appear and re-appear at protests as being senior and hardline party operatives dispatched from Washington.

They include an official from the office of the Republican chief whip on Capitol Hill, Tom Delay, and a Republican lobbyist working for the big pharmaceutical and insurance companies.

The certification of the result will be sent to the office of the Secretary of State for Florida - the hardline partisan Republican Katherine Harris - who will proclaim that Bush has won the state's 25 electoral college votes and with them the White House.

But today's moment of hollow triumph is by no means the end; the certification is a mere gesture in to the maelstrom of litigation and political battle. Both sides have said they are prepared to contest the result past today's deadline, and the certification itself will be challenged by Gore.

The US Supreme Court will convene on Friday to determine the constitutional and federal legality of recounts across Florida. Its intervention, which has surprised some constitutional lawyers, could determine the presidency.

webTitle: Patent allows creation of man-animal hybrid

fields.headline: Patent allows creation of man-animal hybrid
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: A biotech company has taken out a Europe-wide patent on a process which campaigners claim would allow 'chimeric' animals to be developed with body parts originating from humans.
fields.body:
A biotech company has taken out a Europe-wide patent on a process which campaigners claim would allow 'chimeric' animals to be developed with body parts originating from humans.

An Australian company, Amrad, was granted the patent last year, which covers embryos containing cells both from humans and from 'mice, sheep, pigs, cattle, goats or fish'.

Church groups have already reacted with outrage, denouncing the patent as 'morally offensive'.

Details in the patent do not make it clear what use these mixed-species embryos would be put to, but experts are in no doubt that the potential is there to create a hybrid creature.

Dr Sue Mayer, director of Genewatch, said: 'The company is saying that it wants a patent on a process which could produce chimeric animals using cells from a whole range of species including humans. Many people will find the thought abhorrent.'

A spokesman for the Catholic Church said: 'To patent a process where human life is used as a kind of bank to deposit into animals is morally indefensible.'

Dr Donald Bruce, a spokesman for European churches on bioethics, said: 'This patent should never have been passed. If people are talking about using human cells in animals, that is completely unacceptable.'

Last month the European Patent Office claimed it would never grant a patent on mixed-species embryos as they are considered against 'public order and morality'. But this patent, discovered by a researcher in Greenpeace's German office, was taken out in January 1999 and has since been sold to US company Chemicon International.

Thomas Schweiger of Greenpeace called on the European Patent Office to withdraw it. He said: 'The chimeras may be non-human but they may contain human organs, body parts, nerve cells and even human genetic codes. The company does not give concrete medical uses and obviously intended to give the company broad monopoly rights on the process and chimeric creatures.'

Schweiger believes that one possible use might be to grow human organs in animals for transplantation.

According to the patent the chimera-creating process starts by isolating a special hormone, the objective of which is to stimulate the growth of embryonic cells; known as stem cells. These stem cells are the 'master cells' which could in theory be used to produce virtually any type of replacement tissue for a damaged body.

Amrad chief executive John Grace denied his company had ever conducted research in this field and said the patent would not be used to create animals with human cells. He said the process was mainly used to produce genetically engineered mice for research.

webTitle: Real IRA ready to blitz Britain

fields.headline: Real IRA ready to blitz Britain
fields.standfirst:
Terrorists prepare for mainland offensive

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Terrorists of the Real IRA are poised to launch a pre-Christmas bombing blitz in mainland Britain in an attempt to wreck the peace process and provoke a return to violence with loyalists.
fields.body:
Terrorists of the Real IRA are poised to launch a pre-Christmas bombing blitz in mainland Britain in an attempt to wreck the peace process and provoke a return to violence with loyalists.

The news came as it emerged yesterday that police have uncovered a secret arms cache in Derry believed to have been hidden by the breakaway republican faction. Two men and a woman were arrested during a raid on a house on the Galliagh Estate in the city. Police seized seven guns, including assault rifles and chillingly an improvised sniper's rifle with ammunition. In incredible scenes after the raid, a mob of about 150 encircled the police and threw petrol bombs, stones and bottles. One man was arrested.

Unionist politicians and officials from Sinn Fein pointed the finger at the Real IRA for hiding the weapons which could have been used in an attempt to derail the peace process.

Amid the heightened concern of a Real IRA threat security sources have told The Observer that the extremist terrorist group is planning to intensify its highly professional campaign that has seen an attack launched every 12 days since the ceasefire began.

Last week David Veness, Assistant Commissioner of the Metropolitan Police, held talks with his Royal Ulster Constabulary counterparts on the Real IRA threat to London. They discussed the recent attempt by the group to smuggle a 500lb bomb into London in a horsebox and talked about the increasing likelihood of a new mainland bombing campaign.

The group, which was responsible for the Omagh bomb two years ago, has carried out at least 21 attacks, along with scores of firebombs and hoaxes since February.

Its activities yesterday prompted the British and Irish governments to ask the United States to place the Real IRA on a list of designated terrorist groups. This would give US law enforcement agencies extra powers to secure convictions and curb the group's fundraising activities.

The Real IRA's 'one every dozen days' terror campaign has been timed to synchronise with highly publicised political and cultural events across the UK. The terrorist group caused traffic and rail chaos on the day of the Queen Mother's Centenary Pageant last July, when they left a bomb on the railway line at Ealing Broadway Station. The organisation blew up a hotel in Co Tyrone on the morning of the Drumcree march, the most controversial loyalist parade in Ulster's marching season.

Security sources believe the lack of significant casualties was due only to the inexperience of recent recruits - described by army officers as 'lilywhites' - rather than any lack of will among Real IRA planners and engineers.

Many of the weapons used in recent attacks came from the Balkans. Real IRA envoys, including a South Armagh man who had previously worked in the former Yugoslavia as an aid worker, cut a major deal with Croat arms dealers last year. Several small shipments were sent to Ireland via Amsterdam and included Russian-made RPG-22 rocket-launchers. One of these weapons was used in the attack on the MI6 headquarters at Vauxhall Bridge in London two months ago.

One senior military source singled out the attack on the Magilligan army camp in Co Derry as an example of the Real IRA's capability. On 12 September, a two-man Real IRA unit used a powerboat to cross Lough Foyle from Co Donegal in the Republic and penetrate a perimeter fence before leaving an 80lb booby-trap bomb in an army hut. One Royal Irish Regiment soldier was slightly injured in the blast.

'The Magilligan attack demonstrated real guts and professionalism. The only thing they didn't have was luck. It also showed that the Real IRA is politically calculating. By killing British troops they can say they are attacking the British presence.

'But they also know that taking out local guys from Protestant areas is likely to bring the loyalists back into play. If the loyalists start attacking the Catholic population in revenge, it puts up a challenge to the Provisional IRA to strike back,' said a source.

The terror group has also used drug dealers to ship guns into the Province. A drug dealer from Newry, Paul 'Bull' Downey, sold the Real IRA a cache of Uzi sub-machine guns, machine-pistols with silencers, .32 revolvers and Dilinger handguns last year. The Provisional IRA later abducted Downey and shot him dead.

The intensification of Real IRA activity since February is one of the factors in the stalemate over demilitarisation and the peace process. A senior British Army source said the military wanted to reduce the number of troops to a peacetime garrison of 8,000 - fewer than the number of soldiers in the Province before 1969.

The Army and RUC wanted in the short to medium term to maintain the 13 hilltop fortresses in South Armagh, despite Sinn Fein demands that they be dismantled.

Republicans complain that the posts, which overlook the dirt roads of South Armagh, are an irritant to local farmers and provide propaganda for dissidents who claim the peace process has brought no change to the region. Jim McAllister, a Sinn Fein veteran from the IRA stronghold of Crossmaglen, said the posts and heavy presence of British troops on the ground was shaking the local republicans' faith in the peace process.

'Many republicans in this area are saying there are more Brits on the ground and in the air than at any time since the ceasefires. They are questioning the British intentions, asking if they really want to demilitarise or even [want] peace,' McAllister said.

The upsurge in Real IRA operations - the Army describes it as the 'second phase' - is a remarkable turnaround for a terror group that was an international pariah two years ago.

Outrage over the Omagh massacre - in which 29 killed - forced the Real IRA to call a temporary ceasefire and led to pickets outside the Dundalk home of its founder, the former Provisional IRA quartermaster-general, Michael McKevitt.

While the Army insists it wants to return to 'normalisation' in the Province, the Real IRA's campaign stymies further moves to dismantle the military apparatus in areas such as South Armagh. Whether it is rockets and bombs in London, or mortars and incendiaries in Northern Ireland, the Real IRA continues to have an impact on the peace process.

They have launched an attack every 12 days. These are some of them...

30 June

Bomb left on Belfast-Dublin rail link in South Armagh. A secondary one almost killed bomb disposal officers.

7 July

Car bomb explodes outside an RUC station in Stewartstown, Co Tyrone, coinciding with first day of loyalist standoff at Drumcree.

19 July

London Tube station bomb sparks transport chaos on Queen Mother's centenary.

13 September

Mortar fired at RUC station in Armagh city, close to local primary school.

20 September

RPG-22 rocket is fired at the headquarters of MI6 in London, causing knock-on traffic and railway disruption.

webTitle: Leader: Seize the day, Mr Blair

fields.headline: Seize the day, Mr Blair
fields.standfirst:
At long last, the Prime Minister has found a true voice. Now he must put it to good use to win the election

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText:
Tony Blair has shown some unaccustomed steel. Last week, he advocated the elimination of poverty, the lifting of public investment and the improvement of public services. He honoured teachers and others dedicated to public service. He scorned Thatcherism's evident weaknesses. He spoke articulately for Europe, and thus for Britain's interests. And he dared to criticise the pantomime euro-scepticism of the right-wing press. 

The Prime Minister began, above all, to sound a little like a leader with a mission and a set of principles. About time, too.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has shown some unaccustomed steel. Last week, he advocated the elimination of poverty, the lifting of public investment and the improvement of public services. He honoured teachers and others dedicated to public service. He scorned Thatcherism's evident weaknesses. He spoke articulately for Europe, and thus for Britain's interests. And he dared to criticise the pantomime euro-scepticism of the right-wing press.

The Prime Minister began, above all, to sound a little like a leader with a mission and a set of principles. About time, too.

We have now reached a critical point in the politics of the new century. Labour is beginning its campaign to win a general election that realistically offers the party the historic chance of a second full term in government. The challenge for the Labour Party is to reignite the enthusiasm with which it was elected in 1997, but the party must still address the enormous gaps in its appeal to many voters.

It has to engage those who voted for 'New Labour' last time purely because of their misgivings about the return of a fifth Conservative government. It also has to reassure the many constituencies which have been left bitterly disappointed by Labour after more than three years in power. At the same time, Labour must rebuff a populist Tory party more willing than ever to play dirty in its quest for victory. The lesson of last week is that it can be done. Now Mr Blair needs to convince us that he is confident enough in the values of the centre and centre-Left to cede no more ground to the Right - and even to win some back.

When the election comes, Labour will proudly claim a scale of jobs growth and of individual prosperity coupled with low inflation and high investment not witnessed since the war. Additionally, there is an expansion of investment in education, transport and health that requires a long-term platform and which the country desperately needs. The party will be right to boast about its record and it plans.

Where Labour has been on much less secure ground is in the way it has chosen to respond to William Hague's populist opportunism. Home Secretary Jack Straw and others have been correct to stress that it is natural Labour supporters, particularly those living in large, inner-city estates who suffer most from crime - and that noisy neighbours or gangs of rampaging youths or local drug dealers are social problems that require tough responses. Liberal critics, out of touch with these realities, readily dismiss the solutions as illiberal authoritarianism. But as the leaked memos of Philip Gould and Cabinet papers have both underlined, Labour's preoccupations go much further than that. The Prime Minister has shown himself too often wanting to outflank William Hague, leading Labour to positions on asylum-seekers, sentencing policy and jury trial that are hard to defend by any standards, let alone those of a progressive political party.

Number 10 has put immense pressure on Jack Straw to toughen up Labour's act still further, so that from the decriminalisation of soft drugs to penal policy, Labour's position is barely distinguishable from that of the Tories. The calculation is that this leaves Hague little populist opportunity, but the stupidity is that it confers on him something more priceless - legitimacy and the ability to set the political agenda. Straw and his team need to steer a more careful course both in terms of principle and political advantage. The Prime Minister has taken a principled position on Europe; now he should take the same stance on civil liberties.

Labour's position will be much easier if it develops - and boasts of - some first principles. Strong defence and freedom of information might appear to be disparate policies appealing to different voters. They are not. The most appropriate military protection comes with the best public scrutiny, Ministers should be able to argue. Similarly, reducing class sizes and getting rid of the notorious Section 28 can be wrongly characterised as appealing to diverse groups of electors. But both are about providing the best, most honest and appropriate education for Britain's young people in the twenty-first century. In order to champion a catalogue of policies like these - instead of fighting local skirmishes over and over again - Labour needs to adopt a coherent and convincing radical narrative.

For Number 10's cautious advisers, this may seem a risk too far. New Labour has already opened up one flank by taking on the Eurosceptics over the so-called 'European army' last week; to adopt a broadly liberal approach on welfare, crime and race may seem to offer William Hague too much political leeway. Mr Blair should be reassured. Failing to argue a position or pretending to be something you are not explode all too easily in your face, as he should learn from the story of the European rapid reaction force. At first, Labour tried to smuggle the commitment through. Then it stressed what the force was not. It was only latterly that it went on the offensive arguing the case on its merits. And they are demonstrable, particularly at a time when George Bush, Mr Hague's American pal, is flirting overtly with isolationism.

Labour needs the nerve to acknowledge that for all the sound and fury of last week's row over the 'European army', the Conservatives have yet to build political momentum. Of course that is still possible. The Tories are still - disgracefully - praying for an explosion of civil unrest before the next general election just as they privately welcomed the fuel tax disorders earlier this year. But so far, William Hague has achieved no more than to rebuild his coalition on the Right - the odd caravan of euro-sceptics, hard-faced business people, bloodsports campaigners and petrol protesters marching alongside diehard members of the Tory tribe. While it is loud, even hysterical, its appeal is narrow and unable to reach for the political centre.

Mr Blair would be right to assert his principles. His most significant risk is still that he allows the Conservatives to set the political agenda - always the first step to winning the political argument and then elections. He should always remember that the Right is increasingly desperate and, an important lesson for Labour, no concession is or will be good enough for the right-wing press. Whatever he says or does, the Daily Mail and the Daily Telegraph will cavil. These people all remain implacable enemies, and simply do not accept the legitimacy of even a moderate Labour government.

Britain is not the natural home of conservatism it once was. We are much more tolerant and liberal than the discourse of public debate admits. People may well be unsympathetic to grand schemes of European integration, but, equally, most of us have no appetite to leave the EU. Above all, the nation looks for principle and leadership from the governing party, even if it may disagree with parts of its programme.

Mr Blair and Labour thus have a momentous opportunity. Their established pledges to eliminate child poverty within 20 years, to lift the quality of public services and to heighten enrolment in university education are excellent, but they encompass too narrow a swathe of social concerns. Nor are they are bound into a vision of what the just society might be in the twenty-first century - what our cities might look like, how our society can cohere, how our democracy might become more vital.

Too often in the past, Tony Blair's only political passion has appeared to be giving as little offence as possible. Last week he found a voice. Now the Prime Minister should argue the radical case across a range of issues. He should use it to champion a progressive vision of what Britain can be, to reignite the enthusiasm of his own side and to impress the centre.

If he does that, he can once again secure a mandate to serve that vision. A second Labour general election victory, an ample majority, and with it a full term of office in which to continue the reshaping of Britain, is the impossible dream which has eluded the Left for a century. Now that the battle to secure that victory has begun, we need to see more of the political courage which can make it possible.

It has to engage those who voted for 'New Labour' last time purely because of their misgivings about the return of a fifth Conservative government. It also has to reassure the many constituencies which have been left bitterly disappointed by Labour after more than three years in power. At the same time, Labour must rebuff a populist Tory party more willing than ever to play dirty in its quest for victory. The lesson of last week is that it can be done. Now Mr Blair needs to convince us that he is confident enough in the values of the centre and centre-Left to cede no more ground to the Right - and even to win some back. When the election comes, Labour will proudly claim a scale of jobs growth and of individual prosperity coupled with low inflation and high investment not witnessed since the war. Additionally, there is an expansion of investment in education, transport and health that requires a long-term platform and which the country desperately needs. The party will be right to boast about its record and it plans. Where Labour has been on much less secure ground is in the way it has chosen to respond to William Hague's populist opportunism. Home Secretary Jack Straw and others have been correct to stress that it is natural Labour supporters, particularly those living in large, inner-city estates who suffer most from crime - and that noisy neighbours or gangs of rampaging youths or local drug dealers are social problems that require tough responses. Liberal critics, out of touch with these realities, readily dismiss the solutions as illiberal authoritarianism. But as the leaked memos of Philip Gould and Cabinet papers have both underlined, Labour's preoccupations go much further than that. The Prime Minister has shown himself too often wanting to outflank William Hague, leading Labour to positions on asylum-seekers, sentencing policy and jury trial that are hard to defend by any standards, let alone those of a progressive political party. Number 10 has put immense pressure on Jack Straw to toughen up Labour's act still further, so that from the decriminalisation of soft drugs to penal policy, Labour's position is barely distinguishable from that of the Tories. The calculation is that this leaves Hague little populist opportunity, but the stupidity is that it confers on him something more priceless - legitimacy and the ability to set the political agenda. Straw and his team need to steer a more careful course both in terms of principle and political advantage. The Prime Minister has taken a principled position on Europe; now he should take the same stance on civil liberties. Labour's position will be much easier if it develops - and boasts of - some first principles. Strong defence and freedom of information might appear to be disparate policies appealing to different voters. They are not. The most appropriate military protection comes with the best public scrutiny, Ministers should be able to argue. Similarly, reducing class sizes and getting rid of the notorious Section 28 can be wrongly characterised as appealing to diverse groups of electors. But both are about providing the best, most honest and appropriate education for Britain's young people in the twenty-first century. In order to champion a catalogue of policies like these - instead of fighting local skirmishes over and over again - Labour needs to adopt a coherent and convincing radical narrative. For Number 10's cautious advisers, this may seem a risk too far. New Labour has already opened up one flank by taking on the Eurosceptics over the so-called 'European army' last week; to adopt a broadly liberal approach on welfare, crime and race may seem to offer William Hague too much political leeway. Mr Blair should be reassured. Failing to argue a position or pretending to be something you are not explode all too easily in your face, as he should learn from the story of the European rapid reaction force. At first, Labour tried to smuggle the commitment through. Then it stressed what the force was not. It was only latterly that it went on the offensive arguing the case on its merits. And they are demonstrable, particularly at a time when George Bush, Mr Hague's American pal, is flirting overtly with isolationism. Labour needs the nerve to acknowledge that for all the sound and fury of last week's row over the 'European army', the Conservatives have yet to build political momentum. Of course that is still possible. The Tories are still - disgracefully - praying for an explosion of civil unrest before the next general election just as they privately welcomed the fuel tax disorders earlier this year. But so far, William Hague has achieved no more than to rebuild his coalition on the Right - the odd caravan of euro-sceptics, hard-faced business people, bloodsports campaigners and petrol protesters marching alongside diehard members of the Tory tribe. While it is loud, even hysterical, its appeal is narrow and unable to reach for the political centre. Mr Blair would be right to assert his principles. His most significant risk is still that he allows the Conservatives to set the political agenda - always the first step to winning the political argument and then elections. He should always remember that the Right is increasingly desperate and, an important lesson for Labour, no concession is or will be good enough for the right-wing press. Whatever he says or does, the Daily Mail and the Daily Telegraph will cavil. These people all remain implacable enemies, and simply do not accept the legitimacy of even a moderate Labour government. Britain is not the natural home of conservatism it once was. We are much more tolerant and liberal than the discourse of public debate admits. People may well be unsympathetic to grand schemes of European integration, but, equally, most of us have no appetite to leave the EU. Above all, the nation looks for principle and leadership from the governing party, even if it may disagree with parts of its programme. Mr Blair and Labour thus have a momentous opportunity. Their established pledges to eliminate child poverty within 20 years, to lift the quality of public services and to heighten enrolment in university education are excellent, but they encompass too narrow a swathe of social concerns. Nor are they are bound into a vision of what the just society might be in the twenty-first century - what our cities might look like, how our society can cohere, how our democracy might become more vital. Too often in the past, Tony Blair's only political passion has appeared to be giving as little offence as possible. Last week he found a voice. Now the Prime Minister should argue the radical case across a range of issues. He should use it to champion a progressive vision of what Britain can be, to reignite the enthusiasm of his own side and to impress the centre. If he does that, he can once again secure a mandate to serve that vision. A second Labour general election victory, an ample majority, and with it a full term of office in which to continue the reshaping of Britain, is the impossible dream which has eluded the Left for a century. Now that the battle to secure that victory has begun, we need to see more of the political courage which can make it possible.

webTitle: The cost of obsessive rail safety

fields.headline: Speed limit sham that kills instead of cures
fields.standfirst:
Adam Raphael of the Economist, which last week exposed Railtrack's post-Hatfield folly, counts the cost of obsessive rail safety

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Adam Raphael of the Economist, which last week exposed Railtrack's post-Hatfield folly, counts the cost of obsessive rail safety.
fields.body:
What has happened on the railways in the past month is so irrational that it is impossible to defend.

The Hatfield crash which killed four people and injured more than 30 on 17 October was an unnecessary tragedy caused by an appalling failure of management by Railtrack. The broken rail which caused the crash had been identified as defective many months before but had not been replaced. The scenes of carnage - carriages with their roofs ripped off and mangled bodies - are hard to forget. But that does not justify the current chaos.

The immediate reaction to the crash by Railtrack, terrified of a media witch-hunt, was one of panic. Speed restrictions as low as 20mph were imposed across the rail network. More than 250 miles of track and 850 points were deemed to be in need of urgent replacement.

The result has been near paralysis, with train journeys taking longer than they did in the Victorian days of steam. Millions of passengers have been forced to seek alternative forms of transport. The consequences for retailers, business, industry and the Post Office have been devastating, with losses running into hundreds of millions.

If any of this had actually contributed to safety, it would have to be accepted. But the truth has now begun to emerge. This over-reaction, far from reducing risk, has actually increased the dangers to passengers.

The Hatfield accident was unusual. Though broken rails are a relatively common occurrence - averaging at least two a week - they have caused only six fatalities in the last 30 years. Much more lethal are incidents in which drivers pass red signals. These are 10 times more likely to cause a fatal accident than a broken rail.

The risk has been greatly increased by attempts to run a railway with no established timetable. Drivers currently have to consult up to 16 pages of special directions on speed restrictions.

Railtrack has belatedly begun to acknowledge this. It knows that blanket speed restrictions make no sense but, fearful of a public outcry, says it doesn't dare act without political support. 'We cannot afford to have another Hatfield' is the only excuse that is offered by rail executives and politicians.

The wish of those in power to save their own skins is understandable. But the costs to the public of this self-interest are considerable. Diverting millions of frustrated rail passengers on to the roads makes travel much more dangerous. The accident rate on the roads is 12 times that of rail.

In the past month the railways are estimated to have lost nearly a third of their passengers. The resulting growth in road traffic will cause at least five additional deaths and 75 seriously injured, according to road safety experts. Ministers and rail executives know this, of course, but are too frightened to take a lead.

Part of the problem post-Hatfield is the bureaucratic culture of safety which has been accelerated by privatisation. Everyone is determined to guard their own back. Railtrack officials privately admit that if they could be sure of political support they would lift many of the speed restrictions immediately. Since the rail safety story appeared in this week's Economist, Railtrack has revealed that it has asked the Health and Safety Executive to lift roughly 10 per cent of the 550 speed restrictions across the network.

The Executive is still nervous, however. Andrew Evans, professor of transport safety at University College London points out that if the media and politicians continually talk about corporate mismanagement and throwing executives into jail, 'then you will ultimately get totally safety-obsessed regimes'.

The Government's failure to take a balanced approach to safety is shown up by the grossly unequal amounts spent on rail and road safety. Many thousands are killed or seriously injured on the roads each year in accidents which could be avoided if safety expenditure between the two modes of transport was less skewed. All safety measures are judged by estimating the number of lives that can be saved for a given level of investment. The latest government valuation for preventing a fatal casualty on rail is £3.22m - three times that of a road death. These figures bear no relation to public opinion. A recent Health and Safety Executive report found that the public does not place more importance on preventing rail accidents than road accidents.

In fact, proposed expenditure on rail safety is so large that it bears little relation to reason let alone public preference. The former head of the Executive, Jenny Bacon, giving evidence to the joint inquiry looking into the Southall and Ladbroke Grove crashes, said government pronouncements that safety must be paramount were influential in gold-plating rail safety standards.

Take, for example, the proposed new Advanced Train Protection system. This would cost £2bn to install across the network, equivalent to more than £15-£30m per life saved. Contrast this to road safety projects which are approved only if benefits exceed costs by a huge margin. Local authorities will rarely improve road safety if the cost per fatality prevented is more than £100,000.

Rail passengers are right to demand safe trains, but it makes no sense to spend 150 times as much on saving a life on the railways as on saving a life on the roads. Panic is not a sane way to run a railway.

Let us have a sense of proportion and a willingness to acknowledge that all travel involves an element of risk.

webTitle: Saddam deputy's plane trip flies in the face of sanctions

fields.headline: Saddam deputy's plane trip flies in the face of sanctions
fields.standfirst: Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: Iraq turned up the heat in its challenge to the United Nations' sanctions regime as the country's Deputy Prime Minister, Tariq Aziz, arrived in the Syrian capital, Damascus, yesterday aboard the first direct Iraqi flight to Syria in nearly two decades.
fields.body:
Iraq turned up the heat in its challenge to the United Nations' sanctions regime as the country's Deputy Prime Minister, Tariq Aziz, arrived in the Syrian capital, Damascus, yesterday aboard the first direct Iraqi flight to Syria in nearly two decades.

The flight - which had not been approved by the sanctions committee - is the latest challenge to the UN, which has seen flights from more than a dozen countries arrive in Baghdad in recent weeks in defiance of the sanctions regime.

Aziz's flight - believed to be the first to carry an Iraqi official outside the country since the UN imposed sanctions against Baghdad in 1990 following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait - follows the gradual rehabilitation of Iraq among its Arab neighbours, in particular in the light of Saddam Hussein's outspoken support of the present Palestinian intifada.

Speaking to reporters after talks with Syrian Foreign Minister Farouq al-Shara, Aziz repeated his government's views that the UN sanctions did not ban the air travel.

Syria and Iraq, ruled by rival factions of the Baath Party, severed diplomatic ties after the outbreak of the 1980-1988 Iraq-Iran war in which Damascus sided with Tehran, but they agreed to restore relations and engage in economic co-operation three years ago.

Relations between Syria and Iraq have shown a marked thaw recently, not least over the proposed construction of an oil pipeline between the two countries.

The US and the UK - the strongest supporters of the current sanctions regime - insist that the pipeline will be used to pump and sell oil which will be sold outside of the UN's oil for food programme, designated by the UN as Iraq's only official outlet for its petroleum products.

webTitle: Millions at risk from air traffic sell-off

fields.headline: Millions at risk from air traffic sell-off
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Millions of airline passengers could be in danger because of sweeping financial cuts demanded as part of the privatisation of Britain's air traffic control service, documents obtained by The Observer reveal.
fields.body:
Millions of airline passengers could be in danger because of sweeping financial cuts demanded as part of the privatisation of Britain's air traffic control service, documents obtained by The Observer reveal.

A briefing document prepared by National Air Traffic Services (Nats) last month says that plans to cut up to £165 million from their budget over the next five years will undermine safety of passengers and mean that the 1.8 million flights a year over Britain could descend into chaos.

Air traffic controllers and pilot representatives spoken to by The Observer described Government plans to privatise 51 per cent of Nats, which controls air traffic across Britain's skies, as 'horrific'.

'What Nats are saying is that under these plans they cannot maintain the level of safety,' one air traffic controller said. 'Economics is taking the lead in this debate. Quite simply, that is dangerous.'

He pointed out that controllers were already incredibly overstretched and, with air traffic increasing by about 7 per cent a year as more people take holiday and business trips abroad, no cuts could be afforded.

The revelation of Nats' anger at the proposed cuts comes at a particularly sensitive time for the Government. Tomorrow it faces a humiliating defeat in the Lords on its plans to partially privatise air traffic control services, one of the most controversial policies it has attempted to introduce.

Conservative and Liberal Democrat Lords are planning to scupper the Transport Bill which contains the plans. The Government would then have to force through the legislation using its majority in the Commons or abandon the changes until next year.

As part of its consultation on the issue, the Government asked the Civil Aviation Authority, which overseas the regulation of the skies, to come up with an economic formula which would bring big savings.

The CAA came up with an equation also used for other privatised utilities, the RPI minus X formula. The author ity's economic regulation group (ERG) said that real savings of 5 per cent could be found from the Nats budget every year.

'ERG is proposing a tougher X than was set for any other utility at privatisation,' the Nats briefing document says. 'This is especially inappropriate for a safety activity where service depends on adequate investment.

'ERG places too much emphasis on cost reduction and neglects the risk to service delivery.'

The briefing document, dated 9 October, was handed to the white collar union which represents controllers, the Institution of Professionals, Managers and Specialists.

It echoes an earlier consultation document produced by Nats which raised similar concerns in the spring.

The CAA was told to re-think their proposals on the cuts but senior air traffic sources says the follow-up plans 'were hardly any better'.It is to these later plans that the October Nats briefing refers.

The general secretary of the IPMS, Paul Hoon, has now written to the transport minister, Lord Macdonald, demanding that he abandons the plans for huge cuts.

'We have profound concerns about the implications of the ERG proposals for Nats,' the letter says.

'In our view RPI minus 5 would be bound to result in severe cost cutting which would impact adversely on staffing levels, efficiency and safety.

'Bearing in mind the demands on Nats of coping with increasing air traffic and of maintaining safety it is completely unrealistic to expect the organisation to deliver major cost reductions at the same time.'

Controllers are now pushing for the Government to dump the CAA plans and allow for greater investment in the service.

The Government has always argued that privatising part of the air traffic control service would allow private money to be invested in it's creaking infrastructure.

Lord Macdonald said that he had yet to take a decision on the cuts.

'Since I have not yet reached a decision on the level of the charge control and since CAA's advice has not been published, I do not think it would be appropriate at this stage to discuss my thinking in details,' he wrote to Noon last week.

fields.headline: Climate talks end in disarray
fields.standfirst:
 Prescott storms out of Hague summit  US refuses to cut global warming gases : Planet's future grows dark

Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Global talks aimed at saving the world from climatic mayhem collapsed in chaos yesterday, dealing a potentially fatal blow to efforts to cut industrial gases that threaten the planet.
fields.byline: Robin McKie,  Science Editor, The Hague
fields.body:
Global talks aimed at saving the world from climatic mayhem collapsed in chaos yesterday, dealing a potentially fatal blow to efforts to cut industrial gases that threaten the planet.

The convention on climate change in The Hague was expected to agree international rules for controlling carbon dioxide emission but ended dramatically when Britain's chief negotiator, John Prescott, stormed out.

'I am gutted,' the Deputy Prime Minister told reporters as he strode angrily out of the conference centre. 'There is no deal. The talks are finished. We came so close.'

The negotiations - some of the most complex and important international talks ever staged - were being held to find ways of implementing the Kyoto agreement on reducing industrial emissions and to halt growing global warming already triggering sea level rises and climate changes.

Discussions broke down at the last minute yesterday when European delegates rejected a US proposal, brokered by Prescott, that would have allowed America a smaller cut in domestic emissions. Now hopes of reaching a deal rest on a final UN climate meeting in Bonn in May.

Failure then would leave the world perilously exposed to the dangers of climatic chaos. These include total inundation of nations such as Bangladesh and the Maldives, major disruptions in weather patterns, destruction of habitats and crops, and the emergence of new epidemics.

The collapse of the talks was greeted with fury by Green activists. 'If governments continue to act irresponsibly, as they have done this week, then people from rich countries should prepare to build ever higher and higher water dykes from which they can watch the rest of the world suffer and drown from climate change,' said a Greenpeace observer.

'You've sunk the world,' shouted protesters outside the hall. 'The world will pay the price in tears,' said a Friends of the Earth official. 'We will not forgive or forget those who wrecked the talks.'

Feelings of betrayal were shared by delegates. 'We were being watched by the rest of the world,' said conference president Jan Pronk. 'We have not lived up to their expectations. I am very disappointed.'

The breakdown is also a political blow for John Prescott who had staked his reputation as a negotiator on achieving success, but who will only now be remembered for his furious walkout from the convention. In retrospect, his hyping of his prospects before the Hague looks naive.

Yet early yesterday a deal between the US and Europe had looked possible. On one side, Europe had sought a deal in which developed nations' carbon dioxide output would be reduced, mainly through cuts in domestic emissions, while the US was desperate to find alternatives that would not disrupt its citizens' energy-profligate lifestyles.

The US pours more than 1,600 million tonnes of carbon dioxide - 24 per cent of the global total - into the atmosphere every year. But rather than reduce this, the US government has sought to find ways of creating 'carbon sinks' - trees and plants that would absorb carbon dioxide - on its own land, and in the developing world. This idea has been attacked by most delegates, particularly the Europeans, who believe lower emissions are the only way to save the world. Americans accuse Europe of trying to impose moral codes on others.

Negotiations have gone on 24 hours a day for the past fortnight inside The Hague's vast, plush international convention centre. Without a watch, it is impossible to tell whether it is night or day. As one delegate put it: 'It's like living in a Las Vegas casino, except we are gambling with tonnes of carbon and the future of the planet.' Despite this intense, round-the-clock debate - and the years of preparation that have gone into a conference that Environment Minister Michael Meacher described as the most carefully anticipated negotiations he has taken part in - the two sides were still deadlocked yesterday morning.

Prescott then took over and, in exchange for US concessions, brokered a proposal that would have allowed it to reduce its emissions cutbacks. In triumph, Meacher appeared on the Radio 4 Today programme and announced that after an all-night deadlock he and Prescott had achieved a breakthrough. 'This is a very, very important achievement,' he added. Seven hours later that deal lay in ashes after EU delegates - led by leading members of the Green Party, Dominique Voynet of France, and Jurgen Tritten of Germany, had vetoed his compromise package.

'It was a complex deal and we simply ran out of time,' said Meacher later. Voynet disagreed, however: 'Britain conceded too much to America. It was not acceptable.'

In other words, Europe vetoed Britain's bid to assuage the Americans, a point not lost on Prescott as he stormed angrily through the conference hall. Asked whether divisions among the European delegations had been responsible for the breakdown, he told reporters: 'There could have been more unity.' 'Expectations were very high,' announced a grim-looking Pronk a few hours later. 'But we have no agreement.'

Now the world has one shot left - in Bonn in May. Most observers remain gloomy about negotiations then, especially as the next US president could be George W. Bush, who has close links to the oil industry and has displayed an antipathy to the Green movement.

Only Meacher sounded a note of confidence yesterday: 'We got close. We had the core of a deal. We can start with that next time.'

Now hopes of reaching a deal rest on a final UN climate meeting in Bonn in May. Failure then would leave the world perilously exposed to the dangers of climatic chaos. These include total inundation of nations such as Bangladesh and the Maldives, major disruptions in weather patterns, destruction of habitats and crops, and the emergence of new epidemics. The collapse of the talks was greeted with fury by Green activists. 'If governments continue to act irresponsibly, as they have done this week, then people from rich countries should prepare to build ever higher and higher water dykes from which they can watch the rest of the world suffer and drown from climate change,' said a Greenpeace observer. 'You've sunk the world,' shouted protesters outside the hall. 'The world will pay the price in tears,' said a Friends of the Earth official. 'We will not forgive or forget those who wrecked the talks.' Feelings of betrayal were shared by delegates. 'We were being watched by the rest of the world,' said conference president Jan Pronk. 'We have not lived up to their expectations. I am very disappointed.' The breakdown is also a political blow for John Prescott who had staked his reputation as a negotiator on achieving success, but who will only now be remembered for his furious walkout from the convention. In retrospect, his hyping of his prospects before the Hague looks naive. Yet early yesterday a deal between the US and Europe had looked possible. On one side, Europe had sought a deal in which developed nations' carbon dioxide output would be reduced, mainly through cuts in domestic emissions, while the US was desperate to find alternatives that would not disrupt its citizens' energy-profligate lifestyles. The US pours more than 1,600 million tonnes of carbon dioxide - 24 per cent of the global total - into the atmosphere every year. But rather than reduce this, the US government has sought to find ways of creating 'carbon sinks' - trees and plants that would absorb carbon dioxide - on its own land, and in the developing world. This idea has been attacked by most delegates, particularly the Europeans, who believe lower emissions are the only way to save the world. Americans accuse Europe of trying to impose moral codes on others. Negotiations have gone on 24 hours a day for the past fortnight inside The Hague's vast, plush international convention centre. Without a watch, it is impossible to tell whether it is night or day. As one delegate put it: 'It's like living in a Las Vegas casino, except we are gambling with tonnes of carbon and the future of the planet.' Despite this intense, round-the-clock debate - and the years of preparation that have gone into a conference that Environment Minister Michael Meacher described as the most carefully anticipated negotiations he has taken part in - the two sides were still deadlocked yesterday morning. Prescott then took over and, in exchange for US concessions, brokered a proposal that would have allowed it to reduce its emissions cutbacks. In triumph, Meacher appeared on the Radio 4 Today programme and announced that after an all-night deadlock he and Prescott had achieved a breakthrough. 'This is a very, very important achievement,' he added. Seven hours later that deal lay in ashes after EU delegates - led by leading members of the Green Party, Dominique Voynet of France, and Jurgen Tritten of Germany, had vetoed his compromise package. 'It was a complex deal and we simply ran out of time,' said Meacher later. Voynet disagreed, however: 'Britain conceded too much to America. It was not acceptable.' In other words, Europe vetoed Britain's bid to assuage the Americans, a point not lost on Prescott as he stormed angrily through the conference hall. Asked whether divisions among the European delegations had been responsible for the breakdown, he told reporters: 'There could have been more unity.' 'Expectations were very high,' announced a grim-looking Pronk a few hours later. 'But we have no agreement.' Now the world has one shot left - in Bonn in May. Most observers remain gloomy about negotiations then, especially as the next US president could be George W. Bush, who has close links to the oil industry and has displayed an antipathy to the Green movement. Only Meacher sounded a note of confidence yesterday: 'We got close. We had the core of a deal. We can start with that next time.' webTitle: Tories draw up plans to 'privatise' adoption agencies

fields.headline: Tories draw up plans to 'privatise' adoption agencies
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: The tories are drawing up secret plans to privatise adoption services, including the vetting of would-be parents and running of care homes.
fields.body:
The tories are drawing up secret plans to privatise adoption services, including the vetting of would-be parents and running of care homes.

The controversial move would hand unprecedented powers over the lives of vulnerable children to private agencies, charities or religious organisations. It raises serious questions about the protection of youngsters.

But shadow ministers argue that after a string of abuse scandals, and controversy over adoptive parents being rejected by 'politically correct' social workers, the existing system is failing.

Shadow health secretary Liam Fox is drawing up the blueprint with home affairs spokesman David Lidington, who oversees the new US-style Renewing One Nation taskforce aiming to involve religious groups and the private sector in welfare.

Fox told The Observer he was considering all options for adoption reform including bringing in the private sector.

'What we want to have is a properly regulated service, and I don't think it matters so much who actually does it,' he added.

'I want a proper national register for all prospective adoptive and fostering parents with an objective set of criteria, so that if you were on the register you would be considered suitable anywhere in the country.

'And we want to make sure that all children in care over a certain length of time, probably a year, would get an adoption plan drawn up for them.

'I am all in favour of not having it an exclusively state sector, as long as we have protection for children and get suitable monitoring.'

The running of children's homes could also 'potentially' be contracted out to private firms, he added, and be state-regulated as private nursing homes are.

Fox has studied a forthcoming report from the influential right-wing think-tank the Bow Group, which condemns the state as 'the worst parent in Britain'.

It suggests that private providers be paid by results such as educational achievements for children in care, while the private sector should 'take over entirely the vetting of adoptive parents and the placement of children'.

Shadow ministers are not prepared to go that far, arguing for a mix of public and private sector provision.

But their plans were condemned as 'grotesque' by Shaun Woodward, the ex-Tory MP who defected to Labour and is a trustee of Childline.

'The state does not have a record without blemish. But to move from a recognition that something needs to be fixed to saying we completely give up on it and we are prepared to put it into the private sector, which at the end of the day is about profit, is fundamentally wrong.'

He conceded that involving the voluntary sector in some areas could work if regulated. Ministers are expected to expand the role of children's charities in their forthcoming adoption white paper.

A Tory spokesman said different solutions would be expected in different areas of the UK depending on who could provide the best outcome. 'What we need to do is find the method that is best rather than getting hung up on ideology.'

The plan will be seen as evidence of the influence of George W. Bush's 'compassionate conservatism' policy of devolving welfare to charities and private firms.

webTitle: Power of positive thinking on Aids

fields.headline: Power of positive thinking
fields.standfirst:
The public no longer cares about the disease, so Britain's Mr Aids is glad Prince Charles visited HIV patients - no matter what the cynics say. Euan Ferguson meets Nick Partridge

Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: The public no longer cares about the disease, so Britain's Mr Aids is glad Prince Charles visited HIV patients - no matter what the cynics say. Euan Ferguson meets Nick Partridge.
fields.body:
Can there be anything less sexy than what happens after sex? The guddling through ashtrays, the naked traipse through to a grim kitchen to put the kettle on, the furtive binning of the condom, the twilight, the recriminations and, according to one's circumstances, the resumption of telly or the guilty phone call or the long awkward drive back to the zoo. And, for the past two decades, and least sexily of all, people getting very ill, and then very ill indeed, and then dying.

This is less sexy now - in the sense in which the word's been shanghai'd by commercial marketing types - than any other kind of dying. In a definitive recent survey of 24 different health charities, and the public's willingness to give to them, Aids charities expected to come below the popular killers, your cancer and hearts and strokes. They didn't necessarily expect to come absolutely last, somewhere after goitre research and chlamydia relief.

So Nick Partridge, chief executive of the newly merged Terrence Higgins Trust and London Lighthouse project, Britain's Mr Aids, is perhaps the least cynical man in the country about Prince Charles's much-publicised visit last week to the Lighthouse hospice, where he cuddled babies and chatted to HIV positive mothers and invoked the memory of Diana. The Prince received plenty of welcome publicity, of course - though Nick insists he was 'absolutely genuinely interested in what was going on with Aids - as, to be honest, any father of teenage children in Britain today should be.' But Nick and his staff and patients got their names and pictures on the front pages too, and jumped at the chance: for this is Britain's forgotten charity. Stupidly, needlessly forgotten: for there are, today, more HIV positive people in Britain than at any time before.

Nick explains the problem as he sits in Oxford Street's Selfridges organising determined-looking volunteers into the drizzle for a day of bin-rattling ('Selfridges have been very good to us. They've got a good corporate policy. Also, bluntly, they've got a lot of gay staff.') He is a very well-preserved 45, easy to smile and slow, these days at least, to anger.

The problem's simple. The drugs do work. Aids is no longer the genuinely terrifying gorgon it was in the Eighties and early Nineties. Since CT - combination therapy - was introduced experimentally a few years ago to treat HIV, it has proved astonishingly good at saving lives. 'Since 1996/97, the number of people dying from Aids has dropped by 70 per cent,' Nick explains.

'What that's meant is phenomenal. There are all the changes in our services, of course. We teach people to readjust to expect to live, rather than teaching them to plan to die. And many lives have been saved. But what it also means is - ' he sighs - 'a huge complacency. It is still such a problem. It is still transmissible. People still die. But we have to raise £8m a year to keep these charities going, and yet, because of the generational thing, and prejudice, people will always leave their money to animals, or children, a long long time before they leave it to us.'

I ask about the swiftness of the new mood. Can he remember actually feeling a sea-change in the battle against Aids, a new hope?

'Absolutely. It was at the International Aids Conference in Vancouver in 1996, the one that heralded the combination therapy revolution. Being an American/Canadian event, they were deliberately, relentlessly upbeat - there had to be good news every day. But that didn't stop me suddenly realising there genuinely was something new. I'd been involved with Aids work since 1983 - 13 years, in which there was so much, death, illness, loss and grief. Suddenly, after all that, being able to dare to be at all optimistic, even though we were cautious, it was such a joy.

'For me, however, it was also tinged with sadness. At the same time as the CT news was breaking, one of my colleagues, Paul, who managed the hardship fund, was dying back here in London. He was 31. He died on the final day of conference; the first thing I had to do when I returned here was to lead his funeral. So the renewed hope that combination therapy has given to so many people will always for me be coloured with the memory of those who died.'

The last Aids-related funeral he went to was in early 1998. Before that, he was at about one a month. The change is 'unimaginable, even five years ago'. But the drugs won't cure everyone - about 500 will still die this year in Britain - and infection is on the increase once more.

'One of the main barriers is the number of people who won't get tested, even though they suspect they might be positive - they'll be diagnosed too late and the drugs can only halt decline by then, they can't rebuild the immune system.' Today, he added, one of the two communities most affected - gay men and drug-injectors - is much safer, as the shared-needle epidemic has been largely contained, 'thanks to good public health, needle exchanges and the rest.

'But there is real concern at the increase in new infections among young gay men. It's hard to know exactly what the figures are, but I think I know why it's happening. Remember that we're 19 years into this: an 18-year-old man now coming out and exploring his sexuality was only one or two years old when our screens were filled with the iceberg campaign.

'But it's not just young people's ignorance: for older generations now, with the new drugs, there's a sense of wanting to try to forget, to forget the years of difficulty and misery and death. Some will behave as if they have forgotten. And, put bluntly, whether it's ignorance or complacency, both of them still kill. There are about 30,000 people in Britain today living with HIV, but only 20,000 of them know they have it.

'I do know, of course, that being tested is still such a difficult thing to do.' (Has he been tested? 'I don't really want to talk about my own health.') 'You can have it done much faster, within a day, but the result can still devastate, even with these drugs. And there is that whole horrible thing of having to think who you may have infected, and contact them - that's what makes this so different to any other fatal illness.'

There is, I seem to feel from him, a real and vicious anger against the virus: against its suddenness, its capriciousness, the personal devastation it has had on too many friends. He nods, quietly. 'And it's also been a useful touchstone, if you like, against prejudice. There are those who have always had difficulties with gay men and drug users and sex and death, and black Africans' - for this last class, he has explained, is the other group among whom the virus is still raging: on a recent visit to QuaZulu/Natal he found 25 per cent of the adult population were infected. 'The success of the drugs has, if you like, given them new permission to ignore these things.'

He is still worried, he admits, even now at this late stage, of a backlash against gay men: and worried, too, 'that we might still lose against this very stupid virus.'

Stupid?

'Well, you're right, it is just a virus. It just goes where it is allowed to go. But, actually, yes, I do hate it. I try not to personalise it, but it's hard not to hate. And it is stupid: it has its own inbuilt defect, which is that it has to mutate - so the question, over the next few years, is whether pharmaceutical companies can keep up with its mutations: it's a race.'

But it's a race, he says more calmly, 'without that early Eighties sense of panic. Which is good. As long as we don't get something equally dangerous - the complacency that might take its place.'

webTitle: Inner feud divides UVF over truce with UDA

fields.headline: Inner feud divides UVF over truce with UDA
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Serious divisions have emerged inside the Ulster Volunteer Force over negotiations to end their feud with the Ulster Defence Association on Belfast's Shankill Road.
fields.body:
Serious divisions have emerged inside the Ulster Volunteer Force over negotiations to end their feud with the Ulster Defence Association on Belfast's Shankill Road.

The Observer has learnt that one UVF commander has resigned from talks aimed at ending the violence because he believes the organisation has gone soft on the UDA's Lower Shankill unit.

UVF members in the area are also understood to be opposed to their leadership's willingness to accept a truce at this stage.

They feel they are 'winning the war' against Johnny 'Mad Dog' Adair's 'C' company and should keep the pressure on their rivals in order to extract further concessions from the UDA leadership.

But the UVF's so-called Brigade Staff is known to be keen to end the four-month old feud that has claimed seven lives. Given the highly-centralised nature of the UVF command structure it is likely that the Brigade Staff will get its way and secure a ceasefire on the Shankill.

UVF sceptics say the leadership should have held out to force the UDA leadership to discipline its Lower Shankill unit, and oblige Adair's comrades to apologise for starting the feud in the first place.

The inter-loyalist violence on the Shankill began in August, following a UDA band parade through the loyalist stronghold. The UDA broke an agreement made between the two organisations that no banners from the dissident Loyalist Volunteer Force group would be displayed on the Shankill Road.

The flaunting of the LVF banner in front of the Rex Bar, a pub frequented by UVF members, triggered fist fights and eventually a shooting war between the rival factions. While a resolution is now in sight on the Shankill, another feud between the UVF and LVF in Mid Ulster is far from over. The UVF says it has still to exact revenge for the murder of its Mid Ulster brigadier, Richard Jameson, who was shot dead at the beginning of this year.

There are also dangerous divisions between different UDA 'companies' in the Greater Shankill area over their conduct during the feud with the UVF. Members of Adair's 'C' company are bitter that UDA men in 'A' and 'B' company of the organisation's west Belfast brigade failed to participate in the feuding. UDA commanders in the Highfield and Glencairn areas refused to obey orders from 'C' company to drive UVF members and supporters from their houses on the two estates.

More than 800 men, women and children were forced out of their homes during the feud, which has left the Shankill divided into two zones of paramilitary influence. Agnes Street remains the effective border line between the UDA-dominated Lower Shankill and the upper part of the road where the UVF is stronger.
