fields.headline: Risking death on the 'drag'
fields.standfirst:
Victim of violence warns prostitutes of the price to pay for drug addiction

Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: It should never have happened. These are the words used by prostitutes in Glasgow's red light area when they talk about the savage attack on 31-year-old Alison Wallace, a working woman who stood alongside them in the city.
fields.body:
It should never have happened. These are the words used by prostitutes in Glasgow's red light area when they talk about the savage attack on 31-year-old Alison Wallace, a working woman who stood alongside them in the city.

And, of course, they are right. When Alison - a mother of two young children - went with a punter to Drumpellier Country Park in Lanarkshire, she should never have been bludgeoned by him beyond recognition and left clinging tenuously to life - she should have been murdered.

Those who work Glasgow's red light area - the drag, as it is called, with its lanes lit yellow by the street lights and the headlamps of prowling cars - are all too aware of its dangers. In the past eight years, seven working women have been murdered, paying the ultimate price for their prostitution, their drug habits and their poverty.

On 17 July this year, but for a passing taxi driver who spotted her battered and bloody body in that isolated park, Alison Wallace would have been the eighth.

Four months on, Strathclyde police have renewed their attempts to trace an attacker who gave a woman injuries so bad that doctors at Glasgow's Southern General Hospital described them as the worst they had seen.

Alison, from Milton, has little feeling on her left side, is brain damaged and uses a walking stick to get around. A scar runs from the front of her head to the back and she remembers nothing of the attack. It has taken this, she explains, to force her out of prostitution and drug taking.

'Down the drag you think that you will be okay, that it won't happen to you,' she told The Observer, only one of two newspapers she has agreed to talk to since the attack. 'But I feel that I have been to hell and back. This man has done a terrible thing.'

She sits quietly, hunched, and makes little eye contact. Once streetwise, now her confidence has been shattered.

The police say there are more than 1,000 women, 93 per cent of them drug addicts, who take to Glasgow's streets regularly. At Base 75, the drop-in centre for prostitutes, workers report violent attacks, rapes and robberies at the hands of punters.

The women are aware of men who are not averse to using them as punch-bags or who have no qualms about kicking refunds out of them. Yet there is a distinction between the violent minority of men and those who treat prostitution as a business transaction.

Despite the violence and threats prostitutes suffer, however, the number of incidents reported is small.

When The Observer spoke to Alison Wallace, she warned young girls away from prostitution. The same day, a fatal accident inquiry was concluding at the other side of the city. It concerned Michele Kearney, a 16-year-old whose involvement in the world of prostitution and heroin led to her death. Although placed in accommodation supervised by social workers and the subject of a care order, Michele began to work as a prostitute full time.

Last year, she went missing from the social work flat in Springburn and was found dead at another prostitute's flat. She had choked on her vomit after injecting drugs.

Sophia Young, project leader of Turnaround, a group that offers support to female drug-takers and women who work the streets, says all the prostitutes that come through its doors are using drugs heavily. Most use heroin and diazepam but an increasing number are turning to cocaine, which is cheap. But it is the poverty of the women and the violence against them that Young finds most disturbing.

'The number of rapes, attempted murders, kidnaps and assaults against them is almost unbelievable,' she says. 'The West of Scotland has a real problem with violence against working women, which seems to be because more of them are visible and work on the streets.'

At Cranstonhill police station in Glasgow's city centre there is a team of six officers, dedicated to policing and protecting the women on the drag. Resources are few at the office - one electricity power point does for the kettle and the telephone's answering machine.

Sergeant Denis Feeney, who heads 'A' Division's street liaison team, believes most women are there to feed their own or their partner's habit. 'There is no Pretty Woman syndrome,' he insists. 'No one is there to pay for their holiday to Barbados. If a woman earns £60 in a night, £59 will go towards drugs. The biggest problem is not prostitution, but drugs.'

The average age of prostitutes is around 25, but, more are becoming involved as teenagers and who come from areas such as Lanarkshire, Greenock, Clydebank and Ayrshire.

One month after Alison Wallace was attacked, the Government announced a £1.8m plan to get prostitutes off the streets by funding a drop-in centre and accommodation. Jackie Baillie, then Deputy Communities Minister, described it as 'an ambitious new initiative', but some prostitutes said the the accommodation was 'a government-sponsored broth-el'. Three months on, the number of prostitutes on Glasgow's streets is still high.

An initiative that is proving successful, however, is the anonymous reporting scheme, which enables women to give details of crimes and criminals - via a support worker or other trusted person - without making their identities known to the police.

'Through this we have had several successful prosecutions of people who have carried out major attacks,' said Feeney. 'At the moment we have a man awaiting trial for three rapes.'

A memorial book held at Base 75 lists more than 50 names. Most were victims of an overdose or suicide.

Of the eight inquiries, seven were murders but only one - that of Margo Lafferty - resulted in a conviction. fields.headline: Railtrack goes half steam ahead
fields.standfirst:
Moves to win back passengers as go-slow is relaxed

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Leading railway companies are planning to let passengers travel anywhere in the country for £1 in a desperate attempt to woo back furious travellers who are deserting the trains for their cars.
fields.body:
Leading railway companies are planning to let passengers travel anywhere in the country for £1 in a desperate attempt to woo back furious travellers who are deserting the trains for their cars.

The one-off one-day special offer is being considered alongside a raft of promotions for the spring when the railway service should be back to a semblance of normality.

'We will have to be very aggressive with our strategy,' said a source at GNER which has seen numbers fall by up to 40 per cent on some routes between London and Edinburgh. Virgin Trains said it was being 'as creative as possible' in its thinking about how to reconnect with passengers.

Details of the scheme emerged as Railtrack signalled that it will this week remove or relax more than half the 550 speed restrictions that have plunged train travel into chaos over the last month.

The move is expected to be sanctioned at a board meeting tomorrow and will pose a challenge to the safety authorities, which have demanded an ultra-cautious stance after last month's Hatfield crash.

The Observer has also learned that Railtrack is now willing to support the creation of a new national body to oversee rail safety. Outgoing chief executive Gerald Corbett, who resigned 10 days ago, had formerly blocked the idea.

This week's initiative to speed up the trains follows exhaustive inspections of the tracks and growing confidence within Railtrack that it has public and Government support for the move. Yet Britain is still heading for a gridlocked winter. Decades of neglect, overcrowding and recent crises have left many road, rail and even air journeys taking longer to complete today than 40 years ago. In many cases Victorian horse-and-carts moved faster.

The 'rail renaissance' that saw annual passenger numbers rise by a quarter in three years to one billion has been wiped out, and operators say it will take up to a year and a huge campaign of advertising and special offers to regain customers and maintain Government targets to increase passenger rail by 50 per cent and freight by 80 per cent in the next decade.

Railtrack has been facing growing criticism that to persist with the level of caution applied after Hatfield is now excessive and, as The Observer revealed last week, even a threat to safety as tired train drivers grapple with complex speed restrictions. Passengers are flocking back to the roads, where death rates are far higher.

This week, instead of seeking prior approval from the Health and Safety Executive to lift the 20mph limits, Railtrack will issue orders to increase limits to 40mph, 60mph, 80mph or full speed, depending on the state of the tracks. This will challenge the rail inspectorate to prove the plan is not safe once it is drawn up and starts to be implemented.

A senior industry source said: 'Railtrack is going to take a proactive decision and basically defy the HSE to overturn it. There is a feeling that if the plan is blocked the nation is ready to rebel.'

Meanwhile it has emerged that Railtrack's new chief executive Steve Marshall has been persuaded by the Government's 'rail enforcer' Sir Alastair Morton to back a new, completely independent rail safety body for the whole industry that would act as the rail equivalent of the Civil Aviation Authority in setting standards, inspecting them and investigating accidents.

webTitle: End of boom and bust? Maybe

fields.headline: End of boom and bust? Maybe
fields.trailText: In PG Wodehouse's last, incomplete novel (published posthumously) the Chancellor of the Exchequer has difficulty finding the right moment to propose to the woman he loves. Quizzed on this by the Earl of Emsworth's indomitable brother, Galahad Threepwood, the Chancellor complains he never gets the chance, because his private detective is always in the way.
fields.body:
In PG Wodehouse's last, incomplete novel (published posthumously) the Chancellor of the Exchequer has difficulty finding the right moment to propose to the woman he loves. Quizzed on this by the Earl of Emsworth's indomitable brother, Galahad Threepwood, the Chancellor complains he never gets the chance, because his private detective is always in the way.

'The trouble with you politicians,' says Threepwood, 'is that you wrap up your statements to such an extent with double-talk that the lay mind needs an electric drill to get at the meaning. Tell me in a few simple words what the hell you're talking about.'

Many people must have agreed with Threepwood when confronted with New Labour. For three-and-a-half years we have often wondered what they were talking about. Indeed millions who finally showed they had had enough of Thatcherism (even when refined as Majorism) on 1 May 1997 were puzzled to find the new Prime Minister lauding Margaret Thatcher on a number of ill-chosen occasions. To put it mildly, people felt Blair was rubbing salt in the wounds.

Last week, however, there was a significant moment when the Prime Minister finally distanced himself from her. 'I take nothing away from those things that were done in the Eighties that we have kept,' he said, 'but it really is time in my view that we move British politics beyond the time of Margaret Thatcher.'

He went on: 'We are in a new era. Today we have to deal with those problems we inherited from that time - the boom and bust economics, the social division, the chronic underinvestment in our public services.' There was more: 'A sensible, modern attitude to Europe is what we need,' he concluded.

As one of those who have waited approximately so long for him to make such a statement, I was rather pleased to be in the room at the time. Our leader was responding to questions after unveiling 'Spending Review 2000', which fleshes out the departmental details of the Government's new-found resolve to make massive improvements in public sector services, via much greater investment.

Insofar as one can gauge these things when confronted with such a consummate politician as Tony Blair, the remarks seemed to come from the heart. Certainly, they may have been triggered by Baroness Thatcher's objections to the idea of a European Rapid Reaction Force (we all know New Labour has had its own Rapid Reaction Force for years). But the Prime Minister appeared to speak with feeling.

The things Blair objects to form quite a list. One is tempted to ask, after the famous remark to Abraham Lincoln's widow 'apart from that, Mr Blair, how did you enjoy the Eighties?' In fact, of course, what Labour has kept is the altered power structure between unions and employers, much of the 'market' and 'deregulation' approach, and the obsession with privatisa tion. It has also decided to act at only one end of the 'social division.'

For all its attacks on sleaze and fat cats in opposition, the party has dropped the 'politics of envy'. It is a remarkable fact that the whole nation seems to have been obsessed with the million pounds won by Judith Keppel last week; yet appreciable though it is - say £50,000 a year at 5 per cent - the income on that million is a mere fraction of the top people's salaries that used to annoy Labour in opposition.

Essentially, New Labour takes a Croslandite approach, of going for economic growth rather than redistribution. But I somehow doubt whether, given the present state of the public services, the late Tony Crosland would have spent almost an entire first term allowing the 'chronic underinvestment' that Blair complains about to become even worse. Nor would those forefathers of New Labour such as Crosland and Roy Jenkins have gone ahead with the privatisation of air traffic control. It was noteworthy that, in spelling out the public investment plans last week, Blair's only reference to this was a hurried muttering of the acronym 'Nats', which means nothing to most people but stands for National Air Traffic Control System.

One supposes that the Prime Minister now feels he can be more open because he has seen his false friends in certain sections of the press for what they are, and he must now be feeling reasonably secure about the next election, although it would be a mistake for the Government to become too cocky: the down-to-earth British don't like that sort of thing.

Which brings us to that 'boom and bust economics' on which subject I feel the need to utter a friendly warning. Yes, it is amazing that a Labour Government has lasted this long without any of the familiar financial crises of the past. And yes, the Chancellor has piled up the greatest budget surplus since Nigel Lawson's - this time to be invested, on prudent assumptions about the growth of revenue, and not squandered on tax cuts.

Nevertheless, while political capital can be made out of this, it would be presumptuous to believe that the Gov ernment has really eliminated 'boom and bust', either here or, a fortiori , abroad. If the US or continental Europe sneezes, we shall certainly catch their cold.

The latest Economic Outlook from the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development points out that that our exports have benefited from a boom in world and European trade that is almost certainly slowing down, and that 'on most estimates the pound remains overvalued'. It notes that much of the recent consumer spending spree has been fuelled by the buoyancy of the stock and housing markets, and that the UK savings ratio is the lowest since the Eighties and well below that in other European countries.

The International Monetary Fund sees possible trouble ahead from a weakening of sterling, and clearly suspects the strong pound has made the inflation picture look better than the underlying position may warrant. Meanwhile, the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee regards the economy as 'at [or perhaps past] a turning point in the growth cycle', and said in its minutes 'the downside risks needed to be watched carefully'.

Yes, the days of 'boom and bust' may be over. On the other hand, they may not.

webTitle: More dash than full stop for dotcoms

fields.headline: More dash than full stop for dotcoms
fields.standfirst:
The cyperbole is now gone, but the digital revolution has created a whole new business model in the music trade - and every other industry
Net news
fields.trailText: The cyperbole is now gone, but the digital revolution has created a whole new business model in the music trade - and every other industry.
fields.body:
With stricken dotcoms falling fast it's hard to resist a trace of schadenfreude at the sight of Silicon Valley twentysomethings lamenting premature midlife crises and US start-ups stampeding to remove the '.com' from their names. Only the most unscrupulous company promoter will mourn the end of 'cyperbole' - but it would be equally dangerous to lurch to the opposite extreme and conclude that the internet show is over and it's back to business as before.

'The market crash was very cathartic,' says Don Tapscott, internet observer and co-author of Digital Capital , one of the best attempts so far to get under the froth to establish what's really happening to business on the web. 'It ended the period when everyone thought it was about websites, dotcoms, IPOs and off to the races. The real issue is how it changes business models in the commanding heights of the economy.'

For that, look no further than the music industry, the example with which the obliging book opens. The force of the internet, say the authors, is that it fundamentally transforms the economics of organisations. By lowering transaction costs - the costs of searching for information, drawing up contracts and coordinating activities - the internet makes it feasible to do things outside the company that it previously made more sense to do inside.

This potentially means the end not just of vertically integrated companies (imagine that, just a generation ago, Unilever owned oil palm plantations and ships to carry the raw materials to its factories), but of conventionally integrated companies of any sort.

In the past it was most cost-effective to carry out the expensive interlinked activities of finding music acts and recording them, doing deals and arranging manufacture and distribution within a large corpora tion - hence the domination of giants such as Time-Warner, EMI and Bertelsmann.

But the internet has pulled the whole value chain apart. Digitalisation and the peer-to-peer MP3 standard mean that manufacturing and distribution costs drop to nothing - indeed the latter is carried out by consumers themselves. By the same token, musicians don't need the record companies, either, since they can distribute their music in the form they choose from their own websites.

A new business model emerges in which, for example, a band uses free distribution on the web to sell tickets for a concert tour.

Or take Napster, the MP3 site being sued for copyright infringement, which has now done a deal with Bertelsmann that will allow the former to distribute singles on low-cost subscription while retaining control of its copyright for use in other forms.

Or look at the traditional business of stockbroking. It consists of market data and analysis, news and views, advice and discussion groups as well as the transaction of buying or selling shares. Tapscott explains: 'The internet allows us to break all that up into its constituent parts, reaggregate it on the web, brand it and you have businesses like E*Trade and Schwab which have taken away one-third of a whole industry's revenue.'

The strength of Digital Capital is that it has many examples like this. Based originally on a company-funded research programme looking into the business implications of online communities, it changed its emphasis as the internet took off to shifting coalitions of companies forming 'e-business communities'.

These finally crystallised into business webs, or 'b-webs', which Tapscott characterises as the new model of organisation for the internet age - 'the generic vessel into which all companies fall, in the same way as "corporation" was the catch-all term in the industrial age'.

The classic b-web is Cisco Systems, the internet router manufacturer with 32,000 employees and 40 plants. Just 17,000 members of staff and three plants actually belong to the mother company. Cisco is the 'context provider' that orchestrates the 'content' provided by its manufacturing and other affiliates. Cisco also manages, largely through its e-commerce website, its relationships with its end-customers - the direct 'relationship capital' for lack of which the music industry is now being trashed by its customers just like a hotel room being trashed by a rock band.

'The most important thing about what we call the new economy is that business-model innovation is the key to success,' says Tapscott. 'The beauty of it is that it applies to banks, chemical and mining companies as much as anyone else.'

Witness Enron, an old-line US utility that has reinvented itself as a marketplace for energy, telecom bandwidth and much else besides. Tapscott believes that the process of taking apart old com panies and putting them together again on the internet has only just begun. His current research is into the implications for current business models of the mobile economy, in which almost everything that has power will be interconnected in what he calls the 'hypernet'. Although the floods of change may have receded a bit in the last few months, that's just a pause for breath, says Tapscott ominously.

Further ahead is a programme investigating the effects of all this on governance and democracy, the last area of public life to move with the new technologies.

fields.bodyText: With stricken dotcoms falling fast it's hard to resist a trace of schadenfreude at the sight of Silicon Valley twentysomethings lamenting premature midlife crises and US start-ups stampeding to remove the '.com' from their names. Only the most unscrupulous company promoter will mourn the end of 'cyperbole' - but it would be equally dangerous to lurch to the opposite extreme and conclude that the internet show is over and it's back to business as before. 'The market crash was very cathartic,' says Don Tapscott, internet observer and co-author of Digital Capital , one of the best attempts so far to get under the froth to establish what's really happening to business on the web. 'It ended the period when everyone thought it was about websites, dotcoms, IPOs and off to the races. The real issue is how it changes business models in the commanding heights of the economy.' For that, look no further than the music industry, the example with which the obliging book opens. The force of the internet, say the authors, is that it fundamentally transforms the economics of organisations. By lowering transaction costs - the costs of searching for information, drawing up contracts and coordinating activities - the internet makes it feasible to do things outside the company that it previously made more sense to do inside. This potentially means the end not just of vertically integrated companies (imagine that, just a generation ago, Unilever owned oil palm plantations and ships to carry the raw materials to its factories), but of conventionally integrated companies of any sort. In the past it was most cost-effective to carry out the expensive interlinked activities of finding music acts and recording them, doing deals and arranging manufacture and distribution within a large corpora tion - hence the domination of giants such as Time-Warner, EMI and Bertelsmann. But the internet has pulled the whole value chain apart. Digitalisation and the peer-to-peer MP3 standard mean that manufacturing and distribution costs drop to nothing - indeed the latter is carried out by consumers themselves. By the same token, musicians don't need the record companies, either, since they can distribute their music in the form they choose from their own websites. A new business model emerges in which, for example, a band uses free distribution on the web to sell tickets for a concert tour. Or take Napster, the MP3 site being sued for copyright infringement, which has now done a deal with Bertelsmann that will allow the former to distribute singles on low-cost subscription while retaining control of its copyright for use in other forms. Or look at the traditional business of stockbroking. It consists of market data and analysis, news and views, advice and discussion groups as well as the transaction of buying or selling shares. Tapscott explains: 'The internet allows us to break all that up into its constituent parts, reaggregate it on the web, brand it and you have businesses like E*Trade and Schwab which have taken away one-third of a whole industry's revenue.' The strength of Digital Capital is that it has many examples like this. Based originally on a company-funded research programme looking into the business implications of online communities, it changed its emphasis as the internet took off to shifting coalitions of companies forming 'e-business communities'. These finally crystallised into business webs, or 'b-webs', which Tapscott characterises as the new model of organisation for the internet age - 'the generic vessel into which all companies fall, in the same way as "corporation" was the catch-all term in the industrial age'. The classic b-web is Cisco Systems, the internet router manufacturer with 32,000 employees and 40 plants. Just 17,000 members of staff and three plants actually belong to the mother company. Cisco is the 'context provider' that orchestrates the 'content' provided by its manufacturing and other affiliates. Cisco also manages, largely through its e-commerce website, its relationships with its end-customers - the direct 'relationship capital' for lack of which the music industry is now being trashed by its customers just like a hotel room being trashed by a rock band. 'The beauty of it is that it applies to banks, chemical and mining companies as much as anyone else.' Witness Enron, an old-line US utility that has reinvented itself as a marketplace for energy, telecom bandwidth and much else besides. Tapscott believes that the process of taking apart old com panies and putting them together again on the internet has only just begun. His current research is into the implications for current business models of the mobile economy, in which almost everything that has power will be interconnected in what he calls the 'hypernet'. fields.headline: He's got his newspapers. Now he needs a miracle
fields.trailText: It's easy to be sniffy when downmarket magazine tycoons turn national newspaper proprietors. Remember how media society curled its lips as Alfred Harmsworth (of Answers) started the Daily Mail?
fields.body:
It's easy to be sniffy when downmarket magazine tycoons turn national newspaper proprietors. Remember how media society curled its lips as Alfred Harmsworth (of Answers) started the Daily Mail? But Richard Desmond will probably need to be a twenty-first century Harmsworth to make sense of his Express delivery.

What has he got for his £125million? A flagship daily still losing sales steadily - by 2 or 3 per cent every year - and selling only 900,000 or so when you strip out the bulks and cut-price deals: a Sunday partner in an even more parlous plight; and a sprauncy little red-top tabloid that wins praise for making much of scant resources, but with a half-million circulation heavily dependent on the North of England and even more dependent on 90,000 sales of one sort or another in Ireland.

There's nothing central to any of the titles' positioning here. They are - all of them - flat bottom of their particular markets, and the job of turning them round will take flair, patience and far more cash than the first £125m.

In business terms, it's hard to see the point of the purchase. Lord Hollick has offloaded the ex-United Three simply because their feeble profitability - barely a row of beans once the profit from the half-share in the Westferry printing plant is excluded - was a drag on his own share price.

There are doubtless property deals to be done: there always are when a new owner takes over. But Desmond - without other newspapers to his name - brings nothing obvious to the synergy table. Cost-cutting savings have been squeezed from the Express group for years. That cupboard is bare. It isn't deals the Expresses need, it's investment.

These are all marginal brands now, only a slip or two away from the big drop right off advertising schedules. And the figures, from an ad agency point of view, are unforgiving. Readership - on the latest NRS survey - can be made to look quite decent: 2.4 million a day, still a tad more than the Telegraph and more than the Times and Independent combined. But these aren't the comparisons that matter. The Daily Mail has 5.6 million readers - and its curve continues upwards; the Mail on Sunday (at 6 million) dwarfs the Sunday ver sion of the Express (2.3 million).

Worse, Express readers, in spite of some gallant improvements under Rosie Boycott's editorship, are still too old, dying off by the year and making the business of gaining circulation over and above this natural decline even more daunting.

The Mail has 718,000 readers aged between 25 and 34, the Express only 283,000. The Mail, moreover, has almost unlimited resources. Now it can, and will, turn that panzer division of pounds sterling against Desmond - just as the Mirror and Sun (from still stronger circulation bunkers) can outspend the Star at every turn.

How does Desmond hope to take on these formidable battalions? So far - apart from his installation of a non-journalist editorial director to oversee the daily decision-making of the editors he inherits - the emphasis is all on joint bidding for the kind of celebrity picture exclusives he has used to build his OK! against Hello! To start, the Express gets photos from Catherine Zeta Jones's wedding.

Yet, quite apart from pushing the Mail and Hello! into a rival consortium, it's difficult to see how this particular synergy can make durable sense. OK! sells at £1.85p and the cash surge from 200,000 or so extra sales is formidable. Daily middle market or red-top papers can put on something approaching such sales for a day if there's something really juicy on offer - but next day that impact has gone. The key to Mail success has been a brand that can sustain itself and grow through the days when nobody in particular is getting married, giving birth or welcoming the cameras into her lovely home.

What Desmond has to do, in short, is to create a trio of all-round newspapers that attract readers every day of the week for what they are, not what they can occasionally offer on muddy newsprint rather than glossy mag sheets. To do that he will need editors committed to development over long years of hard pounding, with the freedom to give their papers an individual feel that may attract vital young readers, many of whom do not buy newspapers regularly but pick up the headlines from TV and flesh out their week by reading targeted mag-azines such as OK!

One long-term factor of Express decline, in short, has been the success of competitors like Desmond's own celebrity magazine: and the same, save for the Mail , could be said to be true across the tabloid market. These magazines and newspapers don't go together. They are natural competitors. Put them together and what have you got? A very messy balancing act. Who gets first pickings? Who wants to see their wedding on newsprint first?

Desmond may surprise us all with his answers.

Private, but on parade. OK?

Can you stage a 'private and confidential' wedding for 350 celebrity guests in the Plaza Hotel, New York, if you're Catherine Zeta Jones and Michael Douglas? Only British judges, in the majestic dottiness of our law, would think so.

The war of the glossy celebrity mags is quite as fierce as anything Fleet Street can currently offer. OK! magazine bought exclusive picture rights to the Douglas nuptials for £1 million; Hello! got some other, rather fuzzy snaps from an agency and ran a classic spoiler. OK! sought and won an injunction and, for a couple of days, it looked as though Hello! would be Goodbye! - a week's issue banned and pulped. But no, at the last, the Appeal Court thought not. This, apparently, is a case for damages, not bans.

It ought also to be a case for some hard thinking all round. Richard Desmond, the new owner of the Express Group, is the owner of OK! (which has knocked Hello! off its circulation perch). He intends, quite explicitly, to use his glossy buying power as a weapon against the Mail, Mirror and Sun.

After Posh and Becks, Anthea Turner and Grant Bovey, wedding pictures stand, bizarrely, at the cutting edge of competition - if they can be kept really exclusive. But what if some uninvited or free-spirited guest imports a box Brownie under cover of confetti? Then Michael and Catherine are 'very, very upset', steam into court, and one judge at least feels their financial and emotional distress. The rub, though, is whether other judges agree - over this and thus in many prospective disputes over millionaire weddings to come.

A 'private' wedding, in common sense, is a few members of a family celebrating behind closed doors. It isn't half Hollywood taking over the Plaza for the night. How can wedding pictures be deemed 'confidential' when they're sold for imminent publication? British law, in a familiar bind over privacy, is bumbling along in the wake of events - but one bit of case law would seem to operate sensibly.

When the Mirror, a few years back, picked up an illicit copy of Margaret Thatcher's memoirs, bought for serialisation by the Sunday Times, the court then found no breach of confidentiality because the book was scheduled for swift publication. That appears to be the Appeal Court's view, too: any hurt can be addressed, after the event, by a suit for damages.

Who, however, can produce evidence of such hurt? Not Mr and Mrs Douglas, who took Stasi-like security precautions at the door. They'll be paid. And not, you'd think, OK! - pavilioned in much free publicity. Even the Press Complaints Commission, which draws a distinction between the privacy of a hotel bedroom and the non-privacy of the Plaza ballroom, would walk away from this one. The big issue is whether celebrity sales of lavish 'private' occasions has anything to do with the privacy ordinary people feel so strongly about - and, beyond that, whether privacy is a commodity to be sold in segments and then regained if a wedding goes sour.

Meanwhile, Desmond may have a lot more litigating to do along his chosen course: and only the lawyers are smiling.

webTitle: Philip French: Singin' in the Rain

fields.headline: Philip French on Singin' in the Rain
fields.trailText: If I were the Minister of Health, I’d see that chemists were well stocked with cassettes of Singin’ in the Rain and encourage doctors to prescribe it for depressed patients.
fields.body:
Kenneth Tynan famously wrote that 'I doubt if I could love anyone who did not wish to see Look Back in Anger '. As for me, I doubt if I could love anyone who didn't wish to see Singin ' in the Rain again and again and again. I first saw it in 1952 when at a very low ebb. They say you can't remember pain. But you can remember misery well enough and on the last day of my first six weeks of army basic training at Warrington's smog-shrouded, grime-encrusted Peninsula Barracks I felt terrible. The rough khaki uniform gave me a constant itch. Enforced daily shaving had created a painful rash for which a medical orderly gave me a foul ointment of a kind a vet might have prescribed for scrapie. My feet were blistered by square-bashing, my left shoulder bone bruised from supporting a rifle. I'd been sworn at and humiliated by sadistic sergeants and moronic corporals, and I still had 98 weeks left to serve.

After a farcical passing-out parade with a band playing the regimental march ('God Bless the Prince of Wales') we were free for the rest of the day before moving on to another barracks for more of the same. My comrades-in-arms went off to the Naafi and I headed for the nearest cinema. As a member of 'HM Forces in uniform' (the H had recently switched from His to Her), I was admitted for ninepence (less than four pennies in today's money) and the movie was Singin' in the Rain , which had been received with muted enthusiasm by the critics and everywhere compared unfavourably with On the Town, the previous film by the same production team.

So I wasn't expecting too much when I entered the continuous performance at the final point of the montage showing Hollywood's transition to sound - the song 'Beautiful Girl'. Immediately thereafter, singing star Don Lockwood (Gene Kelly) is reunited with ingenue Kathy Selden (Debbie Reynolds), they enter an empty sound stage where with the artifice of a cyclorama and a wind machine he creates a sunset and a light breeze to serenade her with the beautiful Arthur Freed-Nacio Herb Brown song 'You Were Meant for Me'. This was pure cinema, the most romantic thing I had ever seen. I was raised from the spiritual lower depths, my heavy army boots exchanged for ballet shoes as I imagined I was Kelly dancing with Reynolds.

I saw the movie to the end and sat through it twice more, thrilling to every scene. Donald O'Connor's 'Make 'em Laugh' was brilliant, but a little too close to Kelly's 'Be a Clown' in The Pirate (plagiarism by Arthur Freed or a homage to Cole Porter?) his duet with Kelly of 'Moses Supposes' is sublime. Kelly's pas seul of 'Singin' in the Rain' is magnificent, and I used to test my memory by recalling all the shops in the drenched Hollywood street. The 'Good Morning' routine, which revived Kelly, O'Connor and Reynolds after the disastrous preview the way I was rescued from my barrack-room blues, was sublime. The bit I had doubts about was the ambitious (pretentious?) 'Broadway Melody' sequence, an attempt to match the finale of An American in Paris, though I'm now inclined to excuse it as a postmodernist joke in the light of studio boss R.F. Simpson's comment that he'd have to see it before he could understand it.

I emerged from the cinema that evening elated, thinking of life outside and beyond the Army. The film made me want to emigrate to the States more than ever, to become an American. As a comic view of Hollywood, a metaphor for my fanciful notion of America, it perfectly complemented the tragic view of Billy Wilder's 1950 Sunset Boulevard. It confirmed my naive ambition to write about movies so I could share the joy they gave me and challenge the ignorance of Fleet Street reviewers and the grudging equivocations of Sight and Sound, to which I'd lately become a subscriber. The surprising thing is that as I saw Singin' in the Rain every couple of years over the next two decades, my love and admiration were enhanced rather than diminished.

When it at last appeared on TV my family taped the soundtrack, and we'd listen to the playback, recreating the images in our minds. Since the coming of the video cassette I've seen it more often, perhaps too easily. It is, to me, a perfect cocktail of wit, elegance, ebullience and grace, intoxication without a hangover, an innocent Eden to be visited by those well acquainted with good and evil. It's the movie I'd take to a desert island, the film I'd risk my life to save for posterity should the National Film Archive be consumed by flames.

If I were the Minister of Health, I'd see that chemists were well stocked with cassettes of Singin' in the Rain and encourage doctors to prescribe it for depressed patients. Does any work of art have a more agreeably therapeutic title?

fields.headline: Pump up the volumes
fields.standfirst:
Which is the best book of the year? Philip Roth's The Human Stain or Zadie Smith's White Teeth? Our critics choose their favourites
Part one
fields.trailText: Jilly Cooper
fields.body:
Jilly Cooper

Anyone wanting an introduction to the lunacy, avarice and sexual merry-go-round of the New York contemporary art scene should read Danny Moynihan's marvellously funny and accomplished novel, Boogie Woogie (Duckworth). Having run galleries, curated and exhibited himself, Moynihan knows everything about bent dealers, pretentious collectors and thrusting young artists. All the characters are so awful that one ends up very fond of the less awful ones.

Katherine Whitehorn

I usually read paperbacks, so my books of the year are mostly last year's - and the best novel, The Homemaker by Dorothy Canfield Fisher, was resurrected from 1924 by Persephone Books. This is about a miserably obsessive housewife who is able to take a satisfying job only when her husband is crippled. However, I enjoyed The Pale Abyssinian (HarperCollins), Miles Bredin's witty biography of James Bruce, the preposterous Scot who discovered the source of the White Nile, and Yvonne Roberts 's gripping novel, A History of Insects (Headline) about residual snobbery in Pakistan after the Raj.

Paul Bailey

I found Victoria Clark's study of the Orthodox Church in Europe, Why Angels Fall (Macmillan), absolutely engrossing. The book provides insights into a Christian religion notably different from either Roman Catholicism or Protestantism. The novel that most impressed me was Alasdair MacLeod's No Great Mischief (Cape), a haunting family history set in the wilds of Canada and the Scottish Highlands. Lorna Sage's memoir of her nightmarish childhood, Bad Blood (Fourth Estate) is funny, moving, and wonderfully written. In The Million Dollar Mermaid by Esther Williams with Digby Diehl (Simon & Schuster), the aquatic film star says of her third husband, the relentlessly priapic Fernando Lamas, 'He talked about his penis as if it were a dear and talented friend, with excellent posture.' Thanks to Digby, Esther's autobiography is crammed with similar memorable conceits.

Jacqueline Rose

Both my books this year come from or return to South Africa. Gillian Slovo's Red Dust (Virago) transforms South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, with extraordinary skill, into an impossible-to-put-down detective story so that the reader is forced to enter the minds of all sides of the apartheid era, oppressor and victim alike. Marlene Van Neikerk's prize-winning Afrikaans novel Triomf (Little,Brown) rescues for South African literature the forgotten white trash of the country, while presenting its staggeringly dysfunctional, sometimes inspired, family in such uncompromising terms that Coetzee's Disgrace seems positively redemptive in comparison.

David Cannadine

Here are three books which should stimulate and divert the mind over the seasonal shutdown. Michael Howard's The Invention of Peace: Reflections on War and International Order (Profile) distils a lifetime's learning by our greatest military historian. John Simpson's A Mad World, My Masters: Tales from a Traveller's Life (Macmillan) is by turns hilarious and horrifying. And Simon Schama's A History of Britain: At the Edge of the World? 1,000 BC to AD 1603 (BBC) is a bravura performance by the Lord Macaulay of our day.

Paul Muldoon

One of the best books of poetry of the past year was Derek Mahon's Selected Poems (Penguin). Among numerous other distinctions, Mahon is the single most effective manager of the long stanza since Philip Larkin, as is clear from such anthology pieces as 'A Disused Shed in County Wexford' and 'A Garage in County Cork'.

Kathy Lette

John Mortimer is in his anecdotage and his autobiographical The Summer of a Dormouse (Viking), a mix of warmth, wit and wisdom is my book of the year. Whether ruminating on Napoleon's dick, the poor bastard who was jailed for sleeping with his own wife while wearing a beard, the Princess and the dipsomaniac Irish undertaker or the Swede caught spanking his wife with a live eel (and fined for cruelty to animals), the mischievous Mortimer weaves comedy and compassion into his prose.

Simon Callow

Tom Phillips's millennium project, The Postcard Century (Thames & Hudson) is an inexhaustibly fascinating account of private lives and public images over the past 100 years, as intimate and authentic an account of the experience of being alive at that time as we shall ever have. Thomas Wright's Oscar Wilde: Table Talk (Cassell) suggests more than anything else in print what it was like to hear the great man do what he did better than anyone: talk.

John Mortimer

A plot which involves two alleged Lord Lucans and a lady psychiatrist who faked the stigmata could only have gestated in the fertile brain of Muriel Spark. Aiding and Abetting (Viking) is written with the meticulous sparkle which makes her prose the envy of contemporary writers. We live at a time when we seem to be determined to cut ourselves off from our history, a fatal tendency that might be cured by Simon Schama's excitingly readable A History of Britain: At the Edge of the World? 1,000 BC to AD 1603 (BBC), full of kings and battles, puts an end to the fashionable idea that history should only be studied in the lives of medieval bakers or eighteenth-century piano tuners. Finally, the English obsession with verdant and manicured lawns is entertainingly weeded and watered in Tom Fort's The Grass is Greener: Our Love Affair with the Lawn (HarperCollins). It contains one of the best descriptions of a potting shed ever written.

Adam Mars-Jones

The novel and the book of stories I most enjoyed this year are both products of creative Indian summers: Philip Roth's The Human Stain (Cape) and Penelope Fitzgerald's The Means of Escape (Flamingo). Roth's novel addresses with subtlety the issues of sex, race, identity. Fitzgerald, whose death this year ends a brilliant literary career that began when she was 60, constantly brushes up against profundity without ever seeming to have designs on it. A striking debut collection of stories was Never Trust A Rabbit by Jeremy Dyson (Duckworth). His stories nestle in the little vacant chink between Roald Dahl and Borges. Jeremy Seabrook's Love in a Different Climate: Men Who Have Sex with Men in India (Verso) is illuminating - an attempt to describe taboo experience without imposing Western assumptions.

Stephen Bayley

I checked and I haven't actually read anything in the Amazon Hot 100. Not even The Thunderbirds Colouring Book, or David Beckham: My World. It's been a thin year for good books. Certainly, no fiction that sticks. I devoured Michael Lewis's The New New Thing: A Silicon Valley Story (Coronet), a pacy romp around the idiot-savant computer geek Jim Clark, but it's really just a long article, like so many US business books. Two late 1999 publications that have real value are James Campbell's This is the Beat Generation (Secker & Warburg) , an excellent popular history of Kerouac, Ginsberg and their dissolute company, and the re-issue by Books & Co/Helen Marx Books of Iris Origo's gloriously elegant 1953 life: Leopardi - A Study in Solitude. This last has a new introduction by Shirley Hazzard whose miniature Greene on Capri (Virago) was a small pleasure, full of fine observation and detail. But best of all has been City Secrets: Rome (The Little Bookroom) edited by Robert Kahn. This is a straightforward compilation of art, architecture and restaurant tips by people who really know the city: it's cruelly tempting, insightful and inspiring, as well as being nicely designed. The ordinary thing done extraordinary well: I'd never lend my copy, it's always in use.

Melvyn Bragg

The latest collection of Alan Jenkins's poems, The Drift (Chatto & Windus), is stunningly good. Full of passionate regret, clear, erudite, both a chronicle of the poet's time and a comment on it in poems as fine as any being written today. It is some sort of minor miracle that Michael Donaghy's masterly collection comes out in the same year as Jenkins. Conjure (Picador) contains poems which are as deeply structured, as lucid, moving and witty as Auden at his best. He brings powerful forces to bear on the memory of deep attachments and his vivid story-telling sense is a marvel. Adam Phillips's Promises, Promises: Essays on Psychoanalysis and Literature (Faber) is a brilliant collection of essays around the subjects in which disciplines Phillips excels.

Rowan Pelling

I have just started the book which I have waited patiently for all year - Philip Pullman's finale to his 'Dark Materials' trilogy, The Amber Spyglass. After only 20 pages I find myself spellbound by Pullman's storytelling. All my godchildren will receive the complete hardback set for Christmas.

Ian Hislop

Having been a judge in the recent Blue Peter Book Awards, I have read a lot more children's fiction this year than anything aimed at adults. This probably explains why most of the books have seemed so well-written and entertaining. Can I recommend The Shadow of the Minotaur by Alan Gibbons (Dolphin Paperback) and Pilgrim's Progress by Geraldine McCaughrean (Hodder)? You should probably find a child to give them to, but you could do a lot worse than read them yourself first.

Philip Hensher

The novels I liked best this year were Jane Smiley's grand, detailed Horse Heaven (Faber), one of those books which seems interested in absolutely everything, and Patrick McGrath's Martha Peake (Viking). I simply could not put down John Drummond's entertainingly poisonous memoirs, Tainted By Experience (Faber). Graham Robb's life of Rimbaud (Picador) was unfailingly good; a calm, sceptical eye turned on a turbulent life. Helen Simpson's collection Hey Yeah Right Get A Life (Cape) was simply brilliant. Individual stories gave only a suggestion of the cumulative, terrifying force of the whole book. She has always been funny; with this, she displays herself a writer of unusual power.

fields.headline: Pop pickers
fields.trailText: The implication that Pop2000 is the nearest modern equivalent to Woodstock (News, last week) is ridiculous, as is the implication that musicians no longer write songs about 'rebellion, alienation and changing the world'.
fields.body:
The implication that Pop2000 is the nearest modern equivalent to Woodstock (News, last week) is ridiculous, as is the implication that musicians no longer write songs about 'rebellion, alienation and changing the world'.

Pop2000 is a festival aimed squarely at children. S-Club Seven are the spin-off group from the children's TV programme, LA Seven. They are the sound of pre-pubescence. Yes, the expansion of the teenage pop and fashion market in recent years is worrying. But don't dare criticise Britain's youth for their lack of politics. You were the ones that voted Tony Blair in, after all. See you at Glastonbury!
F Burton
Bognor Regis, Sussex

webTitle: Old rockers don't die, they just sing for Microsoft

fields.headline: Old rockers don't die, they just sing for Microsoft
fields.trailText: It's the best kept secret in rock'n'roll, but it has nothing to do with sex and drugs. The rockers who helped define pop culture - counter-cultural figureheads who scorned the establishment and said they'd rather die than get old - are now first in line to drink from the cups of corporate largesse.
fields.body:
It's the best kept secret in rock'n'roll, but it has nothing to do with sex and drugs. The rockers who helped define pop culture - counter-cultural figureheads who scorned the establishment and said they'd rather die than get old - are now first in line to drink from the cups of corporate largesse.

They'd rather you didn't know it, but when it comes to making some spare cash stars like Bob Dylan, Elton John, The Rolling Stones, Rod Stewart and The Eagles know where to turn - the private event.

It's become a massive business in both Britain and America. The world's biggest corporations like IBM, Microsoft, Pepsi and General Motors are lining up to hire the heroes of another era to entertain their staff, up close and in person, take specia requests, flatter their wives, pose for pictures and sing hits, hits, hits.

While stars such as Elton John rarely do more than half a dozen private dates a year, he can earn more than $500,000 a show. And while he never presented himself as a rebel, even those who once stood for resistance can no longer resist the lavish money corporations and well-heeled hosts are willing to pay. Even the constantly touring legend Bob Dylan has set foot on the corporate stage. Spokesman for a generation or not, he and his son Jakob were paid $1m in 1998 to play for 15,000 employees of the Silicon Valley semi-conductor company Applied Materials. It was the only time father and son had performed at the same show, though they did not appear together.

'The funny thing was going to CAA [the Hollywood Agency which manages both musicians] and having them laugh at me on the phone,' organiser Tom Hayes told Rolling Stone magazine. 'And it wasn't even an hour later that they called back and said, "You got to sit down. They're going to make the deal".'

Midway through their last tour the Rolling Stones were paid more than $2m to entertain Pepsi bottlers in Hawaii. Sheryl Crow was paid to entertain the Bank of America, Rod Stewart serenaded Herbalife's sales staff and Carlos Santana played for Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen. Welsh crooner Tom Jones, who charges between $90,000 and $250,000 a show, does up to 10 events a year. His 26-member entourage is included in the price. Ray Charles, who charges $100,000, does about 50.

A Los Angeles firm, TBA Entertainment, organised a party this year for the commissioner of the National Basketball Association. The entertainment included Stevie Nicks, Al Green, Brandy, a house band led by Booker T and Otis Redding guitarist Steve Cropper, a huge gospel choir and 1,000 dancers.

The market has become so big that the huge talent agency William Morris has two full-time agents to book private gigs. 'A lot of big-time artists are doing these things,' says Chris Burke, vice-president of corporate special events at the agency. 'It's amazing what the biggest corporations in America are willing to shell out.'

While artists do not like to broadcast their corporate gigs, the stigma that once attached to selling songs for commercials or playing to bankers, their wives and mistresses, has evaporated. 'It took a long time for artists to feel comfortable doing these dates,' Burke says.

Doing weddings might seem uncomfortably like coming full circle, but it doesn't mean the end of the line. 'If you're performing at the Four Seasons and somebody walks by on the sidewalk, they don't know you're inside,' Burke says. 'So why not be in there making the money?'

While young bands, high in the charts, may flaunt anti-establishment leanings and sniff at the corporate dollar, they too will one day be playing for Barclays. Even some contemporary acts such as Beck, the Wallflowers and Sheryl Crow do private shows. In fact, many bands are encouraged to make corporate gigs a part of their business plans.

'It's all about the money, and it's the best kept secret in rock,' says former Smashing Pumpkins manager Andy Gershon. 'They're great gigs.' In exchange, the act gives up any notion of creative freedom - the client approves the set-list and the customer is always right.

Burke adds: 'There's no question that performing corporate dates is about money. They are not career moves - they're about being paid nicely, staying in first-class hotels and having everything taken care of.'

Demand is now so great that some bands have been created specifically to cater to the private market. World Classic Rockers, which features Denny Laine, formerly of the Moody Blues and Wings, Spencer Davis and various members of the Eagles and Steppenwolf work up to 10 days a month doing private gigs. 'They make a great living just doing special events,' Burke says.

Of course, not all corporate and private concerts go quite as planned. In September Elton John flounced out of a gala concert before an audience of celebrities in Portugal. He flew to Nice in his private jet, despite having received his performance fee of £240,000 in full.

When the singer failed to show, the venue, a casino, froze half his fee and said it would sue.

 Rolling Stones paid $2m to entertain Pepsi bottlers in Hawaii

 Stevie Nicks sang for the commissioner of the National Basketball Association

 Rod Stewart played privately for Herbalife's sales staff

fields.headline: Dangerous trains
fields.trailText: Joanna Walters suggests that the hundred brand new trains stuck in sidings would offer a crumb of comfort to delayed passengers (Business, last week). Sadly, they would not; the seats are a lot more tightly packed, there are fewer of them and the trains are short on leg-room and space for luggage.
fields.body:
Joanna Walters suggests that the hundred brand new trains stuck in sidings would offer a crumb of comfort to delayed passengers (Business, last week). Sadly, they would not; the seats are a lot more tightly packed, there are fewer of them and the trains are short on leg-room and space for luggage. The trains also have fewer doors and are awkward to get on and off.

Nor is there any guarantee that the new trains are any safer, being of similar construction to the aluminium-bodied turbo train in which most of the fatalities in the Paddington crash occurred. The front carriage of this train disintegrated.
Henry Law
Brighton

fields.headline: Tickets to ride
fields.trailText: Apart from playing a key role in some of Florida's presidential election counts (News, last week), chads used to be an essential tool for bus and tram operators, especially before consecutively numbered tickets were introduced.
fields.body:
Apart from playing a key role in some of Florida's presidential election counts (News, last week), chads used to be an essential tool for bus and tram operators, especially before consecutively numbered tickets were introduced.

A conductor punching a ticket activated a mechanical counter while at the same time catching the chad punched from the ticket in the body of his machine. At the end of the day the total number of chads in the machine were compared with the mechanical counter's total. As the tickets, and therefore the chads, were of different colours for the different values, it was also possible to work out the total of the fares which the conductor should have collected.
Francis Jones
London W5

fields.headline: Thatcher's curse
fields.trailText: Andrew Rawnsley's analysis of the influence of Mrs Thatcher on current politics (Comment, last week) doesn't go far enough. She changed not only politics, but almost everything in British life through her attack on the unwritten laws which had governed Britain for centuries.
fields.body:
Andrew Rawnsley's analysis of the influence of Mrs Thatcher on current politics (Comment, last week) doesn't go far enough. She changed not only politics, but almost everything in British life through her attack on the unwritten laws which had governed Britain for centuries. Her question about civil servants - 'Is he one of us?' - at a stroke politicised them. In due course, her destruction of the politically neutral Civil Service led to the BSE crisis. She similarly attacked unwritten laws which governed law, medicine, universities, monarchy, and was able to do so because, unlike the previous male ruling class governed by these unwritten laws, she as a middle-class woman was not. But unwritten laws are fragile and, once broken, are difficult to reestablish. She established new unwritten laws, such as the supremacy of short-term profits.
Professor Lewis Elton
University College, London WC1

webTitle: Pakistan and Iran fight over mummified princess

fields.headline: Pakistan and Iran fight over mummified princess
fields.trailText: Her name is Ruduamna, she is around 2,600 years old, and she is soon to be the star exhibit in Pakistan's crumbling, little-visited national museum. But the mummified corpse of the 20-year-old Persian princess is now the subject of a row between Iran and Pakistan as to which country is her true owner.
fields.body:
Her name is Ruduamna, she is around 2,600 years old, and she is soon to be the star exhibit in Pakistan's crumbling, little-visited national museum. But the mummified corpse of the 20-year-old Persian princess is now the subject of a row between Iran and Pakistan as to which country is her true owner.

The Iranians claim Ruduamna is a member of Iran's ancient royal family and should be returned as soon as possible. They also insist she is not a princess but a prince.

Pakistani experts say the mummy's origins are not clear and are carrying out tests to try to resolve the mystery. An initial scan has revealed that the mummy has no teeth and suffered 'severe trauma' to her spine, which probably killed her. Pakistani detectives recovered the ancient mummy in October when they raided a house in Quetta and arrested a local tribal chieftain, Sardar Wali Reeki. They had earlier received a tip-off that he owned several valuable antiques. Reeki confessed he had tried to sell the mummy on the international black market for $50 million, but had only been offered $1.1 million. He said the mummy had been found 'some years ago' in Kharan, in Pakistan's Balochistan province, after an earthquake.

The princess, swathed in decaying muslin, was lying in an ornate wooden sarcophagus. Her hands were crossed over a gold plate on her chest, decorated with royal symbols, and she had a gold crown on her head. The coffin had inscriptions in Makhi cuneiform, a language prevalent in Persia in 600BC. The inscriptions read: 'I am the daughter of Xerxes, the great King. I am Ruduamna.'

Iran said the mummy had been stolen from Iran and asked for Interpol's help in getting it back. But Pakistan's Foreign Minister Abdus Sattar said Pakistani officials were investigating the mummy's provenance.

Meanwhile, Pakistani officials have approached British experts from Manchester Museum's Egyptology department for advice on how best to display the mummy.

webTitle: Fear grips Ghana as ritual killer claims 34th victim

fields.headline: Fear grips Ghana as ritual killer claims 34th victim
fields.trailText: One of the world's most prolific, ghoulish serial killers is terrorising women in the West African country of Ghana. The killer - or killers - last week claimed his thirty-fourth victim in what police believe was a ritualistic murder.
fields.body:
One of the world's most prolific, ghoulish serial killers is terrorising women in the West African country of Ghana. The killer - or killers - last week claimed his thirty-fourth victim in what police believe was a ritualistic murder.

All the victims have been women, found stripped from the waist down, with their legs apart. In many cases unused condoms have been scattered around, and some of the women had their genitals mutilated. Sometimes, empty syringes were left at the scene. Close examination of some victims revealed pin pricks where some of their blood had been removed.

Mystery surrounds the identities of the women, some of whom are thought to have been prostitutes. Only a few families have come forward to acknowledge the dead.

Police have revealed virtually no information about their investigations, claiming that it would help the killer. They have not said what the cause of death is, but most of the women were not visibly injured and were thought to have been strangled or suffocated. It is not thought the women were raped.

'After so many deaths there are no clues whatsoever, it is strange. The police are not moving fast enough' said Elvis Aryeh, editor of the Daily Graphic, Ghana's best-selling newspaper, which has launched its own investigation into the killings.

The police silence, two years after the killings began, has led to widespread accusations that they are being complacent. Thousands of women - including the President's wife, Nana Konadu Agyemang Rawlings - dressed in red demonstrated against police inaction.

One of the latest victims was discovered lying naked in an uncompleted building in the Asylum Down suburb of the capital, Accra. Her pants and dress were scattered around her and there was foam around her mouth. Unused condoms were found beside her. There were no wounds on the body and no traces of blood at the scene.

The owner of the building, Sylvia Legge, said that her house help, Sarah Antwiwa, woke up at 6.15am to sweep the compound. Antwiwa found the woman lying on the ground naked and raised the alarm. After a recent upsurge in the killings, police increased patrols and the murders stopped. The patrols were called off and a few days later the killings restarted.

Ritual serial killings caused ferment in South Africa earlier this year when the bodies of 10 women were found with candles, mirrors, knives and other objects used in blackmagic lying around.

Police suspect witch doctors were involved in a separate series of killings in the Orange Farm township of South Africa, when the partial remains of three young girls were found. Police said the mutilations suggested the children had been killed for their body parts by sangomas (witch doctors) to strengthen their muti (magic).

webTitle: Investment trust special: Wising up to the world

fields.headline: Wising up to the world
fields.standfirst: Investing internationally can reduce your risk, reports Helen Pridham
fields.trailText: Investing internationally can reduce your risk, reports Helen Pridham.
fields.body:
Many UK investors naturally choose to invest in UK shares. In many ways this makes sense - it protects investors from currency movements and means they are investing in at least some companies they know.

But they could be missing out. The UK stockmarket has not performed particularly well over the last two years, and investors would have been better off putting their money in the US or Europe. So how do you know which market is going to perform best in the future?

One of the easiest ways is to buy an investment trust that invests globally and spreads your money all round the world.

The global growth trusts, previously known as international generalists, are some of the oldest and largest in the investment trust industry. The granddaddy of them all is Foreign & Colonial, which was set up in 1868 to give smaller investors easy, low-cost access to overseas stockmarkets. It is still fulfilling the same role nowadays.

'In many ways these trusts were ahead of their time,' says Peter Walls of stockbrokers Credit Lyonnais Securities Europe. 'Today everybody is talking about globalisation and the need for investors to think more internationally. These trusts have always had that perspective.'

What you get with a global growth investment trust is a 'one-stop shop'. As Robert Graham of Dunfermline-based independent financial advisers Scottish Financial Independence points out: 'You have a complete investment portfolio in one trust.'

They are typically invested around 50 per cent in the UK and the rest overseas. Having such a diversified investment helps to reduce your risk. If some economies are performing poorly, the chances are this will be offset by growth elsewhere. For any investor concerned about the volatility of shares, the very longevity of these global growth giants must be reassuring. They have survived world wars, depressions and numerous bull and bear markets.

There are 33 global growth trusts which adopt a variety of different approaches to achieve their objectives. This is why if you are investing a large amount of money, a financial adviser might recommend that you choose more than one. Mark Dampier, head of research at Bristol-based advisers Hargreaves Lansdown, says: 'Global growth trusts make fantastic core holdings. With a large investment, I would normally suggest a spread of five or six trusts so that you get a variety of investment styles.'

Such differences can be seen among the four largest trusts: Foreign & Colonial (£3.2 billion), Witan (£2.1bn) Alliance (£2bn), Scottish Mortgage (£1.9bn). Foreign & Colonial, for example, tends to invest more overseas than its counterparts. Fund manager Jeremy Tigue explains: 'We currently have 350 investments spread around 30 different countries. When the management team get together we decide where to invest on the basis of where we can find the most good stocks and good ideas.'But he stresses that any changes in geographical emphasis tend to take place on a gradual basis.

Stockbroker Merrill Lynch points out differences between other trusts. Alliance, it says, is 'conservatively run' whereas Scottish Mortgage is 'prepared to take large asset allocation bets'. Alliance's investment manager Gavin Suggett is unabashed about his trust's reputation. He says: 'There is an element of truth in calling us "dull and boring". The fact is we manage the trust on the assumption that it is a core holding. Therefore, we don't want to give our investors any nasty surprises and, for this reason, we don't take any big bets.'

Scottish Mortgage's more aggressive approach can sometimes produce volatility and, indeed, manager James Anderson was recently forced to apologise to shareholders after the trust fell in value earlier this year due to its over exposure to telecoms stocks.

In general, though, global growth trusts tend to produce steady, long-term performance. Fund managers pay particular attention to getting good returns as these trusts are normally regarded as the group's flagship. Consistency is helped by the fact that they are usually a team effort. At Witan, where a new investment director James Robinson has recently taken over, the talents of the seven specialist investment managers from Henderson who will be working with him, as they did with his predecessor Christopher Clarke, are seen as a particular strength.

Recent figures show that the trusts have generally kept pace with or outshone the FT-All Share Index but they rarely make it to the top of the charts as do more specialist trusts.

But Mark Dampier, of Hargreaves Lansdown, sees it as a tortoise and hare race. He says: 'Sometimes specialist trusts shoot out in front but in the end it is often the global trusts, which have been making steady headway all along, that come out the real winners.' He points out that average returns of 12 per cent per annum are typical.

Alliance's Gavin Suggett also emphasises the role of low management charges in contributing to the trusts' long-term success. Alliance has the lowest charges of any investment trust of a mere 0.13 per cent per annum but the other large international trusts do not charge much more.

At Foreign & Colonial total expenses are 0.42 per cent, while at Witan and Scottish Mortgage they are 0.34 per cent and 0.38 per cent respectively.

webTitle: Investment trust special: The best trusts

fields.headline: It's the way they pick 'em
fields.standfirst: Financial experts choose their favourite trusts. David Hunt reports
fields.trailText: Financial experts choose their favourite trusts. David Hunt reports
fields.body:
Tim Cockerill, of Bath-based IFA Chartwell, puts the size of the discount some way down his list of considerations when selecting an investment trust. 'First and foremost you are looking at the management, what the trust is doing and how it has performed,' he says.

Cockerill's favourite trusts include the Ivory & Sime Isis trust in the UK growth sector and the Fleming Income & Growth 2006 Capital Share among the split caps. 'I like the Ivory & Sime trust because of its consistency,' he says. 'It's not at a very big discount - only around 5 per cent - but it has been restructured recently and gives exposure to the bigger companies end of the market and it's managed very well. It will serve you well in the long term.' On a share price total return basis, Isis was up 19.2 per cent over the year to end September, 45.7 per cent over three years and 144.6 per cent over five.

Cockerill picks the Fleming trust because, again, it 'invests at the bigger end of the market, has a good-sized portfolio, has been very well managed but also has the gearing [borrowing to invest] which gives it good longer-term potential'.

Kim North, a partner with London firm Pretty Technical Partnership, opts for a global growth trust - Brunner - and further up the risk spectrum goes for Invesco Continental Smaller Companies and Templeton Emerging Markets.

Brunner, managed by Dresdner RCM Global, 'has the attraction of being truly global with excellent asset performance', says North. The trust has returned 33.6 per cent, 56.5 per cent and 123.5 per cent over the last one, three and five years respectively.

She opts for the Invesco trust because of the group's 'spectacular record in European investments'. European smaller companies have had a rough ride over the past six months, she says, but expects better things. Its share price was up an impressive 150.2 per cent in the 12 months to end September.

North admits that the choice of Templeton Emerging Markets is highly speculative, but standing at a discount of around 20 per cent she says 'this fund has a neon "buy" sign all over it'.

Ian Rankin, of Cheshire IFAs Scott Lang Investment Management, picks the Aim trust run by Ivory & Sime and the Herald Investment Trust. The Aim trust has a spectacular record over both one and three years.

The Herald Trust has an almost equally impressive track record going back even further. 'I would not buy this trust just at the moment, however,' he says, pointing to the fact that it is trading at a premium of around 7 per cent.

'If it gets to a very small premium or discount, then is the time to buy,' he says.

Steve Hancy, of Bristol-based Falcon Group, selects the smaller companies trust Eaglet and, like Tim Cockerill, the Fleming Income and Growth 2006 Capital Shares.

Like Aim, Eaglet trades at a 6 per cent discount in the UK Smaller Companies sector, but is only around half the size. Hancy likes it especially for its highly focused approach.

webTitle: Investment trust special: The perfect net egg

fields.headline: An inspector calls for a nifty nest egg
fields.standfirst: My Isa is right for me, Ofsted worker tells Rachel Fixsen
fields.trailText: My Isa is right for me, Ofsted worker tells Rachel Fixsen.
fields.body:
Francesca Luke was looking for a long-term investment. But because she was self-employed - as an Ofsted lay school inspector - she ruled out schemes, such as endowment policies, that tied her to regular contributions.

'The money I earn isn't static enough - I can't commit myself,' she says.

Francesca, from Chelmsford in Essex, took advice and opted in 1994 to put a £1,000 lump sum into an Edinburgh Investment Trust Isa. Although investment trusts can be harder to understand than unit trusts, she felt comfortable putting her money into this type of fund, partly because her father already held shares in investment trusts.

Investment trusts tend to be more volatile than unit trusts because of the way they are structured and the fact that these funds can borrow to invest. But Francesca says her investment is for the long term, so fluctuations from year to year are not important.

'I was told you may get some years when the value of the investment trust goes down, and there have been years like that. But last year it went up quite strongly,' she says.

Francesca intends to use her investment for retirement, although she may find some other use for it before then, perhaps to help meet the costs of university for either of her two children.

Since she began the investment, she has made regular monthly payments, beginning with £30.

'As my earnings have increased, I've put in more, and now I pay in about £80 a month,' she says. Her Isa is now worth £6,876.

The Edinburgh Investment Trust is invested in a broad range of UK shares, and its objective is to achieve capital growth at a higher rate than the FTSE All-Share, and dividend growth above the rate of inflation. Its top five shareholdings are Vodafone, BP Amoco, HSBC Holdings, Glaxo Wellcome and Shell Transport & Trading.

Francesca says she chose this fund from the many available because it seemed slightly less of a risk than others she investigated.

fields.headline: Discounts are small but the industry is healthier
fields.standfirst: Are trusts less of a bargain today? Not necessarily, says David Hunt
fields.trailText: Are trusts less of a bargain today? Not necessarily, says David Hunt.
fields.body:
Ten years ago an invitation to buy investment trusts would often open with the question: 'How would you like to buy £100 of assets for just £80?' Thirty years ago it was £100 of assets for £70, or even £60. Today, however, the same pitch would be rather less impressive: the average discount on investment trusts has shrunk to just 11 per cent.

Everybody loves buying things at less than face value, but does this narrowing of the discount mean that investment trusts are less of a bargain today than they once were? Not necessarily, say the experts.

Narrower discounts may mean that buying a particular trust can be more expensive today than previously, but in some ways narrower discounts also reflect the fact that the industry is in a healthier state now than in the past.

Each investment trust comprises a portfolio of shares which are valued in the market. This net asset value (NAV) is usually divided by the number of shares issued and expressed as NAV per share. The price of each share, however, is determined by what investors are prepared to pay in the market. If demand is strong and the share price is higher than the NAV, the trust is said to be trading at a premium. More usually, however, the price will be below the NAV and the share will trade at a discount.

Buying shares at a discount means you get more assets for your money. But if the discount widens over the years, the share price performance of the trust will not be as good as the underlying portfolio. If the discount narrows, the opposite is true.

The average discount has been narrowing over recent years for several reasons. First, investment trust groups have made a positive attempt to reduce the supply in the market by buying back their own shares.

At the same time the Association of Investment Trust Companies (AITC) has been trying to stimulate demand from the retail market by a publicity campaign, the next phase of which - an £8 million TV and press advertising blitz - gets off the ground in January. 'At the moment 30 to 40 per cent of investment trust shares are held by the public, and the rest by institutions,' says AITC communications director Annabel Brodie-Smith. 'We want to build up the retail stake in order to reduce volatility. It is not so much the level of the discount that is off-putting to investors as its volatility,' she argues.

Buy-backs have certainly helped in taking out excess supply, says Mark Sewell of stockbroker Capel Cure Sharp.

But he adds: 'The sector has also been busy restructuring; giving trusts more specialist remits. It's important not to become preoccupied with the discount. If a trust is on a wide discount, it's usually for a very good reason - it's either out of fashion, or simply badly managed. Discounts are just part of the equation.

'I would advise investors to look at the management, look at the investment mandate and only then see if they can pick up the trust at an attractive rating.'
