fields.headline: No sanity Claus
fields.trailText: How right Richard Ingrams is about the ridiculously early arrival of Christmas lights and decorations (Diary, last week).
fields.body:
How right Richard Ingrams is about the ridiculously early arrival of Christmas lights and decorations (Diary, last week). I know this isn't the most serious issue we should be concerned about, but we can still be cheered by Christmas lights if they don't stay around so long that we no longer notice them. Surely it would be far better to really enjoy them in December and over New Year during the very darkest days, when we have a deep-seated need for light and festivity around the Winter Solstice. In this way I am sure many of us would recapture some of our childhood responses of anticipation and pleasure at this welcome festive time.
Sue Willson
Newcastle under Lyme, Staffordshire

fields.headline: Game player who uses his cranium
fields.standfirst: Natalie Sutton meets a man who aims to sweep the board
fields.trailText: Natalie Sutton meets a man who aims to sweep the board.
fields.body:
Richard Tait has just invented and designed a board game called Cranium, said to 'stretch the brain'. Having given the Trivial Pursuit series a run for their money in the US by selling more in its first week than the first Trivial Pursuit did in its first year, Cranium is set to take Britain by storm. Projected sales figures for the first year will soon hit £1 million.

The former Microsoft employee obviously has a nose for business investment, but is he quite as clever when it comes to his personal finances?

'I'm in disarray,' confides Tait, a 36-year-old Scotsman.

He has not lacked direction in pursuing his career, though. Tait was determined to succeed at an early age and, following a degree course at Heriot Watt University, Edinburgh, he crossed the Atlantic to study at Dartmouth Business School, New Hampshire.

He yearned to work for Apple, but was turned down because he didn't have a Green Card. Microsoft, however, snapped him up, and Tait became a project manager. He was responsible for many of Microsoft's consumer products and packages, and responded eagerly to the increasing popularity of the internet.

On the 5 May 1997, during a Mexican festival that celebrates life, Tait decided to leave his successful career at Microsoft behind. 'I'm a big believer in life, and I look at my own in ten-year chapters,' he says. 'The past three years had been a complete rush, but I was ready to do something else. I was passionate about creating new products.'

It was, he admits, the scariest thing he had ever done. It was his creative passion, rather than hopes of financial gain, that drove him. Having created an investment company called Brinc (a wry allusion to the fact that he and his partner were on the verge of losing a lot of money), Tait hooked up with Whit Alexander, another former Microsoft employee, who joined him in developing Cranium.

The original idea came to Tait when he and his wife - 'unbelievable' Pictionary players, he says - were on holiday with another couple who were good at Scrabble. It dawned on Tait that the world needed a game which everybody could play together and where everyone has a chance to shine.

In addition, it seemed high time for another global board game success to open up new social avenues, in the tradition of Monopoly and then Trivial Pursuit, at a time when too many people are absorbed in the solitary occupation of 'being online'.

'Whit thought I was nuts,' he says. It took them six months and $100,000 to deliver the game. It has now reached dizzy heights of popularity in the US, with sales of a million copies expected by the end of 2000.

The UK version is on sale now, having been tweaked to appeal to a British sense of humour and, of course, our current affairs.

Cranium was profitable in the first six weeks and has remained so ever since. Clearly a man with very sound financial acumen, Tait is not quite as confident when it comes to his own finances. He dislikes talking about money, claims not to think about it a lot - and certainly avoids dealing with his own.

'On the business side I'm very organised,' he says. 'I can study financials and understand the returns, but on a personal level, it's the last thing I get to.'

Electronic payment was, for him, a godsend. But he is not disorganised enough, however, to have fallen into the credit card trap. He resents the interest of between 12 and 18 per cent charged on credit cards and runs on a 'pay-as-you-go basis', using debit cards.

Luckily for Tait and his family, they have a 'home manager' who looks after some of the household accounts.

Presumably this leaves time for them to play Cranium, although one suspects that it won't belong before Tait is working on another mind-boggling enterprise.

 Cranium is available through Starbucks and Virgin Megastores nationwide, at £29.95.

webTitle: Money writes: Soldier's missing cheque cost £450

fields.headline: Soldier's missing cheque cost £450
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers.
fields.body:
I am in the armed forces and have recently returned from six months abroad. While away, I was due to make a payment in final settlement to First National Tricity Finance for a computer.

My father sent a cheque for £1,296 on 10 August, in time for the final date of 19 August.

On 7 September, he saw that the money was still in his bank account. First National said it had not received the cheque and claimed I now owed a further £450 in interest. I have made the extra payment, but I do feel cheated.
KB, Hereford

First National, owned by Abbey National, still says that your father's cheque was not received. Because the money did not arrive in time, the computer jumped in and started deducting payments.

But the lender admits that, when your father said he had sent the cheque recorded delivery, customer service staff should have investigated before activating interest charges. First National has agreed to refund the £450 you paid and is sending £50 for out-of-pocket expenses.

'I was mis-sold an endowment'

I believe I was mis-sold an endowment mortgage by the Halifax in 1998. I already had one endowment and explained at the time that I was planning to move abroad within a couple of years. I am about to leave the UK and realise the difficulties of being paid in one currency and making payments in sterling.
AP, Armagh

Halifax has checked the file on your interview with its adviser, but says there is no record of verbal statements. This means the bank cannot confirm whether your move abroad was in fact discussed. Because of this doubt, Halifax has upheld your complaint and agrees that a repayment mortgage would have been more appropriate. It is offering you the difference between your position today and the amount that would still be owing if you had taken a repayment loan. This is £293, but Halifax has increased the payment to £400 to compensate for the inconvenience.

Name confusion delays share pack

I have not yet had my share pack from Bradford & Bingley, even though the return deadline is 24 November. On 2 November they said the problem was that they had two names for me on the computer, but that I would receive a share pack within two weeks. I have not.
HV, Storrington

Bradford & Bingley admits your complaints were not well handled. The computer did not recognise your account and so skipped your name when sending the mailings. A share pack was posted last week, which you should receive in time for the deadline. If you don't, B &B says you will lose out only if you want to sell your shares immediately.

Giving Life's Essentials a miss

I have a Gold Barclaycard and on a recent statement noticed £59.95 debited in favour of something called Life's Essentials, which meant nothing to me. After a number of phone calls, the money was returned.

It appears that Life's Essentials sells herbal remedies and discounted membership of fitness clubs. In theory, I am told, Barclaycard holders all receive a phone call about the firm's products, but I had no such call. I find it horrifying that my card number should be bandied about quite so liberally.

Barclaycard say its conditions say I have agreed they can pass on information to 'people who provide a service to us or are acting as our agents'. Nowhere does it make clear that this includes my card number.
PS, Woodbridge

Barclaycard has negotiated discounts with Life's Essentials on various products. It targets which customers to call by analysing the spending pattern revealed by their statements. The only details agents like this are interested in are customers' credit card numbers.

Barclays is going to listen to its taped conversations to see if this explains why your account was wrongly debited, but otherwise cannot explain. This is another reminder to check your statements.

How are annuity rates quoted?

Are annuity rates quoted net of income tax? What is the position for those who pay other than standard rate tax?
AC, Beckenham

All annuity rates are quoted gross of tax, but payments are made with tax deducted.

With compulsory purchase annuities (those you buy with your pension fund), adjustments for tax are made through your tax coding. With purchased life annuities, higher-rate taxpayers pay the extra through their self-assessment form; non-taxpayers and 10 per cent payers can reclaim an overpayment from the Revenue.

webTitle: Investment trust special: Threat that's no wind-up

fields.headline: Threat that's no wind-up
fields.standfirst: The profiteers who kill funds begin our investment trust special
fields.trailText: The profiteers who kill funds begin our investment trust special
fields.body:
Managing an investment trust may sound like a sedate occupation: you buy a few shares here, sell a few there and hope for a decent bonus at the end of the year.

But one piece of news is guaranteed to bring most managers out in a cold sweat. When arbitrageurs take a stake in your trust, it usually means they have scented a killing. If you don't act fast, you may quickly find that the fund you manage has been liquidated.

Arbitrageurs - or 'arbs', as they are known - look for trusts whose share price represents a wide discount to the net asset value.

They reason that, if they can gather enough votes to force the trust to wind up and sell its assets, there will be a mouth-watering profit to be made.

It's not a new game, but it seems to have been gathering momentum in recent years. Peter Walls, investment trust analyst at Credit Lyonnais Laing, says that after some notable scalps were taken during the Nineties, many larger trusts have taken advantage of new rules enabling them to buy back their own shares to narrow the discount and reduce their appeal to arbitrageurs.

'We have got more investors playing the game, but the targets are less obvious ones,' Walls says.

The list of trusts in which arbitrageurs currently hold a speculative interest nevertheless runs into double figures. How many of those trusts will be wound up and how many will escape through evasive action remains to be seen. But it is a fair bet that in the vast majority of cases the arbs will not walk away from their investment nursing a loss.

For even if they do not succeed in forcing a trust to wind up, they will often put sufficient pressure on the management to take some other action that boosts the value for shareholders. Failing that, the management may simply buy their shares from them at an inflated price to get them to go away.

The latest fund manager to have an arbitrageur park its tanks on its lawn is emerging markets specialist Templeton, which has discovered in the past 10 days that an aggressive predator, Value Catalyst, has bought 5 per cent of the shares of its Latin America trust.

Latin America is deeply out of favour with investors now, even compared with other emerging markets. Already one trust, Scudder Latin American, has been wound up after a vote of shareholders. Another, Deutsche Latin American Companies, is also on the receiving end of a Value Catalyst stake, and faces the prospect of liquidation at its annual meeting next year.

David McFadyen, investment trust analyst at ABN Amro, says: 'Emerging markets have been generally out of favour with investors around the world.'

US mutual funds, for example, have undertaken a significant net outflow of investment in emerging markets this year.

There is some speculation that Templeton Emerging Markets, the flagship fund of Templeton, and its charismatic investment head, Mark Mobius, could itself come under pressure if Templeton's Latin America trust crumbles.

Arbitrageurs focus on trusts with a wide discount, usually in the upper teens. But McFadyen says private investors would be unwise to jump aboard in the hope of making a quick buck.

The arbs hedge their exposure to the market in question - be it Latin America, or some other specialist sub-sector - and their investment is a pure play on the discount itself, a position the private investor can't take.

Part of the problem, he says, is that many of the smaller, more specialist trusts do not attract much interest from institutions because of their size.

As a result, they have poor liquidity, and when sentiment turns, the size of the discount to assets can be exaggerated. The large 'international general' trusts are not so vulnerable.

Usually, for an arbitrageur to wind up a trust and dispose of its assets it must obtain 10 per cent of the votes to force an emergency meeting. But quite a few trusts launched in the past 10 years built into their constitution the stipulations that shareholders must vote on continuing or winding up on a particular date, and many of those are fast approaching.

Walls says that if a trust in which you are an investor suddenly falls prey to an arbitrageur, it is probably just as well to hang on and find out what develops. 'The fact that the arbitrageurs are there may indicate that the performance has not been too clever, and so you might expect to see some action on the share price,' he says.

When a trust is wound up, there is usually a 'rollover' option, allowing investors to keep their money in a new fund, which may be a unit trust or Oeic (open-ended investment company).

'We would usually advise them to take the cash and redeploy their funds in another investment trust,' Walls adds.

They reason that, if they can gather enough votes to force the trust to wind up and sell its assets, there will be a mouth-watering profit to be made. Peter Walls, investment trust analyst at Credit Lyonnais Laing, says that after some notable scalps were taken during the Nineties, many larger trusts have taken advantage of new rules enabling them to buy back their own shares to narrow the discount and reduce their appeal to arbitrageurs. 'We have got more investors playing the game, but the targets are less obvious ones,' Walls says. The list of trusts in which arbitrageurs currently hold a speculative interest nevertheless runs into double figures. How many of those trusts will be wound up and how many will escape through evasive action remains to be seen. But it is a fair bet that in the vast majority of cases the arbs will not walk away from their investment nursing a loss. For even if they do not succeed in forcing a trust to wind up, they will often put sufficient pressure on the management to take some other action that boosts the value for shareholders. Failing that, the management may simply buy their shares from them at an inflated price to get them to go away. The latest fund manager to have an arbitrageur park its tanks on its lawn is emerging markets specialist Templeton, which has discovered in the past 10 days that an aggressive predator, Value Catalyst, has bought 5 per cent of the shares of its Latin America trust. Latin America is deeply out of favour with investors now, even compared with other emerging markets. Already one trust, Scudder Latin American, has been wound up after a vote of shareholders. Another, Deutsche Latin American Companies, is also on the receiving end of a Value Catalyst stake, and faces the prospect of liquidation at its annual meeting next year. David McFadyen, investment trust analyst at ABN Amro, says: 'Emerging markets have been generally out of favour with investors around the world.' US mutual funds, for example, have undertaken a significant net outflow of investment in emerging markets this year. There is some speculation that Templeton Emerging Markets, the flagship fund of Templeton, and its charismatic investment head, Mark Mobius, could itself come under pressure if Templeton's Latin America trust crumbles. Arbitrageurs focus on trusts with a wide discount, usually in the upper teens. But McFadyen says private investors would be unwise to jump aboard in the hope of making a quick buck. The arbs hedge their exposure to the market in question - be it Latin America, or some other specialist sub-sector - and their investment is a pure play on the discount itself, a position the private investor can't take. Part of the problem, he says, is that many of the smaller, more specialist trusts do not attract much interest from institutions because of their size. As a result, they have poor liquidity, and when sentiment turns, the size of the discount to assets can be exaggerated. The large 'international general' trusts are not so vulnerable. Usually, for an arbitrageur to wind up a trust and dispose of its assets it must obtain 10 per cent of the votes to force an emergency meeting. But quite a few trusts launched in the past 10 years built into their constitution the stipulations that shareholders must vote on continuing or winding up on a particular date, and many of those are fast approaching. Walls says that if a trust in which you are an investor suddenly falls prey to an arbitrageur, it is probably just as well to hang on and find out what develops. 'The fact that the arbitrageurs are there may indicate that the performance has not been too clever, and so you might expect to see some action on the share price,' he says. When a trust is wound up, there is usually a 'rollover' option, allowing investors to keep their money in a new fund, which may be a unit trust or Oeic (open-ended investment company). 'We would usually advise them to take the cash and redeploy their funds in another investment trust,' Walls adds.

fields.headline: On the market
fields.standfirst: Gartmore Absolute Growth & Income Trust
fields.trailText: Gartmore Absolute Growth & Income Trust
fields.body:
Contact: 0800 289 336

Aim 9.5 per cent gross income and a capital return of of about 9 per cent a year via shares in a split capital investment trust.

Bells & whistles Gartmore have launched six other split capital trusts: 'Smaller companies have returned to favour and strong economic conditions have boosted their earnings growth.'

How it works The trust offers ordinary income shares and zero dividend preference shares, or zeros. It is already running, having raised £80m from institutions and a bank loan. Gartmore wants to replace some of the institutional money with cash from retail investors. Sixty per cent of the fund will be invested in UK growth stocks, and the rest in high income investment trusts and split capital investment trusts. The growth portfolio will be managed by Gervais Williams, its head of UK smaller companies. The income portfolio will be run by Richard Prvulovich, a senior investment manager. Income will be paid quarterly. After seven years the zeros will mature, and the bank loan must be repaid. Any remaining assets will belong to income investors, whose shares will be 'rolled over' into a new loan-backed arrangement.

Minimum £3,000 through Gartmore's Isa, £1,000 through its investment trust savings scheme, called SAVEit.

Charges Initial 3 per cent for lump sums invested via the Isa is halved to 1.5 until 22 December plus 0.5 annually. A 1 per cent dealing charge on the savings scheme is waived until then.

Tax Returns will be tax free through the Isa scheme.

Risk Income shares: high. Zeros: low to medium.

Should you invest? Chris Macdonald of London independent financial adviser Brooks Macdonald Gayer likes the zeros, but not the income shares. He says there is a high risk that income investors will lose much of their money if interest rates rise. He rates Williams' skills highly, but is less sure of Prvulovich.

Tim Cockerill of Chartwell of Bath says that for the income portfolio to buy shares in other investment trusts means 'an element of double charging'.

Points out of 10 Macdonald: zeros - 8, income shares - 2, Cockerill: zeros - 8, income shares - 6.

fields.headline: Pump up the volumes
fields.standfirst:
Which is the best book of the year? Philip Roth's The Human Stain or Zadie Smith's White Teeth? Our critics choose their favourites
Part two
fields.trailText: Which is the best book of the year? Philip Roth's The Human Stain or Zadie Smith's White Teeth? Our critics choose their favourites
fields.body:
Lucy Moore

The Journals of Sylvia Plath edited by Karen V. Kukil (Faber) make uncomfortable reading because she is so searingly, desperately intense - but that is also what makes them so compelling. A fascinating look into a brilliant, tortured mind.

Lewis Wolpert

James Lovelock's Homage to Gaia - The Life of an Independent Scientist (OUP) is not so much a homage to his captivating idea but rather a homage to science and his own life in it. There is no autobiography of a scientist to compete with this one. Hitler's Gift, by Jean Medawar and David Pyke (Metro), tells the stories of 21 brilliant scientists who took refuge in Britain shortly after Hitler came to power in 1933 and Jews were dismissed from their university posts. A moving story and a moral tale.

Simon Jenkins

White Teeth (Random House) by Zadie Smith is funny and sad. Larry Siedentop's Democracy in Europe (Allen Lane, Penguin) was the most original political book of the year. For politics of a lighter hue, nothing beats Andrew Rawnsley's gossipy Servants of the People (Hamish Hamilton), presenting New Labour as a court that Machiavelli would recognise and from which Blairism will never quite recover. And let us hear a cheer for Gladwyn Turbutt's four-volume History of Derbyshire (Merton Priory). This masterpiece of local history, 10 years in the making, is proof that such invaluable books can still see the light of day, defying the outpourings of technology.

Barbara Trapido

While I have tried to make this a writing rather than a reading year, there were two books I couldn't not read. One was Günther Grass's time travelling, massively long Too Far Afield (Faber), in which the 'footnote slaves' of a GDR archive tell the story of an aged file courier whose life is rescued by an obsession with a literary Huguenot. The other, Jonathan Coe's The Rotters' Club (Viking), not out until next March but read in a sneak preview, is a boys' school story set in 1970s Birmingham. Coe can present social history without sacrificing characters to events and both here are a joy. I also caught up, in paperback, with Romesh Gunesekera's beautiful exile story, The Sandglass (Granta).

Robert Harris

The latest selection from Alan Clark's Diaries, Into Politics (Weidenfeld & Nicolson) still offers, for my money, the strongest narrative voice of the year - an elongated Etonian drawl of selfishness, lechery, snobbishness, hypochondria, self-delusion and melancholy, all of which are transfigured by the razor quality of Clark's prose and his reckless honesty.

Graham Robb's Rimbaud (Picador) demythologises the subject while leaving quite intact the magic of the art. Penelope Fitzgerald, who died in April, left us a farewell present of short stories, The Means of Escape (Flamingo): economical enigmas which remind us to reread her last four great novels.

Joan Bakewell
L

J. G. Ballard has always been astonishingly prophetic in his visions. Now Super-Cannes (Flamingo) imagines the dangers, plausible and horrifying, of the culture of global corporations. Even when not on major biographical duty, Richard Holmes is always interesting. Sidetracks - Explorations of a Romantic Biographer (HarperCollins) are minor excursions down biographical byways but offer up insights I couldn't have anticipated. Experience by Martin Amis (Jonathan Cape) is brilliant for its cun ning structure and density of impressions.

Zadie Smith

I choose Martin Amis's memoir Experience (Jonathan Cape) because it's exquisitely written, Edward Platt's intimate biography of the A40, Leadville (Picador), for the same reason, and Dave Eggers's A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius (Picador) because it kicks ass.

Misha Glenny

Michael Burleigh's The Third Reich: A New History (Macmillan) is how history should be written. Illuminating and stylish, it offers insights for the general reader and scholar alike without boring either. Night of Stone (Granta) , Catherine Merridale's account of how ordinary Russians coped with violent death on a scale few of us can even imagine, is an epic and moving his tory. Kosovo: War and Revenge (Yale), Tim Judah's reconstruction of the war in Kosovo and the dynamics of Serb and Albanian politics in the territory, is clear and instructive.

Nicci Gerard

In The Human Stain (Cape) - a stunning, complex novel of snarling rage, passion, sarcasm, scorching humour and extraordinary beauty - Philip Roth manages to weave together public history and private lives and seems to pack 10 novels into this dense one. In October, Philip Pullman published the final in his dazzling Dark Materials trilogy, The Amber Spyglass (David Fickling Books). He understands the power of a good story, but he is an uncosy, often scary and troubling novelist: besotted by myth, compelled by death and desire and faith and grief, in love with Milton and Blake, angry with religion, intimate with compromise and complicity and corruption, capable of radiant prose.

Christopher Frayling

I particularly enjoyed David Skal's Screams of Reason - Mad Science and Modern Culture (W. W. Norton & Co) which begins with Dr Faustus and ends with Stephen Hawking but concentrates in between on Boris Karloff and Hollywood horror. The best-written book I read was Thomas McGuane's elegant and thoughtful essays about the partnership - a partnership he calls 'a burst of poetry' - between humans and horses collected as Some Horses (The Lyons Press).

Jonathan Meades

Atomised by Michel Houllebecq (Heinemann) is the most thrilling novel I've read in several years. Its directness, its energy, its centripetal concentration, its candour, its nihilism and its sod-you-ism are exhilarating. In The Third Reich: A New History (Macmillan), Michael Burleigh proceeds from the premise that Nazism was a quasi-religion whose programme allowed the faithful to perpetrate enormities with a clear conscience. His book is a massive accretion of detail and appalling anecdote.

Brenda Maddox

Andrew Roberts's Salisbury: Victorian Titan (Weidenfeld and Nicolson) is as learned, accessible and well-shaped a biography as I've read. Roberts is a rare historian, with an eye for the human detail and for contemporary relevance. I also loved the outrageous Letters of Kingsley Amis edited by Zachary Leader (HarperCollins).

Antony Holden

Angry, outrageous, wildly funny and infinitely sad, Philip Roth's The Human Stain (Cape) completes the majestic postwar US trilogy which began in equally high style with American Pastoral. Martin Amis's memoir Experience (Jonathan Cape) is up there with Roth's The Facts; when fine fictional stylists turn their laser-prose upon themselves, the result is an auto-brainscan offering a tantalising glimpse towards the heart. I also much admired Miranda Seymour's exhaustive biography of Mary Shelley.

Charles Saumarez Smith

My favourite book of the year is called City Secrets: Rome (The Little Bookroom). Edited by the architect Robert Kahn, it consists of recommendations of what to see and do in Rome as sent in by the American Academy of Rome's many supporters. It's a brilliant idea. I also enjoyed The Long Afternoon (Sceptre), Giles Waterfield's dry and atmospheric novel about his grandparents' life in Menton between the wars.

Jan Morris

In non-fiction I greatly admired and enjoyed Simon Schama's Rembrandt's Eyes (Allen Lane, Penguin), which was published in the autumn of 1999 but did not reach me until the present millennium; also Peter Ackroyd's virtuoso evocation of the most timeless of cities, London: The Biography (Chatto & Windus). I was delighted by Miles Bredin's life of James Bruce, The Pale Abyssinian (HarperCollins), but since Mr Bredin is my godson I'd better not say anything too nice about it.

Mary Riddell

As lucid as anything he has written and, in the paperback edition, particularly well-timed Matt Ridley's Genome - the Autobiography of a Species in 23 Chapters (Fourth Estate) is the A to Z route map for anyone trying to get to grips with the completion of the Human Genome Project.

Tom Paulin

Martin Allen's Hidden Agenda: How the Duke of Windsor Betrayed the Allies (Macmillan) paints a devastating picture of this truly evil royal who was a close friend of Charles Bedaux, a Nazi spy so dangerous that the FBI would appear to have bumped him off in 1944 (officially he committed suicide). Frank Kermode's Shakespeare's Language (Allen Lane, Penguin) is an inspiring work of evaluative critical analysis.

Edna O'Brien

Snow and Guilt by Giorgio Pressburger (Granta) is a perfect little book. Translated by Shaun Whiteside, these six stories have an underlying unity; the writing is austere yet with a life-affirming tenderness. The same cannot be said for The Journals of Sylvia Plath (Faber). Here we witness the rage, the torment and the competitiveness of a deeply wounded young woman. As I began to read them I wondered if all journals ought not to be consigned to the pyre, but by the time I had finished I marvelled at her industriousness and her capacity at transforming her demons into great art. Eilis Ni Dhuibhne is the most gifted young Irish writer. In The Pale Gold of Alaska (Blackstaff Press), her prose shimmers like poetry.

George Steiner

My book of the year (if a delayed finding in paperback is allowed), is Colin Thubron's In Siberia (Chatto & Windus) . There is hardly a sentence in this grim yet strangely luminous memoir without a taut vivacity which makes the whole book 'sing'. Thubron's account of the abandoned Stalinist death-camps in the Siberian Kolyma, of the pounding into ice and mud of millions of innocent men and women, is almost unbearable. Yet even here, in the hell of the anonymous, there are touches of human dignity, of that Russian investment in resurrection.

Gita Sereny

Brigitte Hamann's Hitler's Vienna is a really original account of the young Hitler's years of political apprenticeship between 1907 and 1913. Mark Roseman's The Past in Hiding (Allen Lane, Penguin) is an extraordinary story of a life, particularly read - as I read it - in conjunction with Ian Kershaw's two volumes of Hitler biography - Hubris and Nemesis (Penguin), both of them richly annotated with previously unknown facts. I loved Simon Sebag Montefiore's Prince of Princes: The Life of Potemkin (Weidenfeld & Nicolson). George Monbiot's Captive State: The Corporate Takeover of Britain (Macmillan) confronts us with the corporate control of British hospitals, schools, universities and, indeed, the food we buy and eat. Scary. But I also read a lot of novels this past year, some new, some older: I loved Kent Haruf 's Plainsong and Niall Williams's Four Letters of Love (both Picador). And I have, with enormous pleasure, re-read Robert Harris's Archangel (Arrow), Richard North Patterson's The Final Judgement (Hutchinson), the perfect legal novel, and all the wonderful thrillers written by Michael Connelly (Orion).

Mavis Cheek

'Not for horrid profs,' says Frank Kermode of his Shakespeare's Language (Allen Lane, Penguin) - and he's quite right. It's engaging and clear to read. One critic called Colm Toibin's The Blackwater Lightship (Picador) 'emotional choreography'. I'd add the word 'beautiful' to that. Three generations, three different beliefs, three women coming to terms with each other and themselves. With The World's Smallest Unicorn (Cape), Shena Mackay brings us 10 more immaculate short stories of human folly and fortune and finding the skull beneath the perm.

A L Kennedy

This year No Great Mischief (Cape) made Alasdair MacLeod's position as a master of prose even more firmly assured. This is a work of true lyricism, emotional intelligence and breathtakingly acute observation.

Terry Eagleton

Years ago, I read Mikhail Bakhtin's great classic of the carnivalesque, Rabelais and His World, and wondered why I had never heard of him before. There's now no doubt that this previously obscure Russian thinker, who is said to have torn up one of his own priceless manuscripts for cigarette paper, is one of the supreme literary thinkers of our time. To write the very best book on him to date is thus a remarkable achievement. Ken Hirschkop's Mikhail Bakhtin: An Aesthetic for Democracy (OUP) combines dogged work in the Russian archives with some brilliant insights to show Bakhtin's relevance to questions of politics and popular democracy today.

Glen Baxter

My contenders for book of the year would have to include Flick Knives and Forks (Zillah Bell Contemporary Art) by Anthony Earnshaw - a collection of the great English surrealists' aphorisms spiced with black humour. My next choice would be The Book of Leviathan (Sort of Books) by Peter Bleguad which is funny, enigmatic and beautifully limned - what more could one ask?

Hermione Lee

My book of the year is the Selected Poems of Yehuda Amichai (Faber) edited by his friend Ted Hughes and by Daniel Weissbort. His wry, conversational poems - tender, humane and pragmatic - on war, love, memory, and the fierce history of his city, Jerusalem, are all the more moving now. I was also delighted by the dazzling stories of Peter Ho Davies, Equal Love (Granta) , and by Michèle Roberts's deliciously sensual French novel, The Looking Glass (Virago).

Helen Dunmore

It's seven years since Michael Donaghy last published a poetry collection. Here, after a magical interval, is Conjure (Picador), his best book yet. Conjure takes all the Donaghy virtues - wit, clarity, breathtaking control of rhyme and rhythm - and adds a new intensity of feeling.

David Hare

Why do women write about the recent past so much better than men? Only John Osborne has described the day before yesterday as skilfully as Barbara Skelton, Doris Lessing and Joan Wyndham. Stet (Granta), is a record of Diana Athill's years as an editor at Andre Deutsch. It's hard to believe that most of her authors came anywhere near Athill's own superb literary pitch. Over the internet you can order the American edition of The Selected Letters of Tennessee Williams, Volume 1 1920-1945 (New Directions) - essential reading for admirers of one of America's greatest dramatists

Emma Tennant

Lorna Sage's Bad Blood (Fourth Estate) is a deceptively simple account of a Second World War childhood in deepest Flintshire, which makes sense of the enormous and bewildering changes in society in the last century.

Michael Foot

Don't be misled by any neglect or false testimony into imagining that Rebecca West was not one of the great women of the century. Her Selected Letters, edited by Bonnie Kime Scott (Yale) should dispose of all such misconceptions. She would have appreciated the latest of essays from her protégé, Merlin Holland's The Oscar Wilde Anthology (HarperCollins). And don't miss Have You Forgotten Yet? The First World War Memoirs of C P Blacker, edited by John Blacker (Pen and Sword Books ), an original, plain-spoken record of the First World War which confronts the reader fairly with the Siegfried Sassoon verdict on the whole affair.

Adam Phillips

R. F. Langley's Collected Poems (Carcanet) has a new music of sense-making about it that is, in the way only poetry and music can be, like an illumination. Larry Siedentop's Democracy In Europe (Allen Lane, Penguin) has a remarkable clarity and exhilaration about something that runs the risk of becoming just another topic of debate. Richard Lewontin with The Triple Helix (Harvard) continues to be the scientist everyone should read.

J G Ballard

In The Heart Of The Sea by Nathaniel Philbrick (HarperCollins) is a deeply moving account of the sinking of the whale ship Essex , which inspired Melville's Moby Dick. Rammed by a sperm whale, the Essex sank three days later, and the survivors set out by boat for the South American coast, 4,000 miles away. Nathaniel Philbrick unsparingly describes their ordeal, a hellish descent into starvation and cannibalism. None the less, these desperate men emerge as heroes.

Philip French

George Orwell is possibly the greatest writer of the twentieth century and next year's major publishing event will be the paperback editions at affordable prices of the first three volumes of his complete essays, letters and diaries: All Propaganda is Lies 1941-42, Keeping Our Little Corner Clean and Two Wasted Years 1943 (Secker & Warburg). My three new favourites all address themselves to settling the business of the last century. Douglas Dunn's vivid book-length poem The Donkey's Ears (Faber), purports to be the letters home to his wife by the self-questioning flag engineer of the Russian fleet steaming from the Baltic to the East China Sea to be destroyed by the Japanese in May 1905.

Philip Roth's The Human Stain (Cape) magnificently completes the informal trilogy about post-war America that Roth began with American Pastoral and I Married a Communist. My film choice is Christopher Frayling's Sergio Leone: Something To Do With Death (Faber), a fascinating biography that locates a great director in the complex social and cultural context of twentieth-century Italy.

Andrew Motion

Derek Mahon has always been a busy reviser and re-presenter of his own work. His latest Selected Poems (Penguin) is his best shot yet at self-definition - a wonderfully varied, skilful and abundant book by a writer who is working at his formidable best. Wordsworth was a grand old tinkerer, too, and watching him chop and change is just one of the fascinations of Juliet Barker's enormous, and enormously sympathetic, biography Wordsworth: A Life (Viking). And yet another revision: the third edition of Michael Gray's Song and Dance Man III: The Art of Bob Dylan (Cassell) - the best book there is on Dylan, now better than ever.

Peter Conrad

Condemned to spend hours each week inching in and out of London along Western Avenue, I was fascinated by Edward Platt's Leadville: A Biography of the A40 (Picador). On a trek from White City to Hanger Lane, Platt investigates the lives of the roadside householders, and documents the death of their suburban dream. A small, gritty, monoxide-scented epic.

Chris Patten

Philip Roth's The Human Stain (Cape) is the best new novel I have read for years. It is a powerful, gripping story with some strong set-pieces. Roth is not afraid to wrestle with ideas, some of them unfashionable but troubling for any liberal conscience. The book I used most was the Royal Horticultural Society's Gardeners' Encyclopaedia of Plants and Flowers (Dorling Kindersley). I couldn't garden without it.

Cressida Connolly

The American Rick Moody is one of the most original and inventive of current fiction writers. His new short stories, Demonology (Faber), are touching and funny and downright odd. I very much enjoyed Kazuo Ishiguro's extraordinary novel, When We Were Orphans (Faber). My best book of the year was Carlo Gebler's Father & I (Little, Brown ). Compassionate, wry and ringingly honest. And John Burnside 's new poems, the Asylum Dance (Cape), are pretty good, too.

Steven Berkoff

In characteristic style Peter Ackroyd pulls back the veil and lets us peer within, examining London with intense fascination in London: The Biography (Chatto & Windus) . In Ackroyd's view we are invited to see London as a living, breathing creature, greedy, bestial, even demonic. It is a work on the level of Mayhew's London, raw and compelling.

A Positively Final Appearance (Penguin) affords another view of London. Alec Guinness 's impeccably delicate prose is so undiluted you feel you can hear the old boy's voice. A man of consummate taste and culture, he epitomises England, an England unfamiliar to us now but which still surrounds Guinness like a bubble. His reading is Trollope and Anthony Powell, while for comfort he quotes from Montaigne, but all so unpretentiously. This is an actor's actor, a man of culture, breeding and even a defined morality.

Martin Amis

Fiction: Saul Bellow's Ravelstein (Penguin). Non-fiction: Inside Stalin's Russia: The Diaries of Reader Bullard, 1930-1934 edited by Julian and Margaret Bullard (Day Books).

Read part two of Pump Up The Volumes here.

He understands the power of a good story, but he is an uncosy, often scary and troubling novelist: besotted by myth, compelled by death and desire and faith and grief, in love with Milton and Blake, angry with religion, intimate with compromise and complicity and corruption, capable of radiant prose. Christopher Frayling I particularly enjoyed David Skal's Screams of Reason - Mad Science and Modern Culture (W. W. Norton & Co) which begins with Dr Faustus and ends with Stephen Hawking but concentrates in between on Boris Karloff and Hollywood horror. The best-written book I read was Thomas McGuane's elegant and thoughtful essays about the partnership - a partnership he calls 'a burst of poetry' - between humans and horses collected as Some Horses (The Lyons Press). Jonathan Meades Atomised by Michel Houllebecq (Heinemann) is the most thrilling novel I've read in several years. Its directness, its energy, its centripetal concentration, its candour, its nihilism and its sod-you-ism are exhilarating. In The Third Reich: A New History (Macmillan), Michael Burleigh proceeds from the premise that Nazism was a quasi-religion whose programme allowed the faithful to perpetrate enormities with a clear conscience. His book is a massive accretion of detail and appalling anecdote. Brenda Maddox Andrew Roberts's Salisbury: Victorian Titan (Weidenfeld and Nicolson) is as learned, accessible and well-shaped a biography as I've read. Roberts is a rare historian, with an eye for the human detail and for contemporary relevance. I also loved the outrageous Letters of Kingsley Amis edited by Zachary Leader (HarperCollins). Antony Holden Angry, outrageous, wildly funny and infinitely sad, Philip Roth's The Human Stain (Cape) completes the majestic postwar US trilogy which began in equally high style with American Pastoral. Martin Amis's memoir Experience (Jonathan Cape) is up there with Roth's The Facts; when fine fictional stylists turn their laser-prose upon themselves, the result is an auto-brainscan offering a tantalising glimpse towards the heart. I also much admired Miranda Seymour's exhaustive biography of Mary Shelley. Charles Saumarez Smith My favourite book of the year is called City Secrets: Rome (The Little Bookroom). Edited by the architect Robert Kahn, it consists of recommendations of what to see and do in Rome as sent in by the American Academy of Rome's many supporters. It's a brilliant idea. I also enjoyed The Long Afternoon (Sceptre), Giles Waterfield's dry and atmospheric novel about his grandparents' life in Menton between the wars. Jan Morris In non-fiction I greatly admired and enjoyed Simon Schama's Rembrandt's Eyes (Allen Lane, Penguin), which was published in the autumn of 1999 but did not reach me until the present millennium; also Peter Ackroyd's virtuoso evocation of the most timeless of cities, London: The Biography (Chatto & Windus). I was delighted by Miles Bredin's life of James Bruce, The Pale Abyssinian (HarperCollins), but since Mr Bredin is my godson I'd better not say anything too nice about it. Mary Riddell As lucid as anything he has written and, in the paperback edition, particularly well-timed Matt Ridley's Genome - the Autobiography of a Species in 23 Chapters (Fourth Estate) is the A to Z route map for anyone trying to get to grips with the completion of the Human Genome Project. Tom Paulin Martin Allen's Hidden Agenda: How the Duke of Windsor Betrayed the Allies (Macmillan) paints a devastating picture of this truly evil royal who was a close friend of Charles Bedaux, a Nazi spy so dangerous that the FBI would appear to have bumped him off in 1944 (officially he committed suicide). Frank Kermode's Shakespeare's Language (Allen Lane, Penguin) is an inspiring work of evaluative critical analysis. Edna O'Brien Snow and Guilt by Giorgio Pressburger (Granta) is a perfect little book. Translated by Shaun Whiteside, these six stories have an underlying unity; the writing is austere yet with a life-affirming tenderness. The same cannot be said for The Journals of Sylvia Plath (Faber). Here we witness the rage, the torment and the competitiveness of a deeply wounded young woman. As I began to read them I wondered if all journals ought not to be consigned to the pyre, but by the time I had finished I marvelled at her industriousness and her capacity at transforming her demons into great art. Eilis Ni Dhuibhne is the most gifted young Irish writer. In The Pale Gold of Alaska (Blackstaff Press), her prose shimmers like poetry. George Steiner My book of the year (if a delayed finding in paperback is allowed), is Colin Thubron's In Siberia (Chatto & Windus) . There is hardly a sentence in this grim yet strangely luminous memoir without a taut vivacity which makes the whole book 'sing'. Thubron's account of the abandoned Stalinist death-camps in the Siberian Kolyma, of the pounding into ice and mud of millions of innocent men and women, is almost unbearable. Yet even here, in the hell of the anonymous, there are touches of human dignity, of that Russian investment in resurrection. Gita Sereny Brigitte Hamann's Hitler's Vienna is a really original account of the young Hitler's years of political apprenticeship between 1907 and 1913. Mark Roseman's The Past in Hiding (Allen Lane, Penguin) is an extraordinary story of a life, particularly read - as I read it - in conjunction with Ian Kershaw's two volumes of Hitler biography - Hubris and Nemesis (Penguin), both of them richly annotated with previously unknown facts. I loved Simon Sebag Montefiore's Prince of Princes: The Life of Potemkin (Weidenfeld & Nicolson). George Monbiot's Captive State: The Corporate Takeover of Britain (Macmillan) confronts us with the corporate control of British hospitals, schools, universities and, indeed, the food we buy and eat. Scary. But I also read a lot of novels this past year, some new, some older: I loved Kent Haruf 's Plainsong and Niall Williams's Four Letters of Love (both Picador). And I have, with enormous pleasure, re-read Robert Harris's Archangel (Arrow), Richard North Patterson's The Final Judgement (Hutchinson), the perfect legal novel, and all the wonderful thrillers written by Michael Connelly (Orion). Mavis Cheek 'Not for horrid profs,' says Frank Kermode of his Shakespeare's Language (Allen Lane, Penguin) - and he's quite right. It's engaging and clear to read. One critic called Colm Toibin's The Blackwater Lightship (Picador) 'emotional choreography'. I'd add the word 'beautiful' to that. Three generations, three different beliefs, three women coming to terms with each other and themselves. With The World's Smallest Unicorn (Cape), Shena Mackay brings us 10 more immaculate short stories of human folly and fortune and finding the skull beneath the perm. A L Kennedy This year No Great Mischief (Cape) made Alasdair MacLeod's position as a master of prose even more firmly assured. This is a work of true lyricism, emotional intelligence and breathtakingly acute observation. Terry Eagleton Years ago, I read Mikhail Bakhtin's great classic of the carnivalesque, Rabelais and His World, and wondered why I had never heard of him before. There's now no doubt that this previously obscure Russian thinker, who is said to have torn up one of his own priceless manuscripts for cigarette paper, is one of the supreme literary thinkers of our time. To write the very best book on him to date is thus a remarkable achievement. Ken Hirschkop's Mikhail Bakhtin: An Aesthetic for Democracy (OUP) combines dogged work in the Russian archives with some brilliant insights to show Bakhtin's relevance to questions of politics and popular democracy today. Glen Baxter My contenders for book of the year would have to include Flick Knives and Forks (Zillah Bell Contemporary Art) by Anthony Earnshaw - a collection of the great English surrealists' aphorisms spiced with black humour. My next choice would be The Book of Leviathan (Sort of Books) by Peter Bleguad which is funny, enigmatic and beautifully limned - what more could one ask? Hermione Lee My book of the year is the Selected Poems of Yehuda Amichai (Faber) edited by his friend Ted Hughes and by Daniel Weissbort. His wry, conversational poems - tender, humane and pragmatic - on war, love, memory, and the fierce history of his city, Jerusalem, are all the more moving now. I was also delighted by the dazzling stories of Peter Ho Davies, Equal Love (Granta) , and by Michèle Roberts's deliciously sensual French novel, The Looking Glass (Virago). Helen Dunmore It's seven years since Michael Donaghy last published a poetry collection. Here, after a magical interval, is Conjure (Picador), his best book yet. Conjure takes all the Donaghy virtues - wit, clarity, breathtaking control of rhyme and rhythm - and adds a new intensity of feeling. David Hare Why do women write about the recent past so much better than men? Only John Osborne has described the day before yesterday as skilfully as Barbara Skelton, Doris Lessing and Joan Wyndham. Stet (Granta), is a record of Diana Athill's years as an editor at Andre Deutsch. It's hard to believe that most of her authors came anywhere near Athill's own superb literary pitch. Over the internet you can order the American edition of The Selected Letters of Tennessee Williams, Volume 1 1920-1945 (New Directions) - essential reading for admirers of one of America's greatest dramatists Emma Tennant Lorna Sage's Bad Blood (Fourth Estate) is a deceptively simple account of a Second World War childhood in deepest Flintshire, which makes sense of the enormous and bewildering changes in society in the last century. Michael Foot Don't be misled by any neglect or false testimony into imagining that Rebecca West was not one of the great women of the century. Her Selected Letters, edited by Bonnie Kime Scott (Yale) should dispose of all such misconceptions. She would have appreciated the latest of essays from her protégé, Merlin Holland's The Oscar Wilde Anthology (HarperCollins). And don't miss Have You Forgotten Yet? The First World War Memoirs of C P Blacker, edited by John Blacker (Pen and Sword Books ), an original, plain-spoken record of the First World War which confronts the reader fairly with the Siegfried Sassoon verdict on the whole affair. Adam Phillips R. F. Langley's Collected Poems (Carcanet) has a new music of sense-making about it that is, in the way only poetry and music can be, like an illumination. Larry Siedentop's Democracy In Europe (Allen Lane, Penguin) has a remarkable clarity and exhilaration about something that runs the risk of becoming just another topic of debate. Richard Lewontin with The Triple Helix (Harvard) continues to be the scientist everyone should read. J G Ballard In The Heart Of The Sea by Nathaniel Philbrick (HarperCollins) is a deeply moving account of the sinking of the whale ship Essex , which inspired Melville's Moby Dick. Rammed by a sperm whale, the Essex sank three days later, and the survivors set out by boat for the South American coast, 4,000 miles away. Nathaniel Philbrick unsparingly describes their ordeal, a hellish descent into starvation and cannibalism. None the less, these desperate men emerge as heroes. Philip French George Orwell is possibly the greatest writer of the twentieth century and next year's major publishing event will be the paperback editions at affordable prices of the first three volumes of his complete essays, letters and diaries: All Propaganda is Lies 1941-42, Keeping Our Little Corner Clean and Two Wasted Years 1943 (Secker & Warburg). My three new favourites all address themselves to settling the business of the last century. Douglas Dunn's vivid book-length poem The Donkey's Ears (Faber), purports to be the letters home to his wife by the self-questioning flag engineer of the Russian fleet steaming from the Baltic to the East China Sea to be destroyed by the Japanese in May 1905. Philip Roth's The Human Stain (Cape) magnificently completes the informal trilogy about post-war America that Roth began with American Pastoral and I Married a Communist. My film choice is Christopher Frayling's Sergio Leone: Something To Do With Death (Faber), a fascinating biography that locates a great director in the complex social and cultural context of twentieth-century Italy. Andrew Motion Derek Mahon has always been a busy reviser and re-presenter of his own work. His latest Selected Poems (Penguin) is his best shot yet at self-definition - a wonderfully varied, skilful and abundant book by a writer who is working at his formidable best. Wordsworth was a grand old tinkerer, too, and watching him chop and change is just one of the fascinations of Juliet Barker's enormous, and enormously sympathetic, biography Wordsworth: A Life (Viking). And yet another revision: the third edition of Michael Gray's Song and Dance Man III: The Art of Bob Dylan (Cassell) - the best book there is on Dylan, now better than ever. Peter Conrad Condemned to spend hours each week inching in and out of London along Western Avenue, I was fascinated by Edward Platt's Leadville: A Biography of the A40 (Picador). On a trek from White City to Hanger Lane, Platt investigates the lives of the roadside householders, and documents the death of their suburban dream. A small, gritty, monoxide-scented epic. Chris Patten Philip Roth's The Human Stain (Cape) is the best new novel I have read for years. It is a powerful, gripping story with some strong set-pieces. Roth is not afraid to wrestle with ideas, some of them unfashionable but troubling for any liberal conscience. The book I used most was the Royal Horticultural Society's Gardeners' Encyclopaedia of Plants and Flowers (Dorling Kindersley). I couldn't garden without it. Cressida Connolly The American Rick Moody is one of the most original and inventive of current fiction writers. His new short stories, Demonology (Faber), are touching and funny and downright odd. I very much enjoyed Kazuo Ishiguro's extraordinary novel, When We Were Orphans (Faber). My best book of the year was Carlo Gebler's Father & I (Little, Brown ). Compassionate, wry and ringingly honest. And John Burnside 's new poems, the Asylum Dance (Cape), are pretty good, too. Steven Berkoff In characteristic style Peter Ackroyd pulls back the veil and lets us peer within, examining London with intense fascination in London: The Biography (Chatto & Windus) . In Ackroyd's view we are invited to see London as a living, breathing creature, greedy, bestial, even demonic. It is a work on the level of Mayhew's London, raw and compelling. A Positively Final Appearance (Penguin) affords another view of London. Alec Guinness 's impeccably delicate prose is so undiluted you feel you can hear the old boy's voice. A man of consummate taste and culture, he epitomises England, an England unfamiliar to us now but which still surrounds Guinness like a bubble. His reading is Trollope and Anthony Powell, while for comfort he quotes from Montaigne, but all so unpretentiously. This is an actor's actor, a man of culture, breeding and even a defined morality. Martin Amis Fiction: Saul Bellow's Ravelstein (Penguin). Non-fiction: Inside Stalin's Russia: The Diaries of Reader Bullard, 1930-1934 edited by Julian and Margaret Bullard (Day Books). Read part two of Pump Up The Volumes here.

fields.headline: Online home help
fields.standfirst: Graham Norwood reports on three new websites
fields.trailText: Graham Norwood reports on three new websites
fields.body:
Housebuyers and sellers are now able to keep better tabs on the professionals that dominate the property business thanks to three new internet websites.

There are already some 350 property websites in the UK, most dedicated solely to selling houses or allied financial services. Some, like www.08004homes.com offer added value for consumers or www.fish4homes.co.uk for daily property news and housing market comments. Others are more specialist, such as www.buildinggreen.com for those people building their own environmentally sound homes.

But the three new sites will add to those acting as advocates for conventional buyers and sellers. The first is www.hometrack.co.uk. This site already provides a small amount of monthly price data on homes sold within the M25 and in early 2001 it will extend across the UK. But it will soon provide sellers with free, toughly worded questionnaires for estate agents to complete when conducting a valuation.

Questions will cover the price the agents put on the property, their opinions on the five best and worst selling points, what comparable properties they have recently sold in the same area, and their approaches to marketing the property. By asking estate agents to complete the online questionnaire the seller can then make real like-for-like comparisons on their performances.

Hometrack can also offer online conveyancing services, at a charge, if the seller wants to continue working with the site during the sale.

Buyers get more information, too. Hometrack has made unidentified visits to every estate agency office in UK towns and cities with a 10,000-plus population - over 10,100 offices in total. It made fictitious enquiries about buying and selling and used the feedback it received from the agents to grade them in each locality on their attentiveness and quality of information they provide the public. This allows people moving into the area to choose an agent which has a good track record.

'We want people to use this service to micro-manage the process of selling or buying houses' says Hometrack chief executive Patrick Currie, who is confident agents will warm to his site's approach. 'If they're good, they will have nothing to worry about'.

Another new site is www.fastcrop.com. This is the working title for a website launching in the new year, which aims to bring the property portfolios of up to 200 British estate agents on to one site.

This principle is not new, many sites claim to display up to 220,000 properties on sale across the UK. The difference with Fastcrop is that it is financially underpinned by 200 estate agents who have invested between £10,000 and £1m each and have agreed not to display their houses for sale on any other internet site.

The site's primary aim unsurprisingly is to make money for the agents by offering a range of financial and lifestyle products to online visitors, as well as by selling houses. But indirectly Fastcrop may revolutionise the way agents operate.

The public will be able to view headlines on all the properties on one site. Each participating agent is also electronically linked, making it possible for non-internet house buyers to go into one agent's office and, if the right property is not available, ask what houses are being sold by another local Fastcrop agent .

For the customer this would be a small step towards the respected US system where a buyer can go into one estate agent and see all the properties on sale in an area, including those marketed by rival agents. When a property is sold the sales commission, which is higher than in the UK, is split between the agents. The acid test will be whether participating agents will play ball. Fastcrop chief executive Ian Springett says he will not force his agents to operate collaboratively but adds. 'My own view is that this is essential and common sense.'

Springett says many internet property sites lose their credibility by continuing to display sold or withdrawn houses without telling buyers. He says he will kick agents off the Fastcrop site if they fail to keep their online portfolios up to date, and, like Hometrack, he promises to make unidentified visits to agencies to keep them on their toes.

The third new website is www.undermystreet.co.uk. This site exploits the name of the separate upmystreet.com site which gives data on house sales, school results and local services. Undermystreet offers free flood, subsidence and land contamination histories for each UK neighbourhood.

Online users feed a complete postcode into the website and get a headline synopsis of the land history for that area, as taken from Ordnance Survey maps dating back to 1850 and other information kept on a database run by the Landmark Information Group.

The precise history of land use beneath any one specific address can then be obtained, at a charge, through a more detailed search.

The company claims the UK has more than 400,000 past industrial sites which may have led to ground contamination, plus 25,000 landfill and waste sites, around 45,000 locations with licenses to undertake contaminating or polluting processes, 2,000 dumps for hazardous substances, plus hundreds of former coal and mineral mines.

Landmark says legal searches during house sales rarely come up with accurate land histories. 'How many of us would buy a car without opening the bonnet or checking for rust?' asks the company's Geoff Offen. 'Yet that's what we do when we buy a house without knowing about the land.'

webTitle: Wealthcheck: Where does my cash go?

fields.headline: Where does my cash go?
fields.standfirst: Trainee wants money to travel, reports  Margaret Dibben
fields.trailText: Trainee wants money to travel, reports Margaret Dibben.
fields.body:
Age 27
Lives in Cheddar
Occupation Trainee clinical psychologist
Earns £14,800
Mortgage None
Debts Student loans, student overdraft, Barclayloan, credit cards
Investments Tessa
Pension NHS scheme
Aims To save for a year's travelling

Kate Edgar works four days a week and, as well as playing netball and squash, is studying for a doctorate in clinical psychology. She wants to specialise in psychosis, or personality disorder, working with adults with severe mental disorders. She already has the experience of short-term jobs working as a prison psychologist, an assistant psychologist working with older people, people with learning difficulties and as a research psychologist. She loves the work: 'It is fascinating. It really suits me.'

For her job, Kate is organised and disciplined, but outside work she is quite different: 'At home I am completely scatty.' Financially she is in a mess as well. Although 27, she has not earned enough money since graduating to start repaying her student loans - 'a position I would think quite unusual for someone my age'.

She finishes her doctorate next September and then wants to take time out to travel, ideally for a year but more realistically for six months: 'I want to go abroad because I have been studying for 10 years and I need a break. I want to have a wider experience, see a bit of the world before I settle down.'

But her lack of money is a problem: 'I feel I have so little money, but in reality I do have money: I just don't know what I am doing with it. I pay £300 a month rent and usually have about £300 to spend on food, petrol, car disasters and unforeseen events. I did draw up a budget but I didn't stick to it.'

'I'm not that big a spender: I buy lots of little things and I'm stupid. I buy sandwiches rather than make my own. Little things like that eat up the money. I don't buy many clothes. If you looked in my wardrobe, you'd see I haven't bought anything new for about four years.'

Just as she is confused about money, so she is vague about where she wants to travel: 'I need to be aware of how much I have to spend before I can decide where I can realistically go. I would be prepared to earn money while I am abroad but I have not thought about how I could do that.'

Her pension allows her to take time out and she is confident of finding work when she returns: 'It will be easy to find a job when I get back because there are loads of posts available which they can't fill because there is a bottleneck in the training.' Her earning potential is high.

'Until now I have not really taken control of my finances. I need to get a grip on them, pay off as much debt as possible and ideally save some money for travelling.'

She is determined that she will change her habits: 'If I could put nine months of work into saving, that would be really great, because there would be an end in sight. If I really looked seriously at my finances, I am sure I could do something about it.'

Adviser 1: Nicola Page

Kate has made some in-roads into sorting her finances with a Tessa and a pension, but this does not help her short-term financial goal.

She should amalgamate her Visa cards and Barclayloan as quickly as possible to make one monthly payment with a lower interest rate. Finding competitive terms on the internet is easy. For example, on her outstanding balance of £4,070, Northern Rock charges 10.4 per cent APR, which means monthly repayments of £131.20 over 36 months.

Most importantly, if she does this she must destroy her existing credit cards. She must not start using them again or she will be repeating the exercise in a year's time, creating a vicious circle of debt.

By reducing her outgo ings, Kate should be able to save £100 a month. She should put money into her instant access savings account each month by direct debit - but not touch it. Nationwide has an internet-based account paying 7 per cent gross; L&G Bank has a telephone service paying 6.25 per cent. If she records exactly where she spends her money in one week, she will be horrified but, once she knows where money is going, she'll find it easier to budget.

Kate must also budget for her loan while she is away, and for this needs money on deposit. It would be good to maintain the Tessa and pension, but these are not main considerations so long as she restarts them on her return.

Nicola Page works for Bath-based Chartwell Investments.

Adviser 2: David Turner

Kate has clearly worked hard since leaving university and earned an opportunity to have fun, but her debts are getting in the way. Student loans are competitive and the last borrowings to be paid off, but bank loans and credit cards are often punishingly high and should be repaid first.

It may be possible to extend the overdraft, either to provide travelling funds or to repay other loans. She should speak to her bank manager or try a number of banks to consolidate her borrowing at a low rate of interest.

Kate must get a grip on her budgeting as, without a clear idea of how much she spends, she is likely to continue having problems managing debt. Budgeting may be a painful exercise at first, but will become easier.

If Kate can work while abroad, financing the travelling should not be too difficult once she has bought the air ticket. Trailfinders and other specialist travel agents often have competitive fares if Kate is prepared to travel at an unsocial hour and does not mind taking extra time to reach her destination.

On returning to the UK, she will be in her late twenties and will need to address pension planning. The NHS scheme is excellent and includes a number of additional voluntary contribution (AVC) schemes. An alternative to AVCs may be Isas or a stakeholder pension.

David Turner is a senior consultant with Sedgwick Independent Financial Consultants.

 Advice is for guidance only. Do you want to appear in Wealthcheck? Write, including daytime and evening telephone numbers, a brief list of circumstances and any investments, to: Wealthcheck, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or e-mail: cash@observer.co.uk. You must be prepared to be interviewed and photographed.

'I'm not that big a spender: I buy lots of little things and I'm stupid. I buy sandwiches rather than make my own. Little things like that eat up the money. I don't buy many clothes. If you looked in my wardrobe, you'd see I haven't bought anything new for about four years.' Just as she is confused about money, so she is vague about where she wants to travel: 'I need to be aware of how much I have to spend before I can decide where I can realistically go. I would be prepared to earn money while I am abroad but I have not thought about how I could do that.' Her pension allows her to take time out and she is confident of finding work when she returns: 'It will be easy to find a job when I get back because there are loads of posts available which they can't fill because there is a bottleneck in the training.' Her earning potential is high. 'Until now I have not really taken control of my finances. I need to get a grip on them, pay off as much debt as possible and ideally save some money for travelling.' She is determined that she will change her habits: 'If I could put nine months of work into saving, that would be really great, because there would be an end in sight. If I really looked seriously at my finances, I am sure I could do something about it.' Adviser 1: Nicola Page Kate has made some in-roads into sorting her finances with a Tessa and a pension, but this does not help her short-term financial goal. She should amalgamate her Visa cards and Barclayloan as quickly as possible to make one monthly payment with a lower interest rate. Finding competitive terms on the internet is easy. For example, on her outstanding balance of £4,070, Northern Rock charges 10.4 per cent APR, which means monthly repayments of £131.20 over 36 months. Most importantly, if she does this she must destroy her existing credit cards. She must not start using them again or she will be repeating the exercise in a year's time, creating a vicious circle of debt. By reducing her outgo ings, Kate should be able to save £100 a month. She should put money into her instant access savings account each month by direct debit - but not touch it. Nationwide has an internet-based account paying 7 per cent gross; L&G Bank has a telephone service paying 6.25 per cent. If she records exactly where she spends her money in one week, she will be horrified but, once she knows where money is going, she'll find it easier to budget. Kate must also budget for her loan while she is away, and for this needs money on deposit. It would be good to maintain the Tessa and pension, but these are not main considerations so long as she restarts them on her return. Nicola Page works for Bath-based Chartwell Investments. Adviser 2: David Turner Kate has clearly worked hard since leaving university and earned an opportunity to have fun, but her debts are getting in the way. Student loans are competitive and the last borrowings to be paid off, but bank loans and credit cards are often punishingly high and should be repaid first. It may be possible to extend the overdraft, either to provide travelling funds or to repay other loans. She should speak to her bank manager or try a number of banks to consolidate her borrowing at a low rate of interest. Kate must get a grip on her budgeting as, without a clear idea of how much she spends, she is likely to continue having problems managing debt. Budgeting may be a painful exercise at first, but will become easier. If Kate can work while abroad, financing the travelling should not be too difficult once she has bought the air ticket. Trailfinders and other specialist travel agents often have competitive fares if Kate is prepared to travel at an unsocial hour and does not mind taking extra time to reach her destination. On returning to the UK, she will be in her late twenties and will need to address pension planning. The NHS scheme is excellent and includes a number of additional voluntary contribution (AVC) schemes. An alternative to AVCs may be Isas or a stakeholder pension. David Turner is a senior consultant with Sedgwick Independent Financial Consultants.  Advice is for guidance only. Do you want to appear in Wealthcheck? Write, including daytime and evening telephone numbers, a brief list of circumstances and any investments, to: Wealthcheck, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or e-mail: cash@observer.co.uk. You must be prepared to be interviewed and photographed.

webTitle: How to win a Christmas bonus

fields.headline: Exit Scrooge, bring on Santa
fields.standfirst: How to win a Christmas bonus
fields.trailText: How to win a Christmas bonus.
fields.body:
It's bonus time again in the City as staff share the annual round of pay-outs totalling millions of pounds. But employees elsewhere who ask for Christmas bonuses are likely to be less lucky.

One company director says: 'If someone approached me for a Christmas bonus I'd laugh at them. That's just not part of the work culture.'

Organisational psychologist Gina Connolly says: 'In some jobs and in some sectors the fact is Christmas bonuses are never awarded.' Things 'just don't work that way'.

But if you feel you may have a chance, this is how to set about persuading your boss:

Fundamentally, you need to justify your position. Simply saying you deserve extra cash won't do. You have to demonstrate why. And this argument must be logical, objective, and measurable. 'It all sounds very obvious but really most people don't do this properly,' says Dr Sandi Mann, a lecturer at Central Lancashire University and author of Psychology Goes To Work .

Mann stresses in her book that it is not enough to just point out that you have been with the company for a long time, that a colleague has had a pay rise, or that someone in a rival firm is earning more than you.

Nor is it wise to say you have a large family and lots of presents to buy.

Your reasons should not be based on ego or emotion, says Mann, but on 'what you have actually achieved'. So identify any way in which you have excelled by working beyond your job description, and say why you think this has made a big difference to the company's fortunes.

After you have found a business case for a bonus, imagine how your request will sound to your employer. To do this, try to understand what makes them tick. In his book Negotiating a Better Deal , author Brian Finch suggests you find out: 'What drives them? What are they trying to achieve? What are their sticking points?'

The chances are, they will have a feeling that you are just taking advantage of the situation,' says Barry Eaglestone, a headhunter with Taylor Bennett. 'So be prepared to let them know you are not there for opportunistic greed.' His advice: recognise what you value about your job and be ready to articulate it.

If your boss says there is no money to pay a bonus, think laterally about other ways you could receive it. 'More holiday is an obvious option,' suggests one human resources manager.

Be ready for the old chestnut that if you are given extra, 'everybody else will want the same'. You can say you are very discreet about your pay and never discuss it with other staff.

Put your case only when you have planned it thoroughly, and be ready for resistance.

It is crucial not to appear threatening. Eaglestone says: 'You have to understand the psychology of the situation. No one likes to be forced into a corner. Your approach should not be an intimidating one. It should be consultative.'

Manager Kellie Miles of web design consultancy Surf Pacific, remembers asking for a bonus when she was an executive in the film industry: 'I kept the discussion conversational and non-threatening. I kept my thoughts clear and tried not to exaggerate. I spoke of my work ethic, I outlined my hard work and I stressed my determination to help the company succeed.

'I then asked my boss to comment on my performance. Through doing this, not only did I gain his respect, I also got him to recognise I was a valuable member of the team and that my request was justified.'

But even your best efforts can fail. Kate Dale, editor of a business portal called Clearbusiness.com, recalls her experience in a previous job: 'It was with an independent publisher that viewed staff as nothing more than an irritating nuisance.

'At the last minute my boss would cancel review meetings, or just not turn up. Even once you'd managed to pin him down and reached an agreement for a one-off payment, it would never hap pen. He had lots of lame excuses. The net effect was that you just stopped trying.'

It is not just small companies that refuse to negotiate properly. Kate Dale says: 'One large company I worked for used its middle managers to protect itself from meaningful discussions about bonuses. I felt as though they didn't even value me enough to talk to me personally.'

Henry Ritson, global marketing manager for UUNET, the internet arm of telecommunications company WorldCom, takes a more long-term view of bonuses and salary rises, too. In a changing and fast growing industry, it is more important 'to be seen as an employee who has a history of being focused on the good of the company', rather than someone wanting 'a quick cash win'.

Ritson's strategy has meant he has 'always found myself being underpaid compared to the market value of my job'. However, 'the pay-off for doing this is that you are always seen to be over-performing, and are better positioned to take the high ground in any reorganisation, leading to better long term benefits'.

In the short term though, if you do ask for a Christmas bonus and the answer, despite all your efforts, is no, you must either learn to live with it or leave the job.

If you choose to stay, try to do so on 'amicable terms', says Brian Finch, 'You may feel embarrassed, awkward, stung or bitter. Remember, you have to continue to work with these people.'

But if the answer is yes, celebrate and then invest the cash. We'll examine how next week.
