fields.headline: A fable that could end unhappily
fields.standfirst: The Government-backed Aesop plan may look tempting but beware the drawbacks, says  Maria Scott
fields.trailText: The Government-backed Aesop plan may look tempting but beware the drawbacks, says Maria Scott.
fields.body:
However much your employer sings the praises of its employee share scheme, you should take a long, hard look before you leap. Many people have done well from such schemes over recent years, but the period has also seen spectacular gains from the stock market in general and certain sectors in particular.

If we head into a dull period, employee share ownership may not be a certain bet for profits. Mergers may also take a toll on schemes. Employees may be forced to exercise their options and sell or take their savings.

Asda's scheme survived the Wal-Mart takeover, but employees now receive Wal-Mart's US shares when their schemes mature. Diane Hay, chief executive of ProShare, says: 'Asda has done a lot to help employees cope and has set up effective dealing arrangements, but it's a problem.'

Here are some questions you should ask yourself, or employer, before you decide.

What will I have to pay for the shares and can I afford it?
'If an employer is offering free shares it is basically a no-brainer,' says Hay. But you need to think more carefully if you are being asked to buy shares. For lower-paid employees, in particular, an SAYE scheme may be more attractive than an Aesop (all-employee share-ownership plan) because you can take cash out with no risk to the capital.

What are the risks?
If you are buying, or receiving free shares, you must accept the possibility that their value could fall. Those with share options in some hi-tech companies have learned this the hard way.

Hay says: 'You need to think about the wider financial position, as to whether it is a good thing for you to have your only investment as shares in your employer. You have got the job, your pension and any spare cash in your employer. If that company goes belly-up you have lost everything. You would have been better off putting your money in a unit trust or Isa.'

Fred Hackworth, at the Employee Share Ownership Centre, says that if, under an Aesop scheme, the employer matches the shares that the employee offers to buy, the risk of losing money is much reduced.

Does it matter how long I will work for the company?
If you withdraw from plans early you are likely to lose the tax breaks available and may have to pull out before becoming eligible for shares. You need to be committed to a company for at least three years and possibly five. If you receive free shares under an Aesop you may have to forfeit them if you leave within three years of the date the shares were awarded.

How easy will it be to sell the shares?
If you work for a large company quoted on the stock market, this should not be a problem. But in smaller companies, particularly private ones, it may be difficult to obtain a buyer. Some organisations arrange to sell shares to willing buyers; oth ers will be planning a stock-market flotation. Rose Edmunds, at accountant Grant Thornton, says: 'Where employees are putting their hands in their pockets to buy shares they need to be asking searching questions about how they can realise the value of their shares.'

What if I have to pull out early?
Under Aesop no tax is payable if you have to pull out because of redundancy, injury or disability.

Anything else I should be aware of?
If you are receiving, or expect to receive, certain benefits including maternity benefit, industrial-injuries benefit and working families tax credit the new Aesop could disqualify you.

 The Inland Revenue leaflet IR177, available from local tax offices, explains the situation in detail.

fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.trailText: Pack to end gazumping 'a success' | Mis-selling fears | Cheaper loans
fields.body:
Pack to end gazumping 'a success'

The pilot of a 'seller's pack' designed to put paid to gazumping has been hailed as a success by the Government despite a mixed reception from estate agents.

The compulsory pack is designed to speed up the house-buying process, thereby reducing the risk of gazumping. Sellers will have to compile essential information and documents at the very start of the transaction process rather than after terms have been agreed.

But some estate agents involved in the Bristol pilot felt the time taken to assemble the pack - 11 working days on average - meant sellers missing out on prospective buyers, particularly in a fast-moving market.

The pack contains title documents, replies to local authority searches, a draft contract and a survey on the condition of the property.

The Government hopes it will give buyers a snapshot of a property before they visit it so they will not be faced with any nasty surprises. Problems encountered by agents participating in the pilot included buyers' mistrust of surveys paid for by the sellers.

But the Government is adamant the pilot was a success. Housing Minister Nick Raynsford says: 'The pilot has confirmed consumer support for the seller's pack; demonstrated tangible benefits and identified areas where components of the seller's packs need further work to make them more accessible and easy to use.'

He says 87 per cent of accepted offers in the Bristol pilot resulted in completed transactions, compared with 72 per cent under the current system.

Legal & General housing spokesman Peter Timberlake says: 'Problems which need to be addressed before the pack is implemented in 2003 are the longevity of the survey, the cost and how it can be paid for, and how to guarantee that the information is correct.'

The pack is expected to cost £500, although it was free during the pilot.

Mis-selling fears

With-profit bonds, a popular but increasingly controversial lump-sum investment, are under scrutiny by the Association of British Insurers. The ABI is discussing with companies concerns over how they are marketed.

The ABI has identified four areas of 'ambiguity': the explanations of bonuses, charges, taxation and the fact that with-profit bonds invest in the stock market. The ABI recently met with a dozen key providers but has not yet decided on a plan. ABI spokesman Malcolm Tarling says: 'Once we have formulated our thinking we will draw up guidance for all providers.'

The ABI says it wants to make sure consumers understand what they are buying. Earlier this year, the Faculty and Institute of Actuaries voiced concerns about enticing headline rates in many bands.

Cheaper loans

Nationwide building society will reduce its standard variable mortgage rate by 0.2 per cent from 1 December. A Nationwide customer with a mortgage of £60,000 will see £10 a month shaved off repayments.

The new standard variable rate is 7.09 per cent. The lender says this is 0.65 per cent below the standard rate of its big high-street competitors, which will now come under pressure to copy Nationwide.

The society also intends to trim its savings rates in the near future.

Charges charged

Charges on investment funds can reduce their value by up to 25 per cent according to a new survey by industry newspaper MoneyMarketing .

The survey of more than 3,000 investment funds also reveals a difference of up to 250 per cent between the performance of the best and the worst funds. The best in the UK 'all companies' sector was the Abbey National Stockmarket 100 Tracker Growth while the worst was the Liontrust top 100.

The survey's authors advise you to weigh up charges as well as performance before investing. They say it is a good idea to think about whether you are getting value for money for your annual management charge. The 'fund rating' is a good indicator of management performance.

MM uncovered some tracker funds with high annual charges although these products are not actively managed.

Copies of the survey are available from MM on 020 7292 3730, priced £4.95 each.

Shares on move

You can now buy and sell shares through your mobile phone with Barclays Stockbrokers online share dealing service.

The service, initially to be offered through the Nokia 7110 Wap mobile phone, allows real-time online dealing at a cost of 1 per cent of a trade's value. There are minimum and maximum charges of £11.99 and £39.99.

The service features the stockbrokers' price improver,which scans for the most competitive share price. There is also access to market news. Contact 0845 609 0039 to register.

webTitle: Stakeholders: More than one way to play

fields.headline: More than one way to play
fields.standfirst: Maria Scott  sets out the  options for companies that want to share some of the wealth with their workers
fields.trailText: Maria Scott sets out the options for companies that want to share some of the wealth with their workers.
fields.body:
Save as you earn

This type of scheme is popular among large companies. In April 1999 nearly 90 per cent of FTSE 100 companies offered them.

For employees, this is the lowest-risk employee share scheme available. You save between £5 and £250 a month in a bank or building society account and get the option to buy shares three, five or seven years later at a price generally 20 per cent lower than the market price when the option was first awarded. You must save for three, five or seven years, and will receive a bonus, calculated as a multiple of the amount you save each month, to buy shares when your plan matures. This will be 2.75 times monthly payments over three years, 7.5 times over five and 13.5 times over seven years.

If you don't want to buy shares at the end of the savings period, you can keep the money and bonus. If you buy the shares, you do not have to sell immediately. If you 'exercise' your option, there will be no income tax as long as you have saved until the end of the contract. If you sell, you may have to pay capital gains tax.

There has been speculation that schemes would be phased out once the new all-employee share ownership plan (Aesop) is up and running but the Government moved to quash this recently. As one commentator pointed out, axing such a successful scheme would contradict the Government's desire to encourage saving, even though SAYE leaves employees free to choose whether they take a stake in their company or not.

Company share option plans

In CSOP schemes companies grant employees the right to buy shares worth up to £30,000 per person at a future date.

There is no discount on the shares. The employee does not have to put any money in up front but will need to have money set aside to buy shares in future if they want to take up their option. Some stockbrokers lend employees the money to buy the shares and will then sell part of the allotment to fund the repayment. Employees can let the option lapse if they do not want to buy at that time. If the options are held for at least three years, there will be no income tax payable, but there may be a CGT bill.

Profit-sharing

Shares are given to employees after being held in a trust for three years, with the value being linked to the company's profitability.

Employees can take the shares or opt for cash, and provided the shares have been held for three years before they are given to the employee there is no income tax to pay. Again, CGT may be payable. This scheme is to end in 2002, because some aspects of it have been incorporated in the new Aesop.

All-employee share ownership plans

The Government's new baby is intended to appeal to companies quoted on the stock exchange as well as 'unquoteds'.

For employees, the Aesop scheme carries a higher risk than SAYE, where you can save without actually buying shares. But there are gener ous tax breaks on Aesop and the more you subscribe, the more likely it is your investment will be boosted by free shares from your employer.

You can subscribe up to £125 a month- £1,500 a year - or 10 per cent of your salary, whichever is smaller. You pay out of pre-tax salary so there is no tax or NI to pay. webTitle: Stakeholders: A share of the  spoils

fields.headline: A share of the  spoils
fields.standfirst: A new scheme to reward staff has its drawbacks,    reports  Maria Scott
fields.trailText: A new scheme to reward staff has its drawbacks, reports Maria Scott.
fields.body:
Last month workers at supermarket chain Asda celebrated profits of up to £52,000 each from their employer. These payments were not bonuses, but the fruits of saving in Asda's employee share-ownership plan. The largest amounts went to employees who had saved £250 a month for five years. They profited to the tune of nearly 350 per cent over the life of their schemes, a staggering return. For people lucky enough to work for an employer who operates such a scheme, and where the share price is going in the right direction - Asda's was boosted by its takeover by US retailer Wal-Mart - this type of scheme represents one of the most attractive forms of investment around.

A scheme that simultaneously encourages saving and employee loyalty is bound to fascinate a Government that reveres both. Hardly surprising then, that it wants to see many more people owning shares in the companies they work for. British industry has not embraced employee share ownership with the same gusto as counterparts in the US but the Government is campaigning to change this. At present around 3.5 million people belong to such schemes in the UK and the Government wants to double the number of companies offering the schemes, which should increase membership to around 4 million or 5 million over the next few years.

There are already several schemes available although one of these, profit-related pay, is to be phased out and replaced by a new scheme announced in the last Budget. The all-employee share-ownership plan, or Aesop, is billed by its promoters as having the best tax breaks of any employee share scheme ever introduced in the UK. This is the scheme that the Government is counting on to significantly lift the popularity of employee share ownership and companies are beginning to launch Aesops now. About 170 have applied to the Inland Revenue to launch plans.

The tax breaks on Aesops are generous; shares that employees buy from the schemes are purchased from pre-tax income and so there is no income tax or National Insurance to pay provided the shares are held for five years. If an employer gives shares to employees, these are also free of tax and NI. Potentially, the number of shares that can be swept up by employees is also generous. They can buy up to £1,500 worth themselves, and employers can double that in the form of free 'matching' or 'partnership' shares. A company can, in addition, give up to £3,000 of free shares, regardless of whether an employee has bought his or her own.

Fred Hackworth, director of the Employee Share Ownership Centre, explains: 'Employees could end up with £7,500 of shares in the first year, having spent only £1,500 to get them. When you think about a 40 per cent tax payer, for example, you can see how advantageous that is.'

Another key aspect of the Aesop is that employers can award shares according to the performance of employees. This could apply to the whole workforce or to individual groups; workers at one branch of a supermarket for example. The Government sees this aspect of its new scheme as part of its drive to improve productivity.

Not all companies are expected to offer performance-related schemes. Chris Rebello, head of corporate marketing at Barclays Stockbrokers, which is to launch an Aesop set-up service for companies at the beginning of next year, says the rules on performance-related share allocations are extremely complex. 'To avoid complexities, companies will seek to allocate shares across the board, which is not the way the Government wanted to go.'

Hackworth says companies 'like the smell' of Aesops and predicts that newer companies will be enthusiastic about the prospect of being able to offer incentives to employees. 'Some will say, "This is wonderful"; this is the first opportunity to reward the people who have produced the goods.'

He concedes, however, that companies will need to tread carefully to avoid industrial-relations problems. 'The performance element is going to be controversial. Companies are going to have to think very carefully about how they fix their performance criteria so that everyone can see that it is transparent and fair.'

Rose Edmunds, a tax partner at accountant Grant Thornton, points to another potential problem for employers if worker share ownership widens significantly. 'They could end up with disgruntled employees on the share register.'

The Government, and many employers, are convinced that employee share-ownership plans (Esops) of all kinds can improve a company's performance. But the TUC says experiences with such schemes in the past have been mixed.

Schemes have been disrupted by takeovers, and in some cases managements have tried to use the share schemes to encourage workers to make sacrifices. Sometimes, where the schemes have held large stakes in a company, the distinction between workers and management has become blurred, forcing workers into difficult positions when asked to make sacrifices.

According to the TUC, Esops should be seen as part of a long-term strategy to improve performance and not a quick fix to flatter the company's figures before being sold off.

The organisation points to a study in the United States that examined 45 companies operating share schemes. It measured performance before and after their introduction and compared them with five similar companies without share plans. On average, sales and employment increased 5 per cent faster in the Esop companies than in the others during the five years after the plans were set up.

More than 73 per cent of the Esop companies improved performance significantly after establishing the new schemes. But, says the TUC, the research also showed that the best results came from companies that encouraged the participation of employees in decision-making.

In its response to the Government's proposals for Aesops, the TUC concluded that: 'Employee share ownership can work to assist improved company performance by facilitating increased employee involvement, but it is workplace relationships as a whole that are key to improving company perfor mance. It is important that it is made clear that the introduction of an employee share-ownership scheme should be part of an overall strategy to increase employee involvement.'

Diane Hay, chief executive of ProShare, the organisation that promotes share own ership, agrees that installing an employee share scheme is not, on its own, enough to turn an unhappy, foot-dragging workforce into productive enthusiasts.

Hay, who moved to ProShare from a job as an employee share-scheme specialist at the Inland Revenue, says the Esop must be part of a culture of open communications and generally good employee relations. 'You can't have a successful scheme unless you are going to be communicating with your employees.'

Pioneers reap the profits

Two of the first companies off the block in offering employees the Government's new Aesop employee share are The Share Centre, a share dealing company, and ScottishPower. At The Share Centre staff are being offered two free shares for each one they buy themselves. The company says this works out at a 6.8 per cent bonus to subscribers' salaries.

In late December there will be a special issue of free shares, and the average value for each employee will be around £1,600. The allocations of free shares include a flat sum worth £750 for full-time employees plus varying amounts according to salary and how long an employee has worked for the company.

Gavin Oldham, chief executive of The Share Centre, says 75 per cent of employees signed up for the scheme within a week of its launch, and 84 per cent of these are subscribing to buy partnership shares. Oldham calculates that people buying partnership shares, currently worth 48.5p, are receiving them for 9p or 10p as a result of the 'stunning' tax breaks on Aesops, and the contribution the company is making through free shares.

Next year the company may link the distribution of free shares to the organisation's performance, but Oldham has some reservations about rewarding individual departments. This can result in people becoming more concerned about their own sections than the whole business.

'One approach, which I'm quite impressed with, would be to have two elements. One would consider how much your own area has achieved and the second would be how much you have helped others to achieve their targets.'

The Share Centre is not quoted on the Stock Exchange but the company has set up its own dealing arrangement. Many customers of The Share Centre hold shares which they received as a result of a free issue of stock last year. Oldham says The Share Centre is interested in providing trading arrangements for other unquoted companies who want to issue employee shares.

Ilona Samu, 29, is deputy senior dealer at The Share Centre, where she has worked for five years. She is subscribing the maximum amount to the employee share scheme and says: 'It is a good investment opportunity. I will be here for a long time.'

At ScottishPower, which also runs an SAYE scheme, the Aesop is giving one free 'partnership' share for each share bought by employees. To launch the plan, ScottishPower granted £250 of free shares to employees who signed up. The company points out that members of an Aesop also receive dividends on their holdings and members of its scheme can receive these as cash or additional shares.

Paul Pagliari, group human-resources director says: 'We see the scheme as an important message to our employees. We want to talk to them as shareholders.'

A windfall to sink into the kitchen

Gug Kyriacou works in the press office at Abbey National and has just collected a nest egg from its save as you earn scheme.

The scheme offers options to save over various periods and Kyriacou chose a five-year term. He put in £50 a month, saving £3,000 of his own money. He was then awarded a bonus of 7.5 times his monthly savings, to receive a top-up of £375. Whenhe took out his plan, he was given the option to purchase shares at £4.28 compared with a price of just over £11 last week, a profit of £6.49 per share. He would have to spend £3,372 to buy his shares, and if he sells them he would receive £8,486, a profit of £5,668 on his personal outlay of £3,000.

'I will use the profit from their shares to fix my kitchen in February,' he says.

fields.headline: What's the big ideavirus?
fields.standfirst: How do you spread a consumer epidemic? If you're a multinational company, you put your faith in 'viral marketing'. It's what we used to call word of mouth. So, pass it on...
fields.trailText: How do you spread a consumer epidemic? If you're a multinational company, you put your faith in 'viral marketing'. It's what we used to call word of mouth. So, pass it on...
fields.body:
This year's big idea has been the idea of how Big Ideas spread. The germ of it came from the New Yorker writer Malcolm Gladwell, whose book The Tipping Point, published last spring, investigated the process by which particular products became crazes, and who argued that these social trends mirrored the behaviour of diseases (in particular, happily, venereal diseases) - in that they were spread in the first instance by a promiscuous and energetic few, and, once they gained a hold in a small population, they grew exponentially. (At one moment, for example, a handful of goatee-bearded systems analysts in San Francisco took to riding to work on prototype silver micro-scooters designed by a Swiss eccentric; within a few months they were on the Christmas lists of the whole world.)

Gladwell was fascinated by the precise moment at which a local outbreak of such ideas or trends 'tipped' and they became an epidemic, and by the optimum environment in which this 'tipping' might take place.

Like all the best Big Ideas, this one came armed with a pseudoscientific rhetoric borrowed from a variety of sources that included Richard Dawkins's evolutionary biology (a fertile idea was a 'meme', an organism that grew stronger as it spread) and Yiddish folklore (a propagator of new ideas was a 'maven'). This nomenclature gave Gladwell's thesis a compelling kind of contemporary authority - but, still, anyone who can describe the intimate sales history of a particular kind of flip-flop in Los Angeles (or the curious trajectory of a word-of-mouth bestselling novel) in terms of the spread of syphilis in downtown Baltimore, is likely - in our brand and health-obsessed times - to give their idea, again to use Gladwell's term, 'stickiness'.

One place where Gladwell's word-of-mouth treatise stuck was under the bald pate of Seth Godin, a 40-year-old Californian who, in his own words, has been on the 'cutting edge of internet marketing since before there was an internet'. Godin, formerly a marketing vice-president at the dominant online portal Yahoo!, was a man who had long been in search of a Big Idea - his previous books had included The Ultra Secrets of Game Boy Games and The E-Mail Addresses of the Rich and Famous as well as the bestselling Permission Marketing. When he read The Tipping Point , he says, many of the thoughts which had preoccupied him about the growth of new technology suddenly coalesced into a one large contagious-feeling idea: an 'ideavirus'.

In 30 days he had written a book, Unleashing the Ideavirus, which gave practical application to Gladwell's theorising. Godin posted his book on the internet in August: it has since been downloaded by more than a million people - many of them, you imagine, alarmed publishers - making it the fastest-spreading virtual book ever, and, probably, extraordinarily, one of this autumn's best-read book of any kind.

One of the selling points of Godin's idea - which differentiates it from most other business books - is that it puts its money where its mouth is. Godin's notion of the ideavirus suggests that our future will resemble one vast global Tupperware party. Products (which in his terms are interchangeable with 'ideas') will be sold less and less through traditional means of advertising and more and more by word-of-mouth recommendations and gossip. His book, launched with no advertising budget, is a paradigm of that process; it offers readers easy ways to send the book to their friends, and it keeps a running total of such referrals, currently more than 80 per cent. He describes this with typical unabashed corporate cheesiness as 'word of mouse'.

The idea of 'viral marketing' is not a new one, of course: the term itself was coined by Steve Jurvetson, a venture capitalist who invested in the free e-mail service Hotmail, and who used it to describe the fact that every single email you sent using its service also spread the word about Hotmail itself: 'Get your private, free email from Hotmail at www.hotmail.com' read a line at the foot of your message (both alerting your friends to the availability of this product, and enhancing your status as someone at the sharp end).

Godin has extended this souped-up notion of consumer chatter into a manifesto. Point one of this document for our times reads: 'We used to focus on making food. We used to make stuff. Now we make ideas.' (Godin himself is a case in point. His father runs a company making hospital beds; he flogs slogans to CEOs.) Like a latter-day prophet, he sees parables of this vision wherever he looks: a book shop thus becomes 'the home of ideaviruses waiting to happen'; the stock market 'is nothing but thousands of possible ideaviruses'; and religion is the most pernicious ideavirus of all. (Godin cites the Hare Krishna habit of inviting potential converts to share a meal with them as classic viral marketing and points to the Shakers as the only known cult which made no effort to convert new members by word of mouth: 'And how many Shakers are there now?')

One of the preconditions of this new marketplace is the slow death of conventional - what Godin calls 'interruption' - advertising. 'It is no longer possible,' he contends, 'to buy yourself a share of the market with a big TV ad budget.' You can see, he suggests, the acceptance of this fact in the way that ads are sprouting up on the floors of the supermarket, in the centre circles of football pitches and even in urinals. Billboards are no longer guaranteed to hold our attention; there are too many new things competing for it.

In the absence of us listening to corporations telling us what to buy, Godin argues we will increasingly take our leads from a global community of opinion formers. He points to the fact that Amazon now not only ranks and grades its reviews, but also its reviewers (the most trusted, currently, is a woman named Harriet Klausener, a retired librarian from New York, who arguably does as much to influence the book market as any number of author tours or book shop dump-bins). He argues, too, that a website like Epinions.com, where there are millions of consumer reviews of everything from washing machines to dildos, is the shape of the future.

The success of a film like The Blair Witch Project is of, course, a powerful argument for Godin's prophecy; so too is the £5 handmade parody George Lucas in Love which is currently outselling the new Star Wars movie on video at Amazon. How is this possible? 'Because the parody is an ideavirus. And because the medium of the net is the perfect place for the word to spread,' Godin says.

Word of mouth has, of course, always been a key factor in the spread of trends, but Godin argues that what we are seeing now, and are about to see, is a huge acceleration of that power; partly this is due to the fact that we are more receptive than ever to 'newness'. 'It used to be that only a few stereotypical nerds cared about the latest pocket calculator,' he suggests. 'Today, you'll see people talking about their hand-held computer on the subway. It used to be that only a few people knew about the latest salsa hit out of Mexico or the coolest new chef in Los Angeles. Today, the roles are totally reversed. Your parents are nerds!'

The key people in this overdeveloped economy of nerds are - and, Godin has a lexicon of his own, of course - 'fashion editors': those who seem to have an innate sense for knowing when a 'hive' is ready to adopt a new virus. (Successful venture capitalists, journalists, chefs are all 'great fashion editors'). And once the 'hive' has that virus - be it the fact that is is 'cool' to have embroidery on your jeans, or tattoos on your shoulders, or to eat wraps instead of sandwiches, or have a palm-held computer instead of a Filofax - it is spread by 'sneezers'. Sneezers are people within the hive whose opinions we trust. High-profile examples might be Jamie Oliver or Delia Smith; Jeremy Paxman or Craig David. ('Oprah Winfrey is quite probably,' says Godin, 'the most successful sneezer of her generation.') But they might also be our friends, people we know or look up to and trust.

He describes this with typical unabashed corporate cheesiness as 'word of mouse'. The idea of 'viral marketing' is not a new one, of course: the term itself was coined by Steve Jurvetson, a venture capitalist who invested in the free e-mail service Hotmail, and who used it to describe the fact that every single email you sent using its service also spread the word about Hotmail itself: 'Get your private, free email from Hotmail at www.hotmail.com' read a line at the foot of your message (both alerting your friends to the availability of this product, and enhancing your status as someone at the sharp end). Now we make ideas.' (Godin himself is a case in point. His father runs a company making hospital beds; he flogs slogans to CEOs.) Like a latter-day prophet, he sees parables of this vision wherever he looks: a book shop thus becomes 'the home of ideaviruses waiting to happen'; the stock market 'is nothing but thousands of possible ideaviruses'; and religion is the most pernicious ideavirus of all. (Godin cites the Hare Krishna habit of inviting potential converts to share a meal with them as classic viral marketing and points to the Shakers as the only known cult which made no effort to convert new members by word of mouth: 'And how many Shakers are there now?') 'It is no longer possible,' he contends, 'to buy yourself a share of the market with a big TV ad budget.' fields.headline: Godard only knows...
fields.standfirst: For decades he was regarded as a genius and a revolutionary, but Jean-Luc Godard - 70 years old next week - has spent the last 20 years alienating everyone. Has he finally succeeded in biting off the hand that feeds him?
fields.trailText: For decades he was regarded as a genius and a revolutionary, but Jean-Luc Godard - 70 years old next week - has spent the last 20 years alienating everyone. Has he finally succeeded in biting off the hand that feeds him?
fields.body:
Forty years ago a group of young French film critics, collectively dubbed La Nouvelle Vague, exploded on to the moviemaking scene, sending a cultural tidal wave around the world. They were considered radicals, but in truth only one of them, Jean-Luc Godard, who will be 70 next week, can be seen in retrospect to have been truly revolutionary. The others were mostly renewing traditional cinema. In a 1968 essay Susan Sontag declared: 'Godard is not merely an iconoclast. He is a deliberate "destroyer" of cinema', and she compared his breaking of established rules through jump cuts, inconsistent points of view and confused story lines, with Schoenberg's dispensing with tonality and the Cubists rejecting conventional pictorial space. He was the most intellectual member of the New Wave, though not necessarily the most intelligent.

Godard was born in France of haute-bourgeois Swiss parents, his father a doctor, his mother the daughter of a wealthy banker. When the war broke out he was sent to live in Switzerland, and he returned to Paris in the late Forties to study ethnology at the Sorbonne. But he had been bitten by the movie bug, and along with his new friends - Claude Chabrol, François Truffaut, Eric Rohmer and Jacques Rivette - he devoted himself to watching movies and writing about them in a passionate, personal, complex manner for Cahiers du Cinéma and other magazines. When his family cut off his allowance for neglecting his studies, he supported himself by theft, and then took a job as a labourer on a Swiss dam, made a documentary on the project and sold it to the construction firm.

Following the success of Chabrol's Le Beau Serge (1958) and Truffaut's Les Quatre Cents Coups (1959), Godard's friends generously drew him into feature-filmmaking with A Bout de Souffle (1960) which was based on an idea by Truffaut and credits Chabrol as artistic supervisor. With its B-feature crime plot, hand-held camerawork and natural lighting, references to Sam Fuller and Humphrey Bogart, quotations from Faulkner and Apollinaire, and an opening dedication to the Poverty Row studio Monogram Pictures, there had never been anything like it. It also had striking performances from the well-known Jean Seberg, whose career it revived, and the unknown Jean-Paul Belmondo, whom it made a star. Godard was to work consistently with major names over the next 30-odd years, but he never had another box-office hit.

In the early 1960s Godard was the world's most discussed, interviewed and quoted film-maker, and his appearance (the blue chin, the receding hair, the opaque dark glasses) became familiar the world over. Sayings of his entered the language, among them 'the cinema is the truth 24 times a second' and 'I agree that a film should have a beginning, a middle and an end but not necessarily in that order'. His second picture, The Little Soldier, dealt with the Algerian War and was temporarily banned, the first in a string of controversies. In eight years he made 14 films, most photographed by the great cameraman Raoul Coutard. Some early ones star his first wife, the attractive Danish actress Anna Karina; later ones featured his second wife Anne Wiamensky, the dull niece of François Mauriac. Deeply influenced by Brecht in the use of chapter headings and the 'alienation effect' by which you're kept aware that you're watching a movie, these pictures were a remarkable combination of intelligent invention and irritating childishness as they played games with established genres - science-fiction in Alphaville, the musical in Une Femme est Une Femme , the noir thriller in Made in America.

Only one film started out as a commercial proposition - Le Mépris (1963), which was financed by the American tycoon Joseph E. Levine, who wanted a sexy art-house picture starring Brigitte Bardot. Godard, who loved American films as much as he hated the industry that produced them, deliberately shot Bardot's nude scenes unerotically and sent up Levine as the ignorant Hollywood mogul played by Jack Palance.

Godard nearly got to make a feature in America when the authors of Bonnie and Clyde introduced him to their financial backers. They blanched when he said that shooting should start in three weeks and pointed out that the weather in Texas was unsuitable. 'I am speaking cinema and you are speaking meteorology,' he replied. What really made the producers back off was Godard's claim that 'we can make this film anywhere; we can make it in Tokyo'. Such was Godard's status at the time that the screenwriters, Robert Benton and David Newman, would have been happy to have him make it in Tokyo.

Gradually in the 1960s Godard's characters turned from nihilistic outsiders to committed revolutionaries and the films became more determinedly, if callowly, political. After Weekend (1967), which bears the final title 'Fin du cinéma', he withdrew into collective left-wing productions, but was still capable of attracting stars like Jane Fonda and Yves Montand.

He later moved to Switzerland, his base for the last 20 years. There he's experimented with video, produced a gnomic eight-hour history of cinema, and made a succession of tedious, often deliberately incomprehensible pictures like the ridiculous Lear (Godard had never read Shakespeare's play). The contract for Lear was drawn up on a paper napkin at Cannes with Cannon Films, but its star, Norman Mailer, walked off the set after two days' shooting, and Woody Allen, who's supposed to be the Fool, is seen for a few silent seconds in a cutting room. His only picture of the past 20 years to receive a moderately widespread distribution was his controversial reworking of the virgin birth, Hail Mary (1984), which provoked the wrath of the Vatican, launched the career of Juliette Binoche, and bored most viewers rigid.

If Truffaut's warm, humanistic films are about the death of people, Godard's cold, misanthropic movies are about the death of institutions, societies, civilisation. And there's something correspondingly chilly and despairing in the willed and wilful way he's deliberately cut himself off from colleagues and audiences through the obscurity and offensiveness of his movies and the callousness of his conduct. In Trevor Griffith's play The Party, the veteran Scottish Trotskyist Tagg tells a gathering of left-wing intellectuals in 1968: 'You enjoy biting the hand that feeds you, but you'll never bite it off'.

Starting with Joe Levine, Godard has been trying to do just that. He had a fight with a producer on stage at the NFT; in 1968 he made a documentary called British Sounds for London Weekend Television that couldn't be shown, not because of its revolutionary politics, but because of its gratuitous full-frontal nudity; he deliberately provoked an irreparable rift with Truffaut. In 1973 he wrote an insulting letter about La Nuit Américaine , attacking the film, accusing Truffaut of dishonesty, then asking Truffaut to co-produce and invest 10 million francs in his next film. He received a six-page reply that began: 'So you won't be obliged to read this unpleasant letter right to the end, I'm starting with the essential point: I will not co-produce your film.' Truffaut went on to list a succession of public and private offences, stating that 'you're nothing but a piece of shit on a pedestal'.

The latest recipient of the Godard treatment is an American admirer, filmmaker Richard Brody, who was commissioned by the New Yorker to interview him at his office by Lake Geneva. After the first session he arrived at Godard's office the next day to be met by a note pinned to the door saying that Godard could not go on because 'it was not a real discussion', and also flou (unfocused). That night, Godard and Anne-Marie Miéville, his companion and collaborator for much of the past 30 years, were dining at the hotel were Brody was staying. Godard, hardly looking at him, 'emitted a chilling bonsoir'. After accepting the American's thanks for the time he'd given him, Godard wished him bon voyage, while Miéville looked him over and said nothing.

 The National Film Theatre will be mounting a complete Godard retrospective next June and July, including an international conference on 21-24 June at Tate Modern. For details: www.forevergodard.com.

The wisdom of Godard

'There is no point in having sharp images when you have fuzzy ideas.'

'I don't think you should FEEL about a movie. You should feel about a woman. You can't kiss a movie.'

'Art attracts us only by what it reveals of our most secret self.'

'All you need for a movie is a gun and a girl.'

The director's director

Directors on whom Godard has had a major influence include: Robert Altman, Martin Scorsese, Jim Jarmusch and Quentin Tarantino. 'Tarantino named his production company [A Band Apart] after one of my films. He'd have done better to give me some money,' said Godard.

'Godard is a constant source of inspiration. Before I do anything, I go back and look at as many of his films as I can, as a reminder of what's possible.' Steven Soderbergh

'For me, discovering cinema was directly connected to his films. I was living in Paris at the time. When Made in USA opened, I went to the first show - it was around noon - and I sat there until midnight. I saw it six times in a row.' Wim Wenders

'Godard is like an elite. It's not cinema anymore. It's Godard.' Jean-Jacques Beneix

Three highs

A Bout de Souffle (1960)

The defining example of New Wave cinema which cemented his reputation and revived Jean Seberg's career. It was also his sole major box-office hit.

Pierrot le Fou (1965)

A complex, riveting tale of two runaways - Jean-Paul Belmondo and Anne Karina - in the south of France. Reputedly shot without a script.

Vivre sa Vie (1962)

A portrait of a prostitute (Anna Karina) recounted in 12 chapters. An insightful look at the relationship between the sexes.

Three lows

Sympathy for the Devil (1968)

Confusing rockumentary about the Rolling Stones. It contained some revealing footage of the band but Godard unwisely concentrated on distilling the revolutionary spirit of the era.

Hail Mary (1985)

Controversial update with Juliette Binoche of the nativity story. Mary is a petrol-station attendant and Joseph her cabdriver boyfriend. Condemned by the Pope and the critics.

King Lear (1987)

Godard didn't read the play before embarking on this experimental film based on the great tragedy.

His only picture of the past 20 years to receive a moderately widespread distribution was his controversial reworking of the virgin birth, Hail Mary (1984), which provoked the wrath of the Vatican, launched the career of Juliette Binoche, and bored most viewers rigid. If Truffaut's warm, humanistic films are about the death of people, Godard's cold, misanthropic movies are about the death of institutions, societies, civilisation. And there's something correspondingly chilly and despairing in the willed and wilful way he's deliberately cut himself off from colleagues and audiences through the obscurity and offensiveness of his movies and the callousness of his conduct. In Trevor Griffith's play The Party, the veteran Scottish Trotskyist Tagg tells a gathering of left-wing intellectuals in 1968: 'You enjoy biting the hand that feeds you, but you'll never bite it off'. Starting with Joe Levine, Godard has been trying to do just that. He had a fight with a producer on stage at the NFT; in 1968 he made a documentary called British Sounds for London Weekend Television that couldn't be shown, not because of its revolutionary politics, but because of its gratuitous full-frontal nudity; he deliberately provoked an irreparable rift with Truffaut. In 1973 he wrote an insulting letter about La Nuit Américaine , attacking the film, accusing Truffaut of dishonesty, then asking Truffaut to co-produce and invest 10 million francs in his next film. He received a six-page reply that began: 'So you won't be obliged to read this unpleasant letter right to the end, I'm starting with the essential point: I will not co-produce your film.' Truffaut went on to list a succession of public and private offences, stating that 'you're nothing but a piece of shit on a pedestal'. The latest recipient of the Godard treatment is an American admirer, filmmaker Richard Brody, who was commissioned by the New Yorker to interview him at his office by Lake Geneva. After the first session he arrived at Godard's office the next day to be met by a note pinned to the door saying that Godard could not go on because 'it was not a real discussion', and also flou (unfocused). That night, Godard and Anne-Marie Miéville, his companion and collaborator for much of the past 30 years, were dining at the hotel were Brody was staying. Godard, hardly looking at him, 'emitted a chilling bonsoir'. After accepting the American's thanks for the time he'd given him, Godard wished him bon voyage, while Miéville looked him over and said nothing.  The National Film Theatre will be mounting a complete Godard retrospective next June and July, including an international conference on 21-24 June at Tate Modern. For details: www.forevergodard.com. The wisdom of Godard 'There is no point in having sharp images when you have fuzzy ideas.' 'I don't think you should FEEL about a movie. You should feel about a woman. You can't kiss a movie.' 'Art attracts us only by what it reveals of our most secret self.' 'All you need for a movie is a gun and a girl.' The director's director Directors on whom Godard has had a major influence include: Robert Altman, Martin Scorsese, Jim Jarmusch and Quentin Tarantino. 'Tarantino named his production company [A Band Apart] after one of my films. He'd have done better to give me some money,' said Godard. 'Godard is a constant source of inspiration. Before I do anything, I go back and look at as many of his films as I can, as a reminder of what's possible.' Steven Soderbergh 'For me, discovering cinema was directly connected to his films. I was living in Paris at the time. When Made in USA opened, I went to the first show - it was around noon - and I sat there until midnight. I saw it six times in a row.' Wim Wenders 'Godard is like an elite. It's not cinema anymore. It's Godard.' Jean-Jacques Beneix Three highs A Bout de Souffle (1960) The defining example of New Wave cinema which cemented his reputation and revived Jean Seberg's career. It was also his sole major box-office hit. Pierrot le Fou (1965) A complex, riveting tale of two runaways - Jean-Paul Belmondo and Anne Karina - in the south of France. Reputedly shot without a script. Vivre sa Vie (1962) A portrait of a prostitute (Anna Karina) recounted in 12 chapters. An insightful look at the relationship between the sexes. Three lows Sympathy for the Devil (1968) Confusing rockumentary about the Rolling Stones. It contained some revealing footage of the band but Godard unwisely concentrated on distilling the revolutionary spirit of the era. Hail Mary (1985) Controversial update with Juliette Binoche of the nativity story. Mary is a petrol-station attendant and Joseph her cabdriver boyfriend. Condemned by the Pope and the critics. King Lear (1987) Godard didn't read the play before embarking on this experimental film based on the great tragedy.

fields.headline: Make a killing by bucking the trend
fields.standfirst: Look at the fund manager as well as performance, says David Smith
fields.trailText: Look at the fund manager as well as performance, says David Smith.
fields.body:
The Financial Services Authority is eager to warn the UK's potential fund investors not to rely on past performance data, as strong performance tends not to be repeated. But perhaps one reason for this is that so often the manager responsible for a fund's previous strength has moved on to pastures new and it is the manager, not the fund, investors should focus on.

The best performers tend to be experienced, independent-minded individuals who are willing to put their necks on the line to back their judgments. Here we focus on three managers of UK growth investment trusts who fit this description.

Max King

Capital Opportunities

A Cambridge graduate and a qualified chartered accountant, Malcolm 'Max' King built an enviable reputation managing a range of investment trusts at Finsbury Asset Management before he decamped to JO Hambro in early 1997.

King is known for his idiosyncratic style, based on a 'top-down' approach - driven by a view of the world's macroeconomic picture - rather than investigating individual companies. His style is flexible and he describes Capital Opportunities as a 'go-anywhere fund', although it only invests in UK equities (and some unquoted companies).

King is a 'contrarian' investor - he stands against the tide and invests in areas or stocks other fund managers see as uninteresting. The aim is to buy when they are out of favour and reap rewards as 'the herd' wakes up to the opportunities.

King bought heavily into oil stocks such as Shell at the start of the year in anticipation of a significant rise in oil prices. At the time the market's emphasis was on technology-related companies, into which King had previously invested a significant part of his portfolio. King likes to buy 'growth companies with a hiccup'.

His trust is geared but tends to be a relatively 'flat fund' - no individual holding accounts for more than 3 per cent. He has recently added to his holding in Baillie Gifford Japan investment trust, believing that Japan is set for 'a second burst of energy'.

Colin McLean

Undervalued Assets

McLean established Templeton Investment Management's European fund management business and his reputation with it. He is seen as a tough Scot with a great ability to identify the 'true' value of companies regardless of the prevailing stockmarket opinion.

Although regarded as a 'value investor' - one who seeks to buy companies' shares for significantly less than their intrinsic value - he is not wedded to common concepts of value, such as lower than average price/earnings ratios.

McLean says: 'It is a mistake to look at published factors on companies like p/e ratios, investors can easily fall into a value trap.'

McLean seeks to decide whether a company operates a good business and whether he can buy into it cheaply because it is overlooked by the stock market. The aim is to estimate a company's 'fundamental value' from its long-term earnings power. His portfolio is geared and concentrated but McLean argues true risk reduction comes from intensive research rather than simple diversification.

James Barstow

Aurora

Barstow is another Cambridge-educated chartered accountant who favours a top-down approach. He built his reputation as a UK equities fund manager at River & Mercantile and AIB Govett.

Barstow maintains a tight list of stocks - a maximum of 45 individual companies. If he does not like a particular stock or even industrial sector he will not buy it. His fund is typically geared by about 15 per cent.

Barstow agrees p/e ratios can lead to 'horrible mistakes' - a company may look cheap but its revenues could be falling and foreign competition rising, which will only show up on a wider view. The aim is to 'think through the consequences further than anyone else'.

Barstow is especially optimistic about housebuilders and Irish domestic stocks, although his fund retains a large weighting in technology-related stocks, where he expects a sharp rebound.

 David Smith is investment funds editor for www.citywire.co.uk.

webTitle: Underworld finds a new home in Essex

fields.headline: Underworld finds a new home in Essex
fields.trailText: Half the country's top criminals have moved out of London, the underworld's traditional heartland, and are now living in Essex, a major investigation into organised crime in Britain has revealed.
fields.body:
Half the country's top criminals have moved out of London, the underworld's traditional heartland, and are now living in Essex, a major investigation into organised crime in Britain has revealed.

In the past 15 years, hundreds of successful armed robbers, drug dealers, fraudsters and contract killers have migrated out of the capital and into the county, where they are able to live more comfortably on the fruits of their illicit labour. The remaining 50 per cent of criminals are believed to be dealing directly with the Essex contingent.

The investigation, to be aired as a three-part series for the BBC's Breakfast News next week, will reveal that Essex has become a virtual battleground as successful villains from London increasingly come into conflict with the locals.

Since the beginning of the year, there have been four execution-style murders in Essex. In one, a father of two was shot on his doorstep in full view of his family in Grays. In August two bouncers were shot after wading into a brawl outside a popular Essex nightclub. A man opened fire with a handgun after the pair tried to halt a punch-up involving 30 people in the car park. Moments earlier, a large group had been thrown out of the Epping Forest Country Club in Chigwell for fighting.

In the most recent incident earlier this month, Kenneth Kenny, a notorious villain, was shot three times in a hospital car park in Romford. Police are still hunting his killer, but believe he may have been killed as part of a continuing drug feud.

Essex also has the perfect geographical position for successful criminals. Amphetamines and Ecstasy from Amsterdam and Belgium can be smuggled by speedboat on to miles of unguarded costline and the area has easy connections with the East End to facilitate visits back to old stamping grounds.

'These people have done well out of crime and they are keen to show it,' says Parkinson. 'They generally live in large houses with lots of land, drive flashy cars and are always seen at the top nightclubs and venues.'

One estate agent, who asked to remain anonymous, told how his business was flourishing by selling large, high-value homes to former East Enders who had come into large sums of money. A significant proportion of those buying houses in the £2 million and above bracket were buying with cash. Asked if he ever questions his clients about the source of their money, he said it would be more than his life was worth to do so.

Although top villains in Essex live a glamorous lifestyle, often rubbing shoulders with celebrities, they feel most comfortable engaging in more traditional activities. A spokesman for the National Criminal Intelligence Service said: 'You can take the boy out of the East End, but you can't take the East End out of the boy. Even when they move out to Essex, they still want to attend boxing matches and go to dog racing. There is a huge social network that has sprung up to cater for these people and allow them to continue with many of the activities they were involved in back in London.'

Peter Pomfrey, owner of the Epping Forest Country Club, where two bouncers and one customer have been shot in the past year, said there had been problems in the past but the club was now 'rocking'.

He refused to speculate about whether his venue attracted a large number of the area's criminals.

webTitle: New Deal to scour streets and set homeless to work

fields.headline: New Deal to scour streets and set homeless to work
fields.standfirst: Hardcore underclass will be targeted in purge on welfare claimants
fields.trailText: Drug addicts and the homeless will be rounded up by benefits advisers for the most radical expansion yet of Labour's programme to drive welfare claimants into work.
fields.body:
Drug addicts and the homeless will be rounded up by benefits advisers for the most radical expansion yet of Labour's programme to drive welfare claimants into work.

Hostel places for rough sleepers could even be made conditional on joining job-preparation schemes, under plans being considered for Labour's second term.

But the proposal to target homeless people living in hostels was last night condemned by Louise Casey, the Government's homelessness tsar. 'You have to get people away from drugs and their problems before trying to get them to work. Forcing them on to the New Deal will not necessarily achieve this.'

New Deal personal advisers would be sent to shelters and on to the streets to find rough sleepers, alcoholics and others currently overlooked by the flagship welfare-to-work programme, in an effort to reach the hard core of Britain's underclass.

Initially, they would be offered benefits and help with housing, medical problems or illiteracy on voluntary grounds, before entering the New Deal proper.

'What we need to look at for this group is something like a pre-New Deal programme to address their needs, in order that they can get enough of their lives sorted to start even thinking about work,' said a senior source. It will be about personal advisers going out to people, rather than waiting for people to come to them.

'People who might be on incapacity benefit because of problems, or on no benefit at all, don't qualify for the New Deal, and that is another issue we have got to face.'

Tony Blair will this week announce that the election pledge to get 250,000 unemployed young people into work has officially been met.

Meanwhile, Social Security Secretary Alistair Darling will trumpet savings of £8 billion on unemployment benefits, thanks to the New Deal and fraud crackdowns.

But amid criticism that the Government has only skimmed off the 'easier' cases of relatively employable young people, Ministers are looking for ways to crack problems at the bottom of the pile. Benefits advisers are already due to be sent into GPs' surgeries to target those on long-term sick leave. And in future Ministers want personal advisers to find other hard-to-reach cases. The New Deal currently identifies those claiming jobseekers' allowance, but the chaotic lives of the most marginalised groups means they may not even be able to claim and so fall through the net.

A report from Labour's influential Social Exclusion Unit argues that, once a New Deal for the homeless is established, Ministers could eventually make hostel places dependent on participation.

Six ground-breaking pilot projects were set up in London last month offering help with housing, addiction treatment and careers advice to homeless people. They then pass on to the full New Deal, with options for the 18-24 age group of a job, training, voluntary work or benefit sanctions if they won't co-operate.

The first phase will target people attending job centres, but in future it is likely to use volunteer outreach workers to find rough sleepers. If the pilots work, they are expected to be extended nationally.

The charity Shelter gave a warning last night that, while it welcomed attempts to get the homeless back on their feet, compulsion would backfire. 'Our view is that compulsion can be counter-productive. We would want New Deal advisers to work in such a way that actually supports people and encourages them,' said a spokeswoman.

'Just saying to people "well, here's a job" will not necessarily be helpful.'

Research from the United States shows that its welfare-to-work schemes miss a hard core of about 10 per cent of their target audience - including lone parents who refuse to buckle under US benefit sanctions, drug addicts and rough sleepers.

But programmes teaching the so-called 'four Rs' - not just reading, writing and arithmetic, but 'readiness for work' skills like communication or punctuality - before entering work have had some success in the US, offering a model for the UK.

The standard New Deal will also emphasise 'work-readiness' skills to help candidates get better jobs with promotion prospects.

A key theme for Labour's next term will be not just getting people into work regardless, but creating 'good' jobs where employees are trained and treated well.

webTitle: Larynx switch lets the dead speak

fields.headline: Larynx switch lets the dead speak
fields.trailText: A living person is to be given a voice from the dead. Doctors in Bristol are planning to become the first to perform a fully functioning voice box transplant.
fields.body:
A living person is to be given a voice from the dead. Doctors in Bristol are planning to become the first to perform a fully functioning voice box transplant.

The revolutionary larynx switch will for the first time transplant personal characteristics that identify an individual.

The operation will help thousands of people whose voice boxes have stopped working as a result of cancer or injury. At present the only option is to undergo an operation little changed since it was introduced in 1850, where the whole larynx is removed, leaving patients to breathe through a hole in the neck. It has a severe impact on quality of life, leaving them unable to speak, laugh, cry, sniff, cough, smell, taste or kiss.

The Wellcome Trust paid £1.2 million last week to set up a team at the University of Bristol and Southmead Hospital to establish a method of perfecting the voice box transplant and make it a standard surgical procedure. They will study how to reduce the rejection of the transplanted voice box by the host body and stimulate the repair of the nerves so that the vocal chords work normally.

The only previous laryngeal transplant was done by the Cleveland Clinic in the United States in 1998 but it only proved partially successful because the nerves were not reconnected. The patient got some speech back, but the voice box was not fully functional and he had to carry on breathing through an air pipe in his neck.

The laryngeal transplant would be one of the few aimed at improving the quality of life. Most transplants, such as liver, kidney or heart, are aimed at extending life, unlike corneal transplants and the recently pioneered hand transplants.

The voice box transplant is unique in that it would involve transplanting from one individual to another an identifying characteristic. Corneal transplants do not change the colour of the eye.

After the operation the vocal chords would take several months to start working again, but when the patient spoke he or she would have the same voice as the deceased in terms of pitch and quality.

The team believes that to avoid any ethical concerns, they would have to make sure the lives of the relatives of the donor and the recipient did not overlap. 'It could cause the donor's loved one considerable distress if they heard their voice coming out of someone else,' said Martin Birchall, reader in head and neck surgery at Bristol University, who is leading the team.

Vocabulary and accent are governed by the brain, not the vocal chords, and would remain unchanged but if the donor and recipient came from the same class and geographical region they would sound almost identical.

webTitle: Body in pool victim's family press for fresh police action

fields.headline: Body in pool victim's family press for fresh police action
fields.standfirst: Diane Emerson-Hawley's husband was cleared of conspiring to kill her. Now relatives want his shady businesses investigated
fields.trailText: Diane Emerson-Hawley's husband was cleared of conspiring to kill her. Now relatives want his shady businesses investigated
fields.body:
Relatives of a woman brutally murdered in her own home have hit out at police for failing to bring new charges against her husband, a self-confessed fraudster, after he was controversially acquitted of any involvement in her death.

They are planning to release new evidence about his alleged shady business dealings in an attempt to see him brought to account.

Diane Emerson-Hawley, 36, a beautician, was found floating in the swimming pool of her palatial home in Uffington, Lincolnshire, in October 1999. She had been beaten with a fence post then pushed into the pool by a debt-ridden former nightclub bouncer Darren Lake, 31.

He admitted murder, but claimed he had been acting on the instruction of her husband, Colin Harrold, and had been offered £20,000 to carry out the killing. Harrold was charged, but acquitted.

After the jury returned its verdict, the judge, Mr Justice Morland, cast doubt on the verdict by saying that Lake's testimony about the murder plot was in his view 'essentially truthful'.

In an exclusive interview with The Observer from his home in Scunthorpe, Emerson-Hawley's younger brother, Darren Hawley, said: 'My sister was such a kind and caring person and anyone who met her immediately warmed to her. After she died, I spoke to Colin Harrold on the phone and we couldn't have a conversation without one or other of us breaking down and crying.

'It has been devastating, I couldn't deal with it all. I even had people coming up and shoving microphones in my face at the funeral. I feel more amenable now with the passage of time - anyone would.'

Hawley revealed that he had been made aware of Harrold's illegal businesses long before his sister's death.'We have some evidence, but the only people who could substantiate it all are he and she but she is dead.'

Hawley is engaged to Sophie Mason, and her father Sir John, is a leading solicitor. He has revealed that the family has been frustrated by the lack of police action. Detectives have been examining the possibility of taking action in relation to a number of illegal business practices, importation of pornography, tax evasion and fraud but have so far done nothing.

'From the admissions he [Harrold] made in court, I would have thought there was more than enough evidence to bring charges,' said Mason. 'I cannot believe it has not been done.'

Darren Lake had been best man at Harrold's first wedding, but had since fallen on hard times and had become reliant on carrying out unskilled work for Harrold. When police raided his house, they found a letter to his father, supposedly written before the murder, which was to be opened only in the event of his suspicious death. The letter, which was read out in court, said: 'Colin Harrold has probably either paid for my hit or killed me himself... Colin Harrold has known that I have huge debts and has offered me £20,000 to kill Diane in the pool, plus the cat. He will be in London and Amsterdam perfect alibi. I will come over and get her by the pool and hit her on the head and dump her in the pool to drown. After that I will put the cat in a basket to stop me getting scratched and drown the cat, making it look like Diane went to find the cat and hit her head as she stumbled by the pool and fell under the cover and drowned. This frees him to have a playboy life, to see Tania and others...'

Emerson-Hawley had enjoyed a lavish lifestyle during her two-year marriage to Harrold but he had grown bored. His ex-wife, Annette, testified during the trial that a few weeks before Diane died, he had told her he had fallen in love with someone else. Told that a divorce would cost him dearly he allegedly said: 'I'm doing something about it now. Money is changing hands as we speak.'

The prosecution alleged that he believed he would not be able to get away with a cheap divorce because Diane knew too much about his shady business dealings.

Harrold would buy thousands of end-of-line books from publishers for a few pence a title, claiming they were to be shredded. In fact, he would sell them on to shops at home and abroad, making massive tax-free profits. Harrold admitted bribing officials at two book companies in return for turning a blind eye to his business practices.

'People were looked after,' he said. 'It was a win-win-win situation all the way down the line.' Police estimated he pocketed at least £100,000 of undeclared income each year. He has since come to an agreement with the Inland Revenue. At the time of his wife's death he was setting up a business to import illegal hardcore sex magazines.

The new woman in his life was fitness instructor Tania McCarter. In September, a few weeks before his wife was murdered, Harrold spent the day at a health farm with McCarter. He had booked her in as Mrs Harrold.

On the day of the murder, Harrold left for a business trip to Amsterdam with an associate. During his time there he slept with at least two prostitutes.

Earlier this month, Harrold made an appearance on his local radio station to assure people that they should not be scared of him. 'It's important that people are aware of what I am about so people are not worried if they pass me in the street.' During an hour-long interview with Hereward FM in Peterborough, he spoke of the shock of being arrested and finding himself in prison awaiting trial.

'I was inside for 10 months with no company as such. All I could think about was what had happened to Diane, why it had happened to Diane and what I could have done to prevent it. My grief was probably more than any normal person would be because I had no one there to help take that pain away, take that loneliness away, so my grief was day and night all the time I was in there. And it doesn't stop when you get out because Diane is not walking in at 6pm. For someone to say this guy doesn't care about Diane, his wife, is just crazy.' Yet Harrold had been having a passionate affair with McCarter all this time. During the murder trial, McCarter told the court their relationship had ended, but soon after Harrold was cleared, the couple were spotted near her home in Peterborough. And on the anniversary of Diane's death, the couple were pictured on a beach in Israel. According to Darren Hawley, Harrold has also destroyed or dumped many of Diane's photographs and irreplaceable personal possessions.

Harrold continues to live at the house where Diane was murdered. 'I'm Peterborough born and bred. I did my schooling in Peterborough, I've worked hard to build up businesses around Peterborough. I've got absolutely nothing to hide. Why should I leave the area where my family live? I have done absolutely nothing wrong and Diane would be the first to want me to walk straight and proud.'

After hearing of the interview Darren Hawley said: 'What he is saying is very interesting. I used to believe that Colin Harrold was a nice person, but I don't think he is fooling anybody any more'

webTitle: Army shells out £20m as its medics get it wrong

fields.headline: Army shells out £20m as its medics get it wrong
fields.trailText: Soldiers are being maimed and killed because of medical blunders by Army doctors,  The Observer can reveal. The scale of the problem has led to record compensation payouts.
fields.body:
Soldiers are being maimed and killed because of medical blunders by Army doctors, The Observer can reveal. The scale of the problem has led to record compensation payouts.

Since 1998 the Ministry of Defence has paid out more than £20 million to 191 members of the armed forces, more than £11,500 a year for each doctor employed in the Defence Medical Services.

The total compensation has trebled since 1997 and is now six times higher than in the National Health Service, which last year paid out less than £2,000 per doctor.

For £20m the MoD could have refurbished all the homes on a military base, upgraded 50,000 of its rifles or bought 10 Challenger battle tanks.

Legal experts believe the rapidly dwindling number of medical specialists in the armed forces is one reason for the soaring number of medical blunders, with late and wrong diagnosis a major problem. The Defence Medical Services are losing more than 700 trained doctors, nurses and specialists a year.

Two years ago, father-of-three Stephen Stewart died after developing skin cancer during a tour of duty in Belize with the former Queen's Own Highlanders Regiment.

After suffering from severe sunburn, a mole on his neck began to bleed. An Army doctor confirmed the growth was malignant and it was surgically removed. Stewart was then given the all-clear, but after leaving the Army in 1997 he began to have pains in his neck, suffered a dramatic weight loss and began vomiting regularly.

Doctors confirmed the cancer had returned and told him he had less than a year to live. His widow, Paula Stewart, is suing the MoD, claiming her husband was not given radiotherapy treatment after the cancer first appeared. Lawyers say that this amounted to a crucial lapse in care that would have prevented his premature death.

Lesley Herbertson, head of clinical negligence at law firm Alexander Harris, claims that there is anecdotal evidence of soldiers being made to feel 'weak' if they complain of health problems.

Herbertson has recently acted for a young soldier who had been complaining of chest problems that made it difficult for him to breathe. His medical unit dismissed his complaints and did not take a chest X-ray. Days later he collapsed and was rushed to hospital, where he was diagnosed with pneumonia and required a major operation to save his life. The soldier was left with massive scars around his body and the MoD had to pay out £20,000 in compensation.

In another case, a soldier collapsed into a coma and was left with brain damage after being forced to go on a long run despite complaining of breathing difficulties. It turned out he had pleurisy.

Families of soldiers are also having problems. Last July a Wiltshire family won more than £2m in damages from the MoD after Army doctors in Aldershot failed to carry out a prompt Caesarean birth. The baby was left with cerebral palsy and cannot speak.

Menzies Campbell, the Liberal Democrat spokesman on defence, said: 'Those joining the armed services are entitled to expect the best when it comes to medical treatment. Without a proper standard of care, units could easily be left well short of their full complement, adding to the burdens of overstretch.

'The Defence Medical Services are still paying a heavy price for the cack-handed reforms introduced under the last Conservative Government. But it is time the present administration put things right.'

Earlier this year Admiral Sir John Brigstocke sparked a political row by writing of his concern about the 'parlous state' of the forces' medical service, complaining that the budget for the Surgeon-General's Department, which treats service personnel, had been cut by £1.5m.

In February, the Armed Forces Pay Review Body described manning levels as 'critically low, particularly in the numbers of deployable medical officers'. Since the end of the Cold War in 1989, Britain's armed forces had been cut by a third, but the manpower strength of the Defence Medical Services had fallen by more than half.

Last year the Commons Defence Select Committee reported a 30 per cent staff shortfall, with only 50 per cent of the necessary doctors and 75 per cent of the nurses.

webTitle: Son of HAL to hit high street

fields.headline: Son of HAL to hit high street
fields.standfirst: Computer based on 2001 film to be mass marketed
fields.trailText: It could think for itself, lip-read, scheme and murder. Now HAL-9000, the infamous computer in  2001: A Space Odyssey which turned on its operators and tried to kill them, is being brought back to life by its creator.
fields.body:
It could think for itself, lip-read, scheme and murder. Now HAL-9000, the infamous computer in 2001: A Space Odyssey which turned on its operators and tried to kill them, is being brought back to life by its creator.

Sir Arthur C Clarke, the author of 2001, is backing a colourful British computer entrepreneur in his bid to launch a mass-market version of HAL under the brand name the Clarke Omniputer. It will be the first time that Clarke, now 82, has given his name to an electronic device on the market.

The Clarke 1 Gigahertz Omniputer is being dubbed as the most advanced personal computer in the world, verging on artificial intelligence.

'For the first time, it gives high-quality architecture at low cost, opening the door to handling speech recognition and lip-reading. It will start off addressing issues of consciousness,' said Joseph de Saram, the 28-year-old chief executive of Clarke Omniputers, the Luxembourg-based company behind the project. 'We're on the verge of going off into artificial intelligence. HAL is back.'

The Omniputer has 15 patents on the motherboard alone. It is operated by a touchscreen display, and so won't need a mouse. Clarke Omniputers say they already have 60,000 orders for the computer, manufactured in China, and hope to sell 350,000 in the first year alone. The price of the computer will be under £2,000.

In the film 2001, HAL was the onboard computer for the spaceship Discovery on a trip to Jupiter. It could hear and see almost everywhere on the ship and, in a famous scene, lip-read a conversation between crew members hiding in an escape pod.

HAL managed to lure his operator, Dave Bowman, into space and tried to lock him out. Bowman was eventually able to break back into the spaceship where he removed HAL's chips one by one. HAL begged for its life before being disarmed and turned off.

Like HAL, the Omniputer will, its backers claim, have an instinct to protect itself. 'If user errors start, and files get deleted, it will start to repair itself, just as cells repair themselves,' said De Saram. However, it is thought unlikely that it will try to kill its owner.

The Omniputer was originally going to be called HAL, but there was an objection from the estate of Stanley Kubrick, the director who co-wrote the screenplay of 2001 with Clarke. That obstacle was overcome, but the backers decided that the name sounded too like the word 'Hell' and that it wouldn't have much resonance with younger customers.

The launch of the Omniputer is planned for 1 January 2001, but suffered a setback last week when a British court ordered that De Saram's other company, Rhodium, which he set up in 1995, should be wound up because of £1 million debts.

De Saram, now living in Sri Lanka, was last year on the Sunday Times under-30 Rich List, living a millionaire's lifestyle with several homes and a Ferrari. He insists that he can easily pay the debts but that he relocated to Sri Lanka because his life in the UK was made intolerable by MI5 and the National Criminal Intelligence Service. He claims he was being harrassed because an advanced new encryption programme he devised would make it difficult for the security services to snoop on emails.

A statement from Clarke's office this weekend said that the launch of the Omniputer would be put on hold until the legal issues have been resolved.
