webTitle: Men of 60 to get bus passes

fields.headline: Men of 60 to get bus passes
fields.trailText: More than 1.5 million British men are likely to become eligible for free bus passes after a key court hearing this week.
fields.body:
More than 1.5 million British men are likely to become eligible for free bus passes after a key court hearing this week.

Lawyers for Liberty, the human rights pressure group, will tell the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg on Tuesday that age limits for the benefit - women receive a pass at 60, men at 65 - are discriminatory.

The campaigners, who have brought the case against the British Government, are confident of success.

'Our chances are pretty good. The current situation is totally unjust. Anybody can see that,' said David Lindsay, the legal adviser of campaign group Parity, which is lobbying for equal pension and other benefit provision for both sexes.

Lord Lester of Herne Hill, one of Britain's top human rights lawyers, is leading Liberty's legal team. The court is expected to make a decision before the end of the year under the European Convention on Human Rights. The Government would be bound to accept it.

Lindsay hopes he will then be able to force the Government to lower the age at which the old age pension starts for men too.

A second action to change the laws on bus passes, this time in a British court, has recently been granted legal aid. Lawyers at Lovells, a City law firm, are targeting Croydon Council in a test case.

The Government has had a series of defeats on such issues. At the Labour Party conference, members voted in favour of restoring the link between the basic state pension and earnings. And a year ago the Treasury was forced into an U-turn after the European Court of Justice ruled in favour of a retired postman who argued men were entitled to winter fuel payments at the same age as women.

The court agreed that John Taylor, 64, from Norton, North Yorkshire, had been the victim of unlawful sex discrimination, because women are entitled to the payment at 60.

The decision cost the Government, which already pays £200 million a year in winter fuel payments, an extra £235m - made up of £85m to men aged 60 and over, £125m in back payments to pensioners, and £25m in administration costs.

Julie Mellor, chairwoman of the Equal Opportunities Commission, said the ruling was a further step towards the dismantling of discrimination within the social security system.

webTitle: One woman in five is a shopaholic

fields.headline: One woman in five is a shopaholic
fields.standfirst: Easy credit and peer pressure push millions to buy beyond their means, causing spiral of depression
fields.trailText: Easy credit and peer pressure push millions to buy beyond their means, causing spiral of depression
fields.body:
Posh and Becks do it together. Liz Hurley does it alone and Madonna did it while nine months pregnant.

Retail therapy has become one of Britain's most pleasurable leisure pursuits. But the percentage of the population suffering from the serious medical condition of shopping addiction is reaching crisis point, overtaking the number of drug and drink addicts in the UK combined.

Experts believe 10 per cent of the population, and possibly 20 per cent of women, are manic, compulsive shoppers. Most shopaholics are seriously in debt, and the condition has led to family break-ups, depression, homelessness and even suicide.

Known as omniomania, the condition has been known to psychiatrists since the early 1900s but only now is it reaching epidemic proportions. A European Union report recently revealed that up to half of 14- to 18-year-old girls in Scotland, Italy and Spain exhibited symptoms of shopping addiction, with 8 per cent showing signs of a 'pathological compulsion'.

Jim Goudie, a consumer psychologist at Northumbria University, said the stigma of being a shopaholic, and the fact that so few people take the condition seriously, may be masking an even higher number of sufferers.

'Our figures would correlate to research done in the US showing a similar percentage of the population there suffering from shopping problems. But with some people feeling that being a shopping addict is so downright silly, the true statistics could be much higher.

'One of the reasons behind this sudden rise could be that shopping has never been so attractive. Shopping centres are beautiful these days, absolute wonderlands. Store cards are offered at the till and people can obtain handfuls of credit cards with relative ease.'

Five credit-card companies are in the process of taking Elizabeth, 31, a businesswoman from Leeds to court. While speaking to The Observer she opened her wardrobe to count 26 handbags and 72 pairs of shoes.

'I can't begin to count my clothes, that would take all day,' she said. 'I guess my real weakness is jewellery, though. I do have quite a lot although most of it is the cheaper stuff.'

Elizabeth has been offered Prozac by her GP in an attempt to counter her addiction, which he believes is sparked by low self-esteem. She has just sold her flat and paid off an overdraft of £4,700. But she is still shopping.

'It started when Harvey Nichols opened a shop in Leeds,' she said. 'Everyone in my office was forever rushing off and coming back with bags of lovely stuff but I was saving for a holiday and I felt really left out. I thought, "Stuff it", and went mad buying clothes for my holiday on my credit card. It was a fantastic rush, a great feeling. Then all of a sudden I was just buying stuff all the time. I don't even remember applying for all the cards, they just seemed to appear.'

Goudie believes shopping addiction masks deeper problems. 'Mostly there is underlying depression and anxiety. Often it can be a disturbed relationship with one's parents. Cold and unemotional parents often lavish presents on children and so they associated that with pleasure.

'Empowerment is also an increasing trend among young, professional women. I had one woman who bought 150 pairs of shoes, shopping gave her a buzz. They take the purchase home, feel guilty, then go back out and shop to combat the depression.'

Consumer debt is one of the most rapidly growing national problems in the UK. The National Association for Citizens' Advice Bureaux reported a 37 per cent increase in calls on the subject in just two years. Last year CAB advisers received half a million calls concerning shopping debts and a year-on-year rise is predicted for 2000.

'Our debt calls used to be from people who couldn't pay the gas bill, now its a multitude of consumer debts,' said an association spokeswoman.

The problem is now being taken seriously. At Stanford University in California 24 women are involved in a trial to see whether the condition can be treated by a specific anti-shopaholic drug, similar to an anti-depressant.

Next month the Government will assemble a task force to look at the problem of easy access to credit for those who cannot afford to repay what they are spending. Kim Howells, Minister for Consumer Affairs, said: 'The Government's aim is to protect the vulnerable without inhibiting a good, innovative market for the vast majority.'

Shopping addiction can reach astonishing levels among the rich - this month Sir Elton John admitted going on a £40 million shopping spree in less than two years.

Socialite Tara Palmer-Tomkinson is now attending Debtors Anonymous after admitting snapping up seven pairs of designer jeans at '£300 a pop'. 'Having spent thousands on clothes, I felt invulnerable,' she said. Comparing shopping to her former cocaine habit, she said: 'Spending £6,000 in Dolce & Gabbana was much more satisfying, strutting around the store, being told how drop-dead gorgeous I was.'

Adrienne Baker, a psychotherapist and author of Serious Shopping , said: 'Taking illegal substances in excess is one thing, to shop till you drop arouses only amusement.'

Baker became interested in omniomania after the suicide of a young friend. The girl died leaving 'a plethora of beautiful, unworn clothes' in her flat.

fields.headline: The cruel side of Kipling
fields.standfirst: England's best-loved poet drove his wife to a breakdown
fields.trailText: A new book could destroy the name of the nation's favourite poet by revealing that the writer popularly believed to be an affable, gentle, family man was a callous husband who drove his wife to a breakdown.
fields.body:
The reputation of Rudyard Kipling, a literary legend in Britain for 50 years, has survived generations of critics determined to write him off as a jingoistic Little Englander.

But a new book could destroy the name of the nation's favourite poet by revealing that the writer popularly believed to be an affable, gentle, family man was a callous husband who drove his wife to despair and abandoned her when she suffered a nervous breakdown.

Biographers and fans have long believed that Kipling was brutally oppressed and controlled by his American-born wife, Caroline (or Carrie) Balestier. But author Adam Nicolson, a Kipling enthusiast, believes that the poet, emotionally scarred by a traumatic childhood, destroyed his wife as she battled to cope with a marriage blighted by tragedy.

'Carrie has been totally denigrated by history as a harridan; she has been the despised woman,' said Nicolson. 'But by looking at their lives from her perspective, it's clear that there's another side to the story completely: Kipling was a very angry man with a great deal of cruelty in him.'

Nicolson believes history has overlooked the split between Kipling's public and private personas. 'Although Kipling was very good at being charming in public, he was not a good husband,' said Nicolson. 'His affable manner belied a great misanthropy, and it was Carrie who caught the damage of that.'

The book, The Hated Wife, is part of the first wave of titles from Short Books, a new imprint launching in May 2001 which will offer highbrow texts in novella-size formats. In it, Nicolson suggests Kipling married Carrie in a fit of desperation after the death of her brother, Wolcott, with whom he may have had an affair.

Carrie was certainly not an easy woman, combining an unsentimental, frontier spirit with pride and pugnacity. But Nicolson believes she was deeply in love with Kipling and devoted her life to him, desperately trying to deal with his neglect of her while shouldering the family and business responsibilities he off-loaded onto her. 'Carrie was the victim of Kipling's habitual recourse to absence and retreat,' said Nicolson. 'He was never there when she needed him and would disappear for weeks on end into the urban male world which adulated him.'

Kipling's family, to whom he was extremely close, hated Carrie on first sight and never changed their minds about her. But Kipling would go and stay with them for long periods of time, knowing that his wife would be forced to stay behind.

The relationship deteriorated further in 1899 after the death of their favourite child, six-year-old Josephine, from a fever sustained during a journey back to England after a visit to Carrie's family. There are suggestions that Kipling blamed his wife for the death of their daughter - she had insisted on a winter crossing - and he left her to grieve in isolation.

It was at this period that Carrie's diaries suggest she suffered a nervous breakdown; photographs taken some months afterwards show her thick, brown hair had turned white. 'These diary entries have been seen by Kipling's biographers as the self-pity of a hysteric,' said Nicolson. 'Perhaps they are something else: the outpourings of grief from a misunderstood and despised woman, whose husband perferred the company of his parents to his wife, and who, with her most treasured daughter now dead, found her one purpose - to serve the man of genius - unvalued.'

Neither parent recovered from their loss; their health deteriorated and their relationship ground grimly on in a household where Nicolson says 'brutality lurked as a kind of unacknowledged undercurrent'.

In 1915 the Kiplings were struck by a second disaster when their only son, John, was killed in France. Kipling now abandoned his wife almost entirely; nor was she of any interest to his visitors. 'She was an adjunct, an obstacle.'

Nicolson's claims have angered Kipling scholars. 'This is the work of someone who wants to create controversy for the sake of it,' said Sharad Keskar, honorary secretary of the Kipling Society and editor of The Kipling Journal. 'Carrie was a harridan and was very jealous of Kipling's fame. She ruled him with a rod of iron and he found that hard to tolerate.'

His criticism is echoed by Andrew Lycett, author of an acclaimed Kipling biography published last year. 'There is no evidence to support these claims,' he said. 'She was a hugely difficult woman and Kipling was supportive and sympathetic towards her. There won't be many people subscribing to these new arguments.'

webTitle: British blunder sets off virus scare in Belgium

fields.headline: British blunder sets off virus scare in Belgium
fields.trailText: A fatal blunder by one of Britain's largest makers of health care products has potentially infected tens of thousands of Europeans with lethal viruses,  The Observer  can reveal.
fields.body:
A fatal blunder by one of Britain's largest makers of health care products has potentially infected tens of thousands of Europeans with lethal viruses, The Observer can reveal.

Several deaths in Belgium are being blamed on mistakes made by Johnson & Johnson at its North Yorkshire factory, where it makes Cidex, a chemical used to sterilise surgical instruments in hospitals. A series of millennium bug-related errors and a collapse in safety systems led to the export of a large batch of Cidex that was completely ineffective. As a result, up to 80,000 people in Belgium and Holland were operated on earlier this year with contaminated instruments.

Cidex is used in hundreds of hospitals in the UK and across Europe to kill viruses such as hepatitis, HIV and tuberculosis, and to prevent dangerous infections being transmitted from patient to patient. In particular, it is used to disinfect surgical instruments too fragile to be heat-treated, such as fibre-optic probes and flexible equipment used in endoscopies, which allow doctors to investigate parts of the body without major invasive surgery. It is vital for this equipment to be completely clean because it is used on different patients. After washing the instruments, hospital staff soak them in Cidex.

In January, Johnson & Johnson exported more than 3,000 containers of Cidex that did not contain any of the vital ingredient, glutaraldehyde, which kills the viruses.

Phillippe Maughan, a British doctor living in Belgium who is a director of the European Union's humanitarian office, was running the EU's aid operation in West Africa when he returned to Belgium in March to have a nasal operation. He suffered from a serious post-operative infection which he believes was a result of contaminated surgical equipment.

Maughan is now one of the leading members of the Cidex Victims' Collective, which is taking legal action against Johnson & Johnson.

He said: 'What has happened is truly dreadful. Fortunately for me, I did not catch anything too serious, but thousands of people, many of them elderly, have been put at real risk.'

Last week it emerged that a number of Belgians had died as a result of post-operative infections and dozens of others were seriously ill. One 39-year-old man had died after becoming infected after a minor operation to adjust his pacemaker with instruments 'sterilised' using the inert Cidex. A Belgian woman also recently died after an infection took hold after a endoscopic examination of her throat using an instrument disinfected with faulty Cidex.

One woman who has now tested positive for hepatitis C - a disease which can lead to cirrhosis of the liver and cancer - is 34-year-old Séverine Laurenty. She went into hospital in March for a routine operation to remove material from her womb after a miscarriage. Four months later she received a letter from the hospital calling her for a blood test. On 25 July she tested positive for hepatitis C.

Laurenty said: 'I am very angry. I am convinced that my infection was caused by this unclean equipment, but no one will tell me anything.'

The problem emerged in March, when a Belgian hospital warned Johnson & Johnson that the Cidex it had received was inactive. Ten days later a second hospital reported the same problem. A month further on, the company asked 80 hospitals which received Cidex from the same batch to 'review the potential health risk for each patient who had undergone an intervention with instruments treated with Cidex'.

It has since become clear that the blunder occurred after Johnson & Johnson turned off production at its North Yorkshire factory for a week over the new year holiday as a precaution against the millennium bug.

When staff returned, a series of human and computer errors left the first batch effectively made up of water. Most worryingly, the company's quality control systems did not pick this up and cleared 3,300 five-litre bottles for shipment overseas.

Johnson & Johnson has paid for a large testing programme for affected patients. It will pay compensation claims for 'reasonable, necessary and demonstrable damage', but the Cidex Victims Collective fears it will be difficult to prove that illnesses have been a direct result of contaminated instruments.

fields.headline: Black runners 'have speed genes'
fields.standfirst: Study of Kenyan athletes reignites controversy over race and sporting prowess
fields.trailText: Study of Kenyan athletes reignites controversy over race and sporting prowess.
fields.body:
It has been dismissed as racist and divisive, but scientists are confronting the greatest taboo in sport: that black athletes are 'genetically programmed' to run faster and longer than white athletes.

In the most comprehensive study of the biological differences between African and European athletes, Scandinavian researchers compared runners in Kenya and Denmark. Their findings confirm what observers have long suspected: that many Africans have greater stamina and speed than Europeans.

The study, revealed this week in a Channel 4 documentary, will fuel the simmering row over biological advantage in the high-pressure world of track and field. Many black athletes - including some African Olympic champions - dismiss claims of genetic differences between African and European runners as a racist slur.

Danish sports scientists spent eighteen months in the Kenyan town of Eldoret, the capital of the north-western province where the Kalenjin tribe live. Twelve of the world's top 20 distance runners are Kalenjin and their seemingly effortless victories in 800-metre races and marathons have sparked a passionate debate about genetic advantage.

The scientists compared Kenyan athletes' style and physique with Danish runners. The African athletes' heart rates were remarkably slow, even when running at more than 15mph over long distances.

High altitude - the Kalenjin live on a plateau 7,000ft above sea level - increases the number of red blood cells which carry oxygen around the body and is thought to explain the low heart rate.

Experts, the programme says, went on to observe that the Africans had 'birdlike legs, very long levers which are very, very thin', that enabled them to 'bounce and skip' over the ground, taking off after each footfall far faster than the Europeans.

They 'flowed through the running motion' compared with the Danes, who 'landed heavily and sunk into the ground and almost had to pull themselves forward. They are "pullers", whereas the Kenyans are "bouncers".'

The researchers found that Kalenjin from a particular district - Nandi Hills - outperformed other Kenyans. To test whether Nandi Hills runners were 'born with talent', the scientists chose three groups of schoolboys at random - one from Denmark, one from the Nandi Hills and one from Eldoret - who had never had athletic training.

After three months of instruction, the groups competed against each other over 10,000 metres. The Nandi Hills group outperformed not only the Danish boys, but also the boys from Eldoret.

To confirm the findings were not a fluke, the scientists pitted two of the Nandi Hills boys against one of Denmark's top-ranked distance runners, Thomas Nolan. The schoolboys won.

After the race Nolan said: 'In the beginning they ran quite fast. It was a hot day. I had confidence. I thought, "Let them run. They don't know much about running because they have not done running before".'

But over twelve and a half laps the two novices maintained their lead. 'I could not catch them up - they were getting longer and longer away,' Nolan said. 'I think they were 50 or 60 metres ahead when we came to the finishing line.' One of the boys, David Kemboi, told the scientists: 'I was surprised I won because I didn't have that knowledge that I can run fast like a world champion.'

Bengt Saltin, of the Danish Sports Science Institute, which conducted the trials, claimed they show the Nandi Hills Kalenjin have a genetic advantage over other athletes. 'There are definitely some genes that are special here.' Mike Boit, Kenyan Commonwealth Games gold medallist in 1978, agreed. 'The genetic inheritance is there.'

Kenya's 1988 Olympic gold medallist Peter Rono added: 'It has to do with the tradition, the food, the environment and then, of course, the upbringing of someone because you know we are brought up in a different kind of environment.'

But the idea of genetic advantage is angrily dismissed by other Kenyan Olympic heroes, who insist it is racist. Kip Keino, Olympic gold medallist in 1968 and 1972, said: 'To me it's interest and hard work. There's nothing in this world unless you work hard to reach where you are and so I think running is mental, three-quarters of anything is mental.'

Hugh Montgomery, a cardiovascular geneticist at University College London, who has seen the Danish team's findings, denied that pinpointing genetic factors is racist. 'There is clearly an influence of race on performance, and that isn't to be racist; it's just saying that different races have different strengths.'

 'The Difference' is screened on Channel 4 at 8pm tonight.

'I could not catch them up - they were getting longer and longer away,' Nolan said. 'I think they were 50 or 60 metres ahead when we came to the finishing line.' One of the boys, David Kemboi, told the scientists: 'I was surprised I won because I didn't have that knowledge that I can run fast like a world champion.' Bengt Saltin, of the Danish Sports Science Institute, which conducted the trials, claimed they show the Nandi Hills Kalenjin have a genetic advantage over other athletes. 'There are definitely some genes that are special here.' Mike Boit, Kenyan Commonwealth Games gold medallist in 1978, agreed. 'The genetic inheritance is there.' Kenya's 1988 Olympic gold medallist Peter Rono added: 'It has to do with the tradition, the food, the environment and then, of course, the upbringing of someone because you know we are brought up in a different kind of environment.' But the idea of genetic advantage is angrily dismissed by other Kenyan Olympic heroes, who insist it is racist. Kip Keino, Olympic gold medallist in 1968 and 1972, said: 'To me it's interest and hard work. There's nothing in this world unless you work hard to reach where you are and so I think running is mental, three-quarters of anything is mental.' Hugh Montgomery, a cardiovascular geneticist at University College London, who has seen the Danish team's findings, denied that pinpointing genetic factors is racist. 'There is clearly an influence of race on performance, and that isn't to be racist; it's just saying that different races have different strengths.'  'The Difference' is screened on Channel 4 at 8pm tonight. john.arlidge@observer.co.uk

French investigators said the Breton Revolutionary Army was unlikely to be responsible for a parcel bomb which killed a council worker in La Baule. A deranged act of revenge was thought to be a more likely cause.

Strike grounds jets
The Portuguese state airline TAP cancelled dozens of flights as cabin crews began a 48-hour strike over pay. Many travellers faced long waits.

Lynch law
An angry mob in Lagos clubbed to death two robbers moments after they had killed a man, witnesses said.

Star gets kidnap demand
Kidnappers who seized the eight-year-old son of former Yugoslav tennis star Slobodan Zivojinovic in Belgrade are said to be demanding £770,000 ransom.

Diplomat faces trial
A Finnish man accused of killing a 70-year-old Timorese woman in a hit-and-run car incident faces trial in East Timor. The United Nations has waived his diplomatic immunity.

Disaster dead flown home
The bodies of eight American victims of the Austrian funicular railway fire two weeks ago, were flown home aboard a US military aircraft.

To the top
Tarkan Lohde, 12, slipped past German President Johannes Rau's bodyguards in Berlin and asked him the way to the toilet. Impressed by the boy's savoir faire, he gave him his autograph.

High on wine
Japanese people over 40 who drink moderate amounts of wine did better in IQ tests than teetotallers and heavy drinkers.

New heights
Okendra Singh, an agriculture graduate from north-east India, has entered the Guinness Book of World Records by growing a 60ft tall skyflower plant.

Season of ill will
Opponents of impeached Philippine President Joseph Estrada tried to send him a giant Christmas card urging him to resign, but the post office refused it.

webTitle: Poison water victims seek justice in Europe

fields.headline: Poison water victims seek justice in Europe
fields.standfirst: Camelford residents, after 12 years of being ignored, hope they will finally get an inquiry into their illnesses
fields.trailText: Camelford residents, after 12 years of being ignored, hope they will finally get an inquiry into their illnesses.
fields.body:
Sue Davy struggled to her feet and wobbled painfully as she walked to her car. She had only been sitting down for 30 minutes, but already her diseased muscles had tightened and made every step an agonising struggle.

Faced with a continued government refusal to hold a public inquiry into the country's worst ever mass poisoning, campaigners for victims such as Davy are poised to appeal to the European Parliament to get the justice they have failed to find in Britain.

It is now more than 12 years since 20,000 people in north Cornwall drank, bathed and showered in acid pouring from their taps after a lorry driver accidentally dumped 20 tonnes of aluminium sulphate into a reservoir. The contaminated water flowed into the town of Camelford and surrounding villages. It was so acidic it leached copper and lead from the pipes, making an even more poisonous concoction.

Davy's fondness for strong black coffee proved her undoing. It masked the acid taste and she drank it for two weeks while water officials insisted it was safe. The effects, however, have lasted a lifetime.

At the time, she suffered ulcers and rashes. Then she developed fibromyalgia, a condition that causes muscles to seize up and can lead to sufferers becoming wheelchair-bound. In common with many other victims, she complains of chronic fatigue and has deeply ridged fingernails, which could be a sign of premature ageing caused by the heavy metals she ingested.

Davy still works on her farm but finds making a living tough. 'I get bad days and feel I am not able to carry on. I get depressed and for two or three days I just can't move it hurts so much. But I don't want to end up in a wheelchair. I just have to be strong-minded,' she said.

She is one of the few brave enough to speak out. Camelford is a tightly knit place and many residents just want to forget, thinking it gives the area a bad name and will discourage tourists. Victims who go public are often accused of hysteria, hypochondria or seeking compensation.

'Most of the ones who suffer the worst effects are the ones who keep quiet and, of course, a lot of people have just moved away or died. I am just so angry at the way people have been treated,' said Jenny Thomson, a county councillor at the time of the disaster. Two of the most high-profile victim campaigners, Ivan and Doreen Skudder, recently died of cancer.

The story of Camelford is of 12 years of shocking abuse and passing the buck. After the initial disaster, South West Water took two weeks to warn residents. In the meantime, callers asking why their water burnt their lips were told to dilute it with orange juice to mask the taste. Other symptoms included mouth ulcers, rashes and skin burns. Resident Nigel Jones first knew something was wrong when a layer of skin fell off his back as he towelled himself after a shower. 'I then made some tea and the milk curdled in the cup,' he said.

The disaster happened a few months before the privatisation of the water industry. There was no room for such an embarrassment and calls for an inquiry were ignored. The water company was fined just £10,000. Under Conservative rule, calls for an inquiry and a proper medical investigation were dismissed. Following a visit to Camelford in June by the Labour Environment Minister Michael Meacher victims briefly thought they were at last being heard. Now those hopes are all but dead.

Instead Europe holds the key. The Southport-based Environmental Law Centre has prepared a petition to the European Parliament that if successful could lead to a Brussels-based inquiry within a year. Evidence in individual cases have been gathered from medical records. The centre's Dr K Badsha said: 'The Government no longer feels it has to do anything and so we have only one route left and that is the European Parliament. We have a very strong case.'

Such an inquiry could answer the victims' questions about the potential long-term effects of exposure to heavy metals. British health officials have never carried out a survey. Instead they say they are monitoring local death rates and have noticed nothing unusual. In 12 years, however, no data have been released to back that claim. The only independent research carried out showed that victims did suffer memory loss and brain damage.

A cloud of fear continues to hang over Camelford, particularly as evidence builds up showing Alzheimer's disease is linked to aluminium levels in the brain.

One young mother of three, who dared not give her name for fear of being ostracised by neighbours, was pregnant with her second child when the water was poisoned and believes it left him damaged.

At 11, he has the mental age of a seven-year-old. His life has been marked by illness. A private analysis of his hair showed aluminium levels more than three times normal. His sister, who drank the water, has a blood condition.

The mother said: 'I don't need to know what effect it had on us. I see that every day in my son's life. But I need other people to know that I am not insane and I need to know what the future holds.'

webTitle: BNFL plans new nuclear power plants

fields.headline: BNFL plans new nuclear power plants
fields.trailText: British Nuclear Fuels is lobbying for permission to build a new generation of nuclear power stations which, it claims, would help fight climate change and cut the UK's plutonium stockpile.
fields.body:
British Nuclear Fuels is lobbying for permission to build a new generation of nuclear power stations which, it claims, would help fight climate change and cut the UK's plutonium stockpile.

The state atomic energy group would use technology it acquired through buying reactor-building businesses to construct plants in place of its obsolete Magnox stations.

BNFL believes it has both the technology - with Westinghouse's AP600 and AP 1000 designs and the Swiss ABB company's boiling water reactor - and the sites for the new plants,including its eight Magnox sites and its Sellafield complex in Cumbria.

A company source said BNFL wants to build replacements as the current stations are retired. 'We have got the technology and the Magnox sites, which are already connected to the national grid,' the source said.

BNFL has talked to Whitehall officials, Ministers, and MPs. Some believe the scheme would boost BNFL's value, enhancing government plans for a part-privatisation of the group, safeguarding jobs and mitigating future rises in carbon dioxide emissions.

But others fear that the new stations would not be economic and would perpetuate reprocessing and waste disposal problems which, as highlighted by The Observer last week, would place heavy burdens on future taxpayers.

The issue has been raised in the Government's long-awaited consultation paper on radioactive waste management, which may now be published as early as next week. A draft cites a report from the Royal Society which outlines concerns over global warming. The draft adds: 'If new nuclear build were brought forward, reactors could be designed specifically with enhanced plutonium-burning capabilities.'

BNFL is anxious to find a way of dealing with the UK's 61-tonne stockpile of plutonioum, the toxic substance separated in reprocessing.

It can use it either as a mixed oxide - or mox - fuel, which it makes at Sellafield, or by itself. However, the market for mox fuel was damaged by a scandal last year over falsified data at Sellafield; and British Energy, the UK's privatised nuclear generator, believes it is too expensive.

A Greenpeace spokes-woman said: 'Nuclear power will never be an economic or environmentally acceptable way of addressing climate change.'

A BNFL spokesman said it 'has the skills and technology to take part in a nuclear future, and welcomes the debate about what contribution nuclear power can make'.

fields.headline: Diageo snubs Allied approach
fields.trailText: Drinks giant Allied Domecq has been spurned by rival Diageo over an approach to carve up Seagram's £7 billion spirits and wine empire.
fields.body:
Drinks giant Allied Domecq has been spurned by rival Diageo over an approach to carve up Seagram's £7 billion spirits and wine empire.

The news comes as Seagram sends out draft sale contracts in the auction of its drinks business before the bid deadline of 11 December.

Industry sources say that Allied chief executive Philip Bowman approached Diageo at the outset, proposing to allow its rival to take the valuable Crown Royal Canadian whiskey brand and all Seagram's wine operations while Allied took the rest.

Talks broke down, however, over Seagram's best-selling Captain Morgan rum, a brand which both covet.

Diageo has since teamed up with France's Pernod Ricard. Bacardi has allied itself with Jack Daniel's owner Brown Forman of the US and Sweden's Vin & Sprit, owner of Absolut vodka. Allied, however, has yet to sign Seagram's confidentiality undertaking and do proper due diligence.

Bereft of allies, Allied is now contemplating legal action as soon as Seagram completes its media merger with France's Vivendi on 5 December. Last month, Bowman launched a pre-emptive strike, clinching a deal with Captain Morgan rum supplier, Serralles, which insists it has rights to buy the brand if it changes ownership.

The claims are bitterly con tested by Seagram, which has now included an indemnity over Captain Morgan in the sale contracts. Sources close to Allied, however, say it considers completion of the Vivendi deal - not just sale of the Seagram spirits arm - triggers a change of control.

Allied may also be drawn into a Russian battle to regain control of Stolichnaya vodka, for which it bought US distribution rights this month.

fields.headline: Financial watchdog in fees rejig
fields.trailText: Consumer groups hope this week will bring radical changes in how the public is informed about the cost of investment products.
fields.body:
Consumer groups hope this week will bring radical changes in how the public is informed about the cost of investment products.

The chief financial regulator, Howard Davies, is to announce a long-awaited overhaul of the way consumers can judge the cost of products and compare them with rivals.

The system has been controversial since its introduction five years ago, and some members of the investment industry agree that the information supplied to potential buyers should be simplified.

Trade bodies representing the unit trust and investment trust industries dislike the way charges are expressed as a 'reduction in yield', which aims to show the reduction in profit on an investment expressed as a percentage over the life of an investment.

The Association of Investment Trust Companies and the Association of Unit Trusts and Investment Funds, which represents the unit trust industry, favour a system, known as the 'total expense ratio', that would express charges on an annual basis as a percentage of fund values.

Simon Barnes of Which? magazine supports such a system, but dislikes the name. 'It needs to be simplified,' he says.

Disclosure of charges on investment products was resisted for years by the life insurance industry. It is now thought to feel that the reduction in yield system is ade quate, but that other aspects of the information given to investors should be clarified.

Alan Woods, head of life and pensions at the Association of British Insurers, said: 'Anything we can do to further improve clarity and understanding for customers has got to be a move in the right direct.'

But any change must be practicable.

webTitle: Germany braced for neo-Nazi terror blitz

fields.headline: Germany braced for neo-Nazi terror blitz
fields.standfirst: Stockpiles of arms stir fears of a switch by Far Right to unlimited violence
fields.trailText: Stockpiles of arms stir fears of a switch by Far Right to unlimited violence.
fields.byline: Peter Beaumont, foreign affairs editor, and Kate Connolly in Berlin
fields.body:
German neo-Nazis are stockpiling firearms and bomb-making equipment and organising into cells reminiscent of the left-wing Baader-Meinhof gang of the 1970s.

The change in tactics by the extreme Right has raised fears that neo-Nazis, whose political parties are under attack and facing bans in Germany, may be on the verge of launching a large-scale terrorist campaign. The warnings came as neo-Nazis marched in Berlin yesterday to protest against the proposed banning of the far-right National Democratic Party by German Chancellor Gerhard Schröder.

Anti-terrorism experts are increasingly concerned that neo-Nazis - responsible for more than 130 largely racist murders since reunification a decade ago - may be preparing to target businessmen, state employees and left-wing figures. Amid warnings of a surge in both racist attacks and applications for membership of the NPD, internal security chiefs announced last week that they had seized record amounts of weapons and explosives from neo-Nazis, including pipe-bombs and machine guns in half a dozen raids this year.

Heinz Fromm, head of the Federal Office for the Protection of the Constitution (BfV), which monitors extremist violence, said last week that police and state security agencies were alarmed by the way in which neo-Nazis were discussing terrorism to back their political aims. Fromm's warning coincides with a report from the European Union's main racism monitoring centre showing a sharp rise in racist attacks across the EU. 'The whole scene in Europe has become much more violent, especially in France, Germany, Sweden and several other countries,' Beate Winkler, the centre's director, said last week.

It also comes as Germany's central law enforcement agency, the Bundeskrim-inalamt, reported on Friday that 11,000 far-right, racist and xenophobic crimes had been investigated in the 12 months to the end of October, an increase of more than 20 per cent on the previous year.

The first hard evidence of a dangerous change in the tactics of Europe's neo-Nazis emerged a year ago when the police and anti-fascist campaigners logged a meeting of extreme-right activists from Germany, Sweden, Norway and Britain, near Oslo.

While members of the Far Right meet regularly, this get-together was unusual for its agenda: tactics for eliminating political opponents. It was taken seriously enough by police in the state of Lower Saxony to feel compelled to warn trade unionists and left-wingers to check their mail for letter-bombs. At the same time observers of the Far Right in Germany, Austria and Scandinavia were warning that German neo-Nazis and their counterparts elsewhere had begun preparing lists of potential targets and gathering intelligence.

The security organisations' worst fears were realised in July, when a powerful bomb ripped through a metal walkway at Düsseldorf station injuring 10 Eastern European immigrants, six of them Jews, as they returned from a German-language class.

Twelve days later police in Bamberg defused a crude pipe bomb sent to the former home of a Jewish community leader. After another bomb attack on a Turkish takeaway shop in Eisenach, police arrested an 18-year-old member of the NPD.

Fromm's warning of a resurgence of terrorism in Germany follows three months after the emergence of the former Red Army Faction guerrilla, Horst Mahler, as the leading ideologue of the National Democrats. He spent 10 years in German jails for his involvement with the Baader-Meinhof gang, part of the Red Army Faction, and now runs a successful legal practice in west Berlin.

While there is no suggestion that Mahler's extraordinary conversion from the politics of the Extreme Left to the politics of the Extreme Right is in any way connected with recent neo-Nazi terrorist attacks, security sources in Germany believe that his emergence as a key player on Germany's Far Right has inevitably encouraged neo-Nazis to examine the methods that made his former Red Army Faction colleagues so successful as terrorists.

Mahler joined the National Democrats in late August - a week before Schröder announced his determination to see the organisation banned. 'There is growing evidence for right-wing terrorism,' said Fromm, whose BfV monitors extremists through informants, wire-taps and infiltrators. 'Violence as an option is being discussed among local far-right groupings,' he said. 'There are right-wing extremists who are increasingly questioning their previous reluctance to use violence to further political aims.'

Hajo Funke, professor of politics at Freie University, Berlin, and one of the country's leading specialists in far-right extremism, said: 'The findings of weapons by police have been getting more and more frequent. Right-wing terrorism to date has been mainly down to individuals, but the ideological basis behind these terror attacks is growing.'

He defended Schröder's attempt to ban the NPD despite claims that it would drive it underground. 'The more you place these groups under suspicion, and the more they're aware they're being watched closely, the less they can manoeuvre.'

He said that small groups were emerging out of the violent milieu. 'They will target specific people. Their use of explosives means they are able to target their victims with reasonable accuracy. We can expect their victims in the near future to be companies, democratic organisations, the state and left-wing groups.'

'What we are seeing,' says Graeme Atkinson, European editor of the anti-Nazi organisation Searchlight, 'is a very worrying trend in the organisation of far-right groups with a view to committing terrorism. They are talking about creating a "leaderless resistance" of terrorist cells - what they call a "brown underground" - and of ensuring the creation of liberated zones, with foreigners driven out from rural areas and smaller towns.'

'The far-right extremists have not yet build up the logistic structures the RAF had,' says Fromm. 'But attacks could still be carried out by organisations that are not as tightly organised.'

Fromm's comments came during an address to a symposium on far-Right violence in Wiesbaden last week.

He pointed out that the push for the use of violence for political ends came largely from Kameradschaften, secret clubs of extremists and neo-Nazis.

Rise of terrorist attacks

 March 1998: During a raid, a special police commission in Nordrhein Westfalen uncovered seven machine pistols, 11 rifles, three mines, four grenades, 12 detonators, six containers full of black gunpowder and about 8,000 rounds of ammunition. The weapon collectors were members of the paramilitary Stahlhelm, or steel helmut.

 End of 1998: Bomb blew up the grave of the former chairman of the central council of Jews, Heinz Galinski, in Berlin.

 March 1999: During a house search in Frankfurt am Oder a piece of rough paper was discovered detailing a list of right-wing terrorist action plans.

 In 1999 alone, nine people died because of violent actions by right-wing extremists. In addition, 602 people were injured and there were 36 explosions and arson attacks for which right-wing extremists were responsible.

 July 2000 A bomb ripped through a walkway at Dusseldorf's railway station injuring 10 eastern European immigrants returning from a German language lesson.
fields.bodyText: German neo-Nazis are stockpiling firearms and bomb-making equipment and organising into cells reminiscent of the left-wing Baader-Meinhof gang of the 1970s. The change in tactics by the extreme Right has raised fears that neo-Nazis, whose political parties are under attack and facing bans in Germany, may be on the verge of launching a large-scale terrorist campaign. The warnings came as neo-Nazis marched in Berlin yesterday to protest against the proposed banning of the far-right National Democratic Party by German Chancellor Gerhard Schröder. Anti-terrorism experts are increasingly concerned that neo-Nazis - responsible for more than 130 largely racist murders since reunification a decade ago - may be preparing to target businessmen, state employees and left-wing figures. Amid warnings of a surge in both racist attacks and applications for membership of the NPD, internal security chiefs announced last week that they had seized record amounts of weapons and explosives from neo-Nazis, including pipe-bombs and machine guns in half a dozen raids this year. Heinz Fromm, head of the Federal Office for the Protection of the Constitution (BfV), which monitors extremist violence, said last week that police and state security agencies were alarmed by the way in which neo-Nazis were discussing terrorism to back their political aims. Fromm's warning coincides with a report from the European Union's main racism monitoring centre showing a sharp rise in racist attacks across the EU. 'The whole scene in Europe has become much more violent, especially in France, Germany, Sweden and several other countries,' Beate Winkler, the centre's director, said last week. It also comes as Germany's central law enforcement agency, the Bundeskrim-inalamt, reported on Friday that 11,000 far-right, racist and xenophobic crimes had been investigated in the 12 months to the end of October, an increase of more than 20 per cent on the previous year. The first hard evidence of a dangerous change in the tactics of Europe's neo-Nazis emerged a year ago when the police and anti-fascist campaigners logged a meeting of extreme-right activists from Germany, Sweden, Norway and Britain, near Oslo. While members of the Far Right meet regularly, this get-together was unusual for its agenda: tactics for eliminating political opponents. It was taken seriously enough by police in the state of Lower Saxony to feel compelled to warn trade unionists and left-wingers to check their mail for letter-bombs. At the same time observers of the Far Right in Germany, Austria and Scandinavia were warning that German neo-Nazis and their counterparts elsewhere had begun preparing lists of potential targets and gathering intelligence. The security organisations' worst fears were realised in July, when a powerful bomb ripped through a metal walkway at Düsseldorf station injuring 10 Eastern European immigrants, six of them Jews, as they returned from a German-language class. Twelve days later police in Bamberg defused a crude pipe bomb sent to the former home of a Jewish community leader. After another bomb attack on a Turkish takeaway shop in Eisenach, police arrested an 18-year-old member of the NPD. Fromm's warning of a resurgence of terrorism in Germany follows three months after the emergence of the former Red Army Faction guerrilla, Horst Mahler, as the leading ideologue of the National Democrats. He spent 10 years in German jails for his involvement with the Baader-Meinhof gang, part of the Red Army Faction, and now runs a successful legal practice in west Berlin. While there is no suggestion that Mahler's extraordinary conversion from the politics of the Extreme Left to the politics of the Extreme Right is in any way connected with recent neo-Nazi terrorist attacks, security sources in Germany believe that his emergence as a key player on Germany's Far Right has inevitably encouraged neo-Nazis to examine the methods that made his former Red Army Faction colleagues so successful as terrorists. Mahler joined the National Democrats in late August - a week before Schröder announced his determination to see the organisation banned. 'There is growing evidence for right-wing terrorism,' said Fromm, whose BfV monitors extremists through informants, wire-taps and infiltrators. 'Violence as an option is being discussed among local far-right groupings,' he said. 'There are right-wing extremists who are increasingly questioning their previous reluctance to use violence to further political aims.' Hajo Funke, professor of politics at Freie University, Berlin, and one of the country's leading specialists in far-right extremism, said: 'The findings of weapons by police have been getting more and more frequent. Right-wing terrorism to date has been mainly down to individuals, but the ideological basis behind these terror attacks is growing.' He defended Schröder's attempt to ban the NPD despite claims that it would drive it underground. 'The more you place these groups under suspicion, and the more they're aware they're being watched closely, the less they can manoeuvre.' He said that small groups were emerging out of the violent milieu. 'They will target specific people. Their use of explosives means they are able to target their victims with reasonable accuracy. We can expect their victims in the near future to be companies, democratic organisations, the state and left-wing groups.' 'What we are seeing,' says Graeme Atkinson, European editor of the anti-Nazi organisation Searchlight, 'is a very worrying trend in the organisation of far-right groups with a view to committing terrorism. They are talking about creating a "leaderless resistance" of terrorist cells - what they call a "brown underground" - and of ensuring the creation of liberated zones, with foreigners driven out from rural areas and smaller towns.' 'The far-right extremists have not yet build up the logistic structures the RAF had,' says Fromm. 'But attacks could still be carried out by organisations that are not as tightly organised.' Fromm's comments came during an address to a symposium on far-Right violence in Wiesbaden last week. He pointed out that the push for the use of violence for political ends came largely from Kameradschaften, secret clubs of extremists and neo-Nazis. Rise of terrorist attacks  March 1998: During a raid, a special police commission in Nordrhein Westfalen uncovered seven machine pistols, 11 rifles, three mines, four grenades, 12 detonators, six containers full of black gunpowder and about 8,000 rounds of ammunition. The weapon collectors were members of the paramilitary Stahlhelm, or steel helmut.  End of 1998: Bomb blew up the grave of the former chairman of the central council of Jews, Heinz Galinski, in Berlin.  March 1999: During a house search in Frankfurt am Oder a piece of rough paper was discovered detailing a list of right-wing terrorist action plans.  In 1999 alone, nine people died because of violent actions by right-wing extremists. In addition, 602 people were injured and there were 36 explosions and arson attacks for which right-wing extremists were responsible.  July 2000 A bomb ripped through a walkway at Dusseldorf's railway station injuring 10 eastern European immigrants returning from a German language lesson.

fields.headline: The cost of
fields.standfirst: camel racing
fields.trailText: camel racing
fields.body:
Horse racing is a rich man's sport, but don't despair: another season of camel racing has just opened in the Gulf states. The sport is particularly popular in the United Arab Emirates, where the programme culminates in Dubai's Grand Camel Races.

Before you reach the starting gate, you'll have to acquire a camel. November is a great time to buy: the Pushkar Camel Fair in India is one of the world's biggest. Good camels here can go for £500, but you'll pay transportation costs (at least £2,000 per camel). The same goes for Australia, which has thousands of feral camels and a budding racing scene - the International Camel Cup is contested annually by Alice Springs and Virginia City, Nevada.

Sudanese camels are renowned for their turn of speed, but Arab owners are now building their own breeding stock using artificial insemination: the Camel Reproduction Centre in Dubai is developing bigger, better, faster camels which can cost up to £15,000 and reach a top speed of 20kph. The best place to learn the camel racing ropes is at the Maralal Reserve in Kenya.

October's Maralal Camel Derby is open to amateurs (entrance fee £20) and is perfect for getting used to the more relaxed handling of the Kenyan camel. For £1,000 you can spend a week at the Maralal Safari Lodge (flights included). Your kit should include a helmet and a saddle (without stirrups).

However, once you start taking the sport seriously you'll have to relinquish the reins, because in Dubai the jockeys are small boys, weighing about 15 kilos, who are no younger than 10 years old. They used to be tied on, but these days Velcro is used, and the very best will earn £300 per week for their families.

When racing in the Emirates, stay at the exclusive desert-bound resort Al Maha, where a night in the Owner's Suite will cost £2,100. Camels are associated with many Bedouin traditions - if yours is successful, you should compose a poem of praise (a kaseeda) and its name should convey its qualities (but think of something more original than Desert Orchid).

fields.headline: BA-American link flies again
fields.trailText: British Airways and American Airlines are to relaunch their global partnership within weeks and could make fresh plans next year to merge their transatlantic operations.
fields.body:
British Airways and American Airlines are to relaunch their global partnership within weeks and could make fresh plans next year to merge their transatlantic operations.

The two firms intend to make a 'declaration of renewed commitment' to each other next month and to their global Oneworld marketing alliance of airlines, after months of uncertainty while BA was attempting to buy Dutch airline KLM.

American is keen to file a new application in Washington for anti-trust immunity for the two airlines and to negotiate with the competition authorities in London and Brussels for permission to collaborate on transatlatic prices and services.

But BA is urging caution and a softly, softly approach, particularly to the European Commission, after disagree ments there in 1998 sank the previous plan for a full-blown partnership. Then, the airlines backed away from a Brussels demand that BA give up substantial capacity at Heathrow to allow in more competing US airlines.

They believe they would have to give up much less capacity because the rival Star grouping, led by United Airlines and Lufthansa, is very powerful and now includes British Midland, which has significant capac ity at Heathrow. Sources close to Oneworld told The Observer that American had been ready to jettison BA from the alliance and switch its allegiance to Swissair if it had formed a tie up with KLM and the Dutch carrier's US partner, Northwest. But the BA-KLM talks ended in September without a deal.

BA chief executive Rod Eddington and American chairman Don Carty will meet with the other Oneworld bosses in Atlanta this week.

fields.headline: The loafer's guide
fields.standfirst: Elton John's closet
fields.trailText: Elton John's closet.
fields.body:
Hasn't he already come out of it?
This has nothing to do with Sir Elton's sexuality. After all the recent column inches devoted to his spending £20m in 20 months and the £3.4m payout he received from ex-manager John Reid, The Rocket Man is giving something back by donating some of his colourful wardrobe to charity.

He's giving his clothes to an Oxfam shop?
Not quite. The venue Elton's hired for the sale is 51 New Bond Street, in the heart of London's designer quarter. Calling itself Out Of The Closet III, the event coincides with World Aids Day on 1 December and will raise money for the Elton John Aids Foundation. This is the third time Elton has cleared out his wardrobe. The last was in 1997, when he raised more than £329,000, selling out of 15,000 items in a record five days.

What sort of things can we expect?
A varied selection of his clothes, stage costumes and accessories. We're promised a stage outfit from the 70s, 80s and 90s as well as a black and green Versace suit he wore on stage with Pavarotti. Prices are expected to start from as little as £30 for a shirt, £150 for a suit and £25 for a pair of shoes. If you want a taster, his official website (www.eltonjohn.com) has some photographs of the clothes in question. Don't worry if Elton's clothes are too flamboyant, those with a more conservative dress sense can also peruse items from the more sedate wardrobe of Elton's long-term partner, David Furnish.

So is it a first come, first served policy?
Not quite. Elton will host a special preview breakfast at 9am for some of his friends and charity workers on 29 November and will then officially open the shop to the public at midday.

But all the best stuff might have gone by then!
There's a good chance. One of Elton's close friends is 'super-shopper' Victoria 'Posh' Beckham, who has probably already got her eyes on a few of the more gaudy items for husband David.

fields.headline: Pasta master
fields.standfirst: Cipriani pasta is as smooth as a Harry's Bar Bellini, says Sybil Kapoor
fields.trailText: Cipriani pasta is as smooth as a Harry's Bar Bellini, says Sybil Kapoor.
fields.body:
Choosing dried pasta, particularly one that has been made with eggs, is a challenging task. What makes one brand more desirable than another? Do you like the robust, curling yellow strands of a Carluccio's own-label, or are you more of a silky slick Cipriani pasta cook? Time to consult an expert, namely Nino Sassu, chef and joint proprietor of Assaggi, the superb Sardinian restaurant in London's Notting Hill Gate.

It seems Sassu is a Cipriani man. 'Its quality is outstanding,' he states. 'The pasta has been rolled at least 30 times and it cooks in about two minutes.' Not that he uses it at work - with only three gas rings in his tiny kitchen, he prefers to cook his own. Once home, however, the fragile strands of tagliolini all'uovo are gently lifted out of their tissue-lined box and dropped into a pot of boiling water to make a speedy supper, perhaps tossed with some fresh tomato, basil and olive oil or a little shredded sausage with a garlic tomato sauce.

There are several factors that distinguish Cipriani pasta from other brands. For one thing, it uses rough as opposed to fine-ground semolina. This helps the pasta form ultra-fine sheets as it is rolled over and over again. Open a box of tagliardi all'uovo con spinaci and touch the small green squares of pasta. They feel like satin wafers - you almost want to slip one into your mouth to see if it will melt. Cipriani also cuts its pasta rather extruding it through a machine which, I am told, lessens the pasta's absorption of water as it cooks. If, however, you like your pasta al dente, I would recommend lessening the recommended cooking time on the pasta box.

Naturally, the Cipriani brand carries with it the somewhat exclusive image of Harry's Bar in Venice, all Bellinis and polished wood. Do not let this discourage you from trying the pasta - it is excellent in a smooth, suave sort of a way. Very Venetian.

 Cipriani pasta is available in Sainsbury's Special Selection at £2.99 for a 250g packet Assaggi, The Chepstow, 39 Chepstow Place, London W2 (020 7792 5501)

fields.headline: Norfolk turkeys
fields.trailText: I blame Frank Bough. If it wasn't for 'that most popular of TV presenters' I wouldn't have fallen victim to the ennui for all things rural which jaundiced last week's News from Norfolk.
fields.body:
I blame Frank Bough. If it wasn't for 'that most popular of TV presenters' I wouldn't have fallen victim to the ennui for all things rural which jaundiced last week's News from Norfolk.

The fact is that although our careers are superficially different - I have never knowingly presented Grandstand - they are, at core, very similar. As was Frank's habit, I often travel to London for a hard night's work and end up kipping on a convenient student's floor or, failing that, a student's convenient floor. A practice which is as uncomfortable as it is unsettling and had me hurrying to read Cue Frank! (£2.95, Queen Anne Press, 1980, hardback), in which Frank launches into what he modestly describes as 'a few stories of 15 years on the box'.

These proved to be entirely predictable. There is respect for his employer: 'Our determination not to be deflected by the fleshpots of Asia, by the night clubs and the bath-houses of the Ginza, Tokyo's West End, but to work hard and give the pound-and-a-half of flesh that the BBC demands on big international sporting occasions'. There is self-deprecation: 'There should be one or two places on earth where you can go without having Frank Bough thrust upon you.' But then, bottom of page 191, there is poetic insight: 'This year, 1980, I'm 47.

I embark on my 13th year with Grandstand, my ninth with Nationwide. Tell me: is it too late? What should we all do next?'

Phuughh, who needs Beckett when Bough is knocking out prose of that calibre? 'Is it too late?' Is it any wonder a sullenness descended as I stared out of the west-wing window at the cooking apples floating up the drive etc, etc.

Fortunately, the melancholy was lifted by Ross Benson. Benson, you may remember, was the journalist who surprised the Mail's Nigel Dempster by attacking him from the moral low ground. His gossip column for the Express was the making of the man and he now writes challenging features for the Mail such as last Saturday's, in which he stated, 'Norfolk has become the new Gloucestershire.' A geographically confusing assertion which he backed up with the hard fact that 'the cottage comedian Les Dennis owns would go on the market at some £250,000'. (Cottage comedian? Plays in small houses a bit risqué not a bad description of Les Dennis.)

All this came as something of a shock to someone who had invested the whole stack on a place in Norfolk on an estate agent's word that it was nowhere near Gloucestershire. But later in the article Benson, honing his argument, decreed that it was only North Norfolk that was the New Gloucestershire. Thank goodness for that. We were still in Norfolk and, given the state of the roads, a long way from any Gloucestershire of whatever vintage.

There's nothing like a close shave for upping the spirits and bringing on the disposition to think of those less fortunate than oneself. The kids are in great fettle. One bonus of rural living is that the modern dilemma of whether to play a computer game or with the children disappears. You can do both. Plenty of hours staring at the screen playing World Championship Poker and, as long as it takes, staring at your offspring doing their homework. Result: everyone happy.

Even better, now they are at 'big' school, more often than not they do more in the day than their father. The pressure of bringing news from the outside world, telling the anecdotes, falls on them. Dad: How was the trip to the Ipswich Transport Museum, darling? Fred: I slept on the way there and did pee-pee in my knick-knicks on the way back. Dad: Unhuh. What was the best bit of the day? Fred: The coach.

Boom, boom. Bucolic bliss. And then, a turn up for the books. Turning on Sky Sports, or rather walking into the room where Sky Sports is pretty permanently on, and seeing a bloke Grainne fancied rotten for the better part of a decade playing poker for a first prize of £1m. Rapid is the only word for the speed with which Gron darted down from the bathroom when I shouted up the news. Whaddyaknow, as we watched transfixed, for very different reasons, ol' blue eyes bluffed the lot of them and pocketed what the city boys call 'a unit'.

Quite unsettling, really, sitting with your wife watching someone she has the hots for fulfiling your fantasies. I wonder what Frank Bough

fields.headline: Sitting pretty
fields.standfirst: The closest most off-roaders get to mud is a face pack in Harvey Nichols, but BMW's 4x4 wants to go mud wrestling
fields.trailText: The closest most off-roaders get to mud is a face pack in Harvey Nichols, but BMW's 4x4 wants to go mud wrestling.
fields.body:
BMW X5
Price from £33,000
Insurance group 16
MPG 22.2
Engine size 2979cc
Max speed 128mph
0-60mph 8.5 seconds
Driven wheels Rear 62:38

Unless you live in a river, which, admittedly, more and more of us do these wintry days, buying a 4x4 is a heroically stupid thing to do. Off-roaders are big, stodgy, thirsty and drive like barges. You can't park them in town, you can't take off at the lights showing sports cars a clean pair of mud flaps and, worst off all, they are plain bad for your image. Choose a Jeep, and everyone thinks you're overcompensating madly for lack of performance 'off road'. The Mercedes is just too Annette Bening in American Beauty . The Lexus has no class. John Birt did for the Range Rover, and Land Rovers only make sense in the southern hemisphere.

Mud-pluggers suffer from the same problem as Country Life . They reek of country piles, Harris Tweed, corduroy keks, wet dogs and wellies, but most people who buy them are 0207. The closest they get to mud is the odd face pack in Harvey Nicks. Like their drivers, off-roaders need a makeover, which, fortunately, is just what BMW has done. The Germans may be responsible for some of the worst crimes against style - lederhosen, the Rudi Voller shell suit, and more mullets per head than a Billy Ray Cyrus gig - but with the X5, Made in Munich has become a must-have label.

BMW has not made a 4x4 before now, but the men behind the kidney grill know exactly what we want from a big biff-about motor. We want it to be a little bit ghetto fabulous, a little bit refined, and as we waft along looking down on other drivers, we want to feel just as comfortable as if we were in the saloon cars that most of our friends - bless them - still drive.

The X5 does not pretend to be a mud-wrestling aristocrat in a head scarf. It is far too pretty for that. Its grill juts manfully at the end of an elegantly toned bonnet, which hides giant wheels. The aluminium running boards are studded with rubber, like a JP Tod's driving loafer, and a cheeky little spoiler says 'Catch me if you can'. The four squat chrome exhaust pipes deliver the reassuringly sporty BMW growl.

Inside, the titanium trim, black leather and suede stitching are more loft-living than labrador. Open the boot and there are none of the winches, tow ropes and silly 'I'm-just-off-to-take-the-horsebox-to-Sierra-Leone' accessories. Instead, there are plenty of hi-tech toys - television, satellite navigation, computer - that can be neatly hidden behind black panels in case there is a building boom and architects start making enough money to buy BMWs. The air conditioning is arctic, the roof opens, the back seats and boot are roomy, and there are enough air bags to stop a turbo-charged Rhinoceros.

Go for the metallic gold with lowered suspension and black wheels, and you are Puff Daddy. Silver is more Elizabeth Hurley. If stealth wealth is your thing, try midnight blue. Red is the only red-card offence.

Style alone should be enough but, this being Britain, there are people out there who actually want to know if it is any good at going along. The answer for those who would not know what a Tod's loafer was if it were served à la Milanese is yes, very. BMW may have flogged Land Rover, makers of traditional, agricultural 4x4s, Range Rovers and the popular Freelander, to Ford earlier this year, but they made sure they pinched all the best technology before they turned out the lights and left the keys under the mat.

Most 4x4s feel like they might trip themselves up, if you start having too much fun, but the X5 handles remarkably like a saloon. The 4.4-litre version dashes to 60 in eight seconds - a creditable performance for a car of its size - and hits a top speed of more than 140mph. On country roads, it is stable, cornering with remarkably little body roll, even at high speed. Braking is firm and the steering is effortlessly crisp.

On motorways, it is a Club Class ride, although it can feel a little rough on bumpier stretches. Like any tall car, it is noisier than a saloon, but it is a small price to pay for the extra comfort and the panoramic view. With its suspension derived from the luxury 7 Series, park distance and cruise control, the X5 can hold its own in the executive car park. The only niggle is the split-tailgate, which leaves the back looking a little squashed.

There are none of the low-transmission gears that make the Land Rover and Jeep Kings of the Hill, but if you insist on playing dirty, the X5 can scrap well enough. It chugs through rivers and over boulders without getting stuck. It climbs impossibly steep hills and, if you do not want to drive down the other side, the car will do it for you. Flick on the 'Descent' button, take your foot off all the pedals (Warning: this is very scary) and you will not exceed a glacial 6mph until you are back on the flat.

The X5 is pretty and very well behaved and, like a lot of pretty things that know how to handle themselves, it comes at a price. The models on sale now are the 4.4-litre V8 versions at almost £45,000. Most drivers will choose to wait until next year when the far more affordable and less thirsty 3-litre arrives from South Carolina where it is built.

In traffic jams or on the motorway, the X5 is big and clever, and in the brand-obsessed UK market it has the right badge. The question is whether it provides the sporty driving experience worthy of your Sport-line Prada and Armani. BMW clearly thinks it is and refuses to describe it as a Sports Utility Vehicle - which is what it is - preferring instead Sports Activity Vehicle. Whatever you want to call it, it is booted, suited and ready for Bond Street. It may not be the best 4x4 off-road, but it is the sexiest on it. Go out and get yourself noticed.

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: Nancy Traversy and Tessa Strickland are co-founders of the children's publisher, Barefoot Books. Since 1993, they've managed to juggle both family and work, and now see the company as their eighth child
fields.trailText: Nancy Traversy and Tessa Strickland are co-founders of the children's publisher, Barefoot Books. Since 1993, they've managed to juggle both family and work, and now see the company as their eighth child.
fields.body:
Tessa Strickland: I'd worked in publishing for several years and had an idea for a children's list. My brother is a good friend of Nancy's husband Marty and heard that she had just set up her own business consultancy. He thought she would be the right person to point me in the right direction. The idea for Barefoot partly came out of my experience of Jungian therapy, which had made me increasingly aware of the importance of myth and legend in storytelling. But I couldn't find satisfactory adaptations of these stories for children.

I enjoyed initiating the projects and seeking out writers and artists, but was overwhelmed by the idea of physically producing the books and being responsible for huge sums of money. When I met Nancy, she was intrigued by the idea and wanted to be a part of it.

We were both keen to work from home. I was in the throes of a divorce, and as I had three children who were all under the age of six and Nancy had a new baby, childcare was a major issue for both of us. I was desperate to live in the country and found a dilapidated old farmhouse just outside Bath and set up an office on the top floor.

It was great when my children were small because I was able to work round them. They are very much part of my working life and I test the books on them. However, now I have more staff and the children are older, we're going to move into offices in Bath.

The stress of having to cope with a divorce, moving house and starting a new business was bound to take its toll, and one day, shortly before I was about to drive to Heathrow to fly to Barefoot's first Bologna Book Fair, I lost my vision. Luckily, it was only for about half an hour, but I have no doubt it was stress-related. It was a very frightening moment.

Although I'm based near Bath and Nancy's in London, we talk for at least an hour a day and I usually go to London once a week. One of the reasons the relationship works so well is that we don't share an office. We both have strong personalities and we argue a lot but I think it's a case of the friction and the grit making the pearl.

Nancy Traversy: When I met Tessa we were both in the middle of enormous changes and I was feeling very vulnerable. I was a new mother and it was the first time in my working life that I wasn't getting a regular salary. Because I'd just had a child, I was drawn to the concept of children's books. I've always been interested in art and design and was excited by the prospect of books that would combine beautiful illustrations with intelligent text.

At first I was quite intimidated by Tessa. She's incredibly articulate and she came into my tiny office and spewed out all these words about foreign rights and co-editions. Now I know that Tessa is just very wordy and can make things sound more complicated than they actually are.

We've never formally articulated what our separate responsibilities would be. I think it was assumed by both of us that I would look after the business side of things and Tessa would look after the editorial content, but in fact our roles are rather blurred. As the commercial person, I should look after contracts but Tessa does that as she's brilliant at them - it's part of her obsession with words. Similarly, I've often brought new artists on board and I'm responsible for our website.

I could never have had four children in five years if I hadn't worked from home. I'd go back to work the day after having had a baby and breastfeed during meetings, but I'm beginning to crave more of a division between my private and professional lives. I'm trying to learn from Tessa how to balance my life better. Once, when we were in New York, I was very ill but insisted on going to meeting after meeting. Tessa put her foot down and got me to an emergency doctor and arranged for me to fly home.

Tessa's one of my closest friends but we can spend hours battling something out, but at the end of the day we usually see eye to eye. We have the same view on what should be published and stick to it. It's unquestionably a shared vision. We both say that Barefoot is our other child.

 To get a copy of the Barefoot Books catalogue, call 020 7704 6492 or visit www.barefoot-books.com.
