fields.headline: Well being
fields.standfirst: An alternative look at health issues. This week: the power of positive thinking, getting around ovarian pain, and facing up to acupuncture
fields.trailText: An alternative look at health issues. This week: the power of positive thinking, getting around ovarian pain, and facing up to acupuncture.
fields.body:
It is widely accepted that positive thinking is not only good for your health and state of mind, but also helps you achieve your goals more easily. However, being the grumpy, destructive bunch we are, thinking positively is a habit we have to teach ourselves, and there is no better way than using what became widely known in the mostly California-centred 'human potential movement' of the 70s as 'doing positive affirmations'.

The way affirmation works is similar to the effect of writing 100 lines in school detention: 'I will not talk in class!', for instance. The drawback there is the unconscious mind only registers the positive section of any command and would, in the above example, register 'talk in class!' - line-writing thus only ensuring a steady flow of further detention-room traffic.

Doing positive affirmations means you have to phrase the command only in the positive. (I say 'command' because affirmations are nothing more than auto-suggestion - giving your unconscious mind a positive command.) It doesn't matter how you frame the command, as long as the crucial, active part is positive.

But there's no point kidding yourself. If you've been suffering from chronic depression, there's no way your mind will react cooperatively with such sentiments as: 'I now feel happy all the time!', no matter how many times you repeat it. This is not about brainwashing yourself. It's about accepting where you are and remembering you have the choice to change it. Your mind would be much more likely to accept, 'Through this depression, I learn to face the dark side of myself. Through facing and accepting the darkness, I grow, and in my growth process I find my peace of mind.' Or more simply put: 'Out of this darkness will come great light!'

It is not about denial. If you're struggling with your cashflow - broke, in other words - you won't fool your mind by repeating, 'I am rich, I am rich!' Instead affirm: 'Having no money is teaching me I can survive on very little. Knowing this helps me be more comfortable with the whole material-survival issue. The more comfortable I am with the material plane, the more able I am to operate effectively on it.' This commands your mind to see the positive in your present situation and to open itself to the possibility of an improvement in circumstances.

If, however, you veer more towards the magical view of life, you could affirm: 'Money is now coming to me in huge bundles from every direction at once!' (This one generally works, by the way, and I only take 10 per cent commission.)

More importantly, though, are affirmations designed to produce change in the way you respond to life by developing your positive qualities. If, having tried the money affirmation for three weeks and 100 grand still hasn't landed in your lap, you may wish to affirm an increase in patience and trust levels. You could repeat: 'I am capable of exercising infinite patience and trust in life's benevolence now' or simply: 'I have infinite patience and trust when I feel like accessing it.'

The most effective way to get these affirmations to lodge in your unconscious mind and thus enable you to override the negative is to write each one down at least six times each (it takes six repetitions or more to infiltrate the brain's circuitry). Writing things down is the simplest way to fix the idea. But this is not to say that saying affirmations out loud or even singing them to yourself isn't also highly effective.

The best time to 'do' your affirmations is when you'd be otherwise wasting time and energy sitting around worrying or getting gloomy. Instead, use your time and energy to do some positivity training. Other useful times are while sitting in trains, buses, boats and planes, or instead of doodling, sending silly emails or playing computer games while at work - procrastinating, in other words.

It generally takes about three weeks of daily affirmation-doing before you begin to see results. But natural serendipity aside, the bigger the thing you're affirming for, the longer it usually takes. Though you could always affirm: 'The bigger the thing I affirm, the more quickly it manifests for me!'

You can, in fact, completely and radically alter the entire structure of reality over time, doing affirmations (so be careful what you affirm). Although, according to that old Scottish 'taoist' aphorism, 'What's for ye won't pass ye by and what passes ye by was nay for ye', affirmation-doing will only clarify what you actually want and through clarification accelerate the process somewhat.

Let me leave you with a suggested affirmation for the upcoming week: 'Through the rigours of modern life, petrol shortages, unpredictable weather patterns and train timetables, I realise what a magnificent experience life can be and am uplifted!'

Your letters

Dear Barefoot, For the past year I have been suffering from ovarian pain. I have had scans, but they show nothing out of the ordinary. Have you any suggestions?
Sandra Robinson, Chelmsford

Dear Sandra, Tincture of agnus castus can be helpful to reduce unexplained ovarian pain. According to Oriental medicine, it is often caused by a blockage in the body's only horizontal energy meridian - the 'dai mo' or 'belt channel' - which runs round the waist and is responsible for the healthy flow of energy and blood throughout the reproductive organs. A competent acupuncturist can 'unblock' it by inserting needles or pressing points on the forearm and lower legs. It is best to have treatment just after the period for three menstrual cycles or so.

Dear Barefoot, Do you think acupuncture can work to reduce facial wrinkles?
Ted Lawrance, Brighton

Dear Ted, Facial acupuncture is a speciality of the Vietnamese, who treat the whole body from the face. It was soon discovered that, as a by-product, facial muscle tone, circulation and therefore skin tone would also improve over the course of the treatment. This will smooth out the terrain enough to reduce shadows caused by deep indentations in the skin. Ten sessions over a three-week period can make a noticeable difference. Conversely, this tends to have a beneficial effect on the vital organs as well, so is often worth the experiment.

 Barefoot Doctor is author of 'Handbook for the Urban Warrior' and teaches Taoism, meditation, Chinese medicine and t'ai chi. He has been in practice for more than 20 years, specialising in personal-crisis management. Also, you can visit www.barefootdoctorglobal.com

fields.headline: Game keepers
fields.standfirst: From squirrel to wigeon, there are many gamey species to savour
fields.trailText: From squirrel to wigeon, there are many gamey species to savour.
fields.body:
Mike Feller of M Feller Son & Daughter, 54-55 The Covered Market, Oxford (01865 251 164) usually has plentiful supplies of partridge, pheasant, pigeon (£1.20 each), grouse (£12.98 each), guinea fowl, rabbits, hares and venison, but you may need to order your snipe, woodcock, teal and mallard in advance. Most game is hung for about three to seven days depending on the weather (in the old days when stronger flavours were preferred it would have been anything from 10 to 14 days), and most is hand dressed rather than machine plucked - although the feathery down on mallard makes it time consuming to deal with, they still cost a reasonable £4.98 a bird.

Among the more unusual items of game is squirrel (grey, of course), which Peter Dale and Paul Cook supply at The Game Larder , 24 The Parade, Claygate, Surrey (01372 462 879) and at PJ Dale, 27 Bridge Road, East Molesey (020 8979 3800). Because squirrels are small, a 12-bore scattergun isn't much use, so they need to be either head-shot by a marksman or netted, and sell for £2.98 each. Most small game is head-shot, otherwise it just ends up looking like roadkill, and Dale and Cook employ a man to visit shoots and gamekeepers around the country to pick up whatever they need. Red deer comes from the Balmoral estate (saddle costs £12.78 per kg, rump and topside are £10.12 per kg), grouse can be had for £8.50 a bird, and partridge are £3.60 each.

Steve Downey at Club Chef Direct, Lakeside, Bridgwater Road, Barrow Gurney, Bristol (01275 475 252), which supplies lots of top restaurants, sells both mallard (£5 a bird) and wigeon (£4), but reckons the finest kind of duck to eat is teal: £3.50 each, but allow two per portion. Woodcock is unusual in that it flies here from Scandinavia; since it navigates by sight, it normally arrives at the first full moon in November. And since it has an empty stomach its entrails are clean, and so can be cooked with these still in place. Expect to pay £9.50 a bird. Grouse (£11.50) need a dry spring to breed well, and the last two have been wet, so they are not plentiful, but neither are they endangered since keepers set a limit to how many are shot, so the populations should be self-sustaining. This important principle is adhered to when it comes to hares (£11 each), which Club Chef Direct sources solely from areas with large populations such as Oxfordshire and Yorkshire. Both red and fallow deer are generally reared in parks and culled, so they have a semi-wild existence, but roe deer are completely wild and many people consider their leaner meat and finer flavour worth paying a bit extra for. Club Chef Direct's come from Wiltshire and Somerset, and a boned and rolled haunch of roe deer ready for roasting (about 4lbs weight) comes in at £20.

Rowley Leigh at Kensington Place, 201 Kensington Church Street, London W8 (020 7727 3184) takes a typically enthusiastic and no-nonsense approach to game, favouring simple roasting to get the best out of a good bird, serving grouse and grey leg partridge in traditional fashion with bread sauce and game chips, for example. Teal, meanwhile, comes with bubble and squeak at £11 for one bird, £16 for two. Rowley Leigh considers woodcock to be 'the ultimate in game', more appreciated in France than here, and he takes advantage of its clean insides (you can even eat the intestines) by serving a forcemeat on toast which has absorbed the bird's cooking juices, the whole effect wonderfully rich and gamey for £17.50.

 Jim Ainsworth is editor of The Good Food Guide.

webTitle: Jane Clarke: Cream of the crop

fields.headline: Cream of the crop
fields.standfirst: Nappy rash, eczema, acne... the natural remedy may be kinder than proprietary drugs
fields.trailText: Nappy rash, eczema, acne... the natural remedy may be kinder than proprietary drugs.
fields.body:
The modern trend of seeking complementary alternatives to conventional medication is especially evident when it comes to choosing creams to heal wounds and tackle skin problems. Although they can be very effective in clearing up skin conditions like eczema, many people are now turning away from corticosteroid-based dermatological preparations, partly because they can cause the skin to thin and weaken, and partly because parents are often averse to exposing their children to pharmaceutical drugs.

If you prefer to use natural remedies for skin problems, you no longer need to root around in health-food stores, as tea tree oil and calendula preparations - two of the most popular and effective plant remedies - can now be found among the lotions and potions stocked by many supermarkets, as well as high-street pharmacies.

The tea tree is native to Australia. A traditional Aboriginal remedy, the leaves and small branches of the tea tree have been picked since about 1920, before being distilled to produce an essential oil, which medicinal herbalists believe has powerfully antiseptic qualities. Indeed, the virtues of tea tree oil are also espoused by a number of more traditional medical practitioners and therapists who are reporting fascinating results that seem to confirm its healing properties. You may remember that a few weeks ago I noted that applying tea tree oil to cold sores can have a beneficial effect, with many patients finding that the symptoms of the herpes simplex virus, the cold sores and associated tingling feeling, disappear after only a few days of use.

Tea tree oil's antibacterial, antiviral, antiseptic and antifungal properties manifest themselves strongly in laboratory conditions, although there is still some concern that clinical studies into claims that it clears up a wide variety of skin problems, from acne to minor burns, are still in their infancy. Anecdotally, however, many people find that treating such skin infections as boils, warts, corns, insect bites and even ringworm, with tea tree oil - either in the form of a proprietary preparation or a home-made cream containing five drops of essential oil to one teaspoon of base cream - three times a day, can give convincing results. In addition, dabbing outbreaks of athlete's foot with a tincture made up of three drops of tea tree essential oil to 12 drops of carrier oil can be very effective. Some practitioners also recommend tea tree oil pessaries for the treatment of vaginal infections like thrush.

Although the oil can be made into an infusion (and the Aborigines used it for combating coughs, colds, cystitis, glandular fever and chronic fatigue), some adverse reactions, such as drowsiness, have been reported, so I don't recommend you take it internally, unless you are under professional supervision. Some people may also experience an allergic reaction to tea tree oil or cream when it is used externally, their sensitivity to its key constituents, terpinene, gamma terpinene, alpha terpinene and cineol, causing them to break out into an itchy red rash. Before coating yourself with the remedy, it's therefore best to ascertain your skin's tolerance of it by carrying out a spot check, applying a little of the preparation to a small area of skin and then leaving it for a few hours.

Another often-used complementary remedy for skin conditions, Calendula officinalis , the common marigold, is native to southern Europe, and is now cultivated in temperate regions around the world. The flowers are harvested as they open in early summer and are dried in the shade before being made up into a herbal preparation. Because it is above all a remedy for dermatological conditions, calendula is mainly found in skin creams or ointments to treat minor cuts, grazes and burns, nappy rash and cradle cap, to nipples that have become sore from breast-feeding. It's also commonly used as a tincture, which medicinal herbalists advocate for the treatment of eczema and acne, and as an infused oil to rub on inflamed or dry skin. Herbalists also recommend calendula for the treatment of digestive disorders like irritable-bowel syndrome and gastritis, as well as for such chronic fungal infections as thrush. Again, I would only advocate ingesting calendula under professional supervision.

If, after using tea tree or calendula for a while, your symptoms don't improve, consult your doctor or a registered medicinal herbalist. No doubt you'll receive two completely different opinions, and the choice is yours, but I would be inclined to opt for plant remedies over conventional preparations. As long as they are used appropriately, they can be far kinder on your body than many proprietary drugs.

Whichever treatment you choose, however, note that everything that you place within your body has repercussions on your immune system and bodily organs, including your skin. If you are yearning for a healthy complexion, it is therefore vital that you nurture your body with plenty of water and fresh, wholesome food.

 Jane Clarke is a registered dietician and author of the Bodyfoods series of books

fields.headline: Fever pitch
fields.standfirst: Flu pandemics tend to appear at regular intervals. And the next one may be on its way
fields.trailText: Flu pandemics tend to appear at regular intervals. And the next one may be on its way.
fields.body:
Although few of us are old enough to remember it, we all have vivid images of the First World War, evoked by grainy black-and-white pictures of mud-filled trenches, army hospitals and maimed soldiers. Each year we buy our poppies in honour of the 8.5m people killed in the conflict. Yet there is no commemorative service or Whitehall memorial to remind us of the estimated 40m victims killed worldwide in 1918 by an even more deadly enemy: flu. Although largely forgotten, the Great Influenza Pandemic of 1918 killed not only more people than the First World War, but probably more in a shorter period than any outbreak of infectious disease ever known to humanity, including bubonic plague. It preyed on mainly young, healthy adults and struck just about every country in the world.

The flu threat is very much alive today. Indeed, virologists predict that the next flu pandemic - which could again slay millions throughout the world - may be just around the corner. 'We are like vulcanologists,' says John Oxford, professor of virology at St Bartholomew's and the Royal London Hospital. 'We are sitting on our volcano, and we don't know when it is going to erupt.'

But since pandemics have a habit of appearing at intervals of 11 to 42 years - there were three last century, in 1918, 1957 and 1968 - he believes we can expect the next one 'sooner rather than later'. When it comes it will cause more than a few coughs and sniffles.

Most of us think of flu as a nuisance - inconvenient but not life threatening. We ache all over, take to our beds and feel generally sorry for ourselves. But even last winter, when flu did not officially reach epidemic levels, the health service was overwhelmed, and an estimated 16,000 people, mostly elderly, died from flu-related illnesses in England and Wales. A pandemic - when an epidemic goes global - would have devastating effect.

Although we are far better prepared than in 1918 - and Britain is one of the few countries with a pandemic plan - it will still cause mass chaos and huge numbers of deaths, predicts Professor Oxford. 'We have to be realistic about it,' he says. 'I think there will be a big problem.'

Dr Alan Hay, director of the World Health Organisation's influenza centre at the National Institute for Medical Research (NIMR) in London, agrees. 'It is an ever-present threat. You have no idea when the next pandemic will occur. You have no idea of the nature of the virus.'

Both believe the key to preventing potential catastrophe may lie in understanding what happened in 1918. The quest has led scientists to the frozen wastes of Alaska and Spitsbergen in efforts to isolate the 1918 flu virus from victims buried in the permafrost. The aim is to unravel the bug's unique chemistry - in the hope of detecting what made it so lethal - before another, perhaps equally virulent, virus emerges.

'We want to know as much as possible about that virus because we really don't know why it caused such serious illness in healthy young adults,' says Dr Hay. 'It is not only important scientifically, but that is the feature that makes a repeat so scary.'

An international race against time is on. An American team is trying to sequence the genetic structure of the virus using samples from an Inuit victim unearthed in Alaska. British scientists at the NIMR are attempting the same task using tissue from six Norwegian coalminers exhumed by an international band of flu experts in Spitsbergen in 1998. So far, results have been disappointing.

But Professor Oxford, who was a member of the Spitsbergen expedition, now hopes he can unlock the secret of the 1918 pandemic closer to home. He wants to exhume 11 victims buried in lead coffins tracked down to cemeteries in south-west London. If well enough preserved by their lead encasements, these bodies may provide the specimens which yield the vital clue to the 1918 - and perhaps the next - pandemic.

Pandemic flu has so far confounded scientists. They know the flu virus mutates all the time. The strains around last winter will have subtly changed when this year's flu season takes off over the next few months, although anyone who caught flu in recent years should retain some immunity. A pandemic emerges when the virus changes its genetic code so significantly it is effectively a new virus, meaning nobody is immune.

There have been 31 such pandemics since the earliest records in 1580. In 1918, one-quarter of Britons were struck down, and an estimated 250,000 died. Death came rapidly, within 36 hours, and horrifically, from bronchitis, pneumonia or simply the virus overwhelming the lungs. In 1957, flu caused an estimated 30,000 excess deaths. At its peak, GPs saw up to 100 cases a day, and one Liverpool hospital had one-third of nurses off sick. In 1968-9, there were 78,000 deaths in two waves.

Dr Douglas Fleming was a young GP in 1968. 'I remember my partners and I made 40 visits on Boxing Day,' he says. But in those days, the NHS had much greater flexibility to admit victims, says Dr Fleming, now director of the flu surveillance unit of the Royal College of General Practitioners.

Yet it is still not clear why a new virus emerges or where it comes from. Theories range from dust deposited by comets to the virus lying dormant in elderly people. The commonest belief is that flu in birds jumps species into pigs, which act as a mixing pot for the virus to jump again into humans. Most pandemics originate in Asia, where people, pigs and poultry live in close proximity.

But three years ago, global panic ensued when flu in chickens jumped directly to humans, infecting 18 people and killing six in Hong Kong. The virus failed to take the next critical step, passing from humans to humans, but public-health officials took no chances. They slaughtered every chicken in the province.

The 1918 flu was different. There is no evidence it came from China or birds, although it did affect pigs. Dubbed the Spanish flu, because early cases were identified there, it did not, however, begin in Spain. Professor Oxford now believes it first arose among British troops stationed in Etaples, France in 1916. He identified the camp, which 1 million soldiers passed through, from a censored edition of The Lancet reporting a large flu-like outbreak that year.

If true, this means the virus seeded itself for two years before erupting - probably helped by demobilisation - simultaneously throughout the world in 1918. It is vital evidence, says Professor Oxford, that we may have a similar breathing space to develop a vaccine when another virus appears.

This may still not avert disaster. There is now continuous global surveillance - Britain's NIMR is one of four international monitoring centres - devoted to spotting a new virus quickly. But developing a vaccine could take six months and produce only limited supplies.

'In theory, a new virus could appear in Hong Kong today, get on a plane and be in Europe the next day,' says Dr John Watson, head of the Public Health Laboratory Service's respiratory division. Large outbreaks will probably take longer. 'But,' he says, 'it is very likely that at least the first wave of a pandemic, however severe, would be hitting populations before a vaccine was available.'

The UK pandemic plan, drawn up by the Department of Health after the 1997 Hong Kong scare, details how vaccines will be rationed. Health staff will take top priority while other essential workers, such as police, army and undertakers, will take precedence over the general public. Unlike in 1918, doctors can now treat flu-related problems like bronchitis with antibiotics, and new anti-viral drugs, like Relenza, can reduce flu's effect. But the plan makes clear that such drugs are likely to be in short supply. It envisages that schools may shut, doctors be pulled out of retirement and a national emergency declared.

For Joy Young, the ever-present threat of flu is all too clear. Her partner, Ian Heap, was healthy, active, and just 41 when he died of flu the week before Christmas two years ago. He went to bed saying he might be going down with a cold, she recalls, got up next morning for work, then collapsed. He never regained consciousness and was pronounced dead - from pneumonia triggered by flu - on arrival at hospital. 'It was a shock for everyone because he was so young and so fit,' she says. Indeed, his death was so similar to the way people died in 1918, that she has since raised funds to help research into the 1918 virus - in the hope of preventing another pandemic.

Flu facts

 The flu season usually runs from November to March. So far this winter, no cases of flu have been reported in the UK, although there are plenty of flu-like viruses around.

 Flu is worse than a common cold. It attacks suddenly, usually with a headache, high temperature, general aches and a cough. For most people it is nasty but not serious. You should go to bed, drink lots of fluids and take painkillers, such as paracetamol. You should not need to see a doctor unless symptoms last more than four days, or you are elderly and frail, or have other underlying health problems. For a few people, flu can lead to more serious problems, such as bronchitis or pneumonia.

 The government is encouraging everyone over 65 to be vaccinated against flu. New anti-flu drugs, such as Relenza may soon be available on prescription for those at higher risk.

Related websites

More flu facts on the Public Health Laboratory Service website www.phls.co.uk

The UK's flu pandemic plan is at www.doh.gov.uk/pub/docs/doh/panflu.pdf

Advice on flu from NHS Direct at www.nhsdirect.nhs.uk (or call 0845 4647)

But the plan makes clear that such drugs are likely to be in short supply. It envisages that schools may shut, doctors be pulled out of retirement and a national emergency declared. For Joy Young, the ever-present threat of flu is all too clear. Her partner, Ian Heap, was healthy, active, and just 41 when he died of flu the week before Christmas two years ago. He went to bed saying he might be going down with a cold, she recalls, got up next morning for work, then collapsed. He never regained consciousness and was pronounced dead - from pneumonia triggered by flu - on arrival at hospital. 'It was a shock for everyone because he was so young and so fit,' she says. Indeed, his death was so similar to the way people died in 1918, that she has since raised funds to help research into the 1918 virus - in the hope of preventing another pandemic. Flu facts  The flu season usually runs from November to March. So far this winter, no cases of flu have been reported in the UK, although there are plenty of flu-like viruses around.  Flu is worse than a common cold. It attacks suddenly, usually with a headache, high temperature, general aches and a cough. For most people it is nasty but not serious. You should go to bed, drink lots of fluids and take painkillers, such as paracetamol. You should not need to see a doctor unless symptoms last more than four days, or you are elderly and frail, or have other underlying health problems. For a few people, flu can lead to more serious problems, such as bronchitis or pneumonia.  The government is encouraging everyone over 65 to be vaccinated against flu. New anti-flu drugs, such as Relenza may soon be available on prescription for those at higher risk. fields.headline: Go see...
fields.standfirst: ... Portsmouth's Festival of Christmas
fields.trailText: ... Portsmouth's Festival of Christmas
fields.body:
Those hankering for the nostalgia of traditional Victoriana should make their way to the south coast for Portsmouth's inaugural Festival of Christmas this week. Set in the shadow of the Mary Rose and HMS Victory , the old docks promise to become as bustling a street market as could be found during the era of another of its historic ships, HMS Warrior 1860.

True to the Victorian period, there will be hot chestnuts, costumed-carol singers, a vintage carousel and Grandfather Christmas dressed in customary green, surrounded by craftsmen making 19th-century toys, such as wooden rocking horses, teddy bears and porcelain dolls. Puppeteers, handbell ringers, knot-tiers, shanty singers, a brass ensemble, storytellers, skaters and dancers will perform throughout the dockyard.

Festival producer Annie Taylor says every effort has been made to guarantee authenticity and many of the 400 performers will be wearing costumes on loan from the BBC, National Theatre and RSC.

'We want to inspire a traditional Christmas, to get away from what has become an over-commercialised event. We want to bring back some of the nostalgia you see on an old Christmas card and to create the glowing ambience which European markets are famous for,' she says. The festival also follows the success of the bi-annual International Festival of the Sea, arranged in part by the same producers.

A village of stalls will be set up beside the boathouses with 70 traders selling food, wine and gifts with a European flavour. Elsewhere in the dockyard, a contingent of 13 French market traders will proffer an eclectic range of wares, such as dried flowers, linens, nautical clothing, delicatessen-style food and even toy trolls. A German baker will be on hand to demonstrate the age-old art of breadmaking.

All the historic ships and naval museums in Charles Dickens's hometown will be open throughout the festival. And two-hourly enactments of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert arriving in a horse-drawn landau en route to their nearby home on the Isle of Wight won't be the only royal appearance. The festival is rumoured to be the official Christmas outing of Buckingham palace staff.

 The festival starts on Thursday 30 November and runs until Sunday 3 December, from midday to 8pm each day. Admission is £6 adults, £4 children. For details and bookings, call 02392 861 533.

fields.headline: Muse house
fields.standfirst: Painter John Bratby was so obsessed with his second wife that he dressed her, painted her and covered the walls of their home with her pictures. Now, eight years after his death, Patti is moving out of the house of love
fields.trailText: Painter John Bratby was so obsessed with his second wife that he dressed her, painted her and covered the walls of their home with her pictures. Now, eight years after his death, Patti is moving out of the house of love.
fields.body:
Everywhere you look there are pictures of Patti topless. Here she's dressed in red PVC, over there she's decked out in black leather and thigh-length boots. Thousands of photographs and paintings surround you, and in all of them she's wearing red lippy and a beaming smile.

Patti Prime is moving. The house she once shared with the late artist John Bratby, as his wife and muse, has been sold, and the temple he created to her is being taken apart. Black carrier bags are lined up by the front door while indoors a gentle chaos reigns. The cats have scarpered, presumably in protest.

John Bratby was once a household name. He was the enfant terrible of the 50s who rocketed to fame at 26 with his expressionist- realist works of loos, dustbins and kitchen clutter. And Patti, whom he met through a lonely-hearts ad in Time Out after his marriage to his first wife (fellow art student Jean Cooke) fell apart, became his inspiration, obsession and number-one model. 'He did adore me,' says Patti, matter-of-factly. 'He put me on a pedestal, and I took it as my due.'

It's eight years since Bratby died, collapsing on his way home from the local chippy, but the Cupola and Tower of the Winds, the 20-room house the two of them shared for 14 years high on a hill in Hastings is largely unchanged. Patti, now 70, opens the door. Small, with short, dark curly hair and inquisitive, piercing eyes, she is framed by a jumble of photographs on the wall behind, which sweeps out from the entrance to every nook and cranny in the house. Scenes of Venice, Paris and Moscow jostle for space alongside movie stars, faded correspondence between Bratby and the rich and famous, portraits of the artist and, of course, Patti. The layers and layers of old photographs are gummed one on top of the other like old, peeling wallpaper.

It is a big, shabby, ramshackle house made intimate by the hotchpotch of colourful snaps crowding in from all sides. Canvases, several deep, are propped up against the walls. Most are small portraits from Bratby's 'Gallery of Individuals', for which he invited well-known figures of the day to sit. Paul McCartney, Tom Stoppard and Bob Hoskins were just three of the 1,500 who accepted the invitation to join Bratby's 'elitist series', which he said was 'a protest against the notion of an egalitarian society'.

The rest are mainly of Patti in front of various tourist landmarks. Vulgar, brash, fun and cheery, up to four Patties - invariably topless - appear at once on a canvas, often with the bespectacled artist in tow. Bratby, one of the most prolific painters of all time, who could knock out a portrait in a couple of hours - though often at the expense of quality - described her as posing 'like a 40s and 50s pin-up girl, with a laughing or smiling face and poses reminiscent of the style of Betty Grable'.

The paint has literally been squeezed from the tubes on to the canvas - hence the term tubism which was stamped on Bratby's later work. The colours are pure and unadulterated, giving his paintings a canvas-shaking vibrancy. Throw open Patti's wardrobe and the colours are all here, too: red, yellow, purple, green. Bratby loved dressing up his 24/7 model, and picked the colours he wanted to paint. He spent thousands of pounds on clothes for Patti, which he listed as a hobby in Who's Who, and was constantly asking her to dress up and pose ('It was not worth saying no, as he would go into a sulk'). The wardrobe he put together is flash, brassy and very 80s, packed with full-length red and black PVC and leather coats, sequins, studs, lace and fur, gold, silver and purple jackets, matching flouncy skirts and big, padded shoulders. When he found something he liked, he bought it in several colours. Patti didn't get a look in - she wasn't allowed to choose anything, but instead gave herself over to the role of artist's model. 'I had to like them, didn't I?'

Not surprisingly, she 'got tired of dressing up', and now dresses to please herself. The PVC has gone. And everything black has been consigned to the bin. 'I have never dressed up since [Bratby's death],' she says. 'I don't wear high heels, just jeans and a T-shirt.' Today is clearly an exception - though Patti style - as she's wearing a dragon- covered Issey Miyake outfit ('I have lots of them'), creating a cheerful splash of colour as she shimmers around the dusty, semi- dismantled house. Warm, friendly and chatty, she peppers her sentences with 'sweetie', 'angel', 'precious', 'my dearest love'. And every now and again you catch a glimpse of the Japanese peony tattoo called John on her shin, which used to have a partner in a tigress called Patti that Bratby wore on his arm.

'I'm a failed actress,' says Patti, who was a drama teacher when she met John in 1973. 'If you can't do, teach.' She is very self-deprecating, and you can't help thinking that she must have been swamped by Bratby's creative energy. 'I'm not good at anything,' she states, which is patently not true, given all the sensitive, up-close photographic portraits she's taken of the wild-haired Bratby, who came more and more to look like Raymond Briggs' ratbag of a Father Christmas.

In the 50s and 60s, Bratby, a Royal Academician, was constantly in the press, and the myth that grew up around him painted a wild, flamboyant, though at times contradictory image. He has been described as an extrovert, introspective, shy, sensitive, intelligent, quarrelsome, aggressive, a recluse, egotistical, belligerent and an alcoholic. He himself wrote: 'I do not love people. In fact, I may lean to misanthropy, though people fascinate me.' His public image was further confused when he produced the large-scale works needed for The Horse's Mouth in 1957, which starred Alec Guinness as a difficult, bohemian artist, a character which became associated with Bratby.

Patti sums him up as a 'shopaholic and workaholic'. 'He was volatile, vivacious, moody and grumpy,' she says. 'He thought no one liked him, but they did.' He was also a very practical person and 'a good provider'. 'If we were broke or in a muddle, he would always knock out something or get us out of it.' But with Bratby gone, 'suddenly he was not there to paint another picture', forcing Patti to look for a more modest house nearby, which will allow her to 'carry on travelling while I'm still standing'.

Bratby's career peaked in the 50s, when he was seen as a leading light in the Kitchen Sink gang, a group of artists who painted the ordinary and everyday. His pots and jars and cornflake packets established him as the granddaddy of Pop Art. Then, in 1960, he was, as he put it, 'dropped like a cold potato'. Abstract art followed by Pop Art swept in and shunted the Kitchen Sinkers to one side. At the same time, the critics turned against him. But Bratby was a great self-promoter, which many in the establishment saw as vulgar; he wrote novels and continued to paint away at a furious speed, exhibiting all over the country and selling to an ever-loyal public right up until he started to come back into fashion the year before his death. His great ridges of slapped-on paint tell of his indebtedness to Van Gogh, though he was also heavily influenced by the domesticity of Sickert's work and, initially, his subdued tones.

The couple married in 1977. Bratby's marriage to Jean had been dissolved and his affair with one of his models had come to an abrupt end. 'He tried to kill her in his Mercedes, by driving into a wall on purpose,' according to Patti, 'and that was the end of their relationship.'

The newlyweds lived a life of extreme contrasts. Most of the time they muddled along in Hastings, with the odd 'blazing row', while Bratby churned out works at a feverish pace. Then they would travel - to London, Paris or Venice - and they always travelled in style. Bratby saw a white, chauffeur-driven Roller as a must, and cabs as vulgar. They stayed in the best rooms in the best hotels, and shopped for Patti's clothes on the Champs Elysées. And if the cash got low, Bratby, the obsessively prolific artist, would simply sell another picture. Twenty-two years after they first moved in, the same Regency wallpaper remains. The stairs and windows are bare; the Bratbys never bought carpets or curtains. 'Any money we had we spent on ourselves, not on the house,' says Patti.

There's no doubt that Bratby had an obsessive personality: he was a driven man who focused his energies on art, money and Patti. He fired off bundles of letters on a weekly basis (generally written or typed by Patti, apparently, because his DT's were often too bad for him to write himself), wrote a minutely detailed diary, and kept numerous scrapbooks of his press cuttings - with all references to him helpfully marked in ink. He was also a fiercely jealous man, as far as Patti was concerned. If she met a friend in the street she'd whisper, 'Don't kiss me, John's looking.' He was even jealous of her pets. 'I had a lot of pets at one time, but had to get rid of them, as they took up too much of my time, and he was a very, very jealous person.' Patti used to have 12 doves which flew around the house's picturesque green and white cupola, until John looked up one day and saw the damage they were doing to the gutter. 'He collected the doves and drowned them in the water barrel,' says Patti, without emotion. 'He filled it with seeds and then filled it with water. I never told him I knew, but I knew, and I have never forgiven him for doing that.'

Bratby was by all accounts a big drinker and a recluse, happy to be on his own with Patti. Nobody was ever invited for dinner,' she recalls, 'he would not have anybody in the house', apart from those invited to sit for him for a few hours. This policy even extended to builders. 'If a window was broken, it would stay broken. If a tap came off in your hand, it stayed off.' They never had central heating, and Patti would go to bed during the winter months wearing a coat. His antisocial ways saw the couple up and out by 6am for their daily walk through empty streets. 'John would bring back a dead fox or a sheep's skeleton, which smelled terribly, and paint them.' Food was delivered to the door, and when Bratby wanted cider or beer he'd send a cab or Patti to pick it up.

But the Bratbys had 'a wonderful life', according to Patti, even though she says it is 'very, very hard to live on a pedestal'. They indulged in the high life, and Bratby looked after her well. He described her as 'a jazzy sort of person', and happily gave her credit for inspiring him in his work. 'All my paintings since I married Patti have been affected by her personality,' he said. He also liked her by his side at all times. 'I was always with him,' says Patti. 'He was bolted to my side. He couldn't go to the loo without me.'

She says it took her six years of mourning to finally get over his death. Bulging dustbin bags and cardboard boxes show the ruthless sorting out that is going on. An urn filled with Bratby's ashes sits above the marble and Wedgwood fireplace in the main living room and one-time studio, ready to be packed up - this is something Patti intends take with her wherever she goes. 'On my sad demise, my cousin will have a luxury holiday with her husband and take us out to a lagoon and spread us on it.' Patti admits she's 'desperate to be leaving her beautiful, happy house', but she's also determined to be positive about the future. And when a camera is pointed in her direction, she automatically goes into pose mode, beams at the camera and says, 'Give us a smile girl, give us a smile.'

fields.headline: Regional divides
fields.standfirst: Why London's losing capital
fields.trailText: Why London's losing capital
fields.body:
The other week I visited a world-class museum to see a special exhibition. Later I thought about going to the theatre, but opted to go for dinner instead - a superb Thai-style monkfish curry, thanks for asking. Some time later, I went to another world-class museum to see another special exhibition. This time I had to queue, and pay an entry fee three times higher than on the previous occasion. Later, I tried to go to the theatre, but the ticket prices were more than double those of the earlier production, though the entire run was sold out anyway. I opted to go for dinner, but our first choice was booked. The place we wound up in, after a miserable journey by Tube, cost nearly four times as much as the one above, for bog-standard salmon with indifferent vegetables.

The first case study cited above occurred in St Ives, which has a Tate, innumerable galleries, a yearly live-arts festival and an array of world-class restaurants. Everything is in walking distance, and offset by the grandeur of the Atlantic on one side and the rugged Penwith Peninsula on the other. The second case study occurred in London, which admittedly has two Tates, whose pre-eminence in all things cultural and culinary - for some, the only consolation for putting up with the filth, congestion, expense, inconveniences and irritations of life in the capital - is being challenged by a concerted fightback in what terminal Cockneys still tend to call 'the regions'. The latter now seem bent on winning the quality-of-life argument on all fronts.

There are many reasons for the turnaround. The continuing flight from the capital - population 10m 40 years ago, under 7m now - means there are hordes of ex-Londoners who don't see a move out of town as a quid pro quo; hence the free availability of Carluccio's pasta products in the depths of Norfolk, or a profusion of, say, Camper outlets in areas that, a few years ago, would have solely stocked Clark's, or, at a pinch, K's. Lottery money has also been parcelled out far and wide in a painstaking bid to avoid accusations of London-weighted elitism; furthermore, award-winning and popular new galleries in the likes of Walsall, buzz-generating one-offs like Cornwall's Eden Project, and the instant iconography of The Angel of the North have further exposed the Dome as the nation's leading Aunt Sally.

Similar populist considerations, encouraged by the government's access-all-areas arts policy, have prompted the RSC, National Theatre and Royal Ballet to adopt missionary-type Outreach programmes. The RSC's Tempest abandons the Barbican next year to civilise Barrhead, Ollerton and Dawlish; Peter Hall's 10-hour production of Tantalus , whose British premiere would once have been unthinkable anywhere but the capital, will make its debut next year in Salford. Regional theatres like the West Yorkshire Playhouse get to try out new plays without being condemned to interminable Lloyd-Webber runs to pack in the tourists and raise colossal rents. Movies have been slow to catch up, but headlines were made when the UK premiere of The Perfect Storm , with George Clooney and Mark Wahlberg in attendance, took place not in Leicester Square but in Birmingham, while Jim Carrey's Me, Myself & Irene made its British bow in Ryhl, North Wales (though, unaccountably, Carrey failed to show up). There is a raft of prestige touring art shows - such as Paul Klee in Edinburgh and an upcoming Ed Ruscha retrospective in Oxford - that leave London serenely untroubled.

All this has led to a seismic shift in perceptions; the 'here be dragons' philistinism once applied to anywhere north of Watford or west of Acton has taken a severe dent. Who'd have thought that Harvey Nichols in Leeds - the very idea drew incredulous tittering from the fashionistas before its opening - would now be outperforming its London counterpart? Or that shoals of gourmands would be making the pilgrimage to Rick Stein's piscine temples in Padstow (aka Padstein)?

And any Londoners prepared to make the ultimate cultural sacrifice and explore life beyond the M25 are returning with wondrous tales. You can book Michelin-worthy restaurants from Devon to the Lakes without re-mortgaging against a vague promise of a table half a year ahead. You can take a car secure in the knowledge that the quest for a parking space is unlikely to assume Holy Grail proportions.

This all comes at a time when the old clichés of living in London - worst-performing and most overcrowded schools, highest property prices, council taxes and rents, highest crime rates and insurance premiums, most daunting cost of making it through the day - are being confirmed on a daily basis. No wonder the out-of-town idyll is looking more attractive; while a fifth of Britons live in the country, a recent survey found that more than half of us wish we did.

Will London be reduced to a Cinderella role, moping in silence while the rest of the country whoops it up? Hardly - sheer weight of arts capacity and tradition will buoy it up - though it is in danger of slipping into not-quite-first among almost-equals. So why stay? Not long ago, I'd have said it was the only place where you could go out on a Wednesday morning and buy an almond croissant and the New Yorker and book a pair of tickets for the latest Sam Shepard revival. But now, I'm not convinced that there isn't someone in Macclesfield or Chichester or Belfast doing the same thing, with considerably less hassle.

fields.headline: The perfect adventure
fields.standfirst: Sir Ranulph Fiennes
fields.trailText: Sir Ranulph Fiennes
fields.body:
In the best of all possible worlds, I would love to find a certain lost city in Arabia, which is the sister city of one I have already found. The search is almost as thrilling as the discovery, because you're constantly about to find it.

Every expedition has setbacks to stop you being blasé. The following disasters have happened to me, but the perfect adventure would avoid as many of them as possible:

The locals would not complain that the helicopters we had brought in had frightened their goats. They tried to claim that some of the animals had died, and demanded that we pay them the equivalent of £80 per goat.

The area we chose to explore would not turn out to be highly important to the local people because there are graves there they don't want disturbed, causing them to go to the Minister of Culture to demand that the digging be stopped. This usually prompts a moratorium on the work until complainants are paid off.

The perfect team of archaeologists would not be unbelievably slow, like most archaeologists have to be. They'd put up with me using a pickaxe and shovel, rather than their usual toothbrushes, to speed up their work.

The exploration would not be staffed by volunteers from an air-force compound who were extremely pleased to see that the team comprised 18-year-old blonde archaeologists who I tried, unsuccessfully, to chaperone.

All of this would be conducted not in a blazing heat but with a perfect tropical breeze, and no nasty creepy-crawlies. Ideally, you'd have a tuneful melody maker with a guitar.

Setbacks aside, the thrill of the search is the hunt. Humans have been hunting since the beginning of time, and explorations have the same excitement.

 Ranulph Fiennes's Beyond the Limits (£20, Little, Brown) is out now

fields.headline: Violinist melts Japanese hearts
fields.standfirst: British prodigy whose 'secret' father died in air crash wins over nation in her fight for inheritance
fields.trailText: British prodigy whose 'secret' father died in air crash wins over nation in her fight for inheritance
fields.body:
A British family's battle for compensation after one of the world's worst airline disasters will move from the courtroom to the concert hall next month when 15-year-old violin prodigy Diana Yukawa makes her debut on a Japanese stage.

Yukawa, who is studying at the Royal College of Music in London, was born out of wedlock months after the death of her father in the 1985 crash of a Japan Airlines Boeing 747. The disaster claimed 520 lives.

Her performance on 11 and 12 December at the 800-seat Kioi Hall in Tokyo is the latest step in a remarkable 'coming out' by the illegitimate child whose identity was once a shameful secret in Japan, but who is now gaining public recognition for her talent and sympathy for her family's fight for compensation from JAL and Boeing.

Diana's mother, Susanne Bayly, from Wimbledon, says the recital is also the deadline for an amicable out-of-court settlement.

Diana Yukawa's father, Akihisa - a wealthy executive of Sumitomo Bank - was married to a Japanese woman, but had been involved with Bayly for almost 10 years before a jumbo jet he was travelling on plunged into a mountain north-west of Tokyo.

Bayly did not seek compensation at the time because their romance, along with the existence of Diana and her elder sister Cassie, now a talented pianist, had been kept secret. In Japan ainoko, or illegitimate children, still carry a strong stigma.

Instead, she accepted an offer of private financial support from Yukawa's family, who wanted to avoid public disgrace. Part of the money was used to pay for Diana's violin lessons.

These funds dried up last year, prompting Bayly to start a public battle to have her daughters' identity and right to compensation recognised.

Using DNA testing, she won a ruling from the High Court in Britain in March that legally acknowledged Akihisa as the father of Diana and Cassie. This would have made them entitled to a payout under British law.

JAL, however, insisted the compensation issue was settled with Yukawa's Japanese family. Initially, the airline offered only a scholarship award, worth less than £300 a month to each child.

This was rejected by Diana and Cassie's legal team, headed in Britain by Michael Napier, who earned a reputation as a leading 'disaster lawyer' during cases related to the Manchester air crash in 1985 and the Lockerbie bombing in 1988.

He says the two illegitimate British girls should be entitled to the same compensation given to Yukawa's two legitimate Japanese sons: £900,000.

Diana's ability to play on the heartstrings of the Japanese public has put further pressure on JAL and Boeing - which has accepted partial responsibility for the accident - to reach a compromise.

Diana rose to national prominence on the fifteenth anniversary of the crash on 12 August, when she joined the annual pilgrimage of bereaved families to the Osutaka mountainside where the plane came down. In images broadcast across the nation, she played her violin in front of a shrine to her father.

The following month, Diana released her debut CD, which was dedicated to the father she never met. It was a mixture of classical master pieces and works related to the crash, such as 'Elegy', which was composed by the relative of one of the victims. The CD has sold 25,000 copies. More sales and publicity are likely after next month's recitals, which will be broadcast live by the state-run NHK channel. 'This girl is like an angel. I can almost see her wings,' said composer Shoichi Makino.

Such comments and the emphasis on Diana's purity and innocence by the Japanese media have made it difficult for JAL and Boeing to play hardball.

Her teacher, Rodney Friend, a professor at the Royal College of Music, said it was not only sympathy for Diana that had helped her achieve prominence.

'Her recording is the best by any British violinist of the present time in terms of technique and emotion,' he said.

Since Diana began playing her violin in Japan, sources close to the compensation negotiations say JAL has raised its offer to 10 million yen (about £60,000). The airline said it was not prepared to comment while legal talks were unresolved.

'Our financial situation is so bad that Diana is selling her violin to pay for her lessons,' Bayly said. 'We have patiently waited for JAL to do the right thing, but everyone has a limit. If there isn't a positive offer from JAL while we are in Tokyo, then Diana will speak out at the press conference after the recital.'

webTitle: Letters: Dwell we but in the suburbs

fields.headline: Dwell we but in the suburbs
fields.trailText: It doesn't sound as though Simon Fanshawe has visited either a village or a suburb recently (Comment, last week). He can't possibly have done if he believes that they are typically represented by security compounds of expensive sub-Georgian houses or that villagers subsist entirely on the produce of local farms.
fields.body:
It doesn't sound as though Simon Fanshawe has visited either a village or a suburb recently (Comment, last week). He can't possibly have done if he believes that they are typically represented by security compounds of expensive sub-Georgian houses or that villagers subsist entirely on the produce of local farms. Outside the M25, where sensible people live, your typical suburban house is a 1930s semi with bay windows and a small rose-bed in the front lawn and we villagers queue up for shopping in the local Tesco or Sainsbury's.

There is a case to be made for city living. It is a superb place to live if you're in your thirties, have no children and can earn a very nice whack writing easy tosh for the quality press. For the rest of us, cities are insane places to live.
Peter Sampson
Woodbridge, Suffolk

 Simon Fanshawe puzzles me. He writes that '84 per cent of people in the UK want to live in a small village'. What is his evidence? He goes on to be quite nasty about Laura Ashley and Beatrix Potter. I particularly resent his implying that Beatrix Potter represents suburban bad taste. She was an original and imaginative artist.
Penelope Maclachlan
London W7

 Simon Franshaw's emotional attack on the suburb requires an objective response. Apart from the haven of respite and repose from the stress of the city, suburbs offer significant habitats to bird and wildlife (identified by RSPB research). From an architectural perspective, many suburbs incorporate some of Britain's finest late-Victorian and Edwardian domestic architecture, an important part of our declining architectural heritage. Long may they flourish and enrich our lives.
Grant Pitches
Leicester

webTitle: Baby boomers simply refuse to grow up

fields.headline: Baby boomers simply refuse to grow up
fields.standfirst: Being 50 today means you can be whatever you want. And that needn't be 'forever young'
fields.trailText: Being 50 today means you can be whatever you want. And that needn't be 'forever young' writes Yvonne Roberts.
fields.body:
Age is the new youth and retirement promises to be a second dose of adolescence. According to a report out this week, Fit and Fifty, not only are today's fiftysomethings breathing unaided, they may well be turning into 'Kevins', casting off jumpers and slippers in favour of clubbing or climbing gear, and - the safest sex of all - learning to love themselves through self-development and 'personal creativity'.

Professor Richard Scase of Kent University, one of the co-authors of the study produced for the Government's Economic and Social Research Council, says fiftysomethings are 'adopting more self-focused hedonistic attitudes as they imitate younger ways of living - they expect to retire in their fifties and have another 30 years ahead of them.'

The report follows an announcement that BBC2 is to reposition itself and target a 35- to 55-year-old audience with a more 'mature' (presumably as in 'young mature') format. Over on BBC1, half the nation has been watching silver-haired folk fornicating on EastEnders, and suddenly, old - as in 50-plus - is no longer deemed ugly, toothless, sexless, incontinent, senile, confused and helpless.

Yet the way in which the media, the advertising industry and academics are now cackhandedly trying to redefine this age group paradoxically underlines how strong is our continuing obsession with youth.

The baby boomers have, of course, struck again. Anthropologist Helen Fisher says: 'They travel through society like a guinea pig moving through a python, changing culture as they grow older.' Note, changing culture - not hankering to turn the clock back to their youth. The baby boomers created the teenager, furnished suburbia with Habitat and have now reached the 'November of the body'. The 50-plus group makes up one in three of the population. By 2040 they will account for half.

A proportion of older people will continue to face poverty - particularly women forced to rely on inadequate state and private pensions and those crippled by life-long low pay - but many more will have the cash to amuse themselves to death, if they so choose.

Neil Jenner heads the London branch of the marketing firm Senioragency which focuses on the 50-plus group. In Britain, he says, this group has an annual income of £166bn, and this will rise to £260bn in 20 years.

On average, the 50-plus market has a 30 per cent higher disposable income than the under-50s - yet 90 per cent of all advertising is directed at the young.

'Youth! Youth! There is absolutely nothing in the world but youth!' wrote Oscar Wilde in The Picture of Dorian Grey - and that's precisely how it appears in millennium Britain. Youth rules, so ageism is rife. A study published in April discovered that the Government's voluntary code of practice on age diversity is ignored by two out of three employers. The over-35s are paid less, trained less and regarded already as 'off-peak'. Experience counts for little.

In Beyond Power, Women, Men and Morals, Marilyn French writes: 'The best intentioned efforts to solve human problems falter or fail because they are dyed in the same patterns of thinking that created the problem.' So the 'problem' of age today is viewed as the absence of youth, and the answer is to bring about its restoration. Hence, marketing to the newly retired as if they were born-again twentysomethings - what Jenner, despairing of the advertising industry's lack of imagination, calls 'the grey surfers'.

The obsession with youth underestimates another important difference in the baby boomer generation: people may accrue the same number of years yet be in very different places in their respective life cycles. The parents of today's fiftysomethings courted in their teens, and married in their early twenties, then in their forties saw their own children wed. Then they retired in their sixties. Now, divorce, separation, delayed parenthood, women in the workplace and job insecurity means the traditional cards in the game of Happy Families have been drastically reshuffled.

Life has a far less conventional pattern. Men may marry for the first time in their thirties; women may have their first child in their forties. Others may retire 15 years earlier than their parents did.

Yet in the arts, media and marketplace the portrayal of fiftysomethings often bears no hint of this change. The 'new' old are either relegated to the walk-in bath and chair-lift zone of life or treated to 'role models' such as Joan Collins and Cliff Richard, time bandits frozen at 40.

Perhaps revenge is at hand. Soon the 50-plus age group will make up the majority of consumers - and what will the admen do then? Kath Harris, associate director of RDSi, which undertakes 'grey market studies', this month published a report on the common characteristics of the nouveau grise whom, she concedes, do not profess a desire to be forever young.

Harris calls the baby boomer grey generation 'a child in time', sandwiched between the austerity of their parents' generation and the consumerism of their children. They dislike the actual process of aging but lack 'ambition or aspiration to acquire consumer goods. Identity is rarely played out through the conspicuous adoption of brands as symbols of what they aspire to be.'

In short, they may have the dosh but they have no desire to spend it to keep up with the junior Joneses, or to point up who they are.

Perhaps we're about to discover that with longevity may also come a revival of that old hippy resistance to materialism, acquisitiveness and competitiveness?

Forecasters such as the Henley Centre tell us that we already live in 'the experience culture' in which knowledge, exploration and exercise matter more than the acquisition of objects. We already have 'format fatigue', moving, in music for example, from vinyl to cassette, to CD and then finally losing interest. As consumers we travel from insatiable to discerning and then become saturated.

At the same time as becoming jaded consumers, many in the 50-plus group, by choice or circumstance, are marginalised in the workplace and find themselves divorced from what are supposed to be the driving forces in a capitalist society - power and status. According to research, the new greys don't mourn the absence of either. If they have sufficient income and their responsibilities are manageable, they may become more comfortable with themselves, more spiritual and care less what others think. They have little to prove, so they embark on life as a 'long vacation' and cease to be big spenders.

So when will we see these changes in attitudes, priorities and behaviour portrayed in the media, advertising, films and popular culture? When will the fiftysomethings and, for that matter, the sixtysomethings cease to be regarded as embarrassing reminders of waning faculties? When will they be offered not a playpen and an invitation to relive their youth but a truer reflection of their many and varied selves?
fields.bodyText: Age is the new youth and retirement promises to be a second dose of adolescence. According to a report out this week, Fit and Fifty, not only are today's fiftysomethings breathing unaided, they may well be turning into 'Kevins', casting off jumpers and slippers in favour of clubbing or climbing gear, and - the safest sex of all - learning to love themselves through self-development and 'personal creativity'. Professor Richard Scase of Kent University, one of the co-authors of the study produced for the Government's Economic and Social Research Council, says fiftysomethings are 'adopting more self-focused hedonistic attitudes as they imitate younger ways of living - they expect to retire in their fifties and have another 30 years ahead of them.' The report follows an announcement that BBC2 is to reposition itself and target a 35- to 55-year-old audience with a more 'mature' (presumably as in 'young mature') format. Over on BBC1, half the nation has been watching silver-haired folk fornicating on EastEnders, and suddenly, old - as in 50-plus - is no longer deemed ugly, toothless, sexless, incontinent, senile, confused and helpless. Yet the way in which the media, the advertising industry and academics are now cackhandedly trying to redefine this age group paradoxically underlines how strong is our continuing obsession with youth. The baby boomers have, of course, struck again. Anthropologist Helen Fisher says: 'They travel through society like a guinea pig moving through a python, changing culture as they grow older.' Note, changing culture - not hankering to turn the clock back to their youth. The baby boomers created the teenager, furnished suburbia with Habitat and have now reached the 'November of the body'. The 50-plus group makes up one in three of the population. By 2040 they will account for half. A proportion of older people will continue to face poverty - particularly women forced to rely on inadequate state and private pensions and those crippled by life-long low pay - but many more will have the cash to amuse themselves to death, if they so choose. Neil Jenner heads the London branch of the marketing firm Senioragency which focuses on the 50-plus group. In Britain, he says, this group has an annual income of £166bn, and this will rise to £260bn in 20 years. On average, the 50-plus market has a 30 per cent higher disposable income than the under-50s - yet 90 per cent of all advertising is directed at the young. 'Youth! Youth! There is absolutely nothing in the world but youth!' wrote Oscar Wilde in The Picture of Dorian Grey - and that's precisely how it appears in millennium Britain. Youth rules, so ageism is rife. A study published in April discovered that the Government's voluntary code of practice on age diversity is ignored by two out of three employers. The over-35s are paid less, trained less and regarded already as 'off-peak'. Experience counts for little. In Beyond Power, Women, Men and Morals, Marilyn French writes: 'The best intentioned efforts to solve human problems falter or fail because they are dyed in the same patterns of thinking that created the problem.' So the 'problem' of age today is viewed as the absence of youth, and the answer is to bring about its restoration. Hence, marketing to the newly retired as if they were born-again twentysomethings - what Jenner, despairing of the advertising industry's lack of imagination, calls 'the grey surfers'. The obsession with youth underestimates another important difference in the baby boomer generation: people may accrue the same number of years yet be in very different places in their respective life cycles. The parents of today's fiftysomethings courted in their teens, and married in their early twenties, then in their forties saw their own children wed. Then they retired in their sixties. Now, divorce, separation, delayed parenthood, women in the workplace and job insecurity means the traditional cards in the game of Happy Families have been drastically reshuffled. Life has a far less conventional pattern. Men may marry for the first time in their thirties; women may have their first child in their forties. Others may retire 15 years earlier than their parents did. Yet in the arts, media and marketplace the portrayal of fiftysomethings often bears no hint of this change. The 'new' old are either relegated to the walk-in bath and chair-lift zone of life or treated to 'role models' such as Joan Collins and Cliff Richard, time bandits frozen at 40. Perhaps revenge is at hand. Soon the 50-plus age group will make up the majority of consumers - and what will the admen do then? Kath Harris, associate director of RDSi, which undertakes 'grey market studies', this month published a report on the common characteristics of the nouveau grise whom, she concedes, do not profess a desire to be forever young. Harris calls the baby boomer grey generation 'a child in time', sandwiched between the austerity of their parents' generation and the consumerism of their children. They dislike the actual process of aging but lack 'ambition or aspiration to acquire consumer goods. Identity is rarely played out through the conspicuous adoption of brands as symbols of what they aspire to be.' In short, they may have the dosh but they have no desire to spend it to keep up with the junior Joneses, or to point up who they are. Perhaps we're about to discover that with longevity may also come a revival of that old hippy resistance to materialism, acquisitiveness and competitiveness? Forecasters such as the Henley Centre tell us that we already live in 'the experience culture' in which knowledge, exploration and exercise matter more than the acquisition of objects. We already have 'format fatigue', moving, in music for example, from vinyl to cassette, to CD and then finally losing interest. As consumers we travel from insatiable to discerning and then become saturated. At the same time as becoming jaded consumers, many in the 50-plus group, by choice or circumstance, are marginalised in the workplace and find themselves divorced from what are supposed to be the driving forces in a capitalist society - power and status. According to research, the new greys don't mourn the absence of either. If they have sufficient income and their responsibilities are manageable, they may become more comfortable with themselves, more spiritual and care less what others think. They have little to prove, so they embark on life as a 'long vacation' and cease to be big spenders. So when will we see these changes in attitudes, priorities and behaviour portrayed in the media, advertising, films and popular culture? When will the fiftysomethings and, for that matter, the sixtysomethings cease to be regarded as embarrassing reminders of waning faculties? When will they be offered not a playpen and an invitation to relive their youth but a truer reflection of their many and varied selves?

fields.headline: What a duo - Dylan and Liberace
fields.trailText:
Rambert Dance Company
Sadler's Wells, London EC1
fields.body:
Rambert Dance Company Sadler's Wells, London EC1

Ripeness is all, as the Rambert company nears its seventy-fifth anniversary next year. Mature dancers were celebrated in the second programme at the Wells, with Christopher Bruce making a comeback in his own work to Bob Dylan songs, Moonshine. It was one of three London premieres showing company members in a new light.

Moonshine was created for the older dancers of Nederlands Dans Theater 3 in 1993. The words of the songs, Dylan's harmonica and Walter Nobbe's designs place the action in the United States, although the four travellers with their battered suitcases could be weary performers on the road to anywhere. Bruce presents himself as the rheumy grandpa of the troupe - a game old soak drowning his aches and memories in bourbon.

Sheron Wray is a blaze of vitality as the optimist who won't stay down. Hope Muir has the tricky role of the woman who reaches the end of her tether and hangs herself. Of all the stories on stage and in the songs, hers is told rather than lived. Bruce's folk-based vocabulary otherwise serves as graphic shorthand for the rage and resignation of people running out of options.

Javier de Frutos picks up the theme of dead-end disillusion in his new work, The Celebrated Soubrette. Elizabeth Old, veteran ingénue, enters cruelly toplit, scantily clad. We are voyeurs of her private ritual as she pre pares for a performance. Gazing at us as if into a mirror, she checks on her least favourite body parts and tries out her overworked legs. When the chorus line arrives for the bump-and-grind routines, Old is designated dance-captain, in charge of keeping this show on the road.

The music is Michael Daugherty's Le Tombeau de Liberace , a tribute to the flamboyant pianist in numbers entitled 'Rhinestone Kickstep', 'Candelabra Rhumba' and 'Sequin Music'. Chorus boys and girls are dressed alike in glittering outfits, muscular thighs encased in fishnet tights. Everytime they gang up together, their unison glory soon fragments into spats, tics and hissy fits. There is a dark side to every spangle, a vulnerable child beneath each preening narcissist.

Hoofers on the verge of a nervous breakdown, they let loose a flurry of ballottés , the prancing step that is Giselle's motif. Like her, these brazen hussies have delicate souls. De Frutos's satirical scalpel, however, is blunt, his sympathy for showbiz casualties clouded. The dancers expose themselves gallantly, but they need the vocal music to which de Frutos is addicted to make their agonies plain. Only Old is a fully-rounded character, a low-life Venus who could have survived from an early Rambert classic, Antony Tudor's Judgment of Paris .

Didy Veldman's 7Ds, the programme opener, is a contemporary take on the Seven Deadly Sins. Instead of using Brecht's caustic lyrics, she commissioned a chatty electronic score from Luca Mainardi. The sinners are daughters of Eve, who started it all with a ripe apple. Pride comes before the Fall; greed and gluttony, indistinguishable, involve shards of apple and shavings of grass.

Lust, interestingly, is a solo sin; the writhing woman covers her face with her costume top, anonymous in her need - or shame. She ends with her head in a noose, disconcertingly like the suicide in Bruce's Moonshine . But the wire loop is only a device to introduce sloth, as the dancers dangle idly from harnesses. Veldman lurches between literal and symbolic, trying to show female failings through movement alone.

Since there is no moral to be drawn, the deadliest sin becomes that of ennui: who cares whether we can identify anger or envy, so long as the raucous music stops?

webTitle: Literary fireworks? Just a few sparklers and a lot of damp squibs

fields.headline: Literary fireworks? Just a few sparklers and a lot of damp squibs
fields.trailText: As with London's millennium eve 'River of Fire' so, in the world of books, the year 2000 was the year of damp squibs
fields.body:
As with London's millennium eve 'River of Fire' so, in the world of books, the year 2000 was the year of damp squibs. Almost none of the advertised literary fireworks ignited quite as promised. Some big rockets failed to soar; impressive-looking Roman candles turned out to be penny sparklers; several Catherine wheels simply refused to spin. Those few attractions that did live up to their advance billing failed to spark the popular imagination. There was no big literary sensation, though Philip Pullman's The Amber Spyglass (Scholastic) did manage to illuminate the early winter sky.

The year opened with Zadie Smith's White Teeth (Hamish Hamilton), an exceptional debut whose critical réclame was not matched by the glittering trajectory of literary awards so many had predicted. The prizes, too, did not function as expected. The Orange Prize, for instance, was awarded to Linda Grant's When I Lived in Modern Times (Granta), but it was Orange's lavish hospitality and some ill-founded accusations of plagiarism that made the headlines.

Another disappointment was the performance of those authors whose fame has made them into a kind of commodity: Michael Ondaatje, John Updike, Doris Lessing and Muriel Spark. Each of these literary brands was respectfully reviewed, but without much excitement.

The other big, brand-name performance came from Amis plc. For most of May, it was virtually impossible to avoid reading about either Kingsley's Letters (Collins) or Martin's Experience (Cape). These, of course, were filed in the book shops under autobiography not fiction. If there were real fictional fireworks, they came from across the Atlantic. For The Observer, the outstanding new book of the year was Dave Eggers's A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius (Picador). Among the American veterans, Saul Bellow's Ravelstein (Viking) and Philip Roth's The Human Stain (Cape) were both incandescent performances. At home, there were some predictable reviewing explosions. Two new writers, fiercely hyped, were subjected to an equally fierce retribution. After his publishers had risked Proustian comparisons, Paul Golding's The Abomination (Picador) was likened, not inappropriately, to masturbation. After the longest countdown in rocket science, James Thackera, author of The Book of Kings (Duckworth), blazed briefly and faded away.

Even those professionally committed to drumming up enthusiasm - for example, the Booker Prize chairman, Simon Jenkins - could not deny that it had been a 'disappointing' year. That didn't stop his panel from risking all by short-listing no less than four so-called 'unknowns' (Michael Collins, Trezza Azzopardi, Matthew Kneale and Brian O'Doherty) for our premier literary prize. Having taken this leap into the dark, the jurors then equipped themselves with Very lights and parachutes, bumping down to earth with the predictable, and disappointingly conventional, choice of Margaret Atwood's The Blind Assassin (Bloomsbury).

So the Booker Prize failed to ignite much of a debate about the state of English language fiction, though others tried. Two 'unknowns' - Matt Thorne and Nicholas Blincoe - made a few sparks fly with their polemical anthology of new writing, All Hail the New Puritans (Fourth Estate), but failed to achieve lift-off. Much more luminous was Nick Hornby's Speaking With the Angel (Penguin), a marvellous anthology of new fiction that demonstrated the magic of good storytelling, and a way with language and character.
