webTitle: Television: One foot in the gravy

fields.headline: One foot in the gravy
fields.standfirst: As Victor bowed out, Judith Keppel became the nation's sweetheart. Unless you worked for Auntie
fields.trailText: As Victor bowed out, Judith Keppel became the nation's sweetheart. Unless you worked for Auntie
fields.body:
I Don't Believe It! The One Foot in the Grave Story/One Foot in the Grave BBC1

Who Wants to be a Millionaire? ITV

Hidden Love: A Girl's Best Friend C4

Rory Bremner Special: My Government and I C4

Conquistadors BBC2

Of the five things we British are by law meant to find 'funny' but which are, in fact, significantly less funny than savage rectal polyps, the first three places must go to slapstick, catchphrases and men dressing up as women. (Dennis Norden, since you ask - in twice at numbers four and five, just to be sure.)

So it was a shame that BBC1 chose to precede the last-ever episode of One Foot in the Grave with a montage of 'fondly remembered moments' which seemed to consist wholly of Victor turning pratfalls, Victor mouthing his catchphrase and Victor stripping off, if not actually cross-dressing, all inexplicably backwashed by the sound of a flock of geese being sick with laughter.

A shame because it was a silly, misleading testament to a more subtle, subfusc, funnier and kinder creation.

It was almost impossible to reconcile the endless clips of jokes about pubic hair with the obvious respect accorded the show from the likes of Eric Idle and Paul Merton, and the thoughtful retrospections of Richard Wilson and Annette Crosbie (no one, of course, captures Middle England better than middle-class Scots. Think of Tony Blair). The one genuine belly-laugh came tellingly in a borrowed clip from C4's Father Ted, when Dougal and Ted spot Wilson in a crowd and dare each other to ask him to do his catchphrase ('Sure Ted he'll be pleased... I bet no one ever asks him that'). A shame because, despite the moving, awkward final episode that followed, this retrospective showed, again, that BBC1's corporate feel for its audience is clumsy and simplistic.

While C4 invites us to enjoy the bovine catchphrase-fixation of Dougal, the loveliest stupid man in the world, BBC1 actually thinks its audience is the most stupid, biddable man in the world, and forgets the nine out of 10 of its viewers - intelligent, complex fans of the show - who are staring at the screen in all faith but not actually laughing. There was also, of course, the grim, self-congratulatory boastfulness now peculiar to this channel. The 'Auntie' nickname has recently confused me: aunts are, likely as not, far more sharp, surprising and knowing than their stereotypes, with secret lesbian lovers and a penchant for Lebanese gold and Hilaire Belloc. BBC2 can still fit the bill. But BBC1 seems increasingly like the fat, spoilt, young cousin in the corner, endlessly banging out 'Chopsticks' with stubby adipocere fingers, badly, and shouting about it between clouds of flatus.

And petulant. 'One doesn't want to be cynical,' said a BBC1 insider of the 'fix' that scheduled the first full Who Wants to be a Millionaire? winner against Victor's death. So why give cowardly anonymous press briefings? I can't believe ITV wanted the news leaked, since now we assume we don't have to watch it all the time, merely wait for the papers to tell us the next big winner.

Still, this one was worth watching, not least for the wonderful body-language as Judith Keppel - gamely trying, like the Queen Mum in the Blitz, to go along with the cattle-class long enough to take their plaudits - pretended she wasn't quietly squirming free from Chris Tarrant's slobbering, congratulatory lunges. That stuff's for the prole scum, Chris, the catchphrase crowd. Judith, with one foot in the gravy already, is the kind to which you may offer contact - two cheek-kisses and a soft hand on the shoulder - only if you have known her since prep or fathered a smattering of her children.

But this apart, Judith, a 'gardener from Fulham' in the same way Hardy Amies is a 'tailor from Maida Vale', was surprisingly game - sweetly unashamed of her accent, her knowledge, her difference. She guessed and gambled cleverly, wittily, determinedly.

Far from the show having 'dumbed down', the evening's questions seemed explicitly designed to frustrate the very Lottery classes the programme purportedly wants to win. Judith knew about Eleanor of Aquitaine because she'd recently visited the grave in France; knew about 'squabs' because she'd eaten them in America (which she just refrained from calling the New World).

If there was any 'fix' going on, it was the rather larger one that conspires still to make a private education better than a state one: it's wrong, but it's undeniable.

Her triumph, celebrated through a quiet hug with her daughter rather than the howling cartoonish St Vitus' dance the producers might have preferred, should by rights spark new national catchphrases. 'Oh, bless you.' 'Ah, now I know that one, darling.' Or, mugged silently, 'I'll thank you to remove your hands from my personage; I am no more likely to swoon than I am to start armpit-squelching We Are the Champions.'

Had we been able to ask the female members of that audience which electronic goods they spent money on last year, three times as many would have answered 'a vibrator' as 'a dishwasher'. Maybe not - though I'd love to have seen the graph light up - but this is what we were told by Juliet Stevenson as she drily narrated A Girl's Best Friend, a rather well-made, if ultimately unhelpful, documentary on what used to be known as marital aids and which now come in astonishing designer shapes and sizes (including several blue ones which seemed, mildly disturbingly, modelled exactly on the nose of the old Cresta bear).

There was bravery in facing the cameras, particularly from young stroke victim Sue Dobson, who spoke gleefully about the joy in rediscovering her sexuality after six years trying to be a 'proper' - ie numb - disabled woman, laughing before anyone else could at the idea of the 'tart in a cart'.

The presentation was light but sensibly devoid of nudges and winks: any humour, other than genuine girly laughter, was quite unintentional. Forces' wife Emily, for instance, whose husband bought her a vibrator for his long months away, 'told me that he'd modelled it on himself. It looked just like a penis, it had veins, it was made of latex and it could move' - which had me more than usually worried about the British Army, until I realised she meant he'd modelled it on his penis . Probably.

But, in the end, rather than putting to rest 'one of society's last taboos', that of women and masturbation, this programme left the male viewer, at least, just as con fused as before, if not more so. The first half comprised assertions of how much better it could be than sex with a man - the thrill of a battery-driven buzz at speeds which no hands, male or female, could ever manage, the inch-perfect control and, as Kathryn Hoyle of suppliers Sh! , said - extremely wisely, I'm told - 'the absence, ever, of that feeling that you're taking too long; for as soon as that thought enters your head any connection with your clitoris is gone and you might as well just give him a kiss and stop'.

So far, so happy. But then, in the last segment, the very same women began talking about the inherent sadness of vibrator-only sex: the occasional tears afterwards, the need for someone to hold you, the faint feeling of futility. The overall impression was that if the 'real' orgasm is a petit mort, then the self-generated orgasm is a kind of petit suicid e. Which made it an honest but a confusing programme. Either this kind of sex is liberating or it's faintly demeaning - it can't really be both. But a wise piece of filming anyway, mercifully free from open sexual gloating, and myriad shots of dildos were done tastefully enough to discourage any cheap, unreconstructed smirks. Though they all seemed so small...

Tony Blair is finally getting Rory Bremner right. His Question Time performance on Wednesday was a practically inch-perfect simulacrum of Bremner's Sunday night hour-long special. Unfortunately, the PM had the better script.

Michael Wood's Conquistadors held from the start and gripped tighter than death throes. Traipsing wistfully through Mexico's woeful history, he somehow managed to conjure up the very stench of dried blood and flowers and chocolate: steel and skulls and tears fall in the mud beneath the inspired inhumanity of Hernán Cortez - 'It is given to few people in history,' as Hall put it - 'single-handedly to destroy a civilisation', and will continue to do so for the next five gripping Friday nights for those of us not at the pub quiz.

 Kathryn Flett is away.

The 'Auntie' nickname has recently confused me: aunts are, likely as not, far more sharp, surprising and knowing than their stereotypes, with secret lesbian lovers and a penchant for Lebanese gold and Hilaire Belloc. BBC2 can still fit the bill. But BBC1 seems increasingly like the fat, spoilt, young cousin in the corner, endlessly banging out 'Chopsticks' with stubby adipocere fingers, badly, and shouting about it between clouds of flatus. And petulant. 'One doesn't want to be cynical,' said a BBC1 insider of the 'fix' that scheduled the first full Who Wants to be a Millionaire? winner against Victor's death. So why give cowardly anonymous press briefings? I can't believe ITV wanted the news leaked, since now we assume we don't have to watch it all the time, merely wait for the papers to tell us the next big winner. Still, this one was worth watching, not least for the wonderful body-language as Judith Keppel - gamely trying, like the Queen Mum in the Blitz, to go along with the cattle-class long enough to take their plaudits - pretended she wasn't quietly squirming free from Chris Tarrant's slobbering, congratulatory lunges. That stuff's for the prole scum, Chris, the catchphrase crowd. Judith, with one foot in the gravy already, is the kind to which you may offer contact - two cheek-kisses and a soft hand on the shoulder - only if you have known her since prep or fathered a smattering of her children. But this apart, Judith, a 'gardener from Fulham' in the same way Hardy Amies is a 'tailor from Maida Vale', was surprisingly game - sweetly unashamed of her accent, her knowledge, her difference. She guessed and gambled cleverly, wittily, determinedly. Far from the show having 'dumbed down', the evening's questions seemed explicitly designed to frustrate the very Lottery classes the programme purportedly wants to win. Judith knew about Eleanor of Aquitaine because she'd recently visited the grave in France; knew about 'squabs' because she'd eaten them in America (which she just refrained from calling the New World). If there was any 'fix' going on, it was the rather larger one that conspires still to make a private education better than a state one: it's wrong, but it's undeniable. Her triumph, celebrated through a quiet hug with her daughter rather than the howling cartoonish St Vitus' dance the producers might have preferred, should by rights spark new national catchphrases. 'Oh, bless you.' 'Ah, now I know that one, darling.' Or, mugged silently, 'I'll thank you to remove your hands from my personage; I am no more likely to swoon than I am to start armpit-squelching We Are the Champions.' Had we been able to ask the female members of that audience which electronic goods they spent money on last year, three times as many would have answered 'a vibrator' as 'a dishwasher'. Maybe not - though I'd love to have seen the graph light up - but this is what we were told by Juliet Stevenson as she drily narrated A Girl's Best Friend, a rather well-made, if ultimately unhelpful, documentary on what used to be known as marital aids and which now come in astonishing designer shapes and sizes (including several blue ones which seemed, mildly disturbingly, modelled exactly on the nose of the old Cresta bear). There was bravery in facing the cameras, particularly from young stroke victim Sue Dobson, who spoke gleefully about the joy in rediscovering her sexuality after six years trying to be a 'proper' - ie numb - disabled woman, laughing before anyone else could at the idea of the 'tart in a cart'. The presentation was light but sensibly devoid of nudges and winks: any humour, other than genuine girly laughter, was quite unintentional. Forces' wife Emily, for instance, whose husband bought her a vibrator for his long months away, 'told me that he'd modelled it on himself. It looked just like a penis, it had veins, it was made of latex and it could move' - which had me more than usually worried about the British Army, until I realised she meant he'd modelled it on his penis . Probably. But, in the end, rather than putting to rest 'one of society's last taboos', that of women and masturbation, this programme left the male viewer, at least, just as con fused as before, if not more so. The first half comprised assertions of how much better it could be than sex with a man - the thrill of a battery-driven buzz at speeds which no hands, male or female, could ever manage, the inch-perfect control and, as Kathryn Hoyle of suppliers Sh! , said - extremely wisely, I'm told - 'the absence, ever, of that feeling that you're taking too long; for as soon as that thought enters your head any connection with your clitoris is gone and you might as well just give him a kiss and stop'. So far, so happy. But then, in the last segment, the very same women began talking about the inherent sadness of vibrator-only sex: the occasional tears afterwards, the need for someone to hold you, the faint feeling of futility. The overall impression was that if the 'real' orgasm is a petit mort, then the self-generated orgasm is a kind of petit suicid e. Which made it an honest but a confusing programme. Either this kind of sex is liberating or it's faintly demeaning - it can't really be both. But a wise piece of filming anyway, mercifully free from open sexual gloating, and myriad shots of dildos were done tastefully enough to discourage any cheap, unreconstructed smirks. Though they all seemed so small... Tony Blair is finally getting Rory Bremner right. His Question Time performance on Wednesday was a practically inch-perfect simulacrum of Bremner's Sunday night hour-long special. Unfortunately, the PM had the better script. Michael Wood's Conquistadors held from the start and gripped tighter than death throes. Traipsing wistfully through Mexico's woeful history, he somehow managed to conjure up the very stench of dried blood and flowers and chocolate: steel and skulls and tears fall in the mud beneath the inspired inhumanity of Hernán Cortez - 'It is given to few people in history,' as Hall put it - 'single-handedly to destroy a civilisation', and will continue to do so for the next five gripping Friday nights for those of us not at the pub quiz.  Kathryn Flett is away.

fields.headline: Opera by any other name?
fields.trailText:
Italian Triple Bill/ ENO
Coliseum, London WC2
fields.body:
Italian Triple Bill/ ENO
Coliseum, London WC2

English National Opera's Italian Oddities season, as it should logically have been called, reached virtual topsy-turviness last week. Dallapiccola's The Prisoner (1949) formed the major part of a new triple bill. The other two works were not operas. One was a version of a film score, the other a group of folk songs for solo voice. Not that we need be strait-laced about terminology. Opera is a word of vague origin covering a multitude of sins and inviting a variety of spin. But it's fair to say that generally most people know what they think opera is and that by the light of even a loose trades' descriptions act it should tend to contain some singing. You might even say, risking ridicule, it is likely to be some variant of a sung play.

But why confine oneself? ENO likes to extend frontiers. Last season the company staged Bach's St John Passion (plenty of action there, some might say) and a Janacek song cycle. This year, as part of the centenary of Verdi - who wrote nearly 30 operas - they will stage his Requiem. Not that the Latin Mass doesn't have its strengths as a libretto. Why stop there? What about his string quartet, with all those aria-like violin tunes and ominous, off-beat theatrical cello figures? Most opera-goers have probably never heard it. Then there's his Romanza senza parole , one of only two piano pieces he wrote. At least it contains the warning label that words will not get in the way of things. The only drawback, for an opera house, is that no one opens their mouth in song.

Yet on last week's evidence such niceties no longer apply. Anything goes. Coming soon, full stagings of Beethoven symphonies, Scarlatti's harpsichord sonatas, the complete orchestral works of Boulez and even the film scores of Fellini. Just kidding. Surely no impoverished British opera house would risk their Arts Council grant with ... but no, I've lost the plot again. Here, in the middle of a triple bill, was an orches tral suite of the ballet version of the film score by Nino Rota for Fellini's La Strada. Thirty very charming children ran, skipped, cartwheeled around the stage and ate ice-cream for what seemed a very long time and then stopped.

In the programme note the director, Neil Armfield, writes rather lamely that the piece was done at his suggestion, 'using it as an opportunity for a group of children to play on the stage of the Coliseum'. Those who were paying, rather than playing, must have been delighted. The idea could be extended to, say, the centre court at Wimbledon or Lord's, where there's even more space to play.

A perplexed (paying) friend, who rushed up in the interval saying, 'I kept thinking they were going to SING', had obviously missed the point.

When an innovative idea works, all misgivings vanish. This was just a dull muddle, and it was not the fault of the children. More peculiar still, Nino Rota is a captivating figure worthy of better treatment, a friend of Stravinsky and a prolific composer of concert music. Among his movie scores, the old will remember that musical tear-jerker The Glass Mountain (1948); younger readers The Godfather I and II. In between there were all the scores for Fellini. More to the point, he composed no fewer than 10 operas. If a straightforward Rota opera was too humdrum a notion, one of the pair he wrote for radio might have provided the sort of perverse challenge on which ENO seems to thrive.

The evening opened with a performance of Berio's Folk Songs. This radiant collection of songs from around Europe, accompanied by a small ensemble (deftly played by members of ENO's orchestra) was written in 1949 for Cathy Berberian, soon to become the composer's wife. Susan Parry, dressed in a tight, full-skirted black dress, sang fetchingly. Three children gathered round her, jumping and tumbling. It wasn't clear why this was 'staged' but at least it was cheap, and judging by Nicholas Payne's note in the programme, money is tight. He adds that this Italian 'three-course meal' was in danger of becoming one dish until the Leche Trust helped out.

Had only the Berio preceded The Prisoner , most people might have been satisfied. But hearing two lightweight pieces followed by one of the most dour, depressing works of the past half century was like having double zabaglione before your slab of ox-tongue.

Dallapiccola (d.1975), a severe advocate of 12-tone music, was interned during the Fist World War. His natural sympathy for the persecuted and his anti-fascist beliefs find expression in many of his works. Respected though his music still is, it is hard to love despite its moments of unqualified lyricism.

He wrote his own libretto for The Prisoner after works by Villiers De l'Isle Adam and Charles de Coster. A cast of five singers and an actor is dominated by the unnamed prisoner of the title, whose mournful elegy for his lost liberty shapes the work. The choral interlude based on the Latin liturgy was affecting, if over-amplified. An excellent Peter Coleman-Wright sang with morbid intensity. Susan Bullock was passionate as the distraught mother.

The simple set, which featured a ladder, was by the season's designer, Stefanos Lazaridis. Richard Hickox, throughout, conducted persuasively. This was not a cheerful occasion. At last the true meaning of that old operatic aphorism prima la musica, poi le parole - on which Richard Strauss based an entire opera ( Capriccio ) without a prisoner in sight - became clear: first the music, then the parole. Release from the Coliseum that night didn't come a moment too soon.

fields.headline: Hardly a Numan, even after all this time
fields.standfirst: On his sixth career revival, the nu-metal singer is as neurotic as ever
fields.trailText: On his sixth career revival, the nu-metal singer is as neurotic as ever
fields.body:
Gary Numan, at the last count, has enjoyed five career revivals. He's currently riding on the crest of his sixth. Backstage at 'Die Rohre', a gothic metal club in Stuttgart, on Tuesday night, Numan sits swigging Coke from a plastic cup. He looks not dissimilar to his early-Eighties incarnation, those heavy pen-lined eyebrows constantly creased. 'It's great to have a second life,' he says. 'Not many artists get a second chance. And things seem to be going well.'

Numan first appeared in the charts in 1979 - with 'Cars' - and his trademark metal machine sound that ushered in the birth of electronica. His subsequent career has provided a series of musical mishaps - buoyed by the periodic re-release of 'Cars'. Still, his music has now been reclaimed by heirs such as DJ Armand Van Helden, The Prodigy's Liam Howlett, The Orb's Alex Patterson and Nine Inch Nails' Trent Reznor. 'After hearing Gary Numan's 'Cars' on the radio, I knew I wanted to make music with synthesisers,' said Reznor.

The patronage of his musical offspring seems to have reinvigorated his artistic temperament. His latest album, Pure, borrows heavily from Nine Inch Nails, Marilyn Manson and Ministry - razor-sharp metal chords sellotaped to his charged vocals. 'I think I'm being true to what I feel,' he says. 'I've not often been like that in the past.' He fidgets with his cup of Coke, and grins meekly, remembering all those recording mis-hits.

Numan maintains he has always lacked confidence - and it seems to explain his refuge behind a steely on-stage persona. His 1997 autobiography, Praying To The Aliens, perfectly illustrates the point.

Writing about his now-infamous piloting crash in 1982, he describes flying to Cannes as his plane's alternator broke down: 'The alternator was supposed to have been fixed in France but my friend said that, on investigation, it was ridiculously expensive to have it done there, and it would be better to fly it back to England in the same way that we flew to France and fix it there. Again, alarm bells were beginning to ring in my head, but I lacked the confidence to argue.' The light craft crashed on a road near Southampton, stopping two lanes of traffic.

'I've never really gotten over that one,' says Numan. 'There were jokes about it for years.' He glances at his stage wardrobe - a black trenchcoat. Hanging from an overhead pipe earlier, Nu-man was forced to move it on discovering a leak in the pipe. He sighs: 'I tell you, this is a bit Spinal Tap, to be honest. We do get horribly close to it at times - especially when people talk about my "specialist audience".'

He paces backstage, absent-mindedly toying with the catering supplies. He and his bandmates discuss the latest Marilyn Manson video. 'Have you seen it? He looks gorgeous. So decadent. That's what millions of sales do for you. I can't even afford a video. Any video would be nice.'

Later, on stage, in front of around 300 nu-metal fans, as well as a scattering of goths, Numan's set betrays a weighted emphasis towards his latest album. 'Cars', introduced halfway through, provides an axis for the new material. As his lead guitarist pogos around him, Numan unleashes his neuroses with headbanging judders and flailing arms. Two gigantic banks of keyboards behind him provide a constant electronic hum that underpins his movements.

Throughout the 90-minute set, Numan gazes detachedly at the crowd, muttering little beyond 'thank you'. And much like the first time I saw him on Noel Edmond's Multi-Coloured Swap-Shop, in 1980, he looks dislocated from the cheers of his audience. 'You don't expect him to say anything, do you?' comments someone next to me. 'It's Gary Numan. He's angry, he's disenfranchised. He doesn't talk.'

The new songs are curious examples of metal machine music - characterised by death and re-venge. The title track, 'Pure', hints at violence.

'It's about a girl we know that likes getting beaten up by men,' he grins. 'She walks into organised parties where five men beat here senseless.' Isn't that horrific? Doesn't she need help? 'I don't think so,' says Numan, glaring across the room. He ponders for a minute. 'Well, maybe she does. But only because she might kill herself.' I can't get him to deviate from his 'consenting adults' argument.

Backstage, just after the concert, Numan's wife sits on a sofa in one corner of the dressing room. Gemma, a devoted fan, is credited by Numan for pulling him out of his career doldrums. 'I don't see him as just a revival act,' she tells me. 'He has something new to say with his music. And perhaps he is being more honest with himself. The music is darker, very Gary.' She giggles, adjusting her fishnet tights and black dress. Rushing over to speak to him, she falls to her knees, her head landing on his lap. I look away, as she coos: 'Just wait till I get my lip implants. I'll have fat injected from my bum.' Numan shrieks in horror. 'That's disgusting. I'm not going to kiss you ever.'

The crew leave the venue, and clamber into their tour bus. 'I might read The Hobbit ,' says Numan. 'I read that and The Lord of the Rings every 18 months.' He stretches: 'Yes, I feel a hobbit coming on.' Earlier, his wife had gushed with pride at her acquisition of a proof of Toyah Wilcox's autobiography. On your sixth revival, going forward is harder than ever.

fields.headline: 'Yo TopShop!'
fields.standfirst: Women faint as Craig David rocks his hometown of Southampton. And he doesn't grab his crotch even once...
fields.trailText: Women faint as Craig David rocks his hometown of Southampton. And he doesn't grab his crotch even once...
fields.body:
Craig David Southampton Guildhall

Craig David made quite an impression when he returned to his hometown last week. For starters, the taxi driver sung his praises on the way to the venue even though he was a self-confessed pop philistine. Once inside, I almost stumbled into a dazed, prone fan, who was being revived after fainting. And she wasn't the only one that found the anticipation all too much. Minutes later, just before David stepped on to the stage, there was a collective gasp and the throng parted slightly a few feet in front of me as another young fan hit the deck.

The TopShop brigade, plus a few mums, dads and well-turned out boyfriends, were out in full force to witness the triumphant return of their all-conquering R&B star. It's been quite a year: a Number 1 album and single plus a trio of MOBO awards. Apparently Puff Daddy is a fan and wants to work with him. He started the year as the melodious voice of UK Garage and ends it as that rarest of things: a homegrown soul star. His debut album, Born To Do It , is clearly a British creation. The American-style approach of phat beats and bass lines isn't for him. His record is an inoffensive, sunny confection, sprinkled with Spanish guitar touches and accessible lyrics, squarely aimed at his target audience.

And here they are, dressed to impress. And here he is looking slightly low-key in a purple sweat top and black jeans. But this isn't an ostentatious performer or performance. That's not Craig David's style. He is unthreateningly aspirational: nice clothes, smart hair, busy nightlife. But he ain't ghettofabulous. On stage he struts and swaggers around a bit, but his crotch remains a grab-free zone and flashy dance moves just aren't his thing. The audience aren't too nifty on their feet either. They prefer to gawp rather than dance. But judging by the number of snogging couples in close proximity, David has brought some love into the house.

Mindful of his youthful audience, notably the large number of pre-teens in the balcony, the raunch factor, and with it presumably some of the fun and funk, has been toned down. Even on the suggestively titled 'Booty Man' he begins somewhat incongruously singing 'One, two, buckle my shoe. Three, four, step inside the venue.' In fact, his overall stage persona needs a shot of performance Viagra, but it still proves effective in front of such a compliant audience. But this is his town, after all. He could have got up, read out the Southampton phone book and still earned a standing ovation.

Craig David is obviously a nice local lad, who judging by his extensive guest list at the door has kept in touch with his old mates. This is just as well because many of his songs feature them, especially the girls. 'She's here tonight,' he teases the lucky laydee who inspired 'Fill Me In' - a tale of teen romance and vigilant parents - when he halts the chart-topping song in mid-flow. 'I met that girl in SOUTHAAAMPTON.' The crowd roars its approval, as it does when he later namechecks some of the city's suburbs.

Although his biggest hits, 'Fill Me In' and 'Rewind', are dancefloor fillers, they are kept for the encore. The bulk of the show comprises the album's slower numbers. And on the basis of these it's sometimes hard to see what all the fuss is about. 'Seven Days' and 'Once in a Lifetime' are catchy enough but a few of the others sound like poor relations to The Lighthouse Family. But fans that own and like the album shouldn't be disappointed.

He sings all 12 songs from Born To Do It. But it is the middle of the set, when he covers Usher's languid 'Nice and Slow' and R. Kelly's vibrant anthem of new money, 'Did You Ever Think', that he hints at something more interesting in his future. The former is a showy ballad that lets his heartfelt voice soar and the latter gives the audience a rare chance to jump up and down as David raps and stomps across the stage.

And you have to admire his verbal dexterity as he switches gears from silky singing to fast rhyming on a customised version of his latest single, 'Walking Away'. He performs 'Rewind' accompanied by an acoustic guitar since he's no longer the two-step prince, followed up by a plaintive version of Human League's 'Human' - a strange choice which gets a muted reception.

He naturally closes the show, an hour and a half after it began, with 'Fill Me In'. The crowd erupt. 'This is where it all began and I'm gonna keep flying the flag for Southampton.' It's the perfect end to a perfectly satisfactory night. The local lad has made good, come back and conquered. But, of course, that was never in any doubt.

For starters, the taxi driver sung his praises on the way to the venue even though he was a self-confessed pop philistine. Once inside, I almost stumbled into a dazed, prone fan, who was being revived after fainting. And she wasn't the only one that found the anticipation all too much. fields.headline: He likes brutality and shopping. He's going to be the next big thing
fields.trailText: Rem Koolhaas began his career as an architect not by designing a building, but by writing a book. Not the usual kind of architect's book, full of glossy colour pictures of the author's work, but a book of ideas.
fields.body:
Rem Koolhaas began his career as an architect not by designing a building, but by writing a book. Not the usual kind of architect's book, full of glossy colour pictures of the author's work, but a book of ideas. Delirious Manhattan , as it was called, purported to be a retrospective manifesto, an account of how New York became the embodiment of what Koolhaas describes as 'the culture of congestion'. It was a brilliant move, instantly establishing Koolhaas as an intimidating presence on the architectural landscape when there was nothing to show for what his vision of the architecture of the contemporary world might be like.

A second book followed, a couple of bricks thick, that went by the name S, M, X, XL. This time, there were plenty of pictures of Koolhaas's buildings. He had built a couple of houses by then: a conference centre on top of the TGV station in Lille, a dance theatre in the Hague, an art gallery in Rotterdam. But it was even less like the conventional architectural monograph than Delirious Manhattan . Koolhaas's work was depicted as a series of raw cut-and-paste collages, rather than airbrushed perfection.

Alongside the buildings were lots of other kinds of images - a fantastic history of Mies's Barcelona pavilion, Japanese pornography, the Berlin Wall - as well as diagrams of the amount of time Koolhaas himself spent in hotel rooms. Clearly the intention was to signal that Koolhaas was about something more important than mere architecture. It did as much as his architecture to make Koolhaas's name inevitably linked with every new project involving the requisite high-octane mix of fashion and celebrity.

His architecture is bracing and unsettling and even though nothing he has done yet has had the same popular impact as Frank Gehry's Guggenheim, he is clearly going to be the next big thing. When Ian Schrager decided he wanted a change from Philippe Starck, it was Koolhaas who was his first choice. The surprise was that he is working on the project in partnership with Jacques Herzog and Pierre de Meuron of Tate Modern. Koolhaas certainly has an ego, but he is not interested in the architectural cult of personality.

Miucca Prada has commissioned Koolhaas to design three new stores for Prada in America. But perhaps the most remarkable project Koolhaas is working on is for the Guggenheim Museum. Not content with branches in Venice, Bilbao and Berlin, the director, Thomas Krens, has asked Koolhaas to build a Las Vegas Guggenheim, tacked on to the Venetian, a casino and hotel complex modelled in hyper-real Las Vegas style on the Grand Canal, St Mark's Square, and the Rialto.

Such is Koolhaas's strength as an architect that it is impossible to predict from his previous work what any of these new projects will be like. There are clues. You can see an enthusiasm for jagged shapes, the unabashed use of found industrial materials used as if they were precious and beautiful. He makes abrupt juxtapositions between solid and open, between rough and smooth. Koolhaas isn't interested in signature architecture, in making things look pretty, or in hiding from the realities of contemporary life by treating architecture as a craft skill. Why worry about making an elegant façade, or create a coherent public space, when the world's cities are being overwhelmed by an avalanche of what Koolhaas calls 'junk space'?

What really interests Koolhaas is the reality of the contemporary city; that is the subject of Mutations , a spectacular exhibition that he has organised which opened last week at the Arc en Reve in Bordeaux. It is an exploration of the world of shopping malls and airports, of urbanism Lagos and Shenzen style. The message, delivered in Koolhaas's punchy sound bites, is that we had better get on with it, and start to deal with such places as they are, rather than as architects would like them to be.

To Koolhaas, the phenomenon of shopping has swallowed the world, making museums and malls and hotels all part of a single chaotic whole. He set his doctoral students at Harvard to work on a three-year study of shopping and concluded: 'The best metaphor for shopping is that of a dying animal - a dying elephant that in its death struggle becomes completely wild and uncontrollable.'

The subtext is that Koolhaas is the toughest kid on the block. While most of his fellow professionals wring their hands in horror about theme parks and urban sprawl, he looks the world in the eye and deals with it on its own terms. Talking of the chaos of Lagos, Koolhaas says: 'What I thought would be depressing was powerful, inspiring and brutal.'

Brutal, in Koolhaas's vocabulary, is a term of enthusiasm. Indeed, Koolhaas's client, Thomas Krens, uses it to describe the Las Vegas project. Koolhaas is trying to prove that the well-intentioned architects who tried to tame the contemporary city with pedestrian precincts and conservation got it all disastrously wrong. They should have been trying to intensify the city's intrinsic qualities, not neuter them. 'What is amazing is that you can draw a genealogy between Jane Jacobs and Disney. Since the Sixties, the most well-meaning brains in our profession have con tributed to this final, terminal condition of shopping.'

The effort to preserve the street, the hostility to the car, the hostility to all those elements that were the inevitable elements of the twentieth century - all of this has somehow created the space for this preservation, and, in the name of preservation, the conversion of entire areas in the centre of the city to fundamentally anti-urban conditions. This ought to make everyone weep. Nobody could have guessed that the twentieth century could end on a Faustian bargain with a mouse.

The Las Vegas commission is the project that Koolhaas has always been waiting for, a chance to confront the realities of the contemporary city. The idea of the museum establishing a branch linked to a casino is literally surreal. As Thomas Krens describes it: 'The museum has to make a very powerful statement that cuts right across the main themes of Las Vegas. If you see a city that has embraced artificiality, we will make something that is absolutely the opposite, a very aggressive, even brutal statement.'

For Koolhaas, it's the chance to see if he is tough - and brutal - enough to face up to the void that is Vegas, with nothing more than architecture to help him.

fields.headline: Lange Day's Journey
fields.standfirst: The American actress is magnificent as the addict mother in this autobiographical tale of family breakdown
fields.trailText: Long Day's Journey Into Night | Remembrance of Things Past | Hijra | Love's Work
fields.body:
Long Day's Journey Into Night Lyric, London W1

Remembrance of Things Past Cottesloe, London SE1

Hijra Bush, London W12

Love's Work Gate, London W11

Famous as a masterpiece of American realism, famous as a piece of revelatory autobiography and famous for being - well - long, Eugene O'Neill's best-known play is full of marvels, and full of perils. Under the direction of Robin Phillips, Long Day's Journey into Night is expressively, moodily staged and has a shining performance from Jessica Lange. It also has slow, cumbersome stretches. It looks by turns urgent and awkward.

O'Neill put his life and family on to the stage in this work: a young man suffering (as did O'Neill) from TB, a brother dead in infancy (bizarrely, the playwright gave this character his own Christian name), an actor father - and a mother whose morphine dependency provides the play's title. The confessional pulse and the frank exploration of addiction give the play - written in 1941, but not produced until 1956 - an unexpectedly contemporary air. Its ripe language and heavy explicitness proclaim it as belonging to its period. The performances are crucial.

On this occasion, there's a huge unevenness. Charles Dance, presumably anxious not to overdo the actor-laddie aspect of the husband, underdoes it. Paul Nicholls, compelling as an impaired, desirable youth in EastEnders, is too robust for the consumptive son. Paul Rudd plays his raffish, troubled brother with too much determination, too little abandon.

But Lange is magnificent. As a fog-horn hoots, Simon Higlett's design - a faded traditional sitting-room - is invaded by billows of mist: Lange makes you feel it's her mind that's being infiltrated. With Katharine Hepburn's haughtiness and wobbly grace, she plants the signs of floating away into addiction: a woozy garrulousness; the hands that pick away at a handkerchief. But her bold move, which spreads like fire through the production, is to be dislikeable. She has the manipulativeness of the addict - alternately wheedling and defiant - and the addict's cleverness. She turns wistful moments into barbs: 'I'm sorry,' she says to her husband, as she delivers a harrowing, guilt-inducing memory, 'I remembered out loud.'

Remembering aloud proves a dramatic theme of continual fascination at the Cottesloe. At first, Di Trevis's directorial project sounds doomed. She has taken the 1972 screenplay, commissioned by Joseph Losey but never filmed, which Harold Pinter based on A la re- cherche du temps perdu, and collaborated with Pinter in adapting it for the stage. How could Proust's fluidly interior prose not be barbarised?

Well, of course, there are oddities and short-cuts in Remembrance of Things Past. The characters - apart from Indira Varma's dreamy, ambiguous Albertine and Sebastian Harcombe's pensive Marcel - are performed with the graphic clarity of cartoon. Stripped of Proust's tumbling clauses, the action is startling, sometimes violent, an act of memory which concentrates on gangs of hoydenish girls and melting, dapper young men, on feasts of snobbery and on casual cruelty. The mad manners and arbitrary rules of this society recall Alice in Wonderland: there is even a guest who dozes off, dormouse-like, at dinner.

The shock of this is not a fault but a feat. Trevis and Pinter have wired Proust into an artistic world of unpredictable associations and surrealist nightmares, the world of René Magritte. They have not been reverent: they have been truthful. And what they have pulled off is remarkable: they have found, as Raul Ruiz's film Time Regained found, a way to embody Proust's prose.

You see this in the seamless opening moments. On Alison Chitty's sloping stage, the narrator broods over his infant self, while around him gilded figures in evening dress watch and wait. There are no separate scenes in this performance, only shifts of focus. An individual starts to play the piano or violin: he (it's always he) freezes, and the music lifts off to reverberate around the auditorium as if it had a thousand sources. In these shifts of register, it is as if characters are passing from one Proustian sentence to another.

A new wave of talent is about to hit the English theatre from India. The gorgeous spoof musical Fourteen Songs, Two Weddings and a Funeral returns next year to the Lyric Hammersmith; Andrew Lloyd Webber's Bollywood bonanza will also shortly arrive in the West End. Meanwhile, the descriptions of Indian life, there and here, which have frequently thrown lifelines to the novel, are creeping into plays.

The Theatre Royal Plymouth's production of Ash Kotak's Hijra is welcome as part of this wave. Its subject is intriguing and its dialogue peppery. The 'hijra' is an androgynous spell-casting dancer, who falls in love with a young man he meets in Bombay and slips into a sari to get into Britain as his lover's wife: 'Bad bosom day?' enquires his mother-in-law as he fumbles with his falsies. But the jokes aren't frequent enough to paper over the cracks in a jerky plot. And though Charubala Chokshi, who doubles up as two busybodies, is impressive, the acting is unreliable.

It takes panache, and a sense of paradox, to make your final production a work in progress. That's what Mick Gordon has done as he leaves a distinguished term as the Gate's artistic director. Love's Work, proclaiming itself unfinished with a stage of bare planks and uncurtained windows through which you glimpse Notting Hill buses and buzz, veers between pathos, terrific comedy and queasy sentiment, as actors tell of clandestine, parental and prematurely cut-off love. Its obviously innovative feature is gender-bending: when a shag-hungry young man is portrayed by a young woman, his words are irradiated with preposterousness. But its most valuable gift is to remind us that theatres are places where you can tell stories.

fields.headline: What a photograph...
fields.standfirst: A new show at the Saatchi Gallery explores the increasingly blurred line between painting and photography.  Gaby Wood  asks where it will all end
fields.trailText: A new show at the Saatchi Gallery explores the increasingly blurred line between painting and photography. Gaby Wood asks where it will all end.
fields.body:
When Napoleon died in 1821, Madame Tussaud made a wax model of the emperor on his deathbed. She exhibited the model in her touring waxwork show, and later in the permanent museum she set up in Baker Street in 1835. One of the exhibition's regular visitors was the Duke of Wellington, who would stand over Napoleon's body, gazing at his sometime enemy. Though they could only guess at what was going through his mind, the sculptors at the museum were clearly inspired by these posthumous meetings, since when the Duke died in 1852 they made a model of him as well. He was not depicted in a heroic pose from his celebrated life, but at the scene of this silent battle instead: the Duke of Wellington's waxwork was placed at Napoleon's bedside, where he can still be seen today.

The Japanese-born American artist Hiroshi Sugimoto recently photographed the two figures, in beautiful, large format black and white, so that it looks like a painting composed at the time. But at what time? The point of the amalgamated waxworks is that two time-frames are collapsed. Tussaud's diorama is not exactly a fiction, but the facts are not what they seem. When the event depicted occurred, one of the people was alive and the other was dead, already a waxwork. But now they are both lifeless reproductions, and Sugimoto's image complicates the situation further: it is a repro duction of a reproduction of many other reproductions, stretching telescopically, almost to infinity.

Sugimoto's portraits, which will be included in a forthcoming show at the Saatchi Gallery entitled I Am a Camera , are some of the cleverest responses to a crisis that has been running a low fever for over a century, and has recently reached something of a peak. What is photography? What is painting? At what point do the media meet? Sugimoto has added traditional wax portraiture to the mix, and constructed undateable images, composite representations, a mish-mash of simulacra.

A hundred and fifty years ago, purveyors of the new medium of photography were begging to be accepted in exhibitions of fine art, just as fine art realised it no longer had a duty to report realistically. Now photography seems to have reached some apparently final destination: with the introduction of digital photography and computer manipulation, realism in photography is decidedly dead. Images can be taken to pieces and recomposed thousands of miles away: photography is breaking up, at the very moment photo-based work is taking over the artistic canon.

What this means, in the galleries, is that there is a focus on the newly blurred line, or a revisiting of the old blurred line, between painting and photography. At the establishment end of the art world, there is the Whitney Museum in New York, putting on what is, amazingly, the first major retrospective of Edward Steichen's work. Steichen was a turn-of-the-century pictorialist photographer who aimed, along with Alfred Stieglitz, Clarence White and other contributors to the journal Camera Work , to raise the artfulness of their photographs to the level of paintings. It is a premise often thought to be rather reactionary, particularly since parallel advances in painting were so avant-garde, and it seems pertinent that now is the time thought to be ripe for large-scale viewing of these 100 year-old painterly pictures.

But what does this now mean? Saatchi has been buying photographic work for some time, and has intensified his purchases recently. Sarah Jones, Hannah Starkey, Tom Hunter, Craigie Horsfield, though very different photographers, fall into the first category, while Richard Billingham, Paul Smith, Nan Goldin and Jessica Craig-Martin fall into the latter.

Jason Brooks has gone all the way - turned photographs into monumental oils, drawn up on a grid and reproduced in their most minute detail.

His portraits of Henry VIII and his wives were taken against black backdrops in Madame Tussaud's. It is as if the only answer to the crisis is a question, or a joke. 'Does it matter what we're made of,' the images ask their viewer. 'Can you tell?' What was once an academic rivalry has been diffused into a game, and the artist always has the last laugh.

Among his portraits, Sugimoto has reproduced Vermeer's famous painting, The Music Lesson . He found a three-dimensional replica of it at Madame Tussaud's in Amsterdam, and set out to return it to two dimensions, to make a replica of the replica. But first he had to study the painting carefully, in order to discover Vermeer's exact point of view. In the tilted mirror on the wall above the woman's head, he saw the bottom corner of an easel. Having decided where the artist was standing, he positioned himself identically in relation to the wax models. Sugimoto's version bears an uncanny resemblance to the original painting. Only instead of an easel in the mirror, there is the bottom corner of a photographer's tripod.

webTitle: Art: Treasures of Catherine the Great

fields.headline: From Russia, with love
fields.standfirst: Catherine the Great's passion for her empire and her men was matched only by her passion for collecting
fields.trailText: Treasures of Catherine the Great
fields.body:
Treasures of Catherine the Great The Hermitage Rooms, Somerset House, London WC2

Catherine the Great, as every schoolchild knows, was the insatiable empress of appetites: for sex, knowledge, land and power, for priceless works of art. Five hundred of the million treasures she bought are now at the Hermitage Rooms in Somerset House, beginning with a massive replica of her dinner table from the Winter Palace. Dreamers gazing into its polished surface may think of Catherine at the trencher with her salivating lovers or sparring with Diderot over mounds of beluga.

But the table is not there for romantic effect. By day, it sprouts interactive monitors, displaying treasures from the Hermitage Museum. By night, these screens are folded away, doubling as place mats for what must now be the ritziest corporate dining table anywhere in the country.

A lost wing of the Winter Palace - aka the Hermitage - in miniature, on the banks of the Thames: that is the concept behind this enterprise. Five suites from that stupendous building in St Petersburg have been recreated down to the last doorknob in Somerset House: the scarlet walls, the gold parquet, the chairs of Arctic birch. Catherine's clock ticks from its diamond tower. Her silver wig glistens in the shuttered light. She is all around you in sculptures and portraits: tough, flamboyant and very, very smart.

Treasures of Catherine the Great is the latest in that dependable line of blockbusters that runs all the way from King Tut and Rudolf of Prague to the display of Diana's dresses. It is an inventory of wealth that's supposed to add up to a portrait. Here is Catherine's immense silver coffee pot - she liked it industrial strength, one pound of coffee per litre. Here is her Chinese card table - she used diamonds for chips; here's her steel umbrella, so advanced for the eighteenth century.

Catherine's reputation as some sort of sexual Messalina is downplayed in the captions but encouraged in some of the portraits. Crowned Empress of All Russia in 1762, after the shockingly swift murder of her husband, Catherine was lavishly portrayed until the end of her days. For her coronation statue, she proffers an orb like some teasing flower, brimming out of her plunging neckline in fulsome décolletage . Even in old age, she has an ardent glint in her eye: 'I could not live,' she wrote, 'for a single hour without love.'

The lovers are all present and correct - from pretty-boy Lanskoy, 30 years her junior, to Prince Potemkin, a thundering dynamo with sensuous lips and an extravagant head of hair. As for those false rumours about horses, they take on another dimension when you look at the Equestrian Portrait of Catherine in the Uniform of the Semyonovsky Regiment . She is all man, from her erect sword and muscular thighs down to her steel-spurred boots. The horse, with its girlish mane and pretty hooves, is all coy glances beneath her.

No bores, no gluttons, no arrogant jerks: those were Catherine's rules for the Hermitage - any transgressions punishable with a glass of water and some turgid poems. Catherine's intellectual passions are represented here with busts of Diderot, Newton and a mar vellously sly-looking Rou-sseau. She kept Voltaire on the nightstand, watercolours of classical ruins by her bed, never wishing to forget how quickly empires could decline and fall.

An avid internationalist, she bought Scottish furniture, English steel, French porcelain and any amount of chinoiserie from her Chinese borders. Anyone wondering where those Fabergé eggs came from need only look at the Chinese dragons prowling a tiny jewelled glade in this show.

So, infinite riches in five opulent rooms. But where is the rest of the Hermitage - all those thousands of paintings, only a fraction of which can ever be shown at once in St Petersburg? The single visiting masterpiece from that sublime collection is a lone, decaying Poussin. Next year, we get a dingy Hals and an overwrought Jacob Jordaens. For the rest, you will have to squint at the scant selection displayed on the dining table monitors.

The Hermitage is one of the world's great museums of art: 3,000,000 objects, including some of the most famous of all works by Titian, Raphael, Rembrandt, the impressionists, Van Gogh, Picasso and Matisse, whose wild frieze, The Dance , was painted in St Petersburg before the Revolution. Courtesy of IBM, you can see a mere 58 of these works on screen in London.

A few months ago, I interviewed the director of the Hermitage, Professor Piotrovski. His museum was suffering from leaking roofs, creeping damp and atrocious poverty. Unlike practically every other art museum, it can expect no government handouts, no Lottery windfalls, no council grants for refurbishment. Like Russia's state workers, unpaid for so many months, the museum receives barely a percentage of its state grant and has seen its entrance figures nosedive from four million to 1.7 million last year.

Piotrovski is a brave and dauntless man. He has persuaded millions in sponsorship from IBM and cajoled hard cash out of Russian oil barons. He knew that one solution was to send the paintings out into the world to earn their living and he spoke of Hermitage satellites in London and Amsterdam.

Piotrovski made a deal with Amsterdam: the loan of Rembrandts from the Hermitage in exchange for money to repair the rooms where they hang. In America, he struck a bargain with the Guggenheim Foundation: paintings for its New York museum in return for millions in redevelopment funds. In London, the quid pro quo seems to be décor and dining rights in return for corporate cash. Does this reflect the connoisseurial tastes of the English trustees - or some Russian idea of England as a nation obsessed with royalty, heritage and home furnishings?

Somerset House is so eager to promote the Hermitage experience as de luxe, intimate and selective that only 100 visitors will be allowed to process through these stately rooms at the same time. At £1 per ticket to the Hermitage, the museum won't make much cash. But that is hardly the point. The Hermitage Rooms are about private wealth and patronage, not about public art. For that you must cross Sir William Chambers's spectacular courtyard to the Courtauld Galleries on the other side of Somerset House.

Perhaps it will all change in the future and we'll see Chardins instead of manicure sets, Picassos instead of imperial forks. But at present, the Hermitage Rooms feel more like what they are: a grand private suite, with 24-carat heritage, for corporate hospitality and fund-raising cocktails.

There is the list of founding sponsors, framed in gold on the door. There is the dining table, all ready for the next generation of backers - none of them, surely, for Catherine's sake, arrogant gluttons or bores.

webTitle: The challenge to Charlotte was long overdue

fields.headline: The challenge to Charlotte was long overdue
fields.trailText: Charlotte Church's former manager, Jonathan Shalit, should be applauded for having the stamina and resolve to stand up not just for his own rights but for the rights of all managers and agents operating in the entertainment industry.
fields.body:
Charlotte Church's former manager, Jonathan Shalit, should be applauded for having the stamina and resolve to stand up not just for his own rights but for the rights of all managers and agents operating in the entertainment industry.

In the last few years, the likes of Elton John, Eric Clapton, Robbie Williams, All Saints and B*witched have fired their managers.

A music industry lawyer says he advises his manager clients to take it for granted that no matter what their contracts say, and no matter how well they perform, they will be fired one day and the likelihood of that is all the greater the more successful their artist becomes.

'Artists have no problem with paying managers commission when they [the artists] aren't earning money but as soon as they do, some of them become resentful, forgetting the blood, sweat and tears you have put in over the formative years.'

The hit-miss ratio in the music industry is depressing. Even when artists are signed up to record labels, they can get shelved or dropped with the manager's investment of time and money being treated with contempt.

Ed Bicknell, former manager of Dire Straits, says: 'Just as artists dream of being on Top of the Pops , every manager dreams of discovering and nurturing that talent, not out of vanity but through entrepreneurial ambition. They have careers to pursue, but people seem to think they are doing it for fun.'

Artists aren't usually born with a lack of sincerity and so someone or something causes a breakdown in the artist-manager relationship. It might be exploding egos or a wife/ girlfriend /boyfriend or, as it would seem in Charlotte's case, her parents. On occasions, it might even be the record label. An insider says: 'The music business has bemoaned the lack of good managers for years but it's bad at giving credit where credit is due. Managers get the blame if things go wrong but can be sidelined when things go well so the artists begin to wonder if the manager is dispensable.'

All too often, when a manager is fired, he has neither the financial resources nor the appetite for a legal fight. Jonathan Shalit's legal costs were reckoned to be in excess of £250,000. 'He's lucky,' says Bicknell. 'He had the money to fund the legal case; others are less fortunate. Litigation is a scary business but Jonathan was prepared to go the whole way. He must now feel vindicated.'

Shalit's success coincides with Elton John being in court seeking damages from his ex-management. The case has exposed Elton's extravagant lifestyle, a lifestyle that must have been assisted in part by professional and astute management over many years.

Whereas English courts were traditionally protective of artists, in recent years they seem to have turned against them, as has been shown by George Michael's humiliation by Sony.

Bicknell says: 'The best advice I can give any new manager entering the music business is to hire a good lawyer and then to keep meticulous file and diary notes so that, when that dreaded day comes when he gets fired by fax or by an answer-machine message, he can successfully protect and enforce his rights. For every CD that is sold, a record label makes £4 to £5 profit, the artist makes £1 and of that a manager makes 20 pence. As silly as it sounds, you need to protect those 20ps so that when the artist is selling millions of records your business can prosper. What needs to come out of all this is for the industry to set up some kind of arbitration service so that these court cases can hopefully be avoided.'

These appear to be wise words when you realise that no offer of any compensation was made to Shalit when he was fired and that his lawyers' attempts to instigate settlement negotiations were rebuffed.

 The author is a lawyer whose name has been changed.

fields.headline: You'd better believe it!
fields.standfirst: Victor Meldrew, Britain's great comic curmudgeon who became a national institution, may be dead. But his alter ego, Richard Wilson, is directing a (dead serious) new play at the Royal Court
fields.trailText: Victor Meldrew, Britain's great comic curmudgeon who became a national institution, may be dead. But his alter ego, Richard Wilson, is directing a (dead serious) new play at the Royal Court
fields.body:
Richard Wilson is having a busy day. The BBC are sending a crew round to his flat in a couple of hours because this evening's One Foot in the Grave is the final one where Victor gets mown down by a car and everyone is excited, not least because ITV are trying to spoil everything by slightly fishily having a woman winning Chris Tarrant's million pounds at exactly the same time.

'Clearly they've put it on because of us,' he says, more in resignation than in anger. (Clearly, he is saving his 'I don't believe it!' for the next day, when he sparks a furore in the press over his reported comments that it was a fix. Speaking to me later in the week, he says: 'It's just so suspicious... I just said it was a fix because it looks like one.') Anyway, ahead of Victor's demise this evening, the BBC are also presenting a warm-up obituary special in which Angus Deayton, Paul Merton and other deities of British humour lay bare the hidden mechanism whereby Victor Meldrew makes us laugh and provide us with another chance to see the clips that have turned him into a well-known phrase or saying.

So, naturally, Wilson has to do his bit, which means being filmed watching his TV death and answering questions on the internet afterwards and trying to live up to everyone else's enthusiasm. He's not complaining, though he does have rather a lot on his plate at the moment.

He did point out that, actually, he is in the middle of directing a play. This morning the BBC breakfast news people enticed him down to the studios with the promise that his co-star Annette Crosbie and One Foot in the Grave creator David Renwick would be there too, and wouldn't that be jolly? But it turned out they weren't there too, so he had to be jolly on his own. 'Tricky buggers,' he says. 'I think they just said that to get me in.'

I half expect him to switch on the Victor for this but he doesn't. For the grumpiest man on TV, he's pretty laid back. He laughs a lot. He's amusingly at the right side of self-effacing. He doesn't scowl or sulk or purse his lips. And he's not Victor at C&A. He wears jeans, trainers and a colourful stripy jumper.

We're sitting in the ballroom of the improbably grand HQ of the train drivers' union Aslef in Hampstead, where he is rehearsing a new play for the Royal Court - a three-hander by Stephen Jeffreys called I Just Stopped By to See the Man . The story, set in the Seventies, ricochets between a legendary Mississippi blues guitarist who is presumed by the world to be dead but isn't, his college-educated daughter who has abandoned frontline black politics to come back to their dirt-poor shotgun shack in the Delta and a white English rock star who drops in one dark night to unburden his soul and get to the bottom of theirs.

The themes are big and provocative. It's a long way from net curtains and mug trees, and I wonder whether this isn't Wilson's refuge not just from acting but from primetime comedy in particular. I wonder, for all that One Foot is rich and idiosyncratic in its way, whether it is the burden of popularity that goads him to more cerebral adventures.

Not so. He points out that this other career at the cutting edge of British theatre (in October he won a best director award for Mr Kolpert at the Royal Court and the theatre recently invited him to be associate director) has been running at least as long as the one that has made him a national institution.

'I've always liked to mix it. I like changing hats. And the Court has always been the one I've been excited by - left-wing, new writing. I tend to direct serious plays. I've directed there many times but to be offered associateship at 64 is a great thrill - not to mention a late career move.'

I ask how the rehearsals are going. 'Very well,' he chuckles. 'Though every time I direct a new play I think, why don't I direct old plays?'

'So why don't you direct old plays?'

'Oh, because new writing is the chronicle of our times. But it can be tough. And this one is a big piece. But now that we've thrashed it through and cut it and shaped it, we're getting more confident. We've reached the stage where the bits that worry you cease to worry you, which is exciting. What's interesting is to see whether we can hold an audience with quite detailed speeches about music and the blues and all that. And today, for the first time, it didn't sound like long speeches, just stories. To have three characters hold a play this long is quite daring. They're a very good trio, thank God. Very often you might make one mistake in casting, and then it can be not so good. But this time I'm really happy with them all.'

They even managed to get someone who can play guitar well enough to pass as a world-class rock star, which I say must be handy. 'Yes it is. For the auditions we said they had to be experts, but then some of them didn't bring their guitars, which was a bit worrying...' He rolls his eyes to the ceiling, which is sugar-frosted with pink rosebuds and cherubs. 'Thomas Beecham used to rehearse his orchestra here,' he says.

He'll do some more acting when this project is over. And though he won't exactly mourn Victor's passing, he is grateful for everything the series brought him. He is realistic too about his chances of doing anything that might have anything like the same impact. 'I'm destined to be called Victor for the rest of my life I suppose.'

It's odd, I say, that, although he played the old curmudgeon for 10 years, he has yet to reach pensionable age himself. 'Well, I didn't think of myself as old when it started, but now I look in the mirror some days and I think, Jesus...'

But he's not that old. He still plays squash at the RAC, a traditional gentleman's club. 'Ladies are allowed in as well,' he adds. This is slightly disappointing because I seem to remember reading somewhere that he preferred a younger, showbiz and media crowd; that he reads Face and GQ and Rolling Stone . I thought he might have been a Groucho man.

'Ah, well I'm a member of the Groucho too. I joined the RAC because of the squash and the swimming pool. And I tend to play squash with the younger people, so very often we start off at the RAC Club, because they have very good beer there, and move on later to the Groucho.'

He goes to see Man United play with Angus Deayton, who is a mate and fellow supporter. 'I met Angus on One Foot , and he asked if I'd like to come up to the club's boardroom and have lunch and watch the match in the director's box. We were with Alex. We mixed with the players. It's a pretty good way of seeing it.'

I'm not sure Roy Keane would approve.

What about older friends? 'Older people tend not to go out partying much,' he says. And as for the showbiz crowd: 'Well there's the physical thing - the fact that we work strange hours. But the other thing about actors is that by and large they are very good fun to be with - very generous spirited as a group.'

I tell him that I also read that as a theatre actor he won't do matinee performances - is that because he stays up too late? He laughs. 'I get terrible stick for that. But the reason I don't do too much theatre is the way it takes your life over. And eight shows a week is really tough. My feeling is that in matinees there's hardly ever anyone there. It's just a device to make money. So it's not laziness on my part, it's just wanting to do the best show, to do good work. A lot of traditionalists would think it's disgraceful, but if you've got the power to refuse why not? Actors hate matinees.'

What about films? Well he likes films. He has a passion for foreign films - especially Japanese ones, which loses me for a while as he enthuses about Kurosawa and Ozu and other household names (in Kyoto). He's quite sniffy about Hollywood, though. 'I don't regard the American cinema as having contributed very much,' he says.

This strikes me as a bit harsh. There must be some American films he likes surely?

'Well yes, of course...'

Has he seen one recently? He has a think. He starts telling me about a German one he saw on video, which hardly counts.

'To tell you the truth I don't go to the cinema much. I can't stand the adverts and people do tend to goggle a bit. But hang on... what's the one with the plane in the snow when the survivors find the money?'

'Is this the one where they have to eat each other?' I ask.

'No, no, there's an American actor in it.'

'Er... George Clooney?'

'No. But I did quite like one George Clooney film. Now what was it...'

' Batman ?'

'No, no. And not the new one...'

It turns out that I don't get out to the cinema much either. I ask whether he has any ambitions to do films himself. He looks doubtful. 'It takes so long to set up. In theatre you can work with the actors for four or five weeks at a stretch and you're in control. But as soon as you direct a film you have 18 different departments all trying to get it right. And then you can work on a film for two years and the producers come along and take your name off it.' As for movie acting, he says: ' I did Passage to India and things like that. I would have liked to have done more film but it never happened. I became a comedy television actor. I'm quite pragmatic in terms of looking at myself as a comic character. Though if someone was going to offer me a large movie role I wouldn't say no.'

For all his interest in hanging out at the Groucho and larging it at Old Trafford with Angus, his values are old school. He is a veteran of campaigns ranging from old people's rights to student grants. He is a supporter of the Labour Party though he would like to see it 'get back to its roots a bit'. It's not hard, I suggest, to detect a traditional pipesmoking Guardian reader.

'PIPESMOKING!' he shrieks. 'I think pipesmokers should be shot on SIGHT. They're the most SELFISH group of people. They can contaminate a room in three SECONDS.'

Now that's more like it. Victor dead? I don't bel...

 'I Just Stopped By to See the Man' opens at the Royal Court, London SW1, on Thursday (020 7565 5000). Richard Wilson (and others) will be reading from Roald Dahl at 'Quentin Blake and Friends' in aid of charity at the Royal Court on 7 December (contact as above).

fields.headline: Stockwatch
fields.trailText: Sinking sector
fields.body:
Sinking sector

As if you haven't had enough of the floods already, watch out this week for a deluge of figures from the water sector. The numbers, however, look set to make for even more ghastly reading.

Following new price controls from Ofwat in April, profits across the sector are expected to come in around one third lower, according to broker Merrill Lynch.

Such is the lack of enthusiasm that two firms - Kelda and Welsh Water - have or are trying to set themselves up as mutuals owned by customers. Thames Water has also given up the ghost, falling to a bid from Germany's RWE.

Amid all the misery, broker Schroder Salomon Smith Barney (SSSB) does single out one decent prospect: Pennon, the former South West Water. At 737p Pennon is now trading at above the broker's 713p target price, but still at a discount to SSSB's potential value of up to 791p per share.

Restructuring may come with the results this Thursday, so hold on for now.

Sun peeps out

Despite the flood damage, much-maligned insurer Royal & Sun Alliance has made a steady recovery since March when the first fruits of its recovery plan were revealed in its results.

The shares jumped sharply again last week but even at this level, broker Charles Stanley says, remain significantly undervalued compared with its European peers. Royal & Sun has been a potential bid target for some time, so investors should not just pin their hopes on the likes of Allianz suddenly banging on the door.

There is, however, still the potential that could be unlocked from Royal & Sun's strong fund management side and from its orphan assets.

With funds of £63 billion under management, the operation is a potential candidate for a spin-off.

Or Royal & Sun might be tempted to do something more interesting: like merge it with Rothschilds's ambitious asset management arm. Royal & Sun, remember, still owns a key slice of the merchant bank.

At 552p, the shares remain a recovery buy.

Speculative bet

If you like to lose your shirt, you'll love Zetters. The pools company, of course, has recently reinvented itself as an online gambling and financial services business by buying IFX, the foreign exchange operator.

The marriage of the two, the strategy goes, will allow Zetters to develop a range of financial instruments and betting products.

At 160p, according to broker WestLB Panmure, Zetters shares stand at a significant discount to spread betting expert IG Index. The broker has set a target price of 260p and the stock is, therefore, a speculative buy.

Rocky ride

A rare nugget drops into Stockwatch's hands this week: a research note from blue-blooded broker Cazenove on MacDonald Hotels.

Investors will have missed out on a roller-coaster ride in this hotelier if they took our advice two years ago to steer clear. Then the shares stood at 146p, slumped to a 130p low, rocketed to a 245p high before settling back to 157.5p now. Given the performance of the market since, long-term holders have not missed much.

Cazenove thinks up to five of MacDonald's 26 owned hotels may be sold in the next year but, with management contracts thrown in, the firm still has the best organic growth prospects in the sector. The broker's target price of 190p is based on a sector average multiple of 7.3 times earnings, the minimum fair reflection of MacDonald's growth potential. So perhaps the roller-coaster may be about to restart.

A speculative buy, but given the history remember when to get off.

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.trailText: How mean can a city get?
fields.body:
How mean can a city get?

Fear stalks Glasgow's Sunday Mail . The paper ran a top scoop last week revealing that David Moulsdale, founder of the Optical Express spectacles chain, who is worth an estimated £100 million, was to attend the funeral of murdered Glasgow gangster Tony McGovern.

The night before the story appeared Moulsdale won top prize at a Glasgow charity dinner: 'Be the editor of the Sunday Mail for a day'. Not only that, but the tycoon was last night due to attend the paper's annual 'Great Scot' awards as guest of honour: Optical Express is the event's main sponsor.

Does Moulsdale really intend to edit the Sunday Mail for a day? He insists he does, although no date has yet been set. Mail staff, including reporter Russell Findlay, who wrote the McGovern story, are anxiously awaiting his arrival. 'Maybe he could be the editor on Monday - that's our day off', one staffer said. 'I'll be calling in sick that day,' another added.

Only a spectator after all

Northern & Shell's acquisition of the Express titles has left crusading pundits looking a little tarnished. None more so than our old friend Stephen Glover, the unmissable media columnist of the Spectator . Steve, as his friends in EC1 call him, has followed every twist and turn of the Express saga with wit, glee, and erudition, writing almost a dozen columns. However, not even a man of his expertise and diligence spotted the publisher of Asian Babes on the horizon. Don't worry, Stevie babe, you're still OK! with us.

Sisters under (each other's) skin

Bloomsbury is learning a trick or two from Millbank. The spat between Margaret Drabble and her sister, the Booker prize-winning author Antonia Byatt, over Drabble's decision to write a novel sullying the memory of the woman who raised them, is enough to raise the eyebrows of the most hardened Westminster spin-doctor.

Byatt is too angry and upset to discuss her sister's novel, The Peppered Moth, published in January. When a newspaper phoned last week to ask how she felt, she replied: 'That is the end of our conversation.'

Callers who phone publisher Chatto to find out more are now being referred to a NewLabour-style rapid rebuttal unit staffed by two press officers issued with a list of 'key messages' compiled by Byatt. Phone up, Alastair Campbell, and weep.
