'I'll be calling in sick that day,' another added. Only a spectator after all Northern & Shell's acquisition of the Express titles has left crusading pundits looking a little tarnished. None more so than our old friend Stephen Glover, the unmissable media columnist of the Spectator . Steve, as his friends in EC1 call him, has followed every twist and turn of the Express saga with wit, glee, and erudition, writing almost a dozen columns. However, not even a man of his expertise and diligence spotted the publisher of Asian Babes on the horizon. Don't worry, Stevie babe, you're still OK! with us. Sisters under (each other's) skin Bloomsbury is learning a trick or two from Millbank. The spat between Margaret Drabble and her sister, the Booker prize-winning author Antonia Byatt, over Drabble's decision to write a novel sullying the memory of the woman who raised them, is enough to raise the eyebrows of the most hardened Westminster spin-doctor. Byatt is too angry and upset to discuss her sister's novel, The Peppered Moth, published in January. When a newspaper phoned last week to ask how she felt, she replied: 'That is the end of our conversation.' Callers who phone publisher Chatto to find out more are now being referred to a NewLabour-style rapid rebuttal unit staffed by two press officers issued with a list of 'key messages' compiled by Byatt. Phone up, Alastair Campbell, and weep.

fields.headline: Stealth wealth and happiness
fields.standfirst: For the seriously super-rich, it's inconspicuous consumption that matters most
fields.trailText: For the seriously super-rich, it's inconspicuous consumption that matters most.
fields.body:
I have been brooding about Elton John and what an extraordinarily old-fashioned figure he cuts. He is a national treasure who adds enormously to the gaiety of the nation, but he does go about buying houses and objects, clothes and gewgaws as if he were Citizen Kane or some weird shopaholic left over from the Eighties.

His conspicuous consumption is a million miles removed from the new luxury that is the trademark of today's multimillionaires. A handful of recent images must have told even the most obtuse observer of the lifestyle scene that notions of luxury ain't what they used to be.

There was Bill Gates on television, no longer quite the richest man in the world, but still so rich that few of us, if challenged, could get the noughts quite right - he was wearing an eye-popping collection of ramshackle clothing.

Then there were the photographs of the two would-be US Presidents, both doing their best to look purposeful and worthy holders of America's highest office, and what did their style gurus wheel them out in? Identical chinos and blue cotton shirts, that's what. And then there was Rupert Murdoch, no Johnny-come-lately dotcom millionaire, after all, trolled out in a fine black rollneck sweater instead of a Huntsman suit and a Jermyn Street shirt.

In their visual imagery, all four photographs sent out an unambiguous message: not only have the tastes and habits of the rich changed, but they are changing so fast that only the most agile have a hope of keeping up. New money isn't spending its money the way old money did, and even old money is changing its ways in the face of the demographic upheaval that new money is causing.

To the vast luxury-goods industry, which earns its fat living catering to the needs and whims of the rich, it sends out some challenging signals: it is clear notice that all the rules have changed, that it's time to forget making the things you've been accustomed to making since time began. You'd better start anticipating - and fast - what the new rich might want before somebody else gets there first. Getting it right adds up to unimaginable riches; getting it wrong means a takeover, a putsch, at worst, oblivion.

The problem with trying to define new luxury, though, is that the rules aren't all in place yet. New money doesn't give a toss for many of the old totems of wealth. New money prefers chinos and polo shirts to Savile Row suits, minimalist pads to chandelier-hung mansions, hanging out with pals to white-tie charity dos. New money is fast redefining the parameters of modern luxury - more youthful, more fun and, above all, more subtle. It's not about show and it's not about swank. Stealth wealth is what it's called. Stealth wealth does not mean a diminution of luxury or quality, merely a recognition of where it truly resides. It isn't about cutting back, as it means spending when it really matters, but not bothering when it doesn't. It's about private pleasure as opposed to public swank. It's about wearing the fur on the inside of your coat and never opting for the flash and dash of a Versace number. The new rich don't want to show off so much as enjoy their carefully amassed fortunes.

Stealth wealth is not about spending less (the irony is that it can very often cost a great deal more), but the power and the swagger are subtler. A minimalist pad by John Pawson may look as austere as a monk's cell, but believe me, it doesn't come cheap. As Donald Trump pointed out in a recent interview: 'In the Eighties, you drove around in a limousine and now you drive around in a vehicle that is supposed to look like a Jeep - you know, non-conspicuous - but which actually costs four times more than the limousine.'

So this new luxury is a much more complicated business than the old. Old luxury had very clear agendas. It was supposed to provide a cocoon of comfort for those lucky enough to be able to afford it, but its more serious function was to separate the seriously rich not only from the poor, but also the merely well-heeled. It was also perfectly permissible for old luxury to be conspicuous. That was part of the point. The problem today, as the economist James Sproule puts it 'is not that you don't have enough, it's that other people have too much'. In other words, now that every clubber can wear a T-shirt by Dolce e Gabbana, have the Prada shoes, the table at the Ivy, and long-haul holi days are available to so many, what are the truly rich to do?

If you want to know, watch the Goldman Sachs partners at play, an absorbing study in how times have changed. A Casio watch (£60 for a standard G-Shock), we are reliably informed, is the watch of choice for the firm's chief executive, a man whose annual salary is more than most people earn in a lifetime.

Their wives take pride in spending in an anonymous 'below the parapet' kind of way; they have large and beautifully furnished houses, but the look is never 'showy'. They dress impeccably, but never swankily. You will note that snobbery has not been removed from the matter of luxury, more that new, subtler, more complicated snobbisms have arisen.

The difference is that while any fool can spend millions on expensive objects, spending money the new way takes more than dosh, it takes insider knowledge, sophistication. The new spender likes to feel he's right in there on the inside track, discovering things long before hoi polloi. One type of olive oil may seem much like another, but stealth wealth means knowing whether cold-pressed extra virgin from the groves of Liguria is better than virgin oil from southern Greece. To be one of the new luxury purists, you not only have to buy the very best, but know what the very best is.

Insider information is where the new snobbery really comes into its own. It's being the first to get to the new hide-away luxury lodge; it's knowing a small profumeria in Florence where you can get scents made to order; it's discovering a craftsman who makes handbags in finest calf which are infinitely more desirable than a seen-everywhere, high-profile label.

It's knowing why Alessi kettles, iBooks or tables by Christian Liaigre are better than their rivals. It's finding the small shop that imports the finest teas, knowing why Blue Mountain coffee is judged to be the best in the world. New luxury isn't for the lazy.

It is, however, for the pure of mind; for those who are anti-branding and pro-green; who do not want the products around them to carry an instantly recognisable label that speaks of some big corporation in the background (whether that be Levi's, Versace or Coca-Cola); and who do not want to feel guilt pangs every time they drive a car that guzzles gas or taste a chicken that's been battery-farmed. If you spend your money on the right things, you're telling the world that you're not just rich, you're also enlightened.

These are all matters I've been considering ever since, a few months ago, I joined a group of men who have formed a company called Quintessentially. Its sole aim is to deliver luxury, wherever it is to be found, to its members. So far as we knew, nobody had put together a company solely committed to this sort of new millennium luxury.

But how, we had to ask each other, did we define luxury today? What did we want to deliver? What would appeal to the kind of sophisticated, educated, cultured members of Quintessentially we had in mind? Interestingly, although we are of very varied ages and come from very different backgrounds, we shared an extraordinarily cohesive point of view. Mostly, our ideas of what modern luxury is about centred on simple things done quite beautifully - olive oil, but it had to be the best estate-bottled, cold-pressed virgin olive oil; the finest soap, triple-milled and perfumed only with essential oils or herbs; first-class mature cheddar; and the best-quality white linen sheets, finely hem-stitched.

Things that even the poorest might once have taken for granted - space, quiet, tranquillity, pure water - are luxuries these days. Which explains why, as a symbol of what we stood for, we chose a bottle of the purest water we could find (from Cape Grim in Tasmania, where the rain falls from air that has blown in from Antarctica, making it the least polluted air space in the world).

We found that we minded about quality writing paper and tissue-lined envelopes. And proper candles, divine scents, cashmere sweaters, fresh flowers and good wine. For us, though, the ultimate new luxury had to be time and service. Shortage of time is the modern disease, and if only we could sort out the things that eat into our leisure time, then we felt we really would have a company on our hands.

What the pressed executive really needs is not yet another branded polo shirt as he is much more likely to need someone to arrange his dry-cleaning, buy a present for his granny, wrap up all his Christmas presents and make sure the family flights to Nice are booked. Forget chandeliers and furs - what we wanted was a good manicure or massage at home, tickets for the concert we'd forgotten to book. New millennium luxury, as you can see, is a complicated package to deliver.

I'm not sure Elton John will become a client. But who knows, he may learn to mend his ways and start wearing a Casio watch and chinos.

 This article originally appeared in the New Statesman

webTitle: The mysteries of love are less vital than a catflap

fields.headline: The mysteries of love are less vital than a catflap
fields.standfirst: So that's that. The house has finally been bought. But will this fairy tale have a happy ending?
fields.trailText: So that's that. The house has finally been bought. But will this fairy tale have a happy ending?
fields.body:
I am translated. The house opposite the Poet's is mine. Love has triumphed over estate agents, mortgage companies, surveyors, combative solicitors and my own hard-won insistence on a solitary existence.

Nothing more than a narrow tarmacadamed road separates me from having to admit that I am living with someone. London is my past, Cambridge is my present. The future has been repeatedly defined by the builders and decorators I've contacted as 'not before Christmas', and even that's further than I care to see right now.

Anxious metropolitan friends phone and ask about the state of my spirit/soul/psyche/brain chemistry (depending on their specialisms). I shriek with laughter from the floor of what will be my workroom, what is my workroom as I write this, deskless, chairless, empty of everything but a cushion (squirrelled from the Poet's sofa), a laptop and a phone.

The state of my inner life is for some later, barely imaginable time when I am not finding and negotiating with and co-ordinating plasterers, joiners, carpet fitters, kitchen installers, bathroom renovators, painters and removal vans. There is no time for wondering if I have just made the worst mistake of my life in leaving the only place I've ever known, or if just the one Prozac a day will keep the lurking palpitations at bay.

The mysteries of love pale into insignificance beside decisions about exactly what kind of off-white the walls should be, and whether or not I want to have a wok burner on my new oven (I do, I really do, it turns out). So far the catflap has been fitted - the first priority - a teapot and kettle bought, my floor-level work place set up, and the whereabouts of John Lewis (alias Robert Sayle in these parts) established. I can stroke my traumatised cats, drink gallons of tea, get on screen the book I'm supposed to be working on and then turn it off, and madly order household items I will regret when they are delivered.

All life's other necessities go on across the road in the Poet's kitchen, bathroom, TV room and bedroom. But as to what all this means in any meaningful way, I cannot say. Ask me the drop required for the blinds in the living-room, and I will give you them to the nearest centimetre. Wonder about the relative virtue of twist pile or velvet carpeting and I will provide you with an elegant thesis on the subject. Query the optimum wattage for a fast-flowing shower and I will clear the matter up for you in a trice.

But ask me how I feel about having moved in order to be with a particular person, ask me about love, ask me about the nature of relationships and you might as well be speaking to me in Old Norse. This may be a kind of shell-shock, a deep traumatic reaction, but I've lost all language for things which are not practical and palpable.

There is a kind of reduced dialogue of emotions between the Poet and myself. We sit together, and after a period of silence, one of us will say: 'Are you OK?' The other tenses slightly before offering a clipped: 'Fine. You?' 'Mmm, fine.' This delicate investigation into each other's interior well-being is supplemented sometimes in the middle of the night, when one of us wakes up, nudges the other, and asks: 'Is everything all right?' 'Mmm, fine. Everything all right with you?' 'I'm fine.' So, everything's fine.

Love notwithstanding, we are living or partly living in a hiatus between normalities. At some point, the painters, plumbers and plasterers having left, there will no choice but to acknowledge that real life has started once again. Right now, life is an ongoing emergency, a waiting time, a series of appointments to be kept, deliveries to be made, when no one can tell what they feel about the way things are, because nothing has finished and nothing has started.

As with the improbability of late love having descended so gratuitously, the Poet and I should be thankful for the experience of turmoil at a time when most people are beginning to go into mourning for the loss of the chance of further turmoil in their lives.

But perhaps what causes our monosyllabic reaction to our new condition is not the chaos of the present, but fear of the return to the regular. What if contentment turns out to be the last thing we want? It's never been a state I've much admired, mostly because I don't think I have come across it much in others (ever, I might almost say), but also because I've always doubted that contentment is very good for people. It is no surprise to me that the fairy stories end with living happily ever after while refusing to give the slightest clue as to what that might be like. What would you think if when you asked someone how they were, they replied 'Happy'? Probably that they needed counselling.

What if, once the carpets are down and there are sofas to sit on, happily ever after awaits the Poet and me? Just as with death, sentimentalists and moralists have concocted fantasies about what happiness might be like, but no one I've heard of has ever returned from that place to confirm or deny the speculations. Well, we'll just have to wait and see. Maybe, in time to come, as your intrepid reporter of the ancient heart, I'll be in a position to report back on the matter one way or another.

 Margaret Cook returns next week

fields.headline: Loyd looms large
fields.standfirst: Eyebrows were raised when Grossman, the strangely accented Anglophile, was taken on to pep up the food in NHS hospitals. But he 'rehally' doesn't understand what all the fuss is about
fields.trailText: Eyebrows were raised when Grossman, the strangely accented Anglophile, was taken on to pep up the food in NHS hospitals. But he 'rehally' doesn't understand what all the fuss is about.
fields.body:
Let's look at the evidence. 'Loads of cookbooks, none used apart from a well-thumbed version of Claudia Roden's Book of Middle Eastern Cookery . A Boston Red Sox baseball cap. And, oh, what else can I say... mmm, a bicycle, probably, although I'm not very well known for being a bicyclist. Not even by my local bike shop. So... let's say a television set.'

Unfortunately, we're having to make do with a Loyd Grossman's take on his Fulham house, because he doesn't like the idea of me visiting him there. 'Thanks to the Hunter S. Thompson school of journalism,' he says, 'the interview begins the moment someone walks down the street and notices the empty crisp packet blowing across the pavement.'

So the idea of a stranger coming and poking around in your house is abhorrent to you, is it, Loyd?

Loyd snuffles. 'Heugh, heugh, heugh. Yeugh, it's not my thing particularly.'

Loyd, who is best known for snooping around the homes of C-list celebs on Through the Keyhole and snacking on overwrought dishes on Masterchef , has just been appointed consultant to the government review of the NHS menu. Though the move has earned him the extravagant tabloid sobriquet of Hospital Food Tsar, this is essentially an administrative role. which gives health minister Alan Milburn droit du seigneur over his address book. Since Loyd spent 10 years on Masterchef before resigning this summer - he objected to the show being moved to BBC2, and becoming more of a food programme than a cook-off - he has connections with most celebrated spatula-wavers.

Loyd has already rung up six top chefs, including chaps from the Ivy and the Savoy, and all have agreed to visit the kitchens of various hospital trusts. Their comments will lay the foundation for his 'very small paper', which in turn will be debated by dietitians and caterers, 'and in January we'll all get together for a big session. Some commentators have suggested that it is a prime example of New Labour spin, but as Loyd himself points out: 'If it was intended to be a publicity stunt, they could have got hold of someone a lot better than me to be the fall guy.' Unlike the Jamies and the Nigellas, Loyd - and one can't help wondering occasionally whether this is something he solemnly plays up to - is something of a national figure of fun. His accent, as conspicuous and unwieldy on these cramped shores as a pink stretch Cadillac, actually seems to gets more pronounced with age. Apparently even Bostonians hear it with disbelief on their faces.

And then there is the food issue. We associate Loyd with Rustic Salad of Quail with Wild Mushrooms, with Pistachio Bavarois With Caramelised Bananas, and with spun-sugar baskets: preposterously fussy food for gastronomes, not nutritious hot dinners for invalids. 'We're not coming up with high-falutin ideas,' drawls Loyd, as neat as a seal in his weekend attire of moss-coloured tweed suit, navy cashmere poloneck and long brown brogues, as he sits in a hotel dining room overlooking Hyde Park. He is a regional commissioner for English Heritage, chair of the Campaign for Museums and a member of the board of the Council for Museums, Archives and Libraries (mostly low- or unpaid work financed by his eponymous pasta sauces). 'It has totally taken me by surprise,' he says of his adventures in red tape. 'I never expected to be able to do it even reasonably well. 'We used to say that if he'd gone to a British school, he wouldn't behave like that.' Miaow! 'It's been her claim to fame for about 12 years,' he sighs. '"Hi, what I've got to say is that Loyd Grossman isn't a team player." Anyway, I do work well with people. I'm always very good with teams. That's why I've been able to work on television for so long, because that's all about teamwork.'

In the past, he explains, Caroline Waldegrave, Prue Leith and Claudia Roden have been asked to suggest changes to the NHS menu, with little effect. 'So maybe I won't be able to do it, either. But I can't simply not try because it might not work.' Still, failure would be galling. Will he just sit quietly if his recommendations are ignored? 'No. Because it's not my style. I've been so publicly asked - I would be incredibly irritated, yeugh.'

Though Loyd says he is 'incredibly interested in politics', and would have plumped for Gore, albeit 'by a very narrow margin', he never got around to filling in his US postal vote. He will not be drawn on British politics, although his father-in-law, Lord Puttnam, is a Labour peer. 'I ain't going there. I don't want to be trapped in one camp or the other.'

Private or NHS, Loyd? 'If it was something major and critical, it would be the NHS.' You don't have private health cover, then? 'Oh, I think I must do. But if it was something important, it would be the NHS.'

Milburn's invitation came at the right time, just after the news about Masterchef . Keyhole , extraordinarily enough, is still running after 17 years, but apart from that Loyd has no immediate telly plans. 'I'm talking to people... You know, I did not want to spend my entire television career in the ghetto of lifestyle programming. And thankfully, I think I'm finally making a break.'

As he will tell you, Loyd never set out to be on the box. He made the move accidentally when he was at Harpers & Queen and and was asked to appear on a TV-AM slot, deconstructing the soft furnishings of soap stars. Keyhole has a dubious claim to fame: harnessing interiors and the far reaches of celebrity, it was an indication of the future of television.

At first, Loyd, the foreigner from an upmarket glossy, was jolly rude, just as the TV producers hoped he would be. He was particularly merciless about the impressionist Faith Brown's sideboard. 'Of course, I don't care what kind of wallpaper anyone has, frankly. It's of so little interest to me,' he says, unconvincingly. 'But I thought it was quite a funny idea. It had a tremendous amount of shock value when it started - up until then, no one had really done a TV programme focusing on lampshades.' But pretty quickly he realised that he felt uncomfortable, and retracted his claws: nowadays he sounds rather like an estate agent, oohing and aahing over horsebrasses and inglenook fireplaces. Still, there is a strange tension between the platitudes and the nasal quality to his voice, which means that his remarks usually sound rather sneery. He was never an obvious candidate for the title of lifestyle king. Watching Masterchef , you felt for him as much as the contestants when the time came for him to tour the kitchens and make agonising small talk: he had the air of a prosecution attorney who had stumbled through the back of the wardrobe when hunting for his horsehair wig.

Loyd is quite different in the flesh. On telly, he is remote and arch and a bit of a know-it-all; here, he is cordial, a little shy, slightly prickly, and fairly willing to poke fun at himself. An unabashed aesthete (he orders grapefruit juice, having ascertained first that it is fresh; and, when offered either Earl Grey or English Breakfast, murmurs that what he'd really ad-DORE would be some Lapsang Souchong), yes, but a likeable one. It's not what one expects. Today, though obviously on his guard, he gives the impression of a free man, in comparison to the formal, uptight telly creature I was expecting. So I ask if he feels natural on television.

'Yeugh, I feel very... I like it. I like television.'

Because, I continue, you always seem quite self-conscious, as if you're never exactly relaxed when you're in front of the cameras.

'Probably,' says Loyd, stonewalling.

You always seem rather... conscientious , I venture, trying desperately hard not to say 'swotty'.

'Yes... maybe conscientious,' agrees Loyd, mutedly. He stares at me, and begins to laugh. I have the nasty feeling he knows exactly where I'm coming from. 'Conscientious! There's an accolade!'

I try again. 'Would you say you have a unique presenting style?'

'Eugh-eugh-eugh! Oh dear! Go on, say I'm rubbish! Go on!'

So I ask him to analyse his UPS, but Loyd, though he is making noises like a resident of Sea World, isn't going to play ball. 'Presumably I'm hired to fill up airtime and entertain a few people,' he says, when the smokescreen has cleared. 'But whether it's my conscientiousness or my sex appeal, I don't want to know.' Certainly, his friends tease him about Keyhole , and his background never pointed him in the direction of the lifestyle ghetto.

Loyd grew up in Marblehead, Massachusetts, a seaside town with eight yacht clubs. His father, a Jewish antique dealer who had at one time been a jazz musician, was 59 when he was born in 1950; his mother was in her late thirties. Loyd was introduced to the joys of European history at school, and soon developed a particular fondness for England. While studying history at Boston University, he wigged out over the Stones and the Kinks, and ordered copies of the Who's latest records from Harrods' record department. Later, he played guitar with a band that made number 49 in the charts. He is still an avid pop fan: the last CD he bought was Moby's Play .

His other enthusiasm, apart from glossy British magazines, was Victorian architecture. When in 1975 he came to do his Masters at LSE (it was big on his specialism, pre-industrial economic history), he set off on a rather unusual architectural tour. 'I remember seeing this picture of Manchester Town Hall in a book and my mind was just blown away, because I could not believe this incredible palace was a town hall somewhere in the north of England.' After Manchester, his second destination was the Walker art gallery in Liverpool.

He has no homing instinct for the States, though the family (he and Debbie have two daughters, Florence and Constance) spend summers there. Loyd has an alien's sentimentality for his adopted country. Rapturously, his eye fastens on the window as the Household Cavalry trots past. 'They do look pretty fabulous, don't they? Now, that is cool.' A few years ago, he became a British citizen. 'It was important to me emotionally. I wanted to prove that I have a stake in the country. Because of my public service work, I thought it was important to let people know that I was on board.' I find myself crossing my fingers that Loyd will not be offered any more telly work. He's much more use to us off it than on.

webTitle: Legacy left waiting for Dome's day

fields.headline: Legacy left waiting for Dome's day
fields.standfirst: Nick Mathiason  on the uncertain prospects for converting backers to tenants of the Silicon Tent
fields.trailText: Nick Mathiason on the uncertain prospects for converting backers to tenants of the Silicon Tent
fields.body:
Robert Bourne, the property tycoon, donated thousands of pounds to both Margaret Thatcher and Tony Blair. A self-confessed political chameleon, this 50-year-old entrepreneur is pivotal to Labour's election chances next year.

Bourne's Legacy consortium last Monday won preferred developer status to run the maligned Millennium Dome in Greenwich.

Backed by Irish property investor Treasury Holdings, Legacy has three months to complete on the £125 million Dome deal. If it collapses Labour will go into an election campaign sitting on one amazing fiasco.

Bourne is a tanned, gleaming-toothed, slightly chubby man with more than a passing resemblance to singer Frankie Lane. His vision for the Dome's 1 million sq ft is for it to become London's most important technology hub. Under the Dome's roof, a cluster will form allowing academic institutions, start-ups and technology multinationals to feed off each other and grow, helped by in-house patent lawyers and accountants.

Legacy will create a vibrant campus for 14,000 high-skilled workers in what is a deprived part of south-east London. It will tear slits in the Dome roof to allow natural light to flood in. It will plant 3,000 mature trees within its structure. A Mediterranean climate will be guaranteed. There won't be swifter cables through which to transmit data anywhere in the country, claims Legacy. And rents for start-ups will be 'affordable'.

Bourne's major argument for creating what he calls Knowledge City is that London has run out of affordable space for fledgling businesses. Even for established concerns, he says, finding cheap offices is almost impossible.

True enough, Canary Wharf, a 14 million sq ft office complex, is now on course to being fully let within 18 months. The surrounding Docklands area is thriving, the Square Mile is nearly full and such is the demand for premises in London's West End that two weeks ago, terms were agreed in Mayfair on an unprecedented rent of £90 per sq ft - an all-time UK record. West of London, in the Thames Valley, developers can't build quick enough for dotcom and telecom firms.

Canary Wharf lies across the river from the Dome. Its glass and steel towers contain most of the world's leading banks which, if all goes to plan, will be able to peer down on their investments in Dome-housed start-ups with pride.

If Knowledge City works, it could be the catalyst to regenerate what's known as the Thames Gateway region - a swath of land in Essex and Kent straddling the Thames that for years has suffered from economic hardship.

'It's not Silicon Valley,' said Dr Chris Evans, a leading biotech entrepreneur. 'But it can be quite sexy. It'll take a number of years to do it. But there is a need for this sort of thing in London. The real effort will be dragging firms down there. Once they get there, I'm sure they'll like it.'

Of all the competing uses for the Dome once the 'celebrations' conclude at the end of this year, Legacy's always seemed the most convincing on paper.

The Sports Dome idea was never going to make enough money. A pure business park would have been too dull. And after all that has happened during the last year, it seems clear that Nomura's idea of basing a national visitor attraction in a relatively inaccessible part of south-east London was never going to take-off. Indeed, Nomura insiders - days before its bid's collapse last September - confided that they would replicate Bourne's idea if a visitor attraction failed.

Yet assuming it ever gets to the stage of exchanging contracts with the Government, Legacy has got one mighty battle on its hands if it is to turn the Dome into a success.

The first problem is that the Legacy consortium is relatively inexperienced when it comes to developing a site this big. Trained as an accountant, Bourne made millions during the Eighties out of a company called Local London, the first ever serviced office provider, and sold out before the Crash. He still trades property and is also a senior executive at Clubhaus, the golf course owner. But Bourne has never developed a major site.

Legacy's business development director, Bruce Walker does not have a development background. He trained as an investment banker.

Likewise, Treasury Holdings, which is believed to own up to 75 per cent of Legacy, is also known in property circles as a trading outfit that places as little of its own equity into investments as possible. It has attempted some shopping centre development in Ireland. But never in the UK.

Perhaps more fundamentally Legacy has not got a single tenant to commit to its scheme. Its literature cites 3COM, BT, Sun Microsystems and the Open University as evidence that the demand exists for its scheme.

The Observer contacted all these firms last week and none of them have committed to Legacy's Dome vision. The Open University has indicated it wants a technological showcase venue in London but hasn't committed to Greenwich yet. Marketing chiefs at Sun Microsystems met with Legacy last summer, offered the consortium a letter of support but have no plans to take this further.

3COM and Imperial College appear the most enthusiastic independent backers of Legacy. 3COM already provides the Dome's computer network. It wants to keep this contract and is considering taking space there but at Imperial any decision to locate at the Dome will be taken by the spin-off businesses it fosters in its labs.

Chris Vydra is the man responsible for getting tenants on to the site. Last week, he defended Legacy's progress by saying that no firm is going to commit to a project before contracts have been signed. That's fair enough.

He also said since Legacy was given 'preferred bidder' status, he has received more than 100 letters from small businesses wanting to be a part of what Legacy is trying to create.

If that's the case, it is a good sign. But the public, which regards the Dome as more depressing than recent floods, will not forgive any false hopes.

Interested? They may be

BT Thought to have signed up but hasn't committed yet. 'We are not waving any cheque book but we don't want to pour cold water on it,' a spokesman said. Sees potential for a deal.

Open University Meeting Legacy next week to discuss basing a showcase venue at the Dome. The Milton Keynes-based institution 'endorses the proposal' and designed Legacy's website. Believes the Dome offers OU the opportunity 'to raise the profile of its research and leading edge spin-offs'.

3COM US executives from network provider 3COM will meet with Legacy this week to discuss how its network can be extended for Legacy's tenants. It is interested in taking space and helping to finance the overall project.

Imperial College Since March, the college has helped Legacy to flesh out rental income scenarios and worked on assessing the contamination of the site. Is very supportive of the idea. But decisions to locate there lie with individuals within its spin-off businesses.

Sun Microsystems Likes the concept and sent a letter of support. Cited in Legacy literature as wanting to take space but last week said there's 'no ongoing partnership'.

London Business School The Dean wrote a letter of support for Legacy since the finance director was an LBS graduate. But has no interest in the scheme beyond that.

Merlin Ventures Merlin supports Legacy but is unlikely to take space in the Dome.

NTL The telecom giant cabled the Dome, and is discussing whether its technology can be used in Knowledge City. No plans to locate there or invest yet.

But decisions to locate there lie with individuals within its spin-off businesses. Sun Microsystems Likes the concept and sent a letter of support. webTitle: Cross the Channel, Tony, not the pond

fields.headline: Cross the Channel, Tony, not the pond
fields.trailText: The British have long had an ambiguous view of their transatlantic cousins. On the one hand there was a certain resentment at their GIs being overpaid and over here, dispensing their cigarettes and nylons. On the other we were naturally grateful for the vast armies of Patton and Eisenhower that ensured Germany's surrender.
fields.body:
The British have long had an ambiguous view of their transatlantic cousins. On the one hand there was a certain resentment at their GIs being overpaid and over here, dispensing their cigarettes and nylons. On the other we were naturally grateful for the vast armies of Patton and Eisenhower that ensured Germany's surrender.

Ever since, we have lapped up American culture - Elvis Presley, Steven Spielberg movies, Friends - while complaining about the inevitable dumbing-down effect it has had on our society.

However, this confusion has scarcely troubled our Prime Ministers. Macmillan, Wilson, Callaghan, Thatcher - all have believed in the special relationship. But they seem to have been flying in the face of the evidence. Washington's refusal to write off the loans that allowed us to fight the Second World War arguably brought Britain close to bankruptcy.

Indeed, it has been suggested recently that while the Americans' military objective was the defeat of Hitler, their post-war economic aims were somewhat different, ie to bring the British Empire to its knees and make the world a safer place for US business.

And while we continued to turn cartwheels to please the White House - and keep an independent nuclear deterrent - US foreign policy has subsequently only ever favoured the UK when it suited America. The special relationship is no more than a court jester tumbling for his liege lord.

Of course, for years our stance was based on the delusion that we were still a world power, but for all but the most ostrich-like that delusion has long since faded.

In another part of their collective brain our rulers knew that our future lay with Europe and briefly, in 1975, most of us voted to put the UK there. Since when our relationship with the Continent has been as contradictory as that with Old Glory, but politicians in power have all marched us ever further up the aisle - even Mrs Thatcher, although she talked dirty as she walked.

Business, with the exception of the occasional rich furniture magnate, has consistently been in favour of strengthening this European connection, and who would be surprised?

We imported about £100 billion worth of goods from EU countries in 1999 and exported slightly less to them. Broadly speaking, this is four times the level of our trade - both inward and outward - with the US. And this is not a flash in the pan. Go back a quarter of a century to the time of the referendum and although the numbers were only about a tenth the size, the proportions were the same.

The US is an immensely important market and the focus of vast quantities of British investment. Many have followed in the footsteps of Eighties buccaneer Lord Hanson whose corporate TV slogan was, if you remember 'the company from over here that's big over there'.

But our real special relationship is with Europe, and at last we have a Prime Minister who is saying so. Tony Blair may not thank anyone for pointing this out but he is the first First Lord since Ted Heath to nail his colours so firmly to the mast.

Now he must put his money where his mouth is. The strength of the pound against the deutschmark has destroyed 143,000 UK manufacturing jobs since June 1996, according to the CBI, which predicts a further 73,000 casualties in the next two years. That would be a senseless slaughter.

fields.headline: Allied's fighting spirit
fields.standfirst: In the war for Seagram, a swashbuckling supremo is set to become a hero - or a villain.  Paul Farrelly reports
fields.trailText: In the war for Seagram, a swashbuckling supremo is set to become a hero - or a villain. Paul Farrelly reports
fields.body:
'He who has the vodka has the power.' Ten days ago, the age-old Russian adage looked tailor-made for Philip Bowman, the ambitious chief executive of drinks giant Allied Domecq, as he snatched the lucrative US rights for Stolichnaya vodka away from arch-rival Diageo.

It was Tsar Bowman's second daring coup in as many months. The dying days of October found Allied's helmsman swashbuckling around the Caribbean, readying to loot the good ship Captain Morgan in a pre-emptive strike against Seagram, the rum brand's Canadian owner.

Both acts of piracy are but prologues to the main attraction: the £5 billion auction of Seagram's drinks division, the world's third largest spirits and wines operation. The year's most colourful bid saga is now entering its penultimate act, as Seagram's Wall Street adviser Morgan Stanley issues draft sale agreements to the only three serious bidders: Allied Domecq, Diageo in an Anglo-French pairing with Pernod Ricard, and a three-way alliance between Bacardi, Brown Forman - the US owner of Jim Beam bourbon - and Sweden's Vin & Spirit, purveyor of hip 'n' cool Absolut vodka.

This weekend, Bowman stands a contract away from being hailed as genius or condemned as a villain. Genius, because Stolichnaya gives Allied a much-needed replacement for Absolut, which intends to repossess its valuable US distribution rights now held by Seagram. And last month's deal with Destilería Serralles - the Puerto Rican producer of rum which Seagram sells as Captain Morgan - may not only unsettle its rivals for Seagram but yield Allied the best consolation prize if it loses. If the deal stands up in court, Serralles will claim the Captain Morgan trademark from Seagram and fill the other glaring gap in Allied's drinks cabinet with the world's second-best selling rum behind Bacardi.

And villain, because on both counts Bowman may have been too clever by half. If so, he will be accused of losing Seagram and a once-in-a-lifetime chance to keep pace with Diageo. An also-ran Allied might face a bid from the likes of Pernod and deal-hungry venture capitalists.

'The stakes couldn't be higher,' one leading City drinks analyst said. 'After these deals, Allied is currently going around institutional investors playing down the need for Seagram. Despite the swagger, that smacks of weakness and lack of confidence that Bowman will win.'

The Stolichnaya deal in the States has already prompted rumblings back in mother Russia. Unnoticed by the western press, just 24 hours later a Russian federal body claimed that Allied's partner, Soyuzplodimport (SPI), had no rights to the Stolichnaya brand, stating the trademarks had been illegally privatised. The decision, by the Audit Chamber of the Russian Federation, 'jeopardises the results of an international tender for the right to distribute Stolichnaya in the US,' it said, urging the government to seize 'Stoli' and 42 other vodka brands.

The timing was hardly coincidental. President Vladimir Putin has been fighting a running battle all year to regain control of Russia's vodka industry and its essential tax revenues.

Only a fortnight ago, a 51 per cent stake in Stoli's producer, Moscow's 100-year-old Cristall distillery, was handed over to the Kremlin after it was occupied by armed gangs supporting two rival directors. In May, SPI's Moscow headquarters were also raided by the police's anti-organised crime unit in an investigation into the firm's acquisition of the vodka brands. Cristall, too, has also fought SPI over ownership of export brands.

Last week Diageo was eager to stir the pot, prompting another spat with Allied. 'Up to the last minute, they were keen to keep the rights they held for the last 10 years,' an Allied spokesman said. 'It's sour grapes by Diageo.'

The full Stoli story, however - which The Observer can now reveal - shows the scope there is for Allied to be dragged into messy Russian and overseas litigation over the vodka brand.

The key figure behind Stoli is Yuri Shefler, a 33-year-old, high-living graduate of Moscow State University with a penchant for Monaco. SPI's similarly-named predecessor, Soyuzplodoimport (Old SPI, or literally in Russian 'The Union of Fruit and Vegetable Importers'), had been privatised in 1992 but was poorly managed and quickly fell on hard times.

Shefler took over the management reins in 1997 and set up SPI as a new parallel company, which assumed Old SPI's trading and increasingly ran the business via Cyprus, a favoured offshore haven for Russia's business elite. Old SPI used to route exports through its German operation, Plodimex. Since 1998, however, according to Russian sources, this has been wound down, exports have been shipped direct from Moscow and payments handled by three offshore firms: SPI Spirits in Cyprus, SPI Ltd in Gibraltar and SPI NV in the Netherlands.

In 1998, confusing matters more, Old SPI also changed its name so now there are two identically named vodka companies registered as Soyuzplodimport in Moscow. Old SPI, the Russian authorities allege, also illegally transferred 43 vodka trademarks to SPI. The price, they claim, was a derisory 1.7 million roubles (£43,500), against the Foreign Trade Ministry's valuation of more than £1bn for Stolichnaya alone.

Old SPI's 21 shareholders included its management and Russia's distilleries, including Cristall. The new SPI, however, is controlled by two different firms: Elery, a front for a mystery Russian woman, Yevgena Kocheryzhkina, and Interkatrin Group Corporation, a company registered in Delaware in the US. Who set up Elery and who controls Interkatrin are uncertain. Shefler, meanwhile, has described the Russian authorities' actions as 'extortion'.

As the battle continues, however, SPI's structure raises the prospect, Russian sources say, of litigation spilling over into the US as Putin fights to regain con trol of Stolichnaya and much-needed vodka revenues.

Allied has certainly not gone into the Stoli deal blind: 'We have not paid a material amount up front,' a spokeswoman said. 'We remain a very conservative company, morally and legally, and would not announce anything unless we believed we were secure.' But Bowman failed to sign up Absolut: the Swedes were concerned about Allied's weak US distribution, one of the reasons Bowman covets Seagram. And if Allied fails to win the Canadian firm, it is hard to see Stoli eating into the lead of Absolut and Diageo's best-selling Smirnoff in the US market.

It is the Puerto Ricans, Bowman hopes, who have handed him the trump card in the auction. Founded in 1865 by Don Juan Serralles, the son of a Spanish settler, Destilería Serralles supplies Seagram with its Captain Morgan rums from the city of Ponce on the Caribbean island's south coast. With annual sales of more than $100m, including its flagship Don Q rum label, Serralles is one of the US dependency's biggest companies.

Until Allied's coup, Seagram and its highly paid advisers had given no attention to the 'change of control' clause in Serralles's supply contract which gives it the right to match the price offered by any other bidder for the Captain Morgan brand. Citing US precedent, which Puerto Rican law follows, the Canadians argue they are rock solid in rebutting any Allied claims. So confident are they that a sale of the shares in the drinks company, Joseph E Seagram & Sons, does not trigger the Serralles clause, they have now offered bidders an indemnity against any legal action by Allied and the Puerto Ricans.

Bowman and his gaggle of lawyers, meanwhile, are playing it streetwise. Allied, industry sources say, is putting as much faith in the local clout wielded by Felix Juan Serralles, the Don's great grandson, as legal niceties. 'Serralles is a Puerto Rican company and a pretty big one at that. This will be decided in a Puerto Rican court, by Puerto Rican judges, say no more than that,' one source said.

Allied's chief, however, has left Seagram and Morgan Stanley incandescent by trying to put them over a barrel. How Bowman reveals his cards in the next few weeks will determine whether Allied holds an ace in the hole or has overplayed its hand.

webTitle: Cancer drug ruling will be make or break for Scotia

fields.headline: Cancer drug ruling will be make or break for Scotia
fields.trailText: The fate of Scotia, formerly one of UK biotechnology's star performers, is set to be decided this week as a decision is made on whether it can sell its cancer drug Foscan in the lucrative American market.
fields.body:
The fate of Scotia, formerly one of UK biotechnology's star performers, is set to be decided this week when the US Food and Drugs Administration (FDA) gives a decision on whether it can sell its cancer drug Foscan in the lucrative American market.

Scotia has refiled an application for approval, but the FDA could tell it to restart clinical trials. The FDA rejected Scotia's initial application for the drug in September, triggering a collapse in the company's shares. On Friday they stood at 19p, compared with 229p in March.

The FDA said data provided by Scotia did not prove the efficacy of the treatment. The sample of 50 patients in clinical trials may have been too small. Scotia plans to resubmit data on 147 patients, and hopes that this will lead to FDA approval and a launch within eight months.

But the FDA may require Scotia to carry out an additional clinical trial, pushing back launch of the drug for up to two years, by which time Scotia's financing will have dried up.

Analysts estimate Scotia has enough cash to last to the spring, but will then need refinancing. It has a £50 million outstanding convertible bond, convertible into shares at 340p in 2002. If Scotia's shares do not rise to that level by then, it will have to pay out to bondholders.

Scotia's Dr Robert Dow said: 'We need to establish whether we can refile with 147 patients or whether we have to start a new study.'

Nick Woolf, biotechnology analyst at ABN Amro, said: 'The FDA could say "you have to run a controlled study", which would take two years and cost £10m. The shortest and best alternative would be for Scotia to refile, but that would still take six to nine months.'

He said Scotia was likely to be exploring alliances or a possible merger.

Earlier this year an article in the British Medical Journal said Foscan, a treatment for head and neck cancer, had serious side-effects. Scotia said the research leading to this conclusion was faulty.

webTitle: Canary to bid for two more docks

fields.headline: Canary to bid for two more docks
fields.trailText: The Canary Wharf Group, the quoted owner of the Docklands office complex, is attempting to expand its estate by buying vast tracts of nearby East London land.
fields.body:
The Canary Wharf Group, the quoted owner of the Docklands office complex, is attempting to expand its estate by buying vast tracts of nearby East London land.

The Observer has learnt that Canary Wharf, controlled by Canadian Paul Reichmann's consortium of institutions and rich individuals, is planning to bid £100m to buy East India Dock, five offices to the east of its existing campus. It will face competition from a host of leading property firms and institutions.

Canary wants East India Dock, say insiders, because it will be able to decant tenants there from its main campus while it builds them bigger offices. 'It also gives them greater control in the area,' said one source.

And this week, Canary executives will be locked in talks with the London Development Agency to persuade it to hand over 50 acres of derelict land in the Royal Docks, next to London City airport.

Canary, which in October entered the FTSE-100 for the first time, is on a shortlist of four companies for the site. They are the quoted property firms, Development Securities, and Helical Bar, plus the specialist business park operator Akeler. Royal London is earmarked to become a major new business park.

In October, Canary paid £34m to buy out its partners on a five-acre site west of the 14m sq ft development which it believes will be fully occupied in the second half of next year.

The audacious expansion plan caps a phenomenally successful year for the owners of Canary, who include Saudi Prince al-Waleed bin Talal, the wealthy US Glick family, and the US fund Franklin Resources.

Earlier this year shares were languishing at 309p, but last Friday they closed at 545p. The vaulting share price has prompted the original Canary investors to take profits by selling stock.

Canary Wharf scooped more than £2 billion in government aid to turn the derelict Docklands wilderness into what was called 'Wall Street on water'.

The troubled development went bankrupt in 1992 and became the property of international banks. But in 1995 Reichmann and his syndicate bought it back for £800m. It is now worth more than £3.7bn.

Canary's share price surge is the result of a string of high-profile lettings over the past three months and rising central London office rents

In October, Canary paid £34m to buy out its partners on a five-acre site west of the 14m sq ft development which it believes will be fully occupied in the second half of next year. The audacious expansion plan caps a phenomenally successful year for the owners of Canary, who include Saudi Prince al-Waleed bin Talal, the wealthy US Glick family, and the US fund Franklin Resources. Earlier this year shares were languishing at 309p, but last Friday they closed at 545p. The vaulting share price has prompted the original Canary investors to take profits by selling stock. Canary Wharf scooped more than £2 billion in government aid to turn the derelict Docklands wilderness into what was called 'Wall Street on water'. The troubled development went bankrupt in 1992 and became the property of international banks. But in 1995 Reichmann and his syndicate bought it back for £800m. It is now worth more than £3.7bn. Canary's share price surge is the result of a string of high-profile lettings over the past three months and rising central London office rents

webTitle: Nicky Haslam: 'I sort of think I'm the most terrible bore'

fields.headline: Nicky Haslam: 'I sort of think I'm the most terrible bore'
fields.standfirst: He's 61, he dyes his body hair and last year he had his wattlelifted. So how come the London party set simply adores him?
fields.trailText: He's 61, he dyes his body hair and last year he had his wattlelifted. So how come the London party set simply adores him?
fields.body:
Six-thirty and the party-partying begins. Nicky Haslam checks his pockets before leaving his flat. 'Keys, cash, kerchief, comb,' he recites. 'That's what nanny taught me. Cosmetics, cigarettes, cellular phone, coke and cards - that's my own addition.' Then off into the night, equipped with a stack of stiffies and an itinerary of sorts, because there are a lot of parties to get through, and Nicky has to 'look in' at them all before joining friends for dinner.

He is sporting the scar on his cheek that will be his talking point for the evening. (My great mistake in life, I realise too late, is never having a talking point at parties.) Nicky's scar comes up to scratch - everywhere we go, women rush up crying, 'Darling Nicky! What happened to you?' And every time he says he's been in this terrible knife fight in Brixton, and every time the women are terribly upset and concerned and then he has to reassure them that it is only a stick-on scar as used in the movies. And all this talking about his talking point takes for ever so that parties simply flash by and you never have time to be bored even though you see the same people everywhere you go.

But of course the talking point, the talking point that everyone else talks about is Nicky Haslam. He has achieved the apotheosis of fame whereby he is both gossiper and gossipee - he co-writes a gossip column for the London Evening Standard magazine, but he is also the star of every other gossip column. PRs are paid millions to provide this kind of saturation exposure, but Nicky has no PR, he does it all on his ownio. And because he is so ubiquitous, companies shower him with freebies - an Accurist watch, a Skoda car, all the Evisu clothes he can wear - because, my dears, who else goes to as many A-list parties as Nicky Haslam? But now he is worried that people will think of him only as a party animal (how could this be?) when, of course, as all the world knows or should know, he is really a deeply serious interior designer.

Until a couple of years ago he actually looked like an interior designer, I mean the rather queeny old stereotype. He had bouffant grey hair, and Savile Row suits and handmade shirts with cufflinks. But now he has re-invented himself as - well, what ? He says the initial aim was to look like Liam Gallagher, but now he thinks he looks like a bit of Brazilian rough trade. I'm not too familiar with Brazilian rough trade, but he certainly looks rough, street-cred grungy in his sleeveless denim jacket and baggy jeans, dripping with necklaces and beads, his face haphazardly daubed with make-up. More importantly, he looks young - he is 61 but could pass for 30 in a dim light. He seems to have mastered some sort of age-reversal process - if it goes on at this rate, he will spend his eighties in a babygro.

Until two years ago he was ageing quite normally, but then 'I looked in the mirror one morning and realised I was growing into a blowsy, drunken old bag'. So he decided to change his look. 'I didn't want to look distinguished, I wanted to look fun, and also to fade into the street, into the King's Road. If I don't fade into a room at White's that's fine. My father was chairman of Brooks' and the Beefsteak, and I was brought up in that life, and it bores me rigid.' So he swapped the Gieves & Hawkes for Evisu jeans, and exchanged his cufflinks for power bracelets. He dyed his hair jet black and also dyed his body hair. He says it's great fun to do - 'You go into the bath and come out looking like a gorilla!' Then last year he had a full facelift because he felt that 'Wattle on men is unforgivable.'

So now he is happy or as happy as he can be with his look - he can never be blissed out because 'I've always wanted to look different. I always think I've got this terrible figure. I'd like to be 3in taller. I'd like not to have these great puffy lobes on my ears - I'd like them to taper in. I want ears like yours!' But apparently they can't be fixed because the surgeon told him 'Ears bleed for ever'. (One does learn some fascinating facts from Nicky Haslam, if facts they be.) But at least now he feels his image is more exciting, more fun . He no longer feels like Nicky Has-Been.

The new Nicky got a massive unveiling at his 60th birthday party last year, as featured in OK! magazine. He invited 'just 300 of his closest friends', and the guest list was quite a testimony to his pulling power - not only the predictable Mick Jagger, Jerry Hall, David Bailey, Ringo Starr, Anjelica Houston, Kate Moss, Jemima Khan, Jasper Conran but also Michael Heseltine, Winston Churchill, Nicholas Soames and a very straight-looking septuagenarian who turned out to be his brother Michael. Elaine Paige sang Happy Birthday, everyone made sweet speeches and Nicky cried a lot. It was a very genuinely warm-hearted party by all accounts.

People do really love Nicky Haslam - that fact was impressed on me very early on when several acquaintances rang to say warningly, 'I hear you're doing Nicky - you will be nice about him, won't you?' He inspires protectiveness - not that he is an innocent exactly, but he is so affectionate, so trusting, always rushing up to strangers wagging his tail, that his old friends always worry that his new friends will let him down. And he makes new best friends every week, possibly every day - recent acquisitions include Jay Kay of Jamiroquai, Donna Air of breakfast television, and Vanessa Feltz.

Being Nicky's new best friend is an extraordinary, overwhelming experience - I had a brief taste of it while writing this article and it was truly wonderful, basking in his non-stop flattery. He managed to compliment me on my clothes every single time we met which, believe me, takes some doing. Once, when I was giving him a lift to a party, he even complimented me on my car - 'So smart!' he said, which is not the usual epithet for a filthy four-year-old Ford Mondeo. Best of all was his remark when we were going into a party - 'I'm afraid we won't know anyone here' - I loved that 'we'!

Minn Hogg, the editor of The World of Interiors, who has known him since she was 16, has seen a million new best friends come and go. 'This is what he does: he picks you up, makes you feel a million dollars, says you'll be his best friend for ever and ever - but then somebody else comes along and you'll hear absolutely nothing for a while - or for ever. I learned that lesson very early and of course was very upset, but now we have a very solid friendship, it will never end now. But I mean, Vanessa Feltz - why ? Of course, he's the starfucker to end all starfuckers. He's a wonder - the Cecil Beaton of our age.'

He lives on a diet of champagne, gin, sea breezes and party canapés, though his food of choice is processed cheese sandwiches made with white, sliced Kingsmill bread - he likes the way his teeth leave little indentations in the bread. He never drinks wine, because it's bad for him, although champagne is good. 'I suppose I drink too much,' he says airily. 'But if I was going to be a drunk I'd be one by now.' He smokes 'about 44' Royals a day and snorts cocaine politely when the occasion demands. He tried his first E the other day and loved it, but he is not a great drug user. He is never ill because he believes in Lady Diana Cooper's maxim that being ill is 'common'. (Jet lag is common too, and so are tomatoes.)

He is not a sex addict. He likes 'smooth girls and rough men', but is quite happy to admire them from afar. In fact, he says, he is so cautious sexually that he has never at any point been at risk from Aids - 'That part of sex doesn't appeal.' He has had three long love affairs in his life and was faithful to all three - the last one, with Paolo Moschino, a cousin of the fashion family, finished about two years ago, but they are still great friends as well as business partners. In fact, when I went to see Nicky in the country, Paolo was staying there with his new boyfriend, and they seemed to form a very happy threesome.

Nicky says he is now happy to be unattached. 'Sometimes I think it would be nice to share everything I've got with somebody - and sometimes I think I'm very lucky to have the bathroom to myself. But I feel it would be nice to pass on my knowledge. Perhaps because I haven't got children - one wants to educate somebody.'

Actually, his grandfather married and started a family at 77, so it wouldn't be inconceivable for Nicky to do the same - and what a talking point that would be! He comes from a very long-living, late-breeding family where the normal rules of age don't apply. His parents were literally Victorians - his father was 60 and his mother 43 when he was born. His mother was a Ponsonby, one of the old courtier families, and called Diamond because she was born during Queen Victoria's Diamond Jubilee - Queen Victoria was her godmother. She met Nicky's father William Haslam in Vienna, where he was working at the British embassy after the First World War, and fell madly in love, but he didn't want to get married, so she went off to America, married someone else and had a daughter. Then one day, according to Nicky, 'There was a knock on the door and my father said "I've come to marry you."' So she left her American husband and married William. 'She did love him. It makes me cry really,' says Nicky, bursting into tears.

The Haslams were 'trade' but very wealthy - they invented Aertex. (Unfortunately, Nicky didn't get any of the Haslam fortune, because his father left it to his two brothers - he felt Nicky would only spend it, which of course he would.) Nicky's father brought Diamond back to live in England, and they had two sons and then - after a long gap - Nicky. They lived in a 'perfect' William and Mary house called Great Hundridge Manor near Great Missenden, with an interior designed by Geoffrey Scott, who designed I Tatti for Bernard Berenson. Nicky remembers it as exquisitely beautiful, but unfortunately his parents split up when he was in his teens and sold it, and the house ended up with Arabs. Nicky and his brother thought of buying it back at one stage, but 'You can't really - it had bad memories as well as good ones.'

The worst bad memory was that at seven he contracted polio and was in bed for three years - 'That's when I began to hate myself and feel out of place.' Before the illness he was a beautiful child; afterwards he was 'a fat blob'. For the first 18 months he was kept completely immobile, encased in plaster. He lost all contact with children his own age - 'What it meant was that I only knew grown-ups. I just remember my mother's friends in backless dresses, smoking cigarettes and drinking martinis and talking about the latest American musical. So when I finally went to school, aged 10, there were these horrible things called boys, who farted and picked their noses and played games and I didn't know what they were. And I was quite tubby because I hadn't been able to walk for three years, and I didn't know what a football was.'

But while he was encased in plaster, his great love of decoration was born. His mother presented him with a huge dolls' house which fitted across his bed, and he spent his days rearranging the furniture and putting up new wallpaper. When he went to Eton he immediately decorated his rooms with ostrich feathers and leopardskin curtains. He was encouraged by the art master there, Wilfred Blunt, brother of the spy Sir Anthony Blunt, and met people like Oliver Messel and Cecil Beaton, 'all that extraordinary world of post-war faggotry' who in turn introduced him to Lady Diana Cooper, who became one of his dearest friends.

After Eton, he worked for the photographer John French, where David Bailey also worked as an assistant. 'I adored David, we became the greatest mates in the world - I used to spend my life in the East End, wearing winklepicker shoes.' One day Bailey came round with Jean Shrimpton and said they were both leaving to work in America, and why didn't he come, too? So Nicky locked his house, left his car outside - and didn't return for 11 years. New York embraced him with open arms - Diana Vreeland called him Rembrandt and threw a party to celebrate his new suede suit; Tom Wolfe recorded seeing him at a party for the Rolling Stones, Andy Warhol put him in a film with Baby Jane Holzer. But then he fell in love with a man called Jimmy Davison, whose grandmother owned a large chunk of Arizona and went to live with him there. They bought a ranch (which had its own Hopi Indian reservation) and raised cattle - Nicky describes this as his cowboy period, when he looked like Robert Redford and wore 'these amazing beaded and embroidered suedes, chewed by squaws to make them soft.'

After a brief stay in Los Angeles, he came back to England in 1972 to design a house for Lord Hesketh. This is where his career as an interior designer really began, and his client list since then has widened to include everyone from the Prince of Wales to Ringo Starr, Bryan Ferry, Rod Stewart (who he says has surprisingly good taste, especially in pictures), Rupert Everett, both the Saatchis. As a designer he describes himself simply as 'The Best. I've done rooms that I know should have a preservation order on them because they're so breathtaking and still will be in 100 years time.'

But it is hard to define his style, because as he says, 'I have no style - the room has a style, the building has a style, the country has a style - not one of my jobs is the same.' Minn Hogg says this is true - with most designers she can recognise their style from a single photograph, but Nicky is so adaptable she might not even know it was him. 'He's not a one-note designer. It's a huge talent, he has immense knowledge about decoration. If he only did that, and didn't go to parties, he'd be unbelievably successful. But he can't not!'

He has never advertised, ever - he gets all his clients by word of mouth and is able to pick and choose whom he takes on. I asked if there were any clients he would refuse to work for and he said 'Yes - north of the park.' Oh God. I felt my face freeze as our new best friendship crashed in smithereens. 'Nicky,' I said sorrowfully, 'I live north of the park.' 'Oh no, I mean quite far north - I mean Highgate.' 'That's exactly where I live.' 'Oh no, north of that - Winnington Road.' Oh dear.

Winnington Road is about half a mile north of me, but it's academic - I fear he means Jewish. He says absolutely not, 'I'm not remotely anti-Jewish, I'd love to have Jewish blood, we should all have Jewish blood.' So what in heaven's name does he mean by north of the park? 'I mean new money, Russians and people like that - they're so impossible. They don't know what they want and they can't recognise a wonder when they're given it.' Arabs? 'Dodgy. And Indians dodgy. I'm used to a Christian culture, I like Christian symbols - I mean, with Arabs you can't have a head in the place and you're stuck with all that filigree muck.'

After this unhappy conversation, I mentally put him down as anti-Semitic despite all his disclaimers, but a week later he asked me to a party at a house in Belgravia he had designed and the owners were obviously Jewish, and good friends. One of the guests was Gail Ronson, and I overheard her thanking him for the kind letter he sent when she had her troubles - she meant when her husband Gerald Ronson went to prison. The party was by way of being an unveiling of the new Nicky Haslam interior, but unfortunately the bedroom ceiling had fallen down - not his fault, but the result of flooding upstairs.

Anyway, between all the hugs and hellos he took me on a guided tour and showed me the 15 shades of white he used for the drawing room, the waffle wallpaper he had specially painted for the dining room to match two Chinoiserie panels, the way he rearranged the doors to create an enfilade from one end of the flat to the other, the fabulous black marble bathroom and the even more fabulous lapis lazuli and gold bathroom. As he took me round, we were gradually joined by other guests and the women all started clamouring to see the master bedroom. Nicky was reluctant to show it because of the damaged ceiling, but eventually we all piled in and admired the four-poster bed and the exciting array of joists and wiring revealed by the hole in the ceiling.

But the ladies were still dissatisfied - 'Where are her closets?' they clamoured - and Nicky pushed a secret door (the flat had seemingly dozens of secret doors - one that I pushed by mistake swung open to reveal a safe full of silver) and took us into the wardrobe. There was an Imelda Marcos wall of shoes and two enormous coat rails of clothes in black wardrobe bags. But while I was going 'Oo, aah, wottalotta shoes', the ladies all started sighing with disappointment. 'These can't be all her clothes, Nicky,' they mewed. 'Where are her furs?' Nicky said probably in New York and we left it at that, but later, in the car, he told me, 'There is a fur closet upstairs, but I didn't want to show them.' I think he was quite shocked by their nosiness.

Nicky's own flat is very modest by comparison and in just about the nastiest location possible - the basement of a grim 50s block inches from the thundering traffic of the Cromwell Road. Inside, of course, it is gorgeous, rich dark glowing colours - chocolate, gold, silver, pearl - with classical busts and the famous four stools which, put together when he can remember the right order, make a Picasso abstract. The tables are densely piled with magazines - all featuring articles about Nicky Haslam, it turns out - and the place of honour on the sidetable goes to a photograph of Nicky with his hero Liam Gallagher at a Vogue party.

The flat is dark but he hardly sees it in daylight because he works during the day at his office in Lower Sloane Street, and at weekends goes to his country house, an exquisite little Jacobean pavilion in Hampshire which he leases from the National Trust. The previous tenant was John Fowler, who founded Colefax & Fowler, and Nicky has kept it in his style - lots of elastoplast-pink ragged paintwork, fake panelling, marble busts, carved pelmets over billowing curtains. The house feels more personal than his flat - a portrait of his mother hangs in the hall - and there are two framed letters in the drawing room complimenting him on his decor - one is from the Prince of Wales, the other from the late Nancy Lancaster, the doyenne of interior design - as if he needs that reassurance.

Then there are his photograph albums and what a trove they are! They seem to commemorate every fabulous party of the last 40 years - a sumptuous world of luxury and leisure that is supposed to have vanished after the war. It hasn't vanished at all - it's still going on, wherever Nicky Haslam is. I told him he ought to publish them, and he admitted that he is now trying to write his autobiography. In fact, he's been supposed to be writing it for years but now he is really knuckling down - he is going to Mauritius over Christmas with his old friend Lee Radziwill - 'She's such a close friend she's practically my wife' - and intends to write every morning. But he is very alarmed by the whole exercise - 'I'm not trying to be disingenuous, but I never think I've got anything to say at all. I sort of think I'm the most terrible bore.' Oh I don't know, Nicky. I envy whoever is your new best friend.
