One day Bailey came round with Jean Shrimpton and said they were both leaving to work in America, and why didn't he come, too? So Nicky locked his house, left his car outside - and didn't return for 11 years. New York embraced him with open arms - Diana Vreeland called him Rembrandt and threw a party to celebrate his new suede suit; Tom Wolfe recorded seeing him at a party for the Rolling Stones, Andy Warhol put him in a film with Baby Jane Holzer. But then he fell in love with a man called Jimmy Davison, whose grandmother owned a large chunk of Arizona and went to live with him there. They bought a ranch (which had its own Hopi Indian reservation) and raised cattle - Nicky describes this as his cowboy period, when he looked like Robert Redford and wore 'these amazing beaded and embroidered suedes, chewed by squaws to make them soft.' After a brief stay in Los Angeles, he came back to England in 1972 to design a house for Lord Hesketh. This is where his career as an interior designer really began, and his client list since then has widened to include everyone from the Prince of Wales to Ringo Starr, Bryan Ferry, Rod Stewart (who he says has surprisingly good taste, especially in pictures), Rupert Everett, both the Saatchis. As a designer he describes himself simply as 'The Best. I've done rooms that I know should have a preservation order on them because they're so breathtaking and still will be in 100 years time.' But it is hard to define his style, because as he says, 'I have no style - the room has a style, the building has a style, the country has a style - not one of my jobs is the same.' Minn Hogg says this is true - with most designers she can recognise their style from a single photograph, but Nicky is so adaptable she might not even know it was him. 'He's not a one-note designer. It's a huge talent, he has immense knowledge about decoration. If he only did that, and didn't go to parties, he'd be unbelievably successful. But he can't not!' He has never advertised, ever - he gets all his clients by word of mouth and is able to pick and choose whom he takes on. I asked if there were any clients he would refuse to work for and he said 'Yes - north of the park.' Oh God. I felt my face freeze as our new best friendship crashed in smithereens. 'Nicky,' I said sorrowfully, 'I live north of the park.' 'Oh no, I mean quite far north - I mean Highgate.' 'That's exactly where I live.' 'Oh no, north of that - Winnington Road.' Oh dear. Winnington Road is about half a mile north of me, but it's academic - I fear he means Jewish. He says absolutely not, 'I'm not remotely anti-Jewish, I'd love to have Jewish blood, we should all have Jewish blood.' So what in heaven's name does he mean by north of the park? 'I mean new money, Russians and people like that - they're so impossible. They don't know what they want and they can't recognise a wonder when they're given it.' Arabs? 'Dodgy. And Indians dodgy. I'm used to a Christian culture, I like Christian symbols - I mean, with Arabs you can't have a head in the place and you're stuck with all that filigree muck.' After this unhappy conversation, I mentally put him down as anti-Semitic despite all his disclaimers, but a week later he asked me to a party at a house in Belgravia he had designed and the owners were obviously Jewish, and good friends. One of the guests was Gail Ronson, and I overheard her thanking him for the kind letter he sent when she had her troubles - she meant when her husband Gerald Ronson went to prison. The party was by way of being an unveiling of the new Nicky Haslam interior, but unfortunately the bedroom ceiling had fallen down - not his fault, but the result of flooding upstairs. Anyway, between all the hugs and hellos he took me on a guided tour and showed me the 15 shades of white he used for the drawing room, the waffle wallpaper he had specially painted for the dining room to match two Chinoiserie panels, the way he rearranged the doors to create an enfilade from one end of the flat to the other, the fabulous black marble bathroom and the even more fabulous lapis lazuli and gold bathroom. As he took me round, we were gradually joined by other guests and the women all started clamouring to see the master bedroom. Nicky was reluctant to show it because of the damaged ceiling, but eventually we all piled in and admired the four-poster bed and the exciting array of joists and wiring revealed by the hole in the ceiling. But the ladies were still dissatisfied - 'Where are her closets?' they clamoured - and Nicky pushed a secret door (the flat had seemingly dozens of secret doors - one that I pushed by mistake swung open to reveal a safe full of silver) and took us into the wardrobe. There was an Imelda Marcos wall of shoes and two enormous coat rails of clothes in black wardrobe bags. But while I was going 'Oo, aah, wottalotta shoes', the ladies all started sighing with disappointment. 'These can't be all her clothes, Nicky,' they mewed. 'Where are her furs?' Nicky said probably in New York and we left it at that, but later, in the car, he told me, 'There is a fur closet upstairs, but I didn't want to show them.' I think he was quite shocked by their nosiness. Nicky's own flat is very modest by comparison and in just about the nastiest location possible - the basement of a grim 50s block inches from the thundering traffic of the Cromwell Road. Inside, of course, it is gorgeous, rich dark glowing colours - chocolate, gold, silver, pearl - with classical busts and the famous four stools which, put together when he can remember the right order, make a Picasso abstract. The tables are densely piled with magazines - all featuring articles about Nicky Haslam, it turns out - and the place of honour on the sidetable goes to a photograph of Nicky with his hero Liam Gallagher at a Vogue party. The flat is dark but he hardly sees it in daylight because he works during the day at his office in Lower Sloane Street, and at weekends goes to his country house, an exquisite little Jacobean pavilion in Hampshire which he leases from the National Trust. The previous tenant was John Fowler, who founded Colefax & Fowler, and Nicky has kept it in his style - lots of elastoplast-pink ragged paintwork, fake panelling, marble busts, carved pelmets over billowing curtains. The house feels more personal than his flat - a portrait of his mother hangs in the hall - and there are two framed letters in the drawing room complimenting him on his decor - one is from the Prince of Wales, the other from the late Nancy Lancaster, the doyenne of interior design - as if he needs that reassurance. Then there are his photograph albums and what a trove they are! They seem to commemorate every fabulous party of the last 40 years - a sumptuous world of luxury and leisure that is supposed to have vanished after the war. It hasn't vanished at all - it's still going on, wherever Nicky Haslam is. I told him he ought to publish them, and he admitted that he is now trying to write his autobiography. In fact, he's been supposed to be writing it for years but now he is really knuckling down - he is going to Mauritius over Christmas with his old friend Lee Radziwill - 'She's such a close friend she's practically my wife' - and intends to write every morning. But he is very alarmed by the whole exercise - 'I'm not trying to be disingenuous, but I never think I've got anything to say at all. I sort of think I'm the most terrible bore.' Oh I don't know, Nicky. I envy whoever is your new best friend.

webTitle: Observer review: The Hitchcock Murders by Peter Conrad

fields.headline: Give him enough Rope
fields.standfirst: Peter Conrad's dazzling new study of Alfred Hitchcock, The Hitchcock Murders,  is as tricky as its subject
fields.trailText: Peter Conrad's dazzling new study of Alfred Hitchcock, The Hitchcock Murders, is as tricky as its subject
fields.body:
The Hitchcock Murders Peter Conrad

Faber, pp362, £16.99

Buy it at BOL

Peter Conrad starts his admiring study of Alfred Hitchcock's films with an account of how he first saw Psycho in Tasmania in 1961. The film offered some perverse equations of sex and death, but for Conrad the induction into adult mysteries required some preliminary transgressions on his part. Not only did he have to infringe regulations by sneaking into a film whose certificate excluded 13-year-olds, but since there were no weekend matinées he also played truant from school. For him, there was nothing passive about sitting in the dark, at the mercy of a dark imagination. It was the climax of a crash course of initiations into disobedience and moral danger.

In the four decades since then, Conrad has certainly done his homework on Hitchcock. Not only has he watched the films again and again, alert to such details as a travel poster in North By Northwest emblazoned with the title phrase, or the word spelled out in neon (never seen in full) in Rope - he deduces it as STORAGE, ironically appropriate for a film in which a corpse is concealed in a chest for most of the running time. He has also read the books on which the screenplays were (often loosely) based. This leads to some critical sleight of hand, enabling him to reintroduce, as subtext, material that the films left out.

But then Conrad is the critic as magician, at least as tricky as the film director he so much admires. He rejects a chronological approach as plodding, and prefers to come at Hitchcock's work from all angles at once, darting freely between films widely separated in time. He defends this liberty on the basis that these many films form a unity rather than an evolution - 'I do not believe that his concerns or his tactics changed significantly in a career that lasted half a century.' Temperamentally, too, he has a preference for intellectual omnipresence. This approach makes possible some fascinating discussions, such as an anatomy of the composite Hitchcock house, mined with unease from chimney (The Birds) to cellar (Psycho). The claim of unity is still a strong one, since similar elements in his films have a very different resonance at different stages in his career.

He twice broke the suspense-film taboo against killing off sympathetic characters. In Sabotage (1936), he set up a sequence against the clock (the timer of a bomb, in fact), at the end of which a boy innocently carrying a deadly package was blown up by it. This scene prepares the ground for one of the most emotionally truthful moments in his films, in which the boy's sister (played by Sylvia Sidney), bereaved and in shock, wanders into the East End cinema she runs, and finds herself laughing mechanically at a Disney version of Who Killed Cock Robin? The killing of the boy was not popular with the public, and Hitchcock claimed to repent of exceeding its tolerance. By the time he killed off Marion Crane in Psycho, it wasn't an experiment with an audience, catching the deeper emotions by surprise, but a black joke at the viewer's expense. Conrad aligns Hitchcock, as a liberator of the irrational, with André Breton's political and philosophical sur realism as much as with the more mischievous and opportunistic brand practised by Salvador Dali, Hitchcock's collaborator (on Spellbound). Breton's programme of 'total revolt, complete insubordination, sabotage according to rule' doesn't seem to fit with Conrad's recurring adjective 'cheeky', which suggests the breaking of rules without overturning them.

Later, Conrad modifies his portrait of Hitchcock from revolutionary to setter of limits: 'Inside the darkened room, we are shown what we are capable of... the spectacle, in most cases, scares us into behaving as society ordains... the psychological revolt is contained.'

These two rather different Hitchcocks are awkwardly accommodated in the book's concluding paragraph: 'He encouraged insurgent fantasy, but warned us against expecting our wishes to be fulfilled in the daylight world outside the cinema.' But then a conclusion is a rather prosaic thing, and Conrad's style of criticism is continuously dazzling rather than incremental.

It becomes clear from a discussion of editing, where the individual sentences aren't necessarily more eloquent in themselves than shots in a storyboarded sequence ('Scissors can cut film, but are also liable to carve up human bodies') that Conrad's own procedure is actually a sort of montage of ideas and aperçus, rather than a conventionally mounted argument. His three section titles ('The Art of Murder', 'The Technique of Murder', 'The Religion of Murder') may announce a deepening investigation but the subsections tend to break off, with no feeling of cadence. Tireless as a rule at delving beneath appearances, Conrad takes rather at face value Hitchcock's account of being locked up for a childhood misdemeanour. 'Arrest' becomes 'his abiding trauma', and a word that 'haunted the quaking Hitchcock, who could never forget his childhood sojourn in a cell at the police station, where his parents allegedly sent him as punishment for naughtiness'. That sceptical word 'allegedly' is neutralised by appearing so late in the sentence.

Traumas are not normally publicised by those who suffer them, but perhaps Conrad is striking a bargain here. If he leaves Hitchcock's claims unchallenged, his own rather Gothic self-portrait may escape being seen as a literary or structural device. The boy whose imagination was both awoken and imprisoned by Psycho has, by the end of the book, become a sort of Norman Bates in his own right, living in a house decorated with polyglot posters for his hero's movies, and dreaming of 'a larger, lonelier house, preferably on a hill.' It's a fitting finale to a thrilling rhetorical display of love and knowledge.

webTitle: Observer review: The Terror of St Trinians and Other Drawings by  Ronald Searle

fields.headline: The Terror of St Trinians and Other Drawings by  Ronald Searle
fields.trailText: Searle's vision veers between the disturbingly dark and the surreal
fields.body:
The Terror of St Trinians and Other Drawings
Ronald Searle
Penguin Classics £7.99, pp256
Buy it at BOL
Satirical cartoonist Ronald Searle is probably best known for his St Trinian's and Molesworth cartoons, the former of which make up a large part of this new collection. The editors have included selections from his magnificent The Rake's Progress as well as the less well-known Souls in Torment and Merry England. Searle's vision veers between the disturbingly dark and the surreal. Some of the darkest cartoons are from the St Trinian's books: for example, the four cheery girls gathered below the body of a hanged mistress, with the caption: 'Well that's OK - now for old "Stinks".' But the funniest are the truly ludicrous; one penguin saying to another: 'Read any good books lately?', or the schoolmistress saying to the girl leading a giant hippo through the school corridor: 'Elspeth! Put that back AT ONCE.'

Nicholas Lezard's introduction offers a sketch of Searle's formative experiences, particularly his three years as a prisoner of war in Changi jail, but avoids specific interpretations, letting the cartoons speak for themselves.

fields.headline: Pump up the volumes
fields.standfirst: Which is the best book of the year? Philip Roth's The Human Stain or Zadie Smith's White Teeth? Our critics choose their favourites
fields.trailText: Which is the best book of the year? Philip Roth's The Human Stain or Zadie Smith's White Teeth? Our critics choose their favourites
fields.body:
Lucy Moore

The Journals of Sylvia Plath edited by Karen V. Kukil (Faber) make uncomfortable reading because she is so searingly, desperately intense - but that is also what makes them so compelling. A fascinating look into a brilliant, tortured mind.

Lewis Wolpert

James Lovelock's Homage to Gaia - The Life of an Independent Scientist (OUP) is not so much a homage to his captivating idea but rather a homage to science and his own life in it. There is no autobiography of a scientist to compete with this one. Hitler's Gift, by Jean Medawar and David Pyke (Metro), tells the stories of 21 brilliant scientists who took refuge in Britain shortly after Hitler came to power in 1933 and Jews were dismissed from their university posts. A moving story and a moral tale.

Simon Jenkins

White Teeth (Random House) by Zadie Smith is funny and sad. Larry Siedentop's Democracy in Europe (Allen Lane, Penguin) was the most original political book of the year. For politics of a lighter hue, nothing beats Andrew Rawnsley's gossipy Servants of the People (Hamish Hamilton), presenting New Labour as a court that Machiavelli would recognise and from which Blairism will never quite recover. And let us hear a cheer for Gladwyn Turbutt's four-volume History of Derbyshire (Merton Priory). This masterpiece of local history, 10 years in the making, is proof that such invaluable books can still see the light of day, defying the outpourings of technology.

Barbara Trapido

While I have tried to make this a writing rather than a reading year, there were two books I couldn't not read. One was Günther Grass's time travelling, massively long Too Far Afield (Faber), in which the 'footnote slaves' of a GDR archive tell the story of an aged file courier whose life is rescued by an obsession with a literary Huguenot. The other, Jonathan Coe's The Rotters' Club (Viking), not out until next March but read in a sneak preview, is a boys' school story set in 1970s Birmingham. Coe can present social history without sacrificing characters to events and both here are a joy. I also caught up, in paperback, with Romesh Gunesekera's beautiful exile story, The Sandglass (Granta).

Robert Harris

The latest selection from Alan Clark's Diaries, Into Politics (Weidenfeld & Nicolson) still offers, for my money, the strongest narrative voice of the year - an elongated Etonian drawl of selfishness, lechery, snobbishness, hypochondria, self-delusion and melancholy, all of which are transfigured by the razor quality of Clark's prose and his reckless honesty.

Graham Robb's Rimbaud (Picador) demythologises the subject while leaving quite intact the magic of the art. Penelope Fitzgerald, who died in April, left us a farewell present of short stories, The Means of Escape (Flamingo): economical enigmas which remind us to reread her last four great novels.

Joan Bakewell
L

J. G. Ballard has always been astonishingly prophetic in his visions. Now Super-Cannes (Flamingo) imagines the dangers, plausible and horrifying, of the culture of global corporations. Even when not on major biographical duty, Richard Holmes is always interesting. Sidetracks - Explorations of a Romantic Biographer (HarperCollins) are minor excursions down biographical byways but offer up insights I couldn't have anticipated. Experience by Martin Amis (Jonathan Cape) is brilliant for its cun ning structure and density of impressions.

Zadie Smith

I choose Martin Amis's memoir Experience (Jonathan Cape) because it's exquisitely written, Edward Platt's intimate biography of the A40, Leadville (Picador), for the same reason, and Dave Eggers's A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius (Picador) because it kicks ass.

Misha Glenny

Michael Burleigh's The Third Reich: A New History (Macmillan) is how history should be written. Illuminating and stylish, it offers insights for the general reader and scholar alike without boring either. Night of Stone (Granta) , Catherine Merridale's account of how ordinary Russians coped with violent death on a scale few of us can even imagine, is an epic and moving his tory. Kosovo: War and Revenge (Yale), Tim Judah's reconstruction of the war in Kosovo and the dynamics of Serb and Albanian politics in the territory, is clear and instructive.

Nicci Gerard

In The Human Stain (Cape) - a stunning, complex novel of snarling rage, passion, sarcasm, scorching humour and extraordinary beauty - Philip Roth manages to weave together public history and private lives and seems to pack 10 novels into this dense one. In October, Philip Pullman published the final in his dazzling Dark Materials trilogy, The Amber Spyglass (David Fickling Books). He understands the power of a good story, but he is an uncosy, often scary and troubling novelist: besotted by myth, compelled by death and desire and faith and grief, in love with Milton and Blake, angry with religion, intimate with compromise and complicity and corruption, capable of radiant prose.

Christopher Frayling

I particularly enjoyed David Skal's Screams of Reason - Mad Science and Modern Culture (W. W. Norton & Co) which begins with Dr Faustus and ends with Stephen Hawking but concentrates in between on Boris Karloff and Hollywood horror. The best-written book I read was Thomas McGuane's elegant and thoughtful essays about the partnership - a partnership he calls 'a burst of poetry' - between humans and horses collected as Some Horses (The Lyons Press).

Jonathan Meades

Atomised by Michel Houllebecq (Heinemann) is the most thrilling novel I've read in several years. Its directness, its energy, its centripetal concentration, its candour, its nihilism and its sod-you-ism are exhilarating. In The Third Reich: A New History (Macmillan), Michael Burleigh proceeds from the premise that Nazism was a quasi-religion whose programme allowed the faithful to perpetrate enormities with a clear conscience. His book is a massive accretion of detail and appalling anecdote.

Brenda Maddox

Andrew Roberts's Salisbury: Victorian Titan (Weidenfeld and Nicolson) is as learned, accessible and well-shaped a biography as I've read. Roberts is a rare historian, with an eye for the human detail and for contemporary relevance. I also loved the outrageous Letters of Kingsley Amis edited by Zachary Leader (HarperCollins).

Antony Holden

Angry, outrageous, wildly funny and infinitely sad, Philip Roth's The Human Stain (Cape) completes the majestic postwar US trilogy which began in equally high style with American Pastoral. Martin Amis's memoir Experience (Jonathan Cape) is up there with Roth's The Facts; when fine fictional stylists turn their laser-prose upon themselves, the result is an auto-brainscan offering a tantalising glimpse towards the heart. I also much admired Miranda Seymour's exhaustive biography of Mary Shelley.

Charles Saumarez Smith

My favourite book of the year is called City Secrets: Rome (The Little Bookroom). Edited by the architect Robert Kahn, it consists of recommendations of what to see and do in Rome as sent in by the American Academy of Rome's many supporters. It's a brilliant idea. I also enjoyed The Long Afternoon (Sceptre), Giles Waterfield's dry and atmospheric novel about his grandparents' life in Menton between the wars.

Jan Morris

In non-fiction I greatly admired and enjoyed Simon Schama's Rembrandt's Eyes (Allen Lane, Penguin), which was published in the autumn of 1999 but did not reach me until the present millennium; also Peter Ackroyd's virtuoso evocation of the most timeless of cities, London: The Biography (Chatto & Windus). I was delighted by Miles Bredin's life of James Bruce, The Pale Abyssinian (HarperCollins), but since Mr Bredin is my godson I'd better not say anything too nice about it.

Mary Riddell

As lucid as anything he has written and, in the paperback edition, particularly well-timed Matt Ridley's Genome - the Autobiography of a Species in 23 Chapters (Fourth Estate) is the A to Z route map for anyone trying to get to grips with the completion of the Human Genome Project.

Tom Paulin

Martin Allen's Hidden Agenda: How the Duke of Windsor Betrayed the Allies (Macmillan) paints a devastating picture of this truly evil royal who was a close friend of Charles Bedaux, a Nazi spy so dangerous that the FBI would appear to have bumped him off in 1944 (officially he committed suicide). Frank Kermode's Shakespeare's Language (Allen Lane, Penguin) is an inspiring work of evaluative critical analysis.

Edna O'Brien

Snow and Guilt by Giorgio Pressburger (Granta) is a perfect little book. Translated by Shaun Whiteside, these six stories have an underlying unity; the writing is austere yet with a life-affirming tenderness. The same cannot be said for The Journals of Sylvia Plath (Faber). Here we witness the rage, the torment and the competitiveness of a deeply wounded young woman. As I began to read them I wondered if all journals ought not to be consigned to the pyre, but by the time I had finished I marvelled at her industriousness and her capacity at transforming her demons into great art. Eilis Ni Dhuibhne is the most gifted young Irish writer. In The Pale Gold of Alaska (Blackstaff Press), her prose shimmers like poetry.

George Steiner

My book of the year (if a delayed finding in paperback is allowed), is Colin Thubron's In Siberia (Chatto & Windus) . There is hardly a sentence in this grim yet strangely luminous memoir without a taut vivacity which makes the whole book 'sing'. Thubron's account of the abandoned Stalinist death-camps in the Siberian Kolyma, of the pounding into ice and mud of millions of innocent men and women, is almost unbearable. Yet even here, in the hell of the anonymous, there are touches of human dignity, of that Russian investment in resurrection.

Gita Sereny

Brigitte Hamann's Hitler's Vienna is a really original account of the young Hitler's years of political apprenticeship between 1907 and 1913. Mark Roseman's The Past in Hiding (Allen Lane, Penguin) is an extraordinary story of a life, particularly read - as I read it - in conjunction with Ian Kershaw's two volumes of Hitler biography - Hubris and Nemesis (Penguin), both of them richly annotated with previously unknown facts. I loved Simon Sebag Montefiore's Prince of Princes: The Life of Potemkin (Weidenfeld & Nicolson). George Monbiot's Captive State: The Corporate Takeover of Britain (Macmillan) confronts us with the corporate control of British hospitals, schools, universities and, indeed, the food we buy and eat. Scary. But I also read a lot of novels this past year, some new, some older: I loved Kent Haruf 's Plainsong and Niall Williams's Four Letters of Love (both Picador). And I have, with enormous pleasure, re-read Robert Harris's Archangel (Arrow), Richard North Patterson's The Final Judgement (Hutchinson), the perfect legal novel, and all the wonderful thrillers written by Michael Connelly (Orion).

Mavis Cheek

'Not for horrid profs,' says Frank Kermode of his Shakespeare's Language (Allen Lane, Penguin) - and he's quite right. It's engaging and clear to read. One critic called Colm Toibin's The Blackwater Lightship (Picador) 'emotional choreography'. I'd add the word 'beautiful' to that. Three generations, three different beliefs, three women coming to terms with each other and themselves. With The World's Smallest Unicorn (Cape), Shena Mackay brings us 10 more immaculate short stories of human folly and fortune and finding the skull beneath the perm.

A L Kennedy

This year No Great Mischief (Cape) made Alasdair MacLeod's position as a master of prose even more firmly assured. This is a work of true lyricism, emotional intelligence and breathtakingly acute observation.

Terry Eagleton

Years ago, I read Mikhail Bakhtin's great classic of the carnivalesque, Rabelais and His World, and wondered why I had never heard of him before. There's now no doubt that this previously obscure Russian thinker, who is said to have torn up one of his own priceless manuscripts for cigarette paper, is one of the supreme literary thinkers of our time. To write the very best book on him to date is thus a remarkable achievement. Ken Hirschkop's Mikhail Bakhtin: An Aesthetic for Democracy (OUP) combines dogged work in the Russian archives with some brilliant insights to show Bakhtin's relevance to questions of politics and popular democracy today.

Glen Baxter

My contenders for book of the year would have to include Flick Knives and Forks (Zillah Bell Contemporary Art) by Anthony Earnshaw - a collection of the great English surrealists' aphorisms spiced with black humour. My next choice would be The Book of Leviathan (Sort of Books) by Peter Bleguad which is funny, enigmatic and beautifully limned - what more could one ask?

Hermione Lee

My book of the year is the Selected Poems of Yehuda Amichai (Faber) edited by his friend Ted Hughes and by Daniel Weissbort. His wry, conversational poems - tender, humane and pragmatic - on war, love, memory, and the fierce history of his city, Jerusalem, are all the more moving now. I was also delighted by the dazzling stories of Peter Ho Davies, Equal Love (Granta) , and by Michèle Roberts's deliciously sensual French novel, The Looking Glass (Virago).

Helen Dunmore

It's seven years since Michael Donaghy last published a poetry collection. Here, after a magical interval, is Conjure (Picador), his best book yet. Conjure takes all the Donaghy virtues - wit, clarity, breathtaking control of rhyme and rhythm - and adds a new intensity of feeling.

David Hare

Why do women write about the recent past so much better than men? Only John Osborne has described the day before yesterday as skilfully as Barbara Skelton, Doris Lessing and Joan Wyndham. Stet (Granta), is a record of Diana Athill's years as an editor at Andre Deutsch. It's hard to believe that most of her authors came anywhere near Athill's own superb literary pitch. Over the internet you can order the American edition of The Selected Letters of Tennessee Williams, Volume 1 1920-1945 (New Directions) - essential reading for admirers of one of America's greatest dramatists

Emma Tennant

Lorna Sage's Bad Blood (Fourth Estate) is a deceptively simple account of a Second World War childhood in deepest Flintshire, which makes sense of the enormous and bewildering changes in society in the last century.

Michael Foot

Don't be misled by any neglect or false testimony into imagining that Rebecca West was not one of the great women of the century. Her Selected Letters, edited by Bonnie Kime Scott (Yale) should dispose of all such misconceptions. She would have appreciated the latest of essays from her protégé, Merlin Holland's The Oscar Wilde Anthology (HarperCollins). And don't miss Have You Forgotten Yet? The First World War Memoirs of C P Blacker, edited by John Blacker (Pen and Sword Books ), an original, plain-spoken record of the First World War which confronts the reader fairly with the Siegfried Sassoon verdict on the whole affair.

Adam Phillips

R. F. Langley's Collected Poems (Carcanet) has a new music of sense-making about it that is, in the way only poetry and music can be, like an illumination. Larry Siedentop's Democracy In Europe (Allen Lane, Penguin) has a remarkable clarity and exhilaration about something that runs the risk of becoming just another topic of debate. Richard Lewontin with The Triple Helix (Harvard) continues to be the scientist everyone should read.

J G Ballard

In The Heart Of The Sea by Nathaniel Philbrick (HarperCollins) is a deeply moving account of the sinking of the whale ship Essex , which inspired Melville's Moby Dick. Rammed by a sperm whale, the Essex sank three days later, and the survivors set out by boat for the South American coast, 4,000 miles away. Nathaniel Philbrick unsparingly describes their ordeal, a hellish descent into starvation and cannibalism. None the less, these desperate men emerge as heroes.

Philip French

George Orwell is possibly the greatest writer of the twentieth century and next year's major publishing event will be the paperback editions at affordable prices of the first three volumes of his complete essays, letters and diaries: All Propaganda is Lies 1941-42, Keeping Our Little Corner Clean and Two Wasted Years 1943 (Secker & Warburg). My three new favourites all address themselves to settling the business of the last century. Douglas Dunn's vivid book-length poem The Donkey's Ears (Faber), purports to be the letters home to his wife by the self-questioning flag engineer of the Russian fleet steaming from the Baltic to the East China Sea to be destroyed by the Japanese in May 1905.

On a trek from White City to Hanger Lane, Platt investigates the lives of the roadside householders, and documents the death of their suburban dream. A small, gritty, monoxide-scented epic.

Chris Patten

Philip Roth's The Human Stain (Cape) is the best new novel I have read for years. It is a powerful, gripping story with some strong set-pieces. Roth is not afraid to wrestle with ideas, some of them unfashionable but troubling for any liberal conscience. Cressida Connolly

The American Rick Moody is one of the most original and inventive of current fiction writers. His new short stories, Demonology (Faber), are touching and funny and downright odd. fields.bodyText: Lucy Moore The Journals of Sylvia Plath edited by Karen V. Kukil (Faber) make uncomfortable reading because she is so searingly, desperately intense - but that is also what makes them so compelling. A fascinating look into a brilliant, tortured mind. Lewis Wolpert James Lovelock's Homage to Gaia - The Life of an Independent Scientist (OUP) is not so much a homage to his captivating idea but rather a homage to science and his own life in it. There is no autobiography of a scientist to compete with this one. Hitler's Gift, by Jean Medawar and David Pyke (Metro), tells the stories of 21 brilliant scientists who took refuge in Britain shortly after Hitler came to power in 1933 and Jews were dismissed from their university posts. A moving story and a moral tale. Simon Jenkins White Teeth (Random House) by Zadie Smith is funny and sad. Larry Siedentop's Democracy in Europe (Allen Lane, Penguin) was the most original political book of the year. This masterpiece of local history, 10 years in the making, is proof that such invaluable books can still see the light of day, defying the outpourings of technology. One was Günther Grass's time travelling, massively long Too Far Afield (Faber), in which the 'footnote slaves' of a GDR archive tell the story of an aged file courier whose life is rescued by an obsession with a literary Huguenot. Coe can present social history without sacrificing characters to events and both here are a joy. I also caught up, in paperback, with Romesh Gunesekera's beautiful exile story, The Sandglass (Granta). fields.standfirst: David Vincent on Lost in Music, Time to be in Earnest, Invisible Monsters and Falling Angels
fields.trailText: David Vincent on Lost in Music, Time to be in Earnest, Invisible Monsters and Falling Angels
fields.body:
Lost in Music
Giles Smith
Picador £6.99, pp277
Buy it at BOL

Pop brings out the emotional librarian in most men. Giles Smith's flirtation with musical fame, reissued with a new cover (collectors, please note), presents the timeless duo of wannabe and bedroom shoegazer. Smith knows his pop ABC (and his XTC) and charts 'the tempo of the streets' in desperately ungroovy Colchester. Psychotic record- shop assistants, dingy outlets, dingier fairs and a girlfriend singing in a shop for help recognising a tune - oh, the horror. While his father's death puts the limits of pop into perspective, incidents such as being kissed on stage by a German skinhead provide moments of idiotic sublimity. Smith stands on the cusp between the reactive and the interactive, his shameless bathos conjuring literary virtue from crippling self-consciousness. He desperately wanted to write a classic. Now he has.

Time to be in Earnest
P.D. James
Faber and Faber £7.99, pp281
Buy it at BOL

P.D. James claims an indolent nature, though the evidence suggests otherwise. After 14 masterful crime novels comes this unconventional memoir. Spanning her seventy-eighth year, the entries begin in August 1997, weeks before the death of the Princess of Wales. Fortuitous timing or a writerly sixth sense? Anniversaries spark lively discussion, with no conspicuous narrowing of the critical arteries, of the BBC, the Church of England, the Lords, sexual liberation, women crime writers, the 1930s crime novel, real-life bygone crimes and television adaptations.

She even sets out guidelines for literary reviewers. A fundamental sense of imposing order on chaos would seem to influence this deeply religious Dame's choice of genre but, more accustomed to spilling blood than beans, any insights remain tantalisingly glimpsed, discreet rather than frankly confessional.

Invisible Monsters
Chuck Palahniuk
Vintage £6.99, pp297
Buy it at BOL

After the brawlers of Fight Club, and Survivor 's apocalyptic death cult, Chuck Palahniuk's third novel continues to pile on the aggressive camouflage to outrageous effect. The narrator is a model who has had her lower face shot off. Subsequently mute, she is adopted by Brandy Alexander, a flamboyant transsexual who teaches her that the past only exists to be reinvented. Of course, the past cannot be so lightly dismissed, and nor can this deliciously convoluted plot. The restless narrative ricochets around the hypnotically vacuous rhythms of glossy magazines. Palahniuk has claimed his book's exploration of transgression, and the need to destroy in order to move forward, 'makes Fight Club look like Little Women'. Bruising talk, yet its ferocious satirical bravado can't quite disguise a warm, moral undertow.

Falling Angels
John Walsh
Flamingo £6.99, pp282
Buy it at BOL

From Milton by way of Synge, the title refers to cherubim cast from Heaven but not consigned to Hell, forever in flux. The Independent 's bonhomous John Walsh accords this status to those, including himself, English-born of Irish parents. Green-tinted memoirs abound like fake Irish pubs, but Walsh's Hibernian London blues is distinguished by shrewd observation and zestful craft. His parents stand as the book's fulcrum, instructing young John in an Irishness that will always elude him, and an urge to entertain that will never.

Humiliated when a Cork chum mocks his acquired Oirish, Walsh discovers the Big House cousins in Galway, where the grass really is greener and the life cosily decadent. Though in danger of losing its way in whimsical mist, Fallen Angels succeeds due to its rich stew of language and song, spiced by Walsh's vertiginous charm.
fields.bodyText: Lost in Music Giles Smith Picador £6.99, pp277 Buy it at BOL Pop brings out the emotional librarian in most men. Giles Smith's flirtation with musical fame, reissued with a new cover (collectors, please note), presents the timeless duo of wannabe and bedroom shoegazer. Smith knows his pop ABC (and his XTC) and charts 'the tempo of the streets' in desperately ungroovy Colchester. Psychotic record- shop assistants, dingy outlets, dingier fairs and a girlfriend singing in a shop for help recognising a tune - oh, the horror. While his father's death puts the limits of pop into perspective, incidents such as being kissed on stage by a German skinhead provide moments of idiotic sublimity. Smith stands on the cusp between the reactive and the interactive, his shameless bathos conjuring literary virtue from crippling self-consciousness. He desperately wanted to write a classic. Now he has. Time to be in Earnest P.D. James Faber and Faber £7.99, pp281 Buy it at BOL P.D. James claims an indolent nature, though the evidence suggests otherwise. After 14 masterful crime novels comes this unconventional memoir. Spanning her seventy-eighth year, the entries begin in August 1997, weeks before the death of the Princess of Wales. Fortuitous timing or a writerly sixth sense? Anniversaries spark lively discussion, with no conspicuous narrowing of the critical arteries, of the BBC, the Church of England, the Lords, sexual liberation, women crime writers, the 1930s crime novel, real-life bygone crimes and television adaptations. She even sets out guidelines for literary reviewers. A fundamental sense of imposing order on chaos would seem to influence this deeply religious Dame's choice of genre but, more accustomed to spilling blood than beans, any insights remain tantalisingly glimpsed, discreet rather than frankly confessional. Invisible Monsters Chuck Palahniuk Vintage £6.99, pp297 Buy it at BOL After the brawlers of Fight Club, and Survivor 's apocalyptic death cult, Chuck Palahniuk's third novel continues to pile on the aggressive camouflage to outrageous effect. The narrator is a model who has had her lower face shot off. Subsequently mute, she is adopted by Brandy Alexander, a flamboyant transsexual who teaches her that the past only exists to be reinvented. Of course, the past cannot be so lightly dismissed, and nor can this deliciously convoluted plot. The restless narrative ricochets around the hypnotically vacuous rhythms of glossy magazines. Palahniuk has claimed his book's exploration of transgression, and the need to destroy in order to move forward, 'makes Fight Club look like Little Women'. Bruising talk, yet its ferocious satirical bravado can't quite disguise a warm, moral undertow. Falling Angels John Walsh Flamingo £6.99, pp282 Buy it at BOL From Milton by way of Synge, the title refers to cherubim cast from Heaven but not consigned to Hell, forever in flux. webTitle: Observer review: From Empire to Europe by Geoffrey Owen

fields.headline: Paperback of the week: 26 Nov
fields.trailText: Eldon King looks at From Empire to Europe by Geoffrey Owen
fields.body:
From Empire to Europe

Geoffrey Owen

HarperCollins £8.99, pp533

Buy it at BOL

There have been so many polemical books about the failings of Britain's industrial progress in the twentieth century that it's a relief to find a study of this subject that is, for once, both elegantly written and supremely well-argued.

Owen, a distinguished Financial Times journalist, describes how Britain's major industries responded to international competition after the Second World War and crisply disposes of several widely canvased explanations of British industrial decline. Of course, statistics can be made to prove almost anything, but what Owen convincingly argues is that, among the well-publicised failures, there were some startling successes.

He also demonstrates that a lot of the gloom about the state Britain allegedly got itself into in the Sixties, Seventies and Eighties was itself a characteristic of Britain's painful transition from being an imperial power into 'just another European country'.

By the end of this enthralling analysis, Owen has shown, with commendable optimism, that by the Nineties Britain had not only found a role for itself as a medium-sized nation, well integrated into the world market, but was poised to reap many of the benefits of the internet economy.

From Empire to Europe is the kind of scintillating revisionism that should be given to every economic history student in the country.

fields.headline: Mama lost five stone and became a lesbian
fields.standfirst: Anna Shapiro looks at From Caucasia, With Love, Bone House and The Ice Harvest
fields.trailText: Anna Shapiro looks at From Caucasia, With Love, Bone House and The Ice Harvest
fields.body:
From Caucasia, With Love
Danzy Senna
Bloomsbury, pp413, £16.99
Buy it at BOL

Bone House
Betsy Tobin
Review, pp280, £10
Buy it at BOL

The Ice Harvest
Scott Phillips
Picador, pp202, £10
Buy it at BOL

Reading November's first novels, I kept thinking of Robert Frost's phrase 'grey November days'. All three of these debut publications could legitimately be characterised as overcast, but then, what is a novel if not the occasion to wallow in the miseries of others? From Caucasia, With Love is literary and ambitious, Bone House finely put together and comfortable, The Ice Harvest swift and stylish.

If one has occasion to demur regarding the excellence of a novel, it is never a complaint about the bleakness of subject matter so much as a sense that it didn't let you wallow enough, did not let you deeply into a character's misery, did not make the misery sufficiently lifelike or fateful (or funny). From Caucasia, With Love is the account of a family break-up along racial lines. A marriage between a Boston brahmin and Harvard 'negro' in the mid-Sixties, when integration was an ideal, becomes untenable when negro becomes black and Black Power makes anything but racial delineation uncool. The black husband, white wife and two girls are all casualties, but the focus of the book is entirely on the younger daughter and her sense of identity as - with straight hair and light skin - ethnically African-American.

In that sense, the book is about greyness, the results of mixing black and white. When the father takes up with a sexpot who knows how to shape frizzy hair (it seems to be her chief recommendation), he sweeps the older, darker, frizzy daughter off with him and his lover to Brazil, a country he believes to be race-blind, though at that point he certainly isn't. Birdy, as she is called, is left with her impetuous, furious, fat, hard-drinking blonde mama, who gets so involved with mad gun-smuggling black-power dudes that she has to go on the run, or thinks she has to. Birdy becomes Jessie, and the father is declared (for purposes of camouflage) not only dead but, rather than black, Jewish.

The mother immediately sheds five stone and goes gay. The narrator passes in silence over four years on a lesbian commune, which for this child of strife and counterculture sound placidly benign. But passionate, extremist Mom reverts to rhetoric about feminism as a bourgeois hang-up and drags 'Jessie' off to live in small-town New Hampshire, where the pubescent girl takes up with the rural lumpen who relish words like spic, nigger and, on occasion, kike.

This is a long book, and it earns its length; by the end, you feel the sadness of Birdy losing not only her father and her sister, but herself. As a narrator, however, she seems unable to untangle this moving tale from a kind of sociological documentary about race. One longs for greater art or style in the narration, instead of reportage, something non-chronological, letting the full force of what had been lost contrast with scenes of the young girl's life of pretence. For that, the author would have had to cling less tightly to Birdy's point of view. It would be a great plus, since the parents are by far the most interesting characters, but requires the kind of authorial maturity that places drama above a brief for sympathy.

Bone House has smaller ambitions and, by its own lights, probably fulfils them. A mix of genres involving two sets of gothic secrets, it combines romance novel - plucky little heroine serving in 'great house' attracted to alluring man of higher station - with murder mystery: the universally admired town whore is found dead under possibly suspicious circumstances and is discovered to be pregnant.

The year is 1603 and the highest ambitions of this work relate to historical accuracy. The villagers believe in witchcraft, and the heroine's lady employer takes religion very seriously. However, violations of period abound, as seems to be inevitable in period novels. The author makes careful points about the lack of social mobility, but the attractive characters are practically dizzying in the class leaps that they make, and the male love interest embodies a rather later period's ideal of attractiveness which lies in his being an artist.

There are references to 'ambivalence' and 'romantic love,' as if the seventeenth-century English narrator had read - or anticipated - Freud. But one identifies with her longing for the warmth and largesse that the dead woman embodied, and, as readers of another era, we cannot help liking the psychic freedom represented by the artist. Take it as a sober fairy tale of upward mobility, culturally if not monetarily. In its case, greyness and sobriety are virtues.

Ice Harvest intends to be not grey but black - noir, that is. It's Christmas Eve in a big town in Kansas, and Charlie Arglist, a lawyer who's become moneyman for the local mob (which means, effectively, the two strip joints and massage parlour in town), is cashing in his chips, intending to make off with what he's earned through cocaine deal ing and double-dealing as his big Christmas present to himself.

By morning, he's committed not only his first murder but two others and been betrayed, as is de rigueur in noir, by the inevitable treacherous beauty. When Chandler and Hammett invented this genre, they may have been misanthropists, but they decided that if they had to hate themselves for being human, they would also love themselves for being a little bit better than everyone else in seeing it clearly.

So they made heroes who had just that sense of honour or perspective that raised them up an inch. Arglist, however, is crummy to his wife and kids - you know he's gotta go.

Therefore, this noir ends with a black joke and a view of humanity without highlights to show up the darkness. Call it grise.

fields.headline: Students bite teaching bait
fields.standfirst: Golden hellos are luring graduates to train for shortage subjects, but there's a long way to go, says  Anne McHardy
fields.trailText: Golden hellos are luring graduates to train for shortage subjects, but there's a long way to go, says Anne McHardy.
fields.body:
The primrose path down which the Government would like to lead new graduates to turn them into teachers is strewn with offers which are finally starting to pay dividends in increased recruitment. But the numbers taking postgraduate certificates of education (PGCEs) remain dangerously low.

In their PGCE year, students do not pay university fees; those in shortage subjects, such as maths, foreign languages and information technology, get a 'golden hello' of £5,000, and, from this year, are paid £6,000 training salaries. Before the salary was announced, last April, indications were for a 13 per cent drop in applications.

The package makes taking a three-year subject degree followed by a PGCE year much more attractive than a BEd four-year education degree, with fees each year and no incentive pay, particularly as the subject degree offers more flexibility of final career choice. Those receiving golden hellos have to commit themselves to doing the statutory induction year in teaching and to teaching the subsequent year.

This month, to the delight of its chief executive, Ralph Tabberer, the Teacher Training Agency (TTA) announced a 6 per cent overall increase, and a 5 per cent increase at secondary level, the first increase in registrations for PGCE courses since the academic year 1992/93. There has also been an 8 per cent increase in people coming in to teaching by non-traditional routes, often through career changes.

The Government's target for trainee primary school teachers has been met, but there are still serious shortfalls on secondary PGCE courses, which potentially means that the present crisis level of teacher shortage, which is forcing schools to rely on foreign supply teachers, will continue.

The smallest increases in PGCE applications are in science, at 3 per cent, and maths, at 2 per cent. Big City or industry pay packets still look far more attractive than the golden hellos.

To add to Tabberer's problems, a number of universities are closing their postgraduate teacher training departments. Liverpool shut its completely last June, Warwick, the fifth-biggest university in the country, is having trouble filling its PGCE quo tas, and Loughborough, world renowned as a PE college, has just decided that it will close its postgraduate school next summer. It is transferring some PGCE courses, notably PE, science and maths, to a new school within its humanities department, but will cease to teach many of its subsidiary sub jects, including design and technology, English, Spanish and geography. These three universities are far from alone in finding PGCEs difficult to sustain.

The problem for universities with relatively small PGCE departments is disproportionate fixed overheads, including the ever-rising cost of inspections. Without any increase in budget, universities have to pay schools for taking students on teaching practice - and the PGCE has become more classroom- orientated.

Tabberer, however, remains upbeat. 'In a buoyant economy, graduate recruitment is especially competitive,' he says. 'We are pleased there has been a considerable improvement in registrations on secondary teacher training courses, but we are not complacent over the shortfall on our secondary target.

'We recognise that there is still much more to do, especially with regard to maths. I see it as particularly positive that, with the introduction of training salaries, increased numbers have registered to undertake postgraduate training in the secondary shortage subjects.'

Mary Russell, chief executive of the Universities Council for the Education of Teachers, said the council was delighted that training salaries, for which it had been pressing for years, had at last been introduced.

But, she added, the significant problem remained that teaching was no longer seen as 'status' employment, and that while the emphasis on students working in schools meant more effective PGCEs, the system was costly.

'The institutions are very committed to teacher education and they don't want to give it up, but in some cases it has got to the point where there is no choice,' she said. 'The funding has not been put into the institutions and the schools are doing far beyond what they are being paid for.'

There are also pitfalls for the newly qualified teachers, NQTs, as jargon calls them. They have to work an induction year to be put on to the qualified teaching register, but many are finding it difficult to get substantive jobs, since schools, also under budgetary coshes, prefer short contracts. Many NQTs are signing up with teacher supply agencies, of which there are 70-plus operating in London alone, but supply teaching, even for consecutive periods in the same school, cannot count as induction.

Select, one of the biggest teaching agencies, is among those currently negotiating with the Department for Education and Employment and the TTA to allow supply teaching to be accepted as induction, the predominant problem being supervision. But, says managing director Bob Wicks: 'It is a problem that has to be solved.'

fields.headline: Staff wanted: please apply
fields.standfirst: Is there anybody out there? As unemployment continues to fall,  Alexander Garrett finds firms desperately seeking new ways of enticing - and keeping - employees
fields.trailText: Is there anybody out there? As unemployment continues to fall, Alexander Garrett finds firms desperately seeking new ways of enticing - and keeping - employees.
fields.body:
Sometime soon, barring an unexpected turn of events, the number of people registered as unemployed is going to fall below a million for the first time since 1976. In large parts of the South East, less than 2 per cent of the working-age population is looking for a job - a scenario regarded by economists as full employment. In some employment 'hot spots', unemployment is less than 1 per cent. That is good news for anyone coming into the job market in Britain's boom areas; but it is a headache for employers, who are having to offer higher salaries and find other ways of recruiting and keeping staff.

Basingstoke and Newbury share the honour of having the lowest unemployment rates in the country, at just 0.8 per cent. In Newbury, there are 349 jobs on offer at the JobCentre, many in shops, warehouses and driving positions, plus a smattering of managerial openings. According to one member of staff, somebody with half-a-dozen GCSEs could expect to find a job 'almost immediately'. At Trainers Limited, an IT training company based in Basingstoke, managing director Janice Brown says: 'We sometimes get no responses at all to vacancies, even when it is through an agency - and that includes jobs paying £40,000-50,000 a year.' She says the company often has to resort to word of mouth to find the right people, and has recruited from as far afield as Liverpool and Newcastle, as well as among people coming out of the forces.

The key to keeping people is, she says, to provide continuous training rather than the highest pay. 'We review the position every six months, and find out what training they'd like in the next six months. It's quite unusual for somebody to leave if they're looking forward to their next training course.' At insurance company Winterthur, one of the biggest employers in Basingstoke, head of corporate communications Ginny Broad says one way of coping with low unemployment is to recruit from further afield. Jobs are advertised outside the immediate vicinity - in places such as Southampton, Guildford and Reading.

The company also goes out of its way to pamper employees through benefits, working conditions and the overall environment. Staff get a non-contributory final salary pension - which is increasingly rare - and private health insurance after a year. Mothers are encouraged back to work by an option to negotiate flexible hours individually; and the company has even introduced a scheme for employees to 'buy' extra holiday if they want it. The spacious and comfortable offices are also a draw, says Broad. There are tennis courts, a gym, and a restaurant with outside garden. 'We are very active locally,' she adds. 'We sponsor the theatre and even the railway station. One of our objectives is to be seen as one of the best employers.'

Not every employer can afford such generous perks as these. Alastair Hatchett, at Incomes Data Services, says: 'The problem in some areas is becoming one not just of skills shortages, but of people shortages.' He says the main tool used by employers to recruit and retain people is still pay. 'A company that was paying £17,000 to recruit a skilled craftsman a year ago is probably having to pay £20,000 today. They are effectively having to raise the recruitment rate.'

Companies are also having interim pay reviews - so salaries may be increased twice instead of once a year to keep up, he says. And particular groups that are in short supply - IT, for example - are being upgraded within the organisation.

Some employers have also been redefining their salary 'zones' to take account of where the employment hot spots are. Tesco, for example, has introduced a new zone system so that somebody working in Reading would earn as much as their counterpart in central London. Employers are also benchmarking their pay much more closely against competitors, he says.

Companies are, to some extent, also looking further afield. For every employment hot spot in the South East, though, there is a cold spot elsewhere. Areas of Scotland, Northern Ireland and the North East still have unemployment levels in or approaching double-figure percentages and, in principle at least, provide an obvious pool for those in the hot spots to recruit from. The problem is the obvious one: housing. Towns such as Basingstoke, Newbury and Banbury are already suffering from shortages of housing, and for those coming from less affluent areas of the country prices must seem sky-high.

'It is very difficult for somebody to bridge the gap from Tyneside to Slough,' points out Hatchett. 'And there is also the problem of the trailing spouse. Many couples are now dual-earner, and if one relocates, the other will want to find an equivalent job.'

Back in Basingstoke, Barbara Bryant, chief executive of the Chamber of Commerce, says: 'I was at a meeting with three large companies today, and they were talking about bringing in labour from eastern Europe, and even India. They were wondering how well it would work with the new work permit system.'

She adds: 'I think companies are just beginning to get to grips with this problem, and to realise that it isn't going to go away.'

According to one member of staff, somebody with half-a-dozen GCSEs could expect to find a job 'almost immediately'. At Trainers Limited, an IT training company based in Basingstoke, managing director Janice Brown says: 'We sometimes get no responses at all to vacancies, even when it is through an agency - and that includes jobs paying £40,000-50,000 a year.' She says the company often has to resort to word of mouth to find the right people, and has recruited from as far afield as Liverpool and Newcastle, as well as among people coming out of the forces. The key to keeping people is, she says, to provide continuous training rather than the highest pay. 'We review the position every six months, and find out what training they'd like in the next six months. It's quite unusual for somebody to leave if they're looking forward to their next training course.' At insurance company Winterthur, one of the biggest employers in Basingstoke, head of corporate communications Ginny Broad says one way of coping with low unemployment is to recruit from further afield. Jobs are advertised outside the immediate vicinity - in places such as Southampton, Guildford and Reading. The company also goes out of its way to pamper employees through benefits, working conditions and the overall environment. Staff get a non-contributory final salary pension - which is increasingly rare - and private health insurance after a year. Mothers are encouraged back to work by an option to negotiate flexible hours individually; and the company has even introduced a scheme for employees to 'buy' extra holiday if they want it. The spacious and comfortable offices are also a draw, says Broad. There are tennis courts, a gym, and a restaurant with outside garden. 'We are very active locally,' she adds. 'We sponsor the theatre and even the railway station. One of our objectives is to be seen as one of the best employers.' Not every employer can afford such generous perks as these. Alastair Hatchett, at Incomes Data Services, says: 'The problem in some areas is becoming one not just of skills shortages, but of people shortages.' He says the main tool used by employers to recruit and retain people is still pay. 'A company that was paying £17,000 to recruit a skilled craftsman a year ago is probably having to pay £20,000 today. They are effectively having to raise the recruitment rate.' Companies are also having interim pay reviews - so salaries may be increased twice instead of once a year to keep up, he says. And particular groups that are in short supply - IT, for example - are being upgraded within the organisation. Some employers have also been redefining their salary 'zones' to take account of where the employment hot spots are. Tesco, for example, has introduced a new zone system so that somebody working in Reading would earn as much as their counterpart in central London. Employers are also benchmarking their pay much more closely against competitors, he says. Companies are, to some extent, also looking further afield. For every employment hot spot in the South East, though, there is a cold spot elsewhere. Areas of Scotland, Northern Ireland and the North East still have unemployment levels in or approaching double-figure percentages and, in principle at least, provide an obvious pool for those in the hot spots to recruit from. The problem is the obvious one: housing. Towns such as Basingstoke, Newbury and Banbury are already suffering from shortages of housing, and for those coming from less affluent areas of the country prices must seem sky-high. 'It is very difficult for somebody to bridge the gap from Tyneside to Slough,' points out Hatchett. 'And there is also the problem of the trailing spouse. Many couples are now dual-earner, and if one relocates, the other will want to find an equivalent job.' Back in Basingstoke, Barbara Bryant, chief executive of the Chamber of Commerce, says: 'I was at a meeting with three large companies today, and they were talking about bringing in labour from eastern Europe, and even India. They were wondering how well it would work with the new work permit system.' She adds: 'I think companies are just beginning to get to grips with this problem, and to realise that it isn't going to go away.'

webTitle: How to deal with stressed-out colleagues

fields.headline: How to...
fields.standfirst: ... deal with stressed-out colleagues
fields.trailText: ... deal with stressed-out colleagues
fields.body:
1 Don't become paranoid when someone snaps at you. Rudeness is usually an expression of an unhappy, ignorant or stressed state; it is rarely the fault of the recipient. Other signs of stress include weepiness, difficulty in making decisions, general irritability, aggression and the lack of a sense of humour.

2 Recognise that your ability to help is limited: like alcoholics and other addicts, stress sufferers ultimately have to sort out the problem themselves. Malcolm VandenBurg, of Positive Under Pressure, says that if nothing else works, colleagues must detach themselves. He recommends they express their views by saying something like: 'You may not realise this but we can see that you're not in a good state. It must be bad for you - but the truth is that we can't work with you like this.' A good employer will provide counselling or a cut in workload; a bad employer could get itself into legal hot water by just sacking the person.

3 Avoid being too kind or too strict, says VandenBurg. Kindly colleagues could merely perpetuate the problem - and risk their own health by increasing their own workload and emotional support. If you are too strict, you can 'get into fights and get stressed yourself'.

4 Encourage the person to recognise their problem - if you think that you can give some help. 'We're probably all 5 per cent depressed,' says counselling psychologist Michael Carroll. 'Expect some moodiness about the place, and think about how we can support each other.'

Long hours and constant change - among other factors - mean that most workers routinely experience some stress. The first step towards recovery is recognising the pressure - but many people, particularly men, find it difficult to admit to something that could be seen by some as a weakness.

fields.headline: New economy, old survivor
fields.standfirst: Spirent is an object lesson in adapting to change.  Heather Connon reports
fields.trailText: Spirent is an object lesson in adapting to change. Heather Connon reports.
fields.body:
Baltimore, Autonomy, Cisco, Yahoo - most of the giants of the new economy are new companies, often founded in someone's garage and usually located in a business park in Cambridge or California.

Spirent sounds like one of these companies but has a rather more pedestrian home in Crawley, Sussex. Its name was dreamt up earlier this year to reflect its culture of 'inspired innovation'. Its business is firmly in the technology front-line, supplying probes and other equipment to make sure computer networks keep working. Its shares have turned in a convincingly new economy performance, soaring from around 90p two years ago to more than 600p, a rise almost eight times as fast as the rest of the stock market.

The £1.1 billion acquisition of Hekimian earlier this month, to extend the range of its testing services, was greeted with huge enthusiasm, sending its shares up a further 10 per cent.

But Spirent is an atypical new economy company - and not just because it is already making respectable profits. It started business in 1936 and, until May, had the rather more familiar name of Bowthorpe. Under that moniker it had a reputation for producing solid, if unspectacular growth from an assortment of electronics businesses. Now it has joined the select band of traditional British businesses - others include Marconi, the former GEC, and Volex - who have adapted to take advantage of the rapid growth in technology.

The transformation began five years ago when Nicholas Brookes took over as chief executive. What he found was a company with an entrepreneurial culture, the minimum of bureaucracy and head office functionaries, but with a wide spread of businesses that had little or no contact with each other. It had almost 100 operating units working in 27 different markets. The issue was how to accelerate the steady growth rate it had enjoyed over the previous 10 years.

'It became obvious that, if we wanted to be four times the size, we did not need 400 operating units in 130 markets. It was also obvious that we could not afford to invest in all 100 operating businesses. We had to focus on high-growth, high- margin, high-technology businesses.'

After a year spent analysing the company, its markets and its people, Brookes decided to concentrate on just five global businesses. The first of these, telecommunications, had only just come into the group when Brookes arrived, through the purchase of a US company called TAS, which was in wireless communications testing. Its rise has been meteoric: turnover has risen from just £3.5 million in 1995 to £114.7m - a fifth of the group - in 1999.

That growth is getting faster: in the first half of this year turnover more than trebled - partly due to acquisitions but there was also 80 per cent organic growth. Following the acquisition of Hekimian, this division will account for 80 per cent of group sales.

Brookes was attracted to telecommunications for two reasons. The market was very fragmented, with lots of private businesses concentrated on particular areas - wireless, local area networks and so on. But it also looked likely to grow rapidly. 'I thought that, if we could pull them together under one umbrella, and invest in them, we could have a great business.'

Bowthorpe already had a good reputation for acquiring entrepreneurial companies and integrating them successfully so Brookes could build on that. The secret, he says, is 'understanding, putting yourself in the shoes of the entrepreneur'. Many large corporations will 'put money on the table, promise to invest such and such in your business - and then say this is how you will do things now. That will turn off an entrepreneurial company. Their values are very different to large public corporations.'

Brookes works hard to make sure bureaucracy does not creep in. Once it starts, it is hard to get rid of. Head office is slim - there are no centralised human resources, marketing or other administrative departments. 'We give a lot of authority to people. We act fast. There is a strong financial team and a mergers and acquisitions department at head office, but that is it. We put all the cash into the business.'

He admits that the bigger the company gets, the harder it is to keep bureaucracy out - the Hekimian acquisitions will add at least 50 per cent to sales of Spirent's communications division. 'The key is to carry on as we do, to keep the priority investing in people.'

As part of that, Spirent has developed what it calls a technical ladder, a system that allows its specialist engineers, scientists and other professionals to progress their careers within their specialist areas, instead of forcing them to shift into management - something many of them have little aptitude for or interest in.

The communications division has been the star in the last five years but the other divisions - network systems, cable management and sensing solutions - have also grown rapidly, mainly on the foundation of existing businesses. Brookes found, for example, that Bowthorpe had an excellent network systems business operating in Germany, Japan, the US and Britain. The trouble was that none of these businesses talked to each other, far less co-operated on product development. Now they are integrated under one umbrella with one management. 'We invested in upgrading the facilities and in new product development. The productivity improvements started to come through.'

New product investment has accelerated throughout the group. In the first half of the year spending reached £2.7m, up 40 per cent on the previous year. That accounts for 8 per cent of sales, up from 2.9 per cent when Brookes arrived.

The investment is paying off handsomely. Despite these increases, operating margins have actually risen since the new strategy began. And, if the new economy proves as lucrative as Spirent hopes, that could be just the beginning.
